transcriptionText: This certifies that in the Records of the Church in the First Eclesiastical Church of Huntington Ct. there is the following entry under the list of Marriages Solemnized by the Rev. David Ely was at that time the minister of her Sd church & society viz - 1885 Oct 3rd Married Benjamin Beardsley Junr to Amelia Stevens the above record is in the hand writing of the sd Ely- Attest Thomas Panderson Clerk of the church, and for more than twenty five years their Pastor The chest at present is destitute of a Minister Huntington April 30. 1844

Huntington Sept 11th. '44 This certifies that in the records of the church in the first ecclesiastical Society of Huntington Conn there is the following entry under the list of marriages solemnized by the Rev. David Ely who was at that time the minister of sd Church & Society viz, 1785 Oct 3 Married Benjamin Beardsley Junr to Amelia Stevens The above record I believe to be in the hand writing of the said Rev. David Ely. C. N. Seymour Present Pastor of the Church & Society in Huntington Fairfield County Huntington September 11th 1844 Personally appeared the Rev Charles N. Seymour Signer of the above and made solemn oath that the above is a true copy of record and that he believes it to be in the hand writing of the Rev. David Ely D D former Pastor of the first Ecclesiastical Society in said Huntington Before me Christopher N Shelton Justice of Peace

The majors name was Shipman and the adjutant was Henry Buell, (he thinks). He was stationed at Horseneck on the said sound; during this three months, he was ready the whole time on scouting duty. The remainder of the time was on guard. The field of the said scouting duty was over a wide extent of country and during a part of this term he suffered much for food. The men being allowed but for ounces of beef and five ounces of indian meal to man for twenty four hours. After he had served out the said three months. He was with the other troops who enlisted with him about to return home. At the urgeny request of the said Capt. Olmsted, they served two weeks longer until this place were supplied by other troops at the close of which time he was discharged by the said Capt. Olmstead. And this deponent further says that by _____ of old age and the loss of memory he can not swear positively as to the precise length of his service but according to the best of his recollection he served not less than the period mentioned below and in the following grade. For two years, one month and two weeks I served as a private for which I claim a pension. And this desponant in answers to the seven interrogatories prescribed by the war department states as follows: 1st He was born in said Stratford on the 30th day of January 1754. 2nd The record of his age was in his fathers bible. He has no record of it, of his own. 3: When called into the service he lived in said Stratford, & since the revolutionary war he has lived in sd. Stratford, next in Oxford, Newhaven Co. Connectcutt State, and next in Venice, Cayuga Co. N. York where he now resides. 4 He entered the service, and served throught the whole of the above-named time, as a Volunteer 5 He recollects the following Regular Officers, who served with the troops when he served. Gen'l Schuyler, Generals Montgomery, Worcester, & Putnam. Colonels Demanon, & Meigs & Adjutant Major Walter Bull. & Also recollects Col. Wells & Col. Lewis regiments of the Connecticut Line. & Col. Whitings 6 He received a discharge from the service signed by Capt. Olmstead, but has lost it. 7 The following persons residing in his neighborhood can testify to his character for veracity & their belief of his service as a revolutionary soldier. viz. Samuel Morten, George Young, Augustus Tabor, James Young & James Post. & Moses Remington & William Hewitt. He hereby relinquishes every claim to a person or annuity except the present and declares that his name is not on the pension list roll of any Agency. Benjamin Beardsley X his mark Sworn and subscribed on the day & year first above-named before me __________ Morse a Judge of Court of Com'n Pleas In presence of Jesse Millard and I certify that the above applicant is unable to write having little use of his hand, by reason of the dropsy or inflammatory rheumatism ___________Morse a Judge of Cayuga Com'n Pleas

Stratford 6th March 15th 1844 Arad Joy Esq D Sir, Yours of the 4th Sept. 1843, making enquiry relative to the Marriage of Benjamin Beardsley, I received the 13th of the present month, I see that it was postmarked at Ovid the 8th has inst perhaps the length of time since your letter was written, may render it unnecessary for me to endevour to hunt up the testimony you require. From what I can learn Mr Beardsley formerly lived in the Town of Huntington, which was originally a part of the town of Stratford. The Rev David Ely was the Pastor of the Presbyterian Church in Huntington which is 8 miles distant from this place, a sister of Benjamin Beardsley is still living & if no record testimony can be obtained relative to his marriage, the testimony of some Credible Witness might answer the purpose to establish the Widows claim if the is still living, It will be attended with some trifling expense, in obtaining the proof required I am acquainted with the sister of Benjamin Beardsley and if you wish me to proceed in seeking out the proof you will write me or the receipt of this & I will attend to the business forthwith. Huntington was set off from this town in 1789- I have examined the town records of Stratford & Mr Beardsleys marriage is not to be found recorded Respectfully Your David Brooks

Stratford 6th March 15th 1844 Arad Joy Esq D Sir, Yours of the 4th Sept. 1843, making enquiry relative to the Marriage of Benjamin Beardsley, I received the 13th of the present month, I see that it was postmarked at Ovid the 8th has inst perhaps the length of time since your letter was written, may render it unnecessary for me to endevour to hunt up the testimony you require. From what I can learn Mr Beardsley formerly lived in the Town of Huntington, which was originally a part of the town of Stratford. The Rev David Ely was the Pastor of the Presbyterian Church in Huntington which is 8 miles distant from this place, a sister of Benjamin Beardsley is still living & if no record testimony can be obtained relative to his marriage, the testimony of some Credible Witness might answer the purpose to establish the Widows claim if the is still living, It will be attended with some trifling expense, in obtaining the proof required I am acquainted with the sister of Benjamin Beardsley and if you wish me to proceed in seeking out the proof you will write me or the receipt of this & I will attend to the business forthwith. Huntington was set off from this town in 1789- I have examined the town records of Stratford & Mr Beardsleys marriage is not to be found recorded Respectfully Your David Brooks

Our row-gallies carried each a long 18-pounder on their bows and a number of swivels on their sides. Our guns being far superior to the enemies they were quickly silenced and when morning came the enemy sent out an armed schooner sloop which were also soon silenced by our troops. After this engagement our troops up the lake to the said island without the loss of a man; and after two days the orders were given for the troops to embark. They moved down the lake and when within a short distance of the place of landing they fired upon by the enemy from the shore. Our troops landed and drove the enemy back; In this skirmish Major Hobby was wounded in the hop. Here our troops remained a sufficient time to not a batter which was about a fortnight; after which they marched through the woods and came in on the rear of the fort and took possessions thereof with very little opposition. Here they remained until November following at which times and place this despondent and the regiment to which he belonged was discharged by General Worchester. This service was seven months. He next enlisted at Stratford _______ in May 1776 in the same line for three months under Capt Ja Burton and Ensign Hoyt. He does not recollect the Lt's name; In Colonel Whiting's regiment; this duty was guarding the lines himself between Stratford and Bridgeport of a most harassing and fatiguing nature by night and day. He stayed in this town until August following being three months and was discharged by Capt. Barton at Stratford. He next enlisted at Stafford in December 1776 in the same line as a private for three months under Major Hawley, Lt Hawley - Ensign's name not recollected - his duty was keeping guard. The guard consisted of about thirty privates with their officers. They were stationed at Bridgeport ____- and guarded the lines from there to Black Rock. He served until February, being three months was discharged at Bridgeport by the S. Major Hawley. He next enlisted at Stratford again, on or about the 1st day of April 1777 in said line, for six months, under the said Capt. Burton and Lt. Bangs. Ensigns name not recollected as a private. During this time, he was stationed at Fairfield on Long Island Sound, his duty as before was guarding the line from the attacks of the British and tories; he served this term of six months and was discharged at Fairfield by Capt. Burton. In the month of October 1777 he again enlisted under Capt. John Gates at Stratford of our said as a private in the same line, ______ company marched immediately to Peekskill, where they formed the troops under the command of General Putnam. At this time the British army under Burgoyne was marching down from Canada. ______ were ______ that the enemy from New York would attempt to meet him; General Putnam with the troops under his command were station at Peekskill to prevent such a measure. This despondent served at Peekskill ______ during this term three months and discharged in January 1778 by the said Capt. Gates. The next enlisted at Stratford of our said on the sixth day of August 1778 for three months in the same line as a private under Capt. Olmsted and Ensign Hoyt in Col Welds regiment.

STATE OF VERMONT, Rutland County, ss. On this 26th day of June 1820 personally appeared before the County court for said county of Rutland in open court, (said court being a court of record, agreeably to the laws of this state, having the power of fine and imprisonment, &c. ) Luke Roberts aged 52 years, resident in Pittsford in said county of Rutland who being first duly sworn, according to law, doth, on his oath declare, that he served in the revolutionary war, as follows: in Capt Chamberlain & Capt Baldwin Co in Col Swifts Regiment of Connecticut about 3 years from the Summer of 1780 to 1783 that he made his original declaration on the 6th day of April 1818 has received a Pension Certificate, No. 2923 And I do solemnly swear, that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War," passed on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contain in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed, I1 cow 2 small pigs, 5 hens &a a wasted Jan 1 3yr old Colt side table 6 old chairs, 1 desk 2 iron kettle 1 tea kettle 6 knives & forks 6 iron spoons 4 bowls 1 tin cup 3 tin leaves 4 hearth pieces, 1 tin pail, 1 ceramic pail ,1 wash ???, 2 capes, 2 old hats, then seals, even he Spoons, 4 then bowls, the with pans, this pail, Robert, Rachel Elders, of the pitch forks, 2 old takes, old grindstone, hold lands then Chest of divers, 1 Sheal & longs, Jean Shammels, I had been 1 Saddle & lie, about 40th wool, 1 plow, told her she fines, by death, She knives, lasts, told saw sickle, 1 Chain 1 Clipper, hammer 1 Bible 1 Cook, and Rich, Chest, Shering since ever placed on the pension list I have purchased 24 acres of land with a small house & barn on it for which I promised to pay $264.66, out of my pension money and have paid $114. ?? towards it I have also bought a one horse waggon and a cow & have paid Eleven dollars towards the Cow and been to pay for the waggon & the comander for the Cow out of my pension hereafter my occupation is that of a husbandman hast branch to landed from ill health. I have a wife named Catharine aged 39 years in good health-- I have seven children residing with me to wit, John W. Aged 17yr Roxanne aged 18yrs- Luke aged 10 yrs- Harlow aged 8yrs Lucy aged 5 yrs Alma aged 3 yrs & Edmund C aged 3 months all in good health, I have no claim on the services of Roxana as she is of full age & my son John performs the caring of the family I have nothing due my land are in debt about one hundred dollars besides the debts above mentioned Sworn to and declared on the 20 day of June 1825 Luke Roberts before said court. R. Pierpoints CLERK

i Luke Roberts of Pittsford in the County of Rutland & State of Vermont of lawful ye testify & say that at the June term of Rutland County Court AD 1820 I made declaration before said Court and schedule of my property, agreeably to the laws of the United States for the purpose of being continued the pension list of the United States In the Schedule of my property I mentioned 24 acres of land that I had purchased after I was placed on the pension list and had with my pension money paid $114 doller towards the land. Inconsequence of the discontinuance of my pension I have been compelled to surrender up my land to the person from whom I purchased being wholly unable to pay the ballance The cow that I gave in I have killed & my family have eat it the other cow that I had paid eleven dollars towards the purchase. I agreed to give $22, for her but in consequence of my pensions failing could not pay for her and returned her to the person from whom I had her & he returned me four dollars of what had paid him, the three year old colt have been compelled to turn out to pay a debt I owed before I was placed on the pension list. I am now destitute of a Cow or horse, and all other property except succell 2 small pigs 7 my household possessions Subscribed & sworn before me 9 Dec Luke Roberts 1822 & said Roberts is a credible witness R. Pierpoint Jus Peace

STATE OF VERMONT, County of Rutland, ss. On this 4th day of June 1823 personally appeared before the County court for said county of Rutland in open court, (said court being a court of record, agreeably to the laws of this state, having the power of fine and imprisonment, &c.) Luke Roberts resident in said county, aged 55 years, who being duly sworn, according to law, doth, on his oath, make the following declaration, in order to obtain the provision made by the acts of Congress of the 18th March, 1818, and the 1st May, 1820, that he, the said Luke Roberts enlisted during the war on the 7th day of July in the year 1780 in the state of Connecticut in the company commanded by Captain Pemberton & Capt Baldwin in the regiment commanded by Colonel Herman Swift in the line of the state of Connecticut on the continental establishment; that he continued to serve in the said corps until the 7 June 1783 when he was discharged from the said service, in Peekskill in the state of New York that his name has been placed on the pension list, and dropt therefrom on account of his property. And in pursuance of the act of the 1st May, 1820, I do solemnly swear, that I was a resident citizen of the United States, on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary war,” passed on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed 1 cow 2 small pigs 9 hens 7 geese 9 goats 1 pair tables 6 old chairs 1 pot 2 iron kettles 1 tea kettle 6 knives & forks 6 iron spoons 6 tea cups& saucers 6 earthen plates 4 ??? spoons 4 earthen bowls 1 tim cup 2 tin bowls 4 milk pails 1 tin pail 1 wooden pail 1 wash tub 2 capes 2 old hoes 2 scythes 2 pitch forks 2 old rakes 1 old grindstone 6 old barells 1 small chest 1pr andirons 1 hand tongs 1 ??? & hammer 2 small kegs 1 old saddle & bridle about 17 lbs wool 1 fleece 1 old ??? 1 short hammer 1 old saw 1 sickle 1 chisel 1 clipper 1 slice 1 ///& old heiffer one horse waggon 1 hammer 1 bible 1 hymn book 1 iron candle stick 1 chest 1 spinning wheel That since the exhibition of my first schedule, the following changes have been made in my property. I was placed on the pension list & after that had purchased 24 acres of land on which was a small house & barn for which promised to pay $284.66, out of my pension money actually paid $44 in fact for it of for the balance Samuel Morgan of the Rutland the man from whom I purchased took a mortgage on the rear line at the time of purchase & since I was struck from the roll of pensioners I have not able to pay the fees of said Mortgage of have been compelled to release the whole of the purchase to th2 sd Morgan & sacrifice what I had paid in July 1841 and appear by my deed of that date and acknowledged before John Bains Just peace & recorded in the town Clerks office in Pittsford & further then the cow mentioned in my first schedule became very old & feeble that I killed her & and the leaf in my family & the waggon is old out of repair for the purchase of which I can now in a Judge of Court against me

STATE OF VERMONT, County of Rutland, ss. On this 4th day of June 1823 personally appeared before the County court for said county of Rutland in open court, (said court being a court of record, agreeably to the laws of this state, having the power of fine and imprisonment, &c.) Luke Roberts resident in said county, aged 55 years, who being duly sworn, according to law, doth, on his oath, make the following declaration, in order to obtain the provision made by the acts of Congress of the 18th March, 1818, and the 1st May, 1820, that he, the said Luke Roberts enlisted (for the term of) during the war on the 7th day of July in the year 1780 in the State of Connecticut in the company commanded by Captain Pemberton & Capt Baldwin in the regiment commanded by Colonel Herman Swift in the line of the state of Connecticut on the continental establishment; that he continued to serve in the said corps until the 7 June 1783 when he was discharged from the said service in Peekskill in the state of New York that his name has been placed on the pension list, and dropt therefrom on account of his property. And in pursuance of the act of the 1st May, 1820, I do solemnly swear, that I was a resident citizen of the United States, on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary war,” passed on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed.1 cow 2 small pigs 9 hens 7 geese 9 goats 1 pair tables 6 old chairs 1 pot 2 iron kettles 1 tea kettle 6 knives & forks 6 iron spoons 6 tea cups& saucers 6 earthen plates 4 ??? spoons 4 earthen bowls 1 tim cup 2 tin bowls 4 milk pails 1 tin pail 1 wooden pail 1 wash tub 2 capes 2 old hoes 2 scythes 2 pitch forks 2 old rakes 1 old grindstone 6 old barells 1 small chest 1pr andirons 1 hand tongs 1 ??? & hammer 2 small kegs 1 old saddle & bridle about 17 lbs wool 1 fleece 1 old ??? 1 short hammer 1 old saw 1 sickle 1 chisel 1 clipper 1 slice 1 ///& old heiffer one horse waggon 1 hammer 1 bible 1 hymn book 1 iron candle stick 1 chest 1 spinning wheel That since the exhibition of my first schedule, the following changes have been made in my property. Sworn to and declared on the 4th day of June before said Court I Robert Pierpoint Clerk of County Court do hereby certify, that it appears to the satisfaction of the court, that the said Luke Roberts did serve in the Revolutionary war, as stated in the preceding declaration, against the common enemy, for the term of nine months, under one engagement, on the continental establishment. I also certify, that the foregoing oath, and the schedule thereto annexed, are truly copied from the records of the said court; and I do further certify, that it is the opinion of the said court, that the total amount in value of the property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule is Sixty seven dollars and 25 cents. $67.25 In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand, and affixed the seal of the said Court on this 13th day of June 1823 R. Pierpoint

STATE OF VERMONT, Rutland County, ss. ⎬ On this 26th day of June 1820 personally appeared before the County court for said county of Rutland in open court, (said court being a court of record, agreeably to the laws of this state, having the power of fine and imprisonment, &c. ) Luke Roberts aged 52 years, resident in Pittsford in said county of Rutland who being first duly sworn, according to law, doth, on his oath declare, that he served in the revolutionary war, as follows: in Capt. Pemberton & Capt Baldwin Co. Col. Swifts Regt of Conn about three years from the Summer of 1780 to 1783- that he made his original declaration on the 6 day of Apr 1818 has received a Pension Certificate, No. 2923 And I do solemnly swear, that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled ""An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War," passed on the 18th day of March, 1813; -- and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contain in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. 1 cow 2 small pigs 9 hens 7 geese 9 goats 1 pair tables 6 old chairs 1 pot 2 iron kettles 1 tea kettle 6 knives & forks 6 iron spoons 6 tea cups& saucers 6 earthen plates 4 ??? spoons 4 earthen bowls 1 tim cup 2 tin bowls 4 milk pails 1 tin pail 1 wooden pail 1 wash tub 2 capes 2 old hoes 2 scythes 2 pitch forks 2 old rakes 1 old grindstone 6 old barells 1 small chest 1pr andirons 1 hand tongs 1 ??? & hammer 2 small kegs 1 old saddle & bridle about 17 lbs wool 1 fleece 1 old ??? 1 short hammer 1 old saw 1 sickle 1 chisel 1 clipper 1 slice 1 ///& old heiffer one horse waggon 1 hammer 1 bible 1 hymn book 1 iron candle stick 1 chest 1 spinning wheel Since I was placed on the pension list I have purchased 24 acres with a small house & barn on it, for which I promised to $264.66 out of my pension money have paid $114, toward it I have also bought a one horse waggon & cow and have paid eleven dollars toward the cow & ami to pay for the waggon remainder for the cow out of my pension hereafter my occupation is that of a husbandman but am unable to labor from ill health-- I have a wife named Catharine aged 39 years in good health. I have 7 children residing with me to wit John W. and 17 years Roxana aged 18 years Luke aged 10 years Harlow aged 8 years Lucy aged 5 years. Alma aged 3 years and Edmund C. 3months all in good health I have no claim the services of Roxana as she is of full age, & my son John performs the labor of the family. I have nothing due me but am in debt about one hundred dollars besides the debts above mentioned Luke Roberts R. Pierpoint

STATE OF VERMONT, Rutland County, ss. ⎬ On this 26 day of June 1820 personally appeared before the County court for said county of Rutland in open court, (said court being a court of record, agreeably to the laws of this state, having the power of fine andimprisonment, &c. ) Luke Roberts aged 52 years, resident in Pittsford in said county of Rutland who being first duly sworn, according to law, doth, on his oath declare, that he served in the revolutionary war, as follows: in Capt. Pemberton's & Capt Baldwin's Co. Col. Swifts Regt of Conn about three years from the Summer of 1780 to 1783- that he made his original declaration on the 6 day of Apr 1818 has received a Pension Certificate, No. 2923 And I do solemnly swear, that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War, "" passed on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. 1 cow 2 small pigs 9 hens 7 geese 9 goats 1 pair tables 6 old chairs 1 pot 2 iron kettles 1 tea kettle 6 knives & forks 6 iron spoons 6 tea cups& saucers 6 earthen plates 4 ??? spoons 4 earthen bowls 1 tim cup 2 tin bowls 4 milk pails 1 tin pail 1 wooden pail 1 wash tub 2 capes 2 old hoes 2 scythes 2 pitch forks 2 old rakes 1 old grindstone 6 old barells 1 small chest 1pr andirons 1 hand tongs 1 ??? & hammer 2 small kegs 1 old saddle & bridle about 17 lbs wool 1 fleece 1 old ??? 1 short hammer 1 old saw 1 sickle 1 chisel 1 clipper 1 slice 1 ///& old heiffer one horse waggon 1 hammer 1 bible 1 hymn book 1 iron candle stick 1 chest 1 spinning wheel Sworn to and declared on the 26th day of June 1820 before said court R. Pierpoint CLERK STATE OF VERMONTCounty, ss. Rutland County I Robt. Pierpoint clerk of the County Court for the county of Rutland do hereby certify, that the foregoing oath, and the schedule thereto annexed, are truly copied from the record of the said court:--And I do further certify, that it is the opinion of the said court, that the total amount in value of the property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule is one hundred ninety four dollars and that said Luke owes one hundred dollars In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand, and affixed the seal of said court, at this first day of July 1820 R. State of New Jersey} Gloucester County} City of Camden} SS On this eleventh day of October in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and thirty eight personally appeared before me the subscriber Recorder and Justice of the peace exoficio of said City of Camden, Elizabeth Gresham as resident of said City who alledging (sic) herself to be concienciously (sic) scrupulus (sic) of taking an oath being duly affirmed according to law doth on her solemn affirmation say That she is the widow of George Gresham late of the City of Camden aforesaid deceased who was a Captain of Cavalry in the army of the Revolution, that she was married to the said George Gresham on the third day of July in the year seventeen hundred and ninety two at the Northern Neck of Virginia in Richmond County by a Baptist Minister by the name of Lewis Landeford and that the said George Gresham departed this life on the thirtieth of October in the year eighteen hundred and thirty seven the said George Gresham was a Pensioner of the United States, and received from the Government the sum of six hundred dollars per year payable semi annually during his natural life, from the 4th of March 1831 and further said that the Family Record or Bible now produced having the marriage recorded in, in the following words, vis “George Gresham and Eliza Rust was Married 3rd July 1792,” is now in her possession and has been for a great many years and that the above marriage record was written there by the said George Gresham. Elizabeth Gresham Subscribed and affirmed} to the day and year first} above written before me} J. K. & recorded in the town clerks office in sd Pittsford & further the cow mentioned in my first schedule became very old & since that I killed her & and the leaf in my family & the waggon is old out of repair for the purchase of which I can now ???? & is now in a Judge of Court against me otherwise there has not been any unscheduled alteration except the clearing of the article aforsd & that myself & family remain in the same situation as in my person Schedule except my oldest son John left here the 14th Feby 1821 & from whom she Received no left Piece nor do I ever Expect to as he became unsteady & has gone unto the State of Connecticut as I am informed, & the 2d Cow mentioned in my first schedule I had purchased of Germain Hammond & Expected to pay for her out of my pension, but on being struck off I was obliged to give her back to sd Hammond who took her back by my paying seven dollars for the use of the sd Cow and the colt I have sold to Saml Morgan Junr the proceeds of which I have applied to the pay ment of my debts mentioned in my former Schedule other than those for the pay for low Luke Roberts

George Gresham Coram Edward King I, James Wiltbank, minister of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the United States, being duly sworn according to law, do declare and certify, that I well knew Captain George Gresham, who has subscribed and sworn the above declaration many years ago in the State of Delaware, and that our acquaintance has continued in the City of Philadelphia, to which we both removed, that I believe him to be seventy two years of age; that he was reputed and believed in the State of Delaware, and is now reputed and believed in Philadelphia to have been an officer of the revolution; this belief is general among those who know Captain Gresham, and this deponent has never heard of any doubts existing upon the subject. He himself fully concurs in that opinion. Sworn to and subscribed this twenty second day of October A. D. 1832. Captain John Steele (son of the late Genl. Steele formerly Collector of the Port of Pa) I Athanasius Ford Esqr – to be found with in the profession of the Pension Commr., or the Pension Comee of the Senate. 2nd – That the narrative of Captn. G is loose and indefinite as to length of service – and is in some particulars at variance with the history of the War. As to this objection – it is thought sufficient to say – that until Captn G was incapacitated by old age and infirmities for earning his livelihood – he could never be prevailed upon to apply for assistance from his country – and that when his narative (sic) was drawn up, he was suffering excruciating pain from an attack of Gout – as can be established by the testimony of his medical attendant, a highly respectable physician (Dr Nancrede) of this city We think no one would deem it surprising that, under such circumstances – severe suffering – old age- and great lapse of time since the occurrence of the events he was narating (sic) he should fail in some few particulars. It is hoped that the influence of the Hon members from this city in which Capt G resided for many years before his death and which is still the residence of his widow. And to whom probably the individuals to whose testimony allusion has been made are known either personally of by reputation – will procure for the case of the petitioner that attention it merits - and that justice over

A Schedule of Thomas Howards property 200 acres of land 3rd quality 60 acres nearly worn out and turned out into old field $200.00 1 Mare 18 years old 25.00 1 ditto 12 or 13 do 30.00 1 ditto 5 years do 30.00 3 Cows & Calves with 1 Colt 25.00 2 do & yearlings 30.00 2 heifers 2 years old- 10.00 3 yearlings 12.00 Stock of hogs 30.00 farming Tools 5.00 chairs & cooking utensials 6.00 Small Table .25 403.25 loom 3.00 $406.25 The amount of my out standing debt is 167.00 Number & Situation of the family by the first wife had seven children 3 dead 4 Living by the Second wife mie-do - 3 dead 6 Living 10 living Enlisted in 1777. in Pensylvania in Wm Wirts Company 10. Regt was in five principle fought actions viz Brunswick, Brandywine Surprise of Wayne at Peola, [Paoli] German Town, & Monmouth Battles together with a number of skirmishes, was taken Prisoner in Newark in 1780 and endured considerable privations & hardships of cold & Hunger during my imprisonment Thomas Howard X his mark Attest Peter Lamar Clk The Court viz. Thomas Murray Rem Remson, James E Todd David Glase & Wm Dowsing Esquires, on examination of the foregoing Schedule are of the opinion that the valuation as stated is correct, according to their belief of the value of such article, and moreover believe that the statements of Mr Howard in the affidavit as well

The above statement contains all my property real and personal & for the continuation of the same in my possession I am much indebted to my creditors for their indulgence My family at presents consists of a wife about 45 years of age & by her seven living children (We have had ten & lost three) the youngest of which is going into its fourth year, and the older about twenty years; by a former wife I had seven children all of which has left me, I am by occupation a Farmer when able to pursue it but my extreme age & infirmities of late years renders me entirely unable to support my family by my own Labor. And my family are not in a situation to render me much assistance toward a support. Rhode Island District I Pardon Simmons of Tiverton in said District on solemn oath do testify & say that in the year 1814 I loaned to Ichabod Simmons the sum of fifty dollars & took his note of hand for the same, the said Ichabod was at that time in bad health and unable to do much labour Afterwards in the year 1817 or 1818 I sold said Ichabod a Cow for seventeen dollars & took his note for the same, both of said notes were made payable with Interest & hath from time to time been renewed the Interest added to the principal I also loaned to said Ichabod at several other times small sums of money before the year 1820. In the year 1820 I record reckoned up all that he owed me & found the amount to be one hundred dollars & for which sum he then gave me a new note & tossed all the old ones I had against him This new note was made payable with Interest & continued to run upon Interest until the first day of January AD 1826 when I bought a parcel of land of him for which I allowed him one hundred & ten dollars the land I bought of him is a low rocky swamp, unfit for cultivation & now his in common having never thought it would pay the expence of fencing. I still own the land & I should be glad to sell it for one hundred dollars & would sell it at any moment for that sum the said Ichabod now owes me after taking said lot of land about eight dollars which sum I have never asked him for as I always have & do now consider him totally unable to pay it, when I first loaned him money he promised me that if he could not pay if he would let me have the land, which he has done & I the said Pardon do further certify & say that to my certain knowledge the said Ichabod is destitute of properly & is at this present time in needy circumstances, indeed I do now verily believe he is as regards property worn than nothing, all his property having been expended in support

of Peter's father; she was about 10 years of age at the time of the war; witness has travelled often in an official capacity through the entire County of Bergen, and never heard of any other Peter Van Buskirk than the one now residing in Washington. Polly Van Ryper testifies, 10th May 1861, that she is about 73 years old, has always lived in Harrington, is a daughter of Peter Van Buskirk and grand daughter of Thomas; that her mothers maiden name was Sarah Van Buskirk, daughter of Jacobus. That from an old Family Bible in her possession, it appears that witness's mother was born on the 7th day of April, 1767, and that she always understood from her parents that there was about five years difference in their ages, and that from family records which she has often seen, her father was born in 1762; and further she never knew or heard of any other Peter Van Buskirk in the County, than her father. Rev. Edward J. Corwine, Pastor of Congregational Church of Paramus, N. Jersey

Rhode Island District of [illegible] County of Newport District Court of the United States May Term 1824 ~ On this Eleventh day of May 1824 personally appeared in open court being a Court of Record Ichabod Simmons aged 63, now resident inthe town of Tiverton in said County who maketh the following Declaration in order to obtain the provisions of The acts of Congress for The benefit of Those who served in the revolutionary war viz. said Ichabod declares that in the month of September A.D. 1777. he enlisted as a private in Capt James Wibbs Company and Col. Sherburn's Regiment for Three years and That he continued to serve in That untill he was transferred to Col. Angell's Regiment in which he served untill his time expired when he was honourably discharged which discharge was sent to the pension office when he first made application both of said regiments were of the Rhode Island Line, he also served Nine months in Col. Olney's Regiment also of The Rhode Island Line, and he has [illegible] a Certificate - No 853. ~ but his name was stricken off the roll under The act of May 1. 1820. and I do solemnly swear That I was a resident [illegible] of the United States on the eighteenth day of March, one thousand eight hundred and eighteen; and That I have not since that time by Gift, sale, or in any manner, whatever, disposed of my property or any part thereof with intent Thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress entitled " An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the Land & Naval Service of the United States in the revolutionary war" passed on the eighteenth day of March one thousand eight hundred and eighteen that I have not nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities contracts or debts due to me nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed ~ Ichabod Simmons ~ Schedule of property and income necessary clothing & bedding excepted of Ichabod Simmons [illegible] 1 Cow 1 Heifer 1 Hog 1 old chest 1 -

TREASURY DEPARTMENT Sept. 22 1828 Levi Bishop, of Manlius, in the County of Onondaga, in the State of New York has applied to the Secretary of the Treasury for the benefits of the act, entitled 'An Act for the relief of certain surviving officers and soldiers of the Revolution," approved the 15th of May, 1828. He states that he enlisted in the Continental line of the army of the Revolution, for and during the war, and continued until its termination, at which period he was a Private in captain Mott's company ['the' crossed out] in Lamb's regiment of ['the [BLANK] line' crossed out] Artillery; and that he received a certificate for the reward of eighty dollars, provided by the resolve of the 15th of May, 1778, and further, that he was not on the 15th day of May, 1828, on the pension list of the United States, and that he has received as a pensioner the 3d of March, 1828, nothing. The Third Auditor is requested to report how far the several statements are corroborated by the records in his office. By order of the Secretary, A. Dickins TREASURY DEPARTMENT, THIRD AUDITOR'S OFFICE [illegible] October 1828 It appears by the records in this office, that a certificate for the reward of eighty dollars has been issued to Levi Bishop in Lamb's Artillery ['It further appears that [BLANK] is now on the pension list of [BLANK] agency, and has been so since the [BLANK] at the rate of [BLANK] dollars per month.' crossed out] There is now on the Invalid Pension Roll of the New York Agency a man by the name of Levi Bishop at the rate of $8 2[illegible] month. He has been paid to the 4th March 1828. J Thompson [illegible]

February 5, 1932 BA-J/AWF Mr. F. E. Dawley Fayetteville New York. Dear Sir: The data furnished herein are obtained from the papers on file in pension claim, W. 25239, based upon the military service in the Revolutionary War of Levi Bishop. He was born December 9, 1760, place not stated. He enlisted (date not given) for and during the war and continued in the service until discharged, June 9, 1783, at which time he was a private in Captain Gershom Mott's company in Colonel Lamb's Second Regiment of Continental Artillery. He was allowed pension on his application executed September 9, 1828, at which time he was living in Manlius, Onondaga County, New York. He died February 8, 1849. He married August 9, 1789 in Dutchess County, New York, Nancy Hunt, who was born February 27, 1764. She was allowed pension on her application executed June 12, 1849, at which time she was living in Manlius, New York. She died December 29, 1852. The children of Levi Bishop and his wife Nancy- Martha born December 24, 1790 Mary " [born] February 16, 1793, married July 16, 1812 Levi, Jr. " [born] June 21, 1795, married July 18, 1819 Thomas " [born] March 21, 1798, died June 16, 1829

Lancaster County Va. April 30th 1840 Sir At the request of Elizabeth Christian revolutionary pensions I went to Richmond in November last and presented to Mr. Robinson at the Bank of Virginia the enclosed power of Atty. which he refused to pay upon the [illegible] of haveing received a letter from you directing him not pay such pensions, until the 4th of last month(March) my expenses in the Steam Boat to Fredericksburg and cars to Richmond and returning the same way adding tavern lieu, were over eighteen dollars, which I have to advance out of my own pocket. in consequence of this widow being since the death of her husband entirely destitute of the means of Support, In order to avoid if possible [illegible] and disappointment in obtaining the pensions on the 21st of last month I addressed a letter to Mr. Robinson enquiring of him if he would then pay Elizabeth Christian's pension. I received from him the following reply. Sir In reply to your letter of the 21st Instant I have to state to you that the pensions of Mrs. Elizabeth Christian cannot be paid under the [illegible] formerly presented; which is the same now inclosed to you and which you will please to examine and return to me, with instructions how this pension is to be obtained. please to direct your letter to White House Post Office I am very Respectfully your obdt. Servt. Thomas Armstrong James. L. [illegible] Esqr commissioner of pensions

and has been for ten years past in the army of the United State, same petitioner being left alone with an aged wife is incapable of earning a support by his own labour, he is sixty three years of age and feels as he advances in life much more sensibly the injury done to his thigh during the revolutionary war, thus situated he has determined to lay his case before the legislature of his country, your petitioner will further state that he enlisted in the 5th Virginia Regt under the command of Col Richard Parker and belonged to the company o Cptn Tho.s Gaskins, his service expired at the end of two years he then again enlisted in the same Reg.t and was taken into the life gaurds of General George Washington. and continued in that service for three years. he was then furloughed to visit he parents. In some short time after general orders were issued that all thou who were on furloughs in Virginia should proceed to the Sauthara and join the army under the command of general Green, this order your petitioner obeyed and marched under the command of his first Capt.n who had been promoted to the command of a Regiment and was there Col. Thomas Gaskins. your petitioner having thus devoted the prime of his life to the Service of his country and being now incapable from the effects of his wounds received in that Service and his advanced age from procuring the means of Supporting himself and his aged wife, throws himself on the Justice and County of the Congress of the United States. under the most thorough assurance that the will not suffer the worn out soldier of the Revolution to [illegible] in want for that pittance which would be like a drop from the Ocean when taken from the coffers of a great and wealthy country. your petitioner therefore prays that your honorable body will grant him something for his immediate support and also such an annual pension as you may think just taking into consideration his Service and Situation Northumberland County Virginia December 17th 1817 Rawl C. Christian Lancaster county July 15th 1839 Thomas Armstrong Sworn to and Subscribed on the day and

Lancaster County Va. June 17th 1839 Sir Rawleigh C. Christian a revolutionary Soldier obtained a pension for his Services under the act of Congress of 1818 he died on the 4th day of July 1828 leaving a widow now (in the 87th year of her age) utterly destitute of any Support. And having been married to Rawleigh C. Christian after the expiration of the last period of his Service and before the 1st day of January 1794 it serves clear that she is entitled to the benefit of the act of Congress of the 7th of July last. I will thank you to inclose to me Such regulations and forms or evidence as has been adopted by the war department under pensions to certain widows. and direct to the White Stone P.O. Lancaster County Wa Respectfully your obdt Servt Thomas Armstrong [left margin: James L. Edwards Esqr]

35th CONGRESS 1st Session HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES. REPORT No. 101. MARYETT VAN BUSKIRK. (To accompany bill H. R. No. 276.) FEBRUARY 9, 1858. Mr. GEORGE TAYLOR, from the Committee on Revolutionary Claims, made the following REPORT. The Committee on Revolutionary Claims to whom were referred the petition and papers of Maryett Van Buskirk, heir of Thomas Van Buckirk, respectfully report: That they have examined this case with great care, and they unanimously concur that the facts set forth by the petitioner are fully sustained by the evidence. It appears that the petitioner, Maryett Van Buskirk, is the lineal descendant of Thomas Van Buskirk, who was in his lifetime a citizen of Bergen County, New Jersey. That during the period of our revolutionary struggle he was a wealthy farmer and grazier, and a man of great influence. The evidence before your committee shows, that he was one of the most ardent whigs of the revolution, and in a community where a large part of the population was hostile to the American cause. It further appears from the evidence and certificates on file, that the American troops at different times, under the command of Generals Wayne, Greene, and other officers, during the period ranging between the years 1777 and 1780, encamped at Harrington, (or Peramus, as sometimes called,) in said county and State. in the latter years, the winter of 1779-80, General Washington with the main army were encamped at Morristown, near by. When your committee state that, as early as the year 1777, dates the poverty and extreme wants of the army, and the prostration of the credit of the government, they state facts known to all men. It abundantly appears by the evidence, that from this time, while our army was in winter quarters at Valley Forge, until the year 1780, the said Thomas Van Buskirk was frequently applied to by the several officers commanding the American troops for supplies of cattle, horses, forage, grain, and other necessary articles, all of which he furnished; and he frequently purchased articles from others with his own money, to enable him to supply the army. The difficult task of obtaining supplies at this time, and in a part of the State notoriously disaffected; the resort to force by our officers to obtain them under the command of a resolution of Congress, are facts known in history. The evidence establishes

Iron bar, 1 Table, 6 old chairs, some Iron Ware, 1 ax, some crockery ware, knives forks Spoons, 3 old Hoes, 2 old Spinning Wheels, 1 Looking Glass, 1 old candle Stand, 2 pails, other Than That he has no property - except as above excepted; and he further declares that since he made his application pursuant to May 1.1820. The following changes have taken place - in his property vis The Real Estate mentioned in said Schedule has been all sold to Pardon Simmons & to Abel Simmons for The actual sum of money mentioned in The deeds, (Copies of which are hereto annexed) and the proceeds being appropriated to the payment of his just Debts & in support of his family. In which way he has spent all The proceeds of The Estates sold and The same has not been sufficient for That purpose. That he now honestly owes upwards of fifty Dollars to sundry persons according to his best recollection for the payment of which no provision is made. ~ And the said Ichabod further declares that he is a Labourer & works when he is able but he is now so infirm that he cannot work being much afflicted with the asthma that he has a family consisting of a Wife aged 59. who is so feeble as not to have been able to have done much work for a number of Years, he has also Three children, vis - 2 sons aged 17 & 12 and one Daughter aged 19 who are dependant on him for support, his oldest son is quite infirm & unable to do any hard labor. The 5 sheep mentioned in his first schedule were stolen or they strayed away, he entirely lost them. - he further declares that is now in impoverished circumstances, and the greatest part of his property having been taken to pay his honest debts, he thinks himself entitled to a pension, he served almost 4 Years in the Army for which he never received any adequate compensation and being now iso infirm he must soon depend upon charity unless assisted by his country. - Ichabod Simmons May Term 1824 - Sworn to in open Court. witness Benj Cowell Clk. State of New York Onondaga County SS On this 13th day of June 1849 personally appeared before me Robert Gilmor a Justice of the peace in and for said County Elizabeth Balsley by me personally known as respectable person who being duly sworn according to law doth depose and say that she is a resident of the town of Manlius County aforesaid that she is forty six years of age and is the daughter of the the Live Bishop deceased, and of Nancy Bishop who now makes application for a pension. That she recollects, a bible which was kept in the family in which there was a family record kept, that about Eighteen years since the copied that record upon a painting which she had executed, designed as a family picture and family record that she since was feared, and is now in her possesion. that in the family record above named her father & mothers marriage was recorded as having taken place on the 9th day of August 1789. That she has often heard her father her mother and her grandmother speak of the marriage as having taken place at the time above mentioned, that the Bible in which the record was kept was given by her father to one of her brothers ten or twelve years ago and that the record above mentioned has been torn out or othewise displaced and is now lost that she verity believes the record above named was a true and correct family record. Elizabeth Balsley [signature] Sworn and Subscribed before me the day and year above mentioned Robert Gilmor [signature] J Peace

Know all men by these presents that we Rawleigh Christian and John Christopher Jr are held and firmly bound unto the Commonwealth of Virginia in the penae sum of Fifty pounds current money, to which payment well and truly to be made, we bind ourselves and each of our heirs eyors and admors, Jointly severally firmly by these presents, sealed with our deals and dated this 4th day of July Anna:Dom: 1782. The condition of this obligation is such that whereas there is a marriage shortly intended to be had and solemnized between the above bound Rawleigh Christian and Elizabeth Pope widow, - Now if there by no lawful cause to obstruct the said marriage, then the above obligation to be voids, else to remain in full force [illegible] [Sealed and delivered in the presence of Charles Clarke} Rawleigh Christian [handwritten "seal" and circled] Jhn. Christopher Jun. [handwritten "seal" and circled] Truly copied from the original now on file in my office Attest M. B. Cralle CC July 8th 1839

Soldier died July 4, 1828 in Northumberland County, Virginia. Rawleigh C. Christian married July 4, 1782, Elizabeth Pope, a widow (given name of her former husband not stated). Soldier's widow, Elizabeth, was allowed pension on her application executed July 15, 1839, at which time she was aged eighty-six years, and resided in Lancaster County, Virginia. In 1821, soldier stated that his wife, Elizabeth, was then aged seventy years. She died January 28, 1840. Rawleigh C. Christian and his wife, Elizabeth, had four children. The only son was in the United States Army in 1817 and had then served at least ten years. He was unmarried at that time. The other three in 1817 were married. In 1840, three children were living. No names of children are given. Very truly yous A.D. HILLER Assistant to Administrator - 2 -

Washington September 4, 1931 BA-J/EEL Honorable William L. Nelson House of Representative Washington, D.C. My dear Mr. Nelson: Reference is made ot your letter of September 1, 1931, in regard to Rawligh Chinn Christian and Reuben Hatton, soldiers of the Revolution. Your are advised that it appears from the papers in the Revolutionary War pension claim, W.1889e, that Rawleigh C. Christian enlisted in Northumberland County, Virginia, April 10, 1774, served as a private in Captain Thomas Gaskins' Company. Colonel Parker's Virginia Regiment for about two years; was transferred to General Washington's Life Guard under Caleb Gibbs, commandant; re-enlisted in the Life Guard, was detached and served in Colonels Stephen and Thomas Gaskins'(his former captain) Virginia regiment, and was discharged sometime after the siege of Yorktown. He was in the battles Trenton, Princeton, Brandywine, Monmouth and Guilford, in which latter engagement he received two wounds, one on the left hand, which fractured one finger and rendered his hand almost useless and the other on right thigh a little above the knee. He died July 4, 1828, in Northumberland County, Virginia. The soldier married July 4, 1782, Elisabeth Pope, {handwritten: a widow} Soldier's widow, Elisabeth, was allowed pension on her application executed July 15, 1839, at which time she was aged eighty-six years and resided in Lancaster County, Virginia. In 1821, soldier stated that his wife Elisabeth was then aged seventy years. She died January 28, 1840 They had four children. The only son was in the United States Army in 1817 and had then served at least ten years. He was unmarried at that time. The other three were married in 1817. in 1840 three children were living. No names of children are given. It does not appear that soldier or his widow ever resided in Boone County, Missouri. [handwritten in the right margin: He said in one place that he served 6 may in the Life Guard and the next time he stated that this serv. [illegible] three years, so I did not use either. He said Col Richard Parker but as it appears to have [illegible] Joseph Parker who serv in 5th [illegible] I did not use Christian name}

7th The certificate of the Rev. Edward T. Corwin, pastor of the old Paramus Church, showing that the marriage register of said Church, son to July 24th 1799, is lost. Also, a privited history of said Church, in pamphlet form, on page 83 of which there is a note stating that the records from 1777 to 1799 are lost, also page 80 Rev. B. Van Derline. This evidence accounts for the failure to produce record proof of the marriage of said Claimant, in 1784. 8th By reference to the Bounty & and files in the Pension Office, it will be seen that said Peter Van Buskirk, the claimant in April 1855, made a declaration for Bounty land, in Phelps, N.Y. where then resided, stating his age to be ninety-four years. If born in August 1762, this would have been his age in April 1855 Again, by reference to the Rev. Pension Claims, under act 1838 &c and of Elizabeth Hopper of New Jersey,on file in the Pension Office, an affidavit of said Peter Van Buskirk will be found, made in Dec. 1857, in which he states his age at ninety-six years, which is in like manner consistent with the statement that he was born in Aug. 1862 Both of these affidavit were made

the church of Paramus. 6th A certificate of Edward T Corwin, pastor of the church at Paramus, that the marriage register of said Congregation prior to July 1799 was lost 7th The affidavit of Stephen Westervelt, who testifies that he is 94 years of age, that he knew Thomas Van Buskirk, father of Peter, and all his family, and that he lived with him during the revolutionary war, that he has frequently seen the old family record of Thomas Van Buskirk, and that he knows from his own age, in connection with that of Peter Van Buskirk, that the latter is now in his 99th or 100th year of age. He recollects his own age to be 94, and that there was five years difference in their ages. That he knew all the Van Buskirk Family, and never knew or heard of any one, having the name of Peter, except the claimant. He also states that he knows that Peter Van Buskirk, was an officer, during the revolutionary war, and engaged in buying forage, grain, &c. for the army. 8th The affidavit of And. H. Hoppin, aged 74, that he has spent all his life in Bergen Co. N.J.; that he knew the family of Thomas Van Buskirk well, that he has been Sheriff of the County, and Judge of the Court of Common Pleas, and that he never heard of any person named Peter Van Buskirk, but the claimant, who was a son of Thomas, that Thomas was reputed in his life time, to be a man of grant wealth. 9th. Affidavit of Polly Van Ryper, daughter of the claimant, that the family record of her mother, shows, that she was born on the 7th April 1767, and that she has always understood

State of Georgia } Lincoln County—} Before me Rem Remson a Justice of the Inferior Court came Personally Thomas Howard the applicant for restoration to the pension list of the Georgia Agency who being by me duly Sworn deposeth and Saith in order to explain the difference in the Schedules of his property furnished the War Department the 9 June 1820 and the one furnished the 28 April 1824 is that the tract of land is the Same he lived on valued first at two hundred dollars in the last at Seventy five dollars. Which difference is in the opinion of deponant[sic] owing to the change of times. lands in Georgia Since the time the first Schedule was furnished has decreased greatly in value & the Situation of Deponants[sic] farm from his inability to labour as he used to be is not in the Same Situation Which this deponant[sic] is Supported in by the affidavit of James Curry & Peter Lamar esquires. deponant[sic] further declares that the land Sold to Edward Howard for Sixty dollars to enable him to build him a Cabin Deponant having lived in his old cabin until it became unsafe to Continue in it. and he employed Moses Littleton to build his house for which deponant[sic] p∂ Said Littleton forty dollars. he had some further expence[sic] to pay which consumed the balance the mare sold for which is Stated also in the affidavit of Moses Littleton & Edward Howard; this Deponant[sic] further States that the Colt mentioned in the first Schedule he gave to his son James provided he would raise it. at the time it was of very little value & provisions So Scarce with deponant[sic] that he was not able to feed it. and his others on which he relied for Supporting him. What changes that has been made for the Stock deponant[sic] further Swears has been principally in the support of his family: deponant[sic] further States that he owed at the time provisions ? made for the relief of Invalid Soldiers a Considerable Sum of Money to differant[sic] persons. One hundred dollars was for a part of the Land I now own. Which I purchased of Col. Wm. Curry When land was at the highest rates with us in Georgia. which has greatly decreased owing to the great Change of times & the quantity of lands Georgia obtained in their last purchases from the Indians which was Lotteried out among the people and which Sum of money deponant[sic] has never been able to pay entirely. deponant[sic] further Swears that he has made no waste nor has he taken any Steps to Diminish his property

I Stephen Crandell of Tiverton in the county of Newport and State of Rhode Island aged Seventy Six years being first duly Sworn according to law do on my oath depose and say that I have now in my possession a journal which was made and kept by Elder Peleg Burroughs a Minister of the Gospel resident in said Tiverton duly authorized to join people in marriage, said journal was commenced in the year 1781 and ended in 1781. in said journal in the hand writing of said Peleg Burroughs is the following entry vig. " Seventeen hundred and eighty Sis. fifth month Seventh day - 6.th D. did a variety of work visited Davenport xc. Sister Abigail and Mary green V. us xc. Rested yesterday as usual had the pleasure of hearing & joining my young friends in prayer in my family xc. And to day the very rainy as twas yesterday preached twice in the M. House to fen-heaven but with much freedom & solemn sense of truth on Isaiah 51.3 the Lord shall comfort Lion xc. and James 3.11. "my Brethren these things ought not so to be Spoke against many wrong things & abominations now in the land Slave trade xc. among Professors & others since which went to S Simmon's to attend a marriage and returned just non." "And I further certify that the above is a true copy or extract from said journal with the exception of the date which is expressed on said journal in fair legible figures as follows " 1786 5. mo. [illegible] Stephen Crandell State of Rhode Island} county of Newport. } S.S. But known that on the 11th day of September 1843 before the Subscribed a justice of the Peace in and for said County personally appeared the above named Stephen Crandell a credible person to me well known and made oath to the truth of his above deposition and subscribed the same, before me Asa Gray Justice of the Peace

house, built more than forty years ago, & now leaky & cold. This tenement furnishes him & his family with a shelter from the storm, & the garden provides, with his industry, some summer vegetables. He has not a cow, nor a horse, nor a sheep, nor any domestic animal except a hog & a cat. He has five unmarried daughters, & one son, all of whom depend on his house for a home, & the oldest of these five daughters, has for some years past been very frequently afflicted with seven convulsion fits, which her physicians fear are incurable. His household goods consist of a few old tables & chairs, some iron pots & kettles with farm crockery ware, in the whole, not amounting in value to forty dollars. His daughters by their needles, have earned & purchased a few articles of household goods of more value than those which belong to your petitioner, & which remain in the same house. The property above enumerated, composes the whole estate of your petitioner, real & personal he being entirely destitute of money, or of money outstanding upon obligation or book account; - He is beside, indebted to various individuals for articles purchased for family necessity, the amount whereof is unknown & purpose not necessary to be stated. For the truth of this general statement of his affairs, your petitioner refers the Secretary for confirmation, to the Honble. Mr Dickenson of the Senate, & the Honble Bernard Smith, of the H. R. both of whom have well known your petitioner & his circumstances, for nearly 30 years. In the hope that the Bounty of his Government, once bestowed on him for Revolutionary services & sufferings, will be restored, to cherish & warn him in the winter of life, he appeals with confidence to the justice of the Secretary of War, as the friend of the needy Soldier. Morris County N. Jersey Novr 21st 1820. George Emmel

Fauquier County, to wit: A schedule of the property of John Dulin surrendered on the 1st day of October 1827, in pursuance to the act of the General Assembly for the relief of insolvent debtors Real property none Personal property 10 head of cattle, 1 yoke of oxen and 1 cart, 2 mares, 1 negro man Joe, 1 bed and cloths, 1 cubboard, 1/2 dozen chairs, 1 table, 1 anvill and vice, 1 cary plough, 2 shovel ploughs and stock, 1 clovis and pin, 1 sow & 6 pigs, 1 harrow, 1 wheat fan, 3 sheep, all which property aforesaid is subject to a deed of trust executed by me to Francis W. Brooks for the benefit of Henry L.Y. Pope and recorded in the Clerk's office of the County Court of Fauquier and to another deed of trust executed by me to John Leary for the benefit of John G. Dulin and George Dulin and recorded in the Clerk's office of the County Court of Fauquier and now in possession of Ed Driggs, Sheriff of sd County. John Dulin Fauquier County, to wit: William Horner & Tho: Ingram two of the Justices of the peace for the County of Fauquier aforesaid. To the Sherif or Keeper of the said County. We hereby command you in the name of the Commonwealth forthwith to release and set at liberty John Dulin a prisoner now in your custody by virtue of an execution against him at the suit of Benjamin R. Lakin for the sum of $26.99, with interest thereon at the rate of ix per centum per annum from the 24th day of May 1821, until paid, and $19.68 costs: and also by virtue of another execution against him at the suit of John H. Gaskins, for the sum of $109.74, with six per centum interest on $100, part thereof from the 4th day of February 1826, till paid, and [illegible] for the benefit of Barkley Ward. The said John Dulin having complied with the direct of the act of the General Assembly for the relief of insolvent debtors, if the said John Dulin is detained in your custody for no other cause than the executions aforesaid: And for your so doing this shall be your warrant. Given this 1st day of October 1827, under our hands & seals. Wm. Horner [handwritten seal] Tho: Ingram [handwritten seal] This Indenture made the nineteenth day of October in the year of Our Lord one thousand eight hundred and twenty four between John Dulin and Frances his wife of the county of Fauquier and Commonwealth of Virginia of the one part, and Edward E. Cooke of the County of Fauquier and Commonwealth aforesaid of the other part, Witnesseth, that the said John Dulin and Frances his wife for and in consideration of one dollar lawful money of the United States to them in hand paid by the said Edward E. Cooke, at and before the sealing and delivery hereof, the receipt

the said John Dulin sold to Edward Digges the first named tract who paid to this affiant the sum of $1000, that Henry M. Clarkson purchased the other tract, and that this affiant in order to enable the said John Dulin to pay sundry executions in the hands of the sheriff agreed to release the said Henry M. Clarkson from his claim upon the tract of land purchased by him, and to look to the personal property contained in the deed dated 18th day of October 1896[?] that after the payment of the said sum of $1000 he was a creditor of the said John Dulin to the sum of $270.97/100, that the said John Dulin having taken the oath of an insolvent debtor surrendered a schedule of property, a part of the same being liable to the lien of this affiant, that under this lien 1 sow, 1 pig, 1 bull, 1 steer, 1 brindle cow, 1 red heifer, two calves, one bay mar, one do., 1 lame sow, 1 red cow,1i wheat fan, 1 bellow, 1 cart and a yoke of oxen & 1 brindle heifer, were sold for the sum of $90.20/100, subject to the expences of the sale and keeping the stock that including these expences all the [illegible] given in by the said John Dulin would very little more than pay the sum due to this affiant. H.L.Y. Pope Sworn to in open court, 24th Decr. 1827. J.A.W. Smith, C.T. Virginia: Fauquier County, to wit: I, John A.W. Smith, Clerk of the County Court, of the County aforesaid, hereby certify that the said Court has certified upon its records, that it appears to the satisfaction from the declaration of John Dulin this day made in open Court, upon oath from the affidavits of Edward Digges, Spencer Anderson, Henry L.Y Pope, credible witnesses made on the 31st day of March 1827, & other affidavits and the Certificate of John Marshall Chief Justice of the United States, the deed annexed to the declaration of the said John Dulin, and the records of this Court, that the said John Dulin did serve in the Revolutionary War as stated in his declaration against the common enemy for the term of nine months under one engagement, on the Continental establishment, that the said John Dulin has also taken the oath of an insolvent debtor, is in such indigent circumstances as to require the aid of his Country for support, and that he has no property of any kind. In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand, and affixed the seal of the said Court, this 24th day of December 1827, and in the 52nd year of the Commonwealth. John A.W. Smith, Clk. Fauq. County Court [SEAL]

And the said Declarant on his oath aforesaid further states that he is by occupation a farmer; that for thirty years past he has been constantly [crossed out] afflicted with a constant distressing and debilitating pain in his stomach contracted by means of the fatigues of his service in the Revolutionary War which has rendered him incapable the whole of that period of performing much labour & especially the last 7 or 8 years he has been utterly unable to perform the least labour: that he has living with him in his family depending on him a wife aged 55 years of feeble constitution & a widow of of [crossed out] a deceased son, Lydia Holdridge aged 29 years & her 3 children aged 7, 5, & 3 years That since his former schedule was made out his son William has arrived at that age of 21 years and his daughter Betsey at the age of 18 years & both provide for themselves: That the "50 acres of Land, 2 cows & one calf, 2 two year old steers & eight sheep" which this declarant ignorantly or forgetfully inserted in his former schedule did not belong to him at that time: that in that year 1816, this declarant being wholly unable to labour on his land in consideration of a debt due to his son Ephraim Holdridge Jun. & in consideration that his said son built him a small house, sold to him the said 50 acres except the said 5 acres mentioned in the above schedule and the other articles also belonged to his said son: but the said son being dead & ^ his family & all his concerns falling on the hands of this declarant this declarant did not recollect on account of his enfeebled state of mind to make the discrimination and the said declarant further states that all the said cattle which so belonged to his said son have been sold to discharge the debts of his said son [test crossed out: at his decease, being very [final two words too blacked out to read]] That the said 45 acres of Land which so belonged to his said son at his decease being very poor & rocky is wholly inadequate for the support of his said son's widow & children & of course they are a constant charge upon the hands of this declarant. That the debts for which this declarant was holden for another son & on account of which he held 2 mares appraised at 25 Dollars, has been paid by said son & he has also paid what this declarant had advanced on said debt & the same has been appropriated to the subsistence of his family and the said mares given up. And this declarant on his oath aforesaid further states that he has already for some time depended in great measure on the assistance of others for support & he is wholly incapable to subsist without public or private charity The reason that this declarant did not make this application before the County Court where his former schedule was made out is that said Court will not sit
