[begin italics]Resolved,[end italics] That the Delegates which are appointed to visit the Juniatta Association, be and hereby are requested to visit the Church at Tuscarora Valley, in conformity to the request expressed in the letter of that Church to this Association. 20. [begin italics[Resolved,[end italics] That this Association truly sympathise with the Church at Upper Seneca, and with the family in the loss they have sus tained by the decease of our brethren, Howard Griffith, Deacon of that Church, with whom this body have often taken sweet counsel, and in whom we ever found as able, constant, and zealous defender of Gospel Truth ; but that we sorrow not, as those without hope, for "precious in the sight of the Lord is the death of his saints." Psalm 116, 15. 21. [begin italics]Resolved,[end italics] That the following amendment to the 7th article of the Constitution, be submitted to the churches, with a request that they notice it in their letters to the next Association, to insert after the word "question," "and the vote for admission into the Association, shall be given by churches, each church being entitled to one vote, which vote shall be given by the concurrence of a majority of the Delegates present from each church ; and no church shall be received that shall not obtain the vote of three-fourths of the churches repre sented in the Association, at the time the application shall be finally voted upon." Then continue the remainder of that article from the words, "the suffrage," &c. 22. The Circular as reported by the committee was adopted. 23. Brother J. H. Jones was appointed to the write the Circular Letter for next Association. 24. The Corresponding Letter written by brother Coote, was read and adopted. 25. The Committee on the Treasurer's Account, reported a bal ance in his hands of $28.53 ; that they had made an allowance to brother Choat of $11, brother Poteet, $11, and brother Scott, $6.53, which was about fifty cents per day for their services, in visiting sister Associations. 26. [begin italics]Resolved,[end italics] That our next Association be holden with the Ebe nezer Church, of Baltimore, to commence on Thursday preceding the third Lord's day in May, 1835 ; brother Choat to preach the introduc tory sermon ; in case of failure brother Poteet. [Right page] 7 27. [begin italics]Resolved unimously,[end italics] That the thanks of this Association be tendered to the brethren and friends in the neighborhood, for their kindness and hospitality during our meeting. The business being concluded, brother Choat prayed ; after which the Moderator addressed the Association. JOHN HEALEY, [begin italics]Moderator.[end italics] JOSEPH. H. JONES, [begin italics]Clerk.[end italics] [begin bold]CIRCULAR LETTER.[end bold] [begin italics]The Elders and Messengers, composing the Baltimore Baptist Associa tion, to the Several Churches associated with them, send Christian salutation. Very Dear Brethren :[end italics] As it is customary to address you on some subject, we think the following would be of great service, and if properly attended to, would be much to the glory of God's grace and the comfort of his dear chil dren, and would have a tendency to promote a holy life and a godly conversation, namely : Evangelical matter and manner of preaching. Respecting the matter, it appears from the general tenor of Scrip ture on the subject, that the drift of the Apostles' preaching and wri tings had a tendency to lay the axe at the root of the tree, showing that all mankind are condemned according to the covenant of works ; and that they are entirely helpless in the business of salvation. [begin italics]" He that believeth not, is condemned already, and the wrath of God abideth on him."[end italics]. Being under the influence of a carnal mind, which is enmity against God, not subject to his law, neither indeed can be. The Apostles preached those truths, that left no refuge for the sin ner to fly to, either by his reformation, his prayers, or his tears ; in variably declaring, that Christ was THE WAY, THE TRUTH, and THE LIFE ; and that by him, all that believe are justified freely from all things from which they could not be justified by the law of Moses ; constantly affirming, that the salvation of the righteous is of the Lord, and not of him that willeth, nor of him that runeth, but of God that showeth mercy. They also testified, that a good tree would bring forth good fruit, but an evil tree corrupt fruit ; that the children of God were chosen in Christ, that they might be holy, created in Christ unto good works. The Apostles knowing what sore temptations are; feeling themselves men of like passions with others; touched with the feeling of their infirmities; therefore, in obedience to the direction of their Lord and master, comforted by his people, by saying unto the righteous, it shall be

Declaration In order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress of the 7th July, 1838, entitled, an act of granting half pay & pensions to certain persons [crossed out] ^widows. State of New Jersey, Morris County ss: On this 30th day of August in the year of our Lord 1838, personally appeared before the Judges of the Court of Common Pleas of said County, Martha Emmel, a widow of Morris town in the County of Morris, aged years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on her oath, make the following Declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the provisions made by the act of Congress, passed July 7th 1838, entitled an act, granting half pay & pensions to certain widows. I am the widow of George Emmel, who was a soldier in a Battalion or Regiment raised in Philadelphia, called Colonel Cadwalader Battalion or Regiment, as I understood from my husband. How long he served, I am unable to say, nor can I tell in what other Regiment if any, he did other duties. I think he was then attached to the Pennsylvania line, but am not positive. I believe he was engaged considerable time, in being of the Army in & near to Albany, & along the Hudson river, & at Pompton [not clear] in the State of New Jersey, & my impression is that this was toward the close of the war & that he then was employed in the Commissary or Quarter Masters Department. For details & specifications of his services, I refer the Commission of Pensions to his original Declaration now on file in the Pension Office, and under the law of the U. States of March, 1818, under which he was admitted on the Pension roll of the N. Jersey Agency & was suspended under the law of 1820, & was finally restored to the roll, & recd his pension till his death. -- My name before my marriage was Martha Winons, & I was generally called Patty. My father was Isaac Winons, & he lived when I was a girl at Bottle Hill, now called Madison, in this County. I was married to the said George Emmel at my father's [crossed out] a Mr. Butlers home by Revd Mr. Bradford, then Minister of the Presbyterian Church of Bottlehill on the 7th day of April, in the year in which the rejoicing & illumination of Morris town & the neighboring villages, for peace, took place, by bonfires and burning of tar barrels etc: & I believe it was the year 1782. I believe there is no Parrish record of marriages kept in that church of that early period, as apprantly a certificate of Revd. Mr. Aimes, the present Pastor. I have a family bible, containing a record of our marriage & births of our children a leaf of which bible containing said records I send to the Pension officer, with this Declaration, which I truly believe is a true record. About the time of our marriage we settled in Morris town, where my said husband followed his trade, a wig maker & hair dresser. He was a native of Frankfort when the

John Fox New Hampshire Private, served 3 years from 1777 Farm valued at $400. - Income from the service year 12. - Yoke of oxen $45 & 2 cows 26 69.- 3 two yr old heifers 27 27.- 2 yearling steers 10. - 9 sheep & 4 lambs 12 22.- 3 calves 6.- Farming utensils 9.90 Kitchen furniture etc. 16.- Schedule date 5th July 1820 $461.90 2nd Schedule date 6th August 1823. Heifer calf & hoe and a few articles of furniture and farming utensils value by comt. ----- $71.- Sold real estate to Elijah Noyes Jan 5th 1821 for $500 - copy of deed exhibited Sold 2 oxen 2 cows - 2 [illegible] olds 3 yearlings to pay debts and support his family. Paid debts with proceeds of sale of farm to sundry persons names given to the amount of $436.80 - Rec'd in part payment of farm 'stock' upon which he lost $30 - The only evidence of the debts due from claimant are the original notes given by him to his creditors which were returned to him on the payment of them and which are filed within, is a letter from J.S. Moulton accompanying the receipt, it is stated the these are the only evidence which claimant can produce as the creditors have generally removed to different

District of New-Jersey, Morris Country, ss. On this Seventh day of July 1823 personally appeared in open Court, before the Judges of the Inferior Court of Common Pleas, holden at Morris-Town, in and for the county of Morris, in the term of July in the year aforesaid, (the said court being a Court of Record, possessing a seal, proceeding according to the course of the common law, having a jurisdiction unlimited in point of amount, keeping record of its proceedings, and its judgements being removable by writ of error only) George Emmel in the 69th year of his age and resident in said country, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth, on his oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the provision made by the acts of Congress of the 18th March, 1818, and the 1st of May, 1820, that he the said George Emmel enlisted for the term of one year some time in the month of February 1776 in the city of Philadelphia in the company commanded by Captain Alexander Creighton, in the third battalion, commanded by Colonel John Shee, in the line of the state of Pennsylvania, on the Continental establishment. That he continued to serve in the said [unclear], until he, together with the whole company & battalion with their officers, were captured by the British army at Fort Washington, near the city of New York, in or about the month of November of the same year. - That he was detained as a prisoner by the enemy at the [unclear] house at the Bridwell prison during the term of two months or thereabouts when he made his escape from the enemy reported himself to the Lieut. Col. Lambert Cadwallader, of the same Battalion, then a prisoner [unclear], in Philadelphia, as appears by a certificate of said Cadwallader, on file with the original papers of this applicant in the war office, that his name has been placed in the pension list and dropped therefore on account of his property - And in pursuance of the act of the 1st of May, 1820, I do solemnly swear that I was a Resident Citizen of the United States, on the 18th day of March, 1818, and that I have not, since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War," passed on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts, due to me; nor have I any Income, other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. as follows viz. A small lot of land in the mountains, containing 3/8th of an acre with a dwelling house of wood thereon, built in the year 1702- no barn or stable thereon, the house very old , much decayed, and out of repair- 1 Bed & bedding 1 old corner cupboard 1 griddle 1 old [unclear] 2 old pails 1 old pan (iron) 1 old cupboard 12 old chairs 1 gridiron 1 pair andirons 2 old wheels 1 bake oven (tin) 1 Dr. shovel & Tong 1 old reel 1 chopping knife 1 old [unclear] glass 1 meal chest 1 Small seat in Church 1 pr old candlesticks 1 old cradle 1 family Bible 3 old tables 2 hoes 2 small Bibles 2 old [unclear] 1 rake 1 hymn book 1 old axe eye 1 [unclear] 1 parlor fork 1 old hatchet 1 cane chair 1 tin coffee pot 1 old harmonica 2 dinner plates (1 cracked) 1 pr smoothing irons 1 old saw 1 cracked kettle 1 iron teakettle This [unclear] has no bonds, no notes, or other securities for money due to him. He has no horse, [unclear], or any other cattle. He has two small pigs about two months old- He is indebted to the following persons in the following sums as nearly as he can now ascertain, viz. to Dr Whelpley about five dollars, to the Presbyterian Church about two and a half dollars, to Jacob Mann three dollars

Brooke, his heirs and assigns to the only proper use, benefit & behoof of the said Francis W. Brooke, his heirs & assigns forever. Brooke, his heirs and assigns forever, free from the claims of him and of every other person, and free from all other titles and incumbrances whatsoever - also the following personal property, to wit: Negroes Joe, Ralph, Tom, Amy & Ann, two bay mares, one sorrel horse (pony), one yoke of oxen, one ox cart, all his interest in the farming utensils, ten head of cattle, twelve head of sheep & their increase, all his stock of hogs, one wheat fan and sett of blacksmith's tools. In trust nevertheless, and to the following uses and purposes and none other, that is to say, that whereas the said John Dulin is indebted to a certain Henry L.Y. Pope in the sum of nine hundred & six dollars as evidenced by single bill bearing date the sixteenth day of October, eighteen hundred & twenty six payable on demand, and is desirous to secure the payment of the same, and also to secure to the said Pope any other and further advances that the said Pope may hereafter make for or to him the said John Dulin at his request: Now if the said John Dulin shall fail to pay to the said Henry L.Y. Pope, or his assigns the said sum of nine hundred & six dollars, and the amount of any future advances, if any, and all interest which shall have accrued on the same within one year from the date of these presents, then and in that event it shall be the duty of the said Francis W. Brooke, at any time thereafter, on being so required, to sell the property hereby conveyed to the highest bidder

Montgomary COUNTY, ss. The PEOPLE of the STATE of NEW YORK, by the Grace of GOD, free and independent: To any Constable of said county, Greeting. WHEREAS Judgment has been rendered before me, Nichs Quackinbush Esquire, one of the Justices of the Peace of the said county, against Evert [illegible] in favor of John Noland for four dollars, 80 1/2 cents THESE are therefore to command you forthwith to levy of the goods and chattels of the said defendant, his arms and accoutrements excepted; and also excepting for the term of five years from the 5th day of April, 1810, of the property of every householder, all sheep to the number of twenty, also one cow, two swine, and all necessary wearing apparel and bedding, the amount of the said Judgment, with interest from the 2 day of March on which day Judgment was rendered, till received; and bring the money before me, within thirty days, to render to the said plaintiff for his debt and costs. And for want of goods and chattels whereon to levy, you are hereby commanded to take the body of the said defendant , and convey him to the common gaol of the county aforesaid, the keeper whereof is hereby commanded to receive the said defendant, and him safely keep until duly discharged according to law. Hereof fail not at your peril GIVEN under my hand and seal, at Charlsten this 2 day of March in the year of our Lord 1815 Debt 4 Dollars 0 Cents. Costs 0 Dollars 80 1/2 Cents. Judgment of 0 Dollars 80 1/2 Cents. Nicholas Quackinbush Justice Printed by Websters and Skinners, at their Bookstore, Albany.

[348] 4 perty, the value of which is assessed at the lowest rates and upon reliable date, to wit: Ninety-six negroes, at $300 per capita $28,800 Fifteen head of cattle, at $13 " 195 Six horses, at $100 " 600 Fifty head of sheep at $3 " 150 Thirty head of hogs, at $5 " 150 One canoe -- four-oared boat 100 Carpenters' and coopers' tools, £25. 122 $30, 117 The negroes lost, Major Wigg ascertained, had been carried by the British to St. Augustine, in Florida, at that time a Spanish province, and there sold at auction, and that twenty or twenty-one of the number had been purchased by Mr. Leavitt, a citizen of Georgia, who had brought them with him into that State. These twenty or twenty-one negroes Major Wigg went after, and recovered without molestation, and retained possession of them up to the period of his death, and died under the impression that he was not liable for their value; but in this he was mistaken, for his son after his death was forced to pay for them in full, and he did so. Major Wigg never made application to Congress for relief, in consequence of his belief, up to the period of his death, in the poverty of the government, but it is evident that he designed doing so, from the fact that he made an affidavit to the extent of his losses, (which original paper is among the evidence in the case ) and left it in the possession of his brother-in-law Thomas Hutson, Esq., who was also the magistrate before whom it was executed, undoubtedly with the view of its being placed in the possession of his son, at that time a youth in Princeton college, but it so happened that Mr. Hutson also died soon after Major Wigg, and before the return of Major Wigg's son from college. In this way the paper was lost sight of, and never recovered until recently it was found, by W. M. Hutson, Esq., the grandson of Mr. Thomas Hutson, among some old and long-forgotten papers of his grandfather, and by him given to the claimant, who lost no time in prosecuting the case after he ascertained the nature of it. The facts of this case are sustained by the histories of Garden and Ramsay, and by the affidavits of persons belonging to the most respectable class of society in South Carolina, with the single exception of one colored person, who is the sole survivor in South Carolina of the whole number of negroes belonging to Major Wigg that were captured by the British in 1781; and it is the opinion of the committee that the case is clearly sustained by the evidence and with a remarkable degree of accuracy when the lapse of time is taken into consideration. That Major Wigg was a legal hostage by the act of the British authorities and by the acquiescence of General Greene, and that his property was taken from him by the British while he was a hostage, and for causes growing out of that condition of hostageship, is clearly proven to the satisfaction of the committee. The committee are also perfectly satisfied that neither Major Wigg nor any of his representatives have ever received any compensation for his losses, either from the government of South Carolina or from the United States. The claim for indemnity or compensation rests entirely upon the relation Major Wigg bore to his country at the time the loss occurred. He was

[begin italics]Resolved,[end italics] That the report of the committee of the Hudson River Association, respecting wearing mourning apparel, be printed in our minutes; which is as follows: "The committee to whom was referred the resolution of the First Baptist Church in Albany, relative to the discontinuance of mourning apparel, respectfully report, "That after serious consideration upon the subject, they have arrived at the conclusion, that it was their duty to express their unqualified approbation of the resolution submitted by that church, and to recom mend its adoption by the churches composing this body. "Your committee approach this subject, fully apprised of the danger of cherishing a spirit of innovation, or dissenting from the long es tablished customs of society ; but, they are equally convinced, that when customs, however venerable for their antiquity, or sanctioned by universal prevalence, are obviously useless in themselves, and injurious in their tendency, they constitute an oppressive domination that may and should be resisted,--and, such, in the opinion of your committee, is the custom of wearing fashionable mourning garments as indicative of grief. [Right page] 5 "It is certainly is not commended to our observance by any considera tions of practical utility,--there is nothing in the HUE more than in a peculiar [begin italics]form[end italics] of dress that is expressive of the desolation of heart consequent upon afflictive bereavements. This view of the subject is fully sustained by the fact, that a diversity of colors have been adopted by different nations for this purpose. Some have preferred to mourn in white, others in black, and it would require an ingenious casuist to assign very plausible reasons for the preference of either.-- If a mere display of sorrow be the object in view, it is difficult to con ceive, why [begin italics[grief,[end italics] rather than any [begin italics]other passion[end italics] should assume a pe culiar garb, or obtrude itself upon the public eye in any form of ex hibition ; unless indeed, pride must be gratified even in the trappings of death, and parade and display attend the mortifying monuments of the curse of sin. It is moreover to be feared, that there are cases, where the habiliments of mourning, are but the disguise of the most base and contemptible hypocrisy. It is very possible, and perhaps not of unfrequent occurrence, that it covers any thing but sadness; it is alike assumed by the vicious and the virtuous, the benevolent and the [illegible]; it may sometimes indicate a wounded spirit, or, the heir in his weeds of woe may be exulting in heart, that he is following to the grave the only obstacle to the gratification of his cupidity. "But inutlity is not the only objection that may be urged against this custom; considerations of a more serious character, call for une quivocal expressions of disapprobation of a practice evidently unhap py, if not injurious in it tendency. It is worthy of serious consider ation, whether the Apostolic precept, 'Be not conformed to the world,' is not infringed, by the conformity of professing christians, to a cus tom unsustained by the precepts of the Saviour, or the example of the Apostles, and having nothing to recommend it, but the fashion of the world. Should this point, however, be conceded, and it be ad mitted that there is nothing to direct us upon this subject in the New Testament; yet the embarrassment to which it subjects an afflicted family, is a sufficient reason to induce a renunciation of the practice. If there is ever a time when seclusion and serious reflection are de sirable, it is when God visits our families in a dispensation so solemn and affecting; there is much that is revolting to a sensitive and deli cate mine, in these circumstances, to be compelled to give then atten tion to the fitting of dresses, and the quality of goods, and the officious suggestions of friends with relation to their personal appearance. In fine, when the body is oppressed with fatigue, wearied with unremit ted and affectionate attention around the bed of sickness and death, and the spirit is overwhelmed with sorrow, when the one requires rest, and the other communion with God, these impertinent interrup tions are not only embarrassing, but frequently distressing in the ex treme. There is another evil inseparably connected with this custom, which should be seriously considered; its imperious demands upon the often limited resources of the survivors. Although the expendi ture attending this [begin italics]pride of grief,[end italics] may be of no moment to those who are abundantly "blessed in basket and in store," there is a class of

he is, by occupation, a farmer: And for thirty years past, he has been afflicted with a constant distressing & debilitating pain in his stomach, contracted by means of the fatigues of his service in the Revolutionary war, which has rendered his incapable, the whole of that period, of labouring to effect & especially the last six or seven years, he has been utterly unable to perform the least labour: that he has living with him, in his family depending upon him, a wife aged 53 years, of feeble constitution; One son, William, aged 18 years, one daughter, Betsey aged 16 years, a widow of deceased son, Lydia Holdridge, aged 29 years & has three children, aged six, four & two years; that the said deceased son, while living, had undertaken to take charge of & support the family of this declarant, in consideration that he was to have what little property belonged to this declarant; that instead of being thus provided for, in his distressed & helpless condition, his son died and left his family on the hands of this declarant for support; that he has been involved by two or three unfortunate sons, in several large debts, of which these remains unpaid about $50. And he owes debts of his own to the amount of about 80. Sworn to & declared on the 10th day of June 1820 before the Court aforesaid. Saml. In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand, and affixed the seal of the said Court on this 11th day of July 1820. Saml. Swift } Clerk of the County Court of the Court of Addison. Dear Sir, Shepherdsville Ky July 23d 1833 On yesterday I rec’d from the War department a packet Containing the original declaration of Elijah Wright, Samuel Hornbeck, Samuel Rowland, Lawrence Bishop and William Chappell with the Objections to each case. I found on Examining Mr. Bishops Declaration & the objections thereto that his papers had not been authenticated according to the Regulations. I immediately applied to the certifying Officer and shewed him the papers and he has as you will see put an additional Certificate Seal in the manner prescribed. They are herewith enclosed. An early attention to this case consistent with your official duties, will confer a favour on Mr. Bishop who is a poor & helpless man. I am respectfully Yr Obt Svt Geo. F. Pope Should Mr. Bishop be placed on the pension Roll (& I believe the only objection to it is now removed) please Enclose his Certificate to me. I have no Interest in it except my anxiety to see the old

nor can she specify the different battles in which he was engaged, but she remembers having heard him speak of the White Plains, - of the taking of the Hessians- of Princeton- of Germantown, of Brandywine, of the battle of Monmouth-and of his having been at Wyoming, and also of his having been wounded on one of his feet, the scar of which she has many times seen. She also recollects distinctly of his talking of the hardships, which he, with others, endured during his services. of their making barefoot over the frozen ground, and of the blood dropping from their feet- and of their wrapping cloths round their feet for their protection. and of their suffering much from want of clothing-He also told his recollections of Gen. Washington, and she remembers his saying that he once saw him, watching, through a spy Glass, from a position he had chosen, the movements of the enemy. She has no documentary testimony whatever of his services. but has provided the testimony of two witnesses which is all she could obtain on the subject, which testimony is hereto annexed It was on the 11th day of April A.D. 1813, said Jacob Bishop died. applicant further declares that she was married to said Jacob Bishop on the 25th day of December A.D. 1781. (seventeen hundred & eighty one and that her husband the aforesaid Jacob Bishop died as aforesaid on the tenth day of April in the year eighteen hundred

Rev. War Section. May 13, 1919. Honorable Henry W. Temple, House of Representatives. My dear Mr. Temple: In response to your letter dated the twelfth instant, requesting information relative to Jacob Bishop, for Miss Bird Cook of 818 Ninth Avenue, Beaver Falls, I have the honor to advise you that in the papers in the claim of his widow Mary Bishop T. File No. 3,331 Rev. War, his service is stated as follows. Jacob Bishop enlisted before he was of age, at Hagerstown, Maryland in the Summer of 1776, as a Private in Captain William Heyser's company of Colonel Haussegger's German Regiment and served three years, during which time he was in the battle of White Plains, [lined out: taking of the Hessians, battle of] Trenton, [lined out: battles of] Princeton, Brandywine, Germantown and Monmouth; that he marched to Wyoming, endured severest hardships, and was wounded in the foot in one of the engagements. [lined out: There is no application for pension on file for the soldier; and his age is not stated.] Jacob Bishop was married December 25, 1781 to Mary Powel [lined out: by Joseph Powel a Minister of the Gospel, no relationship stated.] Soldier died April 10, 1813, and his widow Mary was allowed pension on her application executed January 20, 1839, at which time she was a resident of Bethel Township, Bedford County, Pennsylvania, and seventy-four years of age. Her son William Bishop, who was alive in 1839, is the only child referred to. In 1855, Mary Bishop resided in Fulton Co. Pennsylvania, the date of her death is not shown. Very truly yours, [signature:] GM Saltzgaber Commissioner.

Fauquier County. This 24th day of December 1827. Caldwell Carr appeared in open Court and made oath that Joseph Carr, his Father now deceased, did in his life time assign to George Calvert his son in law, a bond due from John Dulin for $203 [partly illegible] with interest from the 26th July 1814, that he has heard his Father say that it was a first debt, and he believes that the said bond originated in a store account contracted by the said John Dulin, with the said Joseph Carr, at Upperville in Farquier County, that a suit was brought upon the said bond by the said George Calvert, and that the affiant believes that the amount with [illegible] was made by execution against the said John Dulin. Sworn to in Open Court, 24th Decem 1827. Jno A.W. Smith, C. [illegible] This 24th day of December 1827, Frances W. Brooke a credible witness of full age appeared in open Court and made oath that the execution an abstract of which is annexed to the affidavit of Law and Digger filed with the declaration of John Dulin a petitioner for a pension is founded upon a bond given by John Dulin and William Dulin to John Scott dated the 9th day of September 1824, for sundry shelf, calle or provisions purchased by the said John Dulin at a sale made by the said John Scott that the bond is in the handwriting of this official who acted in taking it for the said John Scott, and was present when the articles were purchased. This affiant further saith that he is the trustee in one of the deeds of trust for the use of Henry L. J. Pope that bearing date the 18th day of October 1826, that John Dulin having surrendered sundry articles of property named in that deed, in his schedule of insolvency subject to the said deed, he as trustee caused a sale of the same articles to be made, that the sale amounted to $90.20/100, subject to the expenses of the sale, and the records of maintaining a portion of the property by the Sheriff from the time of the surrender to him, that he purchased some of the property and was induced by the extreme poverty and distress of the said John Dulin to leave much as he bought at the house of the said Dulin for the use of himself and family. Sworn to in open Court, 24 Decemr 1827. Jno A.W. Smith [illegible]. This 24th day of December 1827, Henry L. Y. Pope appeared in open Court and made oath that on the 5th day of March 1827, John Dulin an applicant for a pension was indebted to him in the sum. of $ 1271.77/100, that the said Henry L. Y. Pope is now engaged as a man [illegible] in the town of Warrenton, Fauquier County, that the said sum of money was Justly due to him for goods, wares, and merchandise sold by him to the said John Dulin, for sundry debts due from the said John Dulin and paid at his instance by the affiant, and for advances made to him that in order to secure the payment of the said sum, the said John Dulin Executed two deeds of trust, one bearing date on the nineteenth day of October 1824, to E. E. Cooke, trustee, upon the tract containing about 200 acres in the declaration mentioned the said deed calling for 320 acres more or less, but in fact embracing only about 200 acres, and the other bearing date on the 18th day of October 1826 to F.W. Brooke make, upon that act, as well of the tract of 180 acres, that with the permission of this affiant

3 affidavits, duly taken, are within - they are dated in December 1823, 2 go to prove the facts as stated by the affiant in his last his sched: They state that affiant & his family have long & expensive needs and that he is really in distressed & necessitous circumstances. "Hon. C. Rich H.R." Supplement 3d. Sched: (11th Sept. 1823) exhibits personal property - viz: 1 cow $10 - 1 old plough $1 - [no other article higher than 50 cents.] whole amt. of the sched: is $12.87. - = states that he sold his 50 acres of land to Reuben Gillett Jr. for $500 on the 3d of May 1822 - (an authenticated copy of the deed is in there.) The consideration money was paid in various notes against sundry persons - he states that the avails of said note have been expended in the support of an expensive & sick family - in the payment of Physician's visits & in payment of other debts - "the particulars of which he cannot now recollect." - 1 cow sold Jesse C. Higley for $13 in the fall of 1821, to pay a debt done him. 1 & 2 yr old steers sold to Lemuel Derby in the fall of 1821 "to pay a debt." - 15 sheep - part of them consumed in the family - the other sold to buy necessaries. 2 mares returned to his son, he, the son having satisfied that debt for which they were given as security - other articles worn out. = Part of the consideration for land was a lease for the same for 2 yrs to the son of the affiant. An authenticated copy is within. (over)

State of Vermont } At Middlebury in said County on the 3rd day of January 1824, before Addison County ss} me, one of the Justices of the peace for said County, personally appeared Reuben Gillett Jun. of Cornwall in said County, and being duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath testify and say - that I was present, when Ephraim Holdridge of Bridport in said County made his declaration and schedule before the County Court for said County in December last & have heard the same read - that so far as the same relates to his sale of his farm to me it is strictly true - except, that on further recollection, the lease, which I gave to his son, on his account, I think, was repaid at $30 dollars per year, making about 55 dollars - and the notes against Matthew J. Lewis amounted to 113 dollars, instead of 108 dollars: - that I purchased of him ten sheep for about 11 dollars - $8 in cash & three dollars on an account against him for dressing cloth - that for several years & more particularly for two or three years, I have been acquainted with the circumstances of the said Holdridge, & know that the family have been much of the time sick & expensive - that he could have had no income, to any amount, except what has arisen from the sale of his property, as he has stated, and believe him to be now so destitute of property & so helpless, that he's wholly out of his power to maintain his family, and he must depend on public or private charity for his subsistence Reuben Gillet Jun Sworn & subscribed this 3rd day of Jany 1824 before me - and I certify that the above

MONTGOMERY COUNTY, SS -- The People of the State of New-York, by the Grace of God, Free and Independent to any Constable of said County, Greeting WHEREAS Judgment has been rendered before me Nichs Quainboss Esquire, one of the Justices of the Peace of said county, against John [illegible] Antwerp Defendant in favor of John S Quackinboss plaintiff for Seven Dollars and 55 cents ; THESE are therefore to command you forthwith to levy of the goods and chattels (his arms and accoutrements 8 excepted; and also exempting of every householder, "all sheep to the number of ten, to gether with their fleeces, and the cloth manufactured from the same; all necessary wearing apperil and bedding, necessary cooking utensils, one table, six chairs, six knives and forks, six plates and six tea cups and saucers") of the said John S VanAntwerp amount of the said Judgment, together with interest from the 24 day of ganuary on said judgment until collected, and bring the money before me within thirty days to render to the said Plaintiff for damages and costs. And for want of sufficient goods and chattels whereon to levy, you are hereby commanded to take the body of the said and convey to the common goal of the county aforesaid, the keeper whereof is hereby commanded to receive the said John S VanAntwerp and him safely keep until duly discharged according to law. Hereof fail not at your peril. Given under my hand and seal at Charlston this 22 day of Febry in the year of our Lord 1818 Damages 6 Dollars 68 Cents Costs Dollars 84 Cents Judgement 7 Dollars 55 Cents Nich Quackinboss- Justice: SYLVESTER KING, Printer -- Johnstown

State of Vermont Rutland County Ss} Wells March 27th 1844 I Shubael Lamb Minister of the Methodist Episcopal Church int he town and state above written, aged 72 years, Would testify and say, that I was well acquainted with David Howe from the time that he removed into this town until his decease having lived in the same neighborhood with him during the time that he lived in this town. That it was the opinion of the neighbors that he was out in the war of the Revolution, in which opinion I concur. I am likewise acquainted with his widow, Phebe Howe and am knowing to her still living as his widow. I would also state that she is considered a person of truth and veracity and any statements or declaration made by her I should think entitled to credit, and might be depended upon. Shubael Lamb State of Vermont Rutland County Ss} I certify that at Wells on this 27th day of March 1844 the above named Shubel Lamb personally appeared and subscribed the foregoing affidavit and made solemn oath that the same contains the truth and nothing but the truth before me. David B. Lewis Justice Peace I do further certify that I am personally acquainted with the above named Shubel Lamb and that he has been a Minister of the Gospel in this town ever since my remembrance, and that he is a credible witness. I am likewise well acquainted with the above named Phebe Howe who has always since my remembrance lived neighbors to me and would concur int he statements of the Rev. Shubael Lamb as made above. David B. Lewis Justice of the Peace

...was acquainted and with whom he served at the different periods of the Revolutionary War, to which he refers for their names and rank more particularly. And the deponent further on oath declares that he served not less than the periods herein before specified at the times and under the command of the officers as mentioned by him, making an aggregate of Twenty one months and three days service performed by him as a private soldier, independent of his service as a substitute for Richardson, his hiring with his squad in his company, a substitute for one month to join the American Army previous to the Battle of Monmouth and the various services entered by him as a volunteer Minuteman in suppressing the inroads of the British and Tories interacting the communication between them and the disaffected in the country and cutting off their supplies and which is more particularly set forth in his former declaration, to which this is an amendment and for which services he cannot affix any precise length of time, as they were rendered by him at different times on different days, more or less during the Revolutionary War. To the Interrogatories prescribed by the War Department, he answers: I - He was born in Elizabeth Town township in the County of Essex and State of New Jersey on the 10th day of February A.D. 1760. II - That the record of his age was entered in his father's family Bible; a transcript from which upwards of twenty year past was entered in his family Bible where it is now to be seen. III - That he lived in Elizabeth Town township County of Essex and State of New Jersey when called into service and continued residing there until the year 1821 when he removed to Monroe County and since that to Niagara County, both in the State of New York, where he now resides. IV - He was a volunteer, a drafted person, and a substitute for one William Richardson at the times and for the periods set forth in this declaration. V - He served at different periods when Col. Elias Dayton and Col. Matthias Ogden with their Continental Troops of the New Jersey line were acting in concert, as likewise Capts. Neal, Pratt, Pearson, Lieuts. Edmund Thomas, William Shute, Ephraim, Whitlock, Huet again (the last of which he saw both before and after he was killed at Connecticut Farms) and others mentioned in his former declaration. He recollects Col. Elias Dayton's Regiment of New Jersey Continentals being often on duty with them. Col. William Washington's Cavalry and Capt. Huet's company of Continental Artillery, Col. Seeley's militia regiment from Morris County and Col. Jaques's and Col. Samuel Potter's Militia Regiments of Essex County, State of New Jersey. Under the officers belonging to these two last regiments, he principally performed his different tours of duty as set forth in this and his former declaration. VI - That he never received any discharge from any officer under whom he served from the service, none being demanded by him or deemed exquisite by them as this deponent and his officers resided in the same County and were well acquainted with each other. VII - That now as in his former declaration he says that he is well acquainted with Major Benjamin Barton, Isaac Colt Jr., Zina A. Colvin, Esq., and Leonard Shepard, who annexed to his former declaration have testified to his character for veracity and Leonard Shepard to his belief in his revolutionary services [crossed out: and]. Although there is no settled Clergyman in Lewiston, since the making of his former declaration has ascertained from the Reverend Cornelius Mars, an aged Clergyman residing in the township of Lewiston and Niagara County, and who was acquainted with him many years in the State of New Jersey. That he will testify to his character for veracity and belief of his services as a Revolutionary Soldier, to which he, the deponent, adds John Cook's affidavit with the proper attestation of his character for veracity. That he yet knows of no surviving witness except John Cook, by whom he can prove his actual service during or in the war. That he is poor and infirm and not able to undergo any great expenses in searching for such testimony but that he has reason to believe most part of those with whom and under whom he served are dead or residing in places out of his knowledge. He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present and declares that his name is not on the Pension Roll of any State whatever and referring to his former declaration for particulars not contained in this amendment, further saith not. s/ Benjamin Williams Sworn to and subscribed before me the day and year aforesaid. s/ R. Fleming, First Judge Niagara Common Pleas

Hon Dear Sir, You herein that this case is a case put into my hands- I let Mr. B. Peace of N.Y. send it to Washington US I was absent or had to be absent he handled it to some of the members- Contrary to my knowledge This case I sent the certificate of the marriage from the Church Records and other that were present and we helped prove facts of his death. Jc The old lady is poor and needy and this case will [wed] but little investigations as it has been Replied & investigated- & the original declaration I took before Horace Hurd a Justice of the Peace & a new Declaration was required which is now compiled with by me Cannot this case be disposed of - so that the poor suffering old lady can be benefitted by it- She is so feeble & probably cannot live many Years & suffers for want of support of life please to make time short as possible in this case as will id filed & examined & can be examined over again in a short time- all is definitely proven you will find- Truly yours with Great Respect Jacob Slingerland Hon J.L Edwards Com. of Pensions Please to forwards to me to East Cobleskill Schoharie County N.Y.

[Two pages] [Left page] 8 well with him, for God will not forsake his people, which he fore knew, been persuaded of this very thing, that God having began a good work in them would perform it. We think those things should be dwelt upon in the ministration of the word it will have a good effect on the child of grace--it will lead him to realize with pleasure, the truth of that doctrine and instruction, the Apostle gave to Titus, 111 chap. 3, 7 : [begin italics]For we ourselves, were sometimes foolish, disobedient, serving divers lusts and pleasure, liv ing in malice and envy, hateful and hating one another; but, after that the kindness and love of God our Saviour toward man appeared, not by works of righteousness which we have done ; but according to his mercy he saved us, by the washing of regeneration, and the renew ing of the Holy Ghost which he shed on us abundantly, through Jesus Christ our Saviour, that being justified by his grace we should be made heirs according to the hope of eternal life:"[end italics] The Apostles further observes, that this is a faithful saying; meaning the whole of what is before expressed in the above verses, concerning the state and condition of the people of God by nature--the appearance of the love and kindness of God to them--the salvation of them according to the the mercy of God, and not by works of righteousness ; regenera tion by the spirit of God in which so much grace is communicated, and justification by the free and sovereign grace of God, as God's method of salvation, by which the children of God are made to ap pear to be heirs of eternal life, and to have a good hope of it through this grace. Now all of this is a faithful saying, and true doctrine to be believed ; [begin italics]"And these things I will that thou affirm constantly;"[end italics] That is the above doctrine. Now it appears that the Apostle would have Titus be assured of these truths himself, and without any doubt concerning them, and abide firm in them, and speak of them with cer tainty, boldness, and confidence to others, and endeavor to establish his brethren in them ; and for this purpose, would have them fre quently inculcated and insisted on ; and, that with this further view, that they that have believed in God might be careful to maintain good works ; nothing can more strongly engage as a motive for the per formance of good works, than the frequent insisting on the above doctrines of grace, for they are good and profitable unto men. These things are very profitable and useful to influence faith, hope, love, and a cheerful obedience to the will of God. Nothing has a greater ten dency to promote humility and check pride in the saints, than to re flect on their past life, the state and condition they were in, when the love and kindness of God their Saviour appeared to them. In refer ence to this, the Apostle cries out, [begin italics]"This is a faithful saying, and worthy of all acceptation that Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners, of whom I am chief,"[end italics] and again, [begin italics]"Unto me, who am less than the least of all saints,"[end italics] &c. When the child of God thinks of the condition he was in, when the Lord quickened his dead soul, and called him with a holy calling, and gave him a good hope through grace, he is astonished at the long suffering and goodness of God, who hath spared him amid all his [Right page] 9 sins and rebellion, who hath given his dear Son to redeem and save him from the lowest hell. Thus the Goodness of God leadeth him to repentance, to that repentance that needed not to be repented of. He feels his obligation, and his language is, Lord what wilt though have me to do, what shall I render unto the Lord for all his benefits? Thus we see brethren, (as might easily be gathered from a num ber of other portions of Scripture, would the limits of a Circu lar admit,) the good tendency of evangelical matter in preaching. God is glorified in showing that his people are saved by his grace; his children are instructed, edified, and comforted; and it also promotes a holy life and godly conversation. As it regards the manner, we have the Apostles also for our exam ple and pattern; they did not use [begin italics]"enticing words of man's wisdom," "but seeing we have this hope, we use great plainness of speech."[end italics] They did not use guile or deceitfulness, but renounced the hidden things of dishonesty, not walking in craftiness, nor handling the word of God deceitfully; but seeing they were put in trust with the gospel, they so spake not as pleasing men, but God ; who tried their hears, and as stewards of the mysteries of God, they were faith ful ; they kept back no part, but declared [begin italics]"all the counsel of God."[end italics] This they did sincerely, fervently, and with boldness, not intimidated by the threats of men; none of these things moved them, they counted not their lives dear unto them, so that they might finish their course with joy, and the ministry they had received of the Lord Jesus, to testify the gospel of the grace of God. Brethren, we have great cause to lament, that by many professed preachers of the gospel, the example and pattern is lost sight of ; a large majority of hearers, and alas, too many professors would have their ministers to prophecy smooth things, that their preaching may not have the evil tendency of offending and scattering the congre gation, or the still more pernicious tendency of cutting off the ears. Thus fearing men rather than God, it has fully come to pass in many instances, like people--like priest; and it is to be feared, that the real object in view is to be well thought of ; and for this purpose, the glorious truths of the gospel are kept back or completely wrapped up, to the great injury and disadvantage of the children of Zion, and the delusion of sinners, who are pleased to have it so. Brethren, let us remember the words of our blessed Master, whosoever is ashamed of me and of my words, of him will the son of man be ashamed, when he cometh in the glory of his Father with the holy Angels ; let us not be ashamed of the gospel of Christ, but stand fast in faith, and contend earnestly for the same, holding fast a form of sound words, endeavoring to strengthen the things that remain, that are ready to die. The doctrine of the blessed gospel, is now given up by many who once professed to believe it, and others are halting between two opin ions. Let brethren in the ministry be faithful, and speak the truth as it is in Jesus, fully, clearly, and plainly; let them strictly adhere to the Apostolic matter and manner of preaching, and ardently protest against every thing that is not perfectly in accordance therewith, however 2

Norfolk: April 9, 1842 This is to certify all whom it may concern; that I am the pastor of the Congregational church in this place; and that I have in my possession a manuscript book in which Rev. Ammi R. Robbins a former pastor of the same church, was accustomed to record the marriages solemnized by him; and that in this book I find the following record. Married Oct eighth seventeen hundred and seventy seven David Howe & Phebe Cowls. Joseph Eldridge Jr. Dear Sir The above is a transcript of record from our minister the other person you wished information of other is but one in the vicinity; that is Phenzas Frase who is now living at Stockbridge (Mass) if you wish any more information [illegible] the case you can let me know. The above may be sufficient for you. Yours John A. Shepard Norfolk April 9 1842

I have attached the reply-- it appears from the Reply that a part of the Testimony has been overlooked will you have the goodness to peruse the Original Depositions you will find two or three definite witnesses who was present and witnessed the marriage of said James Hamilton and Jemima Gilbert & others who knew them before and after their marriage up to the day of the death of said James Hamilton there is a Record of their marriage taken out of a Bible & prayer Book both in the hand writing of said James Hamilton see the Testimony also there has been all the pains possible taken to find a record as you will perceive by the annexed letters of the Marriage from the Rector of the Church at Newtown the Rector of the Church has now gone to West & will be absent for a length of time - & his Deposition cannot be had now --- but here is definite and positive proof of those who witnessed & was present at the Marriage & others also. better and stronger proof cannot be had or found please to Examine the Original Testimony again all pains have been taken to satisfy the Department with those annexed Letters from the Rector or Pastor of the Church at Newtown as well as the Record made by the Old Gentleman Mr Hamilton himself Please report this claim to me Yours John J. Slingerland

________ Dutchess Country On this 21st day of April in the yea of Our Soul One thoudand Eight hundred and forty. Personally appointed before George W. David, First just of the Court of Connor pleads in the County of Rapdag Judith Newcomb a resident of the town of Pillstown in said County of Renfoilag in said State of New York Aged Eighty years the Eighteenth day of September now last just who being first duly sworn according to law doth on her oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the pension made by the act of Congress perfect July Fourth in the year of Our Lord One Thousand Eight Hundred and Thirty six, and the act extraordinary of said act pope March 3rd 1837, that she is the widow of James Newcomb late of the said ___ of Pettitory in Renfielor County aforesaid who was a soldier in the Revolutionary War and that in the year One Thousand and seven hundred and seventy six he resided in the County of Dutchess in said state in a place that cecttec Settle Ria Patug not few from Cold Spring is the family of Adonijah Newcomb the father of said James Newcomb that James Newcomb went out to New York and Long Stand on reveal expeditions in the Court of the year and way is his service six months and was employed during the time on the Island of New York in building ____ or budding as she was informed and believes and the next year one thousand seven hundred and seventy seven James Newcomb went in the service on an expedition to the north under John Rouse as Captain and was at the surrender of Burgoyne in October One Thousand Seven hundred and seventy seven as I was informed and believe as said James Newcomb was absent from home several months as she then resided in the family and continued there until they were married which marriage was consumated on the Nineteenth day of November One thousand seven hundred and seventy eight by Elder Conneg Bullock a Minister of the Baptist denomination who resided in the Neighborhood of Cold Spring at the time of the marriage

St. Johnsbury, Vt. August 9, 1843. I, Leonard Worcester, now residing in St. Johnsbury, in the County of Caledonia and State of Vermont, do hereby certify that Mrs. Sarah W. Fox, widow of Mr. John Fox, late of Hardwick, in the County and State aforesaid, deceased, is my sister, her original name being Sarah Worcester daughter of Noah Worcester, Esq. late of Hollis, N.H. deceased; and, according to the family record she was born at said Hollis, March 24. A. D. 1765. Although it so happened that I was not at home at the precise time of my said sister's marriage, we were both, at that time, members of our father's family, and I was knowing to the intention of her marriage being published in the usual manner, and, on my return home soon after the marriage, I was informed by the family, and have always understood, that she was married to the said John Fox the latter part of the month of May, A.D. 1782, by the Rev. Daniel Emerson, then Pastor of a Church in Hollis aforesaid. I know, moreover, that the said John Fox, on account of his marriage with my said sister, was, from that time ever regarded by our parents, as a son, and by myself, and my other brothers and sisters, as a brother and the said John Fox, and my said sister, ever afterwards lived together as husband and wife until the time of his decease, and were the parents of a pretty numerous family of children. I am myself nearly 21 months younger than my said sister, having been born at Hollis, January 1st, A.D. 1767. It may be added, that several other brothers and sisters of the said Sarah W. Fox, who, as it was understood, were present at her marriage with the said John Fox, as well as our family STATE OF VERMONT.} Caledonia County, ss} I, Samuel B. Mattock, Clerk of the County Court of the Couny of Caledonia in the State of Vermont, do hereby certify that Luther Jewett Esqr of St Johnsbury in said County is an acting Justice of the Peace in and for said county duly commissioned and qualified; that his commission was dated on the Ninth day of November in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and forty two. and will expire the thirtieth day of November next, and that his signature to the annexed to genuine. Given under my hand and the seal of said County Court, this Ninth day of August A.D. 1843. day of Saml P. Matlock Clerk.

St. Johnsbury, Vt August 9, 1843 I, Leonard Worcester, now residing in St. Johnsbury, in the County of Caledonia, and State of Vermont, do hereby certify that Mrs. Sarah W. Fox, widow of Mr. John Fox, late of Hardwick, in the County and State aforesaid, deceased, is my sister, her original name being Sarah Worcester, daughter of Noah Worcester, Esq. late of Hollis, N.H. deceased; and, according to the family record, she was born at said Hollis, March 24, A.D. 1765. Although it so happened that I was not at home at the precise time of my said sister's marriage, we were both, at that time, members of our father's family, and I was knowing to the intention of her marriage being published in the usual manner, and, on my return home soon after the marriage, I was informed by the family, and have always understood, that she was married to the said John Fox the latter part of the month of May, A.D. 1782 by the Rev. Daniel Emerson, then Pastor of a Church in Hollis aforesaid. I know, moreover, that the said John Fox, on account of his marriage with my said sister, was, from that time, ever regarded by our Parents, as son, and by myself, and my other brothers and sisters, as a brother and the said John Fox, and my said sister, ever afterwards lived together as husband and wife, until the time of his decease, and were the parents of a pretty numerous family of children. I am, myself nearly 21 months younger than my said sister, having been born at said Hollis, January 1st, A.D. 1767. It may be added, that several other brothers and sisters of the said Sarah W. Fox, who, as it was understood, were present at her marriage with the said John Fox, as well as our Parents, and the Minister who solemnized the marriage, are now all in their graves. Leonard Worcester. State of Vermont Caledonia SS M St. Johnsbury in said County, August 9 1843 Personally appeared Leonard Worcester signer of the above Deposition and made solemn ["and made solemn" written again and crossed through] oath that the same contains the whole truth and nothing but the truth. Before me Luther Jewett Justice of Peace

February 24, 1932 BA-J/MLB Mrs. Edgar M. Young 210 Cedar Street Providence, Kentucky Dear Madam: Reference is made to your letter of January 22, relative to Lawrence Bishop, a soldier of the Revolutionary War, in which you ask if there is any record on file of his blindness. You are informed that in the application for pension executed September 17, 1832, by Lawrence Bishop (S. 1166), he states that he had been blind for about twelve years, but there are no further details in regard to his affliction. Very truly yours A. D. HILLER Assistant to Administrator

Fauquier County, to wit: This 31st March 1827, Edward Digges appeared before the County Court of Fauquier and made oath that the above is a correct statement of the sums of money paid to him by John Dulin, of the executions in his hands, as the High Sheriff of the County against John Dulin & of the manner in which the said sums were applied that he was privy to the purchase of the tract of land made by Doctr. Clarkson as set forth in the petition of the said Dulin, that the purchase said to have been made by this affiant was made as is therein set forth, and that the sums due from him and the said Doctr. Clarkson except the small sum mentioned therein were fairly applied to bona fide debts due from the Petitioner, that he is in needy circumstances, and from his knowledge, he is in such needy circumstances as to require the aid of his country for support. Edwards Digges Sworn to in Court, 31 March 1827. J.A.W. Smith, Clk. Spencer Anderson appeared in open Court, and made oath that he knows that John Dulin was a soldier in the service of the United States in the Revolutionary War, and in the third Virginia Regiment commanded by Col. Mercer, that he marched with the said Dulin from Fredericksburg to Williamsburg in Virginia, further he saith not. Spencer Anderson x his mark Sworn to in open Court, this 31st March 1827 Jno. AW. Smith, Clk I certify that Mr. John Dulin enlisted in the year 1775, in the company of Captain William Pickett in the Culpeper minute Battalion in which I served as Lieutenant and that he served his time faithfully. J. Marshall Sept. 12th 1825 31st March 1827. Proved in open Court by the oath of Edward Digges to be in the hand writing of John Marshall Chief Justice of the United States. J.A.W. Smith, Clk Fauqr. County, to wit: This day personally appeared before me a justice of the peace for said County H.L.Y. Pope & made oath that on the 5th Inst. John Dulin was in his debt twelve hundred and seventy one dollars ninety seven cents for goods sold him and for advances made; to secure the payment of which he held a lean on the most of his property and that to his knowledge the sd. Dulin has been greatly embarrassed for several years, and is still so.

to pay a debt. 15 Sheep. A part killed for mutton - and a part sold to R. Gillet Jun. for which he paid a part cash, which has been expended in support of family & part in a debt for dressing cloth. 2 mares etc. My son; of whom they were received returned after my first schedule, and has indemnified me; and taken the horses to himself. The other articles mentioned in the first schedule have since been nearly or wholly worn out. And I further state, that since my former schedule, I have become still more feeble & unable to labour, & have not since been able to perform the least labour - that my wife, my son, William, my daughter, Betsey and myself have been sick since that time, so as to require, a great part of the time, the attendance of a physician & great expense of medicine & medical aid: That William & Betsey have since become of age & take care of themselves - that the rest of the family continue to depend on me for support; - that on account of my broken constitution & inability to attend to attend to any kind of business, I have had no means to support my expensive family, and have been constantly becoming more distressed in my circumstances and must soon become chargeable to the town, where I reside, unless I receive the aid of my country. Sworn to & subscribed on the 11th day of December 1823 Before the Court aforesaid, Saml. Swift Clerk

that Wm Lamb the Justice who officiated in taking the deposition of Joshua Howe, because he is certified in the pension office, in the case of Widow Orya and therefore I do not suppose it is necessary. I thank you very much for the ready answer, you have made to my numerous enquiries heretofore, my ignorance of the law is my excuse, in fact, for troubling you so much & part I thus get pay for your troubling me which you doubtles recollect about. (I have reference to my sending you information of the death of pensioners at the time (or after) [illegible] blew up) if you wish less trouble send me the law granting pensions. But seriously if the testimony will answer in this case send her certificate as soon as may be for she is really needy. Could you see the old lady and see with what cautionness she gives her testimony. So afraid that her memory betrays her that she has to qualify almost every thing she says. It would I think make a favourable impression on your as it did certainly on me. In conclusion if there is any failure tell me where it is and instruct me so that I can fix it and oblige. Yours Orlin Lewis Hon. J. L. Edwards Commissioner of Pensions

State of Vermont Rutland County, Ss} I, Joshua Howe, of Benson in the county of Rutland and state of Vermont, of lawful age, being duly sworn, do make oath and say that I am the brother of David Howe, late of Wells in said county, deceased, and that I was acquainted with him from my youth up to the time of his death. I was knowing to his enlisting and being gone from home in the time of the war of the revolution. I was young and therefore did not go, but my brother told me that he had been out in the war. He went first I should think for two or three months. He then enlisted for one year and went away in the spring, and returned in the forepart of winter. He said he had come home on a furlough. He staid through the winter and the next summer at home. He was married to Phebe Cowles in the last of summer or in the fall by Mr. Robbins the minister in Norfolk Connecticut, where we all then resided; and then went into the service again, but how long he was gone I do not know. He purchased, after this and previous to the close of the war, a piece of land in Ballston, New York, and went there to reside and the Tories and Indians came and drove them off. His wife returned to my father's, and I went to help him drive down his cattle, and when opposite to Albany we could see on the other side of the river near Albany some barracks

Wells VT August 18th 1844 Dear Sir Your favour of the 10th has just come to hand and I find on perusal that you have not received my last papers sent you, as at least I infer this, on the account of the claimants name being written on the margin of the printed circular sent me. I sent you on the 15th of April last the certificate of the Comptroller of Connecticut, the affidavits of Joshua Howe, David Lewis & Shubael Lamb and minister. I have been to the records of the post Office in this place & find that they were duly mailed on the same day that I put them int he office, there must be the ones that you have not received for Mrs howes declarations and the deposition of Saml Howe you have acknowledged the receipt of. I thought I would write you and let you know the time that I sent them thinking that perhaps they might have been received and got mislaid in your office & by you knowing the time that I sent them might assist you in making an examination for them as I procured the papers at great expense & trouble. I should be very sorry to have them lost as I think they contained evidence sufficient to procure her pension, judging from the evidence in other cases that was successful. I also wrote int he same letter of the death of widow Nye, by this you may know if they have been received. Also I wished to know if there was a pensioner on the roll who done duty in Capt Stevens company Swifts regiment by the name of Silas Cole. He was out with David Howe & if he was living I wished to find out where he was, providing the evidence sent was not sufficient & as I have received no answer I again render the request. Yours [illegible] Orlin Lewis N. B. Will you let me know if they are not found?

Wells Vermont April 15th 1844 Dear Sir yours of March 14th was duly received for which I was very thankful. You there enquire, "from which of the States did Silas Cole apply and when was he paid as a pensioner" answer he left this part of the country previous to the act of 1832 and it is not know whether he is a pensioner, he lived the last we heard from him at Valley Forge Penn. I have written there but can get no account of him. he was in the service with David Howe and if living would doubtless know all about it, and there is no other living witness known of. You have in your possession the Declaration of Phebe Home. The affidavit of Samuel Home, and I now send you enclosed as corroborative, the certificate of the Comptroller of Connecticut. The affidavit of Joshua Howe of Benson of Shubael Lamb minister of the Gospel. And of David Lewis Esqr of this town, persons of respectability whose word can be depended upon which I hope and trust will be sufficient if not I know not what will be done Next unless Mr Cole should be living and you can inform me of it and where he is. I know I am troublesome but let my Ignorance of the buisness be my excuse. She is unable to employ or pay any one acquainted with the business Yours Truly Orlin Lewis Hon. J.L. Edwards Widow Abigail Nye died Feb 2 1844. Is there no way to obtain the arrears of her pension, only to administer on her estate, which will cost nearly as much as there is due, she has left no heirs or relatives nearer than a Nephew, and no money to pay her funeral charges. Cannot you send an order as other instrument to save this troublesome expence O. Lewis

State of South Carolina Beaufort District St. Helena Parish On this twenty fifth day of October 1849, Before me John M. Baker magistrate of said District, personally appeared Mary Barnwell aged Seventy five years a resident of said district, and doth under oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the provision made by Act of Congress 3d March 1837 granting five years half pay to certain widows, and the act of 3d Feby. 1848 continuing the same for life, viz - That she is the widow of Edward Barnwell who was a Lt. Colonel commanding in the militia of South Carolina in the war of the Revolution, That her husband the said Edward Barnwell entered the service in or about, June 1775 immediately after the breaking out of the war, and the levying of an army in South Carolina by the provincial Congress, which immediately assembled; his commission being among the first issued. Said Edward entered the service as first or second Lieutenant, she cannot say which. He served as such Lieutenant, under the command of Col. Stephen Bull, who was sent in March 1776 to Georgia by the Charleston safety committee. He was acting as first Lieutenant in the company of Cavalry, commanded by his brother, then Captain John Barnwell, when they routed the British on Port Royal Island early in 1779, and served with the same company, raised in Beaufort and the neighbourhood,[neigborhood] until 20th May in that year 1779, when the company, being then under the orders of Captain James Doharty, was surprissed [surprised] by the British at the plantation of Mr Mathers on John's Island, near Charleston, and the whole party either killed or taken prisoners. Deponent's husband was taken to Charleston, and confined aboard the prison ship Packhorse, then lying in the harbour of that city. This vessel was some time after ordered to the North, with the prisoners for the purpose of affecting an exchange. Off the coast of North Carolina Edward Barnwell and his companions, thirty five in number, rose upon the guard, took possession and ran the vessel into Halifax North Carolina. Thence after many hardships, they made their way through North Carolina to ^their several homes. Soon after his return, this deponent's husband was promoted, and continued constantly serving in arms against the enemy until the close of the war, when he had risen by regular promotion to the command of the Beaufort Regiment of Militia - and that since the war, he ever after, enjoyed the title of Colonel. Deponent swears she was married to the said Edward Barnwell on the 29th July seventeen hundred and ninety; consequently before the 1st day of January seventeen hundred and ninety four; and that he died at Beaufort So. Ca. of gout on the 15th Apl. 1808, and that she is still his widow and unmarried, and she refers to the proofs hereto annexed. Mary Barnwell Sworn to before me on the day & year above mentioned. J [illegable] M. Baker Magistrate

Said Edward entered the service as first or second Lieutenant, she cannot say which. He served as such Lieutenant, under the command of Col. Stephen Bull, who was sent in March 1776 to Georgia by the Charleston safety committee. He was acting as first Lieutenant in the company of Cavalry, commanded by his brother, then Captain John Barnwell, when they routed the British on Port Royal Island early in 1779, and served with the same company, raised in Beaufort and the neighbourhood,[neigborhood] until 20th May in that year 1779, when the company, being then under the orders of Captain James Doharty, was surprissed [surprised] by the British at the plantation of Mr Mathers on John's Island, near Charleston, and the whole party either killed or taken prisoners. Deponent's husband was taken to Charleston, and confined aboard the prison ship Packhorse, then lying in the harbour of that city. This vessel was some time after ordered to the North, with the prisoners for the purpose of affecting an exchange. Off the coast of North Carolina Edward Barnwell and his companions, thirty five in number, rose upon the guard, took possession and ran the vessel into Halifax North Carolina. Thence after many hardships, they made their way through North Carolina to ^their several homes. Soon after his return, this deponent's husband was promoted, and continued constantly serving in arms against the enemy until the close of the war, when he had risen by regular promotion to the command of the Beaufort Regiment of Militia - and that since the war, he ever after, enjoyed the title of Colonel. Deponent swears she was married to the said Edward Barnwell on the 29th July seventeen hundred and ninety; consequently before the 1st day of January seventeen hundred and ninety four; and that he died at Beaufort So. Ca. of gout on the 15th Apl. 1808, and that she is still his widow and unmarried, and she refers to the proofs hereto annexed. Mary Barnwell Sworn to before me on the day & year above mentioned. J [illegable] M. Baker Magistrate
