...The deponent was actively engaged with the enemy in this battle and recollects that Col Elias Dayton's Regiment of New Jersey Regulars were in the action after burning the meetinghouse and several private buildings. They commenced their retreat that night to New Brunswick. As Staten Island, lying in New York Bay, stretched along and opposite to that of Middlesex, Essex and Bergen Counties in the State of New Jersey and was constantly occupied by the British troops from the commencement to the close of the war. The patriotic militia of those Counties were detailed by their several Field Officers to perform tours of duty of a month at a time during the greater part of that period, among whom was this deponent often on detail from his Militia Company or at other times frequent as a volunteer and always prompt in case of alarm under the command of some one or other of the Militia Officers of Essex County. After General Howe left New Brunswick, the Tories and disaffected assembled on Staten Island and became, in conjunction with the British Regular force stationed there, very troublesome by the continued inroads and marauding parties they sent out. The deponent was actively employed with other militia, often under different Militia Officers either of his own regiment or of those of the neighboring Counties, in cutting off the communication between the disaffected in the County and the enemy, restraining their plundering parties and capturing provisions intended for their use, one yoke of fat cattle in particular intended for the enemy, he captured himself from one of the disaffected (although his opponent was armed with pistols) and which were confiscated by the legal authority; his activity and vigilance rendered him so obnoxious to the secret adherents of the enemy that he was privately fired at and various opportunities sought by the disaffected and Tories to capture him. These duties, whether as Guard Patrol or in case of alarm, either detached, on detail or acting as volunteer, this deponent directly avers that he performed more or less from the spring of 1776 until the spring of 1782 as his place of nativity and residence was continuous to the lines of the enemy. In the spring of 1778, his company, among whom was himself, commanded by Capt. Thomas Mulford of the Essex County Militia, hired substitutes by a general contribution from among the company and who joined General Washington's Army previous to the Battle of Monmouth. He, among others, remaining on the lines near Staten Island, continued performing different tours of duty more or less during the year and ensuing winter. The Tories and enemy capturing a considerable number of the inhabitants of Essex and the adjoining counties conveyed them to the Sugar House Provost Prison &c. in the City of New York. To check these depredators required considerable vigilance and activity in the militia in which this deponent largely partook. General Washington was encamped during the winter at Middlebrook to the best of his remembrance. In the spring of 1779, this deponent in a company commanded by Capt. Eliakim Little or Thomas Clark of the militia - he cannot at present say which - marched with others in pursuit of the enemy through Newark, Bellville, and Aquacanac [Aquackananonk], where crossing the Passaic River into Bergen County they had a pretty smart skirmish with the enemy at a place called The Cedars, who were compelled to retire to Hackensack. Shortly after his return, he became a substitute for one William Richardson on a secret militia expedition; officers names not recollected except David Thurston, who was adjutant. They marched from Morristown to Whippany, thence to Paramus toward Bergen County but was taken sick and returned home on furlough. Sometime in the summer of this year, a large body of British Regulars and Green Coats (who were Tories) crossed from Staten Island to the Elizabeth Town salt marshes in the night, pressed on to the town where they were met and opposed by a strong militia force under General Wynes. The deponent was in his regiment commanded by Col. Jaques and had a pretty severe skirmish with them when they marched by Newark, crossing the Passaic River into Bergen County, followed and harassed by the militia all the route with considerable loss to the enemy from Bergen. He thinks they recrossed to Staten Island. The Whig Militia of the Counties in New Jersey contiguous to the City of New York and that seaboard at the commencement of the war had formed themselves into a body styling themselves, "Minute Men" who when not on detailed duty as Guard &c. were ever ready to turn out and meet the enemy, night or day. To this body of men this deponent belonged until the cessation of hostilities and marauding parties of the enemy found frequent employment for them in repelling their inroads. In the winter, General Lord Sterling, with a body of regulars and militia provided with artillery, crossed on the ice from Elizabeth Town to Staten Island (this being what is termed the hard winter) for the purpose of attacking the British ports. This deponent, in his company commanded...

...by Capt. Thomas Mulford of the militia, accompanied this expedition. After some slight skirmishing, the enemy abandoned their outposts and retreated to their fortifications at The Narrows, which were deemed too strong to be forced. After burning their barracks at Ryerson's Ferry, the American troops retired, bringing off their captured stores. The troops under General Washington laying at Morristown this winter and in a suffering condition. The deponent voluntarily turned out with his own team and transported forage and provisions raised among the inhabitants by contribution to their relief without receiving, or expecting to receive, any remuneration for the same. Late in the fall previous to this, he crossed with other volunteers under Capt. Nathaniel Fitz Randolph of Middlesex, to the surprise of the British Guard on Staten Island and succeeded in capturing four, the remainder eight made their escape; it being night and they engaged at the moment of surprise in relieving guard. In June 1780, General Kniphausen landed at Elizabeth Town in the night with a large British force and marched with silence towards Morristown, the American Head Quarters. They were discovered by the deponent and others while yet in the town and he lost no time in communicating intelligence of their movements to Col. Elias Dayton of one (of) the New Jersey Regular regiments who was stationed at no great distance and himself joined the assembling militia under the command of Major William Crane, in firing upon and harassing the enemy on their march, who were likewise vigorously opposed by Col. Dayton's Regulars. At Connecticut Farms they were held in cheek by the Continental Troops aided by the militia with a piece of artillery in charge of Captain Eliakim Little, after setting fire to the meetinghouse and more than half of the buildings in the place and with other outrages, shooting Mrs. Caldwell, wife of the Rev'd James Caldwell, the Presbyterian Clergyman and a noted Whig, while her child was in her arms and in her own house. They retreated that night to Elizabeth Town after having sustained a very considerable loss, harassed continually by the militia on their retreat. In this battle he saw Lieut. Moses Ogden of the New Jersey Regulars lying dead in the road, shot thru [through] the head. The enemy fortified in Elizabeth Town where they remained a week, during which time the neighboring militia, among whom was this deponent, were continually employed in harassing their outposts and watching their movements. At the expiration of that time having been reinforced, they once more marched in the night toward Morristown in two divisions, one moving on main direct, the other on the Vauxhall Road, a harassing fire was kept up on them by the militia until their arrival at Springfield where they were met and opposed before and after their entrance into the village by a large regular force, detached by General Washington from Morristown for that purpose. They were commanded by General Green, to the best of this deponent's recollection. This force with the militia checked their further progress and after burning the meetinghouse and nearly every building in the place, they commenced a rapid retreat to Elizabeth Town and thence during the night to Staten Island, harassed by the regulars and militia, their loss was very considerable. This deponent was actively engaged with the enemy during this action and retreat and saw Captain Nathaniel Fitz Randolph of the militia shortly after he was mortally wounded by the enemy, among other regular officers in these engagements, many of whom at this distant day are forgotten, were Col. Elias Dayton of the New Jersey Line, Capt. Henry and Lieutenant Edmund Thomas. During the remainder of the year of 1780 through the course of the year 1781, and especially after the American Army left New Jersey for Yorktown, and in fact until the spring of 1782, this deponent continued to be detailed for duty by his officers, standing guard patrolling and pursuing the Tories and enemy's parties, who were making continual inroads as usual in one of which they burned the meetinghouse, courthouse and other buildings in Elizabeth Town. At other times carrying off some of the best Whig inhabitants or plundering and destroying others so that this portion of New Jersey near their lines was in a continual state of alarm and suffered very severely from their secret predatory excursions, especially those of the Tories, who were well acquainted with the country, keeping the Essex Militia of which this deponent was one active and vigilant. After the spring of 1782, a kind of a cessation of hostilities took place and continued until peace, very much to the relief of the militia and inhabitants. This deponent avers that the foregoing statement contained only some of the most prominent facts relative to his services for the United States during the Revolutionary War, as he was at various times and places too numerous to particularize under some one or other Militia Officer and much oftener with some of his brother militia men engaged with scouting parties of the Tories...

...and enemy, repelling their inroads or in seizing and capturing cattle, provisions &c. destined for the enemy by the disaffected, which were confiscated and cutting off as much as possible all communications with the British lines. And that these duties and fatigues, when not ordered on others by his officers, he was frequent in the performance of, both in the day and night time, from the first landing of the enemy on Staten Island until the cessation of hostilities. He likewise avers that the aggregate time employed by him in performing tours of duty of monthly detail, on guard, garrison duty &c. by command of his regimental officers and in different expeditions, battles, skirmishes &c. with the enemy at various times from the commencement to the close of the Revolutionary War, would considerably exceed two years of active service rendered by him to the United States in the cause of liberty as a soldier. That he was well acquainted with Col. William Washington of the cavalry and Caleb Huet, Joseph Gathen and Daniel Smith, belonging to this corps at one period while quartered in New Jersey, the year he cannot recollect. He was likewise acquainted with Col. Elias Dayton, Col. Matthias Ogden, Col. Barber, Captains Neal, Pratt, Pierson, Jeremiah Ballard, Joseph Bloomfield and Aaron Ogden; both which last have been governors of New Jersey since then, likewise with Lieutenants Edmund Thomas, William Shute, Jonathan Bucastle, Ephraim Whitlock, Shepard Bollock and Capt. Jonathan Dayton, since Speaker of the House of Congress. Many of whom belonged to one or other of the New Jersey Continental Regiments and with most of whom he has been engaged in some one or other engagement with the enemy in New Jersey. They holding as nigh as he can recollect the rank by commission he has affixed to them. Many of their given names at this distance of time he cannot remember. He served under or was well acquainted at that period with General Wyndes, Col. Jaques, Majors Daniel Halsey, Hays, John Craig, William Crane, Captain Benjamin Cory - lieut. afterwards - Capt. Thomas Mulford, Capt. John Scudder, Capt. Thomas Clark, Capt. Jacob Crane, Capt. Anthony Morse, Capt. Brant, Capt. Jonas Wade, Capt. Joshua Horton, Capt. Samuel Meeker of the cavalry, Capt. Eliakim Little of the artillery [crossed out: and] Capt. Matthias Meeker and Lieut Cornelius Williams of the Essex County Militia, Col. Ellis Cook of Morris and Capt. Nathaniel Fitz Randolph of Middlesex, with many others whom he cannot recollect. He was likewise well acquainted at that period with Abraham Clark, one of the Representatives in the Congress and William Livingston, the Patriotic Governor of New Jersey. That at this present time he knows of no surviving witness he can bring to substantiate those services except John Cook, who saw him at the Battle of Springfield in 1780 and whose affidavit of that circumstance is forwarded with this statement. Most of those who served with him or with whom he was acquainted during that arduous struggle for independence being dead, or if living at the present time, are residing in places beyond the knowledge of this deponent. That he has no discharge from the service, it not being deemed requisite nor was one ever demanded. That he continued to reside in Elizabeth Town, County of Essex and State of New Jersey until the year 1821 when he removed to Monroe County and since to Lewiston [Lewistown], Niagara County, State of New York, where he has resided ever since and still continues. That the record of his age from his earliest recollections was entered in his father's Family Bible, a transcript from which a number of years since he carefully entered in his own where it remains among the records of his own family. That he is well acquainted with Major Benjamin Barton, Leonard Sheppard, Isaac Colthan and Lina H. Colvin, Esquire, inhabitants of Lewiston [Lewistown], Niagara County and State of New York, who can testify as to his character for veracity and their belief of his services as a Soldier of the Revolution. He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present and declares that his name is not on the Pension Roll of the Agency of any State. s/ Benj. Williams Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid before me. Sworn to and subscribed this 27th day of August 1832 before me. s/ R. Fleming, First Judge Niagara Common Pleas

...In the month of December he performed a tour of duty for one month at Elizabeth Town point under the command of Capt. Matthias Potter of Connecticut Farms, being drafted to such service, making his whole period of active service under the command of his officers as a private soldier during the year 1778, two months independent of the hiring a substitute to join General Washington, before mentioned. In the year 1779, having joined a Militia Artillery Company under the command of Capt. Thomas Clark of Essex County. In April and May he performed a two months tour of duty as a private in the same, stationed in Elizabeth Town and at the point a greater part of the time, annoying the enemy's vessels and approaches. The latter end of May he marched with this Artillery Company under the command (of) Capt. Clark and the neighboring militia to or near Hackensack in Bergen County where they had a skirmish with the enemy. In July an alarm being given that the Green Coats had crossed from Staten Island, this deponent in the Militia Company of Capt. Thomas Mulford was engaged with them, supported by the neighboring militia, the enemy being very considerable, marched by Newark and Bergen, followed and harassed by the militia. That affair occupied five days of actual service rendered by him as a private soldier. In September he engaged as a substitute for one William Richardson for a month's tour of duty and after performing three weeks service he was taken sick at Paramus and returned on furlough, having withdrawn his name in the fall from the roll of the Artillery Company. In November [crossed out: having been] he was drafted out of his company commanded by Capt. Thomas Mulford, he performed a month's tour of duty under Capt. Jesse Clark in Elizabeth Town and at the point as a private, serving this tour of duty he went with a party of militia under Capt. Nathaniel Fitz Randolph on to Staten Island where they surprised and took part of the British Guard. The whole period of service performed by him as a private soldier under the command of his officers during the year 1779 was three months and five days, independent of the time he served as a substitute for Richardson, as aforesaid. In the year 1780 in January, he being with his company commanded by Capt. Thomas Mulford with other militia companies and Continental Troops, the whole under the command of Lord Sterling, crossed on the see [sea] to the attack of the British posts on Staten Island, which he performed three days of service. In February, he volunteered with his horses and wagon to transport voluntary contributions to the American Army, then in a suffering condition. In the month of March he served one month at Elizabeth Town point under the command of Capt. Matthias Potter of Connecticut Farms, being drafted thereto out of his company. In June, General Kniphausen invaded Essex County, New Jersey, during which time he burned Connecticut Farms Village and Springfield. He, this deponent, was one among the first who discovered and fired upon them in the night after their landing and gave the alarm. He was engaged with them in the battle of Connecticut Farms and a week after in the Battle of Springfield, harassing them both in their advances and retreats and while in their quarters at Elizabeth Town, under the command of Major William Crane, his battalion officer, and Thomas Mulford, his captain. On this service he performed ten days tour of active duty. In October, he served one month at Elizabeth Town point under the command of Capt. John Scudder being, drafted to such tour of duty out of his company, making the whole period of active service performed by him as a private soldier under the command of his officers during the year 1780, two months and thirteen days, independent of the transportation of supplies to the army, before mentioned. In the year 1781 in April, he served one month as a private soldier at Elizabeth Town and the point under the command of Capt. Thomas Mulford, being drafted for such tour of duty out of his company. The American army having left the Jersey's for Yorktown, the duties and vigilance of the Essex Militia became more severe and accordingly he performed in September and October, a six weeks tour of duty at Elizabeth Town and the point as a private soldier under the command of Capt. Benjamin Williams of Elizabeth Town, being drafted to such tour of duty out of his company commanded by Capt. Thomas Mulford, making the whole period of active duty performed by him as a private soldier under the command of his officers during the year 1781, two months and two weeks. In the spring of 1782, a cessation of hostilities took place. That he, always during the war belonged, when not on detail as draft to Capt. Thomas Mulford's Company of Essex County Militia in the regiment commanded by Col. Jaques Major Daniel Halsey and William Crane, except in the beginning of the war. Capt. Benjamin Cory commanded the same company and in 1779 he belonged for a few months to the Artillery Company of Capt. Thomas Clark of the same regiment. That the different tours of duty performed by him as a private were under the officers, as nigh as he can recollect before mentioned, who either belonged to his regiment commanded by Col. Jaques or to that of Col. Samuel Potter of Westfield, Majors John, Craig and Hays of the same County under the command of all which field officers he has served. That he has mentioned in the former declaration, to which this is an amendment, the continental and militia officers with whom he...

State of New York Niagara County// I, Cornelius Mars, a Clergyman residing in Lewiston township and County of Niagara aforesaid, do hereby certify that I am well acquainted with Benjamin Williams, who has subscribed and sworn to the foregoing declaration and a former one to which this is an amendment made and sworn to by him the Twenty seventh of August last past, and that I have been acquainted with him fifty years past while residing in Elizabeth Town, Essex County, State of New Jersey. That I believe him to be Seventy two years of age. That he has ever been reputed and believed in his neighborhood in the State of New Jersey where he resided for a great number of years to have been a Soldier of the Revolution and I, the said Cornelius Mars, being now Sixty three years of age and born in the State of New Jersey, was well acquainted with many of the events and most of the officers set forth in the foregoing declaration and do believe the said Benjamin Williams to have been a Soldier of the Revolution as he has set forth and a person of truth and veracity. s/ Cornelius Mars Sworn and subscribed the Twenty eighth day of November A.D. 1832 before me. s/ R. Fleming, First Judge Niagara Common Pleas State of New York Niagara County// On this Twenty eighth day of November A.D. 1832, personally appeared before me, Robert Fleming, First Judge of the Court of Common Pleas for the County and State aforesaid, Benjamin William, the within named applicant and it satisfactorily appearing that he is unable to appear in Open Court on account of bodily infirmity. I hereby declare my opinion after the investigation and putting the interrogatories prescribed by the War Department and the answers to which are embodied in the within declaration. That he, the said Benjamin Williams, was a Revolutionary Soldier as he states. And I, the said Robert Fleming, First Judge as aforesaid, do further certify that Cornelius Mars, who has subscribed and sworn to the preceding certificate is a reputable clergyman residing in Lewiston township, County of Niagara and State of New York and that he is a credible person and his statement entitled to full credit. s/ R. Fleming, First Judge Niagara Common Pleas State of New York Niagara County// I, Henry Catlin, Clerk of the County and of the Court of Common Pleas in and for the County and State aforesaid, do hereby certify that Robert Fleming, before whom the foregoing declaration and certificate in the case of Benjamin Williams for a pension were sworn to and subscribed is First Judge of the Court of Common Pleas in and for the County of Niagara and State of New York and that his signature annexed to the declaration, deposition and certificate aforesaid is the genuine signature of the said Robert Fining, First Judge as aforesaid. And further that I have connected this declaration with a former one made by the said Williams the Twenty seventh day of August last past with the certificate of the said Robert Fleming and the depositions of Benjamin Barton, Isaac Colt Jr., Zina A. Colvin, Esq., and Leonard Shepard with my certificate annexed together with the deposition of John Cook and that of Cornelius Mans accompanied with the proper certificates of the said Robert Fleming, First Judge as aforesaid, and myself. All which I have joined together with piece of ribbon and sealed the ends thereof with my Seal of Office. - As witness my hand and Seal of Office this Fifteenth day of December A.D. 1832 at Lockport. s/ Henry Catlin, Clerk

State of New York Renselear County Fs. Jonathan Rouse of the Town of Northumberland in the County of Saratoga, being duly sworn doth depose and say, that he is now eighty one years olde; that he, aeforent from the time he was three or four years old while he was about eighteen years of age resided in the Town of North East in the County of Dutchess in the State of New York at which time he removed to the now town of Pittstown in the County of Rensselaer, where he resided until five or six years ago; This actionent further pays that at the time of his first recollection and when he resided in the Town of North East, in said County of Dutchess, he became acquainted with James Newcomb once a resident of that Town are confereed said acquaintence once intimately with said James Newcomb until the day of his death which took palce in the Town of Pittstown aforesaid. And his aeponent further says, that is the years 1778 & 1779. We said James Newcomb was in the service of the United States as a soldier that the late James Newcomb was married in the Law town of North East in the County Dutchess in year 1778. To Judith Newcomb by the Reverand Norse Bullock a Baptist Clergyman as he verily believes -- that this deponent was known he said Judith Newcomb the widow of the late James Newcomb; and that she is the same identical person , who was the wife of said James Newcomb when was in the Service of the united as before mentioned and that he is the identical James Newcomb mentioned in the Certificate of the Comptroller of the State of New York, and the department was in the army with the late James Newcomb after his removal to the said Town of Pittsford where he died - and further lays not. Jonathan Rouse Sworn to this this day of September 1842 before me Archibald Bull Judge Rens. Co. County - I am well acquainted with the above names Jonathan Rouse He is a man of strait truth and veracity - Sept 3rd 1842 Archibald Bull Judge Rens B County + Comptroller

Kentucky 19437 Lawrence Bishop of Bullett Co in the State of Kent who was a pr in the Co commanded by Captain Brush of the regt commanded by Col - in the Penn line for 6 mos Inscribed on the Roll of Kent at the rate of 20 Dollars - Cents per annum to commence on the 4th day of March, 1831. Certificate of Pension issued the 9 Sept and sent to G. T. Pope Shepherdsville Arrears to the 4th of Sept 50.00 Semi-anl. allowance ending March 10.00 60.00 {Revolutionary Claim, Act June 7, 1832.} Recorded by Danl Boyd Clerk Book E Vol. 7 Page 4

consisted in guarding the frontiers from the incursions and depredations of the Indians. Did you ever receive a discharge from the service and if so by whom was it signed and what has become of it. Answer for the first Tour of duty I received a discharge in writing from my Capt Henry Rush. For the second hour from Capt Thomas Davy and for the Third from Capt George Inlows. I do not now know what he become of them – State the names of persons to whom you are here in your present to as to your neighbourhood and who can testify as to your character for veracity and good behavior & your services as a soldier. Answer I am known to Austin Hall, Joseph Saunders Henry Sousley & Richard P Simmons they can as to my character for veracity & good behaviour & Henry Sousley as to my services. There is no Clergyman residing in my neighbourhood and I am not able to go where I could procure procure the Certificate of one Lawrence Bishop his mark Subscribed & Sworn to the day & year aforesaid I Henry Sousley a Citizen of Bullitt County State of Kentucky do certify that Lawrence Bishop who has sworn to & subscribed the foregoing declaration did go out as a substitute the first two Tours he stated in said Declaration and that he went out & served with the said Bishop on the third Tour & served the time as therein stated Henry Sousley his mark

We Henry Crist and George F. Pope Residing in Bullitt County State of Kentucky do hereby Certify that we are well acquainted with Lawrence Bishop who has subscribed & swore to the foregoing Declaration That we believe him to be Sixty nine years of age and we believe him to be a man of Veracity --- Sworn & subscribed to the day and year aforesaid H Crist Geo F. Pope And the Court do hereby declare their opinion after the investigation of the matter and after putting the interrogatories prescribed by the War Department that the above named applicant was a Revolutionary Soldier and served as he states and the Court further certifies that it appears to them that Henry Sousley, H. Crist and Geo F. Pope who have signed the preceding certificate are residents in Bullitt County Kentucky and are credible persons and that their statements are entitled to credit I Noah C. Summers Clerk of the Court of Bullitt County Kentucky do hereby certify that the foregoing contains the Original proceedings in the matter of the application of Lawrence Bishop for a pension In Testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand and Seal of Office this 17th day of September 1832. Noah C. Summers CBCC

Jacob Bishop, W.3381 BAJ/MCS Mr. Floyd G. Hoenstine Registrar, Veterans Graves Office of County Commissioners Hollidayburg, Pennsylvania Dear Sir: Reference is made to your letters requesting information in regard to Revolutionary War soldiers, Harry or Henry Bennett, Jacob Bishop, William Laird and Daniel Moore. The Revolutionary War records of this officed fail to afford any information to the Harry or Henry Band Daniel Moore described by you, or any Willard Laird. The data which followed were obtained from papers on file in the pension claim, W. 3381, based upon the Revolutionary War service of the only Jacob Bishop of Pennsylvania that is found in the Revolutionary War records of this office. The date and place of birth and names of parents of Jacob Bishop were not given. He first enlisted when he was about sixteen or seventeen years of age but his friends obtained his release on account of his youth. He enlisted in the summer of 1776, at Hagerstown, Maryland, as a private in Captain William Heyser's company in Colonel Haussegger's German Regiment and served three years, during which time he was in the battles of White Plains, Trenton, Princeton, Brandywine, Germantown and Monmouth and was wounded in the foot in one of the engagements. Jacob Bishop married Deceber25, 1781, Mary Powel. The license for marriage was obtained at Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, and the ceremony was preformed by Joseph Powel, Minister of the Gospel. It was not shown that the minister was related to Mary Powel.

Jany. 23 1939 State of Maryland Washington County I David Troxell now in my 79th years of age and at this time a resident of Washington County Maryland personally appeared before me the subscriber one of the Justices of the Peace for the sate of Maryland in and for said County, and made oath on the Holy Evangely of Almighty God, deposeth and saith that he was well acquainted with Jacob Bishop, and that he Jacob Bishop enlisted sometime in the month of June July or August 1776 in Hagerstown, Washington County Maryland, under Capt William Heyser, a common soldier for the term of three years, and that he served out the whole of said term. Capt WIlliam Heyser was attached to the German Regiment Sworn Before Jacob Kausler and of the same day appeared David Harry in the 79th year of his age and made oath on the Holy Evangely of Almighty God, and deposeth and saith, that he was well acquainted with Jacob Bishop, late of Bedford County did that he said Jacob Bishop enlisted under Capt William Heyser in the year 1776. attached to the German Regiment commanded by Col. Houseer, said Bishop enlisted for three years and that said BIshop did serve out the whole term of three years, this deponent saith that the enlistment took place in Hagerstown Washington County Maryland. Sworn before Jacob Hausser State of Maryland Washington County to wit I hereby certify that Jacob Hausler Gentleman before whom the aforegoing affidavit was made and whose name appeared thereto was at the time of the taking thereof and is now a Justice of the Peace of the State of Maryland in and for Washington County duly commissioned and qualified and to all his as to assail full faith and credit is due as well in Court of Justice as (illegible) In testimony whereof I hereunto subscribe my name and affix the seal of Washington County Court this 23rd day of January 1829. O H Williams Washington County Court

1-Rev MH HENSCHEL H. ROSE W. KENNETH BARNES LAW OFFICES ROSE & BARNES HOME SAVINGS BANK BUILDING FAIRMONT, WEST VIRGINIA September 24, 1921. Commissioner of Pensions, Washington, D. C. Dear Sir:- Will you kindly forward to me a statement of the miltiary record of my great-grandfather Jacob Bishop, a revolutionary soldier, with such personal data as your office contains . From Maryland Archives XVIII, at page 191, I find his name given as a member of the "German Regiment", discharged July 26, 1779. At page 264 of the same volume, he is listed as a private in the muster roll of Capt. William Heyser's Company of the "German Regiment" (Maryland troops), under date of October 23, 1776. At page 265 of the same volume, he is given as a private for the months of July, August, September and October, 1779, in the pay roll of Lt. Col. Welton's Company of the "German Regiment" of the Continental Forces of the United States, commanded by Lt. Col. Ludwick Weltner, with the notation that he was discharged July 26, 1779, Jacob Bishop is supposed to have been born in Hagerstown, or at least to have lived there at the time of his enlistment. He died during the year 1816, or prior thereto shortly, leaving a widow whose maiden name was Mary Church. For this search and report I shall be glad to pay your reasonable charges, and will send check in advance, if advised as to the amount. Very truly yours, [signature] H H Rose H. H. Rose, HHR/RH [circular stamp:] U.S. PENSION OFFICE D SEP 26 1921

W Before the subscriber, a Justice of peace in & for said County, personally appeared the Reverend Clifford S. Arms, well known to me personally to be a man of truth & of unblemished reputation, & also known to me as the Pastor of the Presbyterian Christ in Madison, formerly called Bottlehill, who having by me been duly sworn according to law, declare as follows, viz: I am the stated Pastor of the Presbyterian Church & Congregation in Madison, formerly called Bottle hill, of which congregation the Revd Mr Bradford was the stated Pastor during some part of the revolutionary war, & after the conclusion of peace. The words of said Church & Congregation, and in my keeping as Pastor thus, & I hereby certify that I verily believe there are no books or records of any marriages which were solemnized by Revd Mr Bradford, or by any of his predecision in the Ministry in said Congregation. I have made diligent search & inquiry, & find none, & believe that none such exist of a date earlier than the year 1795, at which time a record of Marriages was begun by Rev. [strikethrough] Asa Hillyer D.D., then Pastor of said Church. Sworn & subscribed at Madison, this 14th day of August, 1838. Before me, Eliah Ward J. P. Clifford S Arms I hereby certify that the substitution of the name, "Asa Hillyer D. D. for that of Matthew La Rue Perrin, was made, before signing & administering the oath Elijah Ward J.P.

State of New Jersey, Morris County Before the Subscriber, a Justice of peace in said County personally appeared, Major Luke Miller, an aged & highly respected man, & a [unclear] of the revolution, well known to me as a man of truth & of unblemished character, who being by me duly sworn according to law, declared as follows - I am 78 years of age, & if my life shall be spared till the 8th September next, I shall then be 79. I was a militia soldier in the war of the revolution, & was well acquainted in the family of Isaac Winams, a neighbour of my father, all living in the village called Bottle hill, now called Madison [underlined]. Isaac Winam had a daughter, Martha, who was often called Patty [underlined], & she was about my age. We grew up from childhood to adult age, near to each other. The then said Martha, married to George Emmel, a Guman by birth, & who had been in the Pennsylvania line of the Revolutionary Army, & after marriage with Miss Winam, settled in Morris town & followed till near his death, the business of a [unclear] maker & hair duper. They were married by Revd. Ebenzer Bradford, then Pastor of the Presbyterian Church in Bottle hill, in the spring season of the year 1782, & I think it was in April, as to the precise month or day, I cannot speak with certainty. I was present at their wedding, & was one with them at the many making & the dance. I have know George Emmel & Martha Emmel, to his death, & his widow to this day. They raised a large family of daughters, & two sons, & have always been respected by their neighbours. He died in 1826, as I believe, & she remains his widow to this day, as I believe. Sworn & subscribed at Morristown, this 25th of August, 1838. Elijah Ward J.S. Luke Miller

State of New York Montgomery County I Abraham Van Horne late Pastor of the Reformed Dutch Church at Caughnawaga and now the actual keeper of the church record do hereby certify that I have examined the same and do there find that Nicholas Quackenboss and Magdaline Collier was married on the 8th day of April 1777 And I further certify that I have known the said Magdalin to have been the wife of the said Nicholas for forty years years and that she is now his widow and has never been married since his death Abraham Van Horne J.D. M.

State of New York County of Montgomery On this 24th day of May A.D. AD 1852 before me John Everson a Justice of the Peace in and for said county personally came Abraham A. Van Horn, a resident of the town of Mohawk in said County, who being duly sworn according to law, Deposeth and saith that he is sixty two years of age. that he has resided in said Town of Mohawk fifty Eight years,- That from his earliest recollection he was well acquainted with Nicholas Quackenbush deed the husband of the late Magdalen Quackenbush of the Town of Glen in said County. That the said Nickolas Quackinbush was usually called" Quackenbush That the name was variously written "Quackenbush Quackenboss, but that he knows that both are the same name, This deponent further saith that he is a son of the Rev. Abm Van Horn decd for many years Pastor of the Reformed Protestant Dutch Church of Caughnawaga in said County of Montgomery, and that he is well acquainted with the hand writing of his father, the said Abm Van Horn, and that he verily believes that the certificate or Receipt issued to the said Nicholas Quackinbush for a church pew bearing date of December 28th 1799 and signed by the said Abm Van Horn, which is hereunto attached is Genuine. Abm Alan Horne Subscribed & Sworn to before me this 26th day of May 1852 John Everson Justice of the peace

TO ALL TO WHOM THESE PRESENTS SHALL COME, THE MINISTER, El- DERS and DEACONS of the REFORMED PROTESTANT DUTCH CHURCH OF CAUGH- NAWAGA, in the County of MONTGOMERY, Send GREETING: NOW YE, that we the said Minister, Elders and Deacons , for the consideration of twenty two shillings of lawful money of the state of New-York, to us in hand paid by Nicholas Quackenbush the receipt whereof we do hereby acknowledge , HAVE given and granted, and by these presents, do give and grant to the said Nicholas Quackenbush set in the Pew Number 13 on the selling the fourth Seat. in the Church aforesaid. TO HOLD, to the said Nicholas Quackenbush his heirs and assigns, for ever; subject to the Rules, Orders and Regulations of the Church aforesaid. IN TESTIMONY whereof, we have caused our said Minister to set his hand to these Presents, and our common Seal, to be hereunto affixed, this 28th day of December 1799 Abm Van Horne

Declaration In order to obtain pension under the act of July 29th 1848 passed by Congress for the benefit of certain widows &c. State of Vermont Bennington Count ss.} On the 1st day of May AD 1849 personally appeared before me one of the Judges in and for the County in and for the County of Bennington aforesaid Jemima Hamilton of the town of Sandgate, aged 74 years and upwards who being first duly sworn according to law doth on her oath make the following declaration in order to obtain Pension under said act as passed by Congress as aforesaid on the 29th day of July 1848 provisions made for the benefit of certain such widows as said declarant and all other acts connected in explanation thereof. That she is now the widow of James Hamilton who was a pensioner of the United States at the rate of $40 dollars per annum when he died and who died at Sandgate where I now reside in said county of Bennington and State of Vermont aforesaid in the 25th day of February AD 1824: and I this declarant was lawfully married to the said James Hamilton aforesaid on the 8th day of December AD 1796 before Revd Wm Perry a Minister of the Church of England at Newtown in the county of Fairfield in the State of Connecticut and that she this said declarant is still single and unmarried and is now the widow of James Hamilton aforesaid and that after her marriage she lived in the said Newton aforesaid and moved from this place to the said town of Sandgate in the year 1797 the year after her said marriage to the said James Hamilton, and that she and her said Husband said James Hamilton have resided here in sd Sandgate together up to the death of her aforesaid husband and this declarant

State of Vermont} County of Bennington} Ss Personally appeared before me Horace Hurd a Justice of the peace of the Town of Sandgate in and for the County of Bennington Zada Thomas a Resident of said town of Sandgate aforesaid and being duly sworn before me does testify and say that she is well acquainted with James Hamilton and Jemima Hamilton his widow that said Deponent resided in Connecticut near said James Hamilton and said Jemima, and had an invitation to their wedding and witnessed the marriage of said James Hamilton & Jemima Gilbert. they were duly and lawfully married before Rev'd Perry a minister of the Church of England in the town of Newtown in the Cunty of Litchfield and State of Connecticut where Jemima and said deponent resided there and said deponent moved from that place to said Sandgate about forty years ago near said James Hamilton and was at the Funeral of said James Hamilton who died on the 25th day of February 1834 and left his wide said Jemima a widow and she the said Jemima is single and is not the widow of said James Hamilton Deceased. and says that James Hamilton aforesaid was a pensioner of the United Stated at the time of his death and that they were duly and lawfully married in the presence of this deponent as aforesaid before Rev'd Perry at said town of Newtown and that she bore the maiden name of Jemima Gilbert before her marriage to said James Hamilton aforesaid this deponent has always known said Jemima said widow of James Hamilton.

State of Vermont Bennington County ss personally appeared before me Horace Hurd a Justice of the peace for the Town of Sandgate in & for said County of Bennington Polly Hurd of said Town and County being duly sworn according to Law Deposeth and says that she is sister to James Hamilton of said Sandgate who was a Pensioner of the United States at the time of his death he died in said Town of Sandgate aforesaid on the 25th day of February 1834 and left his wife Jemima a widow. said James Hamilton my Brother was duly and Lawfully married to Jemima Galbert in the Town of Newtown in Litchfield County in the State of Vermont before Revd M Perry a Minister of the Church of England on the 9th day of December A.D. 1796 Deponent says she was present and witnessed their their marriage and Deponant says that said Jemima the said widow of James Hamilton aforesaid resides near her and is still single and unmarried and continues to be the widow of her brother said James Hamilton aforesaid and that said James and Jemima have ted together in all the relations of husband and wife up to the death of said James Soon after their marriage they moved to this place to said Sandgate )and this Deponent also), and have always resided near each other and further this Deponent saith not Polley Hurd [signature] subscribed and sworn before me this 9th day of September A.D. 1848 and I certify that said Polley Hurd is a Credible witness Horace Hurd Justice of the Peace

State of Vermont County of Bennington ⎬ In order to obtain Pension under the act passed by Congress Feby 2nd 1848 On the 9th day of September A.D. 1848 personally appeared before me Horace Hurd a Justice of the peace in the Town of Sand Gate in said County of Bennington and State of Vermont aforesaid Jemima Hamilton a resident of said Town of Sand Gate who being first duly sworn according to Law doth on her oath make the following Declaration in order to obtain Pension from the United States which she is entitled to under an act and existing acts passed by Congress on the first day of July 1848 for the benefit and provisions for such widows and such cases That she is the widow of James Hamilton Deceased who was a pensioner at the time and day of his death at the rate of forty Dollars per Annum and who died at or in the said Town of Sand Gate aforesaid on the 25th day of February 1834 and as this Declarant was duly and Lawfully Married to said James Hamilton on the 8th day of of December 1796 before Rev Mr Perry a Minister of the Church of England at Newtown in the County of Litchfield, State of Connecticut and Declarant says said Jemima is still single and is the widow of said James Hamilton her Deceased husband and that after her marriage to said James Hamilton the lived in said Newtown short time but soon after moved to Sandgate where she now resides and where they lived when her said Husband died and Declarant says that before her Marriage to said James Hamilton she bore the maiden name of Jemima Gilbert and Declarant says that her said Husband James Hamilton died at Sand Gate aforesaid in said County of Bennington on the 25th day of February 1834 as aforesaid and that she this Declarant was duly and Lawfully Married to said James Hamilton her Deceased husband aforesaid on the 8th day of December 1776 as aforesaid

State of Maryland, Baltimore City Ss: On this 21st day of August, 1846, before me, the subscriber, a justice of the peace for the state of Maryland & for said city [following struck out: ; and md.] personally appeared, the Reverend John Healey, minister of the Baptist Church, aged eighty-two years, & solemnly, sincerely and truly affirmed and declared, That he was in timately acquainted with Henry Green and Elizabeth Green, his wife for about forty years, all of which time they were exemplary mem bers of the Baptist Church; that she is a member at this time; and being informed that said Elizabeth Green widow of said H. Green has applied for a pen sion for the Revolutionary services of her said husband, of the United States Government; I take pleasure in saying said Elizabeth Green is worthy of full credit and belief; as I sincerely believe her husband also was a man of truth and integ rity. During all the time I have known said Green and wife they resided where [begin underline] she does now,[end underline] in Baltimore County, near Randallstown in said state. And I have no doubt her said husband, Henry Green rendered the services for which his said widow now claims a pension. Declared and affirmed before me and also subscribed and sealed John Healey [word Seal encircled] Edw. J. Peters J.P.

State of New York County of Dutchess Town of Stanford, J. Luman Burtela of the town of Stanford [formerly called Galeed Bhor Lotte Precinct] in said County of Dutchess king duly sworn deposes and says that he is sixty three years of age and is Elder of the Raphael church in the town of Stanford in the Neighborhood of Coldspring in said county & state that he has made diligent search for a record of the marriage of James Newcomb and Judith Newcomb but cannot find any and further says that there are no records of the said marriage to be found in the said church records, and further his definement with that he was formerly acquainted with Elder Comer Bullock, that he deceased in the year 1812, that he was a minister in the same church where the definement is elder, as he has been informed and virily believes, and also was informed by said Elder Bullock that he presided in the same church as early as the year.... certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War", passed on the 18th day of March 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property, or securities, contracts, or debts, due to me; not have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. 1 Cart, two old ploughs, one case of draws, one trunk, one old comb, two old Spinning Wheels, 1 old brass kettle, 1 pot, 1 kettle, 1 tea kettle, knives & forks, crockery ware (small lot) two chairs, two old grass scythes, 1 pair horse traces, 1 old sleigh harness, two axes, two hoes, two forks, 1 old saddle, 1 small grind stone, one old hand saw, 1 auger, 1 hammer, 1 chisel, seven old cider barrels, one barrow, one heifer, one calf, one hog - My family consists of myself, my wife aged fifty eight years both of much impaired in our constitutions, my wife is not able to perform the necessary work of the house and I am compelled to higher a servant made - my son Jonathan Fox lives with me who is a cripple in one of his hands and of seventeen years of age able to perform some service and my circumstances are such that I am unable to support myself without the assistance of publick or private charity - John Fox

[this page of a 3-page letter is folded a bit on the right side so some letters/words may be missing] If you consider it necessary to examine for yourself I presume that the schedule of John [Fox] together with the statement of his property + [and] circumstances may be found in your Secretaries [secretary's] office I have at my own option writen [written] this as my husband is more advanced in years + [and] not so capable of writing as myself but he acquised [acquiesced?] in what I have writen [written] If you dear sir should not think it consistant [consistent] to grant any relief, an unfortunate soldier who served eight months in the first year of the war + [and] five in the second entered the service again 1777 [?] + [and] served his Country the three succeeding years + [and] underwent all the privations + [and] hardships which the calamitous + [and] embarrassed state of the Country then imposed on the suffering soldier that eventually lost almost all his wages must with his wife + [and] family content themselves to spend their few remaining days in wretchedness + [and] want. I assure you Dear sir that nothing but extreme embarrassment could have induced me in so low condition to address one so elevated in office as the chief Magistrate of the States. The result I cheerfully submit to the superindentence of an all wise Providence Accept Dear sir the assurences [assurances] of my high consideration + [and] respect Sarah Fox Hon. James Munrow

Vermont Wm Larrabee priv 1 yr in 1776 1 Sched. dated July 1820 a life lease of 60 acres of land - 1 mare 1 Cow 1 Colt 2 Heifers 2 Hogs & 1 Sheep valued by Court at $200 No debts given Sched; under act Mar 1823 dated 7th May 1823 [Note that text on the left is worn away] Life lease in 60a Land "fencing Rotten & Land lies a common he being unable to keep it fenced & cleared." Worth as he says " nothing of any consequence" 1 four year old colt 1 Cow, 1 Heifer & 5 Sheep bought with Pension money valued by Court to be $58.00 accounts for the decrease of property &c [In pencil:] file Mch 20 [Note that text on the bottom of page is worn away] died Bull & 1 Hog killed & consumed in family Claimant aged 68 ys a farmer unable to work in consequence of a lameness in both knees, totally Blind in one eye & almost blind in the other & very deaf, Wife 59 ys very sickly, obliged to hire a person to take care of her- Seth Witman Esq St. Albans Vt Let. to William Bridges (widow) February 4, 1840.

[crossed out, illegible] STATE OF VERMONT Franklin County Supreme Court Jany Term 1821 Franklin County, ss on this First day of February 1821 personally appeared in open Court, being the Supreme Court, for the County of Franklin State of Vermont and a Court of Record for said [inserted, two words:] State and County. William Larrabee aged 65 years, resident in Berkshire in said County, who being duly sworn by affiavit [text written in margin, missing] according to law, doth on his [inserted, two words:] of affirmation that he served in the revolutionary war, as follows: -- I enlisted in the year 1776 for one year in Capt Easterbrooks company in Col Beedles Regiment afterward commanded by Col Wait I served a full year & was left sick at Mount Independence and had no written discharge my Original declaration was dated April 23, 1818 & my Pension Certificate is numbered 14983 And I do solemnly [crossed out:] swear affirm, that I was a resident citizen of the United States, on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary war,” passed on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities , contracts, or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed, It will appear from my declaration taken on the 11th of July 1820 that I have a life lease of 60 acres of land in Berkshire aforesaid then had one French mare. one cow. one two year old Colt. two year olds one of them a heifer and the other, a Bull two hogs & one sheep the whole was valued by the Court at two hundred dollars. I now have one old cow one two year old heifer one small very poor old French mare. one small 2 year Colt 2 Small Pigs and one Sheep I have also a few articles of house hold furniture very old and of very little value not worth naming, my cow & heifer & the greater part of my mare. I paid for out of the savings of my pension as I could not live comfortably [The bottom part of the page is missing]

New Haven March 12, 1838 J. Colt Esq Dear Sir yours of 2d was recd in due course & would have been some answered but for my confinement to the House --- you will refer to my letter I think you will not find the word West Haven in it-- In my researches I ascertained that Mr Edwards was the Pastor of the White Haven society at ┃ the time of your Mother Marriage. He was settled in 1768- since I see yours of 2d inst I have had the whole records & the files examined & there is not a Marriage recorded from the time Mr. Edwards was settled to the present time nor is there any on file - The Town Clerk informed me that it had been the practice for some Clergyman to hand in Marriages for record, but Mr Edwards had never done it in a single instance- The Church over which Mr Edwards was settled was organized from the 1st Congregational Church in this Town & was called the White Haven Society-- subsequently there was some difficulty in the Society & a part of the members seceded & formed a society called the Fair Haven Society, neither of which flourished much & both having become destitute of Pastor, a proposition was made to unite which was agreed to under the name of the United Society, which still continues-- For the above information I am indebted to Deacon Bostwick of said United Society who saw the necessity of your having the testimony & consequently has been very thorough in the search-- I offered to pay him, but he would not take any thing I do not think there is any record of your Father Mother Marriage in this City. Mr Lyman says she has often heard her husband tell of in going to call the minister to perform the marriage ceremony & that he was present, & that Mr & Mrs Rice were sent for. You can judge whether such testimony would be of any use - she has examined Mr. Lymans papers for the purpose of finding something that might be of use to you & has found a letter written by your father just before the close of the revolutionary war to his

[Text, top five lines, is a repeat of the previous page's last five lines] by the Court at two hundred dollars. I now have one old cow one two year old heifer one small very poor old French mare one small year Colt, a small Pigs and one Sheep, I have also a few articles of house hold furniture very old and of very little value not worth naming, my cow my heifer & the greater part of my mare paid for out of the savings of my pension as I could not live comfortably without these creatures. I am by occupation a farmer but am unable to do any kind of Labour. _ I am entirely blind with one eye and can see but little with the other and have reason to fear that I shall in a short time be wholly blind I am also very deaf, & by reason of a wound in one of my knees I am not able to walk without a crutch or staff & I have reason to fear that my lameness is permanently seated in my knee- I am still owing [inserted:] for part of my mare I am indebted in the whole between thirty & forty dollars and have no means of paying my debts without distressing myself & family. one of my sons owes me, Sixty dollars but he is poor & not able to labour & I have no reason to expect he will be able to pay me my wife is 58 years of age & is not able to do much work. I have no children that live with me_ William Larabee Affirmed [crossed out:] Sworn to and declared on the First day of February 1821 Before the Court Attest Horace Janes Clerk STATE OF VERMONT. Franklin COUNT, ss. Horace Janes Clerk of the Supreme Court , do hereby certify that the foregoing oath and the schedule thereto annexed, are truly copied from the record of said court; and I do further certify, that it is the opinion of the said court that the total amount in value of the property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule, is Land fifty dollars & Personal property seventy six dollars 50 cents amounting in the whole to one hundred twenty six dollars and 50 cents. In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and affixed the seal of the said court, on this 9th day of February 1821 Horace Janes Clerk.

& by me subscribed - I have a life lease of Sixty acres of poor land in Berkshire about thirty acres of of which has been cleared but again running over with Brush & briars & the fences nearly all rotten down & the land lies Common as I am not able to keep it Cleared & fenced so that I get nothing from it of any consequence One Small 4 year old Colt_ that I bought when a yearling with Savings of my Pension_ 1 Cow & 1 heifer that I purchased with the Savings of my Pension 5. Sheep that I bought with Pension Money - as could Support my family better with the use of these_ Creatures than with the Money they cost - 1 hog - I have no farming tools - or any household furniture - that are worth naming (Except a very little bedding) I presume the whole of my furniture & tools would not sell for one dollar. Wm Larrabee That since the Exhibition of my first Schedule the following Changes have been made in my property (to wit) my old French Mare is dead - my two year Old Bull I killed for the use of my family - & my hog is killed & eat up - I am by occupation a farmer but by Reason of a lameness in both my knees, & being Intirly blind with one eye & almost blind with the other & very deaf- I am not able to do anything for a Support & it was with great difficulty I got to St Albans to make this Declaration. I have no family to support or to help me to a Support Except my wife Amy aged 59 years who is very feeble & Sickly & I have been obliged to hire a person for along time to take care of her-- Wm Larrabee Sworn to & declared on this 7th day of May 1823 before the Court Attest. J Janes Register I Jonathan Janes Register of the Probate Court for the District of Georgia County of Franklin & State of Vermont do hereby certify that it appears to the satisfaction of the Court that the said William Larrabee did serve in the Revolutionary war as stated in the preceding declaration against the Common Enemy for the Term of one year under one engagement on the Continental Establishment I also Certify that the foregoing affirmation & this Schedule thereto annexed are truly copied from the Records of the said Court & I do further certify that it is the opinion of the said Court that the Total amount in Value of the Property Exhibited in the aforesaid Schedule is fifty eight

State of So Carolina Chester District Robert Black of said District appeared and made oath that the origin of the Mortgage given by his Faher James Black to him on the 23rd day of February 1819 was that he the said James was justly indebted to him & a number of others, but the sum he cannot now exactly state, some payments he grants having been made to him, but that there is yet due to him about Twenty-Six Dollars with Interest. Another intention of the said Morrgage was that whereas it contains 98 acres of Land, forty two of which was claimed by a Mr. Wm. McDaniel which his father thought an unjust claim, & intended to go to Law for it & that he the Mortgagee intended to assist him. But for want of money and other embarrassing circumstances it was given out, and the Land finally lost. Fifty Six acres remained which is very poor & mostly worn out. That the Black House, the 15 head of Sheep mentioned in the mortgage are all dead. The Bay Colt, which was a Mare & the mother of the three years old Filly mentioned in the Schedule. Some of the cattle and other articles have been disposed of. So that very little of the original mortgaged property now remains, and from his father's excessive poverty and distressing circumstances in his old age, he never intends to enforce the said Mortgage at least while he lives, and that the foregoing paper is a true copy of the Same. Also that he has reason to believe, and does verily believe, that he the said James Black is in more debt than all the property he is possessed of will pay. And from his inability to labour is making little or no support for the present year. Robert Black His mark Sworn and Subscribed this 17th October 1827 Before William Anderson J.Q.

Hebron September 10th 1836 One Beloved Children We your Aged Parents through the goodness of Almighty God enjoy as good health as can [illegible] I never enjoyed better health-- Some time since had the dropsie [sic] in my legs they swelled considerable. I did not exercise but little; I was very fond of meat, and hearty victuals, I got to be Very Corpulent that could not tie up my shoes- I [illegible] Bucan the family physician and he recommended Skunk Cabbage root dried and powered, it is an Indian medicine and it don’t grow anywhere but in the US. He describes the virtue of it; it is good for the Rheumatism, dropsie, Asthma, and it cures histerical [sic] fits. when much will not answer the only take only two teaspoonfuls of the root every morning untill you are cured; and the Indians take it after they get well-then patient ought to diet himself, and live upon light victuals and not drink any spirits. I have followed what he prescribed for about six weeks, and I find by experience it has answered his prescription. I don’t think that I weigh as much by 30 pounds as I did two months ago. I feel much spryer than I did-I have not joined the cold water society. my hand is not palsied with old age nor with Fatigue [illegible] -The reason that a cow is more healthy than a man is: She is confined to one sort of food and drink - your mother has not joined the cold water society she don’t drink any spirits, she don’t take any opium, and she has left off smokng and her health is about as good as it was when Sarah was here: she keeps knitting as usual-- our family are all well except Lucy Ann her fits continue upon her yet, I think they must wear her out in time. the whole family were greatly encouraged sometime since that she was going to get well but alas, alas, alas-we are almost discouraged now. I believe that she is a sincere Christian, I never heard her complain, she bear her sickness with as much patience as her Aunt Anne did- It is every dying sickly time here. Mr Jonathan Town Widow Mack James Culvers wife reverend Mr. Nichols, Mr. Lord and Mr. Hodges young child have died lately-Deacon Ellis his son, Captain Ellis his daughter and a boy that lives there are all very sick. Captain Ellis life is despaired of given over by his physician-Mr. David Port has been sick and confined to his room, his wife has a wart on the bottom of her foot she cut it off with a razor repeatedly and it has broke out into a sore they are afraid it will be a cancer and it has been very painful and made her crazy-I hear they are getting better-the military academy in Middletown is taken up; and they offer all the buildings and land he had which they compute to be worth $90,000 to the Methodists to build a college their [sic]— The Methodists have agreed to build a college there next summer-- There is now a rebellion in the sophomore class in your college. There is 42 Scholars refuse to obey their Instructors-- The Faculty of college have sent to their parents to send for their sons home, they don’t want them there, what the consequence will be I know not. There is a dreadful stir among the calvinistic ministers for the want of money which they are seeking after with a step as steady as time and appetite as keen as death; only a few years since in this little county of Bolton, Summers, Andover, Gilead, Marlborough Coventry, Hebron have [illegible] [illegible] [illegible] [illegible] most of the [illegible] have got ministers [illegible] or reinstalled; this would have been a new thing under the Sun 70 years ago- General Johnson and his Lady called here few days since, and informed us that your Aunt Elderkin is in a poor state of health; the rest of your Windham friends are all well. My Garden has turned Preacher, and it blooming Tenants are so many lively sermons. I have paid a particular attention to my Garden this summer. I go out almost every morning and work one or two hours in my Garden: my skillful hand has parcelled out the whole ground into narrow beds, and intervening alleys - The same discreet management has assigned to each verdant family a [illegible] and distinct abode; so that there is no confusion amidst the greatest multiplicity, because every individual knows its proper home-- What a source of wholesome dainties grows in any Garden: and all for the enjoyment of man. The Beans stand firm like files of embattled troops-the peas rest upon props like so many companies of invalids; while both replenish their pods with the freshness of the earth; on purpose to pour them on the owners tables. Not on [illegible] among all this bounty of Hosts is a numberer of the ground-- what is still more [illegible] every portion of the year affords such [illegible] as are best suited to the temperature the air, and the State of our bodies: and every one of which tenders as some agreeable present and pays us a welcome tribute; and to furnish us at once with plenty and with pleasure - When I was a young men I did not hoe but one at a time; now I have two rows, one with and with the help of my hoe handle advance forward to the next hills-- When I get tired I have a house in my broad alley which I keep sweeped, and garnished, I set down and rest myself; and contemplate upon the wonderful works of God in making my [illegible] and everything in my Garden grow, and flourish- I planted my Garden with the square compass and plum [sic] line according to rule, Lucy, dropped some of the seeds in my Garden here and kept one [illegible] them out the first time, since I have taken the whole charge of one Garden upon myself-When the Gentlemen and Ladies visit here I invite them into my Garden, and they all give me this [illegible] character, that I have the best Garden, and freest from weeds, of any in the Parish this is an honorable Compensation for all my hard services - Why then should the possessor of so valuable a spot envy the condition of Kings since I can walk daily amidst rows of peaceable and obsequious though mute Subjects, every one of which tenders me some agreeable present and pays willing Tribute

2 Horse beasts worthy $ 45.00 1 Cow worth... 12.00 2 yearling Calves worth 4.00 1 Heifer 2 years old worth 6.00 1 Bull 2 years old worth 6.00 30 Head of Hogs worth 49.50 14 Head of Sheep worth 35.00 7 Beds and beding worth 20.00 6 Pewter Plates worth 2.00 2 chairs worth .50 Table worth 1.00 4 Knives & forks .50 2 twelve gallon Kettles 8.00 1 Stew Kettle 1.50 1 Dutch oven 2.00 one Oven & Lid .50 2 Ploughs 2.50 1 Axe worth 2.00 Six Cups and Saucers worth 1.00 and that there is due him about 82.00 and that he owes about $150.000 for rent and otherwise, leaving about one hundred and thirty Dollars in hand -- This declarant further avers and Swears that his ocupation is a farmer, that he is obliged to rent Land and house to live in, that during the time he was in service he lost the use of his right arm measurably and that by rheumatism and old age he is not able to do more than half the labor of an ordinary man, that he has a wife and three Children living with him, that his wife is about fifty six or seven years old, that she is crippled so as to be unable to earn a livelihood, that the eldest child living with him is a daughter aged about eighteen able to earn a livelihood that the second is a boy thirteen years old unab[le] to do enough for his support from debility that the third was nine years old last January is a boy and unable to do any thing for a support --

State of So Carolina Know all men by these presents that I James Black of Chester District and State aforesaid for and in consideration of the sum of one Hundred Dollars to me in hand paid by Robert Black of the State and Diestrict aforesaid, have granted, bargained, sold, and released, and by these presents do grant, bargain, sell, and release unto the said Robert Black all that plantation or tract of Land whereon the said James Black now lives containing Ninety Eight acres more or less, beginning at a corner in Joseph Simpson's field, and keeps down a branch to George Caldwells, then takes George's line S.E. and comes on the McDonel's line. then through the fields to Joseph Simpson's again, thence to the beginning corner. Together with all and singular the rights. members, heriditaments and appurtenances to the said Tract belonging or in any wise incident or appurtaining, to have and to hold all and singular the premises before mention unto the said Robert Black, his heirs and assigns forever, and I do hereby bind myself, my heirs Ecrs Admintrs to Warrant and forever defend all those premises before mentioned unto the said Robert Black his heirs Ecrs and assigns against myself, my heirs, admins and assigns and against all other persons whomsoever lawfully claiming or to claim the same or any part thereof. And also a certain Black House & a bay Colt and three head of Cows and two Calves, and also fifteen head of Sheep, three Beds and Furniture, and all the rest of my Household Furniture without reserve. In witness whereunto I have put my hand and seal this 23rd day of February in the Year of our Lord on thousand Eight hundred and nineteen, and in the Independency of the United States of America the Forty fourth. Provided always and upon condition that if the said James Black, his heirs, Executors, or Administrators do or shall well and truly pay or cause to be paid the sum of One Hundred Dollars with lawful interest from the date hereof in the year of our Lord one Thousand Eight Hundred and Twenty Seven, and on July the 16th of said year, that then these presents and every thing therein contained to the contrary in any way notwithstanding shall be void and of no effect otherwise to be in full force and virtue. Making my hand & seal the year and day first above written. James Black his mark (LS) Signed & Delivered in presence of us Jho Coulter John Harbison South Carolina, Chester District Personally came John Coulter before me, and being duly Sworn Saith that he saw James Black Sign and deliver the within Mortgage to Robert Black for the purpose

State of New Jersey, Passaic County, ss, Before me John Parke, one of Justices of the peace for the said County, personally appeared Mrs. Sarah Colt widow of Peter Colt decd and being duly sworn according to law, Saith and further declares, that her Marriage with Peter Colt her late husband took place at the house of her Father Daniel Lyman Esqr in New Haven - and that she was married by the Revd Jonathan Edwards, Pastor of the second presbyterian Church in New Haven - she further states that when the British attacked New Haven, they destroyed every thing which they did not take away with them, that was in the house of her Father, he being an active Whig, among the rest the family Bible and other family records and she further says that her late husband settled up & closed his accounts, after the peace, as Deputy Commissary General at Hartford Connecticut with General Wadsworth, who was Commissary General on the day month & year herefore declared under Congress that the papers, vouchers &c. were left in Hartford, Connecticut with his Nephew Elisha Colt, when he Peter Colt removed to New Jersey, and that in subsequent removals, she believes said Books & vouchers have been lost or destroyed as being of No Value and further saith not Sworn before me the 10th day of March, A.D. 1838 Sarah Colt John Parke Justice of the peace

I Samuel Hutchins of Lawful age deposed & say That I am a trader in Bath near the Town of Landaff and that Mr. Benja. Moody who is a revolutionary soldier & an invalid pensioner and now applying for an additional pension He traded with me for many years. that in 1821 in May he owed me for Goods before rec and Debts which I had paid for him over three hundred Dollars. that in 1824 in January I felling unwilling to wait longer obtained a writ of attachments agains him & sent an officer to Moody's and that he turned out all his personal property, on said Writ and by agreement between us to same con - it was advertised and sold at Public Vender. said property sold and a year credit for about $125.00 which after deducting cost of attachment & sale left about 118$ which we allowed him on the [illegible] That in May following we made another settlement & he owed me $240. — & since that time he has paid me something like $32.00 by half of one year pension leaving him still in debt to me over $200 — That said Moody is now quite infirm and indigent circumstances and has been quite sick for several months back and the wounds he received while fighting for his country are painful & distress him much — a great part of above $300. he owed me previous to 1818 - and some years before, a part of it, & I do believe he stands in need of further assistance of his country to make him a comfortable support. November 1821 said Moody let me have a pair of Hogs which amounted to about forty Dollars which I allowed him on my demands - My debt against him was for goods and necessaries for his Family & debts paid for him as stated above & hie always applied it was for or Thomas Townsend his wife past this familys support - I should think his wound gives an pain & full pain for the former sold them by him as stated in his application to this term of the supr Court & I have no doubt he is spoor & really needing the assistance of his country & more there his invalids pension can certain Saml Hutchins Grafton ss May 23rd 1825 Then the Hon Judge Hutchins made solemn oath that the above affidavit by him signed is just & true before me Ira Goodall Jus Peace

My occupation is farming my bodily ability to pursue it is wholly gone from me nor am I capable of any manual Labour. The sciatic and Rheumatic pains the secd of which were set on in my constitution in the active & severe campaign of 76 and 77 have been growing ever since and have now literally rendered me a Cripple - I have but three persons in my family under my control, my wife Jane Finley of a delicate and weakly constitution aged 56 years one son Samuel Finley aged 17 years subject to Fits for seven years part the greater part of his time incapable of any business and it being necessary he keep a watch over him for fear of fatal accidents he is more of a charge than help to me and one daughter named Margaret Finley aged 13 years of a weakly sickly habit - In addition to the difficulties and distress under which I labour I am justly indebted to different persons in the sum of our nehundred and twenty dollars without the means or rational prospect of making payment: what I can consider my self in other light than a Tenant at Will and what little property I possess depends on the courtesy of my condition; indeed from the year 1812 to the year 1818 when I was put on the pension list I have been assisted by private aid, otherwise I know not how I should have got a long. [signed] Jos L. Finley. Schedule of the property of Joseph L. Finley The lot of fifty acres of second rate land on which I live worth about $400. I cannot consider as justly my own as I am yet indebted for the whole of the purchase money and have no prospect of ever being able to pay it.
