1821 2 Vol. Scotts Bible given to two of my married children 1 Truckle 1 pitcher 1 bowl 1 cupboard four [illegible] 1 pot 6 plates 1 Tea Kettle 1 small Kettle 2 buckets worn out shattered & broken 1 note for 10 doll is rendered of no value, the man who gave it has committed felony & fled out of the state leaving no property 3 head of cattle & several hogs slaughtered for use & 1 bullock dead by disease 1 table and a pair of tongs broken My occupation has been Farming, but I have been so long afflicted with a bad state of health and nearly deprived of eye sight, debilitated with the Palsy and [illegible] with rheumatism, having no assistance within my self and unable to hire anymore. I am obliged to relinquish it, nor do I know of any other I can pursue. these reasons and the necessity of paying off the debts upon it have obliged one to sell any claims I have to the lot of ground on which I reside - My family consists of myself now in my 69th year, my wife Jane Finley in the 59th year of her age, a son named Samuel Finley in the 21st year of his age but so reduced by strong convulsion fits that for several years he has ben unable to earn his support and is to me a heavy charge, one daughter named Margaret Finley in her 17th year of tolerable health, but her mothers health is very delicate and a boy about 9 years of age named Thomas Lafferty - it is possible as I write from memory that some of the dates may be inaccurate. all my military vouchers being in possession of the War Department and of other things I made no memorandum, not supposing that I should ever need them [signed] Joseph L. Finley

State of Vermont COUNTY OF WINDHAM, SS. AT the Supreme Court of Judicature, begun and held at New Fane, within and for the County of Windham, on the fourth Tuesday of May, in the year of our Lord One thousand eight hundred twenty three--Present-- Hon. CORNELIUS P. VAN NESS, Esq. Chief Judge, Hon. JOEL DOOLITTLE, Hon. CHARLES K WILLIAMS, Esq's, Assistant Judges On the thirtieth day of May, A. D. 1823, personally appeared in open Court, being a Court of Record, within and for the County of Windham, a State of Vermont--proceeding according to the course of the common law: with a civil jurisdiction unlimited in point of amount, keeping a record of their proceedings; and having the power of fine and imprisonment-Samuel Viall late resident in Jamaica in said County of Windham--Aged 64 years--Who, being first duly sworn according to law--doth, on his Oath, made the following declaration, in order to obtain the provisions made by the Acts of Congress, of the 18th of March, 1818, and the 1st of may, 1820,--That be the said Samuel Viall enlisted for the term of three years on the first day of March in the year 1777 in the State of Massachusetts in the Company commanded by Captain Joseph Williams in the Regiment commanded by Colonel John Graton in the line of the State of Massachusetts on the continental establishment; that he continued to serve in the said Corps until 1783 and on furlough late 1784 when he was discharged from said service in Newburgh in the State of New York; that his name has been placed on the pension list, and dropt therefrom on account of his property. And, in pursuance of the Act of the 1st May, 1820, I do hereby swear--that I was a resident citizen of the United States, on the 18th day of March, 1818--And that I have not, since that time, by give, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an Act of Congress--Entitled "an Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War"--passed on the 18th day of March, 1818. And that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property, or securities, contract, or debts, due to me: Nor have I any income other that what is contained in the Schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. Schedule of real and personal Estate--necessary clothing and bedding excepted. To wit--One Cow worth $15--One Mare with one eye $15--one swine or Pig $4--One large Iron kettle $3--Two small kettles $1.50-shovel and tongs $1.--5 poor chains $0.83 cents--Two old tables $1--knives & forks and crockery $1.50--One Dish (illegible) $3.--One Tea kettle $0.50--one spider .25 cents--Total $46,58 Samuel Viall That, since the exhibition of my first Schedule, the following changes have been made in my property; To wit-- (Chart) Names of person to whom sold: Thirty three acres and one third of an acre of land with appurtenances thereon, set: Time of Sale: September 20th 1820 Amount of money, or description of property received in return: of Peter R Taft for sale of land $400 One Ox in my former schedule valued at $30-Sold to Eben Taylor of Wardsboro for $26.00 in Sept. 1820--Mare (the same as in former schedule in .

STATE OF VERMONT COUNTYOF WINDHAM ss. Phinehas White, Esq. Chief Judge. Hon. John Roberts, Hon. Gilbert Denison, Esqrs., Assistant Judges ON this 20th day of June, a. D. 1820, personally appeard in open court, being a court of record, ^in said State within and for said county, (crossed out-"proceeding according to the course of the common law, with a civil jurisdiction unlimited in point of amount, keeping a record of their proceedings, and having, in certain cases, the power of fine and imprisonment") Samuel Viall aged sixty one years, resident in Jamaica in said county, who, being first duly sworn according to law, doth, on his oath, declare a that he served in the Revolutionary War as follows: Commencing the first day of March 1777. 3rd Regiment of the Massachusetts Line, commanded by Col. John Graton-commanded by Captain Joseph Wiliams. The number of my pension certificate is 240=I served untill the end of the War. (The following was X'd out) That he has received a pension under the act of the Congress of the United States of the 18th March, 1818, that the number of pension certificate is.....and the date of his original declaration is......) AND I DO SOLEMNLY SWEAR, That I was a resident citizen of the United States on the eighteenth day of March, one thousand eight hundred and eighteen; and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner whatever, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself withing the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled, "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the Land and Naval Service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War," passed on the eighteenth day of March, one thousand eight hundred eighteen; And that I have not nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other that what is contained in the Schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. SVHEDULE of real and personal estate, necessary clothing and bedding excepted. Thirty three acres and two thirds acre of land-a small house which has been built about 40 years of small value-and a small barn (?) built standing on th premises. The land with the appertanances will appraise at about $400. one old cabin at $30. one farrow cow $14. 44. one old mare & colt worth $35 2 yearlings 4. $8. 43. 1 old plow 3. 2 hoes .25 1 ax .50 7.75 ------- $510.75 Necessary articles in house besides bedding & apparel 10. ------- $520.75 one grindstone 1.

[italics] The Life and Death of 137 And if that you should linger by the way: But in hope that you will make good speed, There's two Angels to buy you Spurs and Wands. [italics] Post. I thank you, Sir, this will add wings indeed. [italics] Crom. Gold is of Pow'r to make an Eagles speed. [italics] Enter Mistress Banister. What a Gentlewoman is this, that grieves so much? It seems she doth address her self to me. [italics] Mrs. Ban. God save you, Sir, pray is your Name Master [italics] Cromwell? [italics] Crom. My name is [italics] Thomas Cromwell, Gentlewoman. [italics] Mrs. Ban. Know you not one [italics] Bagot, Sir, that's come to [italics] Antwerp? [italics] Crom. No, trust me, I never saw the Man, But here are Bills of Debt I have received Against one [italics] Banister, a Merchant fall'n into decay. [italics] Mrs. Ban. Into decay ineed, long of that Wretch: I am the Wife to woful [italics] Banister, And by that bloody Villain am pursu'd, From [italics] London, here to [italics] Antwerp: My Husband he is in the Governor's Hands, And God of Heav'n knows how he'll deal with him; Now, Sir, your Heart is fram'd of milder Temper, Be merciful to a distressed Soul, And God no doubt will treble bless your Gain. [italics] Crom. Good Mistress [italics] Banister, what I can, I will, In any thing that lies within my pow'r. [italics] Mrs. Ban. O speak to [italics] Bagot, that same wicked Wretch, An Angel's Voice may move a damned Devil. [italics] Crom. Why is he come to [italics] Antwerp, as you hear? [italics] Mrs. Ban. I heard he landed some two Hours since. [italics] Crom. Well, Mistress [italics] Banister, assure your self, I'll speak to [italics] Bagot in your own behalf, And win him t'all the pity that I can: Mean time, to comfort you, in your distress, Receive these Angels to relieve your need, And be assur'd, that what I can effect, To do you good, no way I will neglect. Mrs. 140 [italics] The Life and Death As good luck serves, my Accounts are all made even, Therefore I'll straight unto the Treasurer: [italics] Bagot, I know you'll to the Governor, Commend me to him, say I am bound to Travel, To see the fruitful Parts of [italics] Italy; And as you ever bore a Christian Mind, Let [italics] Banister some Favour of you find. [italics] Bag. For your sake, Sir, I'll help him all I can, To starve his Heart out ere he gets a Groat; So, Master [italics] Cromwell, do I take my leave, For I must straight unto the Governor. [italics, opening bracket included in text] [Exit Bagot. [italics] Crom. Farewel, Sir, pray you remember what I said. No, [italics] Cromwell, no, thy Heart was ne'er so base, To live by Falshood, or by Brokery; But 't falls out well, I little it repent, Hereafter, time in Travel shall be spent. [italics] Enter Hodge, [italics] his Father's Man. [italics] Hodge. Your Son [italics] Thomas, quoth you, I have been [italics] Thomast; I had thought it had been no such matter to a gone by Water; for at [italics] Putney I'll go you to [italics] Parish Garden for two Pence, sit as still as may be, without any wagging or joulting in my Guts, in a little Boat too: Here we were scarce four Miles in the great green Water, but I thinking to go to my Afternoon's Lunchines, as 'twas my manner at home, but I felt a kind of rising in my Guts: At last, one of the Sailors spying of me, be a good cheer, says he, set down thy Victuals, and up with it, thou hast nothing but an Eel in thy Belly: Well, to't went I, to my Victuals went the Sailors, and thinking me to be a Man of better Experience than any in the Ship, ask'd me what Wood the Ship was made of: They all swore I told them as right as if I had been acquainted with the Carpenter that made it: At last we grew near Land, and I grew villanous hungry, went to my Bag, the Devil a bit there was, the Sailors had tickled me; yet I cannot blame them, it was a part of kindness, for I in kindness told them what Wood the Ship was made of, and they in kindness eat up my Victuals, as indeed one good turn asketh another: Well, would I, could I, find my Master [italics] Thomas in this [italics] Dutch Town, he might put some [italics] English Beer into my Belly. [italics] Crom. [handwritten] John Brister W.20772 Conn.

State of Pennsylvania, County of Crawford ss On this the 13th July 1850 personally appeared in open court David Boyle of Mead township county and state aforesaid aged forty three years, who first being duly sworn according to law doth depose and say that he has been a resident of said township for fifteen years, that his former residence was Tompkins county in the state of New York. And further states that he can remember Charles Boyle the applicant named in the accompanying declaration hereunto attached and who resides now in Crawford county Penn. and formerly in the state of New York. And this deponent further states that the said Charles has usually been regarded as a soldier of the Revolutionary war. That he has frequently had conversations with said Charles about services, suffering and hardships during the Revolutionary war. That he has named his officers to him often and have often heard him speak of his enlistement and the battles he has been in. And deponent further states that from the many conversations and the information has has received from his father and mother he is free to say on this his oath that he firmly believes the declaration of the said Charles Boyle hereunto attached to be essentially true. The said Charles Boyle, being held by those who know him, to be a man of truth. Your deponent does not recollect of hearing the said Boyle mention the christian names of his officers, but has heard him name his Generals, Colonels, Captains and other subsordinate officers. And deponent further states that the said Boyle is a very illiterate man and careless in his dispositions and has been in the habit of

his neighbors and citizens as a soldier of the Revolutionary War, that he has frequently had conversations with the said Charles Boyle about his services, sufferings and hardships during the war and further this deponent states that he has heard the said Boyle frequently say that he was or ought to be entitled to a pension, but would not apply as long as he could live without it &c. And deponent further states that he is not interested to the amount of one cent in regard to this pension directly or indirectly in any way. Your deponent would further state, that the said Charles Boyle the applicant for this pension has been a man who has always sustained a good character for truth and varacity, wherever he has lived amongst his neighbors since I have known him. James F. Preston Sworn and subscribed July 13h 1850 G. Church P.J. Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, Crawford County ss. I, William McLaughlin, Clerk of the Orphans Court of said county, do hereby certify that the foregoing contains the original proceedings of the said court in the matter of the application of Charles Boyle for a pension. In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and the seal of the said court, this fifteenth day of July in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and fifty. Wm McLaughlin Clerk O. Court

That as declarant was always informed by his said parents they were married to each other in Plattekill in the County of ulster in said State in the winter of the year seventeen hundred and eighty four by the Revd Mr Goetchius Pastor of the reformed Dutch church of New Hurley in Plattekill aforesaid, Catherine Terwilliger, John & Isaac Conklin, Jacob Roos, and other persons were present at their marriage; that previous to her marriage as aforesaid his mother resided in Plattekill aforesaid and bore the maiden name of Susannah Conklin that his said father went to Plattekill aforesaid from Poughkeepsie at or near the close of the wara where he married as aforesaid and continued to live untill he moved with his said wife and family which he did a number of years ago to Chenango aforesaid in said County of Broom and where he died at the residence of Declarant October 14th 1832, as aforesaid & since which time declarants said mother has remained his widow single & unmaried, and is now totally deranged and insane Declarant employed an agent some years ago to collect the necessary proof in order to obtain said pension but his said mother continuing to remain insane the papers were not forwarded on to the department. Declarant having now no hopes of his said mother recovery now makes the application in her behalf as her lawful guardian as she is in needy circumstances and as Declarant truly believes is honestly and justly entitled to the same. Subscribed and sworn before me the day & year first aforesaid in open court [illegible] Jacob his x mark Conklin now sitting John C. Moore Clerk

This is to certify that I am well acquainted with the within named Samuel Fisher and have been for many years and that he was Pastor of the Presbyterian Church in the Town of Paterson in the County Essex now the County Passaic for many years, and that was also well acquainted with Peter Colt before his death and I am now acquainted with his widow, Sarah Colt, Witness my hand this tenth day of February A.D. 1838 John Parke Judge of Com. Pleas for the County of Passiac State of New Jersey Passaic County I George A. Ryerson Clerk of the said County of Passaic do hereby certify that John Parke, named in the above certificate is a Judge of the Superior Court of Common Pleas in and for the said County of Passaic, That I am well acquainted with the handwriting of the said Judge, and verily believe that the signature John Parke subscribed to the above certificate, is his genuine signature, and proper hand writing - In Witness whereof I have hereunto subscribed my name and affixed the seal of the said County this tenth day of February A.D. eighteen hundred and thirty eight- Geo. A. Ryerson Clerk

I Ezra C Hutchins of Lawful age depose & say that I as agent for my Father Samuel Hutchins attended a sale on the 15th day of January AD 1824 at the House of Benjamin Moody in Landaff of his the said Moodys property — That said Property was attached on a Writ in favor of said Hutchins agains said Moody on a Debt of about $350.00 principal | interest That said Moody agreed to Leave the property sold without fear then cost for the benefit of said Hutchins and that said property was sold on a year credit & fetch? something like $120.00 which after deducting the cost and paid the auctioneer left $110.00 which soon was appropriated on my Fathers Debt [illegible] him. that I was Clerk at the sale and am the only proper testifying officer as it was sold without process - The agreeing to it, was sold 4 Cows 1 yearling Calf about 4 tons hay a small quantity of sryp in the bundle judged at 15 Bushels - 8 sheep 3 small chootes and 2 old Wooden Wheels one linear Wheel and a few other articles of little value - that said moody turned out all the property he possessed & sold all of any value as he states = & I [illegible] he is left poor & needy & he is still owing my father over $200. — a few old chairs and some few mean articles of kitchen furniture sold for 5$ & [illegible] as he say and I he has no property to my knowledge except what he has named in his schedule which is value full I believe - Ezra C Hutchins Grafton ss} Sworn to before me this 23 May 1825 as Just Thur Fragoodall Justice Peace

State of New York Tompkins County ss: On this fifteenth day of February A.D. 1838 personally appeared in open Court before a Court of Oyer & Terminer & General Law delivery in & for the said County of Tompkins now sitting, which said court has by law the power of fine & imprisonment and is duly constituted a court of Record, Joshua Hinckley a resident of the Town of Hector in the County of Tompkins & State of New York, aged Eighty years on the 19th day of September last past, who being first duly sworn, according to law doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the provision, made by the act of Congress passed June 7th 1832. That he enlisted in the Army of the United in the year 1776 with Wicks and served in a Regiment of Artillery called Putnams Regiment in the New York line under the following named officers: That he so enlisted according to his best recollection in the month of May 1776 to serve during the war as a private and did serve for the Term of five years & two months in said Putnams Regiment under the command of Col Lamb on the continual establishment under one enlistment in Capt [illegible] Company in which one Wicks was a Lieutenant. That he was eighteen year of age when he so enlisted and that he then resided at Fredericksburgh in the County of Dutchess now Putnam in the State of New York, at which place he enlisted. That he continued to serve in the same Regiment for the time aforesaid and until the 4th day of July in the year 1781 when he was discharged at White Plains and received a written discharge signed by Col Anthony Lamb. That at the time of his said discharge his company was commanded by Capt Reed, that his discharge together with his house were destroyed by fire many years ago in the State of New Jersey: That during his aforesaid Service he was present & engaged in the Battles of Bunker Hill, White Planes, Kings Bridge Stoney Point and Boston; and that he marched through the Counties of Dutchess, Putnam, Westchester & on Long Island in the State of New York & through the southern part of the State of Connecticut & unto the State of Massachusetts. He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a Pension or an annuity except the present; and he declares that his name is not on the Pension Roll of any agency in any state. And further that the reason he has not before applied for a Pension has been his extreme poverty & inability to pay the expense of his application and his ignorance of his rights - that his wife is now supported in the Poor House of Tompkins County and that he has also been supported there by the publick a considerable portion of his time for several years past, not having any means to support himself. Joshua Hinckley his X mark Sworn to and subscribed the day & year aforesaid in open Court before the Judges thereof Hon T. Huntington Clerk And the said Court do hereby declare their opinion after the investigation of the matter and after putting the interrogatories prescribed by the war Deptment, that the above named applicant was a Revolutionary Soldier and served as he states. And the Court further certifies that it appears to them that John H Carle, who has subscribed & sworn to the annexed affidavit is a Clergyman resident of Trumansburgh in said County of Tompkins and that D. K. McLallen who has also signed & sworn to the annexed affidavit is a resident of Trumansburgh aforesaid, is a credible person and that their statement is entitled to credit.

Key Post Aug 30th 1854 Wm. Grandin Esq. Dar Sir: I enclose the certificate and affidavit of the Rev. Mr. Willis Pastor of the 1st Reformed duch (Dutch?) church of Freehold. I saw the records of Rev. Dubois about with there can not be any mistake. I trust this together with the affidavit of Joseph Walling and what evidence they have at Washington will procure a pension for the old lady as she is very needy and that she is entitled to it on one will doubt the hears her testimony and that of others. Yours truly in haste, Elijah Stout NB I would have attended to this sooner but have been absent for some days. Yours Elijah Stout (NB is Latin for Nota Bene = note well)

Deeming it expedient that Agreeable to the late law of the United States granting pensions to certain Officers and Soldiers of [?] Revolutionary war , that all Applicants for said pension, should Offer to the Honble. The Secretary of war some Evidence that they are embraced within the discriminating bounds, the spirit and intention of said Law. The subscriber late an officer in the Armies of the U States, in said war, the takes the liberty to offer the honest and candid statement and exposition of his circumstances as follows. He is in possession of a Farm in the County of Hampshire in the State of Virginia, the annual rent value of which he supposes and believes to be about $360.00 that he receives from the bounty of the State of Maryland a pension of $160 per annum in Quarterly payments. That he has on hand a small stock of Horses Cattle, sheep and Hoggs, farming Utensils, and sufficient quantity of old fashioned and plain Houshold furniture but little cash and few debts due him. That he is indebted to the Banks $1400, and to individuals about $600 more that if pressed for the payment of this money that his personal property must be sacrificed & would not it is probable suffice. That he is himself old and infirm and Utterly incapable of labour. That his wife is not only old and very infirm, but is now confined to her bed and it is probable will remain so, with a stroke of the palsey, that such is her situation that she requires three women to nurse and wait upon her to remove her in and out of bed &c. That physicians and nurses and other incidental expenses in a case of this kind has been and still must continue heavy &c &c from all which it will appear that altho the Subscriber will not undertake to say he is poor yet it manifestly appears that he is needy John J. Jacob late Lt & paym to the 6th Regt of Maryland May 5th 1818

P.S. Henry the Immortal Barbourn delivered a funeral elegy in the house of the delegates of Virginia upon the life, patriotism death and burial of Peter Francisco a Revolutionary Soldier. Our beloved Children.- Hebron January 13th. 1831. Through the goodness of God, we your aged parents have lived through another year and began upon a New Year - May we live more devotedly to God this year than we ever have done Jeremiah 28th 16. This year thou shall die. Because thou hast never taught Rebellion against the Lord-- This old Bunker Hill Deputy Commissary never taught Rebellion against the Lord; nor against my beloved country. Your relatives and old neighbors’ [illegible] were as common as [illegible] you the mortality and sickness in Gilead since the cold weather commenced has subsided: there has 19 persons died in this parish last year. I received your [illegible] and affectionate Letter December 16. 1831. It has fully convinced and it has fully satisfied my mind, that it was not best to make any application to our Honorable Congress at present for any compensation for the disposition of final settlement notes, or Continental money that I received for my wages; and the supplies I furnished our Continental army the four first years of our revolutionary war under the command of the Honorable Washington By the Message of the President of the way it appears to me that he is engaged to pay off the national debt, and he is perfectly right. I have been through both Wars. Henry, stand still and read the history of the last war and see the salvation of God in our behalf-- God commanded the sun to stand still for General Jackson and his military to smite the invaders of our Country. Their arms were strengthened by Omnipotent aid! And their guns Fired by an unerring eye or they never could have killed 700 disciplined men and wounded 1400 men and taken 500 prisoners. General Jackson Lost only 7 men killed and 6 men wounded-Sacred and profane history give no such interposition of Divine providence to any army before or since Noah’s flood- This memorable Battle has travelled with yonder Sun upon the wings of the wind among all the Nations of the earth and it will strike a dread to all tyrants and [illegible] [illegible] to our country never to invade our beloved country with impunity; as long as General Jackson is President of the [United] states- there are also many whose minds are so little, that they can conceive nothing great, which does not court the eye in all the trapping of dress, and titles, and eternal splendor. American Patriot!: a Blanket Hero; a General from the plow: all these are terms of ridicule and reproach among many, yet each was Cincinnatus in the best days of Roman virtue- and the Immortal Washington in our day- Henry you will perceive by any newspaper the Speaker also laid before the House a letter from James Monroe late President of the U.S. upon the subject of his claim on the Government of the U.S.. which was referred to the Committee of the whole House-- I don’t believe that President Monroe ever took a final settlement note or old Continental money depreciated- for and by the scale of depreciation made by Congress for his wages if he did he ought to complain or the stones would cry out against him- among the memorials presented to day was one by Mr. Verplank from a number of Officers and Soldiers of the Revolutionary army many of whom served in the battle of Princeton, Saratoga, and Yorktown, but whose cases in consequence of their retirement from the Army, do not come within the provision of the act of 1828, praying to be indemnified for the depreciation of the paper money in which their services were with or for relief in any other made which Congress may think proper to grant; and on motion of Mr. V[erplank] the memorial was referred to a select Committee. I guess that Mr. Verplank, a Freemason like Immortal Washington and General H. Knox he had [illegible] for our old Continental officers and Soldiers who achieved our Independence with their blood and treasure and saved our beloved country from eternal slavery with depreciated paper made of old rags without the Spanish milled dollar-Mr. Condict presented two memorials from number of the widows of of deceased Revolutionary officers praying to be allowed some portion of the pensions granted to their respective husbands during her life time; which were referred to the same select Committee. To such men as achieved our independence - Rome in all her glory would have decreed honors and make up the depreciation if they had paid them in old rag money- the Resolves of Congress to transmit the memory of their virtues is worthy of that magnanimity which ought to characterize public bodies-- Jealous and [illegible] rulers are sparing of honors to those who serve them- lest their own should be eclipsed- But your [illegible] Gentlemen can suffer no diminution this way; Henry, I have now sent you an account of the part I took in our revolutionary war and how I received my pay. I [illegible] on my newspapers capturing Mr. Verplank’s appeal on the service of the surviving officers and soldiers of our revolutionary army, etc., etc.,etc.-

Thomas [italics] Lord Cromwell. 133 [italics] Crom. With all my Heart, Sir, and I much am bound, In Love and Duty for your Kindness shown. [italics] Old Crom. Body of me, [italics] Tom, Make haste, lest some Body Get between thee and home, [italics] Tom. I thank you, good Master [italics] Bowfer, I thank you for my Boy, I thank you always, I thank you most heartily, Sir: Ho, a Cup of Beer here for Master [italics] Bowfer. [italics] Bow. It shall not need, Sir: Master [italics] Cromwell, will you? [italics] Crom. I will attend you, Sir. [italics] Old Crom. Farewel, [italics] Tom, God bless thee, [italics] Tom, God speed thee, good [italics] Tom [italics, opening bracket included in text] [Exeunt. [italics] Enter Bagot, [italics] a Broker, solus. [italics] Bag. I hope this day is fatal unto some, And by their loss must [italics] Bagot seek to gain. This is the Lodging of Master [italics] Friskibal, A liberal Merchant, and a [italics] Florentine, To whom [italics] Banister owes a thousand Pound, A Merchant - Bankrupt, whose Father was my Master. What do I care for pity or regard, He once was wealthy, but he now is fall'n, And this Morning have I got him arrested At the Suit of Master [italics] Friskibal, And by this means shall I be sure of Coin, For doing this same good to him unknown: And in good time, see where the Merchant comes. [italics] Enter Friskibal. Good morrow to kind Master [italics] Friskibal. [italics]Fris. Good morrow to your self, good Master [italics] Bagot, And what's the News you are so early stirring? It is for Gain, I make no doubt of that. [italics] Bag. It is for the Love, Sir, that I bear to you. When did you see your Debtor [italics] Banister? [italics] Fris. I promise you, I have not seen the Man This two Months day, his Poverty is such, As I do think he shames to see his Friends. [italics] Bag. Why then assure your self to see him straight, For at your Suit I have arrested him, And

110 [italics] The Life and Death of [italics] Mrs. Ban. That mighty God that knows each Mortal's Heart, Keep you from trouble, sorrow, grief and smart. [italics, opening bracket included in text] [Exit Mistress Banister. [italics] Crom. Thanks, courteous Woman, for thy hearty Pray'r: It grieves my soul to see her misery, But we that live under the Work of Fate, May hope the best, yet know not to what [illegible] Our Stars and Destinies have us assign'd, Fickle is Fortune, and her Face is blind. [italics, opening bracket included in text] [Exit. [italics] Enter Bagot [italics] Solus. [italics] Bag. So, all goes well, it is as I would have it, [italics] Banister, he is with the Governor: And shortly shall have Gyves upon his Heels. It glads my Heart to think upon the Slave: I hope to have his Body rot in a Prison, And after here, his Wife to hang her self, And all his Children die for want of Fund. The Jewels I have brought to [italics] Antwerp Are reckon'd to be worth five thousand Pound, Which scarcely stood me in three hundred Pounds; I bought them at an easie kind of rare, I care not which way they came by them, That sold them me, it comes not near my Heart; And lest they should be stole, as sure they are, I thought it meet to sell them here in [italics] Antwerp, And so have left them in the Governor's Hand, Who offers me within two hundred Pound Of all my Price: but now no more of that, I must go see and if my Bills be safe, The which I sent to Master [italics] Cromwell, That if the Wind should keep me on the Sea, He might arrest him here before I came: And in good time, see where he is: God save you, Sir. [italics] Enter Cromwell. [italics] Crom. And you; pray pardon me, I know you not. [italics] Bag. It may be so, Sir, but my Name is [italics] Bagot, The Man that sent to you the Bills of Debt. [italics] Crom. O, the Man that pursues [italics] Banister, Here are the Bills of Debt you sent to me: As Thomas [italics] Lord Cromwell. 111 As for the Man, you know best where he is; It is reported you've a Flinty Heart, A Mind that will not stoop to Any Pity; An Eye that knows not how to shed a Tear, A Hand that's always open for Reward But, Master [italics] Bagot, would you be rul'd by me, You should turn all these to the contrary; Your Heart should still have feeling of remorse. Your Mind, according to your State, be liberal To those that stand in need, and in distress; Your hand to help them that do stand in want, Rather than with your Poise to hold them down, For every ill turn show your self more kind, Thus should I do; pardon, I speak my Mind. [italics] Bag. I, Sir, you speak to hear what I would say, But you must live, I know, as well as I: I know this Place to be Extortion. And 'tis not for a Man to keep safe here, But he must lye, cog, with his dearest Friend; And as for Pity, scorn it, hate all Conscience: But yet I do commend your Wit in this, To make a show of what I hope you are not, But I commend you, and it is well done: This is the only way to bring your Gain. [italics] Crom. My Gain? I had rather chain me to an Oar, And like a Slave, there toil out all my Life, Before I'd live so base a Slave as thou, I, like an Hypocrite, to make a show Of seeming Virtue, and a Devil within? No [italics] Bagot if they Conscience were as clear, Poor [italics] Banister ne'er had been troubled here. [italics] Bag. Nay, good Master [italics] Cromwell, be not angry, Sir, I know full well that you are no such Man, But if your Conscience were as white as Snow, It will be thought that you are otherwise. [italics] Crom. Will it be thought that I am otherwise? Let them that think so, know they are deceiv'd; Shall [italics] Cromwell live to have his Faith misconster'd? [italics] Antwerp, for all the Wealth within thy Town, I will not tarry here full two Hours longer: As

State of Ohio Pickaway County M to Thomas Wadle Court of Walnut township Greeting Where Williamson obtained Judgment against James Williams before me the Subscriber a Justice of the peace of said township for a Debt of $66.05 and $___121/2 of Cost on the 10th day of September 1821 You are therefore commanded to levy the said debt and Cost and cost that may accrue off the good and Chattels of the said James Williams by Distress and sale thereof Returning the overplus if any to the said James Williams, but for want of such property Whereon to buy then take the said James Williams to the jail of said County there to be detained until the said debt and cost and cost that may accrue shall be paid or he otherwise legally discharged and of this make legal service and due Return given under my hand and seal this 29th of September 1821 Abm Christ G.S. State of Virginia, County of Frederick, to wit, On this 21 day of Sept 1853 came Henry Myers before the subscribed a Justice of the peace for the said County of Frederick and made solemn oath on the Holy Evangelists of Almighty God that on the 4th day of July in the year 1821 the Reverend John J. Jacob a revolutionary pensioner of the United States of America was married to Miss Susan M Davitt at the house of Joseph Cersap in Allegany County in the State of Maryland, their marriage was celebrated by the Rev. Louis R. Fechtig a Minister of the Methodist Episcopal Church in the presence of this affiant. and others -- the said Henry Myers being worthy of credit and disinterested. State of New Jersey Middlesex County Before me the subscriber one of the justices of the peace in and for said County personally appeared Moses Martin who being by me duly sworn on his oath says that I am in the seventy ninth year of my age I reside in the township of Piscataway County of Middlesex as aforesaid and have resided there all my life except about some years when I resided in New York, I was well acquainted with Aaron Bloomfield in his life time, and with his wife Keziah Bloomfield now his widow, I remember will of hearing of the marriage of the said Aaron Bloomfield to Keziah Martin, they were said to be married by the Rev. Renne Runyon, a Baptist minister pastor of the Baptist Church in Piscataway, I cannot tell when the marriage took place, but think was in the fall of the year 1894, the said Aaron Bloomfield and Keziah Martin now Keziah Bloomfield always after the marriage was said to take place have lived together in the same neighbourhood with me as man and wife, they had several children who still survive I have never heard it questioned or purported but that they were lawfully married they having always lived in the same neighbourhood with me, the said Keziah is now a widow and has not been married since the death of the said Aaron Bloomfield which took place some fifteen years since Moses Martin Sworn and subscribed the 23d day of February 1849 before me Peter P Runyon Justice of the Peace

declares to me her marriage to have been celebrated by a Clergyman, who was with the British troops, and went away with them at the Evacuation. She is entirely worthy of being believed in such a declaration; having always sustained a highly reputable character, and being none, amidst the infirmities of ages, in the possession of the perfect confidence esteem & respect of all who know her. appicant named in the annexed declaration ever since he can remember as he is his oldest brother, and has always since been intimately acquainted with him, and that he has often in conversation with him heard him relate his hardships, service and exploits while in the army during the revolutionary war, have heard both my father and mother speak of his enlistement & service during the war, and distinctly remembers of his leaving home to go to the war, his absence and his return home after the war and after the war became personally acquainted with Col Livingston. Have heard him speak of my brothers enlistment and services under him. I also became acquainted with my brothers Capt Robero or Robison who resided after the war near Johnstown in the state of New York. I have also heard him speak of my brothers services and enlistment in his company during the war. Deponent further says that Col. Livingston resided many years before he died at the place and deponent further states that the said Charles Boyle (his brother) was in good circumstances until within the last ten or twelve years, that he is illiterate and a man of no business capacity and formerly been a man of very intemperate habits, and further states that his brother believed that he was not entitled to a pension which he was a freeholder often formerly heard him say that he could live without a pension, and often heard him complain that he was excluded on account of his free hold. And deponent further states that he is not interested to the amount of one cent in regard to this pension in any shape, manner or form. Patrick Y. Boyle - X his mark Sworn and subscribed July 13, 1850 before me & in open court. G. Church P.I.J

State of Pennsylvania, County of Crawford SS On this the 13th July 1850 personally appeared in open court for the County of Crawford David Boyle [illegible] of Mead Township County and State aforesaid aged forty three years who first being duly sworn according to law doth depose and say that he has been a resident of said township for fifteen years. That his former residence was Tompkins County in the state of New York and further states that he can remember Charles Boyle the applicant named in the accompaning declaration hereunto attached, who resides now in Crowford County Penna. and formerly in the state of New York. And this deponent further states that the said Charles has usually been regarded as a soldier in the Revolutionary war. That he has frequently had conversations with the said Charles about his service, suffering & handship during the revolutionary war. That he has named his officers to him often, and have after heard him speak of his enlistment and the battles he has been in. And deponent further state that from the many conversations and the information he has received from his father & mother, he is free to say on this his oath that he firmly believes the declaration of the said Charles Boyle here unto attached to be essentially true. The said Charles Boyle being held by those who know him to be a man of truth. Your deponent does not recollect of hearing the said Boyle mention the christian names of any of his officers, but has been [illegible] name his Generals, Colonels, Captains, and other subordinate officers. And deponent further states that the said Boyle is a very illiterate man & careless in his disposition, and has been in the habit of drinking and neglecting his business and has been in good circumstances until within ten or twelve years, and until within a few years he has always said he could live without a pension and [illegible]

of drinking and neglecting his business and has been in good circumstances until within ten or twelve years. And until within a few years he has always said he could live without a pension and until lately he believed that a freeholder could not draw a pension. And deponent further says that he firmly believes that the above and foregoing are the reasons why the said Boyle has not heretofore applied for a pension. Your deponent further states that he is not directly or indirectly interested in this pension to the amount of one cent in any way. David Boyle - X his mark Sworn and subscribed before me in open court this 13th day of July AD 1850 G. Church P.J. State of Pennsylvania, County of Crawford ss On this the 13 day of July 1850 personally appeared in open court for the county of Crawford and state of Pennsylvania, Henry Robinson of Mead township, county and state aforesaid, aged about fifty-one years who being first duly sworn deposeth and saith, that he does now reside in Mead township county and state aforesaid, but was born & formerly resided in York State, and that he has known Charles Boyle, the applicant named in the annexed declaration ever since he can remember, over forty years, and has always been intimate and well acquainted with him, and that he has often heard him speak of his enlistment as a soldier in the Revolutionary war. Have frequently heard him relate his services, his hardships during the time he was out in the army. He has frequently heard him talk about his Generals, Colonels, Captains other intermediate officers. Your deponent would

South Carolina Chester Dist, Nov 7, 1824 Dear Sir, I at length forward you James Black's papers, which I trust will be quite satisfactory on the subject of the Mortgage. If the poor old soldier was bad off when he made his Schedule, he is worse now, his cow being dead, & not able to buy another. And from his inability to labour, has made little or no support for the present year. And must incuitably suffer without relief from some quarter. It is therefore hoped, that if the evidences of his service will in any way intitle him to the accrual of a Pention from his country, it will be bestowed upon him, as no man can be in more need of it. Most respectfuly you obt. servt Jno McCreary J.L. Edwards Esqr.

State of New York Rockland County ⎬Ss. on this eighth day of February in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and thirty eight Before me a Judge of the Court of Common Pleas in for said County, Personally appeared Samuel Fisher of the Town of Ramapo in said County to me personally known and made oath that for about twenty eight years he has known Mr Sarah Colt of Paterson in the State of New Jersey, widow of Peter Colt late of Paterson deceased that the said Sarah Colt was reputed to have been married to the said Peter Colt & was his wife during the Revolutionary war, and that the deponent has known them to live together as man & wife about fourteen years previous to his death that she has since his death which took place on the Seventeenth day of March Eighteen hundred and twenty four, remained his widow. And further this deponent saith not Subscribed and sworn Saml Fisher to on the day and year above written. Before me Edward Suffens first Judge of Rockland County. Turn over

State of New York Oneida County ss: On this twenty ninth day of January, in the year of our Lord one thousand Eight hundred and thirty Eight before me Hiram Denis, Judge of the Fifth Circuit in the State of New York, personally appeared Timothy Pitkin, & made oath, that for between fifty and sixty years he has known Mrs Sarah Colt of Paterson in the State of New Jersey, widow of Peter Colt, late of Paterson, deceased; that the said Sarah Colt was married to the said Peter Colt & was his wife during the Revolutionary war ; that she has since his death which took place within a few years since remained his widow Sworn to & subscribed Tim Pitkin on the day & year above written. [continued] 1818 & that I have not since that time by gift sale or in any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act Congress called an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land & naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War passed on the 10th day of March 1818 and that I have not nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities, contracts or debt due to me nor have I any income other than what is contained in the Schedule here to annexed and by me subscribed viz 1 Sow & 4 young pigs 4 days old $6.00 One old Bed 1 Broken Kettle $3.00 A few articles of furniture Table as old Chair, old Blankett, and Table Cloths which I redeemed since the sale as sold $5.00 with my scanty pension as lacking the agreed it sold for 1 piece of Chair " 75 ––––––– $14.75 The above is the full value of all my property I am viz & destitute & unwell I have nearly lost the power to labor All my children but Florilla are of age. I must depend on charity for support. I hope as I am an invalid soldier that my country will do it. My eight children have all left me & are under no obligation to support me except Florilla my youngest daughter aged 17 years lives with us & she & my wife I myself are all the family & she is quite feeble & unable to labor much neither of my children have the ability to support me & are unable to render support to me my wife abigail is aged 51 years not able to do much being troubled with the rheumatisms. Benj. Moody

I Wait T. Huntington Clerk of the County of Tompkins & Clerk of the Court of Oyer & Terminer & General Jail delivery holden in & for the said County of Tompkins do hereby certify that the foregoing and annexed contain the original proceedings of the said Court in the matter of the application of Joshua Hinkley for a Pension. In testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand and seal of Office this fifteenth day of February in the year of our Lord one thousand Eight hundred and thirty Eight. [signature] W. T. Huntington Clerk In the matter of the application of Joshua Hinkley for a Pension The Court propounded the following interrogatories to the above named applicant which were answered by him under oath in substance as follows viz: 1. Where & in what year were you born? Answer - 1757 19th September. 2. Have you any record of your age & if so where is it? Answer - I have none nor never had any 3. Where were you living when called into service, where have you lived since the Revolutionary war & where do you now live? Answer - In Fredericksburgh Dutchess Co. N.Y. have since lived in New Jersey & now live in I Hector Tompkins Co. N.Y. where I have lived for the last 20 years 4. How were you called into service, were you drafted, did you volunteer or were you a substitute & if a substitute for whom? Answer - I volunteered was not a substitute. 5. State the names of some of the regular officers who were with the troops where you served, such Continental and Militia Regiments as you can recollect & the general circumstances of your service? Answer - Genl Putnam, Genl Warren, Col. Anthony Lamb, Capt. Green, Capt. Reed, and Leut. Wicks. - was in the battle of Bunker Hill. White Plains, Stony Point, Boston.

State of New York Secretary's Office} I certify that it appears by the Military Balloting Book in this Office that Joshua Hinckley was a matross in Colonel Lambs Regiment of Artillery in the Revolutionary War and that Lot No. 46 in the Township of Brutus in the Military Tract containing 600 acres was granted to him by Letters patent bearing date the 9th day of July 1790 - The said patent was delivered to John Watkins. The said Joshua Hinckley was in Captain Reeds Company at the time he was discharged. said muster roll is now in the hands of Anthony Lamb of the City of New York, Son of Genl. Lamb; This deponent upon his oath further deposeth & saith that he is the identical person named in said Muster Roll, that he is the very & identical Joshua Hinkley [Hinckley] who served in the Revolutionary armey, during the Revolutionary war, & the identical person whose name was returned as said soldier of the Revolution. This deponent further upon his oath deposeth & saith that he was personally acquainted in the said Revolutionary armey with Jepthah Lee John Roberson, Reuben Willis, Sergeant Wickes, William Waddell, Soldiers, and that he knew in person many of the officers, Capt. Westbrook & others & that this deponent had frequently Seen Genl. Washington & Genl. Putnam, Genl. Arnold & other distinguished officers. That this deponent had been to Dutchess County and had made other search for witnesses & had not been able to obtain any other than William Waddel whose name will here unto be affixed, that this deponent is very poor, that his family are now supported and are at the County house in the County of Tompkins, where this deponent has been compelled to spend months of his own time & that he now has no other means of subsistence then charity, or at the County poor house [signature] Joshua Hinkley, his X mark Subscribed and sworn before me this Second day of May 1839. [signature] John Ingersoll Henry S. Bishop I certify that I am of opinion that Joshua Hinkley above named, is as old & of the age represented by him in his affidavit for a pension, & that from hearing the conversation between him and the annexed witness William Waddel, I cannot doubt that he is the identical Joshua Hinkley who served in the Revolutionary armey as set forth by him May 2nd 1839 [signature] John Ingersoll Judge of Seneca County Court

Personally appeared before John Ingersoll one of the Judges of the Court of Common Pleas in and for the County of Seneca and State of New York, William Waddel of Lodi in said County a Revolutionary Soldier, & a Pensioner, being duly sworn according to law, deposeth & saith that he was born in the year 1763 and that he enlisted in the Infantry of the Revolutionary army in the year 1780 at Poughkeepsie in the County of Dutchess & State of New York, that he well recollects Joshua Hinkley [Hinckley] as belonging to the Artillery of the United States of the Revolutionary armey, being a private of Capt Reeds Company & Col Lambs Regiment, and that the said Joshua Hinkley whose name is attached to the foregoing affidavit and application for a pension is the identical Joshua Hinkley who served in Capt Reeds Company of Artillery in the Revolutionary army according to the best knowledge and belief of this deponent, and that he has no reason to doubt this fact, and further that from a long acquaintence with the said Joshua Hinkley he has the fullest confidence in the statement set forth by him, that he verily believes the said Joshua Hinkley to be a man of truth and veracity & that full faith and confidence ought to be placed in all that he has stated; this deponent can further say that from the knowledge that the said Joshua Hinkley appears to have of very many transactions that took place for three years or more of the Revountionary war, that the said Joshua Hinkley must have served for three years or more in the Revolutionary Anney as set forth by him, all of which this deponent declare to be true agreeable to his belief. [signature] William Waddel, his X mark Subscribed and Sworn before me this second day of May 1839 [signature] John Ingersoll Henry. S. Bishop

State of Maryland Allegany County I hereby certify that on this nineteenth day of February in the year of our Lord one-thousand eight hundred and twenty, the underwritten Subscriber John J. Jacob came personally before me Lenax Martin a Justice of the peace for the said County and made Solemn Affirmation that he is now a resident of the County of Allegany in the State of Maryland. That inasmuch as his wife is absent and duly infirmed and unable to walk_ that he himself is upwards of 63 years old and full of weakenings and infirmitys that he sees no prospect of a removal from his present dwelling as least for some time to come if ever unless it is to remove into another world and the more especialy as he has taken room in the family with his wifes so, where in her afflicted situation, she is perhaps ,ore agreeable fixed that she could be in any other situation house or place. But this Affirmant Saith he is afraid to use the words "permanent residence" knowing as he does the nuturability of all things on Earth. And this Affirmant further saith that he served as a Lieut in the Sixth Regiment of Maryland troops in the Revolutionary War, that to the best of his present recollection the company was called then Colonels Company and commanded by himself as the oldest Lieut in the Regiment for the last year or two or more. That as he has removed from Virginia to Maryland he wishes and prays to be transferred from the Roll of Virginia. John J. Jacob Taken and Subscribed before me Lenax Martin Seal

[Note: The first line is a continuation of the postscript on the right margin. I have transcribed it with the postscript.] Americans and wounded 59. the Americans pursued the murderers to Boston and killed 65 and wounded 174. The militia collected from all quarters and Boston in a few days was besieged by 20,000 men - Henry, I have stated to you what part I took in Lexington Battle.Your Immortal Governor Throops Message you sent me. I have read it with the highest Satisfaction and it is the best document of the kind I ever read. We don’t forget the old surviving Continental officers and Soldiers that achieved our Independence with their blood and treasure without one Spanish milled dollar who have not yet partaken of the bounty or shared in the Justice of the government He alludes to these who engaged in the struggle for independence at an early stage of the war stimulated by an ardent patriotism without any promise of reward and have therefore not yet been deemed proper objects of remuneration. There services are certainly not less meritorious cause they were disinterested. The US have an exuberant treasury in money and a world of land to dispose of- when one it becomes criminal to plead the cause of a suffering army when their virtues and Patriotism can no longer be safely recorded; the [illegible] enemy has has put her last hand to her barbarous work- all the valuable purposes of society will be wholly indifferent to the old Continental officers and Soldiers- If our honorable Congress wants to pay off the National debt the old Bunker Hill Deputy Commissary prays that our honorable Congress would give him a good farm that the Honorable Browns might live by the sweat of their brows near where the Immortal [illegible] fatherland is who sacrificed his property and spilt his blood to establish our Independence on this day four score and four years old. Through the goodness of almighty God my health has been as good ten years as it ever was. this arm that wielded my sword the first years of our Revolutionary war under the command of the immortal Washington is still strong and nervous to support the Liberties of my beloved country Let justice rulemale and Independence [illegible] [illegible] not men. pray who made man but God. Yet men Make kings at this day to tremble at their [illegible]- Henry, I feel what I write: but here sincerity obliges him to stop. I wish you and your family the greatest blessing that heaven and Earth can afford and remain your affectionate father [illegible][illegible]- Daniel Brown Henry, write me often and send me your newspapers after you have read them-You must excuse my writing for [illegible] and [illegible]-

State of New York Ulster County ss On this Twenty fourth day of May A.D. 1847, personally appeared before me the subscriber a Justice of the Peace in & for the County of Ulster aforesaid & a Magistrate duly authorized by law to administer oaths Elbert Slingerland, who is well known to me to be the Pastor of the Reformed Dutch Church of New Hurley in Plattekill in said County as Certified to in the foregoing certificate and who being duly sworn according to law deposeth & saith the foregoing certificate by him subscribed is true & correct. to the best of his knowledge & belief. William L Jennings Justice of the Peace

and different officers on many occasions during that eventful period following up the Indians and Tories scounting about the country to but owing to loss of memory cannot now momentary describe his said service. Witness isnow on a visit to her friends in this vicinity, Chenango aforesaid, and is therefore very unexpectedly called upon and is not able to brig the events to mind fully, that transpirced so many years ago without having time for reflections. That her said cousin Captain Gilbert Livingston and her cousin the said John Conklin lived neighbors to such others in said War of the Revoltion in said Town of Poughkeepsie. Witness saith that the said John Conklin went from Poughkeepsie aforesaid to live in Plattekill in the County of Ulster at about the time that the said War of the Revolution closed and had lived there but a short time before he married the said Susannah, the sister of Deponet. Witness was present at their marriage and saw them lawfully united toghether by the Rev. Mr. Gutchess who was then the Minister of the Reformed Dutch Church of New Hurley in Platteskill aforesaid. Witness is unable to state the day the month in which this marriage occured but well recollects that they attended the said wedding with slightly and it must thereupon have been in the winter season. They were married soon after the said war closed and in the year 1784. That between forty and fifty years ago. witness moved from Ulster County aforesaid to said Chenango and soon after the said John Conklin moved also from said County of Ulster to Chenango aforesaid where he died as aforesaid. Witness is eighty three years of age and her Cousin the said John Conklin was at least five years older. Need Help? Policy

I Benjamin Moody Junior of Lawful age depose & say that my Father owed me for Cost I had let here over 130$ 1 Cow $15.00 1 Heifer & some debts I paid for him & provision all about 20$ my Br Nathn. Moody, who owns one half of the farm with me having moved out of the country. it cannot be exactly ascertained; what the amount of his claim was, he took a Deal of my Fathers Farm which is situated in Landaff in Grafton County New Hampshire in June 1821 — in payment of our debts, which amounts to the full value of the Farm and more than it would fetch now. said Farm contains one Hundred Acres pf poor, wet Land, very Rocky &uneven situated in a very obscure part of the Town he is now very feeble & infirm & unable to Labor. My mother is aged & cannot do much work. He has no property of any value & needs further assistance of his country for support — a considerable part of my debt was due me before the year 1818 from my father - I have his debts I let him have many [illegible] from year to year ever since I was of age nineteen years since Nathaniel did the same [illegible] did not take the farm until he owed us its full value. Benja. Moody Jr

Commonwealth of Massachusetts. County of Norfolk ss. On this fourteenth day of November in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and thirty two, personally appeared in open court before the Honorable Judge of the Court of Probate now sitting at Roxbury in and for said County John Pope a resident of Dorchester in said County, aged seventy seven who being first duly sworn, according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress passed June 8th A.D. 1832. THAT he was born at Dorchester aforesaid on the fourteenth day of January A.D. 1755, and that there is a record of his birth in said Dorchester; that he was in the United States service from the first day of June A.D. 1775, to the first day of January A.D. 1776--7 months as a volunteer Lieut. in the Massachusetts Militia &: that he was residing at Squantum in said Dorchester when he entered the service; that he was stationed there during said term and served for the period aforesaid under the command of Capt. Payson of Skovon & in Col. Graton's Regiment: that he served at Squantum with none of the regular troops; and no regular officers were known to him: that he was in no battle and at the end of his service received no written discharge: that since the Revolutionary war he has resided at Dorchester aforesaid: & the number of months he served this time was seven--That he has no documentary evidence of this service, nor is there any person known to him by whom he can prove it ALSO: that he was in the United States service from the twenty ninth day of January A.D. 1776 to the twenty-nineth or thirtieth day of March A.D. 1776 as a Volunteer Corporal in the Massachusetts Militia: that he was residing at Dorchester aforesaid when he entered the service; that he was again stationed at Squantum and served for the period aforesaid under the command of Capt. Hopestill Hall & Col. Lemuel Robinson's Regiment: that he served at Squantum with none of the regular troops; and no regular officers were known to him: that he was in no battle and at the end of his service received no written discharge & the term of this service was two months-- ALDO: that he was in the United States serviced from the seventeenth day of April A.D. 1777, to the tenth day of July A.D. 1777 as a Sergeant in the Massachusetts Militia Line: that he was residing at said Dorchester when he entered the service; that he was at Rhode Island and served for the period aforesaid under the command of Capt. Seth Sumner of Milton & Col. Gill's Regiment.; that he marched from Dorchester to Rhode Island, from thence to Dorchester again-: that he served at Bristol in Rhode Island with none of the regular troops; and no regular officers were known to him; that he was in no battle and at the end of his service received no written discharge. time of service two months & twenty three days--

September and 6th March ---Recorded in the Pension Offices on the Roll of Pensioners under act 1343--- Page 65 Vol 1 Book D" Edward C. Clarke, Clerk She further states that she was married to the said John Pope in Dorchester on the fourteenth day of February A.D. 1799, by one Thaddeus Mason Harris a Clergyman and that her name before her said marriage was Sarah Davis; That her said husband died at Dorchester on the thirteenth day of November A.D. 1834, and that she is now a widow. She makes this declaration for the purpose of obtaining the bounty land to which she may be entitled under the act approved March id. 1855-- and she prays that the certificate thereof may be sent for her to Ebenezer Tolman, Dorchester, Massachusetts. Sarah Pope State of Massachusetts County of Norfolk SS. We, Robert Vose and Robert Vose Jr., residents of Dorchester in the States of Massachusetts upon our oaths declare that the foregoing declaration was signed and acknowledged by Sarah Pope in our presence, and that we believe from the appearance and statements of the applicant that she is the identical person she represents herself to be. Robert Vose Robert Vose Jr. The foregoing declaration and affidavit were sworn to and subscribed before me on the day and year above written; and I certify that I know the affiants to be credible persons; that the claimant is the person she represents herself to be and that I have no interest in this claim. Eben Tolman Justice of the Peace

COMMONWEALTH OF MASSACHUSETTS BY HIS EXCELLENCY JOHN HANCOCK, Esq; Governor and Commander in Chief in and over the COMMONWEALTH of MASSACHUSETTS To John Pope Gentleman Greeting. YOU being appointed First Lieutenant of a Company of Militia in the five Months Service at Rhode Island detached to do duty under the Command of Brigadier General de Choisey agreeable to a resolve of the General Court of the 16 June last. By Virtue of the Power vested in me, I do by these presents, (reposing Special Trust and Confidence in your Loyalty, Courage and good conduct) Commission you accordingly.-- You are therefore carefully and diligently to discharge the Duty of a 1st Lieut. in leading, ordering and exercising said Company in Arms, both Inferior Officers and Soldiers; and to keep them in good Oder and discipline: And they are hereby commanded to obey you as their 1st Lieut. and you are yourself to observe and follow such Orders and Instructions as you shall from time to Time receive from me or your Superior Officers. Given under my Hand, and the Seal of the Said Commonwealth, the fourth day of October in the Year of our LORD, 1781 in the Sixth Year of the Independence of the United States of America. John Hancock By His Excellency's Command, John Ivery annexed by S. Leland Judge Probate

Commonwealth of Massachusetts Secretary's Office, March 27, 1833 I hereby certify, that, from an examination of the Books and Documents, relating to Military Services in the War of the Revolution, which remain in this Department, that John Pope served as followsviz, Under Capt Hopestill Hall, in Col. Lemuel Robinson's Regt. in the capacity of a Corporal for the period of twenty three days commencing January twenty ninth 1775, under Capt. Seth Sumner in Col. Gill's Regt. in the capacity of a Sergeant, for the period of twenty five days, commencing April 17th 1777, & under Capt. Raymond De Guiscard in Col. Turner's Regt, as a Lieut., for the period of two months & three days, commencing October 4th 1781. The Christian name of Pope does not appear upon De Guiscard's Roll. Edward D. Bangs

The right side of the page is torn off for several lines, therefore there will be incomplete words] York Pa Oct 29th 1832 [Illegible] Caleb White Sir I read yours[missing] 19th Oct asking for information in a[missing] – and to the marriage between Josep[missing] L Finley & Jane Blair between 178[missing] & 1789 -- There are no public Recor[missing] of Marriages in this County nor in this State, to the best of my knowled[missing]. Revd Dr Cathcart who is now dead has been officiating as Paster of the Presbyterian Church of this place for near fifty years and I Called on his Soninlaw Mr Latimer who has examined the matter and his records and says nothing could found here, he says there was no Presbyterian Pastor in this place previous to Dr Cathcart who came in 92 or 93 The Lums were doubtless members of Carlisle Presbytery, But neither of them ever resided here. There must be some mistake as to the locality. The elder Lum was a friend of Dr Cathcarts and member of Carlisle Presbytery and he thinks had his charge in Center County -- I make no charge in this Case at all but I have for years back recd numerous letters on the subject of Marriage Records -- I am now very thaory getting ready for

State of New Jersey Monmouth county Personally appeared before me a Judge of said County James Otterson who being duly sworn deposeth and saith that he has in his possession the Register of theDutch Reformed Church of Freeholdcontaining among other things a record of marriages solemnized by the respective ministers of said church - that this is recorded in said register the marriage of Johns Voorhees and Maria Laquear on the sixteenth day of May seventeen hundred and eighty five in the hand writing of the Rev. Benjamin Dubois then a minister of said church and that the following extract is a true copy from the said register which is expressed on the record in fair legible words and figures as follows to wit: May 16th 1785 John Voorhees and Maria Laquear. James Otterson Sworn and subscribed before me Judge as aforesaid by the said James Otterson who is a credible person and whose statement is entitled to credit - October 12th 1838 John Hull

New York, Aug 25. 1854 Sir Herewith I have the honor to transmit additional proof of service of Captain Samuel Carhart, John Luqueer and William G. Crawford in the Army of the Revolution. I confidently trust that these positive affidavits will insure a prompt reply. I also send, herewith, proof of service of John Voris (underlined) in the Revolutionary Army, and the identity of his widow Mary Voris. One week since I wrote to Rev. Mr. Willis, present pastor of the Church, for a certified copy of the Register of Rev. Mr. Dubois, but as yet have received no reply. The fact of the marriage is however established by the affidavits of Mrs. Beers on file (a pensioner) and of Joseph Walling herewith sent to you. Yours Respectfully, Wm. Grandin

New York, Aug 23, 1854 Sir John Voris and John Vorhies may have been applied to the same person on the army rolls, but the probability is that they were different persons. Mrs. Voris could not state positively the name of the Captain or colonel under whom her husband John served. So soon as it can be procured, I shall transmit record evidence of the marriage of John Voris and Mary Luqueer, by Rev. Mr. Dubois, whose records are in existence in possession of the present pastor of the church. Also proof positive that John Voris served for more than two years in the Rev. Army. I shall be obliged for an answer in the cases of John Luqueer and William G. Crawford. Yours Respy. Wm. Grandin

Samuel Viall before Lemuel Whitney Clerk of the Supreme Court of Judicature for the County of Windham in the State of Vermont I Lemuel Whitney Clerk of the Supreme Court of Judicature within and for the County of Windham in the State of Vermont -- do hereby certify, that it appears, to the satisfaction of the Court, that the said Samuel Viall - did serve in the Revolutionary War, as stated in the preceding declaration, against the common enemy, for the term of nine months, under one engagement, on the Continental establishment - I also certify, that the foregoing Oath and schedule thereto annexed, are truly copied from the records of the said Court--and I do further certify - that it is the opinion of the said Court--that the total amount in value of the property exhibited in the abresaid Schedule is Forty six dollars and fifty eight cents. In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand, and affixed the Seal of the said Court, on this tenth day of June A. D. 1823. - Lemuel Whitney Clerk of the Supreme Court of Judicature for the County of Windham in the State of Vermont
