Dear Sir I enclose you a statement received from Mr J J Jacob in reply to a letter written in consequence of our late conversation - you will find transcripts as nearly as they would be made from memory of the papers furnished. On the other page you will find the certificate which you were kind enough to say you would receive whereas of the certificate of the Judge of the dispute. If there be any defect in the papers I should esteem it a particular favor if you would mention it to me -- and if the case is of such a (illegible) (illegible) as you think you would consistently with the law of last session receive, I should be very much pleased. The course which Mr Jacobs has taken, arises from his scruples, he is a minister in the Methodist church and altho' he has been unwilling to take the oath prescribed by the rules of the department i was sure he is much now (illegible) of the Bounty of the government, and in truth requires it much more than some of those who have been less conscientious . With sincere respect I am rs Yours ec Edw Colston Jany 22d 1819

[typed] August 31, 1934 xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx John Jeremiah Jacob W. -11930 BA-J/A F. Mrs. H. A. Coward Haverford Pennsylvania Dear Madam: The data furnished herein were obtained from the papers on file in pension claim, W.11930, based upon the military service of John Jeremiah Jacob, during the War of the Revolution. The date and place of birth of John Jeremiah Jacob are not stated, nor are the names of his parents given. He entered the service in the summer of 1776, and was an ensign in Colonel Shryock's Maryland regiment , until about December 5, 1776, when he was appointed 2nd Lieutenant in Captain Hines' company, Colonel Otho H. Williams' Sixth Maryland Regiment; he was commissioned, October 17, 1777, 1st Lieutenant in the same regiment, he was, also, Regimental paymaster; he was in the battles of Brandywine, Germantown, Monmouth, and Camden; after which he was a supernumerary officer. He stated that he served five months as captain, but never received a captain's commission . He was allowed pension on his application executed May 27, 1818, then aged about sixty-one years, and living in Hampshire County, Virginia; he was then referred to as a minister of the Methodist Church. In 1820, he was living in Allegany County, Maryland, with his wife's son; name of wife's son not given, nor is the name of his wife shown, and no further data as to this wife. John Jeremiah Jacob married, July 4, 1821, at

[Note: The top line appears to be a continuation of a separate entry from the left margin of the body of the letter. I have thus transcribed it at the beginning, where it is physically placed. It appears to be unrelated to the body of the letter which itself is a continuation from the previous page of the letter.] The [illegible] [illegible] [illegible] serving against the U.S. is 68,000 dollars for his services in European [illegible] he never said he well knew the story of the two Spanish [illegible]who were sent to ambassadors the Hague [illegible] the pride of their [illegible] [illegible] they did not despise [illegible] [illegible] [illegible] when they question a plain [illegible] and [illegible] them on [illegible] [illegible]own upon Congress to [illegible] [illegible] their [illegible]-on the contrary they cried out with [illegible]never be able to conquer these people we must even make peace with them [illegible] [illegible] [illegible] to the [illegible]and [illegible] for [illegible] they without any provocation upon Lexington Green. There was a Scottish minister in the street encouragin[g] the militia to march onto Lexington in the name of the Lord of Hosts to exterprate the promited murderers from the face of the Earth!-There came on a company of Minutemen the captain desired the minister to pray with and for them and they all kneeled down upon the ground then marched on towards Lexington a few minutes after There was another company arrived which performed the same ceremonies-after prayers they marched off for Lexington-another company soon after came on a soldier leading a grand horse and chaise with a gentleman in the chaise clothed in scarlet surrounded with fixed bayonets stopped at the tavern where I was. I told the captain if I could get a gun I would join their [illegible] as a volunteer-he said it was impossible to get a gun- Sir, you appear to be engaged in our cause-- have taken Sir Charles Burdett an Englishman a prisoner of war he has prevented two companies going on to Lexington by telling them it was a false alarm-Sir, I deliver Sir Charles Burdett into your hands as a prisoner of war to confine him untill called for. I will leave my Sargent to assist you to guard the Prisoner He had a good sword but no gun- I told the Landlord I wanted a room to confine the prisoner; he told me to walk up stairs ;after the Captain had marched on for Lexington about 15 minutes the Sargent went into another Chamber - Sir Charles got up and said that he would go home. I told him that he should not go home he said that he would. I got up to seize hold of him to such of him he struck me around the head with a long hunting whip which made a great whole [sic] round my head- I was a noted wrestler. I sprung upon him like a tiger, flung him down upon the floor and to him by the throat until his face looked as black, as his boot. I asked him what he ment by striking me. The Sargent heard the noise, ran into the room with his sword drawn got off and I will run the blaid [blade] through the body. the British are killing our people and I will kill him. You shall not kill him for he is my prisoner-- The Sargent was a very strong resolute man-- The prisoner begged for his life and I let him get up-- we were called down to dinner the sargent and I dined- I asked the prisoner if he wanted some dinner he said yes. after he had dined I told him to pay for his dinner he said that he had got no money and I paid his dinner. I went out into the back yard and got a hoop pole about six feet long-feeling— the sound of the Cannon and small arms appeared to be nearer- I told the sargent and prisoner to get into the Chaise and if the prisoner tried to make his escape I told the sargent to run him through. [illegible] and I would nock [knock] his brains out with my club. After we rode a few miles the prisoner said that he lived in that house upon the left hand will you not stop and drink a glass of wine. No! I want no -wine— a real Lady ran out of the house screaming and crying Sir Charles what have you done that a man with a drawn sword is at your right hand and a man behind the carriage with a club to nock [sic] out your brains if you try to make your escape. The prisoner asked me he might get out of the carriage and kiss his wife for he never expected to see her again. I told him NO. he kissed his wife and she kissed him and they took their affectionate leave of each other- which brought tears from my eyes: I told the sargent to drive-we stopped at Ames Tavern in Dedham I could hear the Cannon roar 5 or 6 old men ran out of the house that knew Sir Charles two of them with their swords drawn to kill him for they were killing our people at Lexington I told the gentlemen that Sir Charles was my prisoner and they should not kill him. the Sargent and I had hard work to guard our prisoner. we went into the house and told the prisoner to sit in the corner of the room and the Sargent and I would guard him with our weapons. again the old men- they made several attempts to kill him-- no person in the house went to bed that night seventh and that night-- I convinced the old men that it was not right to kill a prisoner- at daylight I delivered up the prisoner to the Sargent and the old [illegible] [illegible] cryed down like a child and said Sir you have saved my life twice [illegible] [illegible] give you any money you ask. I have plenty of money, ask me if you will guard me-I told the prisoner that the old men would do by him as well as I should and set out to alarm the people from Dedham to Hebron to turn out to defend the liberties of their country. I almost spoiled my horse. after I got home I had 2 packets of powder in the garret weighed out by candlelight to [illegible] wanted it set out next day to victual our militia company to Roxbury, etc., etc., etc. Sir Charles was confined in jail for a number of months tryed and acquitted- The first American blood in our Revolutionary war was spilt at Lexington without any provocation by our British bretheren so called they murdered 39 of

Congress appointed Jonathan Trumbull Esquire before he was governor of this State, Commissioner upon [illegible] Brother Joseph Trumbull later Commissary General of the U.S. Later I settled my account with him at Lebanon. The agent collected all the debts due to me when I was a merchant, and paid it over to me when I was in the army and I paid it out to the men I hired, and for the deficiency of Rations that I did not issue agreeable to the act of Congress-The Supplies that I furnished the Army with: and my wages if I remember right amounted to upwards of Five thousand pounds. the Commissioner never found any fault with one of my charges-- He gave me a final Settlement note for Twelve hundred and four pounds on interest, but no time set for the payment. the Commissioner treated me like a Gentlemen and invited me to dine with him, after dinner he asked me if I wanted to sell the note he gave me - Yes part of it I honestly owe to my Creditors in Boston more than three hundred pounds for goods; they went of with the British when they left Boston. as soon as they return to this Country I want to pay them. I agreed them in cash, but they were not there to receive it andI sold to our contractors for ten dollars [illegible] in money and it is included in this Final Settlement note you just give me- what will you the in hard money in the pound for the note. answer the nominal sum what will you give; One shilling and eight pence on the pound. I will rot in jail before I will take that. he said there was no compulsion- I issued provisions at Fishkill [illegible] 6 or 7 months under Commissary General Steward-he paid me my wages in continental money, an old Dutchman offered me one hard dollar for 7 paper dollars, and before I got home I was sorry I had not taken it- when I returned home it was the coldest weather that I ever felt before or since. Tavern keepers were stated and they would not sell at the stated price and I suffered for victuals, and my horse suffered for the want of hay with my pocketfull of [illegible] money. I started one morning at day light and rode three miles and froze both my knees so stiff, that if I bent then thought that they would break off. and from one foot after I got home, I and my Doctor, was afraid that I should lose my [illegible]. I have stated facts upon memory as simple as truth; Pure as light, and level as water. I will not affect a doubt but I have issued more provisions to the army than any commissary in our Revolutionary war for I continued the longest in the service. my Books and vouchers are in the archives of Congress and they will witness for me. I guess that I have been entrusted with a million dollars of Uncle Sam’s property in provisions and money. I never heard one officer or soldier complain of short weight, or measure, and no Regiment ever waited at my store more than three hours for provisions the whole time that I was a deputy commissary. Extract from the Reverend Leo Morse’s history of our Revolutionary war page 320 “The weakness of the [illegible] mention conjunction with flood of certificates or public Securities which Congress could neither fund or pay, occasioned them to depreciate to a very inconsiderable value - the officers and soldiers of the late army and those who furnished Supplies for public emergency were obliged to receive for wages those Certificates or promissory notes when they passed as official, on [illegible] or a tenth of [illegible] nominal value; being thus deprived at once of the greatest part of the reward due for their services; but such as were under the necessity of posting with them, were robbed of that support which they had a right to expect and demand from their countrymen-page 323. The whole history of this Continental paper is a history of public and private fraud- Congress in 1775 Suggested the idea of issuing bills In the purpose of carrying on the war- and this was perhaps their only expedient-money could not be raised by taxation: it could not be borrowed, and on page 327 such is the history of paper money thus far: a miserable substitute for real coin in a country where the reins of government are too weak to compel the fulfillment of public engagements and where all confidence of public [illegible] is totally destroyed - page 319. A remarkable instance of this happened in Connecticut as soon as the tumult of war had but sided an attempt was made to convince the people that the act of Congress passed in 1778 (When I was a Deputy Commissary at Fishkill granting to the officers of the army half pay for life was highly unjust and [illegible]; and that was the first step towards the establishment of pensions and an unreasonable uncontrolled despotism. The Act of Congress passed in 1783. committing half pay for life for five years full pay, was designed to oppose the apprehension of the people and convince them that this gratuity was intended mainly to indemnify the officers for their loss by the depreciation of the paper currency and only to establish a precedent for granting of pentions [sic]-This act however did only satisfy the people who supposed that officers had been generally indemnified for the loss of their pay by the grants made them from time to time by the Legislatures of the several states-besides, the act, while it gave five years full pay to the officers allowing but one year’s pay to the privates. a distinction which had effect in [illegible] escalating and continuing the popular ferment, and one that turned a [illegible] those of the public rage against the officers themselves-I know by four years sad Experience that Camps of all worldly scenes after exhibit the greatest pictures of distress - the sick and the wounded; the dying and the dead; as well as want and sufferings of the living; our Continental Soldiers were almost naked, and bearfooted [sic], in the winter; which brought tears from the Immortal Washingtons eyes; to order them to march against the enemy- Read the address and petition with a pensive mind of our old Continental officers and Soldiers signed by H. Knox-“At this period of the war it is with peculiar pain we find ourselves constrained to address your august body, on matters of a pecuniary nature and objected that the respective States have made settlements, and given bounties for our [illegible]due for part of the time- let the present value of these nominal obligations be [illegible] by the [illegible] men and they will be found little indeed and yet trifling as they are, many have been under the sod near twenty of parting them

State of New Jersey Middlesex County and the said Court do hereby declare their opinion after the investigation of the maker & after propounding interrogatories, to ascertain the truth that the above named applicant Aaron Bloomfield did render services in the war of the revolution in the maner and for the time as in his declaration is set forth and that all sattisfied that he is Sixty nine years of age and that the above named Holloway W. Hunt is a minister of the gospel as he declares himself to be and that the above named Joseph Sophiel and Joseph Freeman are also residents in the County and State aforesaid and are all men of good standing as to character J Ford Jacob Van Sickle Theo James Nicolas Borlam, Peter P. Runyon I, Nicholas Borlam, Clerk of the Inferior Court of Common pleas for the County of do hereby certify that the fore going contains the original proceeding of the said Court in the matter of the application of Aaron Bloomfield in testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand and affixed the Seal of the said Court this twenty first day of December in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and thirty-two N Borlam Clerk

Declaration In order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress of the 29th July 1848 State of New Jersey Middlesex County ⎬ On this twenty seventh day of February one thousand eight hundred and forty nine personally appeared before the subscriber one of the Judges of the Court of Common Pleas in and for the County of Middlesex Keziah Bloomfield a resident of Piscataway in the County of Middlesex and State of New Jersey aged seventy seven years who being duly sworn according to law doth on her oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the ⎬ provisions made by the act of Congress passed the 29th July 1848 That she is the widow of Aaron Bloomfield who was a private in the Revolution and received a pension at the rate of eighty dollars per annum until his death, for his services in the War of the Revolution this declarant would refer the Commissioner of Pensions to her said husbands declaration now on file in the War Department she further declares that she was married to the said Aaron Bloomfield on the tenth day of November one thousand seven hundred and ninety four by the Revd Renne Runyon Pastor of the Baptist Church in Piscataway the place of her present residence that she has no certificate of her marriage nor family record in which her marriage is recorded for the proof of her marriage with the said Aaron Bloomfield this declarant would refer to record of marriages of the said Revd Renne Runyon now deceased an extract of which is proved by Peter R Hanson and Renne D. Runyon

State of New Jersey Middlesex County ⎬ Before me the subscriber one of the Justices of the Peace in and for said County personally appeared Renne D. Runyon who being by me duly sworn according to law on his oath saith I am the grandson of the Revd Renne Runyon deceased formerly Pastor of the Baptist Church in Piscataway I reside in the house formerly owned and occupied by him in the township of Piscataway County of Middlesex I have in my possession the marriage record of my grandfather the said Renne Runyon deceased from which the following what is taken viz "1794 November 10th Aaron Bloomfield St 0.80 Rene D. Huron above named do depose and say that the above is a true extract from the marriage record of the above named Renne Runyon dec'd And I do further say that a large proportion of the marriages in the said record mentions or records the name of the man and does not mention or record the name of the woman Sworn and subscribed Renne D Runyon the 24th day of February 1849 before me Peter P. Runyon Justice of the Peace I certify that Renne Runyon the above named affiant is known to me to be a credible person and that his statements are entitled to full and impartial belief Peter P. Runyon Justice of the Peace

State of South Carolina City of Charleston } Personally appeared before the undersigned Mrs Mary Anthony a resident of Charleston, aged 76, widow, who being duly sworn, deposeth, in relation, to her marriage with her deceased husband John Anthony, and in explanation of the "14 months" in which he was held a prisoner of war, by the British, during the War of the Revolution, Deposeth, that, She was married in a private manner on account of the troubles of the times, and in the City of Charleston at the house of her relations, with whom She was then living namely Mr. & Mrs. Dilkens on the 12th of October 1780, her maiden name was Mary Johnson, She was at the time 19 years of age, her husband was then a prisoner, but permitted to go at large in the City for about 5 months previously. The officiating minister was of the Church of England.. from whence he came with the British Army and returned with it, after the Evacuation of the City. She cannot recall his name, nor did she that, she remembers ever get from him a certificate of her marriage. Mrs Graves, she believes of all those who then knew the circumstances of her marriage now survive; When she accompanied her husband to Philadelphia, She had documents which might have been useful, but most of her papers were lost in that City. Deposeth to the best of her recollection, the American ministers, would not, be allowed by the British to perform the Marriage Ceremony. The Legetimacy of her marriage was allowed and proved by the public acts of South Carolina Legislature, in rescending an order in her favour for some private property of a private nature these documents however She has not on the possession. After the lapse of Seven months, from her marriage as above, her husband sd John Anthony, still refusing to take protection from, or swear allegiance to the British, was after enduring trials & temptations from the enemy, carried with a number of other loyal Citisens & Confined on board the prison ship "Jorbay" where he reamined a

a prisoner for two months to the best of her recollection, this Deponent was there, with him & Mr Joseph Righton & David Hamilton and a number of others as is related in the History of her Country. Thus was he "14 months" a prisoner to wit, 12 months, in the City, and two in the prison ship. This "explanation" she hopes will prove satisfactory to the Department, She has used diligence by examining the records has to obtain some information, But, the hiatus in the parish registereis of the church by a minister of which She was married, the exile of one minister, the suspended faculties of another, -- the confusion of the period, - and the strong testimony of contemporaneous witnesses, together with the certificate already before the Department, and those now sent, will she humbly hopes, be looked upon as the best proof which can be now had from the nature of her case, and induce the Commissioner and the Honble the Secretary of War, to extend her that aid provided by her country, to these accompanying proofs she refers. Mary Anthony Sworn to and subscribed before me this 30 day of May 1838 and I also certify the Credibility of the affiant PCantwell Not.Pub. & D.W. forsd Dist.

State of South Carolina } District of Charleston } 31 May 1838 - Be it Known, that I Patrick Cantwell Not. Pub. & J.U. for Charleston District SoCa hereby certify, that the signature, attached to the certificate proving that in consequence of the British holding possession of Charleston there is no record of marriages between the dates July 22 1780, & 1 July 1781 in the Parish Digests of St Phillips Church in the proper handwriting of Revd C E Gadsden, the Pastor of the same Dated at Charleston this 31 May 1838 -- and given under my hand & seal PCantwell No Pub & JU for Charleston Dist So Ca --

An inventory or Schedule of the Property of James Bishop the above named deponent: vis: One cow: Worth $15.00 One sow and __small pigs 2.00 4 sheep and 4 lambs 3.00 1 table and one chest ( ___ 12 or 13 years old) 1.00 1 small post and kettle one tea kettle Iron 1.50 3 cups & saucers (earthen) cast new 18 1/2 as a__ 0.09 6 earthen plates 0.87 1/2 3 knives & forks handles off a part of them 0.12 1/2 1 wooden bowl 0.06 1/4 1 old bed they have had it 18 years old when purchased ____ 2.00 0.00 1 straw bed 0.50 [total $24.65] verry scanty bedding for the same not enough to be warm in cold weather. verry scanty wearing apparel for myself and my wife. I live in a small log hut for which I pay $1.00 per month. I have an aged wife.. I have no trade by occupation a Laborer. With me and my wife lve 2 small grandchildren whose parents were unable to support them the eldest 5 years of age. I am as old and feeble that I cannot labour but very little and on account of my age few are willing to give me any employ or any thing for it and I am my wife are unable to live without public or private charity James X Bishop his Mark

Western District of Pennsylvania Huntington County, PA On the twenty eighth day of February in this year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and twenty one personally appeared in open Court of Common Pleas of Huntington County before the Honorable Charles Huston Esq. President and David Stewart and Joseph McCune esquires associate judges of the said Court being a Court of Record for said same District Detrich Aurandt aged sixty years, Resident of Morris Township in the said County of Huntington in the said District who being duly sworn according to law doth declare on his oath that he served in the Revolutionary War as follows, viz [sic]: That he enlisted in the American army in January 1778 by Lieutenant Jacob Snyder Captain Wrigley's company, Colonel Stewart's Regiment Pennsylvania Line and after the Battle of Monmouth in Captain John Bankson's company. That his original declaration is dated the first day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen and lists the number of his certificate as a Pensioner as Mo 15037. And I so solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the eighteenth day of March 1818 and that I have not since that time by gift sale or in any manner disposed of my property, or any part thereof with an intent thereby to diminish it so as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress entitled an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War. Passed the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not any property or securities contracts or debts due to me nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed. List of Declarant's Personal Property appraised by James Stewart and John Keller [illegible] 3 Cows at seven dollars each - $21.00 2 Yearling Calfs at four dollars each - 8.00 1 Mare 18 years of age kept for a riding beast - 12.00 One Sow and five pigs - 6.00 One Stove and pipe - 14.00 One Smooth Rifle - 11.00 1 Saddle, Saddle Bags & Bridle - 4.00 1 Small Trunk - 1.50 2 Tables and 1 Chest - 3.00 A Lot of Iron Kettles & Pots - 8.00 1 Fund [sic] Stone - 1.00 Amount carried over - $99.50

at witch plase I finished my suffering there and then went in Malisha Company after the torys and indians and from one of the said torys I Recieved a wound on my head which I will Carry to my grave about fourteen months I was with the malisha and sill had troubelsome for several months on the account of the indians Brakeing out but during these fourteen years I was taken with several others as a prisoner and was sold for Dear Lether owing to same misconduct in our ofisers there names is not on Record in the war Department many other things I cant name the year if it was neasary but (Judge Clay) you have that the matter before you from some Evidence witch I have produced and I have had the plasure of conversing with you on the subject. Your attention in these things will not be forgotten my situation is verry dificult indeed I have a helpless family a old decriped wife, a Daughter Deseased with the Consumpsion and one not able to work and having not a horse cow or hog in the world on the accout of Badluck

[written] This is to certify that I am acquainted with Issachar Cozzens Junr of north Bergen Township residing near Bull's ferry new jersey- and that he has showed me his fathers old family Bible- and that there is in that Bible a family record beginning with " Issachar Cozzens Born August 21st 1754"- "married Mary Daniels November 1st 1778" "Issachar Cozzens Junior was Born at Newport Rhode Island Dec 15th- 1780" Besides the date of the Births of Frederick S. William B and daughter Ellinor F. there is recorded several other children's births and deaths and his second marriage to Susanna Greene- These records all in one handwriting as far as I am able to judge, and the handwriting I do believe to be the same as that attach ed to the bottom (middle part) of a paper setting forth claims to a pension for Revolutionary Services and signed by "Issachar Cozzens". William [illegible] Mabore Minister of the " Grace Church" North Bergen [illegible] N. J. New Jersey Jan 4th 1853

STATE OF CONNECTICUT, County of HARTFORD, ss. Special County Court, or Court of Common Pleas, holden by order of the Chief Judge of said Court, on the first Tuesday of August, 1820. ON this 1st day of August, 1820, personally appeared in open Court, the same Court being a Court of record for said County, having the power of fine and imprisonment, Ichabod Goodrich aged 62 years, resident in Wethersfield in the County of Hartford, aforesaid, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth, on his oath, declare that he served in the Revolutionary War, as follows: That he entered in the service of the United States on the 14th day of February 1777 in the company commanded by Capt Edward Bulkley in the regiment commanded by Col Samuel B. Webb in the line of the state of Connecticut in the Continental Establishment. That he entered in the service of the United States til the 9th of June 1783 when he was discharged at West Point in the state of New York. That he has deposed to the foregoing parts on the 17th day of April in the year 1818 & obtained a pension certificate numbered 1205. And I do solemnly swear, that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March, 1818, and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War," passed on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts, or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the Schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed." Carpenter aged 30 Years, finds his own board and does not help me any more than any of my neighbors and unable the most of the time to do any work but does what he can, but it is as much as he can do to support himself he is so weakly he is free'd from Military duty on that account I have 5 Children from home who are under no obligation to help me and I really stand in need of my Country's bounty Nathaniel Carpenter The following is a Schedule of the whole estate and income of Nathaniel Carpenter of Hanover in the State of New Hampshire an applicant for a pension (his necessary bedding and clothing excepted) made and subscribed by him according to the provisions of an act of Congrefs pafsed the 1st of May 1820 entitled an Act in addition to an act entitled an Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the revolutionary war pafsed on the 18th day of March 1818. I further certify that I have been a member of Mount Bethel Church, since the year 1805, & have known Mrs Rebecca Liddle since that time, as a member of the same Church. She still continues a member thereof & sustains the character of a consistent Christian, & is in good standing as a member of the Church. I hereby further certify that the middle part of the preceding page was written from erroneous information, & has had the pen dashed through it, by several crosses, by my direction, & it constitutes no part of this deposition. Sworn & subscribed at Long hill, Morris County, September 22d 1838.- Before me Daniel Runyon Justice of the peace Andrew Smalley I hereby certify, that I am now, & have been, since April 1827, the Stated Pastor of Mount Bethel Church in Somerset County. I have been personally well acquainted with Mrs Rebecca Liddle, widow of Robert Liddle ever since my connection with said Church. Her character has been uniformly that of a consistent Christian, & she is now & has been from my first settlement in said Church, a member thereof, & in good standing. I also certify that Andrew Smally Esqr the above Deponent, is the regular & stated Clerk of Mount Bethel Church. I have never heard it doubted by any one, that Robert Liddle & Rebecca Liddle his widow, were lawfully married. Sworn & subscribed, at Long hill, Morris County, 22nd September, 1838. Before me Daniel Runyon, Justice of the peace Morgan R Cox I hereby certify, that Morgan R. Cox, whose name is subscribed to the foregoing deposition, is personally well known to me, to be the stated & regular Pastor of the Baptist Church at Mount Bethel, Somerset County.- that he is a man of exemplary character as a Christian Minister, & is in all respects, fully entitled to belief. Witness my hand, September 22 1838. Lewis Condict Personally appeared before the subscriber, a Justice of peace of Morris County, Lewis Condict & made oath in due form of Law, that the certificate by him subscribed, is true. Sworn at Morristown, October 2d 1838, before me, Elijah Ward J.P.

STATE OF VERMONT, Rutland County, ss. On this 26th day of June 1820 personally appeared before the County court for said County of Rutland in open court, (said court being a court of record, agreeable to the laws of this state, having the power of fine and imprisonment, &c.) Ezekiel Bebee aged 66 years, resident in Rutland in said county of Rutland who begin first duly, sworn, according to law, doth, on his oath declare, that he served in the revolutionary war, as follows : in Capt. Robert Oliver Company the 3nd Massachusetts Regt. commanded by Col. Greaton for three years from January 1777 that he made his original declaration on the 31-day of March 1818 has received a Pension Certificate, No. 3012 And I do solemnly swear, that I was a resident citizen of United States on the 18th day of March,1818; and that I have not, since that time, by gift ,sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War", passed on the 18th day of March,1818;-and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other that what is contained in the schedule here to annexed, and by me subscribed, in 50 acres of foor land 2 old mares,1 cow 8 sheep, 1 sucking Colt, 2 shoats, 2 pigs , 1 old wagon, 4 kitchen chairs ,1 old pot 1 old kettle, 1 tea kettle, 1 spider, 1 {?} table, 1 chest, 2 old cases, 2 old knives,1 pitchfork,1 Cero lace, 3 feet of Chain 1 old heavy, 2 pencils 1 old tub, 1 parcel of land in fifth feed containing ,a couch /10, celey bought of the estate of G. Wheeler at 10 dollars, 6 old ceder barrels, 6 dairy feeders, 6 knives +forks, 3 tea pots, 4 kettles pew,1cream pot 6 teacups & saucers, 3 eleap troffer, 3 oven spoons, 1 thrown earthen platter 1 old saddle. My occupation is that of a farmer wife Anges aged 59. is in poor health, related to labor. I have 1 son John living with us aged 14 years. I came in debt to the court of {clecat} 480 dollars as follows to Seth Barlow 38, Abner Moon 20, to J Barrett & Co 20, to E Darling 4, to Ann Bacon 10, to Fred A. Fuller 25.70, to G. T. Hodges & G. T. Hodges & Co. 185.70, to James Porter 154.53 & sundry other debts amount of 22 dollars. Ezekiel Bebee Sworn to and declared on the 26th day of June 1820 before said court. R. Pierpoint CLERK. STATE OF VERMONT, Rutland County, ss. I Robert Pierpoint clerk of the County Court for the county of Rutland do hereby certify, that the foregoing oath, and the schedule thereto annexed, are truly copied from the record of the said court:--And I do further certify, that it is the opinion of the said court, that the total amount in value of the property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule is three hundred forty nine-- dollars. & that said Bebee owes $480- In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand, and affixed the seal of said court at Rutland this 30th day of June 1820. R. Pierpoint

State of New York, Saratoga county. Be it Remembered that on the twenty eighth day of March in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen appeared before me Thomas Dibble one of the judges of the Court of Common Pleas of the County and State aforesaid Samuel Bishop of the Town of Malta in the County of Saratoga and state of New York who being by me duly sworn deposith and saith that he is knowing to James Bishop's having had a fair and honourable discharge particularly purporting to be a discharge for three years services in the war of the Revolution and that the said discharge was in his this ____ ____ and was burned in the house of the said deponent on the 28th day of August 1804 and further this deponent saith upon his oath aforesaid that he knows the circumstances of the said James Bishop and believes him to be actually needy, and in want of assistance from his country for his support. [Signed] Samuel W Bishop Sworn and subscribed this 28th day of March in the year of our Lord 1818 before me Thomas Dibble one of the Judges of the Court of Common Pleas of the county of Saratoga State of New York

yet more and more awful one said my [illegible] a son of temperance and in high office he gets me to do the [illegible] on elections days. O God my soul within me at the very thought that a few short months shall intervene before his poor degraded maniac outcasts from civilized society shall be brought out into the political are like so many race horses [illegible] and--- gorged with alcohol, you may see them prancing and pacing snorting foaming at each successive round and retiring only at dead of night in the dignity of their stations to maltreat the wretched inmates. I share one [illegible] till the cases of the succeeding day shall be repeated. Who among the the weakest capacities does not know that all this lies the dore of our rulers they have issued laws and have no power to repeal them they would have us believe what child close [illegible] yet they say to us be patient wait this great work cannot be accomplished in one hour, this song we have listened to these forty years and all things remain as they were, our glory is departed only in name, our rulers know just how the matter stands banish alcohol and a great [illegible] no prisons no poor house no galos no house of ill fame no blaspheming the name of the Lord but as all these are necessary to a free and [illegible] famed republic we conclude they will be continued Bless for our beautiful America where are the lovers of his youth where are they who endured hardships and went to defend him even those who would extend to him the friendly hand or salute him with words of consolation are loaded with infamy while the finger of scorn are pointed at them forgive this imperfect [illegible] this pen with a trembling hand and the affusions of a mind distracted perhaps I have not addressed you as I should on in your high station but I have told the simple truth as & would me it at the last day I pray will some little word to me that shall give me consolation. I fail in all and have to act with my family for want I will come an die at the shrine of Washington

Belleforte 1st March 1824 Dear Sir, On the other side you will find a petition which I have directed to Congress entertaining a hope that I may get some relief from my present destitute situation I also herewith return the papers in my case, which have heretofore been sent to the pension office. It is impossible for me to prove more than I have done my witnesses are both too old & infirm to recollect the particulars sufficiently it would seem for me to get for me to get my own Troy County in Council --- Could I but have it in my power to appear before Congress, with my White head covered with scars from the wars of my country and that I did that boldly but know personally my object poverty & destitute condition I shall not fear the result. In God my dear Sir do what you can for me & heaven will reward you for it. You will indeed be struggling to cloath the naked and feed the hungry. I thank uou sincerely for your past kindness. and in your past children I thank you sincerely for your kindness Yr old friend John Edmonson

September 15, 1938 XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX JAMES WHALEY W. 2586 BA-J/MLB Mrs. H. C. Groom Box 294 Brownsville, Texas Dear Madam: You are furnished below the record of the only James Whaley found in the Revolutionary War records of this office. The data therein were obtained from pension claim, W. 280, based upon his service in the Revolutionary War. The date and place of birth of James Whaley and names of his parents were not stated. While residing in Jefferson County (probably on Bull Skin Stream) Virginia (later West Virginia), James Whaley enlisted December 10, 1776, served as private in Captain Robert Beall's company, Colonels William Crawford and Russell in Virginia regiment, was at the battles of Brandywine, Germantown and White Marsh and was discharged December 16, 1779. It was stated that he served, also, in 1775, and was at the battle of Bunker Hill, no further details of that service given. The soldier was allowed pension on his application executed April 24, 1818, at which time he was aged sixty-four years and a resident of Wood County, Virginia (West Virginia). In 1830, his post-office address was Parkersburg, that state. He moved October 10, 1832, to Meigs County, this to be near his children, and died in Salisbury Township, in that county, December 4, 1840. James Whaley married March 6, 1808, in Jefferson County, or in Frederick County, Virginia, Elizabeth Hall widow of Benjamin Hall of Jefferson County, Virginia, to whom she was married in 1798 in Prince William County, Virginia, and who died in Jefferson County, that state, March 21, 1807. Elizabeth's maiden name was Page. The date and place of her birth and names of her parents were not given. James Whaley and Mrs. Elizabeth Hall were married by the Reverend Thomas Littleton, a minister of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

This Indenture made this 19th day of June in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eight between James Whaley of the County of Jefferson and Commonwealth of Virginia of the one part and Wm H Harding of the same place of the other part Witnesseth that whereas the said James Whaley married Elizabeth Hall widow of Benjamin Hall & previous to the said Marriage there was an agreement made and entered into by and between the said James and Elizabeth that whatever the said James and Elizabeth that whatever property the said Eliza. should be possessed of should remain and be for the use and behoof her and her heirs. Now in order to carry the said contract into full effect, the said James Whaley for himself his heirs Ex'rs and Adm'rs doth grant and convey unto the said William H. Harding his Heirs exrs and admrs as Trustee for the said Elizabeth Whaley formerly Hall her Heirs & to be by him held in trust for her use and behoof and her Heirs & all the following articles of Property which were her right and title previous to said Marriage viz Two feather beds and bed cloths one mare one cow three bed steads two tables three chests two small spinning wheals [sic] one big ditto six chairs four Iron pots one dutch oven one tea kettle one skillet four washing tubs four pails two basons [sic] three pewter dishes twelve earthen plates one frying pan one reel one pair of flat Irons four barrels one mans saddle one womans ditto one coffee pot

in the schedule hereunto annexed and by me subscribed viz One bed $15. One Cow $12. One Horse $15. 12 head of hogs $12. One Kettle $2. One Oven $2. One Loom $2.50. Five Chairs $2. one Tea Kettle 75 cents. 2 axes $2. 1 Weeding hoe $1. making altogether sum of $66.25 cents. The declarant is by occupation a farmer. His wife is aged 61 years. He has been considerably failing in strength for five or six years past. He has living with him two Children. He has in all 9 children five sons & four daughters. Five of them are married And all are as healthy as men and women Commonly are. He was in the Battle of Guildford under the Command of Col. Campbell, belonging to the Company of Capt. Crane. He was wounded in that Battle by a flesh wound in the leg of no serious injury. Signed. William Cardwell State of Kentucky I George F. Shepherdsville Mar 12 1839 Dr Sir Enclosed are the Papers, Decan [Declaration] & applt. [Application] of Mrs. Famariah Cardwell & afft. [affidavit] of Wm Cardwell for Pension for Mrs. C. I have written twice to the office in Va. sent once a $5. note out of my own pocket in the hope that the Copy of the marriage could be had — Mr. Geo F. Pope wrote also — we cant get any Ans [answer] — I hope sir, however that enough is made out to show from the records of the family Bible as detailed to answer fully the Case — This old lady is quite old & feeble & very poor — and with all an aimable old Virginian whose case really calls for the aid of her government & I hope Sir that you will find no difficulty in being satisfied with her proof & make & send me a note for her Claim so soon as you possibly can give her claim an Examn. If however by any stern rule or opinion you cannot deem her proof sufficient please advise me and write me this defect — Tho [Though] I am quite sure none can be had — and I confidently hope you will pass this claim very early on acct of the actual want of this truly needy old lady I am Yr Obt Svt [your obedient servant] Noah C Summers J L Edward Comm Pens.

their names written therein, but Mr Condict does not appear, he having served a part of the years 75 & 76, & none in 77. This is all the testimony of my husbands service in my knowledge, & it is not probable that I shall be able to find any other. Mr. Condit died within a few weeks after his deposition was taken, & Saml Allen before the widows law had passed. These were the only comrades of my husband, known in this quarter as living, within a few years. The Osborns, two Woolley's, Isaac & Jacob, Stephen Goble, Saml Wood, Jacob & Benjamin Beagle or Beale, Joseph Shipman, Ephraim Fairchild & others belonging to the same co. living within a few miles of us, were well known to my husband & to myself, & not one of them is now living as I verily believe. It is impossible for me to say with any precision, how many years of actual service my husband performed, but I am confident he fulfilled all his engagements to serve. Whether his enlistment under Col. Ogden was for one year only, or for a longer term, I cannot now tell. He was occasionally at home a few days on furlough or parole, & immediately returned to his duty, as a Sergeant in his company, as I always understood; & it is my belief, that his actual service exceeded three years in the war of the revolution. I have heard him speak of skirmishes & battles, in which he was engaged, viz: Mounmouth, Trenton, German town, Brandywine & others not recollected. I am very needy, as well as aged, have no home of my own, but live in a small cabin not my own. I have had 10 children, 6 of them now living, all poor & unable to assist me, & I greatly need whatever pension my Country may allow me for my husband's service in its defence. I was married to my husband, the said Robert Liddle, in August, 1771, when I was 19 years & three months old, by Revd Mr Crossley, Minister of the Baptist Church, called Mount Bethel Church, in Somerset County New Jersey. Beside the family, there were present at our marriage, John Stephens, Mary Sutton & Elsey Ingard, not one of whom is now living. William Cozad was my father, who lived near to the Bethel Church. All the family except myself are dead. I understand there is no parish record of the marriages of that time, nor have I any family record in my possession of our marriage, or of the births of my children. My husband was many years a Constable in Somerset County, & had a book or volume of the Laws of New Jersey, in which he had written down, the time of the birth of our children. I do not know whether it contained the time of our marriage or not. He sold the Law book many years since, & who bought it, or whether it is in being, or where it now is, I know not. It was the only family record we ever had.

State of New Jersey Morris County ss: Before me, Daniel Runyan Esqr a Justice of peace in & for said County, personally appeared Isaac Smalley of Warren township Somerset County, a neighbour of mine, living within [blank] miles of me, & personally well known to me as a man of truth & irreproachable character, who being by me duly sworn according to law, on his oath saith as follows, viz: I am in the 83d year of my age. was a soldier of Somerset Militia in the war of the revolution, & was personally well acquainted with Robert Liddle in time of the Revolutionary war & before that period. I was also personally acquainted with Rebecca Cozad, before her marriage to said Robert Liddle. we were all young people, living in the same township & County, viz: Somerset, where I now live & have spent my life, & we were in the habit sociable & friendly intercourse. The said Robert Liddle & Rebecca Cozad were married & lived together as husband & wife before the revolutionary by an [?]. They lived near Mount Bethel Church, & had one or two children together, born in wedlock as I believe, before the war began. Said Robert Liddle was an enlisted soldier on the Northern expedition against Canada, & served as a Sergeant as I always understood & believe, in Capt Howell's co. & in Col. Winds' regiment, for the term of one year. He went away from home on that service as was universally said & believed, a little before Christmas, in the year 1775, & returned at the same period in 1776. When he left home on that expedition in 1775, he left his wife & two small children in my neighbourhood. And after his return from Canada, he continued in the Continental army & service as a Sergeant during a considerate part of the war, but how long I am unable to say. Said Robert Liddle moved with his family from Somerset Co. to Morris township in Morris County, about the year 1796. They resided when in Morris Co. not more than 4 miles from me & I knew him & his whole family well, to the time of his death, & up to this time. They raised a large family of sons & daughters, & no one has been heard to question their marriage as I believe. They always lived together reputably, & respected by their neighbours, as husband & wife. Robert Liddle died at his residence in Morris township, in the winter season, between 25 & 30 years ago, & the above named Rebecca Liddle, has not since his death married, but continues his widow to the present time. She is very poor & needy, but is much respected as a woman of fair & unblemished reputation. They were married by Rev'd Mr. Crossley, then Minister of the Baptist Church, called Mount Bethel, to which I belong, & there is no record of marriages solemnized by Mr Crossley. his Isaac + Smalley mark Sworn & subscribed, at Long hill, this 22d September, 1838. Daniel Runyon Justice of the peace

Schedule, One House and Lot; 2 Walnut Tables & Leather Bottom chairs (old) 2 Split bottom do [ditto]. 1 Loom and harness. 1 Quill wheel and swifts 1 Clock 1 cow and two calves 1 old desk 1 Bible and some religious Books, Debts due me about Ten Dollars against which is to be set off debts due by me, besides the purchase money of the said house and Lot upwards of $100. Signed Smith Thompson Sworn to and declared on the 24th day of July 1820 before the said Court of Augusta County Teste Erasmus Stribling I Erasmus Stribling Clerk of the County Court of Augusta, do hereby certify, that the foregoing oath and declaration schedule thereto annexed, are truly copied from the record of said Court; and I further certify, that it is the opinion of said Court that the total amount in value of the property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule is Seven Hundred and sixty Dollars, and that the said Thompson is not able with all his property to support himself and family without the assistance of his country, In Testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand and affixed the seal of the said Court on this first day of August in the year of our Lord One Thousand Eight Hundred and twenty Erasmus Stribling Clerk of the County Court of Augusta

On the 1st of April, 1778, I was drafted for two months into a company of militia commanded by Capt Wm. Hungtington of said Lebanon now decd. Simon Crocker was Lieut, the Ensigns name I cannot recollect, the company were stationed in New London in Connt. We were frequently marched to Fort Trumbull & were on guard in the fort, but the company was not stationed in the fort. Col. Wm Ledyard was commander of the station in this tour, as in all the others, was a Drummer. The whole time of my actual services have been two years & fifteen days. Tho my enlistments were for but twenty three months & fifteen days. But I did one months duty in the hospital (after my time of enlistment expired by order of Capt Clark, who was a very meritorious officer) I was a drummer all the time except the one month aforesaid in the hospital. My pay was seven dollars & 34 cents, or forty four shillings per month - lawful money. But I received my pay in Continental Money & realized little or nothing for my services. I was born in Lebanon aforesaid on the 9th of June 1756 as my mother always told me & in my bible. She is dead. My father died when I was nine months old, he returned to Lebanon sick from the Old French War & died soon after his arrival home. He was a soldier in that war. I have ever resided in said Lebanon where I now live. I am well known to the Rev Edward Bull a Clergyman in said Lebanon & to W. T. Williams of said Lebanon & I do hereby relinquish all claims whatever to a pension except the one now claimed. Sworn to & subscribed the day & year last aforesaid & my name is not on the agency of Connecticut or any state. Asahel Gay Sworn to and subscribed the day & year aforesaid. Mr. Edward Bull a Clergyman resident in Lebanon and Wm. T. Williams of Lebanon, residing in the same town, hereby certify that we are well acquainted with Asahel Gay who has subscribed & sworn to the above declaration. That we believe him to be now seventy seven years old. That he is reputed & believed in the neighborhood where he now resides to

of an amendment to the law, or a new construction having been applied thereto-- When the war was ended, & the implements of death, were to be converted into the implements of husbandry & the war worn soldier was to be transformed into a peaceful citizen-- I returned home to the same house; which, I had left years before; then with a knapsack, a loaf of bread & a peice of bailed pork-- now with a country redeemed from tyrany & a soldiers honour but, without clothing, without money, nothing in my pockets but my certificate of discharge & a government note for my wages, which she was utterly unable to pay at that time-- By reason of her inability to pay, and my own poverty pressing hard upon me, I was obliged to sell her paper, for what, I could get in the market, which was precisely five pounds New York Currency or, Twelve dollars & fifty cents; this amount, with the pension for a short time as above stated is every cent, that, I have ever received for seven years service, of uncommon hardship, imminent danger & unequalled privation-- Well may it be said of the American Army that they lost all, except their Country, their swords, and their honour-- After resting a short time at the house of Moses Bull & delivering my certificate of discharge & government note to his wife for safe keeping, them, I proceeded to the house of William Shaw who resided in the upper part of the same town & who came from the same part of Ireland, that, I did; & went to work for him on his farm-- After remaining in his & others employ for 2 to 3 years I married, then purchased about 48 acres of new & uncultivated land, adjoining the farm of the said William Shaw, erected me a small Loghouse thereon, brought my wife into it, & began to clear away the forest & improve the land-- this house the same that was burnt with the whole of its contents-- this service resident threw me again pennyless upon the world and

That since the exhibition of my First Schedule the Following changes have been made in my Property - Property & names of Persons to whom sold. | Time of Sale | What Recd in Return Sold to Horace Chapman half an acre of land for $25 - - | 27 March 1822 - | Avails applied in payment of a debt I owed to the Firm of M & F Pratt - sold to John S Chapman twelve acres of Land for $145.33 - | April 15 - 1822 - | The avails of this sale were paid to Wm Carter Esq in payment of a debt I owed him to that amount - sold to Cornelius Chittenden 30 acres of Land for $160 - | April 1st 1824 - | Chittenden paid a debt of $110.47 which I owed to Jonn Lay Esq & the remainder of the sale I recd in Cash - Sold to Cornelius Chittenden ten acres of Land with house and Barn thereon for $200 - | April 13 - 1824 - | $197.23 - were applied on a debt I owed said Chittenden the remainder was pain me in cash The Cash which I recd on the two last mentioned sales was applied in discharge of a debt which I owed to the Firm of Pratt & Sons [crossed out] Elliott & C of about $50 - Sold to Charles Chapman horse Cart and Plough for $45 - - - - - | 3d of April 1824 - | $45 applied towards notes which I owed sd Chapman All the Cattle, Sheep, and Swine mentioned in my first Schedule have [illegible, crossed out] ^been Killed and Sold at various times and wither consumed in my Family or applied in payment of debts or in purchasing the necessaries of Life - - Three old cider Barrels 1 old Barrow and one waggon have been worn out and become useless - and several articles of Crockery

with said guard from said Manchester to said Castleton where they remained & were stationed for 7 or 8 weeks according to his orders & there returned with his s'd guard to said ['Manchester' crossed out] said Arlington & they were dismissed, he having been absent upon said service about two months in the whole afterwards, some time about the latter part of Nov'r of this same year 1778. he was again called upon & turned out at said Sunderland with his said Company of Vermont militia, under the command of Eli Brownson then a Lieut of said company, & marched once more from said Manchester to said Castleton about where they were stationed 7 or 8 weeks when they were dismissed by parol & he returned to said ['Manchester' crossed out] Sunderland having been absent upon said last expeditionals about two months - that some time on or about the 1st day of June in the years 1779. he turned out in company with Martin Powel Esq'r to go in pursuit of some Tories, who had taken & detained as Prisoners Jose'h Ormsby of said Manchester & Abner Blanchard of Arlington in the same County - & they pursued & overtook the said Tories, & brought them back to said Arlington, where they kept & guarded them for 7 or 8 days - that he was absent on said expedition & service from home, at least one fortnight that during all the expeditions & services above detailed & many other short tours of duty not distinctly stated he held the rank & did the duty, & acted throughout the whole in the capacity of a Sergeant - he also turned out at several other times, & did other short tours of duty ['duty' crossed out] during the revolutionary war - that he has no documentary evidence to support his said statements - & that he knows of no living witnesses whom he can produce to prove his said services except a small part thereof, but thinks he shall be able to show by the testimony of Lieut. Elijah Burton of said Manchester, who has been a near neighbor to him for almost the whole time since he first removed to said town of Manchester, the whole of the greater part of his said services for the 1777. & a general knowledge or understanding of his other service above stated that the only Clergyman now residing in said Town of Sunderland is the Rev'd William Mark of the ['Baptist' crossed out] Methodist Church, & he is at present purported to be for sometime known about from said town, but he thinks that he shall be able to show by the Rev'd Abraham Brownson, a Clergyman of the said adjoining town of Manchester & many others respectable neighbors of that or this town, the general repute & understanding of his said services - He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present, and declares that he name is not om the pension Roll of the agency of any state. /s/Lemuel Bishop Sworn to & subscribed the day & year aforesaid by & before Myron Clark Judge of Probate Court We Abraham Brownson a Clergyman, residing in the town of Manchester in the County of Bennington & State of Vermont & Horatio Chipman of said Sunderland hereby certify that we are well acquainted with Lemuel Bishop who has subscribed & sworn to the above Declaration - that we believe him to be 85 years of age - that he is reputed & believed in the neighborhood where he resides to have been a soldier of the revolution & that we concur in that opinion /s/A Bronson /s/Horatio Chipman Sworn & subscribed the day & year aforesaid before /s/Myron Clark Judge of Probate Court

(16,788) John Morley, Private. Original claim served from Decr. 1775 to January 1777 Admd. [illegible] 1st Schedule, dated Decr. 1820. Runs thus: 65¾ acres of Land which is mortgaged to the State of Connecticut for its proportional amount, a part of 786 acres, to secure the payment of $856. (evidence of Mortgage within, duly authenticated- and Genl Perkins, Agent for the State of Cont. sworn May 12, 1821 that the Land is still encumbered with the Debt due to the State of Connecticut that the whole sum of the bond is yet due, & about $100, interest, & that the bond is in his hands.) The above 65¾ acres of Land, with a Log Cabin & improvement is valued in schedule at- $230.50 A note of hand due applicant 28.00 Steers $35. Cow $10 pigs $6 51.00 Sundry articles of furniture 56.44 Amount of Schedule $365.94 He owes for the said 65¾ acres of Land $158, in two Notes of Land for $79, each, bearing interest from Apl 1818 He owes to various individuals na[illegible] given) $263.75 over/ 2d Schedule, dated June 25, 1823. A Cow, calf, steer & Heifer, valued at - $24, Sundry articles of furniture - 59.83 Total - $83.83 The changes in his property since his 1st Schedule have been as follows- - 33 acres of Land, sold Apl 19 1822, to Joel Morley, to discharge a debt due him for 4 years services, being $180- - 1 pair of oxen, sold Sept 20, 1823 to John Barnes for $50, indorsed(?) on a Note Barnes holds against(?) me(?) for $79, dated Apl. 1818 - 33 acres of Land, sold April 9, 1823, to John Barnes, for my two notes to said Barnes, dated April 1. 1818, one for $79 & one for $79.35, on both of which was due on the 29 April 1823, a balance of $141.62, not being able to pay for Land- His age 70-a Cooper, by occupation- unable to pursue his trade- Wife 69 - & a Grand Daughter aged 9 years- George Parsons Esqr(?) Warren Ohio

D. one thousand eight hundred and fifty three, personally appeared before me Samuel Beonig residence of [illegible] within and for the county and State aforesaid, Issachar Cozzens Junior, a resident of the township of Mount Bergen in the county of Hudson and State of New Jersey aged 72 years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath make thefollowing declarartion in order to obtain the Benefit of the Provision made by the Act of Congress passsed June 7th 1832 in favour of Pensions, which he considers due tohis father Issachar Cozzens Senior (deceased) for service during the Revolutionary War. Personally and subscribed before me this twelth day of Febuary A. D. Eighteen hundred and fifty three Samuel Beonig Justice of the Peace Declaration of Issachar Cozzens Junior for the Hours of Issachar Cozzens Senior deceased my father Issachar Cozzens Senior was Born in Providence Rhode Island August 21st 1754, and married to Mary Daniels Nov 1st 1778, she died Oct 15th 1798; he then married Susanna Greene Oct 20th 1799--I have thy record in his Family Bible, which is now in my possession-it is in his own hand writing-- In the year 1833 when my Father was nearly 80 years of age, he dictated a Statement which I herwith said in which he describes part of his Services in the army, his manner of joining it and gives the names of the officers who commanded in the Rhode Island Line at that time This statement shows that he was a resident of Newport Rhode Island at the time he entered the Service in 1775-it is signed by himself and is herewith respectfully submitted for your consideration- Clarkson Crosby[?] (an old resident of New York city and for a long time a member of the State Legislature of New York) and the Revd Benjamin Mortimer, pastor of the [illegible] church in New York city, gave my father certificates of character for veracity [illegible] these vouchers and his declaration papers were sent to the War office at Washington and were said to have beenlost or mishanded-- Mr Cousins and the Revd Mr Martimer have been several years although my father makes no mention of it in his

To pay him Swinson sold his horse to Andrew Spruill for $30, took his notes, passed the notes to White: White promised to pay the Balance $6,,50 to Asa Hardison for Swinsons acct; He did not do so: Hardison Warranted Swinson and made him pay him otherwise. Swinson therefore ^[insert] thinks White owes him $6,,50 from that time. But White alledges that he lost more than that sum in the notes against Spruill and so the matter stands. A Claim against Henry Hardy since first of 1822 for here Horse and Cart; for some Brandy; and for a trespass in taking fodder - Supposed balance all things settled $15 and very doubtful if it be ever paid -- A Claim against Brightman Hardison by Note dated about the fall of 1821.
