State of New York Otsego County Ss Lewis Hyatt of the town of Otego aged 41 years being duly sworn according to law deposeth and saith that he is the son of Samuel and Judy Hyatt and that his father Samuel Hyatt is now dead and died a United States Pensioner and that his mother is still living and is the widow of the said Samuel Hyatt and lives in this deponents family and that she has an old bible in her possession in which there is a Record made in the hand writing of his father now deceased in which he the states in said Records that he Samuel Hyatt was married to Judy Pope November 6th A.D. 1782 at Norwalk and he this deponent well Remembers to have seen the said Record in the Bible aforesaid ever since he was old enough to Read writing and presumes his father wrote the names there at the time he was married And this deponent further deposeth and says that he has been to Norwalk and within the year past and searched the town and Church Record, but could not that find any Record of his Father and Mother marriages and further saith not Lewis Hyatt Subscribed and Sworn this 28th day of October A.D. 1837 Before me James C Walworth Judge of Otsego County Courts I certify that I am well acquainted with Lewis Hall the above deponent that he is a very intelligent Credible person & c J.C. Walworth Judge

Elisabeth Primus of Charlestown in the County of Washington and State of Rhode Island on Oath saith that she is 78 years of age and that she the Deponent is intimately acquainted with Sarah Watson of Charlestown in said County of Washington who before her marriage was Sarah Nokey and this Deponent has been so acquainted with the said Sarah from her childhood and knows that the said Sarah at said Charlestown in the month of April 1799 was lawfully united in marriage to one Thomas Watson then of said Charlestown and who before that time had been a revolutionary soldier and the deponent saith that she was present and saw the said Thomas and Sarah united in marriage as aforesaid by Rev John Seketer then an ordained minister and Pastor of the Baptist Church in said town of Charlestown now deceased and the Deponent further saith that the said Thomas Watson died at South Kingston in the month of September 1822 and that the said Sarah has eversince remained a Widow her [Signature] Elisabeth X Primus mark Witness [Signature] Dan King [Signature] [illegible] King Washington Sc State of Rhode Island at Charlestown November - 8th 1838 Personally came before me Elisabeth Primus the above named deponent who upon oath by me administered to her

Daniel Dick of Charlestown in the County of Washington and State of Rhode island on oath saith that he is 72 years of age and that during the revolutionary war and subsequently this Deponent was intimately acquainted with Thomas Watson late of said Charlestown now deceased and know that the said Thomas at said Charlestown in the month of April 1792 was lawfully united in marriage to one Sarah Nokey now Sarah Watson and that the said marriage was solemnized by Rev John Seketer then an ordained minister and Pastor of a Baptist Church in said town of Charlestown now deceased at which time and place the Deponent was present and saw the aforesaid Thomas and Sarah united in marriage and the Deponent further saith that the said Thomas Watson died at South Kingston in said County of Washington in the month of September 1822 and that the said Sarah has eversince remained a widow his [Signature] Daniel X Dick mark Witness [Signature] Dan King State of Rhode Island &c Washington Sc Charlestown August 6th 1838 Personally came before me Daniel Dick the above named deponent who upon oath by me administered to him gave and subscribed the preceding deposition which was by me taken and reduced to writing I also certify that the said Daniel Dick is well known to me that he is a person of veracity and that his testimony and preceding deposition are entitled to credit [Signature] Dan King Justice of the Peace

Eunice Rodgers in the County of Washington and State of Rhode Island on oath says that she is 69 years of age and that she is well acquainted with Sarah Watson a woman of colour who is the widow of Thomas Watson formerly a revolutionary soldier but now deceased and that she has been acquainted with the said Sarah from her childhood And the Deponent saith that in the month of April seventeen hundred and ninety two at said Charlestown the said Sarah was lawfully united in marriage to Thomas Watson aforesaid and that the marriage was solemnized by Rev John Seketer then an ordained minister and pastor of a Baptist Church in said town of Charlestown but is now deceased And the Deponent further saith that the said Thomas Watson died at South Kingston in said County of Washington sometime in the month of September that the said Sarah has ever since remained a widow her [Signature] Eunice X Rodgers mark Witness [Signature] Dan King Washington Sc Charlestown in the State of Rhode Island August 7th 1838 Personally came before me Eunice Rodgers the above named Deponent who upon oath by me administered to her gave and subscribed the preceding Deposition which was by me taken and reduced to writing I also certify that the said Eunice Rodgers is well known to me that she is a person of veracity and that her testimony and preceding deposition are entitled to credit [Signature] Dan King Justice of the Peace

I Moses Stanton of Charlestown in the County of Washington and State of Rhode Island on oath depose and say that I am the settled and ordained minister of the Baptist Church in said Charlestown over which Elder John Seketer was formerly settled and ordained and upon examination of the Church records left by the said Elder Seketer I cannot find any record of the marriages solemnized by him or any other minister of said Church nor have I recorded any marriages which I have myself solemnized I further say that for many years past I have been well acquainted with Sarah Watson widow of Thomas Watson late of this town deceased In the lifetime of the said Elder Seketer she was admitted into this Church and has continued to the present time an exemplary member of it and during more than thirty acquaintance with her I can cheerfully say she has ever sustained an unblemished moral and christian character Her husband the said Thomas Watson died I think in 1822 During their intermarriage she became the mother of a numerous family twelve or thirteen in number as I have been informed Thomas Watson was a very poor man had no education and was somewhat intemperate and as I have understood most of his children left him as soon as they could take care of themselves It is supposed that four of the oldest are dead others if living are in the Western States or gone to parts unknown and some when last heard from followed the seas one of the youngest children still lives in this town I do not know of any record of any their ages nor is it probable there is any [Signature] Moses Stanton

State of New Jersey, Morris County ss: Before me Daniel Runyan Esq a Justice of peace in & for said County, personally appeared Andrew Smalley Esq a Justice of peace in the County of Somerset, a man known to me to be a man of truth & of irreproachable character, & who being by me first sworn, on his oath saith as follows viz:- I am in the 51st year of my age, I live in Somerset County, belong to the Congregation in said County, called the Baptist Church or Society, at Mount Bethel, & am the Clerk of said Church & Congregation, & have in my care & keeping as Clerk thereof the books & records belonging thereto. And I hereby certify, that the Revd Mr Henry Crossley, was the stated Pastor or Minister of said Congregation, before the war of the Revolution, & until the year 1780. I also certify, that there are no records belonging to said congregation, which furnish any account of Marriage by Mr. Crossley, or by his successors, prior to the year 1827, & it is my belief, that no marriage record whatever was kept by said Mr Crossley, during his ministration at Mount Bethel. [The remainder of this page is crossed out] And I hereby further certify, that I was personally well acquainted with Robert Liddle & with Rebecca Liddle his wife, now his widow. They lived together many years as husband & wife, in Smalley town, near Mount Bethel in Somerset Co. & within [blank] miles of my dwelling. They raised a large family of children, & it was never doubted by any one in my knowledge that they were lawfully married. I have known them living together in that character not less than [blank] years, before the death of said Robert Liddle, which took place in Morris township almost 30 years since, where they removed about the year 1796. Robert Liddle was always reputed & believed to be soldier in the war of the revolution by all the older people of the Neighborhood, & I believe no one doubts it. His widow, Rebecca Liddle, has not married since his death, but remains his widow to this day, as I verily believe, & lives in the township & County of Morris, in very indigent circumstances, & justly needing the benefit of the Pension Laws, if from the service of her husband she is entitled thereto. And I hereby further certify that in the original Church word, now in my possession as Clerk, I find the following entry - viz: "December 24th 1803. the Church meet the day before sacrament "according to our common practice; after Divine service, came "forward, Rebecca Littell the wife of Robert Littel & examined, & gave a "general satisfaction to the Church & was baptized the same day."

gift, sale or in any manner disposed of his property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring himself within the provisions of an act of Congress entitled An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and Naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary war"" passed on the 18th day of March 1818 and that he has not, nor has any person in trust for him any property or securities, contracts or debts due to him; nor has he any income, other that what contained in the schedule hereto annexed and by him Subscribed 100 acres of third rate land, with the improvements worth $150 Mar worth & 1 Cow worth 10 Heifer worth 8 $ 2 yearling Calves together $ 35 4 Head of Sheep worth 12 4 Household furniture, Beds & Bedding excepted) to the value of - 12 Farming utentials such as plongly, May and years worth 23 debt on open and due to him to out of 33 Rible and some other old Books with some old buy lumber worth 11 the said Benjamin Peachy also states on oath that he is the following debts is one of 19 and one of 33 $ being Q. two notes he gave for the purchase of the one hundred acres of land above named amouting both together to $152 One other debts due but us obligation given for it. 15 Doctor fees unsetled supposed to act to 20 or 20 pay 2250 the said Benjamin Peachy further states on oath that he is by occupation a farmer, and himself in tolerable health and strength or about as labouring men of his age generally are, that his family consists of a wife, who is entirely helples having been confined to her bed for more than eighteen month, and Grand daughter named Lydia Peach about Eleven years old. - That the foregoing statement exhibit a full true and correct estimate of his property and debts of all and every kind he one on earth, and following how the debts which he owes, with the exception of the pension that may be coming to him .

. some assistance from the County Court, two of his neighbors came in to prove his poverty and distress and the situation of his wife, these facts were also well known to King a Magistrate on the Purch Octor being the Court of Claims and at which the levy was said, being but a senall depontee the Court allowed him $20. which certenty is not one fourth sufficient to maintan him and his wife in their partie helpless situation. If there is a revolu timony soldier in the U.S. that really need the Benefit of the pension Law Peachey is one. The letter of the seat of war, informing him of being struck from the list you will see is referred to in his petition that letter filed with a former petition addressed to the heat of war, seting forth more fill his situation and the situation his wife the all of which is supported by the Testimony of 324 of his neighbours

The State of New Jersey Cape May County ss ⎬ Personally appeared before the Court in open Court Joshua Crawford aged fifty three years who being duly sworn according to law upon his solemn oath did depose and say, that he is the son of Richard Crawford deceased the late husband of Sarah Crawford the above applicant for a pension. That he the said Joshua is president of the board of trustees of the Baptist Church at Cape May Court house, and has in his possession the books of and belonging to said Church and also that he is acquainted with the hand writing of David Smith late a minister of the Gospel and the settled pastor of the Baptist church of the Court house, and the certificate of Marriage of Richard Crawford and Sarah Crawford is in the hand writing of said David Smith and hereunto annexed marked A. that he has often heard his father Richard Crawford and others say frequently that the said Richard served the whole war of the Revolution, that in some engagements he was wounded in the hip, but can't say what- that he has heard the said Richard and Nathaniel Holmes and Humphry Stiles frequently state, that they three were in prison about Eighteen months at Antiga- that the Said Holmes and Stiles have since deceased

I William Hillhouse of New Haven in the State of Connecticut testify that as far as I had any concern with or knowledge of the facts stated in the foregoing deposition of Mr. Jesse Gilbert, the same are truly stated. I further testify that said purchase made by me of said lot of land from said Ichabod Goodrich was a real bonafide purchase and at the price therein stated. That I should not have given said two hundred and fifty dollars, (which was paid and secured as stated in said deposition), for a lot had I not owned said other seven lots. And I am fully persuaded that no part of what was given for the purchase of said lot came or was intended to come into the hands of said Goodrich but that the whole was meant to be and was actually applied to advances which had been before that time made to and for him to pay the taxes and expenses on said lot and for his necessary support, and to save him from suffering, and which I understood from said Goodrich & Mr. Buckley at the time exceeded the value of said lot. From the acquaintance which I have had with said Goodrich and from what I saw and observed I feel myself constrained to say that I think him a truly meritorious applicant. In addition to his being destitute of the means of subsistence (which is undoubtedly to be attributed to the [illegible] of time & property which he made while serving in the Revolutionary war, for which he received a mere nominal compensation) he appears to be laboring under the infirmities of a constitution impaired and broken by the hardships and privations to which he was exposed in long series of faithful services, of which our country and now enjoying the rich profits. That he asks us but a pittance of what he is in justice entitled to. William Hillhouse United States Ss District of Connt Sept 10, 1827 Sworn before me by Wm Hillhouse Esq counsellor & atty at law to me personally known. Wm Bristor District Judge of said Dist of said District of Connt

Hyatt Banks aged Seventy four of the Town and County of Fairfield State of Connecticut being under oath depose and say- That Joseph Perry decd late of sd Fairfield performed military duty and was a fellow soldier with me at Mill River now Southport in the sd State of Connecticut during the war of the Revolution- We were stationed there as a guard under the im ediate command of Sergeant John Parsons. I do not recollect who was the Captain of the company to which sd Guard belonged but think it was Capt Eliphalet Thorp The sd service was performed about the time of the surrender of Cornwallis I think it was in the fall of the year I do not recollect the particular year cannot recollect the length of term of Mr Perry's service but it was not less than two months should think it was three or more I can also testify that I was present at the Marriage of Joseph Perry with Mary Alvord who then a widow of a Mr Alvord, his Christian Name I do not rellect, her maiden name was I think, Beers think she had a child or two by her first husband Alvord, but am not positive as to the number her marriage with Mr Perry his soon after the war of the Revolution. but cannot precise year. I stood up as brides man a custom then general. They were married by the Rev. Timothy Dwight then Pastor of the Congregation Church of Greenfield Connecticut Hyatt Banks

[handwritten letter] Manchester Oct 2d. 1833. To the Hon. J. S. Edwards Com'r &c. Hon. Sir, I have procured & herewith transmit the Certificate of the Probate Court to prove the surviving Children & Heirs of Lem'l Bishop deceased, but whether in the mode & form required, I cannot say - The family are numerous & widely disperse, as you will perceive - and I would inquire, whether the small sum, comparatively, which will probably be allowed this family as the Pension of their dec'd father, cannot be drawn otherwise than by a Power of Attorney signed by all the Members of the family & certified, as doubtless it must be, by the County Clerks, with their respective seals of Office, in the several Counties where they respectively reside, as happen to be at the time, they are executed - That facts & circumstances in relation to the family are these - the Children have been dispensed from their paternal home for sev'l years, except one Son (Chauncey) & one Daughter (Diana) - they each received their little portion of their father's property as they respectively left & for a number of years past, the father had resided with, & been supported by his son, Chauncey - & it was his intention & acquiesced in by all the rest of the family, that what little property possessed at the time of his death, including his pension if obtained, should go to his son Chauncey, his (the father's) support having been attended with large expense for several years, he having been infirm & indeed bedridden for most of the time - & the son also himself is own in an infirm & sickly state & has been so for nearly a year past & confined to his bed for most of the time, at great expense for medicine & medical assistance & withal, in a state of primary distress requiring aid - If a proof of these fact, will induce the granting the Certificate to him as designed by the father & all the family, or to an Adm'r to be appointed, I will procure & forward it on - If not, the Case of Isaac Farwell will present still greater difficulties, as will appear more [illegible] when I [illegible] I rec'd last evening your [illegible] of the 27th Ult. calling for the orig'l Decl'n. of Sim'n LIttlefield - that, I heretofore forwarded, soon after the Decl'ns in the cases of John Frost & Wm. Duston were sent for, & will probably be found amongst the Papers of the Office Very respectfully I am Hon'd Sir Yours &c. /s/S. Swift

of the two Districts the greater part of his life, that he is a man of strict veracity having been a minister of the Gospel for many years and continued in that calling so long as he was able to attend to the duty, and we place firm reliance in the statements he has made believing the same to be the truth. We the undersigned would therefore petition your Honorable Body to take his case into favorable consideration, and grant that a [illegible], infirm Revolutionary [illegible crossed out word] patriot that you in your wisdom should think would best comfort with the dignity of the state and justice of the petitioners claim. The state has many magnificent schemes of internal improvement on hand upon which she from year to year lavishes with a profuse hand the money from her Treasury & we would humbly petition that the old man who is now worn down from the frost of Eighty two winters, who has become so feeble and so helpless as to be unable to get out of the House without good apitance [a pittance?] & care on his friends and relatives who are illy able to help him, deprived nearly of speech and sight, who spent the youthful part of his life in that struggle which tried mens souls who if they had faltered & succumbed to the British Lion we might now be slave in stead of freemen, from these considerations & the liberty which we enjoy as the fruit of their toil we hope that your Honorable Body will make his last days, days of pleasantry and him also realize something as a compensation for his sufferings in the cause of liberty. And as in duty bound your petitioner will ever pray 24th November 1841. (Signed/ John Huiet, L.C. Ready, Allen S. Dozier, John Jennings Sr., James Maynard, Wm. A. Strother, D. Denny, Joseph Long, Geo D. Huiet, John Inlow, Dennis McCarty, Daniel Wheeler Sr., Giles Martin, A. L. Nicholson, Daniel Campbell, W Herbert, James Kilgore, P Schoppert, Isaac Herbert, W Wilson. of the Revolution, she hath repeatedly heard him relate the hardships, said trials and Battles he participated in, but doth not remember, where, or when he was quartered except one place, Staten Island She further states, that there is no documentary Evidence, nor can she procure any in support of her claim She further declares, that her Father and mother was Married in the year of 1792 or 1793. as she hath often heard them say she not having any public or private record of said Marriage in her possession, at or near Unadilla, in the County of Otsego, State of New York by one Jonathan Newman a Methodist Clergyman, and that her mother; name before her said marriage was Deborah Priest, the Widow of Josiah Priest, that her father, the aforesaid Joseph Lull, died on or about the 26th day of November A.D 1829. Near his own residence and farm, by being accidently drowned in the River Susquehanna, near Unadilla Otsego County, State of New York, aged about 70 years She further states, that her said Mother Deborah Lull, died on the 22 day of January A.D. 1851, at the Town of Thompson, near Chardon, Geauga County State of Ohio aged, about 84 years That she was married to her father Joseph Lull, prior to his leaving the service, but the Marriage took place previous to the first of January Seventeen hundred and Ninety four (Viz) at the time above stated

To all whom it may concern I do hereby certify, that the bearer Mrs. Vanamburg is a member in good standing in the M.E. Church, in the Hanline, charge in this city She has a good standing here & has had a series of great & continued trials-- for some years past & is impeded by stern necessity to leave her [illegible] little children & as a lame widow go on a journey to the City of Washington, to secure a claim she has against the government for services rendered in the war by her father, who together with her mother, is now deceased I not only ask for her - kindness & confidence, in her journey. But hope the government will award here as soon as possible her past claim She truly is worthy & needy & hers is a case that strongly urges itself upon the sympathies of all. But strongly demands redress from government. Steubenville City, State of Ohio October 2, 1852 W. B. Dunlap, Paster of said congregation

Steubenville Ohio June Esther Vanemburgh Referred & the Com of Pensions to answer July 1 The Lord grant you have leisure this [illegible]and consider for a few moments what I shall say to you I was born on the banks of the Susquehanna town of Unadilla Otsego Co my father a soldier of the revolution commenced and remained in the same farm a period of nearly forty years and died and is buried here that place he was wealthy but in his later days fell into mental derangement; caused the passions said by only suffering in that condition the sharpers flocked around him stripped him of his all and drove us from our beautiful home on the Susquehanna we left with sorrowful hearts (myself and husband lived on the farm at the time), with nothing but our hands to support ourselves with. my husband was industrious and provided a home for my mother and the unmarried part of the family. three years from this my husband fell sick with the lingering consumption lingered nearly 3 years and died leaving myself and mother poor my mother applied for a pension under the act for the relief of widows of soldiers of the revolution the nation refused to pay her for fathers actual service because my father could not find it companion to suit him a little sooner. I supported my mother at the time by labour of diferant kind; (she being feeble suffering from a cough which remain 21 years before she died. after 3 years 3 months as i Deposed & [illegible [illegible] a man of temperance

Huntingdon County Ss. Before me the subscriber one of the Associate Judges of the Court of Common Pleas in and for the County aforesaid in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania Personally appeared Detrich Ourhand late a soldier in the Revolutionary War with Great Britain and a Citizen of the County of Huntingdon aforesaid in which he doth reside, And after being duly sworn according to law by me. He doth depose and say that he was duly enlisted by Jacob Snyder a first Lieutenant in a Company commanded by Captain George Whitzel in the Regiment Commanded by Colonel Walter Stewart in the Pennsylvania Line on or about the fourteenth day of January in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and seventy eight that he was transfered to Captain Banksons Company in the same Regiment after the Battle of Monmouth in Jersy and continued in the Service of the United States until the fourteenth day of January in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and eighty one having served three years being the time for which he was enlisted and was discharged by General Anthony Wayne a Brigadier General of the Pennsylvania Line on that day. That this deponent will on the eighth day of next November be fifty seven years of age, that he labours under Rheumatic pains of a severe kind, which renders him unable to do any business for three or four months in a year, which disorder he apprehends he became subject to when a soldier as aforesaid, by being exposed to hardship and cold in the service in his youth. That he is reduced in his circumstances in life and stands in need of assistance from his Country for support for himself his wife and two youngest children. his elder children being employed for their own support. Sworn to

and subscribed this first day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen. Before David Stewart [signed] Deitrich Aurand Huntingdon County Ss Before me the Subscriber one of the Associate Judges of the Court of Common Pleas in and for the County aforesaid in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania Personally came John Aurand who being duly sworn by me according to law saith that his Father Detrich Ourhand or Aurand is reduced in his circumstances, and and unstable from a severe Rheumatic complaint that he is afflicted with, to support himself his wife and two youngest Children. That he this deponant verily believes he stands in need of assistance from his County for his support Sworn to and Subscribed this first day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eigh hundred and eighteen. Bellefonte March 18th 1834 Dear Sir, I now take my pen in hand to let you know that I am yet Living through the Mercy & goodness of God though old and verry infirm and my mind somewhat impaired I would still ask you for your Assistantance my Pension matter having made all the proof that is in my power owing to the many Deaths of my old suffering fellow soldiers according to the best of my knowledge I stated my age in former papers saying I was borne in 61 owing to my calculations and what I have been told by one of my Brothers I was Borne in the year 62 it was and is my opinion that I entered the service of my contrary in the year 77 but it might of been in 78 but there is one thing Rember well that is my many sufferings during the Camppain Lying in cold and wintary Blasts many times with nothing to eat for days in Succesion Evan the women had to hide out Bundles of wheat and of night in silant places But out the same and would Boil and eat it without even salt I was taken from plase to plase and at fourt Rutledge or Sinikar [Seneca] Fort or Camily called so on the account of it being on the bank of Sinka [Seneca] River

[written] This is to certify that I knew Issachar Cozzens Sen. 1 in the years 1837 & 1838- when he lived with his son Issachar Cozzens Jun 2- at my farm at Slongha, near Bull's Ferry New Jersey- that i believe htem to be father and son, that the old man was then in his dotage, or that his mind was impaired at the time- Wm. Cooper Slongha near Bull's Ferry N. J. January 3d- 1853-} Thi sis to certify that I am aquainted with Issachar Cozzens Junior of North Bergen Township residing near Bulls Ferry N. Jeesey- that he has shown me his fathery old family Bible and that there is in that bible a family record of " Issachar Cozzens Born August 21st 1754" and also a record of "Issachar Cozzens Junioir -Born at Newport Rhode Island Dec 15th 1780"- besides these there are recorded his marriage and the Births of Frederick S- Wm B, Ellen and sveral then chidre, with deaths etc etc and all in one handwriting as nearly as I can Judge. and that the handwritting is the same as that attached to the bottom (middle part) of a paper setting forth his claim to a pension for Revolutionary Services- Wm Cooper Slongha near Bull's Ferry N. J. January 3d 1853}

Rev.&1812 Wars Section. ADY February 21, 1930. Jessica C. Ferguson, State Library & Museum, Harrisburg, Pennsylvania. Dear Madam: I advise you that from the papers in the Revolutionary War pension claim, S. 5543, it appears that Jacob Huber or Hoover was born December 7, 1756 in Strasburg, Lancaster County, Pennsylvania. While a resident of Pfouts Valley, Pennsylvania, he enlisted in July 1776, served six months as a private in Captain John Stone's Pennsylvania Company in the Flying Camp and was in the battle of Long Island. He enlisted in March 1777, served three years and nine months as a private in Captain Thomas Bull's Pennsylvania Regiments and was in the battles of Brandywine and Rhode Island. He was allowed pension on his application executed June 6, 1834, while a resident of Lancaster, Lancaster County, Pennsylvania. Soldier's father was alive during both of his enlistments, his name is not stated, and there are no further family data. The above data are taken from the papers on file in this soldier's claim for pension. Very truly yours, Earl D. Church, Commissioner.

12 Wars Section, January 17, 1930. Mrs. Jean Oberholtzer, 527 South Second Street, Lykens, Pennsylvania. Dear Madam: I advise you that from the papers in the Revolutionary War pension claim, S. 5543, it appears that Jacob Huber or Hoover was born December 7, 1756 in Strasburg, Lancaster County, Pennsylvania. While a resident of Pfouts Valley, Pennsylvania, he enlisted in July 1776, served six months as a private in Captain John Stone's Pennsylvania Company in the Flying Camp and was in the battle of Long Island. He enlisted in March 1777, served three years and nine months as a private in Captain Thomas Bull's Company, Colonel George Cochran's and David Bole's Pennsylvania Regiments and was in the battles of Brandywine and Rhode Island, He was allowed pension on his application executed June 6, 1834, while a resident of Lancaster, Lancaster County, Pennsylvania. Soldier's father was alive during both of his enlistments, his name is not stated, and there are no further family data. The Revolutionary War records of this bureau fail to afford any information in regard to John Huber or Hoover as described by you or to Jacob Bordner. Very truly yours, EARL D. CHURCH, Commissioner. [Hand Written annotation]could not verify. Bole appears in Pa. Archives so used it instead of Bold. Not on A. B.

District of New Hampshire County of Grafton At the Superior Court of Judication of the State of New Hampshire holden at Haverhill within and for the County of Grafton being a Court of record of said County, by law established, on this thirtieth day of May in the year of our Lord 1820, personally appeared in open Court Nathanel Carpenter aged sixty three years resident in Hanover in said County & District of New Hampshire, who first being duly sworn according to law, doth on his Oath declare that he served in the Revolutionary War as follows, vis. a private Soldier in Capt. James Dana's Company and Col. Andrew Wards regiment in the Connecticut Line, that his original declaration was made and dated the 25th day of April 1818, that he has not received a pension & that the inclosed papers contain his evidence of services and original declaration reference thereto being had. And I do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not since that time by gift sale, or in any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof with intent thereby do so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an Act of Congress entitled an "Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land & naval service of the United States in the revolutionary War passed on the 18th day of March 1818, & that *I have not, nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities, contracts or debts due to me, nor have I any income other than hat is contained in the Schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed. I further declare that I am by occupation a Farmer, I am very lame and unable to do but very little labor. I have a wife aged 60 years; she is very lame and in great pain most of the time and unable to stoop to the floor. I have a son

Shepherdsville 5 Augt [August] 1839 Hon Sec War Sir Enclosed are the affidavits & additional proof required in the Cases of Mrs Susan Hornbeck. Famariah Cardwell — viz Sucky Field for Pension — I have of even date herewith sent direction to Yr Office the Original Bible of Mrs Cardwell & Field - In the first place Cardwell sent the leaf containing the Record — I suppose the original Bible was reqd [required] & sent both Bibles — The original Bible which contained Cardwells birth & is not to be had & is the one which was destroyed by Wm. Cardwell in his foolish effort years ago to make himself of age — the Bible now sent is the one procured & in which the Births & deaths of the only 2 children are registered — as stated in affidavit of Cardwell ^before^ forwarded — Mrs Fields record seems all as usual regular The Extreme poverty of Mrs. C & F has induced me to make these efforts for their success — Knowing them to be exemplary moral & worthy citizens — I truly hope you will find enough on the facts & circumstances to award in their favor — Proof could be had I am informed (if the persons are alive) as referred to by Mrs Cardwell of her marriage & for the number of years stated — but her poverty prevents her sending to search up her witnesses— She has been residing here some 30 years or more — and no one here doubts the facts declared — Sir I entreat you as they are poor & most likely to become County charges not to permit that case to happen — if circumstance with Justice they are entitled under the Severe rules (Comparing no doubt) to entitle very old widows to success — It seems almost a matter of improbability

United States of America Massachusetts District Be it known that on this sixteenth day of August, in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and thirty eight, personally appeared before the Hon. John Davis Judge of the United States District Court being a Court of Record, in the Massachusetts District, Rosanna Lamb a resident of Boston the County & Commonwealth aforesaid; aged seventy seven years who, being first duly sworn according to law, doth on her oath, make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the provision made by the Act of Congress, passed July 7th 1838, entitled "An Act granting half pay and pensions to certain widows". That she is the widow of Thomas Lamb, who was a Lieutenant in the War of the Revolution and served according to the best of her recollection and belief as follows, viz,- He received his Commission on the first day of February seventeen hundred & seventy seven as a First Lieut. in Col Henry Jackson's Regt & entered the Army at Boston at that time and continued in the service of the United States until the twenty fourth day of April seventeen hundred & seventy nine, when he resigned as appears by his discharge written on the back of his Commission now in her possession of which the following is a true Copy. Lieutenant Lamb of Colonel Henry Jackson's Regt in the service of the United American States, at his own request is hereby discharged from his Regiment. Given at Headquarters in Boston the twenty fourth day of April 1779. signed W. Heath M. Gen.

Commonwealth of Massachusetts Suffolk County} ss Be it known that on this seventeenth day of August in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and thirty eight, personally appeared before me the Honorable John Davis Judge of the United States District Court, being a court of Record in the Massachusetts District, Thomas Lamb, a resident of Boston the County & Commonwealth aforesaid, of lawful age to testify, who, being first duly sworn, according to la on his oath makes the following declarations. That, Thomas Lamb, the husband of Rosanna Lamb who subscribed the annexed declaration, died the thirteenth day of January Eighteen hundred and thirteen; That the said Rosanna Lamb has not intermarried, and still continues his Widow. State of South Carolina Sumter District On this 13th day of April A.D. 1850 before the undersigned a magistrate in and for said District duly authorized by law to administer oaths personally appeared Ezekiel Dixon a resident of said District aged fifty One years who being duly sworn according to law deposith and saith that he is well acquainted with Mrs Argent Crosswell and her sister Mrs Sarah Crosswell who are now applying for the pension due to their late Father John Kennedy, and their late Mother Cherry Kennedy for the services of their said Father in the Revolutionary War that he knew the said John Kennedy and Cherry Kennedy his wife more than forty years ago when the despondent was a boy and that his acquaintance with the said John and Cherry Kennedy Continued as long as they lived, that the history of the neighborhood has long been that the said John Kennedy Served Several years as a soldier in the war of the Revolution first in the militia and afterwards in the North Carolina Continental line that he has often heard the said John Kennedy say that he was in the Battle of Camden at the time of Gen’l Gates defeat, and afterwards in Gen’l Greens Battle of Camden with Lord Rowdan, that he was in the Battle of Eutaw Springs, and others

State of South Carolina Sumter District On this 20 day of April A. D. 1850 before the undersigned a magistrate in and for said district duly authorized by law to administer oaths, personally appeared Abel Dixon a resident of said district aged eighty four years, who being duly sworn according to law deposits and said that he is acquainted with Mrs Argent Crosswell and her sister Mrs Sarah Crosswell who are now applying for the pension due their late Father John Kennedy and their late Mother Cherry Kennedy for the Service of their Father in the Revolutionary War; that he has known the said Argent and Sarah from their girlhood, and they have always born the Character of highly respectable and credible persons. And that the history of the neighborhood has long been that the said John Kennedy served several years as a soldier in the War of the Revolution, first in the militia and afterwards in the North Carolina Continental line; that he has often heard said John Kennedy say that he was in the Battle of Camden at the time of Gen Gates defeat, that he afterwards found Gen Greens army and was in his Battle of Camden with Lord Rawdon and also in the Battle of Eutaw Springs. Despondent further swears that he was himself at the Eutaw Springs Battle ground about fifty years ago —

Hill for eighty Dollars to whom he was indebted the full amount, six old leather bottom chairs to L. L. Henson J Warden H.J. Tapp & W. Chambers for two Dollars sixty five & one half cents for all - One Loom & Harness, grill wheel and swifts to Thomas Maupim for a debt due to him being money borrowed about two years ago amounting to fifteen Dollars. A candlestand to Edward Valentine for two dollars- two [? Overy] & one pot sold to H. J. Tapp. A Waddell & David Point for one dollar - one shovel & tongs to M Cabe for 58 cents. one cow to Mary McCullock for Ten Dollars-- one cotton wheel to Henry Speck for 32 cents --All my Books, one Bible excepted by public auction sold to David Points & others in the whole for thirty eight Dollars & twenty cents - out of the money for which the said property was sold this Declarant paid the following debts bona fide due and owing from him to John G Lowry fourteen Dollars for necessaries furnished several

Stand, two iron pot and one pair of tongs and shovel - one dish, four large and six small plates, six knives and forty-five table spoons and six tea spoons - one Tea Kettle, coffee pot - & has a small copper kettle - two pewter basins, One Cow, one small wheel & weight, one Cotton wheel, a bible & a few other books and a few old razors. Independent of the debts which constitute a lien on the real property I owe about one hundred & seventy Dollars which I am unable to pay. The said Smith Thompson further declares on oath that he [Illegible] but that his age and sickness prevent him from labouring a great part of his time - That he has a wife about fourty eight years of age, who is sickly and infirmed and is unable manually to contribute toward her support. He has a servant girl about eleven years of belonging to John Crowers [Esquire?] whose services are of little value and who may be taken away at the pleasure of said Crowers. Signed Smith Thompson

(transmitted) all my said Services. I can prove by the testimony transmitted herewith_ I was a Drummer all the time in Every tour I performed. I was born in Lebanon (County of New Haven then) but now New London) Connecticut, on the 9 of June 1756 (I have no record of my age) (This my mother has always told me) she is now Dec'd_ My father died when I was nine Months old, he came home from the old French War sick, & died immediately on his return. he was a Soldier in that war, I was born in Lebanon aforesaid & have always, & Do now live in said Lebanon. Asahel Gay Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid We Edward Bull a Clergyman residing in said Lebanon and William T. Williams Esq residing in the same place hereby certify that we are well acquainted with Asahel Gay who has subscribed and sworn to the above declaration. That we believe him to be seventy six years of age. That he is reputed and believed in the neighborhood where he resides to have been a soldier of the Revolution and that we concur in that opinion. Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid. Edwrd Bull W. T. Williams

That after my return from this expedition, I continued with the Continental Army in service to the end of the War; and was then honourably discharged by Gen. Washington- That, during the whole time, after enlistment by Lieut. William Bull, I served in the capacity of a Corporal. That, as near as I now recollect, in the year 1789, while I and my wife were absent on business , my dwelling house, together with all its contents were consumed by fire, by that severe calamity, I lost all my papers, including the said certificates of of discharge from Gen. Washington & also a Bible in which was a correct record of my birth & age, notwithstanding , I am certain that, I am seventy eight years old & upwards from other circumstances, that cannot mislead me-- That my Capt. the said William Bull died several years ago; and all the other officers & soldiers, that knew me & served with me to the end of the War, (by whom, I could prove my services}, are either dead or removed beyond my knowledge of their residence-- That, I was wounded in my right leg at the battle of Germantown and would have been killed or taken prisoner by the enemy, had it not been for the kindness & intrepidity of Adjutant William Barber who grasped me by one hand & succeeded in mounting me on his own horse behind the saddle; then putting Spurs to the noble animal he galloped away, carrying both out of the reach of the British army- That I was on the pension Roll under the act of 1818 for a short/service of time, and as far as my recollection serves me now, either received a whole or a half year pension under that act. That, I was subsequently denied the benefits of that act, being unwilling to make oath, that, I was unable to support myself, which, I understood was the conditions required of all those who in future were to receive its benefits, in consequence

of our yearly support - then Sir, estimate for yourself how, we must live, being unable to keep a horse for our use, or even a boy to do our errands or cut our firewood. Sir, Perhaps you will now ask; why, I did not make Oath, that I was unable to support myself & obtain the benefits of the pension act of 1818-- Sir, I will tell you why- No Revolutionary soldier, who is sincerely honest, can hold this Government responsible for a single dollar unless he believes, it is for services rendered and not yet paid for; any more than one individual, can hold another, where no value has been received-- the doctrine of a debt of gratitude, is entirely exploded by me full compensation for that demand is derived from the blessings of freedom and independence under our happy form of Government Then, Sir, If it is a debt due from the Government to the soldiers for value long ago received, and standing before God & country, I now fearlessly declare it is, should any soldier who has braved the dangers & periled his life in the most hazardous of all wars, that of revolted Colonies against the mother country, be obliged to swear to his poverty in order to collect a just & legal debt-- I have said a just & legal debt-- I will state Sir, how, I think it became so-- The inability of the Government to pay her soldiers, at the time, that their services were terminated , was the prominent cause of all their subsequent misfortunes - For what could the poor and ragged soldier do, but sell her paper, which was given to him in payment for his service, for what it would bring in the market, which was from 1/6 to 2/6 on the pound at the time given. Now, Sir this inability in the Government to pay her contracts to the soldier, at the time it could be dispensed with, by him, was the real cause of his losing almost all he had earned in fighting her battles, and from thenceforward, it became a debt due from the Nation to the soldiers which they have never yet received-- they done her work & done it well, and were

Dallas was succeeded by Captain Edsall under whom this deponent continued to serve, until he was succeeded by the said second Lieutenant William Bull as captain of said Company, under whom this deponent continued to serve until the end of the War, and was honourably discharged by certificate from General Washington at the time he disbanded his army at New Burgh in Orange County, which certificate of discharge to this deponent was burnt with all the rest of his papers and household effects, by the accidental burning of his dwelling house about the year 1791 while this deponent and wife were absent on business -- this deponent fought in the following battles under General Washington (to wit), in the battle at Brandywine - in the battle of Germantown where he received a wound from a musket ball in his right leg, in consequence of which, he narrowly escaped being made a prisoner by the enemy in the battle of Monmouth and on that eventful day this deponent, in common with his associate in arms suffered incredible hardship from

make the following declaration in order to obtain the provisions made by the Act of Congress [pending the 18 of March 1878 Entitled an Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and navies Service of the United States revolutionary war. that he served in the revolutionary war as follows to enlist, that in January 1777. at Springfield in Massachusetts entered into Capt. Robert Olivers Co., Col. John Grettuce Regt. + Genrl John Nixion Brigade for three years and served out that time in said Regt. + was discharged near Peakshill in the state of New York, + was at the taking of Burgoyne at the battle at Harts Mill in the state of New York when Genrl Burgoins army--[later) advanced,. that he is in reduced Circumstances +sorely in need of the assistance of his Country for support + that he has no other evidence in his possession of his said services having handed his discharge after the war to Capt. Miller to precure {illegible}+ it was never returned. And the said Ezekiel Beebe further declares + makes his oath that the propriety contained in his former Schedule made Decem 26.1820 + not contained in this Schedule has been disposed of as follows. to wit the principal part of the land area taken on 4th to satisfy the debits George T. Hodges + Geo T. Hodge + co. The rest of the land and the two {illegible} were taken by Doct. James Porter on his debt leaving this despondent still indebted to the said Porter the property not being sufficient to satisfy the debt. the shoats + sheep not enumerated in this Schedule have been eaten up in necessity except two Sheep which were lost or have been killed by some other person--the old weeygon (wagon) hear come to pieces + destroyed- the suckling Colts were also taken for a debt to (elece) to my son Ezekiel Beebe living in Paulett + was if very little value being appraised at only ten dollars. I married a wife named Agnes aged 60 years in Aug.1821 + is in very poor health, my son John aged 16 years lives with us + is the only one of my family upon which I can {illegible} for support being myself in very {illegible} heath. Ezekiel Beebe I sworn before me Ro Pierpoint Clk.

describe +the support of his family had a accumulated against him debts to the amount in value of the few acres of land, which he had holden and age + his debilitated right hand have almost annihilated his means of acquisition. Enroled,in the time past, among the pensioners of the revolution +some of his creditors hoping by apparent kindness to receive a portion of his pension + others from respect to his age +military service having forborne to exsact their claims, your petitioner has remained in this possession of a very small real estate: But so it is may it please your honor, that the creditors of your petitioner ,ascertained that his pension was stoped ,+ that the recovery of their debts against him would soon be hopeless, by legal prouss ,seized upon the residue of his property, liable to creditors,+ your petitions owns nothing of the soil of his country, + win the last cow of your petitioner has by accident broken her leg + is dead . Your petitioner is now in poverty, liable to the charity of others, liable to be imprisoned for the residue of his unsatisfied debts, while his age + increasing infirmities deny him the avails of bodily labor. The country of your petitioner has had the vigor of his youth, devoted to our common independence, he. now in poverty, in age and without the power+ without the means of acquisition, would repose upon the clemency of the same country, as for as was in his power effictreally defended + protected, your petitioner therefore, prays your honor that he may be restored to his pension + be replaced on the general pension list, or otherwise maybe relieved + provided for as your honor in your great wisdom may deem meet, and as in duty bound will ever pray. Rutland, Vt,11. Nov. 1820 Ezekiel Beebe

arrangements which had been proposed. He paid the money due on mortgage, said taxes due and therefor the administrator of Lord Butler and said Mallory released to me (it being in trust for said Hillhouse) seven lots, and said Wells to obviate any on formality in said transfers, and on presumption that said arrangement would be made with said Goodrich, executed a deed of [illegible] of said twelve tracts. Owing to indisposition and to other cause, Mr. Hillhouse did not secure said Goodrich til that12 of Oct when I went with him to Wethersfield and called on said Goodrich who then said that the business respecting said lot with the papers he had been put into the hands of Mr. Waltor W. Buckley of Wetherfield to indemnify him for the money which he had advanced to pay the taxes on said lot and for going to Pennsylvania to look after it &c. And that he had Mr. Buckley would call the next morning. They called accordingly and finally persuaded Mr. Hillhouse to pay fifty dollars in cash and to secure two hundred dollars payable in one year without interest for a release of said Goodrichs rights to said lots. Mr. Hillhouse paid said fifty dollars and secured said two hundred to said Buckley and thereupon said Goodrich executed a deed of release of any right to said lot, by deed dated Oct 6th 1826, to which deed I was a witness and signed my name. Said fifty dollars was paid & two hundred secured to Buckley as I understood for his aforesaid and other advances and that no part of it was coming to said Goodrich. I am acquainted with the above lot and am of the opinion that lands as well situated and of as good a quality have lately been sold and may now be bought as low and even at a less price for cash. Said Goodrich was spoken of in the neighborhood where he resides as a very deserving man, and as a faithful soldier of the Revolution. He appeared also to be very infirm, and in a most destitute situation. And further the deponent says not. Interlined with the words in the ninth line from the bottom before signing. Jesse Gilbert U. States Ss District of Cont Sept 10th 1827 Sworn to before me by the above deponent to me personally known. Wm Bristor, Dist Judge of U. States for Cont District

And the said Judge doth hereby declare his opinion after the investigation of the matter, & after putting the interrogatories prescribed by the War Department that the above named Applicant was a revolutionary soldier & served as he states And the said Judge further certifies that it appears to him that Abraham Brownson who has signed the preceding Certificate is a Clergyman, resident in Manchester in said County of Bennington that Horatio Chipman who has also signed the same is a resident of Sunderland in said County & is a credible person, & that their statement is entitled to credit, Certified by me /s/Myron Clark Judge of the Probate Court - I Elijah Burton Burton of the Town of Manchester in the County of Bennington & State of Vermont, aged 72. years, do certify, testify & say that I have been well acquainted with Lemuel Bishop who has subscribed & sworn to the above Declaration that in the summer and fall of the year 1777. I understand ['I know' crossed out] of his serving as a Sergeant in the Company commanded by Cpat. Jesse Sawyer in the Regiment of Vermont State Troops, called the Green mountain Rangers commanded by Col.Herrick altho I then belonged to a different Corps & Regiment that ['I said [illegible] in the service in said Regiment at Pawlet in the State of Vermont sometime at the fore part of the month of Nov. of the same year 1777. & was present at the capture of Gen'l Burgoyne at Ticonderoga,' crossed out] in the fall of the year 1778 & fore part of 1778 served with the said Bishop at Castleton & am confident that he served then at the time three months, living as near neighbors to him this the whole of the revolutionary war & ever since, I have a general knowledge & understanding of his services through that war, & believe the statement thereof by him above made to be correct /s/Elijah Burton Sworn & subscribed to the day & year aforesaid, & I also hereby further certify that Elijah Burton who subscribed & swore to the foregoing Affidavit is a credible person to me well known, & that this statement is entitled to credit, by & before me /s/Myron Clark Judge of Probate Court. /s/Elijah Burton State of Vermont Bennington County ss. State of New York Saratoga county Be it remembered that on this twenty eigth day of the March in the year of our Lord one thousand Eight hundred Eighteen appeared before me Thomas Dibble one of the Judges of the Court of Common Pleas in and for the county of Saratoga and State of New York James Bishop of the town of Malta in the County and State aforesaid who being by me duly sworn declared that he served in the war of the Revolution against the common enemy for the period of three years. That in the Spring of the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and Seventy Seven he enlisted into the Continental establishment at Fort Montgomery in the State of New York aforesaid in Captain Johnson's Company in Colonel Dubois' Regiment of the New York Line for the period of three years. that he served three years faithfully and in the Spring of the year of our Lord one thousand Seven hundred and Eighty he received an honourable discharge at Morristown in the State of Newjersey. that in the year 1809 his discharge was burnt in the a ___ of Samuel Bishop his son which was also consumed by fire. that he is now Seventy four years of Age and in very indigent circumstances and in need of assistance from his county for his support James Bishop Sworn /Subcribed this 22d day of March 1818 before me Thomas Bibble one of the Judges of the Court of Common Please of the County of Saratoga State of New York

state of New York Saratoga County On this twenty second day of August 1821 per-sonally appeared in open court in the court of common pleas of the said county the same being a court of record for the said county preceding according to the court of common Law with a jurisdiction unlimited in ___ of amount keeping a record of its proceedings and having the power of fine & imprisonment. James Bishop aged Seventy seven years resident in the said county in the state aforesaid who being first duly sworn according to Law doth on his oath declare that he served in the revolutionary war as follows_ That on the commencement of the war he enlisted in a regiment commanded by Col. Rayner that they served in the northern campaign under General Montgomery that he was at the taking of St John Chambler Montreal and at the siege of Quebec at the time General Montgomery was killed that he then served for the space of one year and received an honorable discharge that in forepart of the month of March 1777 he enlisted at Fort Montgomery in the State of New York in a company commanded by Captain Johnson in Col Lewis Dubois regiment of the New York line for the period of three years that he served the said three years faithfully and in the spring of the year 1780 at Morristown New Jersey received an honorable discharge. That his original declaration was made on the twenty second day of march in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen and that his pension certificate is numbered (1779). And I do solemny swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March 1818. and that i have not since that time by gift sale or in any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof with in that thereby so to ____ it as to bring myself within the pension of an act of congress entitled. An act to provide for certain persons engaged

I owe the following debts viz To John Barnes a balance due on the aforesaid 65¾ acres of land included in two notes of hand for $79 dollars each due first about first of April 1821 second about first April 1822 on interest since the Spring of 1818 the 9th day of April 1817 date of said deed and notes Interest to Decr. 9th 1820 $181.28 I owe to Joel Morley for cash Borrowed of him to complete my first payment made on my land so as to enable me to obtain a deed and unpaid 35. 00 also I owe to sd. Joel Morley for labor done in clearing building me a log cabbin [cabin] and out buildings fencing and improving the aforesaid ten acres 181.00 I owe to Elijah Ballard Enoch Hale Ephraim Brown Major Churchill William Barb and Sundry other persons small balances the whole together amounting to about the sum of 47.75 The total amount of debts due by me is $445.05 The amount of debts exceed the amount of property the sum of 79.00½ and I the said Declarant am by occupation a Cooper and have also laboured on a farm but on account of a rheumatic complaint my right shoulder and arm is much disabled so that I have not been able to labour at my trade for almost a year past I am also much afflicted with the stone in the bladder and it is with great pain and difficulty, that I can discharge my urine so much so that in voiding it comes off as slowly as the dropping from a sap tree by these and other infirmities old age and decrepitude I am not able to do much labour My wife aged about 65 or 66 years infirm and affected with the rheumatism and Cramp which much afflicts her though at other times tolerably healthy for a woman of her advances [advanced] age I have but one child a son now living with me aged 25 years

June 23, 1931 Mrs. G. A. Parker 44 Geneva Street Opelika, Alabama Rev. &1812 Wars Section John B. Mitchell - R.7276 EEL Dear Madam: You are advised that it appears from the Revolutionary War records of the bureau that John B. Mitchell was born January 22, 1759, in Bristol, Britain, came into America April 1, 1772, arriving in the city of Philadelphia. While residing in Edgefield District, South Carolina, he applied for pension under the Act of June 7, 1832. It was stated that he volunteered in March, 1776, in Philadelphia, served under Captain Stewart, was in several skirmishes and at the battle of Staten Island, where he was severely wounded in his right leg, was taken prisoner and held on a prison ship for five or six weeks; that he was then taken to St. Johns Florida, where he remained until April, 1778, was then carried to Savannah, was under the British at the siege, but on account of his wound was unable to render any service except at times when he took charge of baggage trains; that at Cambridge, South Carolina, he was captured by Colonel Smith of the American Army, was taken to General Greene who gave him unlimited furlough and an order on every commissary from Cambridge to Philadelphia, but on account of his wound he was unable to proceed further than Mecklenburg, North Carolina, where he remained and took up teaching school for a livelihood. His claim was not allowed by the United States as he failed to furnish proof of six months actual military service in the American Army as was required by the pension laws. He was allowed pension by the State of South Carolina. He continued to reside in North Carolina, until 1789, then moved to Newberry District, South Carolina, and then to Edgefield District, South Carolina. He taught school and was also minister of the Methodist Church. May 26, 1936 Honorable Duncan U. Fletcher United States Senate Washington, D.C. BA-J/EEL John B. Mitchell - R.7276 James Mitchell - B.L.Wt.#2105-300 My dear Senator: The data which follow are obtained from the papers on file in Revolutionary War pension claim, R.7276, based upon the military service in that war of John B. Mitchell John B. Mitchell was born January 22, 1759 in Bristol, England, and came to America April 1, 1772, arriving in the city of Philadelphia. While residing in Edgefield District, South Carolina, he applied for pension under the Act of June 7, 1832. It was stated that he volunteered in March, 1776, in Philadelphia, served under Captain Stewart, was in several skirmishes and at the battle of Staten Island, where he was severely wounded in his right leg, was taken prisoner and held on a prison ship for five or six weeks; that he was taken to St. John's Florida, where he remained until April, 1778, was then carried to Savannah , was under the British at siege, but on account of his wound was unable to render any service except at times when he took charge of baggage trains: that at Cambridge, South Carolina, he was captured by Colonel Smith of the American Army, was taken to General Greene who gave him unlimited furlough and an order on every commissary from Cambridge to Philadelphia, but on account of his wound, he was unable to proceed further than Mecklenburg, North Carolina, wherehe [where he] remained and took up teaching for a livelihood. His claim was not allowed by the United States as he failed to furnish proof of six months actual service in the American Army as required by the pension laws. He was allowed pension by the state of South Carolina. He continued to reside in North Carolina, until 1789, then moved to Newberry District, South Carolina, and then to Edgefield District, South Carolina. He taught school and was also minister of the Methodist Church.

Springfield September 4th, 1846 I have known the man John B. Mitchell for a great number of years. He is a Baptist minister of good standing in his church. He has been for the last forty or fifty years an intelligent English teacher. He has, during my acquaintance with him (which has been from my childhood), always supported a true and excellent character. I have no doubt that his statements regarding his Revolutionary Services are true. He is now a very aged man and ought to be rewarded by the country for which he risked his life in the early years of his life. Jno. B. O’Neall, one of the Judges of the Court of Appeals of the State of S. Car. I have heard the above certificate of Judge O’Neall and can cheerfully concur in its statement of Mr. Mitchell’s character. The said I have been acquainted with since about 1812 or 13. His statements are entitled to implicit credit. Jas. S. Hunter, one of the Senators of S.C. Sept. 13, 1843

[written] prevented his attending to this business in the manner required by law- It is required for a Soldier of the Revolution to prove the lenght of time he served in each campaign- I have no proof (after this lapse of time) to offer, other than his own statementherewith sent and that only mentions the time of his first cam- paign of nine months-In his statement of Sullivan's Expedition he does not show the time he was engaged but from his tradition to me of the skirmishes in the neighbourhood of Bristol & Warren and the capture of Prescot and Sullivan's Expedition in 1778- (which was 3 years after his first joining the army) -the least possible time he could have been engaged in these several Services was one year. Elizabeth Whaley was allowed pension on account of the Revolutionary War service of her husband, James Whaley on her application executed July 2, 1833, at which time she was aged seventy-one years and a resident of Salisbury Township, Meigs County, Ohio. It was stated that James Whaley and his wife, Elizabeth, reared a family of ten children. The only names designated as their children were the following whose ages in 1820 were shown as follows: James, aged nine, Anne Rebecca, aged six; William N. aged four, and Harriet, aged one. The names of two children of Elizabeth Whaley by her former husband, Benjamin Hall, are shown as follows: Sally Ann Hall and John P. Hall who in July, 1883, were living in Wood County, Virginia, and in August, same year, John P. Hall's place of residence was given as Wirt County, Virginia. his age, fifty-three years. The age of Sally Ann was not stated. The name of James Whaley's brother-in-law, William Massy, is shown in the claim, the name of William Massy's wife not stated. In 1820, one Levi Page witnessed the signature of James Whaley in Wood County, Virginia, his relationship to Elizabeth whaley was not shown. In 1833, one James W. Whaley testified in behalf of the soldier in Meigs County, Ohio, no relationship stated between them. In order to obtain date of last payment of pension, the name and address of the person paid and possibly the date of death of Elizabeth Whaley, you should write to the Comptroller General, General Accounting Office, Records Division, this city, and cite the following data: Elizabeth Whaley, widow of James, certificate first issued August 18, 1833, rate as per annum, commenced February 3, 1853, Act of February 3, 1853, Ohio Agency. [illegible] Jan 1840 Kind Sir I received yours of the 1st in showing the decision of the Count of pensions against Correcting the case of my Mothers Claims. They will not acknowledge the date of the marriage or his subsequent services to the authority established. Now, sir the evidence of Stephen Hyatt, David Hyatt, Edward Pope & Susan Hyatt all go to demonstrate those now facts in connection with the bible record. Those evidences are clear and they are proof of good Credit, memory & understanding to the bible record of the marriage they have because the had no children recorded until about three years after. What principle of justice is that? It is outrageous. Consider that the evidence of Susan Hyatt (the nurse) on that point-- yet say they it is not precisely established. What then can establish facts. And as to his subsequent services there is no record but it is fully proved by the above witnesses- they all know that they were married & that he served the United States afterward-most know what the Law demands and I also know- that in the justice & nature of those Laws nothing more can be wanting. Now sir-where is the authority of that bound to adopt rates of decision to counteract the laws of Congress-Yet after considering the case I am bold to say that in some instances they do do it- As you intimated if you will be so understanding as to appeal to the Secretary of war you will oblige. Your most obedient and Humble Servant L. Hyatt Hon. J. H. Prentiss M.C.

State of Newyork ) Otsego County )fs. Otego July the 27th 1838 Personly appeared before me Jefse s. Hurlbut a Justice of the peace within and for the County aforesaid Charles S. Hyatt of said Otego who being duly sworn according to law deposeth and saith that he is Thirty five years of age and a son of Samuel Hyatt late of the aforesaid Town County and State decd.--And that he did transcribe in or about the year 1825 from an old family Bible into a new bible of the family then purchased by his Father the aforesaid Samuel Hyatt the following record "Samuel Hyatt married to Judy Pope the 6th of September 1782" And that the old record from which he copied the aforesaid was in the hand writing of and written by his Father the aforesaid Samuel Hyatt and that the new bible containing the aforesaid transcript is now in his house in safe keeping by his Mother the widow of the aforesaid Samuel Hyatt. And that search of late being much for the aforesaid old record it is not now to be found and that he can now give no other account and thinks that no one can than the following. That the bible was old and much in pieces and that the leaf Containing the record was loose by itself or with another leaf the last he recollects of it which he thinks was as late as within a year or two past. That he had not Considered it of any special value seeing they had other bibles and the same records. And that the old bible is now in his house with the old record and several other parts gone for which he can give no further account. Charles S Hyatt Sworn and subscribed on the day and year aforesaid. That I am well acquainted with the said Charles S. Hyatt and believe him to be a credible witness and worthy to be believed. Jefse S Hurlbut Justice of the peace

State of Kentucky Bullitt County Towit On this Eleventh day of March [February crossed out] 1839 Came Famariah Cardwell widow of William Cardwell decd [deceased] before me David L Brooks a Justice Peace for Said County & State, who being first sworn according to Law, States that she was married to her deceased husband Wm Cardwell in Culpeper County Virginia in 1781, as she confidently believes but she cannot remember the month or day, that they had the marriages & Births & registered in a family Bible and that some number of years ago her son William Cardwell tore out & from the same nearly all the Record evidence - tearing out the Record of her age marriage &c and she has since that time forgotten the Precise dates - She states that she has employed George F Pope Esq and also Noah C Summers to write to the office in sd [said] County of Culpeper Virginia for the Record of Their marriages - she had recd [received] for answer from both of them that they have written and cannot get any response although they first wrote last fall - She states she is poor & Cannot find means to send a special messenger to Virginia or she must do so to try & find the records - She states that the ages of two of her children are recorded in the family Bible & was done long since by the direction of the sd [said] William Cardwell her husband, towit her fourth and eleventh Children - That she has had eleven Children viz Nancy 1st now the widow of Nicholas Brown, Elizabeth, 2d now widow of Robert Shirley, Benjamin 3d (dead) Lewis the fourth son recorded in the Bible born the (25 December 1785.) Twenty fifth of December Seventeen hundred & Eighty Five dead - William (the 5 son) Susan (6th) wife of Joel W Hundley. Jane (7th) married Wm Kirk & is dead - George (8th) John (9th) Mary (10th) married Willis Watson - Edmund, the Eleventh Son, recorded in the Bible born first of November Eighteen hundred & one (1 Novr [November] 1801) dead - She states that she does not now remember of any of her old friends living that can prove her marriage - she has shortly since some towit John Casey & Phillip Yancy of Franklin County Ky
