I Rebecca Burch aged upwards of seventy years for the purpose of availing myself of the benefits of the second Section of the Act of Congress of the 4th of July, 1836 entitled "An Act granting half pay to widows or orphans where their husbands and fathers have died of wounds received in the military service of the United States in certain cases and for other purposed" do declare That Captain Benjamin Burch deceased to the best of my knowledge and belief entered into the regular service of the United States in the Revolutionary WAr in or about the year 1779, in the Maryland line and that he continued in service until the War was over & was regularly discharged and returned home that he entered as a private & as I have been informed & do believe, he held the rank of a Sergeant at his discharge, which was in the year 1783. That Benjamin Burch and myself were lawfully married by the Reverend Mr John Carroll, who was afterwards Arch Bishop of the Catholic Church in America in the County of Prince George in the State of Maryland, soon after the return of Benjamin Burch from the War the month I cannot positively state, but believe it was September the year 1784. That my husband often informed me that he was in several battles during his service the names or places of which I cannot state with certainty except that at Camden in South Carolina which he was denominates as Gates defeat, from which he made good his retreat after the regiment to which he belonged was nearly destroyed; and in his retreat found & joined Genl Sumpters forces and was with them when they were surprised & defeated by Col: Tarlton of the British Army, where my hus-

WAR DEPARTMENT, PENSION OFFICE, July 17, 1838. The following rules, prescribed by the President of the United States, and adopted by the Secretary of War, in order to carry into effect the act of Congress of the 7th July, 1838, entitled "An act granting half pay and pensions to certain widows," are published for the information of applicants under that law. 1. Applicants must produce the best proof the nature of the case will allow, as to the service of the deceased officer or soldier, and the time when he died. It must be clearly shown in what troop or company, and regiment or corps, he served, and the grade he held. Proof, as to service, must be had, either from the records of the War Department, the muster-rolls, the testimony of commissioned officers, or the affidavits of persons of known respectability. Every applicant will make a declaration according to the subjoined form, before a court of record, setting forth, according to the best of her knowledge or belief, the name and rank of the person on account of whose service the claim is presented; the day, month, and year, (of possible,) when he entered the service, and the time when he left the same; and, if under more than one engagement, the claimant must specify the particular periods, and the rank and names of the officers under whom the service was performed; the town or county, and State in which he resided when he entered the service; whether he was drafted, was a volunteer, or substitute; the battles, if any, in which he was engaged; the country through which he marched, with such further particulars as may be useful in the investigation of the claim. From the best sources of information, evidence must be derived as to the period of the death of the officer or soldier. 2. The legality of the marriage, and the time when it took place, must be clearly established; and it must also be shown that the widow was never afterwards married. Record-proof, as to the marriage, is always required, whenever it can be obtained. In a case where the town, county, parish, church, or family records afford no proof as to the period when the marriage took place, the fact must be established by the testimony of one or more respectable persons, whose credibility must be certified by the officer who may administer the oath. And, in order to prevent any mistake or improper use that may be made of the affidavit of an officer who may have the custody of records, from which he may make transcripts of the record, in relation to a marriage, the officer who may give his affidavit will, instead of copying the figures contained in the record, certify "that it is a true copy of the record, with the exception of the date, which is expressed on the record in fair, legible figures, as follows:" [bracket] Here copy the day, month, and year, in letters and figures, in exact conformity with the original. Then let him add the following words: [/bracket] "I, A. B., above named, depose and say: that I hold the office [blank] in the county, town, and State aforesaid, and that the above is a true extract from the records of said [blank] with the exception above named, as certified by me. A. B., Clerk of the [blank] (or rector, or pastor, as the case may be.) Sworn before me, C. D., Justice of the Peace." And then will follow the certificate of the proper officer, under his seal of office, as to the official character and signature of the magistrate who may administer the oath. Where no record proof exists, other than the family record, the original record must be produced and sworn to by the person in whose possession it has been kept. 3. In a case where the service of the deceased officer or soldier is clearly proved by record or documentary evidence, or the affidavit of a commissioned officer, showing the grade and length of service of the deceased, the particulars in relation to the service are not required to be set forth in the claimant's declaration; but she must swear in positive terms that she is the widow of the person

Declaration of Rebecca Burch, widow of Benjamin Burch, in order to obtain the benefit of an act of Congress of the 7th of July 1838, entitled An act granting half pay and Pensions to certain widows. District of Columbia } County of Washington } [illegible] On this third day of September 1838. personally appeared before [word scratched out] me William Cranch, chief Judge of the District of Columbia Rebecca Burch, a resident of the City of Washinton, in the County of Washinton in the District of Columbia, aged about Seventy five years, and being infirm who being first duly sworn according to law doth on her oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the pension made by the act of Congress passed July 7. 1838 entitled "An act granting half pay and pensions to certain widows"-- That she is the widow of Benjamin Burch, who was a Sergeant in the Mayland line of the Continental troops of the Revolutionary army- That all she knows of the service of her said late husband is set forth in her declaration under oath, in due form of law, before [crossed out] the [end crossed out] W Justice Hebb on the 3d of Decemr. 1836, and which was further sworn to in open court before the circuit Court of the County of Washington in the District of Columbia on the 14th of Decmr. 1836, an attested copy of which, accompanies this declaration - She further declares that she was married to the said Benjamin Burch by the Revd. John Carroll, the arch Bishop of the Catholic Church in the United States of America, and in Prince George County in the state of Maryland in or about the month of September one thousand seven hundred & Eighty four (1784) the Exact day she does not now recollect & cannot ascertain

December 29, 1939. Harmon Kelly, Pastor, Methodist Church 405 East Salo Street Tuscola, Illinois RA-J/ILL Jonathan Tharp W. 3877 Dear Sir: Reference is made to your letter in which you request the Revolutionary War record of Jonathan Tharp, a pensioner of North Carolina. The data which follow were found in the papers on file in pension claim, W.3877, based upon service of Jonathan Tharp in that war. Jonathan Tharp, called John Tharp, enlisted sometime in 1779, in Accomack County, Virginia, served as private in Captain Southy Copes' company and under Colonel Bebiger in the Virginia troops, was stationed first at a fort on an island near the Virginia coast, where he, with the company, was taken prisoner by a British privateer schooner, "Irish Hero", was put in irons for a day, after which he was confined in the hold of the schooner, was exchanged, then served at a blockhouse on the Potomac River and was discharged by Colonel John Copper (possible meant for Cropper), having served eighteen months. He enlisted later, served as private in Captain John Kirkpatrick's company, Colonel Webb's Virginia regiment, was in several skirmishes in Chesterfield and Cumberland Counties, Virginia, and was discharged sometime after the surrender of Cornwallis. He was allowed pension on his application executed March 8, 1826, at which time he resided in Surry County, North Carolina. He was aged then sixty-three years: the data and place of his birth and the names of his parents were not given. In 1826, when Jonathan Tharp applied for pension, he had the following children living at home: two grown daughters, one son,

The Methodist Church Harmon Kelly, Pastor Tuscola, Illinois 405 East Sale Street Tuscola, Illinois December 12, 1939 Administrator Veterans Administration Washington D.C. Dear Sir: I am writing to secure any information you may be able to supply relative to Jonathan Tharp, a Revolutionary War soldier from North Carolina, whom I have reason to believe is my great-great grandfather. From the North Carolina Roster of Revolutionary Soldiers, published by the North Carolina Daughters of the American Revolution, page 586 - Revolutionary pensioners under the Act of 1818 and 1832, as reported by the Secretary of State to Congress in 1835, I find 1519 Jonathan Tharp, private. I wonder if there might be records in the pension files which will show names of children, and other data, which may help me to determine if this individual is my great-great grandfather. Thanking you in advance for any information you can give me relative to the above, I am Very sincerely yours, Signature [Harmon Kelly] Harmon Kelly 405 East Sale Street Tuscola, Illinois [Circular stamp RECEIVED Dec 13 1939 MAIL SUB-DIV Reader No. 4 VETS ADM ]

No. 122. party, and gave the petitioner command over them, with the commission of a captain, signed by General Washington; that he acted under it until he left the army; that he continued at Long Island until the army retreated, about the latter part of July, or beginning of August, 1776; that he proceeded from thence to the city of New York, and remained there until it was determined to evacuate the city; that he was then directed by General Washington to assist with his men in the removal of baggage, tents, provisions, stores, &c. up the North river; that he and his men, while thus engaged, were discovered and fired upon by a party of British soldiers, called "row-galleys;" that, by great exertions, they reached the army in safety. General Washington had heard the firing, and met them as they entered the camp, and commended them for their prudence and courage, and directed them to go into the camp and get some refreshments; that the petitioner was in the battle or skirmish at Harlem heights, under Colonel Knowlton, who was killed; he had been reconnoitring, and on his return had fallen in with Colonel Knowlton. In this battle he saw Major Leitch, of Virginia, carried off the field, severely wounded; that the petitioner himself was wounded in this skirmish by a musket-ball in the leg, which rendered him incapable to perform duty for several weeks; that he subsequently accompanied General Washington in his retreat through New Jersey, and was in the battles of Trenton and Princeton, being attached, in these two engagements, to that part of the army commanded by General Washington in person; he was occasionally (in the absence of General Washington) under command of Generals Putnam and Lee; he was acquainted with them, and also with General Arnold, Major Leitch, Colonel Knowlton, Colonel Baldwin, and Major Atwater, of the militia, but has forgotten the names of many other officers with whom he was acquainted. That he left the army, late in the year 1779, in the neighborhood of Morristown, New Jersey, about going into winter quarters; that he left the army in consequence of his wound having broken out afresh, which made him unfit for service: being a volunteer, he did not receive a formal discharge; that he was in the service about three years and six months; that during the whole time, he received neither money nor clothing from the Government, (except his rations,) but was furnished with both by his father, who was then in good circumstances; that, after he recovered, he was engaged in settling his father's estate, and employed as agent for different individuals, to act at different places, for a number of years; that his residence was finally taken up at Burlington, New Jersey; and while on a visit to Homer, in the State of New York, he was taken sick, and reported at home to be dead: in consequence of which, his friends broke open his trunk, and his papers (among which were the commission spoken of, and a journal of the principal events that happened during his service) were either lost or destroyed. To this is attached the certificate of Peter Powell, minister of the Gospel, Moses Lill, and Christian Larzelere, respectable citizens of Burlington, who are well acquainted with the petitioner, that he is a man of good character, and believed and reputed to have been a soldier in the revolutionary war. And the judges of the court of common pleas for the said county of Burlington , having examined the petitioner upon the interrogatories prescribed by the War Department, believe him to have been a soldier of the revolution, and to have served as he states.

Easton Pa June 1, 1840 Dear Sir I have known Chauney Rice, for several years. He is a man of exemplary character & a member in full communion with the Presbytenan Church in this place. He has always been reputed, to have been an officer in the Revolutionary Army, since I have known him. He was in quite comfortable circumstances until within a few years back when he lost what he [unclear] worth by Moses Sill. I can freely bear testimony to his character for unblemished integrity and for undoubted veracity. I do not believe he would utter a wilful falsehood for all the pensions that Congress could bestow. The Revd Mr Gray the pastor of our church is absent or he would cheerfully join in all I say, for I know that we concur in opinion in relation to Captain Rice. Very Truly Yours JM Porter The Honble DD Wagener

Easton June 4th 1840 Honble D D Wagener Respected Sir, The delay in answering yours of the 30th was occasioned by my absence from this place. Having returned last evening I hasten to reply, by saying that in my judgment Captain Rice is a man of strict and undeviating[?] integrity- nay more that he is a man of profound and unquestionable piety. As such, our Church Session unanimously received him in into membership, and as such, after trial, we still unanimously regard him. So fully do or confide in his verity, that I believe Congress does not possess the power or the wealth sufficient to bribe him, standing as he does on the brink of the grave & as I believe on the threshold of glory, to declare a known falsehood. Yours very respectfully &c J. Gray, Pastor of the Presbytenan Church in the Borough of Easton Pa. I concur in the above Tho McKeen

The State of New Jersey Cape May County SS } Personally appeared before the Subscriber one of the Justices of the Peace in and for the said County being a Court of record and in open Court Joshua Crawford, the Son of Sarah Crawford who is the widow of Richard Crawford, who being by me duly Sworn according to law did depose and say that he is the President of the First Baptist Church of the County of Cape May and holds the books of said Church. That his mother Sarah Crawford was married to his Father Richard Crawford by one David Smith Pastor of said Baptist Church - That he has searched and examined the books aforesaid, and find no entry of any marriage made therein by said Smith or of any other person for him of any marriage while he was Pastor as aforesaid which appears to have been about Eight years and that Artis Legrave was also Pastor of said Church for about three years immediately after as the Successor of said Smith, and that that there is no record of any marriage by him during his stay but further says that he has frequently seen the certificate of marriage made and signed by the said David Smith which he believes to have been in his own proper hand writing and believes it to be true- and that the said David Smith is dead, as also all the persons that had any correct knowledge of the particular term the said Richd Crawford Served under Capt Jonathan Jenkins, or the particular names of the vessels in which he served, but that he served during the whole war and that said certificate of marriage has become lost. Joshua Crawford Sworn & Subscribed, this 27th day of April 1837. Witness my hand and seal this day and year aforesaid Joshua Hildreth Justice of the peace

nor the battles in which he was engaged - that Nathaniel Holmes who is since died who during his life time received a pention [pension] was in the same service, and was also a prisoner at Antiga at the same time and was discharged at the same time that the said Richard Crawford was discharged- that said Richard was not discharged untill [until] some time after the proclamation of peace that he was legally married to this deponant [deponent] before his discharge - that said Richard received an honorable discharge Signed by General George Washington- which discharge has become mislayed or lost and cannot now be found-- that she has no documentary evidence in support of her claim. That the said Richard held and exercised the office of Boatswain during a portion of the time he was in the said service- that when the said Richard engaged in the United States service he resided in the County of Cape May and returned there immediately after his discharge. She further declares that she was married to the said Richard Crawford on the 14th day of April 1783, as will appear by the certificate of Marriage hereunto annexed signed by David Smith, who was the Minister of the Gospel belonging to the Baptist Church at Cape May Court House, that her Husband

some property enumerated in his Schedule was unable to support himself without the aid of his country. They are willing to add their own Testimony, so far as the facts have come within their knowledge, to that afforded by the official act of the court, and to state it as their belief that the means in the power of the said Thompson are insufficient for his maintenance. Of the correctness of this opinion there can be indeed but little question. A man of seventy three years of age, exposed in his better days to the hardships of a service more than ordinarily severe; now frequently afflicted with disease, the consequences of his exposure to the inclemency of every climate, can not be expected to acquire a subsistence for himself & his wife by labour alone. His property which indeed is intirely [entirely] at the mercy of his creditors affords no revenue. His house & Lott [lot] so long as it is left in his occupancy may afford him shelter, but where is he to get food & raiment? Is he to sell his property & subsist on it? That might be a transient relief were his property not incumbered. As to his personal property, it will be readily seen that to sell that part which is composed of his mechanical implements & which he can sometimes

And the said Ezekiel Beebe further declares and further states, that his property contained in his former schedule made June 26 A.D. 1820 ,+ not contained in this schedule, here been disposed of as followable, to wit the principal parcel of His land was taken on Execution to satisfy debts of Geo. T Hodges + Geo. T. Hodge Jr Co. the rest of his land his two Mares were taken by Doct. James Porter on his debt, leaving this deposer still indebted to the said Porter, his property not being sufficient to satisfy his debut. The shoats + the sheep not enumerated in this schedule have been eaten up by my family, except two sheep which were lost or have been killed by some other person the old waggon (SIC) has fallen to pieces + destroyed. The colt was also taken for a debt due to my son Ezekiel living in Paulet, + was of very little value, being appraised at about ten dollars. I have a wife named Aganes 60 in Aug 1821.+ in very poor health. My son John aged 16 years lives with me + is the only one of my family upon whom I can place any reliance for support being hisself (SIC) in very infirm health. Ezekiel Beebe

I will send Mr. Gilberts & my depns & the deed if you with it. You can testify to the execution of the deed and to the consideration, and that the above was all you could get for the land - and that this sum was not paid to Capt Goodrich but went to reimburse what had been paid for taxes and expenses which had been incurred on account of said land. The same having been applied to the payment of what had been long before advance to Capt Goodrich for the above and other purposes. If you are in haste to send on the papers, I think you had better give your deposition to the above effect; and that Capt Goodrich is really needy and in distress. As I stated to you before I should prefer applying directly to Congress by a petition praying that the back pay from the time his pension was withheld might be made up to Capt Goodrich. If you should think it best to have a petition drawn I will make it out, and send or get it to you. This however cannot be presented til Congress meets which will not be under some months. I remain with esteem your friend &c William Hillhouse

State of Illinois Pope County⎬ SS. On this third day of June in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and thirty three personally appeared in open court before the Judges of the county commissioners Court in and for the County of Pope in the State of Illinois, now sitting, Daniel Ford a resident of the County of Pope and State of Illinois aged on the first day of January last Sixty seven years who being duly sworn according to Law, doth on his oath make the following Declaration to obtain the benefit of the act of congress passed June the seventh 1832. That he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers and served as herein stated; I Volunteered in the County of Wilkes in the State of North Carolina in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and Eighty as well as I at this distant day can recollect and in the fall season of that year but the precise month and day from the great lapse of time I cannot positively State; under the command of Captain Joel Lewis at Wilkes court house in said County & State, and marched from thence to Guilford court house in Guilford County in the State of North Carolina, where I joined the 7th Regiment of said State. then stilled and known as the Twelve months men, under the command of General Green; from thence I was marched under the command of General Green to High Rock ford of Haw River in the State of North Carolina, where we remained a few days, and from thence was marched back again to Guilford court house; where I was Engaged in the battle against the British army under the command of Lord Cornwallace, where the American army fled, and retreated into the Edge of Surry County in the State of North Carolina; and thence marched back to the Battle ground to bury our dead Slain in the Battle, after this was accomplished, I was attached to Captain John Beaverly [illegible] and marched to Salisbury in Roane County in the State of North Carolina and was stationed at that place to guard the Prisoners, there; where I remained in that service something like Eleven weeks; from thence I was marched to Randolph County in the said State of North Carolina in pursuit of the Torey's [Tories], where I remained about two months; I was then placed under the

command of Captain Samuel Johnson, who was commanded by Major Hargrove and marched from thence to the borders of South Carolina in pursuit of the Tory's [Tories], where we had a small engagement with the Tories, which soon fled; and from thence we were marched into Chatham County in the State of North Carolina where we remained about seven weeks, in pursuit of an other Band of Tories, whom we soon came up with and took about sixty of them and conveyed them to the Barracks at Salisbury; where I remained about two weeks, and was placed under the command of Captain John Beaverly again, who was commanded by Colonel Benjamin Cleaveland, and was thence marched in pursuit of the noted Tory Colonel Bryant with his Band, whom we soon came up with and took about 25 of his band prisoners, whom be returned also to the Barracks at Salisbury where I remained about two months on guard duty; and generally remained on this duty at the said Barracks, until I was finally discharged from the service of the United States of having served something over Twelve months, in all. I hereby Relinquish every Claim that I have no Documentary Evidence of my service, but can prove the same by Barnabus Sisk & William Davis. The following interrogatories were put by the court to Daniel Ford. Interrogatory 1st. Where and in what year were you born Answer. I was born in the State of Virginia, and Shenandoah County on the first day of January in the year seventeen Hundred & Sixty six Interrogatory 2nd Have you any Record of your age, and if so, where is it Answer; I have the Record of my age at my house in Pope County in the State of Illinois; as Recorded by my father in his family Bible Interrogatory 3d. Where were you living when called into service, where have you lived since the Revolutionary War, and where do you now live Answer. When called into service I was living in Wilkes County in the State of North Carolina, I have lived in the State of Tennessee Overton County, in the State of Kentuck [Kentucky], Hopkins County and at this time I am living in Pope County in the State of Illinois

Interrogatory 4th. How were you called into service, were you drafted, did you volunteer, or were you a substitute, and if a substitute for whom Answer. I volunteered into service Interrogatory 5th. State the names of some of the Regular officers, who were with the troops where you served, such continental and Militia Regiments as you can recollect, and general circumstances of your service Answer. General Nathaniel Green, Colonel Cleaveland, General Pickens, Capt Joel Lewis, Captain John Beaverly and Contain Samuel Johnson - the 7th Regiment commanded by General Nathaniel Green-- the General circumstances of my services are as near as I can at this time recollect as above in this Declaration stated Interrogatory 6th. Did you ever receive a discharge from the service; and if so by whom was it given, and what has become of it Answer. I did receive a discharge from the service, given and signed by Captain Samuel Johnson. Which discharged burned together with my house and all that was contained in it in the State of Kentucky I hereby Relinquish every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present, and declare that my name is not on the pension Roll of the Agency of any State, or (if any) only on that of the Agency of the State of North Carolina Sworn to and Subscribed the day and year aforesaid Daniel Fox his X mark We John Hamilton - a Clergyman, residing in Pope County in the State of Illinois and Jason B. Smith, Esqr Residing in the County of Pope and State of Illinois hereby certify, that we are well acquainted with Daniel Fox who has subscribed and Sworn to the above Declaration; that we believe him to be Eighty seven years of age; that he is reputed and believed in the neighbourhood where he resides, to have been a soldier of the Revolution, and that we concur in that opinion. Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid John Hamilton Jason B. Smith

State of Illinois Pope County Sct. And the said court do hereby certify declare their opinion, after the investigation of the matter, and puting the interrogatories prescribed by the War Department, that the above named applicant was a Revolutionary Soldier, and served as he states. And the court further certifies, that it appears to them that John Hamilton who has signed the preceeding certificate, is a clergyman resident in the County of Pope and State of Illinois, and that Jason B. Smith, who has also signed the same is a resident in the County of Pope and State of Illinois and is a creditable person, and that their statement is entitled to credit. I, George W. Waters Clerk of the county commissioners Court in and for the said County of Pope in the said State of Illinois, do hereby certify that the foregoing contains the original proceedings in the matter of the application of Daniel Fox for a pension. (L.S.) In Testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand and private seal (there being no public one) in my office at Golconda, this third day of June A.D. one thousand eight hundred and thirty three and of the Independence of the United States of America the fifty seventh. Geo. W. Waters Clk C.C.C.P.C. This is to certify that I am personally known and acquainted with Geo. W Waters whose signature is to the above certificate and know him to be the Clerk as therein stated and certificate and attestation is in due form according to the Laws of Illinois Washington City Dec 3 1833 Chas Slade Dan'l Fox 24.885

five years, when her said husband died leaving her with two children, that she was married to sd Alvord the Rev. Noah Hobart pastor of the Congregational Church in sd Town of Fairfield that her maiden name was Mary Beers that in the 15th or 16th of June 1785 she was married to the said Joseph Perry then of sd Fairfield by the Revd Timothy Dwight Pastor the Congregational Church in Greenfield Parish in sd Fairfield that from the time of Sd Marriage to the day of sd Perrys death she always resided with him that his death occured on the 21st day of December 1829 that from that to the present time she has remained the sd Joseph Perrys widow that she was not married to the sd Perry prior to his leaving the service, but that her marriage took place previous to the 1st of January 1794 viz at the time above Stated Sworn to and subscribed on Mary Perry the day and year as above written before me the interlocutions, Record, made before signing Rufus Blakeman Judge And this sd Court hereby declare its opinion that the facts stated in the foregoing declaration of Mary Perry are true and that the sd Perry in the opinion of this Court is a person fully entitled to belief in her statements and that she is a credible person Rufus Blakeman Judge

And that some time afterwards he had a conversation with the said John Kennedy in regard to the Battle fought at that place that said John Kennedy appeared to be perfectly familiar with the situation or location of the said Battle ground and gave despondent much information about the Battle. Despondent Verily believes that the said John Kennedy did much actual service in the years 1780, 1781 and 1782 and was in the service until the end of said war. That beside the Battles before named the said John Kennedy told him the other Battles in which he had share which he cannot now recollect, that from the time that his acquaintance with said John Kennedy commenced which was nearly fifty years and which acquaintance continues until the time of his death he always knew him as a man of the most strict integrity & honor in all respects and therefore cannot doubt that everything that said John Kennedy told him of his Revolutionary Services was truth and nothing but the truth. Despondent resided in this same neighborhood in time of Revolutionary war and often saw parties of the British Soldiers while they were stationed in Camden and was acquainted with many incidents of the war which would confirm statements made despondent by said John Kennedy. That the said John Kennedy died in Nov 1832 and his widow Cherry Kennedy survived him until about the first of April 1845. That he knows their deaths occurred about those

which he does not now recollect that the said John Kennedy often related to despondent many circumstances and incidents connected with the Revolutionary war and that he (unknown) believes that the said John Kennedy did much actual service in the years 1780, 1781,& 1782, and was in the service until the close of the said war; that he knew the said John Kennedy and Cherry Kennedy his wife as very respectable and credible persons. that the said John Kennedy died in the month of November 1832 and his widow Cherry Kennedy Survived him until about the 1st of April 1845 when she also died, that both John and Cherry Kennedy died in this District, that he knows their deaths occurred at about the time mentioned above from Circumstances within his own recollection, that the said Argent Crosswell and her sister Sarah Crosswell are the only surviving children of the said John and Cherry Kennedy and their only heirs, that the said Argent and Sarah Crosswell are highly respectable and credible persons and it is the belief of all their acquaintances that their Father, the said John Kennedy was a faithful soldier of the revolutionary War. Despondent has seen the affidavits of John Crosswell Esq. and believes all that is stated therein to be the truth. Despondent farther swear that

day of March 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, and property, or securities, contracts or debts due to me; nor have any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. viz. Two hundred and twenty nine acres of poor land worth. . $100.00 Three head of horses (one mare and two colts) worth . . . . .60.00 Five head of sheep worth . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 5.00 Nine head of hogs worth . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 14.00 Seven head of cattle including 2 cows & calves 3 yearlings worth . . 25.00 One negro man 42 years of age worth . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 250.00 $454.00 And at the same time I justly owe the following debt and interest thereon for 3 years & eleven months } $421.86 by note, which note was given for the price of the } . . . . . .111.54 aforesaid negro man, to Charles Stark } Sub . . . . . . . . . . $533.40 Which leaves your petitioner in debt . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .$79.40 He further swears that he is by occupation a farmer and has been ever since he left the army, that his family consists of three persons viz himself, his wife Ann and an old negro man, that he himself is now seventy three years of age and is badly crippled in his right arm and leg so as to be utterly unable to maintain himself that his wife is sixty nine years of age, and is badly afflicted with the asthmatic affection and has bee so for about seven years and is entirely unable to maintain herself and is an expense and great trouble; the negro man is forty two years of age and as stout as men usually are at his age though somewhat on the decline. That since the eighteenth day of March 1818 the following changes have been made in my property, at that time, I was possessed of a tract of land of seventy one and one fourth acres two head of horses, four head of cattle and nine head of hogs; that land was sold by me to Martin Fralix in 1820 for the sum of three hundred and eighty dollars in money (but good and sufficient titles were not made until the twenty second day of September in the year of our lOrd one thousand eight hundred and twenty eighty as will be seen by reference to the authenticated copy of the Deed of Conveyance of the said land herewith exhibited) and a mare rated at eighty dollars, and after paying the debts that I then owed which was about sixty dollars, the balance was applied to the purchase of the tract of land that I now live on; I have had five head of horses to die since that time and

New Jersey --- Ezra Brown, Private, served 1 year from 1775 -------- 1st schedule dates 11 July 1820 containing 42 acres of land, 1 horse, 1 Wagon & harness 1 Cow, 2 hogs, 8 sheep, and sundry articles of furniture $ 299.21 Debts due by him and names of creditors given $719.50-------------- Schedule under act March 1823, dated July 1823 contains 41 acres & 27/100 of an acre of land without any buildings- 1 cow, 4 sheep, 1 hog and various farming and household articles $354.54 --------------- Owes to Joseph Pierson for the land mentioned in schedule $250.00 and to sundry other persons. 48.00 $298.00 Accounts for decrease the property by sale of the house the value of which has been consumed in support of his family, and the wagon in the same way. The debts due to him have been collected and [cut off] also paid to persons to whom [cut off] was indebted for the same, and owing to deprecation of landed property[cut off] pension that the laws will not be sufficient to pay the balance due it, and that the last payment will be due in October next. Claimant exhibits his affidavit made the 23d February 1824, before David Thomas [cut off] Jr. Master in Chancery, stating that since the rejection of his claim the agent of Joseph Pierson to whom he owed a balance of $250 for the land, ordered a prosecution for the balance rather than undergo which and be subject to additional costs the claimant sold the land to Lewis Pierson for $272, which cancelled the bond for the land. Joseph Cutler who was the agent to prosecute, and Lewis Pierson who bought the land, certify the claimant's statement is correct and an authenticated copy of deed to Lewis Pierson is produced. The Hon. Mr Condict states that the claimant is his neighbor and that he personally knows him to be destitute and needy; that he is prudent & temperate man, and in poverty constitutes any title to a restoration the claimant deserves it.- Hon Lewis Condict, H.R. Restored April 13 1824 & sent as above Mar 1819

He looked out no foe was to be seen; and calling to negroes to be on their guard, he hurried to his own particular post, trembling lest ould find his temporary absence had given advantage to his enemies. tily sweeping the top of the wall with his he next looked to the fastenings of the and finding all secure, he drew a long of relief, and resolved henceforth to be watchful and guarded. He then reprimed le, keeping a wary look-out for the en- nd leaning the piece against the stockade, k up another, (he had four altogether) he had placed there after arming the previous to his shooting the savage. d likewise reprimed, and returned to its putting the axe beside it; and then bra- back against one of the palisade posts, nging his favorite weapon into a good po-or a quick aim, he awaited, in anxious the next hostile movement of the r the simpleton, the moment Hargrave left him, he turned to the arrow which had so nearly proved fatal to his benefactor, and the point of which had been driven deeply into one of the logs of the cabin, and drawing it forth, coolly examined it, with an air of idle curiosity. While standing thus, he heard a distant twang, a whizzing sound, and, almost at the same instant, another shaft, with lightning velocity, passed close by his head, and buried its point in the same log as the first, and within an inch of the same spot. "O-ho, Mr. Savage: is that your game?" he muttered looking up. "You shoot from the sky, so you? but you don't stand on nothing, as any fool might know; and so on what you do stand is clearly manifest." Drawing the second arrow from the log, he quickly advanced to the stockade to avoid further exposure, and followed this round till he came to Hargrave. "See!" he whispered, holding out the arrows: "here are two of Beelzebub's cards, inviting us to a goblin frolic." "Tso?" returned Hargrave, in surprise. "Yes, Major - one came since you left- but don't let us accept the invitation." "Ha!" said Hargrave, uneasily; "two arrows shot into the enclosure, and the Indian living to repeat the daring feat! I fear Dick's eyes are not quick and keen enough for his post!" "Why, sir, you shouldn't blame Dick for not seeing what is not to be seen" returned Jacob. "You were there when the first arrow arrived - did you see where it came from?" "Some Indian must have climbed the stockade, and shot it from the top. True, I did not see him - but I think, if I had been in Dick's position, I should have seen him the second time." "No!" said the simpleton, positively; "no, Major, you would not. I know where the Indian was and is," he continued; "and he was and is where you do not suspect him to be." "And where is he then? If you know, speak!" said Hargrave, quickly. The simpleton was about to give a correct answer, when his hand accidentally rested on the barrel of the rifle that stood leaning against the palisade. Had it been light enough to have seen his features at that moment, the observer would have been struck with the expression of idiotic cunning which they displayed. "In the air, Major - in the air," he said in reply to Hargrave's question. "Go, Roley - go into the house," rejoined the Major, kindly. "Heaven never made you for such scenes as these - and you will only get killed, without doing us any service." The simpleton seemed to slink away as Hargrave ceased speaking- but, unperceived by the latter, he carried the rifle with him. As soon as he believed himself entirely beyond the Major's observation, he both laughed and danced, but without making any noise. When he had thus given sufficient vent to his hilarious feelings, he began a seris of operations, the design of which, if design there was, might have puzzled any one of more brains than Jacob to make out. He first crept round to the spot where the arrows had lodged, and, laying his rifle down alongside the cabin, deliberately took off his coat, keeping his person the while as close to the ground as possible. Then placing the coat over the muzzle of the piece, he laid himself flat on his back, and raising the garment high above his head, moved it slowly to and fro, keeping his eyes at the same time on the upper line of the stockage. The ruse was successful; for in less than a minute, an arrow, from an unseen source, pierced the garment, and pinned it to the cabin. We say from an unseen source came the arrow - for he who shot it remained invisible, and not so much as a shadow was seen along the top of the wall. The simpleton, however, seemed perfectly satisfied with the result, and at no loss what to do next. With great caution he removed the coat form the arrow, leaving the latter sticking in the log; and then carefully cocking the rifle, he placed the breach against the cabin, a little back to the gate, and at once felt for the weapon in question. To his surprise, his utter astonishment, he found it on the very spot where he had placed it. "This is wonderful!" he said to himself, as he returned to the negroes. but danger was pressing, and he made no further remark to them on the subject. After giving them some instructions in a low tone, the three advanced to the front wall. Carefully withdrawing the block from the loop hole nearest the gate, the Major, exercising the greatest caution, peered through the aperture. Within a few feet of him stood a number of dusky, half-naked savages, all seemingly intent upon their task of hewing down the gate. Perceiving he was not observed, the Major drew back and then slowly and cautiously the muzzles of the three rifles were pushed through the little opening, in an oblique direction. The moment these were fairly brought to bear upon the group of dusky forms, Hargrave, in a tone that was intentionally raised to a perfect yell, cried: "Fire!" Like one piece, with a single report, the three rifles belched forth their deadly contents; and four savages, one dead, two mortally wounded, dropped to the earth, with cries of pain. For a moment their companions stood paralyzed with surprise and terror; and then, with screeches and yells, loud and wild, they suddenly bounded away down the knoll, leaving the wounded at the mercy of their foes. It was now that Hargrave, acting wholly from impulse, and with a reckless daring worthy of a madman, threw down his rifle, seized his axe, tore open the gate, rushed out, brained the deserted Indians, gather up their weapons, and bounded into the enclosure, escaping unharmed. All this was the work, as it were, of a single minute; and not till it was over, did the Major fairly comprehend his own fool-hardiness- Then, trembling at the thought, that he had for the time perilled not only his own life, but lives of those he held more dear than his own, he grew weak as a child, and leaned against the stockade for support. "What a thing is man, when reason loses control!" he muttered: "a mariner without a compass - a vessel without a helm." (TO BE CONTINUED.) Presence of Mind. - the Calders, of Calder, were descended from a brother of Macbeth, to whom, on his assumption of the crown, he resigned the thanedom of Cawdor. They ended in an heir as, Muriella Calder, who was captured in childhood by John of Lorn and the Campbells, whilst walking out with her nurse near Calder Castle. Her uncles pursued and overtook the division to whose care she had been entrusted, and would have rescued her but for the presence of mind of Campbell of Inverliver, who, seeing their approach, inverted a large camp-kettle, as it to conceal her, and commanding his seven sons to defend to the death, hurried on with his prize. The young men were all slain, and when the Calders lifted up the kettle, no Muriella was to be found. Meanwhile, so much time had been gained, that further pursuit was useless. The nurse, at the moment the child was seized, bit off a joint of her little finger, in order to mark her identity, - no unnecessary caution, as appears from Campbell of Auchinbreck's reply to one, who, in the midst of their felicitations on arriving safely in Argyle, asked what was to be done should the child die before she was marriageable? "She can never die," said he, "so long as a red-haired lassie can be found on either side of Lockame." John of Lorn and his captive were afterwards married. PERSONAL APPEARANCE OF MARIE ANTOINETTE._- Her precocious beauty elipsed that of Madame du Barry, the favorite of Louis XV., and the modern Phryne. But the beauty of Madame du Barry was that of a courtezan; the beauty of Marie Antoinette was that of a princess. Nature had adorned her with all the gifts that made her, as a woman, an object of admiration , and, as a Queen, an object for adoration; in shape tall, her movements were swanlike in carriage and deportment; in elegance such as to lose nothing of her majesty; her hair was blonde and silken, and its warm tints reminded the beholder of the wavy tresses of a Titian; a lofty oval forehead, like to those of the fair daughters of the Danube; eyes of liquid azure, in which the calm and the tempest of the soul made the look by turns sleep or undulate; the nose slightly aquiline; the mouth Austrian, of her family, that is, a mingling of pride and of a smile; the chin turned up; her color heightened by the chill climate of the north; an irresistible grace shed like a youthful vapor over all her features, and which did not allow her to be viewed but through an atmosphere of fire or of inebriation. -- Larmatine's History of the continent Assembly. down, and how you wondered what people meant by calling the moon "cold;" how you wound up your watch half-adfozen times a day, and hadn't the slightest idea whether you were eating geese of grindstones for dinner; how affectionately you nodded to Mr. Brown, of whom her father bought his groceries; how complacently you sat out the minister's seventh-l lie by her side at church; how wolfy you felt if any other piece of broadcloth approached her; how devoutly you wished you were that little bit of blue ribbon round her throat; and how one moonlight night, when she laid her head against your vest pattern, you --- didn't care a in-julep whether the tailor ever got paid for it or not! Now, just imagine her paps, stepping in and deliberately turning all that cream to vinegar; wouldn't you have effervesced? Certainly. See that little army of boots in the entry ouside the doors. May I need a pair of spectacles, if one of their owners has a decent foot! No. 20 turns his toes in, NO. 80 treads over a the side; No. 40 has a pedestal like an elephant. Stay! there's a pair now -- Jupiter! what a high instep! what a temper that man has! wonder if those are married boots? - Heaven help Mrs. Boots when her husband finds a missing button! It strikes me that I should like to mis-mate all those boots, and view, at a respectful distance, the young tornado in this entry, when the gong sounds! Oh, you cunning little curly-headed fairy-footed, dimple-limbed pet! Who is blessed enough to own you? Did you know, you little human blossom, that I was aunt to all the children in creation? Your eyes are as blue as the violets, and your little pouting lip migth tempt a bee from a rose. Did mamma make you that dainty little kirtle? and papa find you that horsewhip? "Papa is dead, and mamma is dead, too. --Mamma can't see Charley any more." God bless your sweet helplessness! creep into my arms, Charley. My darling, you are never alone! - mamma's sweet tender eyes look lovingly on Charley out of Heaven; mamma's bright angel wings overshadow ever little Charley's head; mamma and the holy stars keep watch over Charley's slumbers.- Mamma sings a sweeter song when little Charley says a prayer. Going? - well, then one kiss; for sure I am the angels will want you before long. What is that? A sick gentleman, borne in on a litter, from shipboard. Poor fellow! how sunken are his great dark eyes! how emaciated his limbs! What can ail him? nobody knows; not a word of English can he speak; and the captain is already off, too happy to rid himself of all responsibility. Lucky for the poor invalid that our gallant host has a heart warm and true. How tenderly he lifts the invalid to his room; how expeditiously he despatches his orders for an Italian doctor and nurse; how imploringly the sufferer's speaking eyes, are fastened upon his face. Ah! Death glided in at yonder door with the sick man; his grasp is already on his heart; the doctor stans aside and folds his hands - there is not work for him to do; dark shadows gather round the dying stranger's eyes; he presses feebly the hand of his humane host; and gasps out the last fluttering breath on that manly heart. Strange hands are busy closing his eyes: strange hands straighten his limbs; a strange priest comes all too late to shrive the sick man's soul' strange eyes gaze carelessly upon the features, one glimpse of which were worth Golconda's mines to far-off kindred. Now the undertaker comes with the coffin. Touch him gently, man of business; lay those dark locks tenderly on the satin pillow hear you not a far-off wail from sunny Italy, as the merry song at the vintage feast dies upon the lip of the stricken-hearted? FANNY FERN. BEAUTY AND THE BEAST -In November, 1783, Anne, the eldest daughter of George the Second and Queen Caroline, was married, in the Chapel Royal of St. James's, to the Prince of Orange, a man, the hideousness of whose appearance is said to have been only exceeded by some monster in a pantomime, or some ogre in a fairy tale. In giving him her hand, the princess seems to have been entirely influenced by a love of power. "I would die to-morrow to be a Queen to-day." she observed on one occasion to her mother. When her father spoke affectionately to her of the ungainliness of her lover's appearance, and told her it was not yet too late to recede - "I would marry him," she said, "even if he were a baboon." The subsequent story of the princess and her lover is that of the "Beauty and the Beast" over again. Lord chesterfield tells us that he had many excellent qualities; and, accordingly, notwithstanding his revolting ugliness, the princess not only grew extremely fond of her husband, but is said to have been sensibly alive to his attentions to other women. District of New-Jersey, Morris County, ss. On this seventh day of July 1823 personally appeared in open Court, before the Judges of the Inferior Court of Common Pleas, holden at Morris-Town, in and for the county of Morris, in the term of July in the year aforesaid, (the said Court being a Court of Record, possessing a seal, proceeding according to the course of the common law, having a jurisdiction unlimited in point of amount, keeping record of its proceedings, and its judgments being removable by writ of error only) Ezra Brown aged seventy one years, and resident in said county, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth, on his oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the provision made by the acts of Congress of the 18th March, 1818 and the 1st of May 1820 that he the said Ezra Brown enlisted for the term of one year on the 29th or 30th of October 1775 in the State of New Jersey in the County of Morris in the Company commanded by Capt Joseph Norris in the Regiment Commanded first by Lord Stirling and afterwards by Col. Winds in the line of the State of New Jersey on the Continental establishment that he continued to serve in the said Corps until the expiration of his term of enlistment that he was sent by his Commanding Officer to attend at the hospital and continued to serve there and was not with the regiment when it was discharged.- that his name has been placed on the pension list and was dropt therefrom on account of his property And in pursuance of the act of the 1st of May, 1820, I do solemnly swear that I was a Resident Citizen of the United States, on the 18th day of March, 1818, and that I have not, since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entiled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War," passed on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts, due to me; nor have I any Income, other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. Note, since the exhibition of my first schedule, the following changes have ben made in my property as follows viz: forty one acres and twenty seven hundredths of an acre of land, upon which there are no building of any kind One Cow 3 Sheep and one lamb One hog 10 fowls & 25 Chickens Narrow Ax & Grindstone Pocket wedge I Santer 10 old chairs Shovel tongs and andirons 1 pot and dish Kettle teakettle and frying pan 1 old barrel and three tubs 1 Cider Barrel 1 Lyetub pounding Barrel and tub 1 Copper tea kettle 1 old pail 1 large wheel and reel 1 little wheel 3 flour barrels Lot of old Boxes Vinegar Keg & 8 tubs 2 old Buckets 3 Earthen pots 1 pair Steelyards Socket wedge & 1 lantern 1 Looking glass hand bellows shears snuffers and 3 Candlesticks 6 tea spoons 2 Decanters and 2 Bottles 7 Knives & 6 forks 15 Earthen plates 9 Dishes 2 Tumblers & 1 wine Glass 6 tea cups & saucers teapot & Coffee pot 1 Bible 1 Psalm Book & 2 other books 8 Brooms

State of New Jersey County of Essex ss On this the Eighteenth day of August in the year of our Lord one thousand Eight hundred and fifty two personally appeared before me the subscriber a Justice of the Peace in and for the County of Essex aforesaid, Joshua E. Rue aged thirty five years who being by me first duly sworn according to law on his oath depose and say that he is a Clergyman of the Baptist denomination of Christian and as is the settled Pastor of the Baptist Church of Scotch Plains in the County of Essex aforesaid, and that by virtue of his said Office he has the custody of the ancient Records of said church. And that in a Book of Records Entitled The Records of the Baptist Church at the Scotch Plains in East New Jersey in the year of our Lord 1747," he finds the following entry "December 15th 1785 Pursuant to the above agreement Mr Van Horn moved to and took charge of the Church the 15th of December 1785" And he further states that the Church referred to, was the said Church of Scotch Plains, & that it appears from the same Record that the said Mr Van Horn in other places named William Van Horn continued to officiate as their minister until the twenty ninth day of July AD eighteen hundred and seven when the following entry appears Elder Van Horn being too much indisposed to preach it was agreed that the four deacons make such arrangements as they think proper for obtaining occasional supplies &c

(symbol of hand pointing right) The late snow storm appears to have extended from Maine to Virginia, and embraced a range of territory over three hundred thousand square miles. All the papers in these various quarters speak of it as being the most severe snow storm of the season. (hand pointing right) A Canada paper, speaking of the opening of the Great Western Railway, says: "As the first train of cars sped through the marshes of West Tilbury, on Tuesday last, a herd of wild ponies took fright, ran away, swam the Ruscum, Pike and Belle rivers, plunged into the wild St. Clare, made good the American shores, and were seen, on Wednesday, on the Plains near Chicago, making upwards of 300 miles in twenty-four hours. Most of them went on snow shoes." (hand pointing right) The New York Tribune thinks that aristocracy does not bear showing up anywhere. Even though it escape negro blood, it stumbles over a cobbler's work-bench, or an old woman's apple stall, and in fact is very ordinary crockery at best. (hand pointing right) The Height of Inconvenience. - There is a man, somewhere in America, who is so tall that he is obliged to run up a ladder every time he brushes his hair. (hand pointing right) Barnes, formerly editor of the London Times, said to Thomas More, that the great deficiency he found among his writers, was not talent, but common sense. The log is perfectly sound, and is supposed to be 100 years old. Miscellaneous. Progress of Steam. - In August, 1814, Mr. Niles, the indefatigable editor of the Weekly Register, made an elaborate calculation to show that the grand route from Buffalo, in New York, to New Orleans, a distance of 2,744 miles, might be performed in a steamboat of 500 tons, except between Michigan and the Illinois River, where there was a small obstruction, (since removed.) in thirty-two days and eight hours for the voyage down, and in forty-six days for the passage up! The route from Washington, by way of New York city, Buffalo, Chicago, and St. Louis, to New Orleans, a distance of nearly 8,000 miles, can be traversed in less than eight days! And the return trip does not require ten hours longer time! If our venerable contemporary of 1814 could now revisit the earth, what would be his astonishment at the progress of improvement by steam power! - National Inteliigencer. (hand pointing right) The Law's Delay. - If, in the celebrated arbitration case of Paris and Apple of Discord, the three goddesses - Venus, Juno and Minerva - had been each defended by counsel, we wonder when the case would have come to an end? The apple would have been thrown into Chancery, as a matter of course, and the chances are that the celebrated judgment would not have been delivered at the present day! - Punch. The New Jersey Railroads. - Com. Stockton, in reply to a Committee of the Senate of New Jersey, says the terms upon which the joint companies, (Camden and Amboy Railroad and Delaware and Raritan Canal) will surrender to the State the works of the companies, as follows: - They will transfer all stock of the companies, at the rate at which the last thousand shares of stock have been sold in the market. - The stock consists of 30,000 shares, of which the State now owns 2,000, leaving 28,000 unbought, which at $145 per share, which is about the market rate, would amount to $4,060,000: the debt due by the companies, which would naturally have to be assumed by the State, including subscriptions to Belvidere, Delaware, Freehold and Jamesburg, and Flemington Railroad Companies, would amount to $5,230,000, (bearing interest at six per cent., excepting $1,008,000, which is at five per cent.;) this would make a total of $9,200,000, for which the State would become possessed of all the works. A New Post-Office Delivery. - The Post-Office wagon drove down to the corner of California and Davis streets, on Wednesday, and dumped a load of paper rubbish into a hole at that spot. Some spectators of this apparently unobjectionable proceeding were prompted by curiosity to overhaul the pile of rubbish, and were no doubt very much astonished to find among it a number of letters and papers that should have been delivered somewhere else. We were shown one letter, post-marked New York, Dec. 17 1853, and directed to Santa Clara, which, of course, cam by the Golden Gate mail; also several eastern newspapers, which, from their dates, must have also arrived by the same mail. We were informed by a spectator that several other letters directed to Maysville were also found. This is certainly a very singular occurrence, the result of very culpable carelessness somewhere in the Post-Office Department. We trust the Postmaster will look to it, and prevent its recurrence. - San Francisco Herald. Extraordinary Exhibition. - A curious spectacle (says the Paris Pays.) was witnessed in the great avenue of the Champs Elysees the day before yesterday: - A well dressed person appeared with a great number of bladders, each nearly filled with pure hydrogen gas, covered with a net-work of silk, and attached to his body by means of a strap fastened to a belt beneath his arms. The bladders possessed a sufficient ascensional force to diminish the weight of the man by three-fourths, without lifting him from the ground. This lightened he was able to take leaps of five or six yards at a time with extraordinary rapidity. After descending the great avenue from the quarter Baujon to near the Palais de l'Industrie, he returned in the way he came. A vast crowd followed him, and seemed astounded at his pace. Children born Abroad. - The editor of the American Law Register, in writing on the laws of American citizenship, says: "It does not, probably, occur to the American families who are visiting Europe in great numbers, and remaining there, frequently, for a year or more, that all their children born in a foreign country are aliens, and when they return home, will return under all the disabilities of aliens. Yet this is indisputably the case; for it is not worth while to consider the only exception to this rule that exists under the laws of the United States, viz.: the case of a child so born, whose parents were citizens of the United States, on or before the 14th of April, 1802."k Colts' Revolver Beat. - The Boston Daily courier says that there is now in the market a better pistol than Colt's, which is manufactured by, and the property of, the Robbins & Lawrence Company, of Windsor, Vermont. - This pistol is said to be entirely different from any ever before offered to the attention of the public. It is simple in its construction, has a revolving hammer instead of a revolving cylinder, is loaded by unscrewing the barrel, which exposes the chambers, and is not at all liable to become inoperative by corrosion or rust, as all the working parts are contained within the stock or breach, free from any connection with the exploding gas. Sudden Check to Railroad Speed. - It is computed by the Journal of Commerce that the effect of a sudden and accidental stoppage to a railroad train, the cars going at twenty miles an hour, is equivalent to a fall of thirteen feet and a half; at a speed of forty miles, to a fall of fifty-four feet, while fifty miles an hour would give a smash as if we had come from the top of a steeple of eighty-four feet. Passengers may amuse themselves, while travelling, by noting the rate of speed and calculating the chances between getting a fall of thirteen feet and a-half, and one of eighty-four feet, with its possible effect upon the machinery of the cars and their own personal security. Board of Health. - The number of deaths during the past week in this city 280 - Adults 92 and children 138 (next column) burglars early on the morning of the 23rd ultimo. Mr. tiller escaped from the house in order to procure help, and during his absence the burglars shot Mrs. Tiller dead and carried of $400. The Legislature of New Jersey has again rejected, by a decided vote, a bill to charter the Air-Line Railway from New York to the Delaware Bay. The Tayleur Disaster. - From Dublin we learn that the verdict of the Coroner's inquest found that the three hundred and fifty passengers on board the ship Tayleur, were drowned in consequence of the highly culpable neglect of the owners permitting the vessel to leave port without compasses properly adjusted, or a sufficient trial having taken place to learn whether she was under the control of her helm or not. A Buffalo correspondent of the New York Express says that there is no truth in the report that any "engagement" exists between Ex-President Fillmore and Miss Porter, of Niagara, as stated from Washington by the Washington gossippers! The Palace of Industry in the Champs Elysees, Paris, which was so immense as to inspire astonishment, turns out to be too small by one-half for its destination. On being measured in every direction, it only offers a surface of 48,000 metres, and the Commission of the Exhibition, in accordance with the Engineers, declares that it can do nothing with less than 95,000 metres. A report has been addressed to the Emperor demanding the authorization to create additions to the edifice. After some hesitation he has accorded it, on the express condition that not a single tree shall be cut down. Caution to Purchasers. - A tradesman advertises that, on receipt of a postage stamp, he will forward, gratis, an illustrated catalogue of his goods, with prices affixed, proving them to be cheaper than those of any other establishment in London. Don't believe a word of it. The mere fact of his asking you to send a postage-stamp proves that he means to stick it on. - London Diogenes. A Splendid Diamond. - The following paragraph in regard to a remarkable diamond found in South America, appears in the money column of the London Times: One of the largest diamonds known was deposited yesterday at the Bank of England, by a London house, to whom it was consigned from Rio Janeiro. Its weight is 251 carats and its estimated value, according to the scale, (pound symbol) 280,000. It is said to be of the finest water, and without flaw, and was found by a negro slave, who received his freedom as a reward. Sea Soundings. - for a year or two pasts, during the summer season, vessels have been kept at sea sounding the depth of the Atlantic Ocean, and in no place has it been found deeper than 1,500 fathoms, 9,000 feet, which is much less than the height of many mountains on the earth. Mount Washington, in New Hampshire, is between 6,000 and 7,000 feet high. A Mohogany Bridge. - One of the bridges built by the Nicaragua Transit company, on the road leading from Lake Nicaragua to San Juan del Sud, is made entirely of mahogany. A cargo of American salted beef arrived recently at Marseilles. The Mayor has published a proclamation on the subject, to the effect that he has tasted it and fins it very good; that it may be had at the extremely low rate of eight cents a pound, and that to render it eatable and to withdraw the overdose of salt, purchasers must soak the meat half a day in cold water. Salt beef must be scarce in that market. Old Times. - The building occupied by the Germantown Bank, at Germantown, Pa., was at one time owned and swelt in by Clarkson, a popular Mayor of Philadelphia, before the year 1793. Also by Dr. Brandt, an eccentric and imaginative philosopher of some note in his day. And during the prevalence of the yellow fever in Philadelphia, in 1793, it was occupied by Thomas Jefferson, and by Mr. Randolph, the Attorney General of the United States. It was also in the garden attached to this building, that the first Paper Mulberry tree was planted, by Mr. Baylie, who for many years, and up to his death, was a clerk in the bank. The tree was brought from the East Indies; and by the time that is real character was discovered, it had over-run a portion of the garden, and required considerable effort to extirpate the young trees. - Daily Register. He analyzed the various charges of unconstitutional interference on the part of the Prince, either at the Horse Guards, or with Ministers themselves, by thwarting their advice; and lastly give an emphatic denial to the assertion of his having kept up a correspondence with English Ambassadors abroad. He succeeded in eliciting the sympathies of his hearers for the Prince Consort as an extremely ill-used person, and was loudly cheered by all parties at the conclusion of his speech. The London Advertiser, however, looks upon the refutation as affording indirect testimony of their truth. (next column; the edge of the page is torn, and some words are obscured by this) arrived here from San Francisco, brought on her deck one of the greatest natural curiosities that could be offered to the public. It is nothing more nor less than a section of the great California tree; the largest single tree that has been discovered in the modern Eldorado - the largest in the world. This tree was situated in the south-westerly slope of a hill, in a soil fifteen feet in depth. Its roots extended in all directions for more than fifty rods upon the hill-side, and downwards to the depth of the soil. At the ground its circumference was 92 feet, 4 feet above that it was 88 feet, and 10 feet above 66 feet, and the tapering of the shaft was very gradual and symmetrical upwards for 325 feet to its very top. From actual estimate of its diurnal layers, it is more than 8,000 years since this unparalleled majesty of cedar was a sapling in its teens. Then for a large space on the outer surface next to the bark the rings of growth are so thin as not to be distinguished from each other. The outward dimensions of the main trunk were about the same as the Bunker Hill Monument. From actual measurement it contained more than 300 cords of wood. A vast deal of labor was required to level such a mountain of wood to the earth, and after almost incredible toiling with augers, axes and saws at its foot, it finally fell prostrate, the crash can neither be imagined nor described, the jar of the hill was perceived for miles, as if an earthquake had passed that way. The base having been much burned by the fires of the Indians, it was necessary in order to get a perfect section, to chop the tree entirely through twice. After one hundred and fifty days incessant labor this was effected, and the block of ten feet in length lay severed from the huge pile. But the next thing was to transport such a mass, and by any available means at hand it was apparently as impossible as it would have been to move the hill where it laid. It was finally burned through the centre, the earth was dug away from one end and a fire built underneath, which was left burning for several weeks. The auger hole made a good chimney, which was gradually enveloped by the action of the fire until the men could work inside with their axes. In this manner it was excavated to within about two feet of the outer surface. It was afterwards moved down the levers for more than a mile, then drawn 18 miles by 20 oxen to Mentinut, and then shipped to San Francisco. At San Francisco, only about fifty miles from the place of its growth, it was the greatest curiosity ever exhibited. The whole city of men, women and children flocked to see it. One hundred men could easily stand inside the hollow at the same time, and a six foot man rode a full-sized horse through it without touching his hat to the upper surface. This great curiosity is to be exhibited in this city for a short time before its removal to New York and Boston. - Philadelphia Ledger. Walking on Water. - The perilous experiment of "walking on water" was recently repeated, before a concourse of Dublin spectators, by the Hon. Mr. Swift. This gentleman's former experiment, was that of "walking" by sea, from Venice to Trieste, a feat by which his life was well nigh forfeited. In repeating the attempt in Dublin harbor, between the Custom House and the Pigeon House Fort he encountered no risk, and was thoroughly successful. His apparatus consists of two air-tight tin floats, twenty feet in length, tapering to a narrow point at each end, and joined together by bars of iron. Standing on the floats, Mr. Swift propels himself by a double bladed oar, which he uses with great dexterity. A Noble-Hearted Wife. - A romantic story of female devotedness has just been circulated at Valence. Is it stated that a Prussian woman, named Hipson, has been working in male attire, as a navvie on the railways, for more than five years. She had an infirm husband and four children; their family were starving she disguised herself, worked hard, and had her wages advanced for her assiduity; with her earnings she supported her pretended "father" and "brothers and sister," her husband and her children. When her secret was discovered, gifts poured in upon her from the neighborhood, and work more suited to her sex has been provided. Railroad Collisions. - Two passenger trains recently came into collision on the Columbia road, this side of Lancaster. Some eight cars and five or six engines were disabled. One the passengers, a Mr. Hudson, of Philadelphia and formerly of Lewistown, had both his legs broken, one near the hip, and the other at the ankle. Mr. Wm. Lerk, also of Philadeph had the toes of one foot cut off; and another man had an arm broken. His name could n be ascertained. The Extent of the Storm. - At Porl there was a brisk gale, but no snow. At M treal no storm was felt, and no snow fell. New Bedford the snow fell to about two inches in depth, and travellling was badly peded. At Baltimore and Pittsburg the sn was very deep - not far from two feet. W Cincinnati, Louisville and St. Louis were vis by heavy rains and strong gales, Chicago a Buffalo enjoyed clear and spring-like weath At Cleveland and Columbus snow fell only the depth of two or three inches. A Sensible Woman. - A magnificent do tion has been made by the widow of Ant Arevalo de Alverado, the executrix of her h band, who had designed $25,000 to be given the priests, for masses. She concluded she would better consult the benevolent des and do something more acceptable to the s of God for the salvation of her deceased h by making a different appropriation of the ney; and she has given it to the Hospita Valparaiso.

15 Petition of Claimant State of Alabama} Talladega County} SS. The Petitioner Isaac Brewer, the Claimant in this case for a Pension showeth that he is old and infirm and has always felt some disability from his wounds received in the wars. That owing to his occupying so many of his years in the service of his country and the effect of losses & misfortunes he has now accumulated are grown rich as some have, but is now and has been for some years in a needy condition, That he now ha his old wife who is some 78 years old & one daughter now an old girl and himself all of whom he considers helpless as regards the strugling and success in Life as even in that of Living, That he has children but they are all in need themselves and could not help him with convenience, also that he is not able to buy or to have any others other known but to live on a Little improvement wedged up in the spurs of the mountains as public or government land, and knows not how soon he may be deprived of that by the entry made by someone else. That all the support for his said family subsidy, consists in a small Pony mare, two or three cows and a few Pigs, with what they can make on this.

that he never knew until recently that those who enlisted for eighteen months were entitled to pensions and until recently I have been able to support myself and family by my labor. New Hampshire Joseph Daniels Private 1776 - one year see letter to A. Peirce April 29. 1824 Aged 72 years my occupation a Farmer but unable to pursue the same by reason of old age and infirmities, wife aged 82 years, not able to help herself. Schedule dated 1 July 1820, contains 50 acres of land one story House and barn thereon. $400.00 1 Horse, 2 Oxen, 1 Cow, 2 heifers, 6 Sheep, 5 lambs, 2 Swine, furniture in his house, and farming utensils, valued at 115.00 --- Total 515.00 That he is indebted to sundry persons in the sum of $50.00 - Schedule under act of March 1823. dated 26 November 1823 Real property none Personal the amounts to $24.00 accounts for the decrease of his property as follows, 50 acres of land and the house thereon and a small Barn he sold to Saml Lock on the 19 of November 1822 for the sum $400, which sum the sd Lock paid to him by taking up demand from his creditors to that amt which he then owed one horse died. One oxen killed and con sumed in his family, the other exchanged for a yoke of steers, which sd steers he afterwards was obliged to sell to support his family and 2 Heifers sold for the same purpose sheep & 5 Lambs consumed in his family, and the swine and for the same purpose. That at the time he made his 1 Schedule he did not know that he owed so much being destitute of education and Receiving no accounts with his creditors. Saml Lock make affidavit before the Court, that he did on the 19 day of November 1822 purchase of the applicant all his real estate for the sum of $400 which sd sum be paid to the applicant by taking up demands against him to that amount. see authenticated copy of the deed from the applicant to Saml Lock dated 19 Nov 1822 for the sd 50 acres of land. A Peirce Esq Dover, N.H.
