State of Indiana Lawrence County SS} Lawrence Circuit Court June Term 1820 On this 6th day of June 1820 personally came the said James Thomas named in the foregoing declaration and being first duly sworn in open Court on his oath states that he did inlist [enlist] in the service of the United States in the year 1776 in Baltimore in the State of Mariland [Maryland] in the company commanded by David Plunket as set forth in the foregoing declaration that the said company wintered the following winter in Baltimore. that in the spring of 1777 said company or troop marched to Philidelphia [Philadelphia] with other companies and were there joined or formed into a [repeated: a] regiment afterwards known by the name of the 4th Pennsylvania Regiment of Light Dragoons which regiment was commanded by Col Stephen Moyland. that he con tinued in service in said corps until the close of the war that he received a wound in the Battle of Germintown [Germantown] and another in the battle at the taking of Savanah [Savannah] in the State of Georgia. The following schedule contains a correct statement of his property according to the act of Congress in such case made and provided to wit One mare and colt two cows a small stock of hogs and three head of sheep beding [bedding] and wearing aperil [apparel] excepted and further saith not We John Milroy and William Erwin associate Judges of the Lawrence Circuit Court do certify that it appears to our satisfaction that the said James Thomas did serve in the Revolutionary war as stated in the preceding declaration against the common enemy for the term of nine months at one time on the Continental establishment we are also satisfied that he needs the assistence [assistance] of his country for support And we now transmit the proceedings and testimony taken and held before us as also his former declaration taken before John P. The [illegible] Witness James L Bradley Clerk at office this 5th day of November 1849 Jas L Bradley clerk The Last Will and Testament of Rebecca Bowers- In the name of Almighty god Amen I Rebecca Bowers of sound mind, but of advanced age with much bodily affliction, and feeling [illegible], that according to the ordina- ry dispensation of an all wise Providence my days on earth are well nigh numbered; do hereby of my own free will and accord make this my Last Will and Testament, revoking any and all other wills heretofore made In consideration of the affection and special regard for my son Lenard Bowers; and his increasing attention and kindness toward me in my declining age and helpless condition I give and bequeath to my said son Lenard Bowers for the only use and behoof of himself and his heirs all my effects of every description personally or otherwise, he first paying my funeral expenses, and all other just debts against me at the time of my deceased I also give and bequeath to my son Lenard Bowers the use and hire of my life Estate in two negros, slaves Sarah and Stephen [illegible]-with all the debts of whatever amount and description that is now owing to me or that may hereafter be- come due to me by principle or interest including that part of of my Pension received from the General Government not [illegible] by me, as well as whatever sum that may yet be due and coming to me under the act of Congress Granting Pensions to the widows of Revolutionary Soldiers- I also give and bequeath to my son Lenard Bowers the following other property (to wit) one cow and yearling calf one oven and lid one skillet and lid two milk pails-one set of tea cups and saucers two boles one coffee pot one churn eight crocks [illegible] ten cups 1 [illegible] towels two table clothes one sheet three pillow slips & one washing tub It is also null and desire that the bond now in the possession of William Rockhold made between my son Lenard Bowers and myself in which certain provissions were made

Charles Campbell Westmoreland County Ss. Personally came before me Michael Huffnagle Esquire one of the Justices of the Peace and of the Court of Common Pleas in and for the County. The subscriber Samuel Craig who being Sworn upon the Holy Evangelist of Almighty God deposets and saith that he was a Lieutenant in a company of Militia commanded by Captain Robert Orr and marched on an Expedition carried against the Indians by General George Clark in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and eighty one. That on the Ohio River below the mouth of Big Miami they were attacked by the Indians, where a number of Officers and private men were killed and the remainder of the party taken prisoners- That the said Captain Orr was Wounded in his left arm, was afterwards carried to detroit where he was put in the Hospital to be cured of his wounds, and was left there by order of the Commanding Officer at Detroit, ("at Detroit" was crossed out) when the other Prisoners were just forward to Montreal- That hear a year afterward while the deponent was yet a Prisoner at Montreal the Said Robert Orr was brought there, his wound being better, but not cured. That the deponent was with the Said Robert Orr from that time until they were both released, and came home together. The Said Robert Orr being then able to travel, but still much afflicted with pain occasioned by the Said Wound, and that the deponent has reason to believe that the Said Robert Orr is not yet, and probably never will be perfectly returned to strength and use of his arm. /s/ Samuel Craig ("sworn + subscribed" the rest too faded to read) /s/ Chas Campbell ???(illegible)

Westmoreland County Ss. On the fourteenth day of August in the year of our Lord one thousand Seven hundred and eighty eight Came before me Michael Huffnagle Esquire one of the Justices of the Peace and of the Court of Common Pleas in and for the County of Westmoreland and also Prothonotary of the Said County. The Subscriber John Cummins. Who being Sworn on the Holy Evangelist of Almighty God deposeth and Saith that he has been acquainted with Captain Robert Orr of Westmoreland County ever since the Spring of the year one thousand Seven hundred and eighty one. That when he first knew him he was a healthy Active man. And that he never heard him complain of any Wound or pain, until he Returned from an Expedition that was made under the direction of General Clark against the Indians in the year one thousand Seven hundred and eighty one- that after Said expedition the deponent heard Said Robert Orr often complain of a pain in his left Shoulder and arm, which the deponent understood was occasioned by a wound which the Said Robert received by the Indians, on the Said expedition. That he has observed the Said Robert Orr unable to Work at hard labour, and has seen him holding his hand in Cold water to alleviate the heat and pain with which he Said he was much afflicted ("on account of" crossed out) by reason of the Said Wound /s/ John Cummins Sworn + Subscribed Before me} August fourteenth 1788...... } /s/ Mich Huffnagle ________________________

Edgecomb April 21, 1827 Sir I have repeatedly visited Mr. Hood the application for a pension "He is the oldest member of the church to which I administer in this town; a man of undoubted piety and (ineligible) in this town; His poverty and his need of a pension cannot be attributed to want of temperance industry on economy but to the visitation of good. Of the fact that he spent Seven months in the Continental Establishment there is no doubt on the minds of gentlemen who he communicated his suffering and the names of his officers many years ago. But owing to his great age and extreme disability his memory has failed to the degree that he seems to have lost all distinct recollection of names with which he was familiar during the Revolution I am Sir respectfully yours Daniel Kendrick, Minister of the gospel J.L. I John Riffe a Justice of the Court of record holden in the County of Casey where the declarant resides, do hereby certify that the above named Osborne Coffey is from a disease called Palsey & a bowel complaint with which I am credibly informed and believe he has been afflicted for the space of 18 years with the palsey & the bowel complaint off and on for the same time, unable to attend the court of which I am Justice. And I do not think from present appear -ances that he will be able to attend the court above named at its next session. State of Rhode Island & Providence-Plantations. Newport Sc - Court of Common Pleas, May Term, A. D. 1820 On this Twenty sixth day of June 1820, personally appeared in open Court, being a Court of Record within and for the County of Newport in the State of Rhode-Island, &c. Daniel Lake aged Fifty Eight Years residing in the Town of Tiverton in said County who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his Oath declare, that he served in the Revolutionary War as follows: -- Nine months in the company commanded by Capt [illegible] Holden in the Regiment command by Col Jeremiah Olney in the continental army, as will appear by Documents in the Secy of War Office, accompanying original application My occupation is that of a farmer - my family consists of self, wife 57 years - have eleven children, Six of whom reside with me. Eldest Son aged 21 - Second Daughter 19 years- third, Son 16 years - fourth Daughter, 14 years - fifth Daughter 12 years Sixth, son aged 10 years totally helpless - two infant grand children left by a decease son, and dependant or me for support. That he made a previous Declaration on the Sixth Day of May, 1818, and that he has received a certificate for a pension, being No. 10, 999 And in pursuance of the Act of Congress , passed May 1st, 1820, I do solemnly swear, That I was a resident Citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner whatever, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an Act of Congress, entitled "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War,” passed on the 18th day of March, 1818; And that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the Schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. A SCHEDULE of Property and Income, (necessary clothing and bedding excepted) of Real Estate Sixty acres off of Land, about ten under improvement—800,, one pr of Oxen, one Horse & two cows --- 110,, 8 Sheep & 2 Small Hogs -----12,, Coffer Pat – [illegible] Pat. &c -----18,, One [illegible] bar, one plow, 2 hoes - 2 rakes &c ----- 11 Daniel Lake 951,,

Sixty acres off of Land, about ten under improvement—800,, one pr of Oxen, one Horse & two cows --- 110,, 8 Sheep & 2 Small Hogs -----12,, Coffer Pat – [illegible] Pat. &c -----18,, One [illegible] bar, one plow, 2 hoes - 2 rakes &c ----- 11 Daniel Lake 951,, Sworn to and declared, on the Twenty sixth day of June before the Court HY Cranston Clk Clerks Office Court of Common Pleas for the County of Newport I hereby certify that the foregoing oath & the Schedule thereto annexed are truly copied from the records of said Court, that it is the opinion of said Court, that the amount in value of the property exhibited in the aforesaid Schedule is nine hundred fifty are Dollars. I further certify that said Court is a Court of record being so constituted by Statute, possessing original and unlimited Jurisdiction in all civil causes proceeding according to the course of the common Law & keeping a record of its proceedings. In testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand & affixed the seal of said Court this Ninth Day of September in the year of our LORD. Eighteen hundred and twenty & forty fifth of American Indepence By order of Court H.Y. Cranston Clk

That since the exhibition of my first schedule, the following changes have been made in my property.- Fifty acres of Land in Barrington, a home thereon one story high and a small barn I sold to Samuel Lock on the 19th day of November 1822 for four hundred dollars, which sum be paid to me by taking up demands from my creditors to that amount which I then owed One horse died Two oxen - one was killed for beef and [illegible] in the family, the other exchanged for a yoke of steers which steers I was afterwards obliged to sell to support my family Two heifers, sold for the same purpose 6 Sheep & 5 Lambs made use of for provision in my family two swine used for the same purpose- That when I exhibited my first Schedule I did not know of owing so much, being destitute of education & keeping no account on settling with any creditors I found myself so much in debt, I was compelled to sell my property to discharge the debts, & which has left me totally destitute in my old age & wholly unable to labour on account of age and infirmities my family consists of my wife aged 82 years not able to do any thing or even help herself Joseph Daniels his mark Sworn to and declared, on the 26th day of November A.D. 1823 before the Justices of said Court A. Peirce Clerk of said Court

New Kent County} Virginia to wit } On this 8th day June Anno Domini 1820 personally appeared in open Court being a court of record for the said County of New Kent so constituted by the laws of this state and being a court possessing the power of fine and imprisonment, Ansolem Bailey about 62 years, resident in the aforesaid County who being duly sworn according to law, doth, on his oath declare that he served, in the revolutionary war as follows in the 1st Virginia regiment on continental establishment in Captain Abner Crumps compy [company] that he has received a pension number of the pension certificate 8007 that he served from the 4th day Octr. 1776 until December 1779, the day of discharge not recollected and do solemnly swear that I was resident citizen of of the United States on the 18th day March 1818. That I served in the virginia line under Brigadier Genl. Muhlenberg that I have not since that time by gift, sale, or in any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring my self within the provisions of an act of Congress entitled "an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and Naval services of the United States in the Revolutionary war, passed on the 18th day March 1818 and that I have not nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities, contracts or debts, due to me nor have I any income other than what is contained in in the schedule hereunto annexed and by me subscribed. The declarant is by occupaption [occupation] a farmer, in consequence of his infermity and old age he is unable to pursue his occupation so as to maintain his family. he has in family five persons Viz. Susannah Bailey his wife aged 28 years and children three Viz. Rebecca 6 years Marth[a] 4 years and Ansolem 1 year old and a free boy 16 years old.-A schedule of the property of Ansolem Bailey, of the county of New Kent with the valuation thereof, by Matthew Higgins and Parks Martin freeholders of the said County Viz 1 Grey mare - $10-00 Do Colt Bay - $25-00 1 Cow & calf - $15-00 1 Heifer - $5-00 Amt carried forward $55-00

State of South Carolina Beaufort District On this Eighteenth day of January in the year of Our Lord One thousand Eight hundred and fifty one, personally appeared before me Jos Dan'l Pope Esq a Magistrate appointed to keep the peace and duly commissioned under the Great Seal of the State, Rev. Richard Johnson a clergyman of the protestant Episcopal Church who being first duly sworn according to law, says that he is now forty-one years of age that he knew from his earliest childhood John McKee the former husband of Mrs Margaret McKee who is now a widow residing in the Town of Beaufort in the District and State aforesaid that the said John McKee was a citizen of high standing, and was always regarded by the community particularly the elder portion, many of whom we now dead, as a Revolutionary Soldier who had seen long and arduous service; that he has on many occasions when a child, heard the said John McKee relate incidents of the campaign in which he served; that he always spoke of these incidents with the familiarity of an eye witness, and was not infrequently the actor himself. He further declares that the

Six months - That in the year 1781 he was engaged with the aforesaid Regiment under Col Drake for a period of at least three weeks at one time in marching through the counties of Westchester & Putnam for the purpos of driving the fat cattle & hogs out of the reach of the enemy which he thinks was in the month of November - for which last mentioned service he received certificates for pay for one months service - That during the fall of 1782 this despondent with the aforesaid Reg. under Col Drake was actually engaged in foraging & transporting hay & oats & other provisions from White Plains, Rye, Mannmouth to Cortland & to the [illegible] villages for the use of Genl Heaths Brigade and other portions of the American Army thru quartering in that vicinity- And that in whole he was actually engaged in the service of the Revolutionary War from 1777 to 1783 as private in the above mentioned Regiment at the different periods above stated period in the whole amounting to not less than two years and four months continued service- And further this despondent saith not- {signature] Richard Ferris Subscribed and sworn before me this 8th day of February 1837 [signature] Caleb B Drake JP I certify that I have been well acquainted with the said above named Richard Ferris for thirty years past and that during such acquaintance he has sustained a good reputation for truth and veracity and his statement entitled to full credit and belief. [signature] Caleb B Drake JP

Deponent further says that he has frequently more [illegible] thirty years ago and since heard the Said Richard Smith say, That he was a soldier of the revolution, and a Waggon master or Waggon Conductor in the waggon department of the revolutionary war, with great Brittain. And was attached to Colonel Lambs Regiment in the New York line. That he entered the Service about the beginning of the War, and that he was engaged under the five or six months Service or some shorter period of enlistment and Continued in the said Service for about five years. Deponent has heard him say he was at White Plains with the army when the battle was fought and at Peekskill also about the time the Public Stores were burnt by the british. And that he was at Pluckemin in New Jersey, and at different places in Pennsylvania as a Waggon Master or Waggon Conductor in the Continental army Deponent has also frequently heard him relate many Cicumstances[circumstances] of peculiar hardship and distress of hunger and fatigue while he was in the Said Service Deponent has frequently seen a quantity of papers and books of account purporting to be a kind of journal of business transaction of the Said Richard Smith as a Waggon Master or Waggon Conductor in the said Continental army belonging to the said Richard Smith at his residence more than thirty years ago. Deponent says he has frequently examined and read the said papers and books but does not reccollect to have seen the same for a period of at least twenty years, but deponent believes they are destroyed. Deponent further says they are the same papers and books mentioned in the declaration of the Said Susannah Smith the Widow of the Said Richard Smith deceased and Sworn too by her on the Twenty dix day of October eighteen hundred and thirty eight. Vermont, but if I ever heard his name I have forgotten it. I well remember, that it was reputed and believed in the town of Sharon, after the return of the soldiers above mentioned that they had been to Quebec, and joined the American army in its neighbourhood and that they were with the army in its retreat from Canada. And I further testify that our of the Soldier above named, during the subsequent campaign in which we were engaged, towit, David Abel, related to me the particulars of their march to Canada, during the preceding winter, of their perils and sufferings in Canada, and more particularly, that the said William Abel was sick, at the time they retreated and that he, the said William, suffered great hardships and distress during the retreat- And I also testify that at another time, another of said soldiers, towit, the said Hezekiah Frisbie, related to me the particulars of the said march to Quebec, and the said winter campaign in Canada, and that he told me that the said William Abel was through the whole of it-- I well recollect the return of those members of said Cartwrights Company who lived in Sharon, that ? William was among the others that came home from the northward and that it was well understood and believed at the time that the said Abel, and the other members of said company served in the Army in Canada as above set forth - John Lord State of Connecticut ss County of Litchfield ⎬ Decr 4th 1833 Personally appeared John Lord of Sharon in said County to me well known as a person of truth and a credible witness, and made oath to the truth of the foregoing deposition by him subscribed Before me Chas. F. Sedgwick Justice of the Peace

the old man posesses about 200 acres of poor land perhaps worth $600 and 2 horses worth say $100 2 or 3 cows & other small property $100 more making about the sum of eight hundred Dollars his children has all left him his plantation gone to wreck old and worn out he himself 70 yea of age and a criple from a white swelling in his hip. his wife is old and helpless he is in reality an object of charity he hates to sell his old plan & have no house over his head, and it is a positive fact it will not rent for what will barly support him & his wife in the most plain & poor manner. if ever there was a neciety[?] for government to extend the hand of charity to any one he is one. it is well known that he was a galant soldier in the revolution, has been a civil honest industrious citizen ever since and is now poor and needy-- I hope you will be good enough to give him such information as to the amount of property

Wiscasseh July 17, 1827 Hon. Secretary of War. On behalf of Daniel Hood of Edgecombe in the State of Maine I herewith enclose his papers for a pension as a Revolutionary Soldier - his great age & poverty heretofore prevented his providing the proper evidence of his services. When his papers were returned the last time the defect was that he had not stated who his Captain was - he has now supplied that deficiency as well as his memory will permit as will appear by his affidavit - he appears very conscientious & does not wish to state things beyond his knowledge - I have also added a communication from the Rev. Mr. Kendrick the worth Pastor of the church to which Mr. Hood belongs. He will appear by the papers that Mr. Hood made early application in 1819, but by reason od ill health & the difficulty of finding the evidence to support his petition, he has since been obliged to live upon charity With much respect Your most humble sece J. Bailey

Lines of Original Poetry - 1st Farewell my loving consort here My partner in distress Likewise my little infant dear you’ve both obtain'd bright bless 2nd you first grew ripe for endless joys And Jesus took you home Sorrow and pain my hours employs while through this world I roam 3rd you happy round the throne of God your tunefull tongues employ While all your robes are washed in blood And nothing nears your joy 4th I still with tempests here am tor’d “While through this world I roam” But yet in Jesus’ cross I boast And trust to reach my home 5th I trust to join the hapy throng In those bright realms of Day And with the ransom’d march along And with the harper’s play 6th I trust the baby [illegible] to sing

Williamstown, (Mas.) April 28, 1835 Deacon Asahel Hurlbut, of this town is a man of high moral excellence, entirely destitute of property, in the 77th year of his age. He was a soldier of the revolution for one year; he was afterwards a minute man for four years, in which time he was often called out & was in several battles. When the late war of 1812 was declared, he was in inhabitant of Canada, & had an estate there worth $2000. His two sons being dafaughted [drafted] into the British Army, fled into the United States; from a persuasion that Deacon Hurlbut had advised the measure, he was about to be seized; upon which he fled to his native country. The consequence was that all his property was confiscated & lost. Thus from his attachment to his country he was reduced to poverty, & has been destitute ever since. He most earnestly wish that he may obtain a pension, & fully believe that he is justly entitled to one. E D Griffin, President of Williams College. Maryland Anne Arundel County - to wit: Be it remembered that on the fifteenth day of August in the year of our Lord Eighteen hundred and Eighteen personally appeared before the subscriber Associate Judge of the Third judicial District of Maryland John Hill of the county aforesaid and did deposeth and say and declare that he enlisted as a private in Colonel Stephen Maryland Regiment of Light Dragoons belonging to the army of the United States on the fifth day of February in the year seventeen hundred and seventy seven for the term of three years and that he faithfully fought in the revolutionary war against the collective enemy during the whole period and was duly discharged at the expiration of his enlistment. The said John Hill did further at the same time doth say and declare that he is indigent and in distressed circumstances and stands in need of the aid and assistance of his country for support. I the subscriber do further certify that on the 25th day of April in the year eighteen hundred and nineteen that John [illegible] of Anne Arundel County aforesaid did also appear before me and made oath in the Holy Evangelists of Almighty God that he was well acquainted with the deponent John Hill during the revolutionary war and that the said John Hill did enlist as a private in the Dragoons for three years during the revolutionary war and did fight as such against the common enemy during that period in the army of the United States. Sworn to before me Richard Redgoly Be it therefore know that I Richard Redgoly Associate Judge in aforesaid do hereby certify to the Honorable Secretary of the Department of War that

This address was well-timed and had a good fect upon the blacks, who promised obe ence, and retired into the dwelling. For an ur longer, the Major stood at the loop-hole, zing out toward the west, his mind busy with housand thoughts of a nature the most asant. By this time the light of the fire s no longer visible; and only the pale rays the moon illumined a scene, which a combi ition of circumstances made appear most oomy to the eyes of the mourning, solitary tcher, who now carefully closed the aper re, and with slow, heavy steps, paced to and beside the lonely grave of his beloved wife. length he turned away, and stealthily entered dwelling, where he found the children leep, and Cuba and Dick stretched out on the or before the dying fire. Without disturbing y one, he took down all the rifles, powder- rns, and bullet-pouches, and with these re- rned to his post. Some three or four hours now passed in a ence broken only by the cheerless hooting an owl, or the distant howl of some hungry olf. The moon now went down, darkness retched it sable pall over the earth, and a ousand bright stars became visible in the ure vault above. It was now the Major felt at vigilance waws most needed - for if the vages were near, and meditating and attack, it is now that they would begin to put their ans in execution. Accordingly, he took a vey of the scene outside - beginning at the uthern loop-holes and ending at the western but without seeing any thing to excite his arm. At the central loop-hole on the western de, he was still lingering, and congratulating mself that his fears of a night assault would obably prove groundless, when his eye chanc- d upon a dark object at no great distance, which o at first believed to be a stump, but which, otwithstanding, he eyed with a strange interest at he could not account for. While looking eadily at this object, he fancied it drew nearer: ertainly it either moved, or his eyes deceived im. With awakened suspicion, he now riveted his gaze upon it, and watched it with breath0- ess attention. He was not long kept in doubt - for, in less han a minute, the dark object had dawn so ear to the stockade that he could no longer see it. What was it? was the next quiry to e settled. Could it be an Indian? If so, it as an Indian creeping upon his hands and nees - for it had not, while in sight, assumed n upright posture. The Major listened, but e could hear no sound. All was still - a gloomy, ppressive stillness - a stillness that seemed oreboding, like that which precedes the burst f a tempest. Stilll keeping his position at the loop-hole, argrave now ran his eyes hurriedly over the m scene, in eager search of some other object give a sad confirmation to his worst fears; t oping the while, with a faint, tremulous pe, that nothing to excite further apprehen- n might be seen. While looking, he heard soft notes of a whipporwill, so close to him, t he fancied the bird must be sitting on the of the palisade above his head. He took a p back, and turned his eyes upward - but hing in the shape of the nocturnal warbler visible on the dark line which the stockade w against the clear sky. REsuming his place he aperture, he again peered through; and he did so, the music of the bird ceased, and dismal hooting of an owl, not quite so near, upon his ear. This continued but a few ments, and then all became as silent as ore. Hargrave now began to indulge the belief t the dark object he had seen was merely ne proling animal, and consequently that ere was no cause for fresh alarm; and he s just on the point of closing the aperture , d turning away, when he was again startled, seeing some ten or twelve moving objects, t unlike the first, within a few yards of him, d all approaching at the same slow pace. e of these objects, ere it drew so close to the ockade as to be to him invisible, suddenly elongated vertically, and displayed the figure of a human being. All hope of danger being distant was now banished - all doubt concering (sic) the objects he had seen was now dispelled. He knew he was surrounded by a band of hostile savages, all eager to begin their bloody work; and he rightly conjectured that what he had believed to be the notes of the whipporwill and ow., were merely the signals of a scout to his dusky brethren, conveying some intelligence by which their first movements were to be determined. Major Hargrave was, in the full sense of the term, a brave man; and one who could bear up unshrinkingly against much that would appal some, who, though of weaker nerve, might prove themselves heroes on the field of battle; but in this terrible moment of grief and danger - danger not only to himself, but to all he loved - he was completely unmanned; and with the first consciousness that a blood-thirsty foe stood within a few feet of him - a consciousness derived at the very point of time, too, when the elastic spring of hope was raising his depressed spirits - he was seized with a violent trembling; and his knees fairly smote together, as did those of the ancient King, Belshazzar, when he saw the spirit-fingers write his destiny on the wall of his palace. Happily, this nervous fear was only of short duration; and then the Major collected his scattered faculties, grew composed, and prepared to act as became one in his situation. Cautiously, carefully, silently, he closed the apertures, gathered up his rifles, etcetera, and, stealthily advancing to the door of his dwelling, pushed it open, without noise, and entered. He found the two negroes still stretched before the fire-place, and his little children asleep on the bed so lately occupied by the cold remains of their dear mother. He bent over them, and, with lips that trembled with deep emotion - for who could say this might not be the last time - pressed a father's warm kiss upon each little upturned face. Then moving away, with a noiseless, step, without disturbing their innocent slumbers, he sought the apartment of Gerturde, and whispered her name. She started up in bed, for dark fancies had kept her awake, and in a low, eager tone, inquired: "What is it, Edward?" "Hush!" he whispered - "do not speak above your breath! Try and be firm," he continued; "and, so far as you are able, act the part of a heroine - for you are about to be put to a fearful trial. We are surrounded by a body of savages, of whose numbers I know nothing, and ere long they will begin their attack." "Oh, merciful God!" groaned Gertrude, in horror. "Hush!" he again whispered - "do not let them hear a sound that can make them aware that we are cognizant of their pesence. I am about to go outside again, to render what defence I can, and shall take Cuba and Dick with me. You had better get up and keep the door; but do not disturb Aunt Chloe, or the simpleton, who I trust are asleep above - for neither, in such a time, would be of any service." He then advanced to her side, pressed his lips to hers, and added, in much agitation: "Should I fall, let this be our farewell kiss. Should I fall, and you and the dear children escape, be as a mother to them, dear Gertrude - be as a mother to them - and tell them their father died in their defence. There! there! farewell! farewell! and may God have mercy on us all!" Saying this, he made a hasty retreat, leaving poor Gertude trembling with horror, and more dead than alive. Advancing to the negroes, he roused each with a shake, and said, in a fearful whisper: "Hush! be silent - not a word - not a breath. Get up and follow me as stealthily as a cat. The least noise may coast you your lives. WE are surrounded by Indians, and nothing but bravery can save us from a horrible butchery. Here is a rifle and ammunition of each of you. I charge you not to speak - scarcely to breath! When we go out, I will station each of you. You must watch with eagle glance, the top of the stockade; and if either of you see a human head rise above it, give it the contents of your rifle. There - come! Come! for delay may be fatal." Neither of the blacks replied; but both silently arose, trembling with terror, and each mechanically took his rifle and followed the Major. At the south-west angel of the palisade he stationed Dick, and at the north-west Cuba; and as he left each, he grasped his arm, without speaking, and pointed upward, as a sign that he must keep his eyes fixed on the upper line of the wooden wall. This done, the Major, with stealthy steps, repaired to the gate, and placed himself in such as position that he could command a view of one half of the stockade - of all, in fact, that could not be seen by the blacks. Now came moments of painful suspense - of a suspense that seemed to have in it more of horror than the certainty of real action. Minute succeeded minute, and save an occasional movement of some of the horses, not a sound was heard, and nothing to indicate the presence of a savage fore eager for blood. Minute succeeded minute, and a quarter of an hour passed away, and yet all remained still and quiet; and the wondering and expectant Major was beginning to hope that his senses had deceived him - or, if no, that the Indians, finding him so well fortified, had gone to seek other and less guarded victims - when he fancied he heard a slight noise at the gate. Cautiously he drew up to it, and placed his ear against the timbers. No! his sense of hearing had not deceived him. There was a noise here - a very slight noise - noise as of some one slowly and carefully climbing. "It is as I expected." thought Hargrave. "They will first assist one of their number to scale the wall, to reconnoitre and unfasten the gate. t is a perilous venture for him." He clutched his rifle with an iron grip, set his teeth hard, and, gently cocking his piece, raised it to the position of an upward aid, and then fairly held his breath with anxiety. He had not long, to wait. first one dark, shadowy-looking hand, then another, was seen to grasp the top of the post above him; and then slowly - very, very slowly - a dark, shadowing-looking head and face rose into view. A single moment the Major glanced at the grim, shadowy face along the barrel of his rifle, and then his finger pressed quick and hard against the trigger. A sharp report, and a spasmodic groan, simultaneously followed; and then a dull, leaden sound, as of the fall of some body heavily to the earth. The next moment there arose upon the still midnight air a series of such horrible yells as the bravest have never heard without quailing - yells that sounded as if all the demons of hell had suddenly been let loose; and with the infernal screeches mingled the reports of at least twenty fire-arms, the balls of which ledged in the stout posts of the stockade without doing any injury. For perhaps a minute, these yells and screeches continued without cessation; and then, as suddenly as they had burst upon the ear, they ceased, and the silence without became awfully impressive. CHAPTER XVIII. THE ATTACK. For a few moments after the savage outburst of rage and fury had subsided, not a human sound was heard, as if terror had for the time paralyzed every tongue. Then arose a series of wild cries within the cabin, and voices were heard calling to each other in tones of frenzied alarm. The Major knew enough of the INdian mode of warfare, to feel satisfied that no concerted attack would commence till the latter had taken time to deliberate upon the facts, that their presence was known, that their first attempt to gain an entrance had proved a failure, and that the besieged were armed and resolved to dispute possession with their lives. Accordingly, he reloaded his rifle, even while the demoniac yells of his disappointed foes were ringing in his ears; and then hurried to Dick and Cuba, to see what effect the startling events recorded had produced upon them, and be able to judge what amount of dependence he could place upon them in the moments of greatest peril and sorest need. He found each at his post, watching the upper line of the palisade as he had directed; and though both were much frightened, he rejoiced to perceive that neither would be likely to prove craven-hearted in the hour of dangerous trial. Calling them together, he hurriedly related what had taken place; complimented them on the courage they had displayed, in remaining where he had stationed them, and doing their duty, under circumstances calculated to appal the bravest; and said that with vigilance, caution, and firm resolution, he nothing doubted being able to keep the savages outside the walls, till such time as succor might arrive, or they, becoming weary of the contest, might be glad to raise the siege and depart. "Remember, boys," he continued, impressively, "all will depend on you. If you stand firm, and act courageously, all may be saved - if you falter, and coward-like, shrink from your duty, we are lost. Yet I will not ask you risk your lives for me and mine without the hope of further reward than the mere saving of your own lives. If, by reason of your good conduct and bravery, we escape from our foes, you, Dick, and you, Cuba, with your wife, shall each and all have you liberty. I promise on my own part, and I take the responsibility of promising on the part of Miss Gertrude, that you shall be set free, to be your own master, and go where you like." The address of the Major roused the pride of the negroes, who felt they were appealed to as freemen, rather than as servants in bondage; and his offer to make them freemen indeed, touched their finer feelings, and affected them deeply. "God bless you, Mas'er," cried Cuba, "and Missus Gertrude, and de childrens! I'll do what I can for yo all, de Lord help us! and I's jus' say for myse'f, dat dar was no need ob dat dar compli'tary succumstance ob de liberties, to make dis ole nigger do his best - dar." (sic) "'Sider what Cuba says, said for me," (sic) chimed in Dick sententiously. "Well, now, each to his post, and be wary," rejoined the Major. "There is no telling what moment the savages may begin the attack in a body, and we must all be prepared to give them a warm reception. If you have occasion to fire, remember to load your piece the very first thing you do, and as expeditiously as possible. By-the-by, I will provide each of you with a knife and an axe, which will be serviceable weapons should we come to close quarters with the enemy, which God forbid! Will now speak to those in the house - for they know not what has happened, and are in a state of wild alarm and terrible suspense. Saying this, Hargrave hastened around to the front of the cabin, passing three or four horses on his way, which, with heads up and ears erect, were snuffing snorting, and exhibiting other signs of alarm, occasioned by the fearful and unfamiliar sounds they had so recently heard. Making a quick but keen survey of the top of the wall, to be certain that no other Indian had ventured upon the experiment which had cost the first one his life, he advanced to the door, and gave several quick heavy knocks with the breech of his rifle. "Who is there/" called out Gertrude. "Is is I - Edward - all is so far safe - do not be alarmed." "Thank God! thank God!" ejaculated Gertrude: "I was afraid you were killed. Come in!" she added, opening the door. As Hargrave was about to comply with her request, the simpleton darted out past him. "Here, Jacob," he called, "you must remain inside." If Jacob heard, he did not heed, but turned the corner of the house with a bound, and came nigh receiving the contents of Dick's rifle - who, startled at his sudden approach, and supposing (the next column is mostly torn off, and only a few letters of each line are readable. They are not transcribed. thentic materials, according to "Pictorial Times," from which we engraved. "The San Francisco was a new vessel, and built by Wm. H. Webb, for W. H. Aspinwall & Co., proprietors of the Pacific Mail Steamship Line. She had a fine model, and was considered a very strong craft. The spar and hurricane deck ran the whole length of the vessel. She had a plain clipper bow, and was rigged with two masts, carrying foresaid top-sail, and jibs, with smoke-pipes fore and aft. Her deck length was 285 feet; keel, 280; beam, 41; hold 25; tonnage, 3,000. "Under a charter from the Government, the San Francisco sailed on Thursday, Dec. 21st, from New York, for San Francisco, purposing to to touch at Rio Janeiro, Valparaiso, and Aca- ment, constituted over 500 men. "At 9 o'clock, in the words of Lieut. Winder, a passenger on board the ill-fated vessel, on the morning of the 22nd day of December, a tremendous gale sprang up, which increased to a hurricane; and about 12 o'clock at night the engines gave out, and the foremast was carried away. The starboard wheel-house was smashed in by a tremendous sea, and a portion of the upper cabin was stove. This destructive sea swpt away, in a few moments, over 100 souls. The scene on board, from this moment forward, became truly distressing. The lower cabin was crowded to suffocation with passengers, who had rushed there under the impression that it was the only safe portion of the ves- pumps, though worked with vigor, were unable to keep the water from gaining. A temporary steerage apparatus was erected, and some attempts were made to get the vessel under way. But after one or two revolutions of the wheels, the machinery gave out; and it was evident that further exertion in that direction was useless. During all this awful scene, when the passengers were lying soaked in water, expecting the vessel to founder every moment, and fresh disasters and losses of life were every instant announced, nothing could exceed the calm courage with which the officers of the ship performed their duties. He bought two extraordinary large oxen from his brother-in-law (illegible), of Hagerstown Maryland for which he paid him forty pounds sterling, in gold and silver coin. He drove them home to his farm in Earl Township, Lancaster County, Pennsylvania and kept them some 18 months. In the mean time these cattle became fat and in high condition and a Mr. Wertz, who was at that time in Lancaster acting as a commissary for the army and hearing of those cattle, came to my husband's, Christian Garber, farm, drove them off, and had them slaughtered for the use of the army without ever paying a farthing for them. He left my husband a paper which has been mislaid or lost. During this critical period he often had whole troops of calvary quartered upon him for nights and days who came took up his barn, went to his grainery, took as much oats as he required, together with hay for their horses. Then went to his cellar from whence they took anything they could find to appease their hunger. She further states that she often helped them to such edibles as the soldiers required. In the summertime they would turn their horses into our grass fields. One evening in particular a troop came to his house just as we were making preparations for haying. The day following that night they turned all their horses into the only grass field we had reserved for hay. It was ruined to such an extent that the following winter we ran short of fodder for our own cattle who had to suffer in consequence thereof. He also served under Captain Jacob Forney in 1785 who was active in settling down the

State of Pennsylvania County of Lancaster S.S. On this th day of July personally appeared before me a justice of the peace in and for the County of Lancaster and State of aforesaid Jacob Johns Senr resident of upper Leacock Township Lancaster County and State of Pennsylvania who being first duly affirmed according to law doth depose and say, That he was personally acquainted with Christian Garber Deceased, of Earl Township Lancaster County husband of Anna Garber, that he upon more than one occasion heard Christian Garber Deceased say during his life time that he served as a soldier during the revolutionary war, that he served as private upwards of one year that he served the greater part of that eventful struggle as waggoner driving his own team and horses. State of New York Chenango County| Ss: Be it remembered that on this fourth day of November in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred & eighteen, before me one of the Judges of the court of Common Pleas of the County of Chenango in the state aforesaid personally appears Joseph Guthrie resident in the town & county aforesaid who being by me first duly sworn according to Law doth on his oath make the following declaration & depose and say that he is personally acquainted with David Dixon of the aforesaid. That the said David Dixon is a farmer by occupation, has a small farm in Sherburne upon which he lives & from which he derives support for himself & family. That on the thirty first day of October last this deponent together with Asa Gifford [?quese?] of Sherburne, at the request of the said David Dixon, under oath administered by a Justice of the Peace of said county, did examine & appraise the farm & [?not?] property on which the said David Dixon lives as aforesaid and did then value the said Real property of the said David Dixon at sixteen hundred & fifty dollars & his personal property consisting of two cows two oxen a mass scott at one hundred & forty dollars - and that the said Real & personal property of the said David Dixon which they [?used?] as aforesaid is not, in the Judgment of this deponent worth any more than what they so appraised them at. That they estimate the debt of the said David Dixon ^owing by from the best information they could obtain, at about four hundred dollars - and this deponent saith further that he verily believes they appraised all the property of the said David Dixon Real & personal except [house hold - crossed out] a smal [sic] amount of joining to it, household furniture & provisions - This deponent further saith that the said David Dixon has been & still is greatly burdened by severe sickness in his family. That he has for a long time had a sick & almost helpless daughter to support also a sick and perfectly helpless wife who will probably

Charlestown June 21 1830. Dear Sir Mr Daniel Davison, the gentleman who called upon you yesterday, is a member of a Church in Meredith, N.H., and a citizen of the adjoining town, called Guilford. I have received ample testimonial of his excellent character, and have no doubt of the entire evidence of those statements he made to you respecting the battle of Bunker Hill. Mr. Davison accompanied me on [illegible] last to the battle ground, and pointed me to the [illegible] where he received the wound in the left side of his head and fell His descriptions of the whole of that memorable scene will [illegible] interesting, such as no other than are eye witness could have given. From the wound he then received, Mr. Davison has suffered extremely. He was told by his Physician at that time he would never survive its consequences . He is even now so much afflicted, as to prevent him from doing any labor to support himself and his aged [illegible]. His testimonial from gentlemen, to me of which I know; The scars which he bears, and the pain he manifests, are the evidence upon which I place my belief.-

I advised her to renew her application for the purpose of proving as far as possible the service of said Joshua by living witnesses, which is but traditionary yet it comes from the best source among them is our Presbyterian minister a clergyman of high standing and others of equal worth and respectability. This said Joshua was doubtless the son of an Indian woman from the land of Montauk, of a very light complexion as his grandchildren now living are of a lighter color than that of ordinary Indians. And it is not fair to presume that he was barely considered in the army as a colored man and therefore was permitted for a short time to hold the office of Corporal as a reward for some particular service as it will be seen by his certificate that his promotion was merely temporary. I can only add that the said Hannah is honest poor and destitute and if she be entitled to a pension it will be a sure of relief to her and her grandchildren, who are likewise poor. Yours respectfully, Josiah C Dayton

2 father also referred to having been captured by the British & comfined for 9 months as a prisoner on board the British [illegible] A short time previous to this imprisonment in the enemy ship his leg had been broken by a swivel shot and sufferd quite pain during first week of his imprisonment, he made frequent mention of his being four miles below york town when Lord Cornwallis [illegible] he was stationed there to prevent the junction of enforcement of British troops with the army of Cornwallis he spoke of having been wounded on the arm which remained stiff until his death & he spoke of having been presence by the British and of swimming James River and having been fired on by four British officers while crossing that river. he often spoke of Washington and Lafayette and Gen. Green & Col. Morgan he was personally acquainted La Fayette & intimately with Gen Washington with whom he claimed family relationship who presented him with a sword which he lost in a scuffle with the enemy while crossing a river - he after alluded to his acquaintance with one Gordon a revolutionary Soldier - also spoke of his being in battle where some highland Scotch were taken Prisoners by him & his men - His Father in his life time had both a commission and discharge, which he was informed was placed in the hands of a man named Allen under a promise to obtain a pension for his father Lewis Lanier died and inquiry was made of Allen brother who stated that he could not find them among the papers of his deceased Brother and he therefore conclude that his said Fathers Commission and discharge have been sent to Washington or that they are otherwise lost. [illegible] declarant is quite certain that his father in his life time never drew any pension on was placed on any pension role His father after his military service and marriage in Essex County which marriage is duly of record in the old family Bible, home and to N. Carolina where he also served as a volunteer or in the militia of that State in the same companies N. Carolina he was for service years a member of the Legislature of N. Carolina afterwards he thinks about 50 years ago, his father moved to Georgia

Isham Burks [illegible] That since the 18th day of March 1818 the following changes have been made in my property on or about that time I was passed of seven head of horses and mares, a good waggon and gear, between three & 4 hundred dollars in bank bills, five feather beds, and furniture, five good Cows house hold and Kitchen furniture the amount and description the not precisely recollected and one thousand dollars owing me by said Emmerson I do not recollect the different changes which have taken place and can only say that it is all gone out of my papers except two Feather beds and some few articles of Small Value, My occupation is coopering and turning and chair making but afflicted with disease and visited with the infirmities of old age, I am seldom able to work at either. My family is composed of the following members, my wife Elizabeth Burks, who is about 65 or sixty six years old the 16th day of January or February last, and crippled in her right hand, James Payne Burks my youngest child 21 years old in May last and Nancy Sexton my Grand daughter who is [illegible] by my son in law Isham Burks [illegible] Sworn to and declared on this 22nd day of June 1839 in open Court before me David Todd Judge of said Court State of Missouri County of Boone } SS I Roger N. Todd Clerk of the Circuit Court for the County aforesaid do hereby certify that it appears to the satisfaction of the Court that the said Isham Burks did serve in the Revolutionary war

DECLARATION, in order to secure the benefit of the Act of Congress, passed June 7, 1832. COMMONWEALTH OF MASSACHUSETTS. COUNTY OF WORCESTER, SS. ON this Sixth day of September in the year of our Lord, eighteen hundred and thirty two personally appeared in open Court, before Nath Paine Judge of Probate for County of Worcester now sitting Jesse Bemis a resident of Spencer in the County of Worcester and Commonwealth of Massachusetts, aged Eighty one years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress, passed June 7th 1832. THAT he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers and served as herein stated, that on the twentieth day of April A.D. 1775, the next day after the battle at Lexington and Concord he marched from thence to as a minute man so called, in the company commanded by Capt. Ebenezer Mason, went from there to Roxbury and there home being gone about ten days. Immediately after I came home in April aforesaid I enlisted into a company of Massachusetts Militia commanded by Capt Joel Green. David Prouty was Lieut and Reuben Slayton was Ensign, in the Regiment commanded by Col. Ebenezer Larned, was stationed at Roxbury Mass. the whole term being eight months, and was there while the battle of Bunker hill was fought, and was honourbly discharged. also, sometime in the month of February or March 1776, he again enlisted into a company of Massachusetts Militia, commanded by Capt. Seth Washburn in the Regiment manded by Col. Whitney, marched from said Spencer to Dorchester near Boston, Mass. for the term of two months and was then honourably discharged, and was at Dorchester when the Brittish troops evacuated Boston. also, sometime in the latter part of the month of August or beginning of September 1776, he again enlisted into another company of Massachusetts Militia, commanded by Capt Josiah White and Col. Samuel Denny commanded the Regiment, and marched to Tarrytown, on the river Hudson, and we stationed there and at Singsing for the term of two months and was then honourably discharged, also, on the seventh day of April A.D. 1777 he enlisted into the United States service in the Continental line for the term of three years, the company was command by Capt Mick Holden, in Colonel Nixtons Regiment and General Nixton's Brigade he marched from Spencer to Peekskill on the river Hudson, N. York, was stationed at various on the river Hudson, assisted at the taking of Genl Burgoynes army, was at the close of the battle at Stillwater, and many small skirmishes and received a written discharge on the seventh day of April 1780, having served in the continental service three years, and having served in the whole four years. The first year in the continental service I was a corporal and did corporals duty and the two last years I was a Sergeant and had a sergeant, warrant for the same, for this last service I received a pension under the act of Congress of March 18. A.D. 1818 the certificate is numbered 676, but was stricken as I suppose on account of property. My discharge I suppose is in the Secretary of wars office, and suppose my sergeants warrant is there also, to which I refer for further evidence. In my former pension I was paid as a private only but ought to have been paid as a sergeant. He was born at said Spencer June 3d 1751, lived in Spencer during all his enlistments, and live, there now and essence, except four or five years in the State of New York. My age is recorded in the records of the Clerk in said Spencer. His enlistments were all voluntary, have no other documents except my discharge and sergeants warrant above referred to. I refer to Jonas Bemis and William Pope Ergrs, also to Major Isaac Lamb & Capt. David Livermore some of my neighbours who can testify to my character for truth & veracity. He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present, and declares that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any state. Jesse Bemin Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid before Nathl Paine Judge of Probate for the County of Worcester

He was born in the Town of Stanford in the State of Connecticut in the ['the' crossed out] 1760 He has a record of his age in his family Bible he knows of no other record - He lived in the Town of Hancock in the commonwealth of Massachusetts when called into service, since which he has lived in New bedford in the State of New York about three years - in New Lebanon in the State of New York about eight years - in the Town of Canter bury in the State of New Hampshire about six years - and in Lyme in said State of New Hampshire where he now lives about thirty three years - The first, third, and fourth terms of his service he was Drafted the second term he enlisted or volunteered He saw General Washington frequently at white plains also General Waine (Wayne) does not recollect the names of other officers more than he has mentioned in the body of his declaration and he cannot be more particular as to the general circumstances of his service He never received any written discharge but was dismissed at the expiration of his terms of service - He refers to the Rev Moses Cheney & David Pusher who reside in his neighbourhood who can testify to his character as to veracity & their belief of his services as a Soldier of the Revolution /s/John Bishop We Moses Cheney residing in Lyme NH and David Pusher residing in Lyme hereby certify that we are well acquainted with John Bishop who has subscribed and sworn to the above d; that we believe him to be 72 years of age that he is reputed and believed in the neighborhood where he resides to have been a soldier of the Revolution and that we concur in that opinion. /s/Moses Cheney /s/David Pusher Sworn and subscribed the day & year aforesaid And the said Court do hereby declare their opinion after the investigation of the matter and after putting the interrogatories prescribed by the war department that the above named applicant was a Revolutionary Soldier and served as he states. And the Court certifies that it appears to them that Moses Cheney who has signed the preceding certificate is a Clergyman residing in said Lyme and that David Pusher who has also signed the same is a resident in the the Town of Lyme and are credible personas and their statement is entitled to credit. /s/Edward Webber Judge of Probate I Moses Dow clerk of the Court of Probate aforesaid

I Richard Sluyter Minister of the Gospel residing in the town of Claverack in the County of Columbia & State of New York the immediate successor of the Rev. John G. Gerhard now deceased with whom in his lifetime I was well acquainted & with whose hand writing I am well acquainted, do hereby certify that the Church Record of the Dutch Reformed Church in Claverack aforesaid is in my possession and that I find on said Record in the hand writing of said Gerhard the following entry viz - Twentieth of April one thousand seven hundred and eighty six John Henry Plass and Lena Elliot were married. (The name Lena may be rendered in English, Magdalena) I further certify that the above is a true copy of the Record with the exception of the date on the Record which is expressed on the Record in fair legible figures as follows "20th of April 1781" Richard Sluyter Pastor of the Reformed Dutch Church in Claverack Columbia County SS. State of New York Orange County; Ss, Thomas Pope of the town of Windsor County and State aforesaid, being duly sworn deposed and says that he was fifty years of age on the twenty seventh day of April last that he is the third child of John Pope deceased and Elizabeth Pope, the widow, the person described in and who has subscribed and sworn to the foregoing declaration. That the said John Pope and Elizabeth Pope, had four children, the oldest of whom if living would be fifty six years old- and this deponent is the third child and that his father the said John Pope died on the twenty seventh day of December in the year one thousand eight hundred & twenty three or twenty four. And that his mother the said Elizabeth Pope has remained a widow ever since the death of his father the said John Pope and at present resides with this deponent. And that during the life time of his father he has frequently heard him and his mother the said Elizabeth converse of and concerning their marriage that in these frequent conversations between the said John Pope & Elizabeth Pope this deponent learned that his parents the said John & Elizabeth were married soon after the close of the Revolutionary War at a place called Parsipany in the state of New Jersey, that being their place of residence at that time. And that the name of the clergyman who married them was "Grovier". And that shortly after their marriage they removed to the State of New York. And this deponent further says that his parents had no education and could neither read or write and that no entry was ever made by either of them of their marriages and that the entries of the births of their children were made by other persons and also that the family Record hereunto attached is taken from my Bible and that the entries of

incursions of the Savages. In March A.D. 1781 he raised a new Company for the same purpose, which were enlisted for & during the War in August of that year being ordered & invited to join Col Clark in his expedition against the Western Indian Towns in the attempts to do so with his company he & they were attacked, defeated & the survivors taken prisoner by the Indians on the Ohio River near the mouth of the Sisto River After marching on foot from there to Detroit suffering incredible hardships & cruelties from his Savage Captors, he was delivered into the hands of the British Authorities of Canada by Capt. Braun whose captive & have he had been given the time of his capture by the Indians. He was carried by the British Authorities to Montreal & there imprisoned, on account of some harsh Retaliatory measures between the two [illegible] until the close of the year 1782, being a period of about fourteen months & a part of the time in irons. All of forty five officers closely confined at Montreal he was one of only nineteen who survived the wants of air & provisions during that cruel confinement on the 15th of October A.D. 1782 he was put on onboard a vessel with other prisoners & delvd to New York. He arrived in Philadelphia in the year 1783 in a very forlorn & destitute condition but immediately on his return to the Western Country he again raised a company for the defense of the frontiers & continued to do his duty until the close of the War of the Revolution & on the first day of July 1783 he & his company were honorably discharged from Service, with the thanks of the Public

Washington D.C. January 31, 1853 Rev & Dear Sir, will you please oblige a poor family by doing them a favor to wit - Jacob Wheeler was married to Sophia Starkweather between 1769 and 1779 by Rev. Willoughby Have you the old church records, & do you find a record of such marriage, or a record of the birth of any of their children, if to please give me a copy of marriage record, & of dates of the birth of the children. If you have no such record, please get this letter into the hands of the Town Clerk & I ask him to answer it, answer on the page directed to me here, much oblige Rev. Minister Your obedient servant, Arad Joy Dear Sir, I have made diligent inquire but can learn nothing on the point of your inquiries. The oldest inhabitants can give no information and there are no words either of the Church or Town [illegible] so far back to be found. Yours, S. N. Steele, Pastor

Irvin a resident of Jefferson Township in the County of Fayette and State aforesaid aged Sixty one years who being first duly sworn according to law doth on his oath make the following amended declaration on behalf of his mother Elizabeth Irvin in order to obtain for her the benefit of the provision made by the act of Congress passed July 4, 1836 and to which he believes she is justly entitled. That she was married to Andrew Irvin deceased as he verily believes in the year 1774 by a Mr Brander then a minister of the Episcopal Church of England in Bedford County Virginia as he always understood since his earliest recollection from his said father and mother. That he well recollects at an early age to have seen and often read a family record of such marriage and the ages of their children as nearly as he can recollect as follows to wit “Andrew Irvin and Elizabeth Mitchell Married 1774 - Robert Irvin born August 6. 1775 - Jane Irvin born Jany 3, 1777 - Mary Irvin born Sept. 1778- Stephen M Irvin (this affiant) born Octo 1780- Lucinda Irvin born June 1782 - Caleb Irvin born Jany (or Feb) 1785 - Joshua Irvin born Sept 1787- John Irvin born May 1790 - Elizabeth Irvin May 1792 - William Irvin born March 1796. which record when witness first saw it was kept in a family Bible and there remained until said Bible was worn out by use & said record very much mutilated and torn for which reason it was transcribed from thence into a family Dictionary where it was also kept a long time from which the children all derived their ages & the sons who are

AT a court of Common Pleas held at the Court-House in the village of Batavia, in and for the county of Genesee, in the State of New York of the fourteenth day of June of the term of June 1820, being a Court of Record, in place of the 41st article of the Constitution of the state of New-York, which has unlimited jurisdiction, keep records of is procedings, and has immemorially exercised the power of fine and imprisonment, Present, the Hon. John Jones, Isaac Wilson, Richard Smith Moses Hayden - Judges GENESEE COUNTY. -- On this fourteenth day of June 1820, personally appeared in open Court, (being a Court of Record), Curtis Smith aged sixty years, resident of the town of Clarkson in said county, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth, on his oath, declare that he served in the Revolutionary war as follows:-- Two years, served in Capt. Thos. Lee's Company in Col Warner Regiment of the New Hampshire Line was discharged at Saratoga the last of December 1779 that his pension certificate is numbered 11.955 And I do solemnly swear that I was a resident Citizen of the United States, on the eighteenth day of March, one thousand eight hundred and eighteen, and that I have not, since that time, by gift sale or in any manner whatever, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled "An act to provide for certian persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the revolutionary war,” passed on the eighteenth day of March, one thousand eight hundred and eighteen , and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts , or debts, due to me; nor have I any income, other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed. Schedule Real Estate I have none I am in possession of Forty Eight acres Land situated in the town of Clarkson in sd. County owned by Leroy Bayard & Co on which there is ten acres improved and a small log house and on which there is now due the owner of the Estate Six Dollars 75 Cents per acre or $324.00 in the whole. Personal Property (except necessary wearing apparel and bedding which does not twenty five Dollars in value in the whole one cow 1 year old heifer 1 Hog 1 Plough &1 Harrow 1 Iron Shovel Broken 2 axes & 2 hoes 1 mid Size Iron pot 1 Bake Kettle 1 Iron Tea kettle 1 Iron basin 6 common chairs 1 common law chest, 6 barrels for meat & flour, 1 pail 4 Common earthen bowls, 6 cups & Saucers 4 Common Plates 3 Knives & forks 1 Earthen tea pot 1 pewter plate 1 small grindstone
