Bishop Register of Probate. [small folded paper to the left of this signature]

State of New York County of Herkimer SS Abraham G. Rosecrants of the Town of Little Falls in the County of Herkimer being duly sworn doth depose and say that he is the personal a presentative and son of George Rosecrants deceased, who was the son of the Reverend Abraham Rosecrants deceased and that the said Abraham Rosecrants deceased in his lifetime was the minister of the Reformed protestant Dutch Church of Herkimer and German flatts; that he was always informed and believes, that his said grandfather as such minister solemnized marriages and kept a record of marriages and that he also kept a record of the baptism of the infants of parents and that the book in which such records was kept was after the decease of his said grandfather in the possession of the father of this deponent until his decease, which went took place on the 21st December 1838 and this deponent further says that since the death of his said father the said Book of record has been & still is in the possession of this deponent, be this deponent being the executor of the said George Rosecrants deceased and this deponent further says that he has not on an examination of the record of marriage, in hand book found any record of the marriage of Christian Hesse and Elizabeth Hesse but among the records in said Book of the baptism of infants this deponent finds a record in the words and figures following to wit "1781, Parents Infants Susceptores N of 8th Nov. [Parents]Christian Hesse and Elisabeth [Susceptores] Friedrick Hast and Elisabeth B.R. 18th Nov Augustines [infant] and further this deponent says not- Abraham G. Rosecrantz Subscribed and sworn this 28th day of March 1840 before me William Brooks J. Peace Report [illegible]

State of New Jersey Bergen County Personally appeared before the Subscriber A Justice of the Peace in and for the County aforesaid the Rev. Isaac D. Cole who being first duly sworn according to Law Deposeth and saith, That he is the present Pastor of the Dutch Reformed Church at Tappan, (part of the Congregation Resides in the State of New Jersey and part in the State of New York, the meeting House is nearly on the line between the two States above named) that he has in his possession a Record belonging to that society in which marriages are recorded from the year six teen hundred and Ninety nine untill the year Seventeen Hundred & Fifty four From that period it appears from said Record that it has been omitted by the Rev, Samuel Nerbryck who was then Pastor of said Society-- In the year Seventeen Hundred & Eighty four the Record is commenced by the Rev Nicholas Lansing and continue by the said Lansing untill the year Eighteen Hundred and Thirty one from that period untill the present by the Subscriber and that Jacob Bamper & Ann Bamper is not Revealed on said Record Isaac D Cole J.D.M Sworn and subscribed before me this 8th day of July AD 1837Albert J. Terhene Justice of the Peace I do hereby certify that the Revd Isaac D Cole who has sworn and subscribed unto the above affidavit is a Minister of the Gospel and pastor of the Dutch Reformed Church at Tappan and in good standing Albert J Terhune J. P

S. Sir, Ponds Near Paterson July 12th 1837 In reply to yours of the 12th June She saith that she Received from the Rev. Samuel Verbryck then Pastor of the Dutch Reformed Church Tappan a Certificate of her marriage, and belived she had given it to her sister Col. Bell widow for safe keeping for which a search has been made amongst the papers of said Widow but cannot be found-- her fathers family Bible contains no Record of any marriage whatever and has no documentary evidence as yet to be found The enclosed affidavit of the Rev J.D. Cole she hopes will give some satisfaction I am Respectfully your Obt Servant A.G. Lydecker J.L. Edwards Esqr Commissioner of Pensions B. If consistent, please inform me if the widow Pings application is in the office sent by the Subscriber A G Lydecker

yet if you should decline to comply with my request I might have got alon but for the following misfortuneto wit, that last fall being in New York & shiped on board the steam boat Albany to be landed at the City of Albany property to rather more time I was actually than worth which was wholly lost by the ship wreck of the steam boat in the Hudson river which bankrupt me [unk] reducedme to [unk] and helpless condition and I am now in great want of means to procure my daily food and to [unk] my witness I have not a child on Earth or any other being who can be made [unk] for a [unk] must and if I am alive next April that will find me eighty years of age and tho in health an quite unable to earn anything to help support myself and unless helped by my pension must continue to pay out a life of pain of mind and [unk] of body all the [unk] he said to be well enough for me if I was had or now do in the least live [unk] on in any degree on extravagant life this can not be vessel for at the close of the sum I returned to my natural place command the Study of Law ad finalized it until old age drove me from its pursuits and I have seen much better days to me than these but [unk] a;; these privations and wants it yeilds me much satisfaction to reflect that my time of life fell in gloryous [unk] and that is in my country was strugling against tyrony and oppression and labouring for independance I took in full I have in those memorable events and now [unk] to me and live under the best government now on Earth and to see that government administrated in all it departments in the best possible manner and may these blessings be perpetuated until Earthly government shall be no more gentlemen I fear that I have to for intruded upon your time and patience for which please pardon me and suffer me to beg and pray that one of you will have the goodness as soon as possible to write me directed to Oswego in the county of Oswego State of New York and inform me if anything can and will be done to help me or not that I may be relieved from this state of suspense so painfull to rev old soldier and returning to childhood again I am gentleman with the greatest respect your humble servant. Dan Chapman L Crass Sec of War J. L. Edwards commissioner of pensions Washington

Declaration In order to obtain the benefit of the Act of Congress of the 29. July, 1848 State of New Hampshire County of Grafton ss.} On this 14th day of November A.D. 1848 personally appeared before me D. C. Churchill a Justice of the Court of Common Pleas within and for the County of Grafton and State of New Hampshire Sally Bishop a resident of Lyme in the County of Grafton aforesaid aged 76 years who being duly sworn according to law, doth on her oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the provisions made by the act of Congress passed the 29" July 1848, that she is the widow of John Bishop, who was a private in the Army of the Revolution and a pensioner of the United States upon the Rolls of the New Hampshire agency under the act of Congress passed 7th June 1832 at the rate of twenty eight Dollars and thirty two cents per annum, she further declares that she has no documentary or other evidence of her said husband's service but respectfully refers to the Declaration of her said husband on the Rolls and records of the War department to support her claim - She further declares that she was married to the said John Bishop on the tenth day of August in the year seventeen hundred and ninety seven, that her husband the aforesaid John Bishop died on the third ['second' crossed out] day of April eighteen hundred and forty two. that she was not married to him prior to his leaving the service, but the marriage took place previous to the second of January eighteen hundred viz; at the time above stated. She further swears that she is now a widow, and that she has never before made any application for a pension. she further states that her name before her marriage was Sally Kimball - /s/X her mark Sally Bishop before /s/D. C. Churchill J. C. C. Pleas - I further certify that the above applicant can not attend the court from bodily infirmity, her disability consists of an affliction of the lungs & a severe cough of long standing /s/D. C. Churchill J. C. C. Pleas

State of Tennessee Lawrence County Court of Pleas and Quarter Session January Term 1836 on this siscth day of August 1836 personally appeared in open Court Neill Conly a resident citizen of the County of Laurence and State of Tennessee aged about seventy two years in next August as recorded in his father’s family Bible now in his possession, who being first duly sworn according to law doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefits of the act of Congress passed June 7th 1832. That he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers and served as herein stated; to wit that he took the place of Macon Smith who was drafted for sisc months under Capt Neill McRainy and became Rowan in the State of North Carolina and County of Cumberland in the town of Fayetteville originally called Cross Creek in the month of August 1780. That he was attached to a foregoing Company commanded first by said McRainy and afterwards by Capt Nichy Smith and was employed in gathering cattle for the main army after Gale’s defeat about the time General Green took the command, that he served out his time and got a discharge signed by General Butler and Capt. McRainey which he got burnt at John Watson’s when his home was burned that he was with the waggons and had the charge of one of them during the battle of Guilford and received a wound on his Shin from a sword inflicted by one of Tartans Troopers but Col. Washington rescued

State of Tennessee Lawrence County. Court of Pleas & Quarter Sessions January Term 1836 On this 6th day of January 1836 Neill Conly appeared in open Court and being first sworn according to law answered the within interrogations as follows to wit 1, Question? When and in what year were you born Answer. I was born in Cumberland County North Carolina on the 4th day of August 1764 2. Have you any Record of your age & what is it Answer. I have my age recorded in my fathers bible which descended to me after his death 3. Where did you live when you went into the service & when have you lived since. Ans. I lived when I went into the service in Cumberland County State of North Carolina & continued to live there until he moved from that place to Lawrence County State of Tennessee where he now resides. 4th How were you called into service. were you drafted, did you volunteer or were you a substitute & if so for whom. Answer the first time I went into serve I was a Substitute for Macon Smith, that is Duncan Buie and Macon Smith give me five cows & calves to stand then draw Buie was not drawn and Smith was and I served out his term of sisc months & after that [illegible]

and he turned out himself or sisc months and served out said time 5th State the name of the Regular officers who were with the troops where you served & such can [Illegible] & Malitia Regiments as you can recalled & the General circumstances of the Campaign Answer. I only saw the affairs when I drove cattle to camp & when I drove one of the Camp Waggons. I recalled that I saw General Gales [Illegible] after his defeat. I recalled General Greene well and [Illegible] Gen. Morgan & Col Washington of the light Horse. I recalled General Butler & Stephens but think they commanded the Militia. I saw General Peckens with Morgan after the battle of Cowpens. I cannot recalled the names of the regiments for I did not muster in them but only assisted in feeding them. In my first campaign the Battle of Guilford & the Cowpens were fought. in my second the battle of Camden [Illegible] was fought. In my [Illegible] in both Campaigns I was confined to North Carolina and South Carolina except when he crossed Dan River flying with the prisoners taken at the Cowpens where pursued by lord Cornwallis when I was in the edge of the State of Virginia. 6 Did you ever receive a discharge from service & if so by whom were they given Answer I received a Discharge at the emancipation

Westmoreland County Ss. On the fourteenth day of August in the year of our Lord one thousand Seven hundred and eighty eight, Come before me Michael Huffnagle Esquire one of the Justices of the Peace and of the Court of Common Pleas in + for the County of Westmoreland County ("County" crossed out) and also Prothonotary of the Same County The subscriber Robert Hunter who being Sworn upon the Holy Evangelist of Almighty, deposith and saith that he was well acquainted with Captain Robert Orr before he went with Colonel Archibald Lockry to join general Clark on an Expedition against the Indians in the year our Lord one thousand Seven hundred and eighty one_ and that he Said Robert Orr was the Healthy able man to perform any kind of labour belonging to Farming- That after the Said Robert Orr Returned from that expedition the deponent ( who often lived and Boarded with the Said Robert Orr) observed that he was unable to work, that he has seen him endevaring to cut a Stick of Firewood and obliged to quit it with great burning Pain. That he has observed him restless at night complaining of a pain in his left arm and hand which he said was occasioned by a wound which he received in his left arm ("arm" was crossed out) Shoulder when he was taken prisoner by the Indians on the above mentioned Expedition- And that the deponent is well injured that the Said Robert Orr is injured thereby in such a manner as to render him incapable of making a livelyhood by hard labour. Sworn + Subscribed Before me} august fourteenth 1788. } /s/ Mich Huffnagle /s/ Robert Hunter

COMMONWEALTH OF MASSACHUSETTS. Be it remembered, that on this third ----- day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and Eighteen before me, SAMUEL DANA, Chief Justice of the Circuit Court of Common Pleas, for the Middle Circuit, (comprehending the Counties of Essex and Middlesex, in the Commonwealth aforesaid) comes Moses Chase of Groton in said county of Middlesex, and on oath declares, that he served in the War of the Revolution for the space of seven years and untill the end of that war, that having served from the commencement of the war. In January, in the year of our Lord, One Thousand seven hundred and seventy seven, he enlisted upon the Continental establishment, during the War, into the company of Capt. Luke Day in the seventh Massachusetts Regiment, commanded by Col. John Brooks, in this company he remained ["to" struck through] untill near [preceding two words inserted with caret] the end of the War -- & he was mustered at Concord by Jonas Heywood Esquire He was in the Battles of Bunker hill [sic] - the Battle of White plains [sic] - the battle of Brandy wine [sic][Brandywine] - the battle of Harlaem [sic][Harlem] heights [sic] -- at the close of the war, he was in a company commanded by Capt. North his Lieuts., were George Reed, & Lt. Sturstevant, and in the Regiment commanded by Col. Henry Jackson, who gave him an honorable discharge at the City of New York in the Spring of AD 1784 -- This discharge he preserved many years, but the same is now lost by time, and accident --- He is fifty nine years old wholly destitute of property, and has no way to procure subsistence but by manual labor, and his ability to labor declines -- by reason of a wound he received at the battle of Brandywine and _____ by reason of his reduced circumstances in life he stands in need of assistance from his country for his support. Thus, made, subscribed, and sworn to at Groton in said county of Middlesex the day and year aforesaid. Saml. Dana

CommonWealth of Massachusetts On this first day of July in the year of our Lord one thousand Eight hundred and Nineteen before me Samuel Dana Cheif [sic][Chief] Justice of the Circuit Court of Common Pleas for the middle Circuit and a Justice of the Peace throughout the same Commonwealth, personally appeared Joseph Moors and Samuel Lawrence Esqrs. and each for himself severally made Oath that the within Depositions by them respectively subscribed are just and true in all their particulars. -- And I Certify that the said Joseph Moors and Samuel Lawrence are both resident in Groton well known to me as respectable Citizens and each of them Justices of the Peace for the County of Middlesex, that they are wholly disinterested in the application of Moses Chase to be placed on the pension list and that they [preceding word inserted with caret] are entitled to full faith and entire credit before all tribunals and in all places. -- And I further Certify that the said Moses Chase is a poor man destitute of property and that he stands in need of assistance for his support ---- Given under my hand the day and year aforesaid Saml. Dana

[Illegible seal] To the Honorable JOHN C. CALHOUN, Secretary of the Department of War of the United States. I, the undersigned Samuel Dana, Chief Justice of the Circuit Court of Common Pleas, for the Middle Circuit, (comprehending the Counties of Essex and Middlesex) in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, being a Court of Record, duly established by Law, Do hereby certify, That on the third -- day of April -- in the year of our Lord, one thousand eight hundred and eighteen Personally appeared Moses Chase --- and made and subscribed the declaration which is hereunto annexed. from which it appears to me, that the said Moses Chase did serve in the War of the REVOLUTION, against the common Enemy, upwards of nine months, and the said Moses Chase is well known to me, to be poor and indigent wholly destitute of property and standing in need of assistance to obtain his support Wherefore, in pursuance of the directions of an Act of Congress, made and passed the eighteenth day of March, one thousand eight hundred and eighteen, entitled, ""An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War," I have transmitted the said Declaration to you the said Secretary, that such further proceedings may be had in the premises, as the said Act may require. In testimony of all which, I have caused the Seal of said Court to be hereunto affixed. Given under my hand within the [obscured] said Circuit, the third -- day of April -- in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and Eighteen. -- Saml. Dana

contained in the schedule hereto annexed and by me Subscribed. Sworn & declared before me this 27th day of June 1820. Jeremiah Evert John Talman Mayor I have no property except a small hut made of stone and rough boards, standing on the land of John Livingston Esqr worth about -- $12. and the following articles of personal property 4 Common chairs six knives & forks Six cups & saucers, three bowls, shovel & tongs pail and axe and one Hog worth collectively about- 10.00/$22.00 My family consists of myself aged sixty one years a poor and helpless cripple and my wife Polly aged fifty three years, -- these are the resources on which I depend unaided by friendship and the scanty means of subsistence - which my condition in life affords and without the aid of public or private charity I could not exist Jeremiah Evrit Hudson Mayor Court of the Term of June, June 27. 1820 Present the Hon. John Talman Esquire Mayor of said City

In Marine Court State of New York City & County of New York } ss. One this Seventy sixth day of October one thousand eight hundred and thirty eight, personally appeared before me Judah Hammond and one of the Justices of the Marine Court in open court Susannah Smith a resident of the City of New York in the County and State of New York aged seventy seven years who being first duly Sworn according to Law doth on her Oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the provision made by the Act of Congress passed July 7, 1838, entitled "An Act granting half pay and pension to Certain Widows." That she is the widow of Richard Smith, who was a wagon master as she believes in Colonel Lambs Regiment of the New York line. That she has no documentary evidence whatever now of her said husbands Services, it having been destroyed. That he was born at [illegible] Queens County Long Island. Becaues[because] he entered the Service when at Long Island or Fish-kill in Dutchess County[Fishkill, Dutchess county] about the beginning of the war, and that he served about five years [blacked out] five [blacked out] six months or some shorter term of service of the revolutionary war with great Brittain[Britain]. That her said husband was at Boston in Pennsylvania as a Wagon master in Said war, and in New Jersey but dont reccollect at what particular place. He was at white plains where the battle was fought at place he was also at Peeks Kill about the time the public stores were burnt she has after heard him speak frequently speak of the privations, fatigue and sufferings which he endured, while in the revolutionary service. She knows that there was a considerable quantity of papers and account books purporting to be of the [illegible] of the said Richard Smith as a waggon Master in the revolutionary war as the [illegible]. That the said papers and books were paeserved until about the year eighteen Hundred and sixteen. When presuming they were of no kind of use and never expecting any application for a pension would be made, and as they were deemed troublesome and useless they were Condemned in order to get them out of the way. That the said Richard Smith left the service about the year seventeen hundred and eighty one, or eighty two; at Fish Kill, and that he died at the City of New York on the ninth day of February eighteen hundred and thirty two, aged about seventy seven years. She further declares that she was married to the said Richard Smith on the twenty fourth day of July in the year seventeen hundred and eighty three, at Poughkeepsie precinct, in the County of Dutchess in the State of New York by the Reverend N Risedy Re of the Reformed Dutch Church, and who preached alternately at Poughkeepsie Hackensour, and Fish-Kill in the County of Dutchess, and was not married to the Said Richard Smith prior to his [illegible] the Service, but the marriage took place after the [crossed out "last period"]expiration of the last period of his service, and before the first day of January Seventeen hundred and ninety four. Viz at the time above stated. That after his marriage she lived with her husband the Said Richard Smith at Fish-Kill between one and two years when they removed to the City of New York, where they have ever lived until the day of his decease, and that she is now the widow of

he was actually in the army in Canada and Mrs. Paddock, if I recollect right, fixes the period of his return in the fore part of June- It would seem from the facts setforth in these affidavit that he must have served in the army 5 months or more, and that no fact can be better found than that this service was performed. I have made this Communication at the request of Mr. Abel, and you will see that accompanying affidavits of Messes Lord & Roots than is a request under his hand that his pension may be made payable at the Connecticut Agency-- Mr Abel has now become very old & infirm, and having no family of his own, has concluded to spend the short remnant of his life among his relatives & acquaintances in this town. You will also perceive that this course meets the approbation of Mr. Chittenden, who made the first application in behalf of Mr. Abel, as will appear by his letter to me, which I enclose- I will only add, that Mr. Abel does not know of any further proof by persons now living, which he can obtain, and that if the affidavits here entered are not deemed sufficient to establish his claim for services performed in the winter of 1776, he must accept of the 9 months pension which it seems it is agreed he is entitled to- He is extremely destitute and dependent on charity for his present subsistence, and an early determination of his case would much relieve his present distress- Respectfully your Obedient Servant Chas F Sedgwick

FORM OF A DECLARATION TO BE MADE BY THE WIDOW OF A DECEASED PERSON WHO HAD A LAND WARRANT, AND DESIRES ANOTHER. OF NEW YORK, COUNTY OF Saratoga On this twenty sixth day of May, A. D. one thousand eight hundred and fifty five personally appeared before me, a justice of the peace, within and for the county and State aforesaid, Mary Avery aged 70 years, a resident of Saratoga Springs, in the State of New York, who, being duly sworn according to law, declares that she is the widow of Stephen Avery deceased, who was an artificer in the company commanded by Captain Lamb, in the regiment of commanded by in the war with Great Britain known as the revolutionary war FOLLOWING IS CROSSED OUT: (declared by the United States on the 18th day of June, 1812, that her said husband enlisted at about the day of A. D. for the term of and continued in actual service in said war for the term of and was honorably discharged at of the day A. D.) She further states that she was married to the said Stephen Avery in Pittsford VT on the 16th day of August A.D. 1798 by one Rev M. Hardwood a Minister, and that her name before her said marriage was Mary Walker; that her said husband died at Brandon VT on the 6th day of September A.D. 1838 and that she is now a widow. She makes this declaration for the purpose of obtaining the bounty land to which she may be entitled under the "act approved March 3, 1855." She further declares that she now receives a yearly pension as such widow of said Stephen Avery & there is now on file as she supposes proof of her marriage with the said Stephen Avery of death her widowhood and of the services of the said Stephen Avery. Signed Mary Avery We, Jerome B. Buklee? and Eliza A Munger, residents of in the State of New York, upon our oaths, declare that the foregoing declaration was signed and acknowledged by Mary Avery in our presence, and that we believe, from the appearance and statements of the applicant, that she is the identical person she represents herself to be. JB Bucklee Eliza Munger The foregoing declaration and affidavit were sworn to and subscribed before me on the day and year above written; and I certify that I know the affiants to be credible persons; that the claimant is the person she represents herself to be, and that I have no interest in this claim. John T. Carr Justice of the Peace.

Revolutionary Claim, under Act of Congress, May 1, 1820. STATE OF VERMONT. Chittenden COUNTY, ss} ON this 17th day of September 182~ personally appeared in open Court, being the County Court for the County of Chittenden and a Court of Record for said County. Alexander Durand aged 55 years, resident in Charlotte in said County, who being duly sworn, according to law, doth on his oath, declare that he served in the revolutionary war, as follows: - In Capt Stephen Retts Company in Col. Webbs Regt of the Connecticut line, as will more fully appear in the original declaration made before the Hon. Zadock Wheeler, and on which I have heretofore received a pension certificate, which is herewith attached. That I have a wife who is now sick and unable to support herself. That I have three children dependent on me for support. And that I am myself very infirm by reason of a Breach. That the reason I have not heretofore applied to have my Pension continued was that I was in hopes of supporting myself without a Pension, but am now poor & destitute. And I do solemnly swear, that I was a resident citizen of the United States, on the 18th day March, 1818; and that I have not, since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary war," passed on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities, or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule here to annexed, and by me subscribed. We, the subscribers, citizens of Pennsylvania, and residents of Philadelphia, have long known Jacob Dowderman, an applicant for a revolutionary pension - He is not only "in reduced circumstances", but poor indeed, utterly destitute of property save some essentials of household furniture, of little value; and being old and infirm, is unable to support himself and wife by labor, Philadelphia February9, 1819.- [notation] I believe the fact stated Richard Peters [signatures Joseph Hertzog John Stow Jim Geyer Andrew Leinau Dan Smith David Weatherly Peter Christian

and served as captain. In August, 1781, he joined a force that was to go on an expedition under Colonel Clark, and while on the way at the mouth of the Scioto River on the Ohio River, they were attacked by the Indians and Captain Thomas Stokely was taken prisoner, and conveyed to Montreal, Canada , wherehe was held, a part of the time in irons, until October 15, 1782, when he was placed on board a vessel and sent to New York, and reached Philadelphia in 1783, "in a forlorn and destitute condition." It was stated that out of forty-five confined with him, only nineteen survived. He returned to his home and immediately raised a company and served as its captain until the close of the war, leaving the service,July 1, 1783. It is not shown that he served in the war of 1812. Thomas Stokely died in Washington County, Pennsylvania, July 25, 1824. The soldier married June 9, 1788, Betsey or Elizabeth Mumphford. The marriage was recorded on the records of the Presbyterian Church of Lewes, Delaware. The date and place of birth and the names of the parents of Betsey or Elizabeth are not stated. Soldier was called Major ThomasStokely. He was also referred to as Colonel Stokely. No explanation for the titles was given. Soldier's widow, Elizabeth, was allowed pension on her application executed March 1, 1841 at which time she was aged seventy-five years and eleven months, and resided in Steubenville, Jefferson County, Ohio. She died July 12, 1846, place not shown. No reference was made to children. In 1841, General S. Stokely was a resident of Steubenville, Ohio. No relationship to the family was shown. Very truly yours A. D. Hiller Executive assistant to the Administrator -2-

State of New York } Onondaga } s.s. Elizabeth Lord of Syracuse in said county being duly sworn says that she is aged fifty five years and upwards. That she is a daughter of Jacob Wheeler deceased and Sophia Wentworth whose declaration is hereto annexed. That deponent well recollects her said father - before his departure from home and [illegible] as stated in said declaration. Deponent further says that when a small girl she has heard [blurred image] further relate anecdotes of his being taken by Indians during the Revolutionary War. One in particular is the following. He was taken and was required to run the gauntlet between two rows of Indians. And he was told by a Squaw to clasp his hands over the top of his head and run through with all possible speed. That he followed her directors & succeeded so well that he received but a very few blows. Deponent further says that she has heard her said father state that he had suffered very much & endured a great many hardships while engaged in service during the Revolutionary War, & further says not. Elizabeth Lord Her mark X Subscribed and sworn before he this 19th day of March 1844 } John H. Johnson, Justice of the Peace

& in 1797 her said husband left home & soon afterwards she was informed he was dead. She never saw him again & believes he died in 1797 - married John Wentworth on or about 23rd February 1800. He died 1st June 1838 & she has remained a widow ever since (omitted.). Deponent says her husband after re-entering army continued in actual service till close of war & was discharged at Whitehall - has no documentary proof of marriage or services of Jacob (certificate of Judge that deponent is too inform to appear in Court.) Elizabeth Lord - says she is Jacob's daughter & heard her father speak of his capture by Indians - & suffering in war. Mary Haggerty - says she is daughter of Jacob - understood from parents she was born on 22nd day, 1775. Always retained a lively recollection of rev. war - her father was absent from home as a soldier & recollects his return home last time his service ended. Deponent was then 7 or 8 years old. war then over. Heard Jacob relate incidents of war, etc. and that he was a solider about 7 years. Deponent's mother marriage again in February 1800 to John Wentworth. John died on or around 1st June 1838.

State of Massachusetts I Daniel Hood a Citizen of the United States, now resident at Edgecombe in the County of Lincoln in the State aforesaid do on oath testify and declare that in the War of the Revolution, in the month of April or May 1778 I enlisted and entered and was engaged in the land service of the United States on the continental establishment and/ proceeded to Fishkill in the state of New York where I (ineligible) muster & joined my company in the month of June 1778, I enlisted for nine months & served out that time (ineligible) as a private soldier against the common enemy, without any interruption or absence: that I belonged to a Captain's company which I have forgotten in Col. Nixon's Regiment Gen. Nixon's Brigade in the Massachusetts line. and that I left the service in March or April 1779 at Fishkill Peekskill in the State of New York & received an honorable discharge verbally on the parade - and that by reason of my reduced circumstances in life and poverty, I stand in need of assistance from my country for support, being now of the age of seventy five years. I enlisted in the month of April or May 1778 as I have before stated we marched Fishkill & was there mustered & served nine months from the time I was so mustered - when the nine months were out. I with some others agreed to stay two months more at the earnest request of our officers, which we (ineligible) did And I hereby relinquish all claims to every pension heretofore allowed me by the laws of the United States, if any may be or hath been so allowed. Daniel Hood (handwritten signature) Commonwealth of Massachusetts Lincoln. BE IT REMEMBERED That on this fifteenth day of May in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and nineteen. Pursuant to a law of the United States, entitled, "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the revolutionary way, made and passed on the 18th of March A.D. 1818, personally appeareth before me Jeremieh Bailey Judge of the Court of Probate within and for the County on Lincoln in the commonwealth of Massachusetts the same being a Court of Record of said County the above named Daniel Hood and after due examination and caution to testify and declare the whole truth, he maketh oath to the declaration aforesaid, and subscribes the same in my presence; and on examination duly made by me the said Judge, it appeareth to my satisfaction that the said declaration is true. Jere Bailey (handwritten signature) I John H Sheppard Register of the Court of Probate for the County of Lincoln

in the revolutionary war passed on the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not nor has any person in trust for me any property or certificates contracts or debts due to me nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed. I do further declare that I am a pensioner under the act of Congress of the18th of March, 1818, and that my Certificate is numbered 11.198 that I am by occupation farmer but from age and infirmities, and wounded consequence of a broken thigh, not in a situation to follow it and that my family consists of a wife in the sixty second year of her age very much afflicted with the Rheumatism Schedule of property in the possession of John Hill on the 2 day of September 1828 one horse, one cow, one table, two chairs, two pots, one skillet, a few plates, knives and forks, cups and saucers. Also a pension of $40 a year from the State of Maryland. The property enumerated in the above schedule is hereunto valued by the Court at sixty five dollars. John Hill Sworn to and declared on the twenty third day of September in the year 1820 before the judges of the third Judicial District of Maryland sitting in open Court in and for Anne Arundel County. the aforegoing deposition was taken before me in the [illegible] and at the[illegible] there in po. I, William Strickland, a Citizen of the United States now resident in the Town of Gill in the County of Franklin and Commonwealth of Massachusetts do on oath declare that I belonged to the Army of the United States in the Revolutionary War. I entered the Service in the month of January (?) in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and seventh six as a soldier for the term of one year in the company commanded by Captain Libbeus Bull in the Regiment commanded by Colonel William Sheppard in the Massachusetts Line where I served until the expiration of my term of enlistment and a few days before my term of enlistment had expired as aforesaid I enlisted again in the same company Regiment and Line for a further term of six weeks and served until that had expired and was then honourably discharged from the service. When I left the army I was honourably discharged as aforesaid but never had a written one. I am now sixty two years old. I am very poor and in ...... circumstances in life and hence in great need of assistance from my country for support. ... at Greenfield in the County & Commonwealth aforesaid this eleventh day of April A.D. 1818. (signed) Wm Strickland

Commonwealth of Massachusetts Franklin ss At a Special Session of the Circuit Court of Common Pleas, for the Western Circuit, began and holden at Greenfield, within and for the County of Franklin, on Monday the tenth day of July, in the year of our Lord, one thousand eight hundred and twenty, et de die in diem to the fifteenth day of the same month. Personally appeared in open Court, being a Court of Record, within and for said County of Franklin established as such by the Constitution and Laws of said Commonwealth, William Strickland aged sixty four years, resident in Gill in said County, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth, on his oath, declare that he served in the Revolutionary War as follows: I entered the service in the month of December A.D. 1775, as near as I can recollect, for the term of one year in the company commanded by Capt Lebbeus Bull in the regiment commanded by Lt. Col. Shepherd but was called Reed's regiment in the Massachusetts line I continued to serve in the same until my term of enlistment had expired, when I enlisted for a further term of six weeks in the same company and was finally discharged near Morristown N.Jersey. My certificate was dated Mar. 22. A.D. 1819. The pension to commence 11th April A.D.1818 and is numbered 7477. My occupation is that of a labourer which I am almost precluded from pursuing by a palsy. My family consists of myself and wife Patience aged 55 years, who is quite feeble, and my son Jonathan Lyman aged 15 years and my daughter Barbara aged about seven years, all whom are dependent on me for their subsistence and support.

Elizabeth Sept the 17th 1862 Dear Sir here is a letter from the pention office and if you can give them any more information for goodness sake do for we are in destitute circumstances I was sold out in that house where you saw us last and I was nine months without A home we were scaterd [scattered] to and fro we are here doing the best we can that is very poor I wish you to write to J H Moorehead giving him all the information that you can and write to me also Mother is well but very weak we are in good health thank god Capt James May yours & Nancy Hinckerley N B please answer immediateley

I Elijah Fisher, now in my seventieth year of age do depose further and upon oath declare that on the 10th of April 1823 before the Court of Common Pleas at Augusta, within & for the County of Kennebec, I made a second schedule of my whole Estate, and the same was with sundry depositions forwarded to the Pension office, for the purpose of my being restored to the Pension Roll. I had not then, nor have I at this time, any Real Estate, or any personal property other than the few articles of old house hold furniture mentioned in said Schedule. The cow mentioned in said Schedule has been disposed of for my support and that of my family so that I am now left destitute upon the prospect of my obtaining my pension again, I have incurred some small debts, which if I fail of obtaining I am wholly unable to discharge. I served in the Revolutionary War over five year, and am now poor, and very infirm, wholly unable to labor and must depend upon public or private charity for my support- I now most earnestly require to be restored again to the Pension list of the Maine agency There was partly due my son Grinfell sixty six dollars for his labor after he become 21 years of age. I have been feeblet and unable to labor for the last ten years, but a small part of the time during that period - the transactions between myself and my son Grinfell were fair and I did suppose the deposition would be satisfactory to the Pension Office Elijah Fisher Kennebee SS Subscribed, sworn to and declared this fourth day of October A.D. 1882 Nathan Weston Jun Just S.J.C. I Grinfill Fisher aged thirty two years of age, do further depose and say that in April or May 1821 (not having my deed with me I am unable to say the precise time) I purchased of my father his homestead place, and agreed to pay sundry debts then existing against him as will appear by the deposition forwarded to the pension office - the consideration mentioned & agreed upon was three hundred dollars as will also appear by said depositions, I paid my father the full & just value of the premises purchased. There was no written contract as to my taber

[emblem of State of New Jersey on left] District of New Jersey, Morris County, } SS. On this Eleventh day of July, 1820, personally appeared in open Court, before the Judges of the Inferior Court of Common Pleas, holden at Morris-Town, in and for the County of Morris, in the term of July, in the year aforesaid. [The said court being a court of record, possessing a seal, proceeding according to the course of the common law, having a jurisdiction unlimited in point of amount, keeping records of its proceedings, and its Judgments being removeable by writ of error only] Ezra Brown aged sixty eight years, resident in the township of Morris in said county, who being sworn according to law doth on his oath declare, that he served in thte first Jersey Regiment first commanded by Lord Sterling afterwards by Col Winds in Captain Joseph Morris Company; that made his original application and declaration for a pension on the 6th day of April 1818, that he has received a pension warrant which is numbered 4.499- And I do solemnly was that I was a resident citizen of the United States, on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled " An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary war," passed on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts, due to me; nor have I any income, other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. That I am sixty eight years old; my occupation is that of a laborer but by reason of a lame hand and the weakness of old age am not able to do half a days work in a day; that my family consists of my wife named Bethia aged 67 years afflicted with Rheumatism occasionally and not able to support herself: and of my grand daughter named Ann aged only 12 years not able to support herself but of some service to us in our advanced age- Ezra Brown Sworn to & declared the 11th day of July 1820 before Gab H Ford

Petition of Neighbourhood of Claimant Talladega County} We the undersigned State of Alabama} Petitioners whose names are hereunto set, do honestly and truly show that we are and have been acquainted with the Claimant for a pension, Isaac Brewer for several years and know him to be old and helpless in a good degree and poor and in need, that he lives on public land of the governments no do we believe him to be able to buy him a house or to have the comforts that old persons many times need. We believe him to have been an honest hard working simple sort of man, and is and has been a regular member of the Baptist Church in this vicinity and is reputed to have been a soldier in the Revolution, and other causes for the defense of our Country, which we have no reason to dispute; but believe and think it the general believe. We hope that the Department at Washington may find it in their power to make a favorable allowance to him in proportion to his services rendered in favor of our common country, all which we respectfully submit and as in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray - Given under our hands this 7th day of March 1851

State of Delaware New Castle County Before me Amos Sanders one of the Justices of the peace in and for the County afsd [aforementioned] Personally appeared Margaret Dannagh of the County and state afsd [aforementioned] widow aged sixty-four years, after having been solemnly sworn on the holy Evangelists of Almighty God, deposeth and saith that Richard Wild Lieutenant in Captain McKannens company in the Delaware Regiment was her stepfather, that she very well remembers that the said Richard Wild was wounded at the Battle of Germantown in the American Revolution and that he was brought home on a litter where he lay for a great while under the case of Doctors Steward and McDonnough- That he was in extreme pain and little hopes of his recovery for some months and he was so disabled by his wound that he could not do any thing for his support, or the support of his family. That he still languished under the pain of his wound till the time of his disease which she believes was occasioned by the ball remaining in his thigh and lodging against the bone which brought on the locked jaw which terminated his death which took place she believes about the year 1786 - but deponent is not certain as to the dates. Deponent further states that her mother had several children by Richard Wild and that they are all dead without leaving any issue Except Elizabeth Robinson wife of James Robinson Esqr, and residing in the Village of Newark in the State of Delaware and that she is the only heir at law of the said Richard Wild deponent further states that she fully believes that Lieutenant Wild during his lifetime nor his family since his disease did ever receive any pension either from the United States or from the State of Delaware or she would have known it, and further deponent saith not Sworn and subscribed the 26th day of September AD 1833 Before Arno Sanders [underlined] Margaret Dannagh

State of Delaware, to wit Be it Remembered that on this Twenty first day of December in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and thirty two Before me Thomas McDonell Notary &c Public of the State of Delaware duly qualified and legally authorised residing at the city of Wilmington, personally appeared by Peter Jaquett to me the said notary well known, who being sworn in due form of Law doth depose and say that he was personally well acquainted with Richard Wild, an officer of the Revolutionary army. that in the year of 1776 he was a Lieutenant of the Flying camp Regiment of Delaware commanded by Col Samuel Patterson, at the close of the campaign he was appointed a Lieutenant in the Delaware Regiment in this or [?] company, in that capacity he remained and on the fourth day of October 1777. in the Battle of Germantown, on that day received severe wounds in his privates and thigh of such a nature as compelled him to decline the performance of active service, but continued as an officer until the fall of 1778, when from this the increasing suffering from the wounds received he being unable to perform the duties required, and at The earnest solicitation of his Brother officers to make room for promotion, he resigned his Commission.

Talladega Alabama 26 April 1853 Gen Jno M McCalla Washington D C Deer Sir We are again brought to a halt in our Pension case. Mrs Barnes cannot furnish the leaves of the Family Bible containing the record of her childrens Births The family Bible was burned up with their house several years ago. The ages of several of her children however are set down in their own Bible as copied from the original From them, as copies of the original record she gave her testimony - You will observe that Mrs Barnes uses her mark, she can neither read nor write and to require her to produce and swear to a record would seem to us a hard task. Indeed we think the Department voices a marvellous strictness in dispensing justice to the helpless widow of an old soldier. In any Court of Justice of which we know anything the oath of a parent would be sufficient to show the age of a child and that is all the records sought for in this case, would proves if furnished

Another fact which we think ought to have some influence in this case. This family record is not the property of a party but of a witness and this witness in no sort interested. We have no hesitation in saying that if this record were now in existence Mrs Barnes would not suffer it to be mutilated for any such purpose - Our client would clearly have no right to it, and it would be a strange requisition of a witness to be required to furnish evidence to discredit himself. The fact sought to be proved can only be used as a collateral to establish the correctness of the witness statement of an independent fact, and tends in no way whatever to prove when Mrs Liner was married. In addition if Mrs Barnes has sworn falsely it would add but little to her criminality to forge sustaining proof and she could easily procure an old Bible in which to make her entries. We have forgotten the precise times used in Mrs B.s affidavit in reference to what she got from the family record, but if she was there made to say that she had the original Record kept by her husband before her at the time it was wrong - the dates were copied from her sons Bible which was furnished to refresh her recollection and confirm it, and that is the only record in existence on the subject as far as we know - If an affidavit of the destruction

Declaration In order to obtain the quantity of Land due to Elizabeth Borst as the widow of Martines Borst under the act of March 3, 1855. State of New York ) Schoharie County ) On this Nineteenth day of March A.D. One Thousand Eight hundred and fifty-five, personally appeared before me Henry W. Herron a Justice of the Peace, in and for the County and State aforesaid, Elisabeth Borst, a resident of the town of Middleburgh in said County of Schoharie and State of New York, who being duly sworn according to law declares that she is the widow of Martines Borst, deceased, who was a soldier of the United States in the War of the American Revolution and at the time of his death a Revolutionary Pensioner of the United States in consideration of the services by him rendered and performed in the said War of the Revolution. Declarant owing to old age and consequent loss of memory is not now able to describe the services of her husband, the said Martines Borst in said War, but believes that he served with the Militia of said Schoharie at different times and on many occasions during the said War. She further declares that she was married to her husband the said Martines Borst in said Schoharie County, on or about the twenty-fifth day of November in the year seventeen hundred and eighty-seven by a Lutheran Minister of the Gospel ... Schoharie, and that her name before said marriage was Elizabeth Lamb.

it as to bring myself within the provision of an act of congress entitled an act to provide four certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary war passed on the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities the contracts or debts due to me nor have I any income other than what is contained in this schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed & I further swere that my family consists of my self aged as aforesaid and I am a Mill right by trade but I have by reason of a blindness been enable to do labor of any kind for several years and unable to provide for my self my wife named Betsey in her seventieth year. She is infirmed and unable to support herself my youngest son named Amzi aged 23 years heathy? and strong and he has been my only support for some but I have no securities of his saying with me for he is his own and has only continued with me through a sense of gratitude and my entire helpless Moses Spenser [signature] A schedule of my property at this time beds & necessary clothing excepted to wit one mare one horse

he was at the battle at Mill Stone & belonged to the Regiment that crossed the stream, first breaking the ice & then wading the stream, he was one that assisted in taking from the British at this time upwards of seventy loaded wagons, and a large number of horses, horn cattle [illegible] that he was out at this tour from November 1776 to March 1777 making five months in the militia as a private that he was out under Taft Henry Gulick --at the skirmish at Springfield when the meeting house was burned & the ministers wife was killed, at this time the company or regiment took two [illegible] who were tried found guilty and executed at Springfield--That he was out at various times under Capt Henry Gulick, serving in the militia at various places, and that in all he served more than two years as a soldier in the defense of his country in the war of the revolution That he has very little hope of finding a living with [illegible ink smudge]who was out & served with him, that he has heard of the death of many of them, and fears they all be all dead and gone I'm making the application for a pension he does hereby relinquish all and every other claims for pay for revolutionary services, and he declares that he is not a pensioner He further declares that the cause of the delay in making his application, has not been from any fear or apprehension that he was not fully and richly [illegible] to a pension, but he can further say that since the passage of the act under which he now applies, he has always & at all times been fully of opinion that he was most honestly and most honorable entitled to a pension But the delay of making an application for a pension has been in consequence of his not having been placed in needy circumstances, and from his having had a good and comfortable living without it this cause and this cause alone, has been in the way, & prevented an earlier application, having heretofore considered it rather a delicate subject to ask for a pension, but laying aside this delicacy, he now makes his application & asks that his claims be not prejudiced from his past

probably impossible, but we think the [illegible] circumstances. The old Bible the Family Record, with the birth and birth place of both parties, his marriage with the applicant, his age and death, and lastly the different certificates of the Conn State Comptroller, are so corroborative as to leave no reasonable doubt that this widow is the real widow of Theodore Gridley, deceased, who lived in Farmington, Conn and served in the Revolution. Please see the Family Record &c. This widow is old and needy, and it is hopeful your Hon will make a personal examination of the case. Since writing the above I am apprised that William Ely is knowing to the fact of this widows husband's having lived in Farmington, Conn, and his proper affidavit is herewith enclosed. As you can determination of this matter is very important to this widow. I in confidence trust you will give a careful examination to the case in person. Very Respectfully L. F. Bingham

1846 Wilson Niagara County Sept 4th Arad Joy Esq I see the letters you sent Mr. Oliver he says he read the one concerning his own business I have Seen Mr. Spencer and his wife they cannot tell her Leonard Kingsbury post office address or certain Town where he lives this Unis Spencer says he is over 53 years old has no record of her age or marriage she has not been in this Town but a few years she has lived in Clarkson Orleans County when her father and mother lived there I have seen her by Curtis Smith he lives about a mile from me he says there is no person living that was present at the marriage of his father and mother I think he is older than Unis but dont know if he is her age can be proved by him it is possible that Selden can find where Kingsbury Lives by your writing to him Mary Spencer days when she let him have the bible it was very much broken and thinks it must have been used up long since the remembers will that it contained a record of the age of her parents their marriage and the births of all the Children Mary Spencer is willing to do all she can for her mother but she is infirm herself and lives some five miles from me and it is attended with some inconveniencess to me to go and make the enquiries still if I can render service to the needy I am willing Zebulon Cates Lives about a mile from me I will go and see him and get all the information from him I can and write you in ten Days Norman Shepard

Rensselaer ss. Ebenezer Birch named in the annexed papers, being duly sworn doth depose and say, that he did make application to subscribed on the pension list, in the month of April 1819. and the application has been continued ever since, that the papers of this deponent on such application, were returned to Judge Vandersee at Greenburk on the 11th day of March 1819 who has since left the County, This deponent has had several to do his business, but until the communication recently received from the war department, by the Clerk of the County of Rensselaer, he has not understood absolutely what was wanted or why his name was not inscribed in said pension List, And this deponent further faith that the amount of property contained in his Schedule annexed to his first application or that which he has had since any one time has not exceeded in value the sum of Forty dollars. The property contained in his first Schedule has all been expended for the support of this deponent and his wife does not now recollect what was contained in said first Schedule or Inventory, but from the fact of his being very poor at the time & finds it must have been property of very little value if any- Ebenezer[his X marks] Birch Sworn to this 17 day of February 1827 before me Archi Bull Commr. Rensselaer , John Stearns of the Town of Schodack being duly sworn doth depose and pay that he has been re-acquainted with the above named Ebenezer Birch for more than nine years last last & has lived as neighbor to him during that time, and from such acquaintance has no doubt but what the facts above stated are true- John Stearns Sworn to this 17 day of February 1827 before me. -Archi Bull Commr. Archibald Bull do hereby certify that I am acquainted with Ebenezer Birch & John Stearns above named & verily believe them credible men and John Stearns & Moses Bishop I believe to be credible & disinterested witnesses - February 17, 1827. Archi Bull, Commission

Peace State of New York elder County ⎬ I Certify that James Cox whose signature is affixed to the above [illegible] affidavits was as the time of taking the same respectfully one of the Justices of the Peace in for the County of Renselaer In Testimony whereof I have hereunto set my name & affixed the seal of said County first day of December 1826. Archibald Bull Clerk

State of Illinois Sangamon County Personally appeared this 2d day of Dec 1841 Before me Noah W. Matheny Clerk of the County Commission Court the subscriber John Watkins and made oath in due form of Law & states that he is personally acquainted with the within named Rebecca Thomas (whose maiden name was Rebeca Logsdan) and that he has been acquainted with her for more than forty years having lived Neighbor to her. That he was raised near her, children together was in the fort in Kentucky together when children that she was married in the Neighborhood he resided in to the said James Thomas and has never been married to any other person that said James Thomas was a Revolutionary Pensioner and died near his Residence in Menard County Ills on the 2d Nov 1833 and that the old family Record in the Bible of W. Thomas shows that James Thomas and Rebecca Thomas were married on the 8 day of April 1793. all of which facts I have no doubt are true. That she is now a widow of the said James Thomas and is poor and needy and has not intermarried since or before his death Sworn to and subscribed this 2d day of Decr. 1841 before me John Watkins N W Matheny Clerk C C City of Springfield Ill Decr 2. 1841 I certify that Rebecca Thomas appeared and made out the foregoing papers in my office and that John Watkins also signed the above and made the foregoing statements and is a person of credibility she Mrs. Thomas wishes the papers forwarded to me in Springfield Ills and that I shall act as her agent. Erastus Wright attending to office of D. Hay Pension Agent for Ills

but declarent recollects but few of the narrative details by his father. He mentioned Tankard's wharf he appears to have fought in a battle somewhere, (in Virginia in declarant believes) called the Long Bridge or Longs bridge. The said Lewis Lanier is stated to have been present when Norfolk or some other city of Virginia was burnt; he was present and saw Ferdyce or Fordyee or such names a British officer when he fell in battle. The said Lewis Lanier also referred to having been captured by the British, and confined for nine months as a prisoner on board the enemy's vessel. A short time previous to this imprisonment on the enemy's ship, his leg had been broken by a swivel shot, and suffered great pain during the first weeks of his imprisonment. He made frequent mention of being four miles below York Town at when Lord Cornwallis surrendered; he was stationed there to prevent the junction of a reinforcement of British Troops with the army of Cornwallis. He spoke of having been wounded in the arm, and which remained stiff until his death. He spoke of being pursued by the British, and of swiming James River, and of being fired upon by four British officer while croping that river. The said Lewis Lanier often spoke of Washington and LaFayette and Gen. Green and Col. Morgan, and he was personally acquainted with La Fayette, and intimately, with Gen George Wash

Hon. Nathan Burton then Chief Justice of the County Court in & for the said County of Bennington in which said Oath & application & statement accompanying the same the aforesaid enlistment & term of service above particularly stated & refered [sic] to were wholly omitted by mistake or misrecollection since which time I have been completely unable by reason of poverty infirmity & the want of assistance to make further application until the present time. The above is true according to my best knowledge & belief [Signed] Benjamin Lamb Sworn to & declared at Manchester in the County of Bennington & State of Vermont on the 13th day of August AD 1827 in open Court before Joel Pratt Clerk I Joel Pratt Clerk of Bennington County Court do hereby certify that the foregoing application & Oath hereto annexed are truly copied from the record of the said Court. MAnchester Vt Sept 13th AD 1827. Hind, Sir, Enclosed I transmit to your the Oath & application of Benjamin Lamb with a view to obtain a pension under the Laws of the United States . In addition to his advanced age he has become very infirm of late, and may have made some small mistakes in dates and other particulars but I presume, from his reputation for veracity, that it will be found to be substantially correct. I also enclose to you a former application which was rejected on the ground that the enlistment & service was not on the Continental Establishment, as will be perceived - The enlistment & service mentioned in this last application was by some mistake wholly omitted in the former application. [Illegible word and space] of the omission are unknown to me, as I am informed by Mr. Lamb, that he stated it to the Judge who took his oath in that case, I therefore presume it was either accidental, or supposed by the Judge to have been immaterial & wholly unnecessary, as the term of service therein stated would have been sufficient to have obtained his pension, if it had been in the line of the U.S. Since the first application above referred to, Mr. Lamb has been so reduced by poverty, & disabled by reason of duressitude (living a distance of near 20 miles from the places of holding the Courts in this County) that he has been utterly unable to renew his application, except thro' the intervention of friends, & which he has not been able to obtain for the reasons before stated until now - Whatever communications may be made in consequence of this application to or for him, I would thank you [last word inserted] Hind. Sir, to direct to me at this lalce, in his behalf - & I hope for his sake,

that the result may be favorable, & without any great delay, farther than necessary for the examination of the claim etc., as he is very needy, & cannot probably long enjoy the bounty of his God & Country - I am Hond. Sir, most respectfully your obedt & very humble servant Serinus Swift Hon. James Barbour Secy of War

[following is written; page 1 of 2 page doc] State of Maryland City of Baltimore To Wit on this Eighteenth day of October Eighteen hundred and forty five Personally appeared Elizabeth Pascall an old lady who is well known to me to be a lady of the strictest moral character and I would rely on any statement she would make for veracity and truth, and it is her general character in the neighbourhood where she lives And she makes Oath on the Holy Evangely of Almighty God that she is well acquainted with Frances Riley the lawfull widow of Bennet Riley and I knew the said Bennet Riley well and my reason for recollecting him well is that he had a split lip which was done by a sword in the war of the revolution and I have often listened to him and my uncle Solomon Harris speaking about their services during the Revolutionary War and was often entertained to hear them speak of the many hardships they had to encounter and I knew Frances Riley and Bennet Riley well and living

From the above referred to rules, I see it is requisite that the time of marriage must be established by the testimony of at least one respectable person, whose credibility must be certified by the officer administrating the oath. In this case, we have the affidavit of W. Requa, which complies with the requisitions in every particular, together with the evidence of Berthyah Requa and Gloade Requa and the Bible Record. I herewith enclose the Declaration of Mrs. Susannah Cronk, which I do not deem necessary, farther than it shows that she is now living, for when I sent for her to come into court. I did not know that she had before made a declaration, which I find was made and forwarded you some time in the year 1844 from Mercer Co., Pa where Garret Cronk died and from which place the widow followed her son here. I would beg leave to call your attention to the Joint Resolution of Congress of July 1st 1848 “relative to evidence in applications for Pensions,” and would State that Garret Cronk served during the revolutionary in Col. Lees Legion, Virginia Line and that he received a pension until his death of $8.22 1/2/100 per month, as you will see by referring to his pay certificate in your office. I would further state that the widow Cronk is very poor and needy and would respectfully request your immediate attention to her claim. (Illegible) very truly yours Wm. Wynkoop P.S. Direct to me at Bellevue, Jackson Co., Iowa

State of Missouri Boone County August the 29th day 1829 In addition to a former declaration made by Isham Senior before the Circuit Court for Boone County state afore said on the 22 day of June 1829 the said Isham Burks Sr personally appeared before John Slack a Justice of the Peace in and for the County and State aforesaid and after being first duly sworn saith that in the year of 1818 or 1819 that he left Burksville Cumberland County Kentucky State in the month of March in order to move to the Black Water with about 31 children and grandchildren that by the time they had reached Franklin County in West Tennesy [Tennessee] that he found that he had incured a Considerable Expence [expense] in traveling he concluded to stop for a season which he did and raised a crop and owing to the high price of grane [grain] and other necessaries that by the fall of the said year he had nearby expended all his money that him and his children moved into what was cald [called] Jacksons Purchase in the upper end of the state of Alabama and that when he left Tennessee that he had only seventeen dollars left of the money brought from Cumberland County and there he found that cane and meat and salt higher in price than in Tennessee and was compelled to contract a considerable debt in order to keep his family from suffering at length he sent his Eldest son Charles Burks to Kentucky to collect money from Thomas Emmerson who owed him $1000 [inserted] in two bonds of $500 each but he could not get one cent from him that the said Charles Burks bartered of one bond to Peter Simmerman for dry goods for $500 dollars and give 20 percentum on the goods above their selling price that the proceeds of the said goods went to pay his debts and support his children -that since that time 1818 he has lost by death and thieves eight good head of horses and mares and six good milk cows and after he lost his horses he sold his wagon and hind gear to John Burks [illegible] receive a and shortly after he was murdered and his estate not sufficient to pay his debts.

State of New York Jefferson County ⎬ ss. Personally appeared before the subscribed John Negus a resident of said County aged fifty two years the 22d of August (1845) Eighteen hundred and forty five who being first duly sworn according to law deposeth and saith, that he is a son of Lydia Negus whose application for a pension is hereby annexed, - on account of the Revolutionary services of her late husband John Negus, who was this deponents father, who was formerly a resident of the town of Dummerstown in the County of Windham in the State of Vermont, and whom this deponent has often heard speak of the privations - hardships and sufferings, he (the said John Negus) underwent while a Soldier in the Revolutionary War; that this deponent has always understood from his earliest recollections to the time of his fathers death from his said father John Negus. and since his death, from his mother Lydia Fergus above named, that his said father John Negus had done service for some two or three years in the war of the Revolution in the army of the United States,- from said County of Windham State of Vermont and that he was married to Lydia Howe (the maiden name of this deponent) in the year (1782) Seventeen hundred and Eighty six that he has always understood from his parents the above named John and Lydia Negus, that they were married in the said town of Dummerstown Windham Co. Vermont, by the Revd Mr Aaron Crosby a Presbyterian Clergyman of the aforesaid town, that this deponent has three brothers and sisters (if living) older then this deponent - own children to said John & Lydia Negus this parents of this deponent, and brothers & sisters of this deponent, that the eldest if living, is upwards of fifty Eight years of age, that the said Lydia Negus this deponent mother, widow of John Negus, has not intermaried since the death of the said John Negus this deponents father, but still remains his widow, that the said John Negus, died in the year 1810. John Negus Sworn and subscribed before me this 12 day of June 1844 Joseph Boyer Judge of Jeff County I certify that the above named affiant is a respectable person Joseph Boyer Judge of Jeff Co Court

State of New York Jefferson County ss. Personally appeared before the subscriber a Judge of the Court in and for said County, Abigail Brockett of said County aged 39 years and upwards who being first duly sworn according to law deposeth and saith that she is a daughter of Lydia Negus, whose declaration, for the purpose of obtaining a pension is hereto annexed, that the said John Negus for whose Revolutionary services she claims a pension, was this deponents father, that this deponent has always understood from her mother the said Lydia Negus that her said father John Negus, had been a soldier of the Revolutionary War, and that he had done service for some three or three years, in the army of the United States in the Revolutionary War That this deponent has had eleven brother and sisters older than this deponent all are brothers and sisters of this deponent and all are children of her said father and mother, the said Lydia and John Negus, and that the eldest of now living is upwards of fifty Eight years of age That she has often heard her mother speak of her marriage with John Negus, who had done service in the Revolutionary War, and tell of the privations & hardships he had underwent during the same, and that she has always heard her state where speaking of the subject, that she was married to said John Negus, about the year 1786, in the town of Dummerstown in the State of Vermont, that they were married by her Rev W Crosby a Clergyman of the Presbyterian Denomination, then a clergyman of that place That her mother the said Lydia Negus us has not intermarried since the death of an late husband John Negus who was this deponents father and who died about the year 1810 Abigail X Brock her mark Sworn and subscribed before not this 12th day of June 1846 - Joseph Boyer Judge of Jefferson County Court I certify that the above named affiant is a reputable person, & that for [illegible] is unable to write her name, Joseph Boyer Judge of Jeff Co. Courts
