State of Massachusetts, I Jesse Bennis a Citizen of the United States, now resident at Spencer in the County of Worcester in the State aforesaid, do on oath testify and declare, that in the War of the Revolution, on the 7th day of April AD 1777 I entered and was engaged in the Land service of the United States on the continental establishment, and served accordingly from that time to the 7th day of April AD 1780 as a private & Sergeant against the common enemy, without any interruption or absence; that I belonged to the Company of Infantry, Commanded by Capt Abel Holder in the 6th Massachusetts Regiment commanded by Col Thomas Nixon and that I left the service on said 7th day of April 1780 and that, [crossed out: by reason of my reduced circumstances in life and poverty] I stand in need of assistance from my country for support, being now of the age of Sixty Six years And I hereby relinquish all claims to every pension heretofore allowed me by the laws of the United States, if any may be or hath been so allowed. Jesse Bemis BE IT REMEMBERED, That on this 24th day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and Eighteen pursuant to a law of the United States, entitled, ""An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War," made and passed on the 18th of March, A. D. 1818, personally appeareth before me, Edward Bangs Esquire, for associate Justice of the Circuit Court of Common Pleas for that Circuit the abovenamed Jesse Bemis and after due examination and caution to testify and declare the whole truth, he maketh oath to the declaration aforesaid, and subscribes the same in my presence; and, on examination duly made by me the said Judge, it appeareth to my satisfaction that the said declaration is true. Given under my Hand and the Seal of said Court, the day of the date aforesaid. Edwd Bangs

Pennsylvania Greene County}SS One this 17th day of December 1821, personally appeared in open Court, in the Court of Common Pleas for the County of Greene in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania and being a Court of Record proceeding according to the Court of the Common Law) James McCann of said County aged (underlined of to age) about sixty three years and being duly sworn according to law, on his solemn oath declares that he served in the Revolutionary war as follows; in the company of Captain John Morrow in the second Regiment of Pennsylvania Rifleman commanded by Colonel Miles at first, next, after he was taken at Long Island, by Colonel Daniel Brohead and then by Colonel Bull and by Colonel Walter Stewart- the company was organized at John Garbus on the Susquehanna River. This despondent was enlisted on Easter Sunday in the year, one thousand seven hundred and seventy six, as is explained in his original application certified by David Gray Esquire, dated the 16th day of March 1819. That he marched to Marcus Hook on the Delacroix River where he joined the Regiment, marched thence to meet the enemy at Lewistown on the Delaware bay, returned to Philadelphia where he, with the Regiment lay during the winter marched thence to [illegible] at the mouth of [illegible] River, thence to New York, thence to Fort Washington, then to Long Island and fought the enemy the next day, returned to Fort Washington. In this battle Colonel Miles and Lieutenant Colonel Piper, the next in command were both taken by the enemy Colonel Brohead succeeded till the Regiment came to Philadelphia then he marched to Brandywine Battle-that he was enlisted for one year and nine months and served the whole time of his enlistment aforesaid and was honorably discharged at Valley Forge by his old Captain Morrow or Murray who was then raised to be Colonel of the Regiment and was about taking the Command. I do so swear that I was a resident citizen of the United Sated on the day of March 1818 and that I have not since that time by gift, sale or in any way or manner disposed of my property or any part thereof with intent to diminish it so as to bring myself within the provision of an act of Congress entitles an act to provide for persons engaged in the land and navel service of the United States in the Revolutionary War, referred the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not nor has any person in trust

for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts due to me, nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule [illegible]a next and by me subscribed-I so who swear that to the best of my knowledge I am about sixty three years of age and very infirm-that my family consists of my wife who is, as nearly as I can ascertain business (crossed out) trade but [illegible], till unable to follow it , about seventy years of age-I was before and at the time of my enlistment, apprentice to the Tanning (crossed out word) trade but [illegible], till unable to follow it, been a day laborer. I also swear that I was a resident citizen of the United State on the 18th day of March 1818 and have not, since that time moved out of the same into that all the property, dates and claims to which I am entitled me contained in the schedule hereto annexed. This despondent further saith that he is in [illegible] circumstances and need the assistance of his country for his support and makes his declaration herein contained in order to obtain the benefit of the acts of Congress of 18th day of March 1818 and 1st of May 1820. Schedule of all the property and effects of James McCann Dol. Cents 1. two year old heifer worth 7.00 2. Half bed and some very poor [illegible] clothes for them 5.00 2. Weller one broken 5.00 1. axe worth.75 4. Small earthen pots and a cream pot .50 3. Home made knives and two forks .25 4. [illegible] and two to shoe knives.30 6. Tin cups given when my house was burnt .20 3.[illegible] fowl .20 appraised to 18.95 James McCann x his mark sworn to and subscribed in open Court the 17th December 1821. Attnt Wm T. Hays Prothy

Schedule of property, owned by James Anderson of Hartford, August 10th 1830. One rood of land , with a small dwelling house. thereon, one story high value 400 Two small looking glasses----1. Two old silver spoons -----1. 1 old brass kettle -------- 75 (cents) [total] $402.75 The small dwelling house barely affords a shelter for the family, and the little piece of land around it a little 1 acre and a few vegetables. And said Anderson under oath declares that his occupation has been that of a carpenter, or joiner, which trade he has followed until lately, when old age and bodily infirmity have compelled him to give up work, and that now he is only exercise a little, to preserve a tolerable degree of health, so far as the same can be enjoyed, at his time of life, but he is unable to labor, for the support of his family - that his family consists of his wife aged 72 years, who is greatly afflicted with the asthma, and can do nothing towards supporting the family, In addition to this, his daughter Abigail who married, Mr. Bull, has within this year been left by her husband at New Haven, who having become dissipated, abandoned his family consisting of his wife Abigail and three children, who have been brought home to her Father's James Anderson the present applicant, Abigail & her children are perfectly poor, & dependent upon James Anderson the applicant, & public charity for support. James Anderson

State of Tennessee } Carter County}} July Term 1845 On this 8th day of July 1845 personally appearing in open court John Nave [illegible] and upon his oath deposed and saith that he saw Rebecca Bowars married to Leonard Bowars, decreeing that their marriage rights were celebrated by Parson Kelly a minister of the Baptist order and that he is certain that the marriage took place at or near the time that she has set forth in her declaration toward the 2nd day of August AD 1785. the reason why she is so certain of the above mentioned fact is from [illegible] own age and the ages of said Rebeccas children which is herewith exhibited on a leaf taken out of Leonard Bowar's old bible in my hand writing done at the request of Leonard Bowars, deceased, commencing with Leonard Bowars age and then Rebecca Bowars age, then commence, William Bowars age, their oldest child who was born as [illegible] 22nd day of May 1787 and so following on with the several children, names as per record on the said leaf, deposed further saith that he has lived a [illegible] to Rebecca Bowars ever since her marriage and that he has never heard of the validity of her marriage called into question, and the reason why he is certain of her marriage previous to 1794 was his minority at the time of the marriage, deposed further saith that he has lived in this county some sixty odd years and that he is well acquainted with most or nearly all the old citizens of said county that lived cotemporary with said marriage and that he does not know an individual living in or near said neighborhood all of said old citizens that were at the time of said marriage have either removed or deceased as said deposed has taken a [illegible] survey to ascertain if any of the inhabitants of said neighborhood or county in 1785 were still living and further deposed said not. John Nave

State of Tennessee } Carter County } We the undersigned Citizens of the State and County aforesaid, having been calld upon at the [illegible] of Rebecca Bowers on our oaths do make the following statements which we are advised she intends using to establish her right to a pension. Which pension Declara- tancy, as exhibited by her, [illegible] date the 9th Nov 1844 I Abraham Nave, Seventy Six years of age & I John Nave, Seventy four years of age, deposeth & saeth, that we both well recollect to have seen Rebecca Bowers married to Leonard Bowers. And the reasons why we know they were married, it took place in our Fathers house on the same farm Leonard Bowers lived untill his death & where the widow Rebecca Bowers now lives. And I John Nave recollect that the rites of Ceremoney was administered in joining them together as man & wife by the Rev. Joshua Kelley a minister in the Babtist Church of the [illegible] order. And Deponents further saeth, that said marriage took place to the best of our recollection, in the year 1785. And certain that it was previous to the year Seventeen hundred & Ninety. And Deponents further declare that said Rebecca Bowers is yet a widow and has never intermarried since the

Winter. He lost the use of one of his eyes in consequence of his inhuman treatment while a prisoner. He was not exchanged untill a long time after the surrender of General Burgoyne and his army- that the said Charles Bison previous to his death obtained from the United States a pension; and from the State of Pennsylvania a gratuity for his military service in the Revolutionary war - She further declares that the was married to the said Charles Bison on the eighth day of March in the year seventeen hundred and seventy four at her father house in Gwynedd township now Montgomery County aforesaid (then Philadelphia County) by Philip Rapp a church minister in the presence of her father Evan Roberts and mother Mary Roberts and her brother Edward Roberts, Nicholas Selsor, Mary Selsor, Sarah Morgan, Sarah and Ann Ray, Enoch & Daniel Morgan, the said Philip Rapp the minister and all witnesses present at her marriage are now dead. In the year 1827 after the decease of her husband she applied for and obtained from the State of Pennsylvania a gratuity of forty Dollars a year on account of the military services rendered by her husband. - She then procured the affidavit of the said Edward Roberts to prove her marriage with the said Charles Bison which affidavit she expects is now on file at Harrisburg Penn. She knows of no record that was kept of her marriage. She had for many years marriage Certificate but it has been lost or destroyed long time since. The had nine children by the said Charles Bison six of whom are now living. And she further declares that her husband the aforesaid Charles Bison died on the twenty eighth day of March in the year one thousand eight hundred and twenty six and that she has remained a widow ever since that period as will more fully appear by reference to the proof hereto annexed Affirmed to and subscribed on the day due year above written Before me Jos. Royer Elizabeth [+] Bisson

We Moses Cheney residing in Lyme NH and David Pusher residing in Lyme hereby certify that we are well acquainted with John Bishop who has subscribed and sworn to the above d; that we believe him to be 72 years of age that he is reputed and believed in the neighborhood where he resides to have been a soldier of the Revolution and that we concur in that opinion. /s/Moses Cheney /s/David Pusher Sworn and subscribed the day & year aforesaid And the said Court do hereby declare their opinion after the investigation of the matter and after putting the interrogatories prescribed by the war department that the above named applicant was a Revolutionary Soldier and served as he states. And the Court certifies that it appears to them that Moses Cheney who has signed the preceding certificate is a Clergyman residing in said Lyme and that David Pusher who has also signed the same is a resident in the the Town of Lyme and are credible personas and their statement is entitled to credit. /s/Edward Webber Judge of Probate I Moses Dow clerk of the Court of Probate aforesaid do hereby certify that the foregoing contains the original proceedings of the said Court in the matter of the application of John Bishop for a pension [court seal affixed] In testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand & seal of office this twenty seventh day of August A.D. 1832 - /s/Moses Dow

Lectori Benevolo S Lutem I do certify that Peter Hamrickhouse of Germantown Philadelphia County bachelor and Mary Hadelman of same place spinster were lawfully joyned together in Holy Matrimony in the Year of our Lord One Thousand Seven Hundred and Seventy Seven. Given in Gertingfect Township, Philadelphia County. Witness my Hand and Seal, Michael ?, Minister of the Gospel

Peter Humrickhouse died February 13, 1837, at Hagerstown, Maryland. Peter Humrickhouse, bachelor, married February 20, 1777, Mary Hadelman or Stadelman, as shown by the certificate of marriage written by the minister or Mary Post as stated by her son, Frederick Humrickhouse. No explanation for this discrepancy in name is shown. The soldier was the, of Germantown Pennsylvania. Soldiers widow, Mary, was allowed pension on her application executed September 14, 1838, at which time she was aged 81 yeas and resided in Hagerstown, Maryland. She died October 17, 1839. She and her husband were buried in the German Reformed Burying Ground in Hagerstown, Maryland. The following names of the the children are shown: George Humrickhouse born November 21, 1777, died July 12, 1782. John Humrickhouse born August 29, 1779, died October 25, 1814 in Lexington, KY. Margaret Humrickhouse born September 5, 1781, Married Dr. Arnold Hannenkemph and died February 14, 1827 and was buried in the German Reformed Burying Ground in Hagerstown, Maryland. Peter Humrickhouse born August 26, 1783 Maria B. Humrickhouse born June29, 1795, died June 12, 1826, buried in the German Reformed Burying Ground, Hagerstown, Maryland. Albert Humrickhouse, born May 5, 1787. Jacob Humrickhouse, born August 12, 1788. Christian Frederick Humrickhouse, born July 6, 1791. Augustus Humrickhouse, born February 19, 1793. William Humrickhouse, born January 29, 1795. Charles Humrickhouse, born --ember 19, 1796. [blurred] Elizabeth Humrickhouse, born September 2, 1798. Samuel Humrickhouse, born June 5, 1801. The following appears also: Frederick Augustus, son of Arnold and Margaret Hannenkemph, born June 29, 1811. Louisa Erwin, born January 1, 1796. Only two children survived their mother, namely Frederick and Albert Humrickhouse. Both were living in 1850, Frederick in Hagerstown. -3-

We Richard Andrus a minister of the Gospel resident in the town of Erin in the County of Tioga, and Nathaniel Scofield a resident of the same Town do herby certify that we are well acquainted with Richard Ferris, the above named declarant: that we believe him to be of the age he represents; that he is reported & believed in the neighborhood where he resides to have been a Soldier of the Revolution & that we concur in that opinion: Sworn & Subscribed the day and & year aforesaid Green M Tuthill [?] [signed] Richard Andrus Nathaniel Scofield And the said Court do hereby declare their opinion, after the investigation of the matter, and after putting the interrogations required by the War Department, that the above named Richard Ferris was a Revolutionary Soldier & served as he states. And the said Courth further certified that the above named Joshua Ferris and John Jones Esquires who have sworn to the foregoing affidavits before the Court are residents of the Town of Spencer in said County, & are respectable & worthy citizens and entitled to full faith & credit - That Revd Richard Andrus who has signed the preceding certificate is a clergyman of good standing & resident in the Town of Erin in the said County & Nathaniel Scofield Esq who has also signed the same is a resident of the Town of Spencer in said County, and is a credible person, and that their statement is entitled to full faith & credit - [signed] J.B. Bacon [?] Judge I Green M Tuthill clerk of the said Couth of Common Pleas do hereby [?] certify that the foregoing contains the [?] proceedings of the said Court in the matter of the application of Richard Ferris

and placed in the hold of the British prison ship "Old Jersey" where he was held for twelve months, "wanting one day"',suffering many hardships, and was then paroled. In 1786, he moved from Maryland to North Carolina, and resied in Caswell County, and Orange County, that state until 1821, when he moved to Smith County, Tennessee, and resided untill 1826, then moved to Carroll County, Tennessee. Samuel Everett was allowed pension on his application executed December 10, 1832, while residing in Carroll County, Tennessee There are no data as to soldier's family. In order to obtain the date of last payment of pension, the name and address of person paid and possibly the date of death of the Revolutionary War pensioner, Samuel Everett (S.2543), you should address The Comptroller General, General Accounting Office, Records Division, this city, and cite the following data: Samuel Everett, Certificate No. 7583, issued May 3, 1833, rate $20 per annum, commenced March 4, 1831, Act of June 7, 1832, West Tennessee Agency. Very truly yours A. D. HILLER Executive Assistant to the Administrator.

State of New York, Orange County Ss. Personally appeared before me, John Sly a Justice of the Peace in and for the County of Orange and State aforesaid, George Pitts, a resident of the Town of Warwick in said County and State, aged Sixty nine years past, who being duly sworn deposes and says; That he is a brother of Elisabeth [Elizabeth] Pope, who subscribed the foregoing Declatation; and that he was also acquainted with John Pope, the late husband of the said Elisabeth Pope, and knows of his visits to the said Elisabeth, previous to their Marriage. And also, that at the time of their Marriage, they went from Newfoundland in the State of New Jersey, to Percipany in Said State, because there was no Clergyman in Newfoundland authorized to marry. This Deponent well remembers the Person who took them to Percipany; his name was Abraham Strait. And further that they returned to this deponent’s father’s house, and had an [illegible] there. And this deponent further saith, that they lived together as husband & wife, & reared a family of Children, and that they were always reputed to be husband & wife by the whole vicinity. That this deponent was about Eleven years of age, at the time of their marriage; and

Say that the Said Richard Smith was for many years before his death attached to a Corp of Revolutionary Vetrans[Veterans] Composed at the time of his joining the Said Corp wholly of of such as had served in the revolutionary war. Deponent further says that he has examined the records of the Reformed Dutch church at Fish-kill, Hackensack and Poughkipsie in Dutchess County. The several places where the said Records of the said Reformed Dutch Church were kept. and where the Reverend Mr. Risedyks the pastor of the said church alternately preached at the time of the said marriage as set forth in this said declaration aforesaid and that no record of the marriage of the said Richard Smith to Susannah TerBoss the present widow of the said Richard Smith could be found therein Deponent further says that he has seen the deposition of Francis Purdy of the town of Fish-kill in Dutchess County taken before Joseph Cromwell a Justice of the Peace on the 3d day of October 1838. and that the Susan Smith therein named and the Susannah Ter Boss on the Family record herein before mentioned is the same person and that she hath not again been Married but is now the widow of the said Richard Smith deceased Deponent further says that the age of the said Richard Smith as the same appears on on the family records was always considered by the said Richard Smith and family as a mistake as deponent believes. and that he was of the age of seventy seven years when he died Henry Smith. The above named Henry Smith was on this 29th day of October

State of New York County of St Lawrence}ss On this fifth day of March in the Year of Our Lord One Thousand Eight hundred and thirty nine personally appeared before the Undersigned David C Judson Esquire a Judge of the County Courts in and for said County of S Lawrence Lois Abel late a resident of the Town of Bastard in the Province of Upper Canada aged seventy three years and who is to me satisfactorily proven to be unable by reason of bodily infirmity to attend the Courts in said County to make this Declaration therein who being first duly sworn according to Law doth on her oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the provision made by the Act of Congress passed July 7. 1838 entitled An Act granting half pay and pensions to certain widows" That she is the widow of William Abel of the State of Connecticut who was a private in the war of the Revolution and a pensioner of the United States under the act of June 7th 1832 and whose pension certificate is hereunto attached and to the proof of whose service on file in the War Department the applicant respectfully begs leave to refer to establish the service of the said William Abel She further declares that she was married to the said William Abel on the fifteenth day of April in the year of our Lord One Thousand seven hundred and Eighty six at New Canaan in the State of New York by Samuel Camp a Presbyterian minister the said William Abel and the said Lois being at the time residents the said William of the Town of Washington and the said Lois of the Town of Pittsfield in the State of Massachusetts and that her husband aforesaid died at the Town of Kitley in the said Province of Upper Canada on the seventeenth day of

Pittsford Vermont February 6th 1850 I certify that I hold the office of Clerk of the first congregational church in this Town, over which the late Rev. Elander Harwood was the past settled minister and that I have carefully examined the records of said church now in my possession, and have not been able to find therein recorded the marriage of Stephen Avery & Mary Walker. And I further certify that there is not to my knowledge any marriages Recorded in the records of this Church. The word “society” erased & the word "Church ?” before signing. Asa Nourse State of Vermont Rutland County ss Be it known that on this 6th day of February 1850 before me the ember a Justice of the peace in & for said County personally appeared Asa Nourse who hath subscribed the above certificate & made solemn oath that the same contains the truth & nothing but the truth and I do certify that the said Nourse is a credible witness, and is Clerk of the Church as above stated Tho. State of Vermont District of Chittenden fs On this fourth day of August A.D. 1838, personally appeared before the Probate Court for the District of Chittenden and State of Vermont, Elizabeth Durand, a resident of Charlotte in the County of Chitten-den and State of Vermont, aged sixty nine years and ten months who being first duly sworn according to law, doth, on her oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the provision made by act of Congress passed in the month of July 1838. That she is the widow of Alexander Durand, late of Charlotte aforesaid, deceased who was a private in Capt Betts Company - Col Webb's regiment, Connecticut him in the continental army - in the service of the United States during the war of the revolution; that he enlisted as she believes for the term of three years - and was discharged at the close of the war - but the precise period of his services - or the year when he enlisted she is not able to state, but for a full statement of his services she respectfully refers to the muster rolls of Webbs regi-ment, and to such other documentary evidence in relation thereto as still remains in the War Department that he was a pensioner of the United States, inscribed upon the roll of the Vermont Agency under the Act of the 18th. of March 1818. and also refers to his original declaration for a pension and the proofs accompanying the same, still supposed to remain in the pension office She further declares that she was married to the said Alexander Durand on the 23rd day of April in the year one thousand seven hundred and eighty seven, at Canaan (now called New Canaan) in the state of Connecticut, by the Rev M. Mitchell, then pastor of the church in Canaan, that her husband, the aforesaid Alexander Durand died

State of Ohio Clinton County ss. On this 12th day of July 1842 Personally appeared before me the undersigned President Judge of the Court of Common Pleas held within the 7th Judicial Circuit of said State (& which includes said County of Clinton) Stephen M. Irvin who was at the last April term of said Court for Clinton County duly appointed a Committee for and on behalf of Mrs Elizabeth Irvin widow of Andrew Irvin deceased, an applicant for a Pension from the United States for services rendered by her deceased husband during the Revolutionary War & who being by me first duly sworn in due form of law [illegible] as such Committee and on behalf of said applicant State that he is the son of said Andrew and Elizabeth Irvin and now aged sixty one years: That from his earliest recollection - They lived together as man and wife until the death of said Andrew in the year 1830 that he understood from them both that they were married by a man named Brander a minister of the regular Church of England in Bedford County Virginia in the year 1773 or 1774 & by that marriage had the several children named in his deposition with their respective ages thereto annexed & now on file in the War department & which deposition is referred to and made a part hereof. That he has always understood from his deceased father from his earliest recollection that he had served as a private and as an officer during the Revolutionary War in the American Army. That he had served in Company with Richard Bane as stated in his deposition & spoke particularly of his Bane’s having made him a suit of cloths, but the length of time he cannot recollect to have heard him say. He often heard him mention the names of Col. Henry, Col Christy & Captain Wm Campbell being among the officers under whom he served during this tour (belonging to Captain Campbells Company & at one time attached to the Regiment of Henry & then to that of Col Christy but how or for what reason was never detailed by deceased to this deponent. He has also heard the deceased in like manner state that he started on the tour from Bedford County to Hillsborough as a Lieutenant in Command of the Company then dispatched from that County & that it was when this deponent was three days old & must have been the 6th of October

Mr. E D Griffin, a clergyman residing in the town of Williamstown in the County of Berkshire and James H Meacham residing in Williamstown aforesaid hereby certify that we are well acquainted with Asahel Hurlbut who is making application for a pension. That we believe him to be seventy six years of age, that he is reputed & believed in the neighborhood where he resides, to have been a soldier of the Revolution & that we concur in that opinion. James H Meacham State of Massachusetts Berkshire for May 2, 1835. E D Griffin I Daniel N Dewey a Justice of the Peace with & for the County aforesaid do certify that the above named persons personally appeared before me & made oath in one form of law to the foregoing,. That I am well acquainted with the said Griffin & Meacham that they are persons of good reputation for truth & veracity. Daniel N Dewey Justice of Peace Commonwealth of Massachusetts. Berkshire, ss. I Henry W. Bishop, REgister of the Court of Probate in and for said County, do hereby certify that Daniel N Dewey Esquire, before whom the annexed deposition was taken is one of the Justices of the Peace within and for said County, duly and regularly appointed, and that I am well acquainted with his hand writing, and have no doubt that the Signature annexed to said deposition is genuine. In Testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand and affixed the seal of the Court this fifth day of May A. D. 1835. Henry W Bishop Register Probate

and had social parties I herd much talk about Thomas Forbes in these parties but do not recollect of ever seeing him at our house The men that came to the Saturday evening parties were neighbours that lived within a few miles say two or three miles from our house some nearby There were many of our neighbours who had been out in the Revolutionary Army I many nights sat listening to the soldiers [inserted next word] telling of the Revolution telling of their hardships privations and suffering at different times and places I often went to sleep listening to them when I was a child My mother died in Pittsburgh about twenty six years ago She was in her eighty ninth year when she died. do not know my Fathers age when he died but know that my Father was considerably older than my Mother

information from deponents that is not sworn to as I did not deem it proper to make long documents This is a case you as well as myself [next 3 words underlined] will feel bound to lend your influence without charge This worthy old Lady with the past four Score and ten winters on her head has a strong claim to consideration of her old acquaintances who can [next 3 words underlined] conveniently and properly without expense render her [next word underlined] essential service by inducing the Department at Washington City to [next 3 words underlined] hasten proper act and administer Justice in the case [next word underlined] promptly without the imposition of Tax of Lawyer Fees I hope [next 3 words underlined] your prompt action in this case will make up for my awquardness and want of tecnical form Mrs. Forbes has [next 3 words underlined] very few Seniors Therefore should command prompt attention from her Juniors Your sincere friend James May This is a rough copy of a letter I addressed to my venerable friend Hon William Wilkins I went to Homewood to see him and submitted the papers to him He whist [whilst] suffering severe pain being then quite sick wrote a strong letter in favour of the Claim of Mrs Forbes siting forth his personal knowledge of Said Thomas or Said Sargent Thomas Forbes He said to me that he had no doubt of the Department awarding the claim He said he was aware of some Revolutionary widdows claims being awarded on [word underlined] less Testimony than I had submitted to him I thought the opinion of that old statesman good J. May

The undersigned, citizens of Upper Leacock and West Earl township, Lancaster County, Pennsylvania. Do hereby certify, that we are personally acquainted, with Anna Garber, Widow of Christian Garber, Deceased. who has made declaration, that she is of the age,as stated in her declaration, and that she is too infirm, to be taken to Lancaster, to have her declaration, taken in open court, and that she is a woman, of most extraordinary mind, and memory, for a woman of her age, and that her character, stands high in the neighborhood, where she lives for veracity, and that her statement, can well be relied on to be true. In testimony whereof, we have hereunto set our hands, this 17th of July 1854. Samuel Trumbauer Pastor of the Ev. Lutheran congregation in Upper Leacock Township L. County Penna. Christian Rupp Pastor of the German baptist congregation of West Earl township Lancaster County Pennsylvania

State of Virginia county of Monongalia} ss. On this 25th day of February, in the year 1833, personally appeared in open court, before the County court of Monongalia now sitting Caleb Furbee the same person named in the foregoing declaration, who being first duly sworn according to law doth on his oath make the following declaration in addition to his former one, That he was born on the 22d of November in the year 1752 in Kent county Deleware, on the Deleware bay within three miles of the serf- that the record of his age is recorded in fathers bible now in the possession of ^his brother Haitman[?] living in Tyler county Virginia- that he always lived in Kent county when ordered into the service of the United States, and removed from that county, into the county of Monongolia aforesaid, in the year 1796- that he recollects the names of the following regular officers in the Deleware state Col. Pope, Col. Hall, Col. Richardson- Genl. Wayne, Mercer, Smallwood- Major Vaughn- Capt. Kirkwood. John Rhodes, of Deleware regiment and many others whose names he has forgotten- that his company

and there joined Co. Richardson’s Regt of Regulars. From Christian Bridge the army marched to Brandywine. Remained there awhile after the Battle, then returned to the Buck on the Delaware. We remained there for a short time before we went in pursuit of Clancy’s army or rather [illegible] (this man Clancy was in [illegible] then under him were also tories) he had collected a good many men and built a fort. On getting near the fort and offering [illegible], he came out with his [illegible], a battle ensued. Clancy was defeated,. Many of his men were killed & Many later [illegible] - he himself escaped to the British Fleet but was subsequently taken and hung for by tory [illegible]. Col Pope commanded us in this engagement We then marched to Dover, remained there and in the vicinity until succeeding March. I was in service this tour at least ten months. All my subsequent service was in pursuit of Refugees. I was enlisted [illegible] ‘of[f] and on" for two years-- I cannot detail all the different tours performed, the tours were generally short and frequent- I am perfectly confident I did at least nine months service again[s]t the Refugees. I was Lieutenant in [illegible] service and was at the Battles of Masmelon [Mispillion] & Shirley’s Bar, in the latter was taken prisoner. Was a prisoner 15 days, procured my release by giving a barrel of Brandy and a barrel of flour. - I knew my services in part by Wightman Furbee. Thos P. Ray with my Declaration. I gave him the same [illegible] [illegible] again. In Witness whereof I have subscribed my name. Nov 10 1834 Caleb Furbee

Deponent further states that her mother had several children by Richard Wild and that they are all dead without leaving any issue except Elizabeth Robinson who is the wife of James Robinson Esq. residing in the Village of Newark in the State of Delaware and that the said Elizabeth Robinson is the only heir at law of the said Richard Wild of ponent further states she always understood that Lieutenant Wild resigned his commission knowing there was no hopes on account of his wound of his being able to render any further service and that he did not think our government was then able to make payment while he could render them no service and deponent says she is very positive that neither Lieutenant Wild during his lifetime nor his family since his decease ever received any pension either from the United States or the State of Delaware or she would have known it for she had often heard her mother say she never had anything allowed to her for all her trouble and expenses and that the expense of Doctors Bills was very great. And when she the mother of this deponent would persuade him to try and get something from government he would reply that the government of his Country poor and that he was well paid for all his sufferings as he had lived to see the British conquered and the Independence of his

DECLARATION, in order to secure the benefit of the Act of Congress, passed June 7, 1832. COMMONWEALTH OF MASSACHUSETTS. COUNTY OF Berkshire, ss. On this Sixth day of May in the year of our Lord, eighteen hundred and thirty four personally appeared in open Court, before Hon. William P. Walker Judge of the Court of Probate for County now sitting John Dawes a resident of Windsor in the County of Berkshire and Commonwealth of Massachusetts, aged seventy one years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress, passed June 7th 1832. THAT he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers and served as herein stated. I was born in the town of Bridgewater in the County of Plymouth on the fourth day of March 1763 have no record of my age but presume it may be found in the records of that town. I resided with my fathers family in Bridgewater until I was about thirteen years old when my father and family removed to Cummington in the County of Hampshire. I resided in Cummington until I was about twenty five years old when I removed to Windsor in the County of Berkshire and have resided there since. In the month of September 1779 according to my best recollection I volunteered as a private for the term of three months in a company commanded by Capt Clapp and Regiment commanded by Col Chapin. Marched from Cummington in the County of Hampshire to Great Barrington in the County of Berkshire was stationed there a short time and from thence marched by way of Claverack and Kinderhook to Albany in the State of New York and remained at Albany until I was discharged in the month of December. Again in the month of August 1780 I again volunteered as a private for the term of three months in a company commanded by Capt Sheldon and Regiment commanded by Col Murray marched from Cummington by way of Lenox in this State and Fishkill in the State of New York to West Point whilst at West Point was detached up the River about thirty miles to chop wood for the Garrison at West Point was with this party at the time of Arnolds treason returned to West Point and was discharged in the month of November both these terms of service were performed whilst I resided in Cummington. I have no documentary evidence and never received a written discharge. Amos Ford, Cyrus Latham & Opher Daws are persons to whom I am known in my present neighborhood and who can testify as to my character for veracity and their belief in my services as a soldier of the revolution. I further state that at a Court of Probate of said County holden on the twenty eighth day of August A D 1832 I made a declaration before said Court, which with the evidence in its support was transmitted to the War Department and which as I am informed by letter from Hon. George N. Briggs member of Congress was returned to Henry W. Bishop. Register of Probate-- that said Bishop has upon his docket of pension applications [illegible] that they were received & sent to [illegible] attorney, since which nothing has been heard from them & nothing can be found of them tho diligent inquiry has been made. [text missing] hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present, and declares that his name is not on [text missing] pension roll of the agency of any state. Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid. John Dawes W. P. Walker Judge of Probate

I Daniel Davidson of Gilford, Strafford County, State of New Hampshire, depose and say, that I enlisted as a private into the service of the United States in the Revolutionary War in the month of May 1775, in the Company commanded by Capt. William Bullard and the Regiment commanded by Colonel Frye, Massachusetts line, for the term of eight months, and was in the Battle at Bunker's hill (so called) and was severely wounded in said Battle by a Musket ball entering my left ear and passing out at my left eye leaving a fragment of the ball in the wound, said would considered great loss of blood pain and distress - And further testify that immediately after my being wounded the officirs [officers] of said Regiment had me conveyed home to Hampton Falls to the house of [text blocked here] Wife's father to receive Medical aid, and was [text blocked here] the Doctors hand or care about five months [text blocked here] by reason of the wound aforesaid which was the occasion [text blocked here] of my not returning to the Army again on the [text blocked here] above mentioned enlistment; and have always felt other effects of the wound, and more so since I have advanced in years being more of the age of seventy years and almost past labour - And further testify the reason of my not calling or making application before as on Invalid Pensioner, was that while I was able to labour and support myself and family thereby (being a Shoemaker by trade) was not willing to call upon Government for - support - And further that I am not on the pension list of any State of the Union - And that after my leaving Hampton Falls I moved and resided in -

circumstances: Mrs Anna Liner is the sister of deponent, and was married to Christopher Liner when she was Seventeen years of age, that the Said Anna was married in my house, by a Baptist Minister of the name of James Riley, that deponent gave birth to a child, named Lucrecy Anderson during the previous year that the Said Christopher and Anna Liner were married, that the birth day of Said child was put down in the family Bible and is according to Said family record the 1st day of May A.D 1798 Deponent further swears that one of her children, named John Anderson died during the year previous that the said Christopher and Anna Liner were married, that the death of Said child was recorded at the time in the family Bible, and is according to Said record the 1st day of September A.D 1798 These are the facts and circumstances at least the most reliable ones, that enable deponent to swear So certainly and positively to the time of the marriage of the Said Christopher and Anne Liner and further the deponent Saith not Margery ( her X mark ) Barnes Sworn to and subscribed before me by the said Margery Barnes, by making her mark; and I hereby certify that the Said Margery Barnes is a woman of respectability, and that I believe her entitled to full faith and credibility this 22nd day of March AD 1853 George Miers JP {Justice of the Peace}

State of South Carolina Beaufort District On this eighteenth day of January in the year of our Lord one thousand Eight hundred and fifty-one personally appeared before me Jos Danl Pope a Magistrate appointed to keep the peace and duly commissioned under the Great Seal of the State, Mrs Mary Baker of the Town of Beaufort in the District and State aforesaid who being first duly sworn according to law says that she is now seventy nine years of age; that from her earliest childhood she remembers Mr John McKee who was as she has many times heard a soldier of the Revolution; that she heard him frequently relate incidents of the several engagements in which he was, that he was the husband of Mrs. Margaret McKee with whom he lived for many years, and by whom he had a large family of Children, that she lived in their family for many years and has many opportunities of knowing their domestic circumstances. That John McKee died on or about the Eighth day of September A.D. One thousand Eight hun-[dred]

State of New York, County of Seneca I've Personally appeared before the subscriber a Justice of the peace in and for said County Rev Thomas Lounsbury of said county and as being duly sworn sworn according to law dponeth and saith that he is a minister of the Gospel of the Presbyterian order duly ordained, and that he has been settled in Ovid in the county of Seneca New York for the space of nineteen years part path, has had under his charge a respectable congregation - that he is and has been since his residence in Ovid acquainted with Nicholas Gulick of Seneca Co. who is applying for a pension that he is a member of his congregation and an attendant upon his preaching, that he is of highly good moral character and is much esteemed as a man of truth and strict integrity, that I consider him of the age of eighty four years and support him to have been a revolutionary soldier - that this deponent is also personally acquainted with Andrew Dunlap and Thomas Covert, the annexed evidence in the care of the said Nicholas Gulick, that they are both members of his congregation and regular attendants upon the public worship and are both men of good exemplary moral character, both men of strict truth uprightness and integrity and that he considers them either of them of the age of more than eighty years - That this deponent is personally and well acquainted with William Dunlap and Joseph Stull of Seneca Co. who have appeared as witnesses in the proof of the revolutionary services of Nicholas Gulick the applicant for a pension that the said William Dunlap is a member of this deponents church in good standing, and has always and at all times since this deponents

State of New York Seneca County SS I certify that the Rev Thomas Lounsbury who subscribed the foregoing deposition is a man of first standing, bearing a high christian character, that I am personally and intimately acquainted with him and have been so acquainted for the space of seventeen years, residing a near neighbor to him, that I have from beginning to and ever considered him a worthy Christian and a worthy and faithful minister of the Gospel, highly respected and esteemed by his neighbors, and respectable congregation, a man of truth and integrity fully to be believed, and that full credit is due to the foregoing deposition subscribed by him. Dated Nov 9th 1842 James Foster Justice of the Peace in and for Seneca County

State of Vermont District of Addison ss } On this 20th day of March in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and fifty six, before the Probate Court for the District of Addison in said State, personally appeared Molley Smith a resident of Bridport in said District and State aforesaid, aged sixty six years who first being duly sworn according to law, doth on her oath, make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefits of the provision made by the act of Congress, passed the 3d day of February A.D. 1853. granting pensions to widows of persons who served during the Revolutionary War; that she is the widow of Jacob Smith, who was a private in Captain Lee's Rangers and served as a substitute of Benjamin Andrews about four months, and who also served from six to eight months in the company commanded by Captain Sawyer in terms of one month each, without leaving the service; that he enlisted in January 1779. at Rutland Vermont where he then resided, under Capt Sawyer and belonged to the Regiment commanded by Col John Claghorn; and that he was in the service over one year, as I verily believe, She further declares that she was married to the said Jacob Smith, on the 7th day of May A.D. 1816 in said town of Bridport, by Henry Chamberlin a Minister of the Gospel and has lived with the said Jacob Smith

In matter of the application of Jacob Smith for a pension for Revolutionary Service } State of New York Essex County SS. } Elijah Bishop being duly sworn doth depose, and say, that he reside in the town of Elizabethtown said county. That he is Seventy years of age and upwards. That he knows Jacob Smith now residing in Bridport Addison County State of Vermont. That he also knew said Smith when he known said lived in Rutland said state some years since. That he has known said Smith since early in the Spring in the year of our Lord one thousand Seven hundred and Seventy nine. That at that time this deponent first became acquainted with said Smith - That this deponents acquaintance with said Smith commenced as above at Fort Ranger in the town of rutland in the now State of Vermont - That within two days from the time of first seeing said Smith, this deponent became a soldier in a company stationed in said Fort. That said company was commanded by Thomas Sawyer who was Captain - The Lieutenant of said company was Joseph Holmes - Ensign Jonathan Coburn. Said Sawyer was commander of said Fort - said Company belonged to a regiment - commanded by Col. John Claghorne. That this deponent was enlisted and served nine months. That directly after this deponent commenced said service the said Smith also acted as a soldier in the same company with this deponent. That said Smith to the certain knowledge of this deponent did Soldiers duty in said company as well and ably as any Soldier belonging to said company and as this deponent believes to the entire satisfaction of his commanding

Rensselaer County ss. Do it remembered that on the 28th day of March in the year of our Lord 1827. personally came before me Silas Thomas Esqr one of the Justices of the peace in and for said County of Moses Bishop of Stephentown in said County & being duly sworn deposes and faith that some time in the year 1776. I was an enlisted Soldier in Captain Luther Stoddards Company in Col. Burrell Regiment, and was in the service during a campaign to Quebec, and that about the time I enlisted. I became acquainted with Ebenezer Burch, who was also an enlisted Soldier in the same company and Regiment, and was with me during a campaign to the northward which campaign or term of service, was about one year, and that we were regularly discharged, and that we retired in company to Salsbury & Canaan in Connecticut on the respective place of above, and that I have been acquainted with the said Ebenezer up to this day, and know him to be the same identical Ebenezer Burch that I alluded to the above mentioned service-and further judgement. Sworn to this 28 day of March 1827 before me} Silas Thomas Justice of the Peace Rensselaer County ss I hereby certify that I am personally acquainted with the above named Moses Bishop that he is a man of good moral character and full faith and credit may be given to his testimony Silas Thomas Justice of Peace Stephentown March 28th 1827 State of New York Rensselaer County} ss. I certify that Silas Thomas whose signature is affixed to the above Testimony affidavit & certificate was at the time of taking them respect one of the Justices of the peace in & for the County of Rensselaer. In testimony any whereof I have hereunto set my name & affixed the seal of said County this 30th day of March 1827.

Lincolnton 24th December, 1823 Doct. Joel Abbott Dear Sir, I take the liberty of incloseing to you the application of John Crosson to be replaced on the pension list as a revolutionary soldier. I have selected you more particularly to address on the subject notwithstanding I should be very glad indeed if the representation of our state if they can use any influence to get Crossons pension that they should remember his case. You I remember to have pointed out Crosson too, during Court. You also know pretty well the quality of land in the neighborhood of the Court house, his land I am indeed to believe has been the Cause of his being stricken from the Roll of pensions the valuation first made was more than the land would over have sold for it is now scarcely worth being called a home. He is unable to work, and if the word of Col. Triplett of Wilkes County there was few better soldiers than Crosson independent of this he has not been an extravagant man in drink as has been the case with many of the soldiers of the revolution, he was always able to pay his way until about 5 years ago afflictions of body caused him to cease from labor himself his children left him and the failure of a crop he has never been able to get over he has been one of the most industrious men of the age. My being one of his Creditors will not I trust be considered a motive in writing in his praises, for if he never receives a Cent he will never be distressed through or by me, but my knowledge of so many that is now pensioned, some drunkards unfortunate speculators & others of much more property than he possesses is among the inducements I have & his being in actual distress. he never aspired after wealth, more than the labor of his hands all of which I trust will be sufficient inducements

Bellevue Jackson Co, Iowa, Dec 9th 1868 Hon. Shepard Leffler, Dear Sir, Enclosed, I send you the application of Mrs. Susannah Cronk for a pension, and wish you would be so good as to hand it to the Commissioner of Pensions in person, and as the widow is very poor and suffering for the want of the necessaries of life. I wish you would insist upon the immediate examination of her claim. By attending to the above, you will add one more, to the many favors already confined. Yours very truly, Wm. Wynkoop Ho Refs Jan 2/44 The commissioner of Pensions will please view this case ex anno as soon as possible as it seems to be one of great hardships. McEdwards Shep Leffler

Bellevue Jackson Co. Iowa December 9th, 1848 Mr. J. L. Edwards Commissioner of Pensions, Sir, Your favor by the hand of J. G. Berret of 16th Oct. 1848, in answer to my letter of 21st Feb. last came duly to hand a few days since. You say “that the claim of Susannah Cronk, widow of Garret Cronk, has not been allowed in consequence of the failure to produce satisfactory evidence of their marriage prior to 1794”. You also say “Record, or documentary evidence upon this point has been required to bring her claim within the provision of the act of 7th July 1838 and such evidence has not as yet been furnished”. Record evidence there is none, other than what may be gathered from the Bible record of the family of the deceased Garret Cronk, which only implies a marriage by giving the time of the birth of the children, which can only be used as corroborating evidence. At the time of their marriage, it was not customary to keep a record of marriage in the State of New York, and if done, it was only for the private interest of the minister or office performing such ceremony. In this case, the minister performing the ceremony (Oliver Sherwood) has been dead many years and his family have removed or died, as they are not to be found. I would refer you

Personally appeared before the subscriber a Justice of the Peace in and for said County Silas Prentiss of Williamson in said County, who being first duly sworn according to law deposeth and saith that he was sixty years of age on the 11th day of January 1844, that [words crossed out] he was well acquainted with John Negus, formerly of Dummerstown Vermont, and consequently become intimately acquainted with him at his earliest recollection, that he always understood and fully believed, from the statements of said John Negus that he had done service for several years in the Revolutionary War. that he has heard him repeatedly speak of his revolutionary services of the hardships privations and suffering he had endured, while performing such service, that he was known, in the vicinity where he lived, as a Revolutionary solder and that the said John Negus above named is the identical person, who was formerly the husband of Lydia Negus, now a resident Jefferson County New York who as his widow has applied for pension Silas Prentiss Sworn and subscribed before me this 4th day of November 1826 William Fuller Justice of the peace in said County I certify that the above named affiant is a respectable person, & that the words "well acquainted" interlined before executing William Fuller Justice of the peace in the said County

State of Connecticut Hartford County ss Hartford On this 6th day of August 1838 personally appeared before the Court of Probate for the District of Hartford aforesaid George Goodwin is a credible person well known to this court aged [illegible] years who being duly sworn according to law doth on oath declare that he is well acquainted with the late James Anderson formerly James Anderson 2nd of said town of Hartford and well knew of his being a pensioner as a soldier of the revolution. That he is well knowing to the first that the said James Anderson Jun was married to Abigail Goodwin at said Hartford in the forepart of the winter of 1787. Fifty one years next December they were married by the Rev. Nathan Strong then pastor of the first church of Hartford at the house of Mr. Samuel Goodman. And he is also well knowing to the fact that the aforesaid James Anderson died at said Hartford on the latter days of September 1836 and he is well knowing to the fact that the present widow Abigail Anderson is the surviving widow of the said James Anderson that she has never again intermarried but is still a widow. Geo. Goodwin Sworn a subscribed the day & year first named

New Prospect Bergen County New Jersey Enclosed I forward the application of Capt Jacob Bamper for a renewal of his pension. He has been rejected on the alledged account of having more property than the law allows. It is true he has a life estate in some mountain land as stated in the Schedule but unable to dispose of it he does not at present nor has he for many years received any thing for it as you will find certified by five of the Judges of the court all of whom are personally acquainted with the fact. He is a Neighbor of mine and an object of distress, wretchedness and disease, at present laboring under a confirmed Diabetis spent family fortune in the war of the Revolution and like many of the Patriots of that period possessing a high minded nobleness of soul and only lacking the virtue of economy He is now laboring under all the accumulated Miserys of age poverty and infirmity- --- In the whole number of those who have the Bounty of Gov't I feel confident none require it more and few who deserve it better, he was stricken from the pension list from a wrong statement of his income. The reason of my addressing you on this occasion arises from what I conceive a duty I owe to humanity and an honorable worthy unfortunate Man Most Respectfly Your very Humble Svt Charles Kinney The Honl James Barbour Secretary at War -

company all three of which in their term had the command of Catlins Company after he left it, and that Colonel Miegs commanded said Regt after the death of Colonel Deming circumstances that did not occur to me is here I made the application but which may be proved by searching the returns and papers of the 6th Connecticut Regt now in the Secretaries office. Sometime in 1822 I recd Mr Edwards letter to Mr Hubbard (herewith restored) marked No 2 in which to him he claims in some manner to [unk] the mistake if I understood him and out of which he might have been easily led had he looked at the returns of the 6th Connecticut Regt- Besides my evidence forwarded with my first application were deemed sufficient under the act of Congress of March 18, 1818, and why not under the subsequent act- Mr Edwards finds no fault with the evidence rejecting my indigent situation but says I do not prove my actual service, the act of 1820 does not require (as I understand) for the proof of actual service but of poverty which he admits is more useful in my second declaration or says that when my service is satisfactorily make out that then I shall be entered the fact is that I have not mistaken one fact but may not have been quite explanatery enough, Mr Edwards says that I d not prove that I am the identical person whom name appears on the muster roll, or that I am the same person who drew a pension under the act of 1818 or at least I take that to be his meaning pray how come I but that muster roll [unk] being an orderly sergt of that company how would I know the [unk] of the certificate in which was read by Dan Chapman under the act of 1818 unless it was granted to me. There are only 2 facts necessary in general required in order to entitle a person to a pension under either or both the aforesaid list, towit, did he actually service as required by Law, second is he actually read both of which I think I have made out. Now Deorder so the best you possibly can and as quick as you can as I am actually in distress or way near it, you shall be remuniated by yours respectfully. D Chapman Dec 1 1823

State of New York Steuben County On the 5th day of March 1846 before the subscriber a Justice of the Peace in and for the said County personally comes Gershom Bennett, and being by me duly sworn deposeth and says that he reside in the town of Bath County of Steuben & State of New York, and that he was born in Warwick, Orange Co. N. Y. in the year 1765. And this despondent further says that during the four last years of the Revolutionary War he was engaged as a soldier in the service of hismcountry the greater share of the time, that his first service was as a substitute for his brotherMitchell Bennett in the Militia under the Command of Genl John Hawthorn - Col. Henry Wisner - Captl David McCauley- also a part of the time under Col Wisonfelt & I think Major Dewit - Capt Westfall - Lieut John English, David Silsby or Silsberry as he was called was the first Sergeant. And further this Despondent says that his Brother Mitchell Bennett enlisted in the nine months service & was taken sick & that the fore part of May this deponent went and filled his brothers place as a substitute until some time in the month of September following & further that during the time he was serving as such substitute for his brother he answered at roll call to the name of Mitchell Bennett as he was told to do so by the officers in command - that my said brother Mitchell Bennett never received a pension from the United States & that many years since he moved to Onandaga NY and died there as this desponent thinks about the year 1809. And this desponent further says that as a "minute man" he was almost constantly employed for 3 years or more in hunting and pursuing Tories in this State and the State of New Jersey.

and was there stationed & built block houses while there and remained there to the end of the tour for which that were called which despondent is sure was as long as three months and thins longer - Capt. Hashies company of nine months men from Sussex County New Jersey were stationed there at same time, despondent was dismissed and went home. And inn a few days was ordered out and marched to Chambers Fort near the junction of the Neversink and Delaware Rivers in Capt. David McCauleys company and stayed there some time, thinks three months ws dismissed and went home - a few days after he ws again called out on an alarm(?) (?)(?) ten days under Capt McCauley - Col (?) regiment & Genl Hawthorns Brigade. Went home and was soon after drafted and sent again to Neversink and served out his tour the length of which he does not recollect but is was long enough to get his class certificate for 25 acres of land - at this time was attached to Capt John English's company - from this time up to the close of the Revolutionary War deposent was almost continually engaged in the services (excelpt in the heart of winter) on scouts. thinks he was in actual service as much as twenty seven months That in 1783 he moved to Northumberland, Pennsylvania lived there till 1790 or 91. Then moved Cheming Triqus County New York and remained there till 1803 or 1804 - then moved to the Town of Frederickstown now Lyons in Stueben County New York where he has continued to and still does reside. That he is well acquainted with Gentts William Abraham that and Silamus Arnold in his present neighborhood and with (?) Cooper in said County (illegible after)

Declaration In order to obtain the benefit of the acts of congress passed June 7th 1832 State of New York County of Steuben October 1832 Gershom Bennett appeared in open Court before the Judges of the Court of Common Pleas of said County of Stueben. Gershom Bennett as resident of the town of Tyrone in the County of Stueben aforesaid and State of New York aged Sixty Seven years who being first duly sworn according to Law doth on his oath make the following Declaration in order to obtain the benefits of the Act of Congress passed June 7th 1832. That he entered the services of the United States under the following named officers and served as herein stated. That he was born in the town of Mountainville, County of Orange and State of New York on the 20th day of November 1765 That he has no record of his age and knows his age from his parents told him. That when first called into service he was living at the said place of his birth. That when he first entered this service was when in his 14th year of age he took the place of his brother Mitchell Bennett who was hurt by a fall from waggon the wheels running over him. This was in the opening of the year 1777 as despondent thinks and the comapny was commanded by Capt. Westfall of Mountainville in Orange County aforesaid and by Lieutenant John English from the same place. Cannot recollect the names of his field officers but his Col (from?) Orange County. Marched on to the frontier where Neversink empties into the Delaware River. Was quartered at Chamber's Fort at the forks of the Neversink was out at this time nine months and lay at this place during the whole of said tour - was discharged when his times was out and went home - unmarried then till spring of 1781 early in April went as a substitute for one Grant Rickey of Sussex County New Jersey in Capt. Pattersons comapny & Lieutenant Benjamin Morse from (?) County. Can't remember the names of his Field Officers. We than marched to the Delaware River opposite Milford

State of New York Cayuga County Personally appeared before the subscriber a Justice of the Peace in and for said County Daniel Ferris of the County of Tioga aged fifty three years after being duly sworn according to law deposes and says that he is a son of Richard Ferris deceased and his wife Catharin who is making application for a pension as the widow of the said Richard Ferris for Revolutionary services performed by him that this despondent is the seventh child of his said father and mother and that his mother the said Catharine Ferris is still a widow Daniel Ferris Subscribed and sworn to January 15th 1849 before me Harvey Heath Justice Peace I certify that the above named Daniel Ferris is a respectable person Harvey Heath Justice Peace I hereby certify that Harvey Heath is a Justice of the Peace in and for the County of Cayuga in the State of New York, that he has been such Justice for several years [illegible] that I am acquainted with his hand writing & verily believe his signature as certain in the foregoing papers to be genuine [illegible] July 16, 1849 H.S. Conger

The despondent Sarah Bigelow questioned before me 1st Where was you her and in what year Ans In Norwich Connt in AD 1764 2nd Where did you first become acquainted with Stephen Avery & when Ans AD. 1764 at Rutland (?) 3rd When was you married to your first husband Ans A.D. 1782 4th Is there any circumstance which enable you to recollect any particular time when you heard your first husband say that the Stephen Avery was in a soldier in the war of the revolution if so relate it Ans Yes. About A.D. 1783 I saw a scar upon his stomach and asked him the cause of it. He told me that when he and his brother Steph in Avery was in the war they both were severly burned by the explosion of Gunpowder David Merriam Justice fee &

An Appeal from the first Congregational Church and Society in Malone, NY to all the patrons of good order, morality and religion. Dear Brethren- About twenty-two years since, a few families from New England and this state, opened a settlement in this extensive wilderness under circumstances peculiarly forbidding. With but few exceptions, they were literally poor, from 50 to 70 miles from any market, the roads few and intricate, and at particular seasons impassable. With these discouragements, however, the number of settlers increased to that degree, that in 1807, this church was organised by two missionaries of the cross, consisting of 25 members, who unanimously covenanted to maintain public worship every Lord's Day which they fulfilled. [paper torn] of the administration of the word and ordinances of the gospel, having no ordained minister nearer than fifty miles, __[paper torn] uneasy with their situation, and in 1809 presented a call to their present pastor, who was ordained the following season. [paper torn]__ made for his support, though very honorable to the people, considering their number and embarrassments, were very __[paper torn] exigences, and consequently both parties, in forming and perpetuating the pastoral union, have made sacrifices __[paper torn] cases. __[paper torn] war with all its desolating evils, threatened to devour us. The labors of the field and shop were necessarily __[paper torn]abandoned a families separated some of our best citizens. __[paper torn] country; the public mind continually in agitation from the alternate visits of our own and foreign armies, __ with speculators, thieves, &c. Under such a system of complicated evils, no community can be expected to __ of the world, or religion. the church and congregation, feeble before, was now more feeble; and such were __ of their pastor, arising from this source, that he was induced to ask a formal separation from his people. God, __ interposed; efforts were made for his relief, and he continued his labours. Having struggled with multiplied difficulties, and particularly the expenditures of the state ministry, this people have been unable to erect a house for the worship of God. for many years we have had the occupancy of either the Court House or Academy in this village, for public worship, which have afforded tolerable accommodations, though neither is sufficiently capacious to entertain all the congregation at all seasons. But our privilege in these places is now abridged. As they are public buildings, two other denominations of christians among us, claim the right of occupancy. And although their numbers respectively are small comparatively, yet we have no inclination to deny or retain their privileges and appearances indicate, that if we do not provide some other place for worship, we shall be under the painful necessity of meeting in different sections of the town, at private houses, or in a school room, where not more than one hundred bearers can be accommodated; whereas the usual number of worshippers is about three hundred. At this state of things the church and society have been deeply affected. For several weeks past a most desperate effort has been made to furnish monies for the erection of a church; and contrary to our expectations, the sum of several thousand dollars has been subscribed, to be paid in the produce of the country. A few hundred dollars more in cash will be necessary to purchase such articles as demand cash; and we are perfectly at a loss what course to pursue to obtain it, aside from that anticipated in this address. We are confident that we speak truth when we say, that we have already imposed as heavy a burden upon ourselves, as we are able to bear. To live any longer destitute of house of worship, would not only be trying to our feelings, but detrimental to the interests of truth in this region. To erect a house of small dimensions, would not answer the future wants of this people, as we have an unusual proportion of youth, and the tide of emigration from other places is rather increasing. To solicit alms of any people or individual is humiliating to our feelings; we had rather apply to our own resources, if they were not empty. But we know the object is momentous, and can never be contemptuously treated by any man who honors the tremendous name of him whose power is seen every where, and who, nevertheless, condescends to "dwell with men on the earth." We consider also, that notwithstanding the embarrassment of this people, we have annually contributed something for similar objects, and hope we shall have the ability and disposition to increase our charity in future. Our agent, Major Enos Wood, a member of this church and a man in whom we and all patrons may place the highest confidence, is authorised to receive any donation; which, however small, will be gratefully accepted, and sacredly appropriated to the object contemplated in the appeal. With sentiments of love and christian affection, we subscribe ourselves your obedient servants. Ashbel Parmelee, Pastor Building Committee Deacons Jonathan Stearns Jacob Wead John Barns David Sperry Samuel Peck Malone, April 14, 1825

THE MAILS. The Ithaca Journal complans of the late in regularity of the mails upon this route, and in timates that they are detained over the Sabbath wherever Saturday night overtakes them." Upon this subject the Journal is certainly misinformed . Except in a single instance, the not been detained on any part of this road. And it is only when going East, that the Mail which leaves Ithaca on Saturday morning remains in this place until the following Monday morning; an arrangement which we understand from the Contractors to be absolutely necessary to their having a regular day of starting from either end of the route. May 1820 I do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not since that time by gift, sale, nor in any manner disposed of any property on any part there. of with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress entitled an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and navel service of the United States in the Revolutionary War passed on the 18th of March 1818 and that I have not nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities on _____due to me nor have I any income other than what Is cert____ in the schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed. 1 Cow - - - - - - - $11.00 1 Calf - - - - - - - - 8.00 1 Sheep - - - - - - - 5.00 3 Lambs - - - - - - - 2.50 1 Hog - - - - - - - - 5.50 2 Pigs - - - - - - - - 3.50 1 Ton of Hay (damaged) - - -5.50 1 Axe - - - - - - - - 50 1 Chest - - - - - - - 50 1 Pine Table - - - - - - - 8 1 Old Chair - - - - - - - 8 $37.16 David Choate My occupation is that of a farm labourer, but owing to an infirmity under which I have been suffering for the space of about one year past. I am unable to earn any thing by my labour, nor do I ever expect again to enjoy such health and strength as to be able to support myself alone. And I have in family residing with me, my wife Meriam Choate aged sixty seven years who is past labour; and my two daughters Eunice, aged about thirty years, and

act of Congress entitled “an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War” passed on the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities contracts or debts due to me nor have I any income other than what is contained in the Schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed – to wit, ten head of hogs, one sow and six pigs, one cow and calf, two yearlands, one old mare, another mare and colt, two ovens and two plows. he owes twenty dollars, and has three dollars & fifty cents due to him, has a wife named Mary about forty five years old, has two children, a son about 18 years old, but deformed & helpless – a daughter, about 14 years old – he is farmer by profession, and so infirm that he is not able to work for a support. James Porter Sworn to and declared in open Court before the Justices of said Court, the 21st day of May 1821. Attest. Jonathan Pickett Clk.

A Schedule of the property of David Holbrook a pensioner of the United States under the act of Congress of the 18th of March AD 1818 Except beds and wearing apparel Real estate valued at two thousand 2000.00 One Desk $3.00 three cows & one heifer $47.00 50.00 One case of draur 2.00 seven sheep and eight lamb 15.00 17.00 One beaureau 2.00 One hog and four pigs 16.00 18.00 One horse 40.00 three chests 2.00 42.00 3 Looking glasses 4.50 One chaise old & sleigh 18.00 22.50 Two tables 2.00 One old wa(g)gon 6.00 8.00 One plough 2.00 [Cart] body 1.00 3.00 Harrow 1.00 three brass kettles 4.00 5.00 Chains, shovel, & hoes 5.00 Iron ware 4.00 9.00 Wooden ware 2.00 S(c)ythes and axes 3.00 5.00 Wooden vessels 5.00 17 chains 4.50 9.50 Crockery & glassware 5.00 Plate 5.00 10.00 Carpet old 2.00 Tinware 2.00 4.00 nine kitchen chairs 2.25 Pewter & earthen ware 2.00 4.25 $2207.25 The Declarant further states that his occupation has been a farmer but now by season of age and infirmity he is unable to pursue it, or to contribute to the support of my family and that my wife is sixty eight years of age and of a slender constitution that his family consists of a lad 12 years of age and a girl of 15 years of age and that by unforseen misfortune I am involved in debt in notes given five to ten years past for 1300 Dollars besides these is a mortgage on my real estate unpaid of 1737.00 dollars had it not been for the favour of his friends and forbearance of his credits he must have failed long since. David Holbrook

the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not since that time by gift, value or in any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof with intent thereby to be diminished my estate as to bring my self within the provisions of act of Congress, entitled an act of Congress to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War passed on the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not, nor any person in trust for me any property or securities contracts or debts due to me, nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule annexed and by me subscribed, to wit one mare, one cow, seven head of hogs, (three of them grown the other four pigs) two ovens, one plough, that he owes fifteen dollars and one dollar owing to me, has a wife named Mary near sixty years old and has two children, a son about twenty years of age deformed and helpless, a daughter, about sixteen years old and that I am a farmer by profession and so infirm as not to be able to labor and cannot live without public or private charity.
