Killed by dogs or wolves. I then put out 5 to Peter Service of Matilda Upper Canada for which he agreed to return me double the number in three years; the time has expired but I have not been able to get any back and in consequence of the poverty of service never expect to receive any thing for them. After the loss of these Sheep my grandson gave me 4 of which I have 3 left having sold one as above mentioned. The calves from my two cows mentioned in my Inventory hereto annexed and the increase of the sheep and the fleeces of the same have been used for the support of myself and my wife. And I do further declare that I am by occupation a farmer but for the last ten or twelve years have not been able to do any manual labor, my only occupation being to assist my wife in winding spools & who is by trade a weaver, is now aged seventy four but is not able to get enough work to keep her employed through the year, Myself and my wife reside with our grandson by whom we are principally supported. I have two children living, one son, John Sabins Jr. and one daughter Elizabeth Scott both of whom have families and in poor circumstances. John Sabins Sworn to and declared on the 13th day of October 1829 before me in open Court J.C.S. Canada for 10 sheep mentioned in my Declaration. No other debts Securities contracts or property no books of account No real estate either in Law or Equity expecting reversion or remainder John Sabins

Bangor, Nov 1821 We the undersigned Select men of Bangor have been to See W^m Forbes & find him destitute of most of the conveniences & many of the comforts of life when he was placed on the Pention Roll it placed him in credit so as to purchase some stock such as one pair of oxen & one or two cows but not being retained on the Pention list has been compelled to return the stock to make payment, said Forbes has a large family of Children & many of them small they appear to be very destitute for furniture in the house they say they have but one cow which they are aging to kill for the family food & seven sheep which constitute the whole of their stock & in our opinion he is a subject that is needy of the assistance of his government {Wiggins Hill James Tilton} Select men of Bangor

District of Pennsylvania Indiana County } On this twenty seventh day of September in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and twenty personally appeared in open Court of Common Pleas that being a court of record which proceeds according to the course of common law with a jurisdiction unlimited in point of amount keeping a record of their proceedings and having a Seal for the said County James Shields aged Seventy six years resident in Mahoning Township in said County who being first duly sworn according to law doth on his solemn oath declare that he served in the Revolutionary war as follows he was enlisted in Captain William Chambers Company in the Congress old Regiment commanded by Colonel Moses Hazen in the year 1777 for the term of three years or during the war which time he served and was at the battle of Brunswick, Whitemarsh, Germantown where he was wounded in the arm Brandywine, Horse Neck Stony Point Little York, Monmouth & others that he was also wound in the left eyebrow and in the right arm. That a certificate was granted to this declarant on 6th day of September 1819 by the war department No 14110 under the law of the 18th March 1818 and he was discharged at Pompton Plains in 1783 and I do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not since that time by gift sale or in any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War passed on the 18th of March 1818 and that I have not nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities contracts or debts due me nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed -- List of declarants property One old mare five dollars one horse $27.00 One Cow $11.00 two sheep and one lamb $2.50

State of Pennsylvania Philadelphia County Ss. Mary Dawson of the District of Southwark, Widow aged about eighty years, being duly sworn, deposeth and saith, that she is the widow of Anthony Dawson deceased, who was in his life time a soldier of the Revolutionary War, under Captain Ripley. He enlisted for two years, as a private in the rifle Company, and was wounded in the left thigh at the Battle of Three Rivers, when he was discharged as disabled from duty. He lived until the year eighteen hundred and fifteen suffering during the whole period from his being wounded until his death, from his painful wound, which gave him little or no rest. He was pensioned, and received a soldiers pay, she thinks fifty dollars a year, until his death from the United States Since the visit of Genl. Lafayette, the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania granted a Pension to her of forty dollars annually, as one of the Widows entitled to it in right of her husband, which she still receives. The regiment in which he served was the Sixth Regiment of Infantry, under General Erwin, of the Pennsylvania Line, and in the second year of his service he received his wound, as she verily believes. After the War he was taken into service again as a soldier and performed Garrison duty for six months and upwards at Fort Mifflin, in the river Delaware. Deponent was married by a German Clergyman of the Maryland Church in Baltimore, during the Revolutionary War, and has had five Children by said Marriage, one of whom was born before the Capture of Lord Cornwallis at York. The Certificate of her Marriage, which she held many say, may twenty years ago, until it has been unfortunately

State of Vermont Hon. Cornelius P. Van Ess, Esq. Chief Judge, Hon. Joel Doolittle, Esq,. Assistant Judge Hon. Charles K. Williams, Esq. Assistant Judge On this thirtieth day of May, A.D. 1832, personally appeared in open Court, being a Court of Record, within and for the County of Windham and State of Vermont - proceeding according to the course of the common law : with a civil jurisdiction unlimited in point of keeping a record of their proceedings; and having the power of fine and imprisonment - Daniel Harris resident in Wardsboro in said County of Windham - Aged Sixty two years - Who, being first duly sworn according to law - doth, on his Oath, make the following declaration, in order to obtain the provision made by the Acts of Congress, of the 18th of March, 1818, and the 1st of May, 1820, - That he, the said Daniel Harris enlisted for the term of three years in April or May in the year 1782 in the State of Massachusetts in the Company commanded by Captain Story (Christian name forgotten) was transferred soon after to Captain Nathan Dixe's Company in the Regiment commanded by Colonel Michael Jackson in the line of the State of Massachusetts on the continental establishment : that he continued to serve in the said Corps until the during Wars men were discharged in June 1783. Then in the 3 Regiment commanded by Col. Maxfield until Dec 31 1783. (Maxfield's name omitted by mistake in declaration of 1820) when he was discharged from said service, by Major Gen Knox honourably in the State of New York that his name has been placed on the pension list, and dropt therefrom on account of his property. His former certificated dated 30th Nov. 1818 and is No. 4,683. Original declaration April 18th 1818 And, in pursuance of the Act of 1st May, 1820, I do hereby swear - that I was a resident citizen of the United States, on the 18 day of March, 1818, And that I have not, since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an Act of Congress - Entitled "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War" - passed on the 18th day of March, 1818. And I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property, or securities, contracts, or debts, due to me : Nor have I an income other than what is contained in the Schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. Felton being a debt which I justly owed to Felton To Abner Plympton 30th June 1820 17 of three year old Steers for Forty Dollars - which he paid Jonas Mann twelve dollars, which I justly owed said Mann, and $28 dollars I justly owed said Plympton. To Leland Fairbank 2 Nov 1820 - One Horse for forty two dollars, and went in payment of a debt which I justly owed said Fairbank. To Abner Plympton 29th May 1823 - One old Iron bar, Dungfork and shove, 2 old chairs, brush scythe, and bill hook and 4 harrow teeth, for six Dollars and 34 cents and accounted to me, for a debt which I justly owed said Plympton. One cow killed and consumed in my family - Six Sheep and two lambs killed and consumed in my family - 2 Hogs killed and eat in my family - One old Cart worn out - one small plough worn out - On old Yoke and ring worn out - Iron wedge and beetle lost - 3 harrow teeth lost - 4 plates broken - Tea pot and set broken, 2 pint bottles broken - one chair worn out - 2 old sickles broken - 1/3 (?) Pork - 1/8 (?) beef consumed in my family - 22 bushels Rye consumed in my family - 1/2 case old knives & forks worn out. And as it respects the small Tenement of 20 Acres which I stated in first Schedule was conveyed by quit claim deed to my wife and her heirs by her Brother Executor & her Fathers Estate I now find that I was then mistaken

Commonwealth of Massachusetts Norfolks Court of Common Pleas April Term 1823 On this second day of May AD 1823 personally appeared in open Court, bein a Court of Record for said County, keeping a record of its proceedings [illegible] David Holbrook, aged seventy six years, resident in Wrentham in said County who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath declare that he served in the Revolutionary War as follows, on the First of January AD 1776 I enlisted as a Sergeant in a Company commanded by Captain Andrew Petey in Col Joseph Reeds Regt Mass. line, and served one year, was then appointed a Lieutenant in Capt Moses Knapps Company in Col Wm Shepards Regt and served in said capacity more than three years, was there appointed Capt in the same Regt. and continued in service to the close of the war for which service he received a pension certificate dated a Apl. 5 1819 and No 9084. The above dictation he makes and oath he takes in order to obtain the provisions made by the act of the 18th of March 1818, the 1st of May 1820 & 1st of March 1823 - And I do solemnly swear that I was a resident Citizen of the United States on the 18th of March 1818 and that I have not since that time by gift, seale, or in any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War" passed on the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not, nor have any person in trust for me any property or securities, contracts, or debts due to me, nor have I any income, other than what's contained in the schedule hereunto annexed and by me subscribed. That since the exhibition of my first schedule, which is as follows Dols Real estate valued at 2000 - - - 2000 1 Desk 3.00 3 Cows & 1 Heifer 47 - - - 50. 1 Case of Drawers 2.00 Seven Sheep & 8 lambs 15 Dols - - - 17 1 Bureau - - - 2.00 one hog & 4 piggs - 16 --- 18 1 Horse --- 40.00 3 Chests --- 2 --- 42. 3 Looking Glasses - 4.50 1 old chaise & Sleigh - 18 --- 22.50

or any part thereof with intent thereby & to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of congress entitled an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the united States in the Revolutionary War passed on the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not nor has any person for me any property or securities contracts or debts due to me nor have I any income other than what is contained in the attached schedule hereunto annexed and by me subscribed--And I I [repeated] do further swear that I am by profession a common labourer [sic] at farming but in consequence of my bodily infirmities I am unable to work at it at all---that I have a wife (to wit) Christina Hobough [sic] aged about 55 years who is unable to work to any advantage in consequence of old age and bodily infirmities; also 5 children (to wit) Molly Hobough [sic] aged 14 years Michael aged 12 years Elizabeth aged 10 years--Susan aged 8 years and Peter aged 4 years who are about as healthy as children of their ages commonly are, but one not more than able to procure subsistence for themselves -- Schedule of property owned by Philip Hobough [sic] (to wit) 1 Horse of the value of $30 -- 1 Mare and colt value of 40 -- 9 Head of cattle value of 55 -- 12 head of hogs value of 12 -- 11 head of sheep value of 11 -- 1 old set of waggon [sic] & ropes value of 20 -- 2 setts [sic] of horse gear value of 6 -- 174.00

District of Virginia County of Brooke SS. On this 28th day of May 1821 personally appeared in open Court being a Court of record by the laws of the State Virginia for the said district and County, John Gallagher, aged Sixty three years, resident in said county, in said district, who being first duly sworn according to law on his oath declares, that he served in the Revolutionary war as follows: in the sixth regiment commanded by Col. Williams in Captain Andrew Hinds company of foot in the Maryland line for the term of three years and was discharged in the City of Annapolis in the year one thousand seven hundred Eighty, That the date of his original application is the 23d day of May 1818 and his pension certificate is number 10, 215. And I do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March 1818; and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress Entitled "an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land & naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary war", passed on the 18th day of March 1818, and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities contracts or debts due to me nor have I any income other than what is contained in the Schedule hereunto annexed and by me subscribed. 82 Acres of land the title to which is in dispute and doubtful value if the title was good at $1.50 per Acre . . . . $123.00 Of the said land there is about 15 acres cleared, but much out of repair and the said declarant is unable properly to cutibate the same owing to bodily infirmity, and his sons are unable to assist him and he has not the means to pay an assistant. 3 Small Cows. - a $8.00 ... $24.00 1 two year old Heifer .... - 5.00 1 Horse 12 years old ... - 25.00 1 Mare & Colt .................30.00 1 Pow & Gears $6.00 Pot metal $4.00 .. 10.00 Dresser furniture.. $4.00 1 ax & 1 Hoe $2.00 6.00 1 Wooden Clock............... 5.00 $228..0 8 Sheep - - - - - 6.0 234.00 Deponent is indebted (besides two years & tax) 50.00 184..00 John Gallagher x his mark

STATE OF VERMOND Franklin COuny, ss Supreme Court [illegible] Term 1820 on this Eleventh day of July 1820 personally appeared in open Court, being the Supreme Court of said State for the County of Franklin and a Court of Record for said State & County. having the Power of fine and Impress Samuel Laflin aged 63 years, resident in Georgia in said County, who being duly sworn, according to law, doth on his oath declare that he served in the revolutionary war, as follows:- I enlisted in December 1775 under Capt. Georens in Col. Durkees Regiment in the Connecticut line served one year and was discharged that I enlisted in the year 1782 under Capt. Tisdall Col Hulls Regiment in the Massachusetts line and served till 1784 when I was discharged by Col Saml Millens on west Point that my original declaration is dated April 20th 1818 m Pension Certificate is numbered 3723 And I do solemnly swear, that I was a resident citizen of the United States, on teh 18th day of Marc, 1818; and that I have not, since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congres,[sic] entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary war," passed on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities, contracts, or debts, sue to me: nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. Sixty five acres of land purchased of Robert Bowne in November [illegible] for which I fave my note for the sum of two hundred dollars and the land has been mortgaged for the payment of said note and is now holden nothing having been paid one cow one two year old heifer one old mare & cold 7 sheep & 2 lambs three small swine one

Pennsylvania Beaver County On the 19th day of September 1820 Personally appeared in open Court being a court of record for the County of Beaver John Patridge aged Sixty nine who being first duly sworn according to law doth on his Oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the provisions made by the late act of Congress of the 18th March 1818 and the 1st of May 1820 that he the said John Patridge, enlisted being in the Pennsylvania militia in the State of N Jersey, in December 1780 in the Company commanded by Captain John Alexander in the Regiment commanded by Colonel William Irvin (late Genl Green) on the continental Establishment in the line of the State of Pennsylvania that he continued to serve in said Corps untill peace was made with England in 1783 he was discharged from said Service at Philadelphia in the State of Pennsylvania that he was in the battles of Green Springs and capture of Cornwallis's Army and that he has no other evidence now in his power of his said services except what accompanied his former application to the war office dated the 1st of May 1818 he was placed on the Pension list Pennsylvania agency as will appear by his certificate Signed by the Secretary of war bearing date the 6th day of September 1819 No 15,038 and in pursuance of the act of the 1st of May 1820 I do Solemnly Swear I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not since that time by gift sale or in any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof with intent to diminish it so as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress entitled an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary war passed the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities contracts or debts due to me nor have I any income other than what is contained in the Schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed Schedule 2 horses & one Colt one cow two heifers three Calves one Sow and 9 pigs two hundred acres of land he purchased at dollars pr acre and paid only $40.00 of the price Eight Sheep houshold furniture not exceeding $10.00 his John X Patridge mark

To the Justices of the Court of Common Pleas now sitting at Dover within and for the County of Strafford and State of New Hampshire on the first Tuesday of July 1820. John Richards aged Sixty-Six, resident in Rochester in said County, comes into court, and in pursuance of an act of Congress passed on the 1st day of May 1820, brings with him, and in his proper person exhibits to said Court a Schedule by him subscribed, containing his whole Estate and Income--his necessary clothing and bedding excepted - as follows: -- one cow and one year old heifer $25.00 one swine and two pigs $7.00 five Sheep and Six lambs $12.00 one hoe, one Shovel, two shears & one [illegible] $1.50 one [illegible] axe & one hatchet $1.00 one pitchfork & one rake .50 Total $47.00 Nearly 3 acres of Land in said Rochester with a small one-story house therein & a small unfinished barn $35.00 Grand total $82.00 John Richards And the said John Richards in pursuance of aforesaid produceth to said Court the following oath by him duly taken and subscribed: -- viz. I, John Richards do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March 1818, and that I have not, since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled "an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the revolutionary war,” passed on the 18th day of March 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts due to me, nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. John Richards And the said John Richards doth here in Court further declare on oath, that he served in the revolutionary war as follows, viz. in Capt. John Brewster's company in Col Peirce Long's Regiment from August 1776 to August 1777 one year -- Col Long's Regiment belonged to the New Hampshire line

STATE OF VERMONT. COUNTY OF ADDISON On this 4th day of July 1820, personally appeared in open Court, being a Court of record (having the power of fine and imprisonment) for the said County Samuel Pierce aged sixty four years, resident in Salisbury in said County, who being first duly sworn according to law. doth on his oath declare that he served in the Revolutionary war as follows:-- he enlisted on the 31st day of December 1775, for one year & served for that period in Capt. John Stevens's company, Col. Burrell's regiment of the Connecticut line; that afterwards, he enlisted & served for three months; at the close of that period, in April 1777 he enlisted for six months, & before the close of the last period, he enlisted for three years in August 1777 served for that period in Capt. Jesse Him bolls company, Col. Chandler, being the eighth Connecticct regiment. said regiment was commanded also by Colonels Russel & Sherman. that the date of his original declaration is the 24th day of April 1818, the number of his pension certificate is 3408 And I do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States, on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, since that time, by gift sale or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled ""An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary war,” passed on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts due to me, nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. One undivided half of 130 acres of land in Salisbury, with a small house & barn, under a mortgage of about $1450, purchased in April 1819, in company with my son, Rodney Pierce, on his credit & on the prospect of my pension money; toward the payment of which my said son has also mortgaged another farm estimated by the Court at much less than the mortgage Notes against S.A. OBITUARY. Communicated. DIED --In this county on Wednesday evening the 15th inst. at the residence of C. L. Yancy, Esq. Mrs. MARTHA A. WITHERS, late of Culpepper county Va. aged 68 years 7 months and 10 days. Mrs. Withers was born and raised in Faqnier county Va., and resided there the greater part of her life, she then removed to Culpepper and in the fall of 1831 emigrated to Gibson county, Tenn. Mrs. Withers from her youth, had a great deference and respect for religion, and for a number of years, has been a professor of the christian religion, but never attached herself to any church, until the fall of 1834, when she joined the Baptist church at New Hope; and from her pious and upright deportment showed that she felt, as well as possessed ^& professed^, the influence of the Holy Spirit on hers, that she was born of God. In the loss of this matronly and pious lady, the church has been deprived of an exemplary member, society of one of its brightest ornaments, her children of a kind and affectionate parent, and her domestics of a humane and benevolent mistress. Mrs. Withers was aflicted with a long and painful disease, which she bore with that philosophical composure so becoming the christian; and though for the last six months of her life entirely confined to her bed, and unable to move without assistance, she was never once heard to murmur or repine. The writer of this has witnessed several scenes of serenity and composure in a dying hour, but has never beheld any which surpassed that displayed by Mrs. Withers. When asked by a friend how she felt respecting the hour of her dissolution; Ah! said she, "I am ready." Although deprived of the power of speech for six [illegible] hours previous to her death, yet she manifested by signs to her friends, that she was perfectly sane. --A beam of tranquility and compromise ^composure seemed to settle on her countenance; and thus she sank, into that eternal sleep of death, appointed for all the living. Such, will ever be the case, with those who have a hope full of immortality. The holy triumphs of their soul Will death itself outbrave; Leave dull mortality behind, And fly beyond the grave.

Leigh In Inventory of all the estate and property of Isaac Morehouse, real and personal, referred to in the foregoing Declaration of him the said Isaac Morehouse, together with an account of his family, their several ages and occupations. I Isaac Morehouse was seventy five years of age on the seventh day of June 1831, my family consisted of myself, my wife and Jane Morehouse my granddaughter. My wife is seventy four years of age, is deranged and totally helpless and has been so for the last three years. My grand daughter is nineteen years of age and capable of doing the ordinary work of a female. Real Estate, I have none. I own the following personal property One span of horses worth not to exceed the sum of $40 Two cows, worth not exceeding the sum of 24 Thirteen hogs, worth not exceeding the sum of 78 Seven pigs or shoals, worth not exceeding the sum of 14 Four one year old calves, worth not exceeding the sum of 20 $176

of June (I think the 3d day) the same year. My discharge was given to me by my Captain William Pratt - I was wounded in a battle fought at the Springfield in New Jersey in the ankle by a musket ball, and have never entirely recovered from the wound. I am now seven[ty, as found on image 6 which overlaps this page] one years of age. I have a wife who has been under the care of a Doctor upon of eleven years, who is weakly and very worn, and unable to do scarce any kind of work-- I have had 10 children-- 8 of them now (I believe) living) Two of my children through the providence of God are in a helpless condition - the one a daughter 22 or 23 years of age, who had fits at the age of 9 years and which have and still continue, she is nearly as helpless as an infant - I have one son who is 21 years of age who has been afflicted for number of years with a disease which has rendered him unable to do any work or earn himself a living-- I am a verry poor man, and nothing to support myself and helpless family only what I earn by days works, for about four years past I have been compelled from poverty to get assistance and help to support myself and family from the town in which I reside

State of Virginia Marion County August Term 1826 On the 21st day of August 1826 personally appeared in open Court John Doss of the County & State aforesaid who having been duly Sworn according to law doth on his oath make the following Declaration as an amended one to the one filed by him in the Circuit Court of this county in April 1825 to obtain a pension. This affiant States that the reason Why he did not apply for a pension sooner As that he being Ignorant did not know whom to apply for it And he made frequent inquires but Could not get any person to do it for him until April 1825. That he was poor and unable to employ Lawyers to do it & he did not know what provisions had been made for old soldiers as how to obtain that provision and further that he was so much afflicted since 1819. Until the year 1825 that he could not assist himself & that he could not frequently rise without help & could not walk but with crutches & that he is now much afflicted & entirely unable to support himself and has no person to do it for him The account of my property as the 8th March 1818 and since will appear in the following pages [Chart of property] Description of property one horse worth $20 two Cows$20 the other cow I kept to give milk until 1825 [illegible] I inployed a man to fatten his & [illegible] Names of persons to whom disposed of Swap to with James Doss Sold one to Joel Doss Time of sale in 1819 in the winter in 1820 [illegible] Recd. in Return a mare which died in 1821 comes to work for me [round black ink stamp] THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES OF THE UNITED STATES

his and I paid him a part of her for it and hog as pet pig which I eat in 1824 my son Give to me The cow mentioned as in my Schedule of April 1825 was a calf that I saved from the cow last mentioned above. [ZECHARIAH] CHAP. IX, X, XI. [23..]even shall take hold of the skirt of him that is a Jew, saying, We will go with you: for we have heard that God is with you. 9 The burden of the word of the Lord in the land of Hadrach, and Damascus shall be the rest thereof: when the eyes of man, as of all the tribes of Israel, shall be toward the Lord. 2 And Hamath also shall border thereby; Tyrus, and Zidon, though it be very wise. 3 And Tyrus did build herself a strong hold, and heaped up silver as the dust, and fine gold as the mire of the streets. 4 Behold, the Lord will cast her out, and he will smite her power in the sea; and she shall be devoured with fire. 5 Ashkelon shall see it, and fear; Gaza also shall see it, and be very sorrowful, and Ekron; for her expectation shall be ashamed; and the king shall perish from Gaza, and Ashkelon shall not be inhabited. 6 And a bastard shall dwell in Ashdod, and I will cut off the pride of the Philistines. 7 And I will take away his blood out of his mouth, and his abominations from between his teeth: but he that remaineth, even he, shall be for our God, and he shall be as a governor in Judah, and Ekron as a Jebusite. 8 And I will encamp about mine house because of the army, because of him that passeth by, and because of him that returneth: and no oppressor shall pass through them any more: for now have I seen with mine eyes. 9 Rejoice greatly, O daughter of Zion; shout, O daughter of Jerusalem: behold, thy King cometh unto thee: he is just, and having salvation; lowly, and riding upon an ass, and upon a colt the foal of an ass. 10 And I will cut off the chariot from Ephraim, and the horse from Jerusalem, and the battle bow shall be cut off: and he shall speak peace unto the heathen: and his dominion shall be from sea even to sea, and from the river even to the ends of the earth. 11 As for thee also, by the blood of thy covenant I have sent forth thy prisoners out of the pit wherein is no water. 12 Turn you to the strong hold, ye prisoners of hope: even to day do I declare that I will render double unto thee; 13 When I have bent Judah for me, filled the bow with Ephraim, and raised up thy sons, O Zion, against thy sons, O Greece, and made thee as the sword of a mighty man. 14 And the Lord shall be seen over them, and his arrow shall go forth as the lightning: and the Lord God shall blow the trumpet, and shall go with whirlwinds of the south. 15 The Lord of hosts shall defend them; and they shall devour, and subdue with sling stones; and they shall drink, and make a noise as through wine; and they shall be filled like bowls, and as the corners of the altar. 16 And the Lord their God shall save them in that day as the flock of his people: for they shall be as the stones of a crown, lifted up as an ensign upon his land. 17 For how great is his goodness, and how great is his beauty! corn shall make the young men cheerful, and new wine the maids. 10 Ask ye of the Lord rain in the time of the latter rain; so the Lord shall make bright clouds, and give them showers of rain, to every one grass in the field. 2 For the idols have spoken vanity, and the diviners have seen a lie, and have told false dreams; they comfort in vain: therefore they went their way as a flock, they were troubled, because there was no shepherd. 3 Mine anger was kindled against the shepherds, and I punished the goats: for the Lord of hosts hath visited his flock the house of Judah, and hath made them as his goodly horse in the battle. 4 Out of him came forth the corner, out of him the nail, out of him the battle bow, out of him every oppressor together. 5 And they shall be as mighty men, which tread down their enemies in the mire of the streets in the battle: and they shall fight, because the Lord is with them, and the riders on horses shall be confounded. 6 And I will strengthen the house of Judah, and I will save the house of Joseph, and I will bring them again to place them; for I have mercy upon them: and they shall be as though I had not cast them off: for I am the Lord their God, and will hear them. 7 And they of Ephraim shall be like a mighty man, and their heart shall rejoice as through wine: yea, their children shall see it, and be glad; their heart shall rejoice in the Lord. 8 I will hiss for them, and gather them; for I have redeemed them: and they shall increase as they have increased. 9 And I will sow them among the people: and they shall remember me in far countries; and they shall live with their children, and turn again. 10 I will bring them again also out of the land of Egypt, and gather them out of Assyria; and I will bring them into the land of Gilead and Lebanon; and place shall not be found for them. 11 And he shall pass through the sea with affliction, and shall smite the waves in the sea, and all the deeps of the river shall dry up: and the pride of Assyria shall be brought down, and the sceptre of Egypt shall depart away. 12 And I will strengthen them in the Lord; and they shall walk up and down in his name, saith the Lord. 11 Open thy doors, O Lebanon, that the fire may devour thy cedars. 2 Howl, fir tree; for the cedar is fallen; because the mighty are spoiled: howl, O ye oaks of Bashan; for the forest of the vintage is come down.

ZECHARIAH [XI] 3 There is a voice of the howling of the shepherds; for their glory is spoiled: a voice of the roaring of young lions; for the pride of Jordan is spoiled. 4 Thus saith the Lord my God; Feed the flock of the slaughter; 5 Whose possessors slay them, and hold themselves not guilty: and they that sell them say, Blessed be the Lord; for I am rich: and their own shepherds pity them not. 6 For I will no more pity the inhabitants of the land, saith the Lord: but, lo, I will deliver the men every one into his neighbour's hand, and into the hand of his king: and they shall smite the land, and out of their hand I will not deliver them. 7 And I will feed the flock of slaughter, even you, O poor of the flock. And I took unto me two staves; the one I called Beauty, and the other I called Bands; and I fed the flock. 8 Three shepherds also I cut off in one month; and my soul lothed them, and their soul also abhorred me. 9 Then said I, I will not feed you: that that dieth, let it die; and that that is to be cut off, let it be cut off; and let the rest eat every one the flesh of another. 10 And I took my staff, even Beauty, and cut it asunder, that I might break my covenant which I had made with all the people. 11 And it was broken in that day: and so the poor of the flock that waited upon me knew that it was the word of the Lord. 12 And I said unto them, If ye think good, give me my price; and if not, forbear. So they weighed for my price thirty pieces of silver. 13 And the Lord said unto me, Cast it unto the potter: a goodly price that I was prised at of them. And I took the thirty pieces of silver, and cast them to the potter in the house of the Lord. 14 Then I cut asunder mine other staff, even Bands, that I might break the brotherhood between Judah and Israel. 15 And the Lord said unto me, Take unto thee yet the instruments of a foolish shepherd. 16 For, lo, I will raise up a shepherd in the land, which shall not visit those that be cut off, neither shall seek the young one, nor heal that that is broken, nor feed that that standeth still: but he shall eat the flesh of the fat, and tear their claws in pieces. 17 Woe to the idol shepherd that leaveth the flock! the sword shall be upon his arm, and upon his right eye: his arm shall be clean dried up, and his right eye shall be utterly darkened. 12 The burden of the word of the Lord for Israel, saith the Lord, which stretcheth forth the heavens, and layeth the foundation of the earth, and formeth the spirit of man within him. 2 Behold, I will make Jerusalem a cup of trembling unto all the people round about, when they shall be in the siege both against Judah and against Jerusalem. 3 And in that day will I make Jerusalem a burdensome stone for all people: all that burden themselves with it shall be cut in pieces, though all the people of the earth be gathered together against it. 4 In that day, saith the Lord, I will smite every horse with astonishment, and his rider with madness: and I will open mine eyes upon the house of Judah, and will smite every horse of the people with blindness. 5 And the governors of Judah shall say in their heart, The inhabitants of Jerusalem shall be my strength in the Lord of hosts their God. 6 In that day will I make the governors of Judah like an hearth of fire among the wood, and like a torch of fire in a sheaf; and they shall devour all the people round about, on the right hand and on the left: and Jerusalem shall be inhabited again in her own place, even in Jerusalem. 7 The Lord also shall save the tents of Judah first, that the glory of the house of David and the glory of the inhabitants of Jerusalem do not magnify themselves against Judah. 8 In that day shall the Lord defend the inhabitants of Jerusalem; and he that is feeble among them at that day shall be as David; and the house of David shall be as God, as the angel of the Lord before them. 9 And it shall come to pass in that day, that I will seek to destroy all the nations that come against Jerusalem. 10 And I will pour upon the house of David, and upon the inhabitants of Jerusalem, the spirit of grace and of supplications: and they shall look upon me whom they have pierced, and they shall mourn for him, as one mourneth for his only son, and shall be in bitterness for him, as one that is in bitterness for his firstborn. 11 In that day shall there be a great mourning in Jerusalem, as the mourning of Hadadrimmon in the valley of Megiddon. 12 And the land shall mourn, every family apart; the family of the house of David apart, and their wives apart; the family of the house of Nathan apart, and their wives apart; 13 The family of the house of Levi apart, and their wives apart; the family of Shimei apart, and their wives apart; 14 All the families that remain, every family apart, and their wives apart. 13 In that day there shall be a fountain opened to the house of David and to the inhabitants of Jerusalem for sin and for uncleanness. 2 And it shall come to pass in that day, saith the Lord of hosts, that I will cut off the names of the idols out of the land, and they shall no more be remembered: and also I will cause the prophets and the unclean spirit to pass out of the land. 3 And it shall come to pass, that when any shall yet prophesy, then his father and his mother that begat him shall say unto him, Thou shalt not live; for thou speakest lies in the name of the Lord: and his father and his mother that begat him shall thrust him through when he prophesieth. 4 And it shall come to pass in that day, that the prophets shall be ashamed every one of his vision, when he hath prophesied; neither shall they wear a rough garment to deceive: 5 But he shall say, I am no prophet, I am an husbandman; for man taught me to keep cattle from my youth. 6 And one shall say unto him, What are these wounds in thine hands? Then he shall answer, Those with which I was wounded in the house of my friends. 7 Awake, O sword, against my shepherd, and against the man that is my fellow, saith the Lord of hosts: smite the shepherd, and the sheep shall be scattered: and I will turn mine hand upon the little ones. 8 And it shall come to pass, that in all the land, saith the Lord, two parts therein shall be cut off and die; but the third shall be left therein. 9 And I will bring the third part through the fire, and will refine them as silver is refined, and will try them as gold is tried: they shall call on my name, and I will hear them: I will say, It is my people: and they shall say, The Lord is my God. King James Version 14 Behold, the day of the Lord cometh, and thy spoil shall be divided in the midst of thee. 2 For I will gather all nations against Jerusalem to battle; and the city shall be taken, and the houses rifled, and the women ravished; and half of the city shall go forth into captivity, and the residue of the people shall not be cut off from the city. 3 Then shall the Lord go forth, and fight against those nations, as when he fought in the day of battle. 4 And his feet shall stand in that day upon the mount of Olives, which is before Jerusalem on the east, and the mount of Olives shall cleave in the midst thereof toward the east and toward the west, and there shall be a very great valley; and half of the mountain shall remove toward the north, and half of it toward the south. 5 And ye shall flee to the valley of the mountains; for the valley of the mountains shall reach unto Azal: yea, ye shall flee, like as ye fled from before the earthquake in the days of Uzziah king of Judah: and the Lord my God shall come, and all the saints with thee. 6 And it shall come to pass in that day, that the light shall not be clear, nor dark: 7 But it shall be one day which shall be known to the Lord, not day, nor night: but it shall come to pass, that at evening time it shall be light. 8 And it shall be in that day, that living waters shall go out from Jerusalem; half of them toward the former sea, and half of them toward the hinder sea: in summer and in winter shall it be. 9 And the Lord shall be king over all the earth: in that day shall there be one Lord, and his name one. 10 All the land shall be turned as a plain from Geba to Rimmon south of Jerusalem: and it shall be lifted up, and inhabited in her place, from Benjamin's gate unto the place of the first gate, unto the corner gate, and from the tower of Hananeel unto the king's winepresses. 11 And men shall dwell in it, and there shall be no more utter destruction; but Jerusalem shall be safely inhabited. 12 And this shall be the plague wherewith the Lord will smite all the people that have fought against Jerusalem; Their flesh shall consume away while they stand upon their feet, and their eyes shall consume away in their holes, and their tongue shall consume away in their mouth. 13 And it shall come to pass in that day, that a great tumult from the Lord shall be among them; and they shall lay hold every one on the hand of his neighbour, and his hand shall rise up against the hand of his neighbour. 14 And Judah also shall fight at Jerusalem; and the wealth of all the heathen round about shall be gathered together, gold, and silver, and apparel, in great abundance. 15 And so shall be the plague of the horse, of the mule, of the camel, and of the ass, and of all the beasts that shall be in these tents, as this plague. 16 And it shall come to pass, that every one that is left of all the nations which came against Jerusalem shall even go up from year to year to worship the King, the Lord of hosts, and to keep the feast of tabernacles. 17 And it shall be, that whoso will not come up of all the families of the earth unto Jerusalem to worship the King, the Lord of hosts, even upon them shall be no rain. 18 And if the family of Egypt go not up, and come not, that have no rain; there shall be the plague, wherewith the Lord will smite the heathen that come not up to keep the feast of tabernacles. 19 This shall be the punishment of Egypt, and the punishment of all nations that come not up to keep the feast of tabernacles. 20 In that day shall there be upon the bells of the horses, Holiness Unto The Lord; and the pots in the Lord's house shall be like the bowls before the altar. 21 Yea, every pot in Jerusalem and in Judah shall be holiness unto the Lord of hosts: and all they that sacrifice shall come and take of them, and seethe therein: and in that day there shall be no more the Canaanite in the house of the Lord of hosts.

Schedule of Properrty one black mare worth--------------$40.00 one brown horse "------------------ 50 Eighteen Shoats "--------------------10 3- 2 years old & 3 three yrs old cattle & 1 cow & calf }--------------25 1 shovel plow------------------------1 2 pair horse geers--------------------2.75 1 set plow irons & dowle hees and clevises--------------------4.75 4 old hoes----------------------------0.75 1 old axe piece of log chair and one iron wadget}----------------2.00 1 old Scythe auger & Knife----------1.00 Eight old chairs 2 old wheels & reel-------------------------4.25 8 Pewter plates 8 broken Set cups and Saucers-----------------1.00 1 old chest and table-----------------3.00 Castings-------------------------------4.25 old kitchen furniture------------------1.00 1 skillet & hooks----------------------1.25 1 Paid andirons -----------------------1.00 --------------------------------------165.00 he is indebted to John Mahaffy------$8.50 to John Coe----------------------------3.37 to William Armstrong-----------------18.56 to John Copple------------------------1.88 ----------------------------------------32.51 His family consists of himself, aged 71 years, and his wife, Elina Rankins, who is aged fifty-five years. His son, James Rankin, aged 18 years; Nancy his daughter, aged 16 years; and John, aged 15.That his occumaption is that of a farmer by he is totally unable to follow it himself his right arm having ben dislocated is useless and he is otherwise infirm & & diseased his wife is also very infirm having lost the use of her left army by t the rheumatism. He also never presented any schedule since he was stricken from the pension list. The reason of which is he intended to support him if possible without the aid of his government but he finds it a successless attempt and from his poverty & infirmity he is compelled again to present his petition & schedule. Daniel (his X mark) Rankin The Court of opinion that the property contained in the above declaration or schedule is of the value of one hundred and

PSALMS CXLIV, CXLV 11 O Lord, for thy name sake, Be pleas'd to quicken me: And for the truth, forth take My soul from misery, 12 And of thy grace destroy my foes, and p shame All who my soul annoy For I thy servant am. PSALM CXLIV 1 O Blessed ever be the Lord, which wondrous are, O Lord, who is my strength and might, Who doth instruct my hand to war, my fingers teach to fight. 2 My goodness, fortress, my high tow'r, deliverer and shield, In whom I trust, who under me my people makes to yield. 3 Lord, what is man? that thou of him dost so much knowledge take! Or son of man? that thou of him so great account dost make! 4 Man is like vanity: his days as shadows pass away. 5 Lord, bow thy heav'ns, come down, touch the hills, and smoke shall they. thou 6 Cast forth thy lighting, scatter them; thine arrows shoot, them rout. 7 Thine hand send from above, me save; from great depths draw me out; 8 Whose mouth speaks vanity: And their right hand is a right hand that work deceitfully. 9 A new song I to thee will sing, Lord, on a psaltery; I on a ten-string'd instrument, will praises sing to thee. 10 Ev'n he it is that unto kings salvation doth send; Who his own servant David doth from hurtful word defend. 11 O free me from strange children's hand, whose mouth speaks vanity; And their right hand a right hand is that works deceitfully. 12 That, as the plants our sons may be in youth grown up that are; Our daughters like to corner -stones, carv'd like a palace fair. 13 That to afford all kind of store, our garners may be fill'd: That our sheep thousands, in our streets ten thousands they may yield. 14 That strong our oxen be for work, that no in-breaking he Nor going out: and that our streets may from complaints be free. 15 Those people blessed are who bein such a case as this: Yea, blessed all those people are, whose God JEHOVAH is. PSALM CXLV. 1 I'll thee extol, my God, O King; I'll bless thy name always. . 2 Thee will I bless each day, and will thy name for ever praise. 3 Great is the Lord, much to be prais'd; his greatness search exceeds. 4 Race unto race shall praise thy works, and shew thy mighty deeds 5 I of thy glorious majesty the honour will record; I'll speak of all thy mighty works, which wondrous are, O Lord. 6 Men of thine acts the might shall show, thine acts that dreadful are: And I, thy glory to advance, thy greatness will declare. 7 The mem'ry of thy goodness great they largely shall express; With songs of praise they shall extol they perfect righteousness. 8 The Lord is very gracious, in him compassions flow; In mercy he is very great, and is to anger slow. 9 The Lord JEHOVAH unto all his goodness doth declare; And over all his other works his tender mercies are. 10 Thee all thy works shall praise, O Lord, and thee thy saints shall bless; 11 They shall thy kingdom's glory show thy pow'r by speech express: 12 To make the sons of men to know his acts done mightily, And of his kingdom th'excellent and glorious majesty. 13 Thy kingdom shall for ever stand, thy reign through ages all. 14 God raiseth all that are bow'd down, upholdeth all that fall. 15 The eyes of all things wait on thee, the giver of all good; And thou, in time convenient, bestows on them their food. 16 Thine hand thou open'st lib'rally, and thy bounty gives Enough to satisfy the need of ev'ry thing that lives. 17 The Lord is just in all his ways, holy in his works all. 18 God's near to all that call on him, in truth that on him call. 19 He will accomplish the desire of those do him fear: He also will deliver them, and he their cry will hear. 20 The Lord preserves all who him love; that nought can them annoy: But he all those that wicked are will utterly destroy. My mouth the praises of the Lord to publish cease shall never: Let all flesh bless his holy name for ever and for ever. Another of the same. 1 O Lord, thou art my God and King: Thee will I magnify and praise; I will thee bless and gladly sing Unto thy holy name always. 2 Each day I rise I will thee bless, And praise thy name time without end. 3 Much to be prais'd and great God is; His greatness none can comprehend. 4 Race shall thy works praise unto race, The mighty acts show done by thee. 5 I will speak of the glorious grace, And honour thy majesty; Thy PSALMS CXLVI, CXLVII. Thy wondrous works I will record. 6 By men the might shall be extoll'd Of all thy dreadful acts, O Lord; And I thy greatness will unfold. 7 They utter shall abundantly The mem'ry of they goodness great; And shall sing praises cheerfully Whilst they thy righteousness relate. 8 The Lord our God is gracious, Compassionate is he also; In mercy he is plenteous, But unto wrath and anger flow. 9 Good unto all men is the Lord; O'er a;; his works his mercy is. 10 Thy works all praise to thee afford; Thy saints, O Lord, thy name shall bless. 11 The glory of thy kingdom show Shall they, and of thy power tell: 12 That so men's sons his deeds may know, His kingdom's grace that doth excel. 13 Thy kingdom hath none end at all, It doth through ages all remain. 14 The Lord upholdeth all that fall, The cast-down raiseth up again. 15 The eyes of all things, Lord, attend, And on thee wait that here do live; And thou in season due doft send Sufficient food them to relieve. 16 Yea, thou thine hand doft open wide, And ev'ry thing dost satisfy That lives and doth on earth abide, Of thy great liberality. 17 The Lord is just in his ways all, And holy in his works each one. 18 He's near to all that on him call, Who call in truth on him alone. 19 God will the just desire fulfill Of such as do him fear and dread; Their cry regard, and hear he will, And save them in the time of need. 20 The Lord preserves all, more and less, That bear to him a loving heart. But workers all of wickedness Destroy will he, and clean subvert. 21 Therefore my mouth and lips I'll frame to speak the praises of the Lord; To magnify his holy name For ever let all flesh accord. PSALM CXLVI. 1 Praise God, The Lord praise, O my soul. 2 I'll praise God while I live: While I have being to my God, in songs , I'll praises give. 3 Trust not in princes, no man's son in whom there is no stay: 4 His breath departs, to earth he turns; that day his thoughts decay. 5 O happy is that man and bless, whom Jacob's God doth aid; Whose hope upon the Lord doth rest, and on his God is stayed: 6 Who made the earth and heavens high, who made the swelling deep, And all that is within the same; who truth doth ever keep: 7 Who righteous judgment executes for those oppressed that be, Who to the hungry giveth food; God sets the pris’ners free. 8 The Lord doth give the blind their sight, the bowed down doth raise: The Lord doth dearly love all those that walk in upright ways. 9 The stranger’s shield, the widow’s stay, the orphan’s help, is he: But yet by him the wicked’s way turned upside down shall be. 10 The Lord shall reign for evermore: thy God, O Zion, he Reigns to all generations. Praise to the Lord give ye. PSALM CXLVII. 1 Praise ye the Lord; for it is good praise to our God to sing: For it is pleasant, and to praise it is a comely thing. 2 God doth build up Jerusalem; and he it is alone That the dispersed of Israel doth gather into one. 3 Those that are broken in their heart, and grieved in their minds. He healeth, and their painful wounds he tenderly up-binds. 4 He counts the number of the stars; he names them ev’ry one. 5 Great is our Lord, and of great pow’r; his wisdom search can none. 6 The Lord lifts up the meek; and casts the wicked to the ground. 7 Sing to the Lord, and give him thanks; on harp his praises sound; 8 Who covereth the heav’n with clouds, who for the earth below Prepareth rain, who maketh grass upon the mountains grow. 9 He gives the beast his food, he feeds the ravens young that cry. 10 His pleasure not in horses’ strength, nor in man’s legs, doth lie. 11 But in all those that do him fear the Lord doth pleasure take; In those that to his mercy do by hope themselves betake. 12 The Lord praise, O Jerusalem; Zion, thy God confess: 13 For thy gates’ bars he maketh strong; thy sons in thee doth bless. 14 He in thy borders maketh peace; with fine wheat filleth thee. 15 He sends forth his command on earth, his word runs speedily. 16 Hoar-frost, like ashes, scatt’reth he; like wool he snow doth give: 17 Like morsels casteth forth his ice; who in its cold can live? 18 He sendeth forth his mighty word, and melteth them again; His wind he makes to blow, and then he waters flow amain. 19 The doctrine of his holy word to Jacob he doth show; is statutes and his judgments he gives Israel to know. 20 To any nation never he such favor did afford; or they his judgments have not known. O do ye praise the Lord. PSALM

PSALMS CXLVII, CXLIX, CL PSALM CXLVIII. 1Praise God. From heaven praise the [illegible] in heights praise to him be . [Lord, 2 All ye his angels, praise ye him; his hosts all, praise him ye. 3 O praise ye him, both sun and moon, praise him all stars of light. 4 Ye heavens of heavens him praise and above the heavens height. [Hood 5 Let all the creatures praise the name of our almighty Lord: For he commanded and they were created by his word. 5 He also for all times to come, hath them establish'd sure; He hath appointed them a law, which ever shall endure. 7 Praise ye JEHOVAH from the earth, dragons, and ev'ry deep: 8 Fire, hail, snow, vapour, stormy wind, his word that fully keep. 9 All hills and mountains, fruitful trees, and all ye cedars high. 10 Beaks, and all cattle, creeping things, and all ye birds that fly. 11 Kings of the earth, all nations, princes, earth's judges all: 12 Both young men, yen , and maidens too, old men and children small. 13 Let them God's s name praise; for his name alone is excellent: His glory reacheth far above the earth and firmament. 14 His people's horn, the praise of all his saints exalteth he; ANOTHER OF THE SAME. 1 The Lord of heav'n confess On high his glory raise. 2 Him let all angels bless, Him, all his armies praise. 3 Him glorify Sun, moon, and stars; 4 Ye higher spheres, And cloudy sky. 5 From God your beings are, Him therefore, famous make: You all created were, When he the word hast spoke. 6 and from that place Where fix'd you be By his decree, You cannot pass. 7 Praise God from earth below, Ye dragons and ye deeps: 8 Fire, hail, clouds, wind, and snow, When in command he keeps. 9 Praise ye his name, Hills great and small Trees low and tall; 10 Beaks wild and tame, All things that creep or fly. 11 Ye kings, ye vulgar throng, All princes mean or high; 12 Both men and virgin: young, Ev'n young and old, Exalt his name; For much his fame Should be extoll'd. O let God's name be prais'd Above both earth and sky. 14 For he his saints hath rais'd, and set their horn on high; Ev'n those that be Of Isr'el's race, Near to his grace. The Lord praise ye. PSALM CXLIX. 1 Praise ye the Lord: unto him sing a new song, and his praise In the assembly of his saints in sweet psalms do ye raise. 2 Let Isr'el in his Maker joy, and to him praises sing: let all that Sion's children are be joyful in their King. 3 O let them unto his great name give praises in the dance; Let them with timbrel and with harp in songs his praise advance. 4 For God doth pleasure take in those that his own people be: And he with his salvation the meek will beautify. 5 And in his glory excellent let all his saints rejoice: Let them to him upon their beds aloud lift up their voice. 6 Let in their mouth aloft be rai'd the high praise of the Lord, And let them have in their right hand a sharp two edged sword; 7 To execute the vengeance due upon the Heathen all, And make deserved punishment upon the people fall. 8 And ev'n with chains, as pris'ners, bind their Kings that them command; Yea, and with iron fetters strong, the nobles on their land. 9 On them the judgment to perform found written in his word: This honour is to all his saints. O do ye praise the Lord. PSALM CL. 1 Praise ye the Lord. God's praise within his sanctuary raise; And to him in the firmament of his pow'r give ye praise. 2 Because of all his mighty acts, with praise him magnify. O praise him as he doth excel in glorious majesty. 3 Praise him with trumpet's sound; his with psaltery advance; [Praise 4 With timbrel, harp, string'd instruments, and organs, in the dance. 5 Praise him on cymbals loud; him praise on cymbals sounding high. 6 Let each things breathing praise the Lord, Praise to the Lord give ye. Schedule State of Maryland Dorchester County Ss: On this twenty sixth day of October 1820, personally appear ed in open court being a court of record which proceeds according to the course of the common law with jurisdic tion to an unlimited amount for the said county- Zadock Harvey aged seventy one years resident in Dorchester ter County in said State who being first duly sworn, ac cording to law, doth on his oath declare, that he served in the Revolutionary War as follows: in the Second Company of the fifth Maryland Regiment the date of the original declaration is, in Feby. or March 1818 the number of the pension certificate now in his possession is 309-and I do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th March 1818; and that I have not, since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War" passed on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not nor has any person in trust for me, any property, or securities contracts, or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the Schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. A pension of Forty dollars per year from the State of Maryland. 1 Cow & 1 Heifer, 2 Small Hogs, 4 old chairs } [Note written vertically in right 2 old Tables, 1 Tub & 2 piggins, 1 Iron pot } margin] valued by the Court 2 old Coffee pots, a small quantity of earthen ware } exclusive of the State a few knives & forks, 1 old plough } pension to $40.00 4 Hoes & 2 axes, 4 Hens, Rooster & a few } chickens, and 1 old cupboard } My occupation is that of a Farmer, but from affliction & old age am not able to do hard labour, I have (including myself) eleven in family, viz, my wife Mary aged about thirty nine years infirm, eight children viz (Polly)

Rev.&1812 Wars Section MMHF November 8, 1929. Honorable Cordell Hull, House of Representatives, Washington, D. C. My dear Mr. Hull: In response to your letter of November 6, 1929, I have the honor to advise you that the Revolutionary War records of this bureau fail to afford any information in regard to Luke Steinsborg. However, since numerous inquiries have been made relative to the schedule of property of the Revolutionary War soldier Luke Stansbury, it is presumed he might be the soldier in question. In the Revolutionary War pension claim of Luke Stansbury (W.165) he stated in April 1824 that he had no income other than the schedule he named which was - one mare, one cow, and calf, four hogs, some chairs, some household furniture, some tools, but no land of his own. In 1825 he stated that he had sold the said mare to aid in the support of himself and family. Very truly yours, EARL D. CHURCH, Commissioner.

1812 Wars Section. November 4, 1929. Honorable Kenneth McKellar, United States Senate, Washington, D. C. My dear Senator: In response to your letter of October 26, 1929, with one herewith returned, from Mr. M. S. Wyrick of Crab Orchard, Tennessee, I have the honor to advise you in the Revolutionary War pension claim of Luke Stansbury (W.165) he stated in April 1824 that he had no income other than the schedule he named which was - one mare, one cow and calf, four hogs, some chairs, some household furniture, some tools, but no land of his own. In 1825 he stated that he had sold the said mare to aid in the support of himself and family. Very truly yours, EARL D. CHURCH Commissioner.

my stock of Hogs and Cattle; the same to be equally Divided betwixt them to their use and disposal forever, wishing it remembered at the same time that I do not consider the Cow call- ed old Silk and her increase as belonging to me. She being the private property of my Daughter Lucy Griffin given to her by her aunt, though in my mark and brand. Item: I give and bequeath unto my Son Bruner Griffen my riffled gun to his use and disposal forever. And lastly it is my will and desire that my Beloved wife Elizabeth Griffin, my Brother James Griffin, and my Son John Griffin, Be and they are hereby appointed, and declared to be the Executrix and Executors of this my last will and Testament. In witness whereof I have hereunts [not sure] set my hand and seal this twenty-sixth day of November in the year of our Lord One Thousand Eight Hundred and Nine. Signed Sealed published and Declare by the above named Samuel Griffin to be his last will and testament in presence of us who have here unto subscribed our names as witnesses in the Presence of the Testator. Saratoga County Ss. John Palmeton of the Town of Orange County of Saratoga being by me duly Sworn on the holy Evangelist of the Almighty God deposeth and Saith that the Applicant, Benjamin Palmeton is his Brother, and that he actually enlisted in Capt Jerusha Stantons company in Cap Seth Warners Regiment and actually served fourteen months, & that the said Benjm Enlisted in said company & Regiment on the 15th of September in the year 1775, and that this Deponent served in the same Company and Regiment with the Applicant Benjm Palmeton for the term stated in his declaration, and that he the said Benjamin was actually in the Battles as stated in his declaration, and actually knows the said Benjamin to be very Poor and under the Most distressed and [illegible] circumstances, with a family to maintain and no means to Support himself and family, but by his day labour John Palmeton Sworn & subscribed before me this firth day of July 1819 Abraham Moe Saratoga County Ss. Benjamin Palmeton of the Town of Wells Town [Nelliston] in the County of Montgomery being by me duly Sworn on the holy Evangelist of Almighty God, Deposeth and Saith that he is assurred of no kind of property whatever, not so much as a cow to furnish his family with a little milk and has no other means of helping himself and family to support, but by his day labours, and is actually in a suffering cituation [situation] Benjamin Palmeton his x mark Sworn and Subscribed before me this 5th day of July 1819 Abraham Moe

State of Pennsylvania Dauphin County On this 11th day of September 1820 personally appeared in open Court. being a Court of record for said State Samuel Kearsley aged 70 years on the 15th [illegible] and resident in the County aforesaid who being duly sworn according to law doth depose and Say that he was a soldier in the revolutionary War. that he first marched as a volunteer in the Company of Captain John Steel in december 1776. That he was afterwards commissioned a Captain at the instance of General Washington. and raised a Company of Regulars to serve three years or during the War. - that he was also a Volunteer at the time of taking the Hessians at Trenton -and in the fall of 1779 was obliged to retire from the service in consequence of the peculiarly distressed State of his family - And I do solemnly swear that I was a resident Citizen of the United States, on the 18th Day of March 1818. and that I have not since that time by gift, sale, or in any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof with intent thereby So to diminish it. at the bring my self within the provisions of an act of Congress entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War." passed on the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not nor has any person in trust for me, any property, or securities, contracts or debts due to me, nor have I any income other than the pension heretofore allowed me, but what is contained in the schedule of property hereto annexed and by me subscribed- Sworn & declared in open Court this 10th day of September 1820 John Machesney Pootky No. 20 Sam Kearsley Schedule of property owned by me being all the property I. possess 1 House aged about 14 years worth about $30, an old cow - 2 pigs one month old. some poultry. an old Bureau. 10 or 11 old chairs. a Rifle Gun. a few good Books. including a family Bible. and some military authors. an old looking Glass. a few prints of the pilgrims progress in frame - an old silver Watch - one or two old waitersr, an old braekfast table. a pair of old brass candlesticks. some cups & saucers- tea pot & some other culinary articles of Kitchen furniture of small value. some emty flour casks one containing a little flour recently purchased. an old umbrella covered the second time - a case of Razors. an axe. a Dining fork. an old Shovel. two old hoes. a mattock and spade. a crook shovel & tongs. some vessels to salt my provisions in. a soap barrel. an old fishing Rod and hooks an old Cowskin. a cane, a ten plate stove. an old pair Iron and [illegible] a mans and womans saddle and bridles,. an old [illegible], an old powder horn and shot pouch. - I have a wife and 5 children all of whom are married and I reside on a small farm on lot of 5 acres of land which I. cultivate. the rent whereof cost me $40. per annum. - my youngest daughter whose husband has left her. and gone to the army. live with me and I support her and her three children. my certificate of pension is dated 31st March 1818. - Sworn to and declared in open Court on the 11th day of September 1820. - John Machesney Prothy Sam.. Kearsley

COMMONWEALTH OF MASSACHUSETTS. COUNTY of Hampden Ss On this twenty eighth day of August 1820, personally appeared in open court, before the Circuit Court of Common Pleas the same being a Court of Record and so established by a Statute of said Commonwealth, said Court being now in session at Springfield within and for said county of Hampden John Gaylord aged fifty five years resident in Westfield in said County of Hampden who being first duly sworn, according to law, doth, on his oath, declare that he served in the Revolutionary War as follows: Capt John Burnham's company in Col Michael Jackson's Regiment being the eighth regiment in the Massachusetts line three years My original declaration was made, I believe the twenty eighth day of April 1818. Living pension certificate is numbered 3070 there are residing with me my wife Jane Gaylord aged about fifty eight who is afflicted with the Dropsy who has not been able to do an ordinary days work these six years she is always much bloated & is often helpless My daughter Margaret aged eighteen & my son James Henry age sixteen - I am by occupation a farmer, but in consequence of a severe turn of the pleurisy I am unable to work & the Rheumatism is constantly upon me, so that I lie upon my bed, in the same positions for the space of five minutes at one time being a resident citizen of the United States 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, since that time by gift, sale, or in any manner disposed my property or and [illeg] Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War" passed on the 18th of March 1818 [illeg] I have not, nor has nay person in trust for me, any property, or securities, [illeg] or debts, due to me; nor hav I any income, other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. SCHEDULE. six sheep one chest one pig one flat iron 12 Crop of Hay two or three articles of crockery 2 old tables two pails one stand nine chairs a few articles of his bellow ware 1 set of knives & forks one shovel & [illeg] two rakes the hatchet for flax one sickle & one scythe ten harrow [illeg] one hammeraxe six cyder barrels two kegs two wash tubs one pitch fork some corn & potatoes one Whipple tree & chains John Gaylord Sworn to and declared on the twenty Eighth day of August before the Circuit Court of Common Pleas Attest John Ingersoll Clerk I John Ingersoll Clerk of the Circuit Court of Common Pleas for the County aforesaid do hereby certify, that the foregoing oath and the schedule hereto annexed, are truly copied from the record of the said court, and I do further certify, that it is the opinion of said court that the total amount in value of the property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule is thirty seven Dollars and fifty tow In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and affixed the seal of aid Court, on this twenty ninth day of August 1820 John Ingersoll Clerk of the Court for the County of Hampden

STATE OF VERMONT. Caledonia COUNTY SS. At a County Court, began and holden Danville within and for said County on the first Monday of June 1A. D. 1820. Present in Court, the Hon. Isaiah Fisk Chief Judge. William Cahoon & John W. Dana Esqr Assistant Judges On this 9th day of June 1820, personally appeared in open Court (being a Court of Record, with a jurisdiction unlimited in point of amount, and having the power of fine and imprisonment) Abel Conant aged Sixty four years, resident in Hardwick in said County, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath declare, that he served in the Revolutionary War as follows: - to wit in the Regiment of Col William Prescott in the Company of Capt. Reuben Dow & [blank] Morse in the Massachusetts line a private that he made his first declaration for a pension on the eighth day of April 1818 and has received his pension from that to the 4th March of the present year on a pension Certificate numbered 10,794 And I do solemnly swear, that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March, 1818, and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled ""An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War,” passed on the 18th day of March, 1818 and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed .
