And that I have not since that time (or at any other time [point crossed out] of my life) by gift sale or in any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof with intent thereby so to diminish it asto[as to] bring myself with in the provisions of an Act of Congress entitled an Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land & naval service of the United States in the revolutionary War passed on the 18th day of March 1818 And that I have not nor has any person in trust for me any property securities contracts or debts due to me nor have I any income other than that contained in the schedule hereunto annexed & by me subscribed, nor have I disposed of any of my property in any manner or for any purpose since or long before the 18th March 1818, except to a very small amount which was applyed[applied] to the payment of some little demands against me. I did not know of any law allowing pensions to old soldiers till about three years past and was told I was obliged to swear I could not live without it before it would be allowed me & wishing to live without being an expense to my Country have been the reasons which have prevented my previous application for a pension. My property consists of 1 horse & mare both 13 years old, 1 Negro man about fifty years old & infirm 4 Cows, 4 Calves. 2 heifer & 1 Steer, 2. Sons, 13 shoats & 4 pigs John H Ragland Mark[x above] my wife is dead I have three boys living with me the oldest 18 years ole the next 15. the next 12 my ocupation[occupation] is a farmer. I am unable from age & infirmity to do any thing of consequences-- I owe about $100. John Ragland mark[x above]

First duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the provisions made by the Act of Congress of the 18th March 1818 and the first of May 1820 that he the said William Isham enlisted for during the war in the year 1777 in the State of Connecticut in the Company commanded by Capt Allen, afterwards commanded by Capt Stilwell in Col Samuel Willis' regiment in the line of the State of Conecticutt [Connecticut] on the continental establishment that he continued to serve in said Corps until the Year 1783. When he was discharged from the said service at West Point in the State of New York and was regularly discharged. His discharge was sent to the Secretary of War with his first declaration, his pension certificate is No. 11225 that his name has been placed on the pension list and dropt [dropped] therefrom on account of his property. And in pursuance of the Act of the First May 1820 I do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March 1818, and that I have not since that time by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property or any part thereof, with the intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War ____ 18 March 1818, and that I have not nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities, contracts, or debts due to me nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed One cow, 1 yearling Heifer 1 fire pail Iron kettle 2 old kitchen chairs, 1 old chest, 1 pair old handirons 1 old shovel and tongs 1 old kitchen table. I have no real estate. The two 2 year old hefiers [heifers] and the yearling bull mentioned in my first and second schedule were long since disposed of the pay for the expenses of the sickness of my wife who is now dead. And I cannot now reccolect [recollect] the exact sum I received on the articles for them but I think I received the pay in grain and turned it out to pay for necessaries. In my first

pension roll of any states and I hereby declare that I have subscribed the foregoing with my mark, by reason of total inability from the [illegible] to hold a pen. Nathaniel (his mark) Judson Sworn to and subscribed on the day and year aforesaid Christian W Shear, Justice of the Peace and one of the justices of Justice Court of the city of Albany. I, William Longhead, a Clergyman and pastor of the Third Presbyterian Church in the City of Albany and residing in said city, hereby certify that I am well acquainted with Nathaniel Judson, who hath subscribed and sworn to the above declaration, that I believe him to be seventy eight years and upward of age, that he is reputed and believed in the neighborhood where he resides, to have been a soldier in the Revolution and that I concur in that opinion. William Lochead, Pastor of [illegible] Sworn to and subscribed before the Justices Court of the City of Albany in open court. I G Watson, Clerk I, Silas Booth, formerly of Stratford in Connecticut, now of the city of Albany, do hereby certify and declare on oath that I am well and intimately acquainted and have been for fifty years last past,, with Nathaniel Judson who hath subscribed and sworn to the above and foregoing declaration, that I am personally knowing to the greater part of the facts therein stated to be true, and that from my intimate knowledge of the said Nathaniel as a person of truth and veracity, I believe all the facts stated therein to be true. Silas Booth, aged 73 years and upwards Subscribed and sworn in open court, I G Watson, Clerk

State of Maine Somerset County, SS. On this twenty seventh day of June, 1820, I personally appeared in open court before the Justice of the Circuit Cout of Common Pleas, for the Counties of Lincoln, Kennebec and Somerset, being a Court of Record for said Counties, proceeding according to the course of the common law, having original jurisdiction, unlimited in amount keeeping a record of their proceedings, and having the power of fine and imprisonment, Ebenezer Hilton aged sixty six years, resident in Anson in the County of Somerset within said Circuit, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth, on his oath, declar that he served in the Revolutionary war as follows, viz. in the Compay commanded by Captain Samuel McCobb and Regiment commanded by Colonel Nixon of the line of Sate of Massachusetts upon the Continental Establishement, for the period of more than one year that his original declaration was made before Judge Weston on the twenty second day of April 1818; that he is now on the Maine Roll, and that his pension certificate is numbered 6,030. And I, the said Ebenezer Hilton do solemnly swear, that I was a resident citizen of the United States, on the eighteenth day of March, one thousand eight hundred and eighteen; and that I have not, since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner whatever, disposed of my property, or any part therof, with intent therby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled, "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War," passed on the eighteenth day of March, one thousand eight hundred and eighteen; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts, due to me; nor have I any income, other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. [signed] Ebenzer Hilton The following is a Schedule of my whole Estate and income, necessary clothing and bedding excpted, viz: one horse of the value of twenty dollars, one yoke of young [illegible] of the value of thirty dollars, 2 cows and 2 calves of the value of twenty eight dollars, 1 two year old heifer of the value of eight dollars, 2 yearlings of the value of eight dollars, 6 sheep and 4 lambs of the value of twelve dollars, 2 swines of the value of six dollars, farming utensils of the value of nine dollars, 1 cart and wheels of the value of fifteen dollars, 1 horse waggon of the value of thirty dollars, old house hold furniture (besides bedding) twenty dollars. I have debt due me which may be collected to the amount of ten dollars. I owe as much as one hundred dollars, the income derived from the above property and a life lease of the farm and buildings where I now live does not exceede fifty dollars a year. My family consists of four persons, myself, my wife Abigail age sixty two years, feeble health and under the doctors care for the most part of the time. My daughter Anna aged thirty years and my daughter Abigail aged twenty [illegible] years. Except the above and my [illegible string of words] estate or income whatever [signed ]Ebenezer Hilton

Pennsylvania John Patridge, Private 1780, was aged 75 years by occupation a farmer unable to pursue the same by reason of lameness. Wife very old Ground [illegible] 1 Schedule dated 19 Sep 1820 contains 200 acres of land for which he was to pay $2 per acre. He states that he duly paid $40 on the same. 2 Horses 1 Colt, 1 Cow 2 [illegible] 3 Calves, one sow 9 pigs, 8 sheep household furniture total amount in value of the property exhibited $92. Schedule under the act of March 1 1823 contains the same property as exhibited in his 1 Schedule except the two hundred acres of land. He states that not being able to comply with the contract made for the said land he gave it up to the Agent of the population company for the purchase money. See the Affidavit of Enoch Marvin filed within in which he states that the applicant and his son William purchased of him on the 27 April 1817, as agent for Wm Griffith & John B Wallace a tract of land containing 400 acres for the sum of $800 with interest thereon from the 1st 1818 payable in annual instalments of $100 the last of which payment will be due on the 1 Apl 1825, that a deed was made on the day of purchase to the sd John & Wm Patridge jointly and there Bond and Mortgage taken for the amount of the purchase money. He further states that the sum of $40 only in part of interest on the said Bond & Mortgage only has been paid and that there remains unpaid $800 & interest of $105.33

[illegible] Town Aug 20 1844 Hon M.[?] Edwards D Sir I was prevented yesterday, a gentleman having came in the office, from stating to you, the distress of the petitioner her declaration presents her affliction, being very old and destitute of everything needful, being so extremely poor & helpless -- your kind attention to her claim will merit many thanks from him as it is the first & may be the last I have to present -- I trust you will pass the claim as soon as convincing for you to take it up -- for which I will be exceedingly indebted to you. Yours Respectfully Claim of Mary McDowell, Calhoun Mason Deringer

Mr. Joseph Davis Esqr. Sir Henry Bakeman the bearer says he served as a soldier in the revolutionary war and I am persuaded his infirmity and extreme indigence justly entitles him to the bounty of government. I have therefore assisted him in preparing a statement of his situation and directed him to you for further aid. Peter Lehinsk [see comments] Henry Bakeman at the age of 16 years in the year 1781 enlisted in the United States service under Capt. Benj. Pierce of the Infantry (who now lives in Albany) in a Regt. commanded by Col. Willett at Stone Arabia in the state of New York. with home I served one year and was then placed under Capt. Cannon in the same Regt. under whom I continued during the war Was in a skirmish with the Indians near Fort Plaine- was in an expedition again at Oswego (which failed) in which I had my feet frozen and remain a cripple to this day in consequence thereof - at the close of the war I received a regular discharge at Poughkeepsie. I am a cooper by profession and posessed [possessed] of the following property to wit. Real estate none personal. exclusion of necessary wearing afford and hedring as follows 1 cow 1 two year old heifer 7 sheep 1 calf 3 hogs - Tools as follows 2 jointers 3 shaves 1 jack plaine [plane]. I have 1 saw old cross cut saw. 1 old Froe. 1 broad ax. 1 narrow ax 1 old hart ax. 1 compass 1 breast bit. 1 croze. 1 old chain 4 feet long. 6 small match plains. - about 1 M. pine staves. 2 salt barrels 1 4 pail kettle 2 small .do. 2 small pots 2 tea kettles 1 Trammel. 6 Plates 1 Platter 6 Knives & Forks 1 Chest 4 Botls. Eels. Debts due me as follows Note against Silas[?] Brackete of 60 dollars who abscinded five years ago. James F Wright about $15.00 insolvent. John Finkle $4.00 Zadoc Allen $4.00 Wm & James rec. Pas land $20.00 (as near as I can recollected) I am Indebted as Follows of Thadeus M. Wood. $97.00. Thommas R. Gold $100. Alvin Branson $36.00- Daniel Folley $23.00. Benj. Bakeman $150.00 Fischer Eastes $21.00 (as near as I can remember). My Family consists of the following persons my wife aged 53 years, infirm: my Daughter Laney 17 years old in good health. Rachel 14 in good health my Son Andrew 10 my Daughter Mary 8 my Grand Son John 2 years all in good health.

of Mjr. Michael Dickson and continued with Genl. Cortland County Freetown New York Act 10th 1833 As this is the third declaration drafted and forwarded me for the same applicant an explanation may be necessary first was made soon after the Act of June 1832 was passed I had then but very little knowledge of the regulations of the War Department on that subject that application was of course defective in several material points the second was taken in open court in this county I think about a year ago also without the proper understanding of your regulations as I had not seen them before I went in to court with the applicant near the close of its siting I did not then understand that the clergymans certificate was indispensible or that a reason must be assigned why it was not obtained I am well acquainted with the clergyman of our vicinity and will venture to say (and would as [illegible] had he been at hame this [illegible] from conversations with him on the subject but did I then understand that so much particularity was necessary in the history of his services. Considering the good character of the applicant and his very necessitous circumstances and his bodily infirmity it was thought proper to make and other application some additional particulars have been obtained from him but I cannot deny that this relation of his services is not as full as I could with I presume nothing more particular will ever be obtained He seems to be almost lost to all the other events of his early life as to his services in the Revolution. I think it not probable that any better [illegible] part of his declaration can ever be obtained [illegible] to increase from adjoining neighborhoods the number of certificates of which I am convinced ought be close. His hoped that all the circumstances of his and almost helpless man who is dependent on the companion of his youth for support will be relieved from the strong hand of poverty that sometimes bean heavily on him Please direct to Freetown Corners Abraham Aker Agent for the applicant

where the army was stationed - he was again sent back to Hartford for another load which he conveyed to White Plains and (and is crossed out) soon after his arrival with this last load, the army took up a march for the south - this claimant under Captain Roswell Ransom of the Congress Regiment under Colonel Ante the troops marched through the Eastern part of New York through New Jersey passing through Princeton, and Trenton, through (Downtown is crossed out) Philadelphia , and Wilmington, - and arrived at Elkstown in Maryland in the month of October 1781 at this place this applicant was taken sick and continued so for the space Blue Mountain the mean time the body of the army proceeded to Yorktown, Virginia, took the army of Lord Cornwallis and the regiment of Colonel Antle to which this applicant belonged returned to Elkstown from whence they proceeded by the route above described to White Plains from where they started at which place they arrived in the month of December 1781 this applicant then discharged having served nine months the town of his enlistment. The claimant had no documentary evidence of his service or discharge nor does he know of any person whose testimony he can procure who can testify to his service. There is no resident clergyman near the applicant. He hereby relinquished every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present and declare that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any state. Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid Julius Tozer J P Bull

in the course of one or two days, that in consequence of the distress and loss of his father, said Daniel Hunt was permitted to return home as above stated, having been in service from the year prior 1779 to March 1781; that he did not receive any written discharge on leaving the service but was verbally told he might go home to take care of his Father and family, that all or nearly of his associates in army on the occasion alluded to, are either dead or removed to distant States and he does not know that it is now in his power to finish his service positively by any one except by Capt Andrew Carson of the County of Iredell in North Carolina and Robert Hearn, Esqr for the County Rowan. These persons will be seen and their depositions will be here to annexed if the facts stated can be positively proved by them. The Rev'd Richard Parks, a clergyman of the Methodist Episcopal Church and resident in the County of Surry: and Daniel Cockerham, a citizen of said County have heard the said Daniel Hunt (illegible) of his service in the revolutionary war and his statements are hereto annexed. And in reply to the interrogatories suggested by the Secretary of war the said Daniel Hunt returns the following answers - 1. Where and what year were you born? Answer., I was born the year 1761 in Rowan

And that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts due to me, nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed. That it is utterly impossible for this Deponent to give a particular account of the changes that have been made in his property since the 18th day of March 1818- that he has never since that time owned any real estate. That being a farmer by occupation, he has always had a team consisting of a spare of horses- that since that time he has not sold a horse, but has lost by sickness and disease five horses and two colts and has managed so as to purchase others in their place so as to keep a team to work with. That this deponent has during the said time some times owned one, some times two and some times three cows and never over three. That this Deponent during said time has never owned more than thirty sheep in any year. That the past season this deponent owned twenty eight sheep but was obliged to sell and dispose of them in September last to pay a Physician's bill for attending upon the wife of this deponent who has been insane and helpless for the last three years. That this deponent at this time owns but four sheep. his Isaac x Morehouse mark Sworn to and declared on the eighth day of December 1831, in the court of common pleas of the County of Washington in the State of New York, in open Court, held at the court house in the town of Kingsbury

Grafton SS November 2nd 1830 Personally appeared David Choate Jn and made oath that the foregoing affidavit by him subscribed is true. before me [signed] George Conant Justice Peace We Grover Burnham Daniel Gile and Amos Morse near neighbours of David Choate do depose and say that we have many years been well acquainted with said David Choate and his family one member of which his daughter Eunice has been suffering with illness for the share of twelve or fifteen years past that she has been most of the time, confined and under the care of Physicians, which we believe to have been one cause of his present reduced circumstances - He has also been a sufferer by the loss of property such as two horses and one cow within the last few years. besides which the state of his own health has been latterly infirm, more especially for the space of eighteen months past. His wife has become so far worn down with the care of her sick daughter, that she is incapable of rendering him much aid in his distress [signed] Grover Burnham [signed] Daniel Gile [signed] Amos Morse Grafton SS November 20th 1830 Sworn to before me - [signed] George Conant Justice Peace

District of Massachusetts, ss: On this 3d day of July 1820; Personally appeared in open Court before the Circuit Court of Common Pleas, begun and holden at Lenox, within and for the County of Berkshire, is the Western Circuit, on the 4th Monday of June 1820, the same Court, being a Court of records for said Circuit; proceeding according to the course of the common Law, with a jurisdiction, unlimited in point of amount, keeping a record of its proceedings, and having the power of fine and imprisonment. Cromwell Luther - aged Sixty years, resident in Pittsfield in the County of Berkshire aforesaid, who being first duly sworn, according to law, doth on his oath declare, that he served in the Revolutionary war as follows; that he enlisted in the company commanded by Captain Wills Clift in the regiment commanded by Colonel Samuel Willis in the line of the State of Connecticut on the Continental establishment. That his original declaration is dated April 21-1818. and that his pension certificate is numbered 1,706-- And I do solemnly swear, that I was a resident Citizen of the United States, on the 18th day of March, 1818, and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale or in any manner disposed of my property, or any part thereof with intent, thereby as to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an Act of Congress entitled "An Act to provide for certain persons, engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary war", passed on the 18th day of March, 1818, and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities, contracts or debts, due to me, nor have I any income, other than what is contained in the schedule, hereto annexed, and by me subscribed--schedule of property, necessary clothing and bedding excepted--to wit: Thirty three & one half acres of land with a dwelling house and Barn thereon----------$410.00 Two cows & one steer two years old------49.50 one hog--------------------------------------4.50 one plough-----------------------------------3.00 one wooden clock----------------------------4.00 one small Looking Glass----------------------.37c Iron ware--------------------------------------4.00 Crockery ware----------------------------------.66 Six chairs---------------------------------------1.75 one chest----------------------------------------.50 one table----------------------------------------.50 Draft chain------------------------------------1.37c Two shovels-----------------------------------1.00 one Dung fork---------------------------------.75 one set [illegible - tokas] chairs---------------.40 --------------- $482.39 The Real Estate within mentioned I purchased in Jan'y 1820 - I now two hundred forty one Dollars for the home, and I have no means of paying the said sum unless my pension should be continued. That I am by occupation a Labourer that I am afflicted with the Rheumatism so that I am unable to labour but a little part of my time - that the number of my family residing with me is four, that their names and ages are as follows: Esther Luther, my wife - aged fifty two years of feeble constitution - having had a shock of the palsy - Eliane Luther my son aged sixteen years - Maria Luther my Daughter fourteen years of age & Speedy Luther my Daughter aged seven years. that my said wife is wholly unable to help herself & has been so for seven years past-- (sign) Cromwell Luther Sworn to, and declared on the 3 -- day of July 1820, before the said Court -- Parker L. M S James Archibald Barry John Dolley Reuben L Gunter David Pratt This affidavit sworn to and Subscribed before me William James a Judge of Orleans County Court the 17th day of September in the year Lord one thousand Eight hundred and Thirty Three William James a Judge of Orleans County Courts I, William James a Judge of Orleans County Courts. Do hereby Certify that I am well acquainted with Uriah L. James, R. L. Gunn, Archibald Barry, John Dolley, and David Pratt a Clergyman, who have sworn to and Subscribed the foregoing affidavit and Certificate that I have been acquainted with them for a long time, that they are men of the first reputability as to truth and veracity and that these statements are entitled to credit and I do further state that I have been acquainted with John Ackerson the foregoing applicant who has sworn to the foregoing Declaration and I do believe that he is a man of truth and veracity and that he had served in the Army of the Revolution as he has stated in his Declaration and that he has been always since my acquaintance with him reputed to have been a Revolutionary Soldier in the Army as he States. Sworn to and subscribed before me this 7th Day of September AD. 1832 William James State of New York Orleans County Co On this 1st Day of September in the year of our Lord one thousand Eight hundred and thirty two personally appeared before me, William James one of the acting Judges the Court of Common pleas in and for the County of Orleans, aforesaid Maria Elizabeth Ackerson aged (74) years the 19th day of May 1832, who being first duly sworn according to law doth on her Oath make the following statement and declaration. She says she was born at a place Called Cobuskill [Cobleskill] about 10 miles from Old Schoharrie [Schoharie] then called Albany County sometime Livingstons Manor, that she was well acquainted with John Ackerson in the year our Lord 1775

I Benaiah Dore testify and say that since my pension has been suspended, and since the Schedule of my property was exhibited - I have been obliged to sell all my personal property except One Cow - one heifer & some small articles of household furniture - and a part of the Land exhibits in my Schedule - for the support of my family and to satisfy the demands of my creditors - the residue of the Land left is of so poor a quality that it will not sell for but a very small sum - I am not able to labour but in part of the time on account of Rheumatic complaint & being subject to faintness - My wife has not been able to perform any labour for the last year being confined with sickness & I have one one Son 13 yrs old who is not able to do any labour being subject to bleeding - my other children are healthy And I further say that if my pension should be withdrawn my family must suffer or be dependant [dependent] on private charity for support - Benaiah Dore X his mark

State of Tennessee ) Warren County ) This day being the 7th of October 1823 Personally appeared before me Jesse Coffee an acting justice of the peace in and for said County Jesse Billings who being first duly sworn Saith that he is a near neighbour [neighbor] of Reuben Roberts the person who claimes [claims] a pension of Government and knoweth the situation of his affairs and states that the property of said Roberts is as stated in his declaration of this day in court, he the said Billings does know of the cows dying and the destruct =ion of the sheep and that the saaid [said] Roberts is poor and has no property abbout him and ap;ears destitute, that he the said Billings has always understood that the land stated in the said declr =ration was the property of John Roberts and that he let his father live in it as he had some of his own that he has been [illegible] to it for upwards of four years and that 70 Acres is all the land that he or they ever claimed and further this deponent Saith not. Jessee Billings Sworn and Subscribed before me this day and date above Jesse Coffee Justice of the Peace

State of Tennessee ) Warren County ) This day being the 7th of October 1823. Personally appeared before me Jessee Coffee an acting Justice of the Peace in and for said county. John Roberts who being duly sworn according to law doth say that he purchased the land that his father Reuben Roberts gave in, in his Schedule sent to the war department, in the year 1817 of John Edwards of Warren County for two Hundred dollar paid in [illegible] & [illegible] his own property that is in a horse and cattle and a mans Saddle that he had the deed made to his father as he was a single man and did not know where he should be that he settled his father on it and went to Madison County Alabama State to work for George Laundes and lived with him about four years after this he returned and have lived on his own ever since and have a wife a child and supports the said Ruben Roberts his father who also lives on the same land the tract contains 70 acres and no more nor has father he or me had any other land in state of Tennessee and land John Roberts further says that his father has [illegible] the land to him as he said John so wished and [illegible] the said John says that he knew of no property that the said Reuben has other that that mentioned in his [illegible] in open Court this day and that he is in a helpless and destitute situation and unable to support himself and is now sick with the agues & [illegible]. Sworn & subscribed to before me the day & date Jesse Coffee Justice of the Peace John his x mark Roberts

debts he owed as they were stated. I have observed that many have been retained on the Pension List whose property was much more in amount then Mr. White. Their infoities (sic) I am convincerd could not exceed his. Believe me Sir, that if there are any of the Revolutionary Patriots who are deserving of the Pension M. White is among them, as well on account of the infirmities of body and consequently a total incapacity to provide a support for himself and family which oft-times suffer much. As on the Score of services to gain our Independance. At the time Mr White made his application last Summer he had 2 cows that he had been able keep by the assistance of the Pension: but since then he has been compelled by the cries of hunger to sell them both besides many other articles that were surrendered for the purpose of getting bread for himself & equally helpless family. His situation that of the family appear fully by his statement under oath. The charity of his neighbors has done much to relieve the sufferings of this truly deserving Patriot The enclosed representation is Signed by persons of respectability being all ^of them intimately acquaint

I was born Feb, 18 1746, am now 74 years old and in addition to the ordinary infirmities of old age, am afflicted with a Hernia and subject to violent attacks of Rheumatism, a few weeks since I had a severe shock of numb palsy, by which I am deprived of the use of my limbs and rendered helpless and wholly unable to work at my trade which is that of a weaver. I have no dependence but on public charity or the bounty of my country. My family is a wife 71 years old + quite infirm. I have no other estate or income than that contained in the foregoing schedule nor any debts due me. I served in the Militia in 1775, 76 + 77 and in the later part of 1777 I enlisted into the army of the Revolution for the term of three years as a carpenter and entered the service in the company of Capt. John Wood of Westborough in this Commonwealth in Col: Hay's Regt. in which I served till the summer of 1779 when I left that Company, by enlisting for during the war and entered the Company of Capt. Andrew Moody, in the 2.d_ N. York Regt. of Artillery under Col. John Lamb in which I served as a matross till my discharge, June 9th, 1783. teste S. Minot Edmund E. Hill (his mark) Essex ss July 13. 1820. Then the abovenamed Edmund E. Hill made oath that the said schedule and statement by him subscribed are true before me . Stephen Minot Judge of said court

Sworn and subscribed to in open court the day and year aforsaid Abraham Hiley Me David Quick a Clergyman residing in the County of Derry in the state of Indiana and Presley Hall residing in the same hereby Certify, that we are well acquainted with Abraham Hiley, who has subscribed and sworn to the above declaration and believed in the neighborhood where he resides to have been a soldier of the Revolution, and we concur in that opinion. Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforsaid in open court David Quick Presley Hall And the said court do hereby declare their opinion after the investigation of the matter, and after putting the Interrogatories prescribed by the war department, that the above named applicant was a Revolutionary Soldier and [illegible] as he states, and the court further Certifies that it appears to them David Quick who has signed the proceeding Certificate is a Clergyman resident in the County of Derry, and that Presley Hall, who has also signed the same, is a resident of the county aforsaid, and is a Credible person, and that their statement is entitled to credit. I, Soloman Lamb Clerk of the Circuit and Probate courts of Derry county State of Indiana do hereby Certify, that the foregoing contains the original proceedings of said court, in the matter of the application of Abraham Hiley, for a pension testimony whereof I have hereunto with my hand and seal of office, this 12th day of November, in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and thirty three Solomon Lamb Ck

D. Sir, I send you the documents of Mrs L. Morgan, which I hope will be satisfactory to Mr Edwards- I supposed that the marriage was sufficiently proved by the testimony of the affidavits of Curtis & the minister at Berlin, and thru the entry on her Bible was mainly circumstantial & in addition to the other testimony - Mr Curtis was an officer & in the army with Galpin I was at Berlin when & when Galpin was married & that he Galpin immediately returned to the Army remained their, till he was discharged- Goodrich the minister now of Berlin swore that he knew the minister who married Galpin that the minister has been dead more than 30 years, & that upon inquiry & search no record of the marriage can be found the reason that they must have been lost or destroyed. Two other witness, old men who resided there knew of the marriage at the time & it was while our Galpin was in the army & that they knew both Mr & Mrs Galpin well - the leaf of Mrs Morgan Bible carry evidence upon His face, that they are genuine & what she represents them to be, and was taken from an old record which is lost.- Mrs Morgan is my only feeble & very destitute and I think her case is a clear one & that she is well deserving of a Pension & you will please forward the papers to E. W. Walbridge June 29, 1877

State of New York Rensselaer County ss Ebenezer W. Walbridge of the Village of Lansingburgh in the County of Rensselaer aforesaid Counselor at Law, being duly sworn, doth depose & say, that he is well acquainted with Widow Lucy Morgan, that he first became acquainted with her in the year one thousand eight hundred and one at Lansingburgh aforesaid where she then & now resides, that when this Deponent, first knew her she was the widow of Jehial Galpin deceased; that on the twenty sixth day of July one thousand eight hundred and five, she was married again to Jonas Morgan Esqr of Lansingburgh and lived with him until the 7th day of October one thousand eight hundred & twenty four. And the said Lucy has never remarried and is now unmarried. When he died and this deponent was at the funeral of the said Jonas Morgan, and he was also present at the time when the said Jonas Morgan was married to the said Lucy Galpin, and now Lucy Morgan the widow of the said Jonas Morgan deceased - And this deponent further says that Mrs Lucy Morgan is a person of good character a poor Christian woman and much respected & esteemed by all her acquaintances. She is gotten needy & destitute & has been for some time, and becoming quite infirm, she has always been a very industrious and prudent person and well deserving of a better living, better than she has had for several years past.-- she has a daughter aged about fifty years, who has always lived with her mother, and is & has been for

AND I do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March, 1818, and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled, ""An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary war," passed on the 18th day of March, one thousand eight hundred and eighteen: and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed, to wit: Real Estate, None Bureal Estate as follows - a small wooden building or dwelling house to be given up at the experation of the lease one feather bed 2 [illegible] heads 20 two Beacons 12 one Dog Chans 6 One Rdy Coupet 5 two plandous [illegible shovel] tongs 4 the one Cooking Stove 10 One cot & two bedsteads - 5 Coll Kitchen furniture 10 one old walsh 6 70 And I do further certify that my family consists of my wife Rachel aged 58 years who is infirm, one daughter [illegible] aged 17 years and in orphan child aged twelve years and a very aged helpless mother in law when I have entirely to support. and faith that I have for six years been sorely afflicted with a rupture and for years with a general [illegible rity] attended with the sitting of God which has actively disabled me doing hard labor here now a Componing employment which affords a very scanty Substence and soon frequently disqualified from doing any business by bodily weakness so that I know not how long I shall be able to attend to and employment at all and that my debts amount to three hundred and twenty eight dollars which I am bound to pay and that the debts due come amount to the sum of Sixty one Dollars same are doubtful.- John Gaffit Sworn in open Court this 1 day of July 1820 Benjin Ferris CLK

Mansfield March 25th 1822- This certifies whom it may concern, that Mr Ezra Fuller of Mansfield in the County of Windham & State of Conct is man of correct morals and sober habits - a man far advanced in life, being nearly Eighty years of age, of Slender constitution and infirm health - in needy and straightened circumstances being wholly destitute of real estate & possessed of no personal estate except a cow & a few article of necessary household furniture, scarcely worth naming - and in our opinion he is unable to support himself without assistance and is as justly entitled to public consideration as any man whose name now stands on the List of pensioners - Jno Saltes Caleb Trowbridge Fulman Stones Nesbit Smith Alfred Howes Nath. Levi Hotchkiss _ Lieut _ Connecticut. Enlisted as a Sergeant in July 1776 for 6 months on Douglass’ regiment appointed on Ensign 1st January 1777 in some regt. promoted to a Lieutenancy in 1779 in Col. Giles Russells regt Conn. line- resigned in June 1779 on account of ill health 1st Schedule 24th January 1825 1/2 of an old dwelling house worth ….100.00 3/4 Acre of land and half a barn…. 75.00 1 workshop…. 30.00 3 Acres of land…. 43.00 1 horse 20. cow 10. heifer 10…. 40.00 $288.00 No creditors mentioned. This is an application to be continued under Act 1 May 1820 his reasons for not applying sooner were that he had understood until lately, that it was necessary to be entirely destitute of property to obtain the benefit of said act. Informed that the amount of property exhibited, operated as a bar to his continuance- see letter to him, to the care of Cornelius Tuttle 11th March 1825. On the 17th August 1825 he exhibits a 2d Schedule in which he states that he has disposed of all his property to David Hotchkiss Junr. to pay his just debts, and that all he now possesses is a note of hand from the said David for Forty seven dollars. ($47) seven of which he has received. the property was sold at the prices annexed to each article in 1st Schedule amounting to $288.00 The evidence. my husband was in the battle of Brandywine, & of Springfield & of Connecticut farms, & many skirmishes which I have heard him mention. He was at Ash [illegible], Woodbridge Short-hills - Millstone & Boundbrook. He performed duties under Capt. McKoy along the Raritan & Millstone rivers. He was out on duty when the Pennsylvania troops revolted. I know he was in the public service as a soldier, under his company officers, every year after our marriage, until the war ended, & several months in each year. _ Beside his service under Captain Baily for 5 months. I sincerely believe he did not perform less than three months duty in any one year of the war, & that in the two first years after his five months service, he performed not less than four months service in each year: making all together, not less than 25 or 26 months of active faithful service. _ He was always called. Sergeant Kinnan, & I only believe he was a Sergeant throughout the war. He always wore upon his shoulders, tassels, or some badge, which privates did not wear, & which it was said, belonged to Sergeants. _ After the war closed, I lived with my husband in Baskingridge, till the year 1787, when we removed from New Jersey to Western Virginia, & settled on Tigers valley river, a branch of the Monongahela. In the year 1791 [inserted, two words:] May 13th the Indians fell upon us [inserted, two words:] at night murdered my husband & one child on the spot, badly wounded another child, & this child, a boy, older than the other, escaped. I was carried off by them a prisoner. When I was dragged out of the house, my infant had just been scalped, & lay gasping on the floor. _ My boy who escaped, has since been a soldier in the last war of 1812-- was wounded, & now is an invalid pensioner, under the name of Joseph Kinnan. _ I was carried a prisoner thro the wilderness, & remained a prisoner during 3 years & 3 months, on the Maumee river, near fort Wayne, from where I contrived to make my escape, & by the aid of a brother. I finally returned to my friends in Jersey, where I have lived till this time. _ The family bible, which contained a family record of the age of myself husband, as well as of the childen, was destroyed when my husband & children were massacred. I have never married since the massacre of my husband Joseph Kinnan, by the Indians. I am still his widow, am destitute, & poor, & aged, & not able to do much labor, were it not for kind friends, I know not how I should be supported, unless by the public. I humbly ask my Country for a pension, on account of the long & faithful revolutionary services of Joseph Kinnan, my decd husband, for whom I have often filled his knapsack with provisions & clothes, whilst he was cleaning his musket, to meet the enemy. Most of my husbands comrades in the revolution, have gone to the grave, & I fear I shall be able to find but few living witnesses of his militia services. _ Mrs Tone, a former nieghbor & friend of my youth, daughter of Capt McKoy, is living in Morris town, & Isaac Bedell also, who knew my husband in the war. John Hall also, was in McKoy's co. & lives a few miles from Morris town, & knew my husband in the war. My own residence, though in Somerset Co. is nearer to Morristown, than to Somerville, where the Somerset Court is held, which is the reason why I apply to the Morris Court as being much more convenient for myself & for Mrs. Tone & Mr Bedell, two of my witnesses The other witness, John Hall, is totally blind, & so infirm & helpless that he cannot travel only as he is supported by the arms of other persons. Mary X her mark Kinnan Sworn & subscribed in open Court, this 4th October, 1830 before me [Illegible] book By order of the Court Joseph Dalrimple Clerk

Webb Florida Mobile District In the name of God Amen. I Samuel Griffin of the lower Tensaw Settlement and District above mentioned being in body weak and indisposed, but of perfect and sound mind and memory- Blessed be the almighty God for the same. and knowing the uncertainty of life, have thought proper to make, publish and declare this my last will and testament in manner and form following. First I do give and recommend my soul into the hands of the almighty god, who gave it me. And my body to the Earth to be buried with decent Christian burial. I give and bequeath to my beloved wife Elizabeth Griffin my house and plantation together with the household furniture and farming utensils, to her use whilst she remains my widow and if she change her name or at her decease my will is that it be equally divided betwixt my sons Jogn Bruner and James Griffin to their use and disposal and I also give unto my said wife to her use and disposal forever my black mare. I give and bequeath unto my wife Elizabeth Griffin, my sons Jogn Bruner and James Griffin and my daughters Nancy, Elizabeth, Lucy, Hannah, Patsy and Polly Griffin all

not for Eight Hundred dollars as is therein exprefsed, but for five Hundred only--the word "Eight" being a mistake in coppying as this Deponent believed-- At that time he also owned another house and sold it to W. Bust and took his note which becomes due next Winter, as is mentioned in the Schedule hereto attached...At that time he also made a [illegible] of his personal chattles for which he realized about the sum of forty dollars--He also sold a cow for about eighteen dollars--that the monies arising from the Sale of the Lease aforesaid, and from the property aforesaid, was appropriated in the first place to the payment of debts which he owed in and about Schoharie, to Physicians and Merchants amounting to more than one hundred dollars, and for the purchase of a waggon to move to the County of Monroe, which waggon he now owns, and is mentioned in his Schedule aforesaid, and that the balance of his money which he received in his Goods and Lease aforesaid he appropriated to the purchase of the land mentioned in his schedule aforesaid--and he further says that the persons to whom he paid the sums of money have, some of them moved from Schoharie and this applicant lives at such a distance and is so destitute and helpless that he is unable to procure their affidavits of the payments and further this deponent saith not Beriah Stiles Sworn to and declared in open Court before the Judges of Common Pleas of Monroe County this 31st day of March 1830. H.B. Stanton Dept. Clk Monroe [Common stricken out] Com pleas

State of New York, Herkimer County} ss: On this sixth day of June one thousand eight hundred and forty-three personally appeared before the Court of Common Pleas of said County of Herkimer in open court before the Judges thereof the same being a Court of record John J. Kill who is in the fifty ninth year of his age and who being first duly sworn according to Law who on his oath makes the following supplemental declaration in order to obtain for the children and heirs of Polly Kill, deceased, the benefit of the provisions of the Act of Congress passed July 4th, 1836. That he is one of the children of Christopher Kill and Polly Kill, both deceased. That the said Christopher Kill, the father of this declarant in his lifetime was, as this declarant was always informed + believed, was a soldier in the service of the United States in the Revolutionary War in the Regiments of Col's. Willet, Clyde + Lamb +c.___ That his said father in his lifetime received a pension under the Law of the United States for his services in said war at the rate of Ninety-six dollars per year. That his said father + mother, the said Christopher Kill + Polly Kill, whose maiden name was Polly Nier when they were married as this deponent was always informed by them at Stone Arabia (then Tyron, now Fulton County) in the later part of the year 1782 by the Rev'd. Mr. Reese who was a clergyman of the Lutheran Church at that place and which information this declarant always believed and now believes to be true. That his said father + mother had nine children, two of whom died young + previous to the decease of his said father + mother. That his said father died about fourteen years ago last fall. That his death took place in the month of October. The day of which event this declarant cannot tell as he came to his death by drowning in the lock in the Erie Canal at Amsterdam in the County of Montgomery. That he left the said Polly Kill his widow him surviving. That the said Polly Kill died in the Town of Van Buren in the County of Onondaga. (continued on page 38 of this record.)

[handwritten] Christian Gobble is now about 77 years of age, was born in Pennsylvania. His father removed when he was so young he does not recollect it, to Baltimore County Maryland, then to Frederich county same state where he died. This applicant was then an apprentice to a saddler. The year New York was taken, this applicant enlisted at Tawney town about the 1st of June under Capt. Jacob Goode in the Reg commanded by Col Griffin of the Maryland troops called the flying Camp, enlisted for six months. Marched to New York and arrived there before it was taken by the British. From N York marched to Fort Washington then commanded by Col Bull. From Fort Washington marched to and was in the battle of the White plains. We went to reinforce Gen Wayne. After this battle marched to fort Lee under Capt. Bartman of the Maryland troop [indecipherable] to Fort Washington which was then attacked by the enemy. The fort was taken and this applicant with the other troops taken prisoners. In the fall the fort was taken and this applicant was kept in close confinement between tow and three months. He was then liberated from confinement on parole but was unable to walk from the suffering he had underwent in his imprisonment. He was carried from place to place and was able to reach his home about twelve months afterwards and he was not able to do any labor for six or seven months after reaching home. While a prisoner he was confined in N. York in what was called the Sugar house. A discharge was given to him at Tawneytown which has been lost. He was not exchanged for several years after he was taken prisoner [/handwritten]

In submitting the applications of Levi Munday and Courtland Kinsey, both of Woodbridge N.J., for pensions for revolutionary services, I wish to call the attention of the Commission to some facts & circumstances which, it seems to me, have a bearing, or should have, upon these cases. It is a well known fact that Lord Howe, the Commander of the British Army, established his headquarters on the Heights of Staten Island, which overlooks a very considerable extent of country, including the Township of Woodbridge, the residences of the two aged applicants. That he held this position until April 1783, being separated from New Jersey only by a narrow channel of water called The Sound, which was in 1780-81 frozen over and passable for large teams & heavy artillery. Hence, it became necessary for the people living on that frontier, and in such proximity to the enemy, to be always on the alert, as they were constantly subject to alarm and annoyance by the British & their more dangerous & inveterate enemies, the Tories of their own state. The families of both these applicants suffered many privations, and were special objects of revenge in consequence of their firm adhesion & patriotic devotion to the American cause. That of Kinsey were robbed & plundered, & had their house & barn burned to the ground & the last cow they possessed, with two fat hogs, driven off in Dec. 1780, the family escaping to the woods without clothing to...

Extract from the records of the church in Hardwick, written by Rev. David White who was pastor of said Church from Nov. 1736 to Jan 1764 The Page is headed 'An Account of Marriages Hardwick' and contains a record of fifteen Marriages, the thirteenth of which is as follows, Joseph Hunt and Elizabeth Fay May sixteenth one thousand seven hundred and seventy-nine (May 16, 1779) State of Massachusetts, County of Worcester, Hardwick Town Clerks Office Feb 10th 1840 -- I certify that the foregoing is a true copy from the record of marriages in said office, (by courtesy) now in my custody as Town Clerk of said Hardwick, with exception of the exception of the date which is expressed on the Record in fair legible figures as follows: May 16, 1774 Attest Joseph Stone, Clerk of said town of Hardwick, for the year 1859-40 Joseph Stone, above named, depose and say that hold the office of Clerk of the Town of Hardwick in the county & State aforesaid and that the above extract from the Church Record of Marriages in said Hardwick, with the exception above named as certified by me Joseph Stone, Town Clerk of said Hardwick [illegible] subscribed and sworn to this 19th day of February AD. 1850. Before me, Gardner Ruggles Justice of the Peace I hereby certify that the above named Despondent is reputable for truth Gardner Ruggles

I was born in the town of Hebron Connecticut on the 25 of March AD 1854 I have no record of my age except that I have understand it was recorded in said Hebron records and in my father family bible lived part of the time in said Hebron and part of the time in said New Hampshire in the towns of Haverhill Hanover and Bath County of Grafton during the revolutionary war when called into service and since the war have lived in said New Hampshire untill the year 1820 since which last mentioned time I have lived in said Lebanon Conn. where I now live I never received any written discharge and have no documentary evidence of my services. I am known to the Rev, Edward Bull and Deacon Solomon Gilbert who can testify to my character for veracity and belief my services, from bodily infirmity old age from my much distance from New Hampshire and long length of time and [illegible]I don't know if it is possible to obtain a [illegible] I hereby relinquish every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present and declare that my name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any State Absalom Peters Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid The Edward Bull a clergyman residing in said Lebanon and Solomon Gilbert residing in the same place hereby certify that we are well acquainted with General Absalom Peters who has subscribed and sworn to the declaration that we

State of Connecticut Probate District of Litchfield in Litchfield County On this 18th day of April 1837 personally appeared in open Court before the Court of Probate for the District of Litchfield said Court being a Court of Record, Frederick Wolcott Esq Judge of said Court. Abigail Wadhams of Goshen in the County of Litchfield & State aforesaid aged Eighty four years who being first duly sworn according to law doth on her oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the provisions made by the Act of Congress passed July 4th 1836 entitled "An act granting half pay to widows or orphans where their husbands and fathers have died of wounds received in the Military service of the United States in certain cases and for other purposes," and of the provisions of "A Bill explanatory of the act aforesaid passed the 3d March 1837. That she was born on the 14th Day of February AD 1753 and in the month of February 1773 She was lawfully married to Heman Allen of Salisbury in the County of Litchfield and State aforesaid by the Revd Mr Lee, Pastor of the Congregational Church in said Salisbury, That according to her best recollection and belief, the said Heman Allen appointed to the command of a Company of Infantry and received a Captain Commission in the month of July 1775. from the Congress of the United States [which said commission is x'ed out] & he immediately raised a company of men & he immediately raised a company of men & entered the service of the United States at the head of said Company & joined a Regt commanded by Col. Warner of Vermont & were called Green Mountain Boys. The commission of her former husband Heman Allen was forwarded by her some time in the course of the last Winter to the Hon Heman Allen Member of Congress from the State of Vermont, that she is therefore unable to say positively at what time it was granted. She well recollects that during the warm season of the same year in which the sd Heman Allen receved his commission that he left home & joined the army of the Revolution, & was from that time engaged in the service of the United States as a Captain in the army of the Revolution until after the capture of Gen Burgoynes army in October 1777, soon after the surrender of Genl Burgoyne the said Heman Allen, say having by reason of the fatigue of the camp & the hardships he had endured, become sick & unable to perform duty obtained leave of absence and returned to Salisbury in Connecticut, sick from which sickness he never recovered & he died on the 18th Day of May 1778 That she is confident that the said Heman

fit for the saddle, the dray, the carriage, or any other draught, as you see he is poorly formed, having neither strength nor symmetry, and his master changes his occupation so often, that we hardly count him in the regular number of steeds. The next is the Times, a very good family horse, of an easy gait and good bottom. Occasionally he starts before the tap of the drum, but is generally manageable. He has been lately brought into the stable however, and we do not know enough of him yet to trust him entirely out of sight. This prancing courser we have never been able to break; his name is Enquirer, and as strange a nag he is as ever wore bit and saddle; he is a wayward beast: for one mile heats he does very well, but for bolting, running away, throwing his rider, and all sorts of villanons pranks, he beats the d--l. He has bottom enough, and spirit enough, and we hope to get him manageable, but shall have a job of it. The Commerecial, standing along side of him, is an old horse, who, though not the strongest in the stable, is kind in harness, and for a steady jog answers a very good purpose. The Statesman, as you see, is a clever nag, and for common use is not bad; great speed can be got out of him when he has both his riders: one of them is away: when he returns, we intend pushing him hard upon the course. "This," said he, pointing to a ninth, "is one of the oldest horses in the stable, and for hard service an thorough work, is in spite of his years more to be relied upon than any of the stud: the Post for that is his name, is one of those crow, k[illegible] horses, that very often runs away wi[illegible] unskilled rider, but when kindly treate[illegible] ied upon for a long journey. [illegible] the American, is as you see a [illegible] well built animal and [illegible] saddle answers very well: fashionable [illegible]ades are fond of riding him: his carriage is easy and graceful. He shows his teeth occasionally, but seldom bites. He has not quite the bottom of the Post, and is hardly as secure in bad travelling: he is a fair horse though, and when a little older will run against the field." My attendant was then going on to speak of a number of colts; but I was obliged to hurry off and hear his story another time. N.Y. Times A Nose for an Arm. That class of people in New Jersey who are very particular about the etiquette of fashionable life, have a habit, when inviting their guests at table to help themselves, of saying, "Make a long arm." A good woman of this unsophisticated class, having one day a Scotchman to dine with her, who had an exceedingly long nose, could not help taking particular notice of that distinguished member of her guest's face, and as the enormous pro[illegible] was naturally uppermost in her thoughts, when she would have said, "Make a long arm," she was unfortunate as to say, "Do make a long nose, Sir." -- "A lang nose, quotha!" replied the Scotchman, "I thought in a' conscience, gude woman, ye wad be content wi' the ane I ha." Of catching Yankees! There is an old black woman at the Hayana, known to almost every one who frequents that port, as a washer of clothes, in which business she employs several slaves, having acquired a handsome property by it. She is partial to the Americans, having made the greater part of her money through them. When some of the British ships stopped there on their way for the coast of Louisiana, she, as usual, boarded the ships in search of business and having despatched that, she asked the captain of one of the 74's, "Where are you going massa?" who replied, "We are going to catch some d--d Yankees at N. Orleans. We shall stop here as we come back and I will sell you a dozen or two very cheap, for washer-women." "Ah, ha; [illegible] you better let [illegible] d--d Yankee lone," [illegible] I tell ye, you better let him Notice that Application will be made for Letters Administration, must be published forty days. [Letterhead] THE CHRISTIAN CHURCH EDGAR L. KNIGHT, PASTOR 414 HALLIBURTON KIRKSVILLE, MO. [Typed text] September 18, 1937 [To the right a faint, circular stamp] RECEIVED SEP 22 1937 MAIL SUB DIV. VETS ADM. READER NO. 19 [Typed text] Veterans Bureau, Department of Revolutionary Soldiers Washington D. C. Dear Sirs: Do you have in your files of solderis who participated in the Revolutionary War a David Boynton. He was born in 1742 and was a participant in the French war as well as the Revolution. He lived in Hampshire County Massachursetts [handwritten addition with arrow] (town of Wendell) and in 1834 moved to Hague, Warren County New York. He died there in 1834. The fore going information was secured from the book of Boynton family history on pages 231 and 232. Also according to the information given this David Boynton drew a pension during the last year of his life. I shall appreciate any information that you may be able to give me as I am very anxious to complete this data with regard to this ancestor. Yours truly, [Signature] Marian E. Knight (Mrs. Edgar [illegible initial] Knight)

District S.C. 2d - I have seen such a record in an Old Family Bible in the Possession of my Mother about forty years since, at which time She removed to Kentucky and I have not seen, it Since 3d - In Chester District S.C removed from there to my present residence in Anderson District S.C where I have resided forty four years 4th First a Volunteer for a three months Tour, the next drafted for a three months Tour, the next Volunteered for an indefinite time in which Tour I was at the battles of rocky mount Hanging rock & Sumpter's defeat 5th I do not remember any of the regular officers except Genl. Sumpter neither do I remember to what regiment I belonged but recollect of Serving under Capt. Hugh Whiteside Lieut. Robert Cooper, Mjr. Michael Dickson & Genl. Sumpter - I have Stated the General Circumstances of my Services in my declaration - 6th I do not remember 7th William Walker, Samuel Maverick, Samuel Cherry, E. M. Benson Esq, Doctor F. W. Symms, the Hon. John C. Calhoon, James C. Griffen Esq. - Sworn and Subscribed the day and year aforesaid - Nicholas Bishop Jno. B. To the Justices of the Court of Common Pleas now sitting at Dover within and for the County of Strafford and State of New Hampshire, on the first Tuesday of July, 1820. Benaiah Dore aged fifty five, resident in Milton in said County, comes into court, and in pursuance of an act of Congress passed on the 1st day of May, 1820, brings with him, and in his proper person exhibits to said Court a Schedule by him subscribed, containing his whole Estate and Income - his necessary clothing and bedding excepted--as follows: -- 53 acres of land with and old dwelling house and barn on the same - 2 oxen - 3 Cows - 3 hogs & 2 shoats one half of a pair of wheels - One plough & half of one, harrow. One ax & one hoe - Iron hollow ware 7 chairs - One loom and two wheels - 3 Tables 1 Chest & 1 case of drawers - One heifer one year old. Income $25.- Attest Levi Jones Fred Ballard Benaiah Dore his mark X And the said Benaiah Dore in pursuance as aforesaid produceth to said Court the following oath by him duly taken and subscribed: -- viz. I Benaiah Dore do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March, 1818, and that I have not, since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled ""an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the revolutionary war,” passed on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts due to me, nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. Attest Levi Jones Fredck Ballard Benaiah Dore His Mark X And the said Benaiah Dore doth here in Court further declare on oath, that he served in the revolutionary war as follows, viz. that he enlisted at Lebanon in the County of York in September or October 1781 in Capt Fuller's Company in the 4th Massachusetts Regiment, commanded by Colonel Shepard that he marched to West point and continued at that station until the last of August of the first of September in the year 1783 at which time & place he was sick and was discharged

That relying upon this information and being discouraged by his friends from renewing his application he made no further exertions until the last year when hearing that the provisions of the act had been obtained without the production of the certificate of discharge he was induced to apply by letter to the Honorable Silas Wright Jr. then a member of Congress from this District & was informed through him what course to pursue- And in pursuance of the act of the 1st of May 1820 I do Solemnly swear that I was a resident Citizen of the United States in the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not since that time by gift sale or in any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress entitled "an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary war"" passed on the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities contracts or debts due to me nor have I any income other that what is contained in the Schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed. Winchester Randolph County Indiana The Honorable the Secretary at war Sir Some time in June last I forwarded to you, in the form that you directed, an application for my Pension this became Necessary as I had formerly recd my Pension in the State of Ohio but have now removed to the State of Indiana and wish to Receive the same there I am an old revolutionary Soldier that have fought for our Independance [sic] I am now in poverty have no person to assist me and am afflicted with pain (independant [sic] of my age) so that I am not able to labour [sic] for my subsistance [sic] for the sake of humanity if you have not sent the papers to enable me to draw my Pension do pray send them as soon as possible Pardon this intrusion which is the effect of Urgent necessity As I am almost naked for Clothes your complyance [sic] with this request will be held in greatfull [sic] remembrance by a sincere friend to yourself and Country Phillip Hobaugh [signature] h t

to fort Pitt, to get a passage down the River, I arrived at the falls of Ohio about three [3] weeks before Christmas in 1781. and there gave my pass to Genl [General] George Rogers Clark, and returned to Boonsborough [Boonesborough], in my absence Capt [Captain] Watkins had returned to Virginia and I understood was in the Battle of Guilford. I never received a discharge nor any pay as a soldier, I served afterwards on scouting parties at various times under Capt. [Captain] Thompson and Capt. [Captain] Chas [Charles] Kavanaugh at the time of the Battle of the Blue Licks I had been left to guard the fort. I went & assisted in Burying the dead among whom were Cols [Colonels] Lodd & Trigg & another Col [Colonel] whose name I have forgot. I never held any Commission except in my bible in my hand writing which I have no record of my Birth so I have never applied for or received any pension from the United States or any of the States I have no documentary evidence of my service and know of no persons living by whom I can prove my service except George Richardson living in this County & Ansel [Ansol] Goodman living in the County of Russell. Same state thereby relinquish every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present and declare that my name is not on the Pension roll of any agency of any state, I do not know whether I was ever exchanged as a prisoner or not, after my return I was called on to march and took from my grandfather's bible & my age was recorded by the pastor at & over church ([illegible] Douglass) who also christened me & married me & christened 2 of my children.

He was allowed pension on his application executed July 12, 1833, at which time he was referred to as Richard Wade, Senior, and was living in Cumberland County, Kentucky. He stated that his age was recorded in his grandfather's (name not given) Bible by Mr. Douglass, the parson at Dover Church, who also christened him (the soldier) and married him and christened two [2] of his children (names not given). In 1833 the soldier lived alternately with a grandson in Wayne County, Kentucky, and a son-in-law [son in law] in Cumberland County, Kentucky, (their names not stated). The papers in said pension claim contain no further data relative to the soldier's family. The data which follow were obtained from papers on file in the pension claim, W. 3059, based upon the military service of Elisha Witt. He was born September 18, 1759, in Albemarle County, Virginia. He moved from Albemarle County to Amherst County, Virginia, and enlisted there in 1776 or 1777 and served three [3] months as private in Captain Richard Ballinger's company in Colonel Hugh Row's or Rose's Virginia regiment. He enlisted in 1778 and served three [3] months as private in Captain John Jacob's company in Colonel Francis Taylor's Virginia regiment. He enlisted in June, 1780, and served three [3] months as private in Captain John Diggs' company in Colonel John Pope's Virginia regiment. He enlisted in June, 1781, and served until after the surrender of Cornwallis, as private in Captain William Harris' company in Colonel John Pope's Virginia regiment and was in the siege of Yorktown. He was allowed pension on his application executed November 20, 1832, at which time he was a resident of Estill County, Kentucky, having moved to that state in 1795. He died December 16, 1836

among them were Catharine Miller daughter of Lorenz Miller, aged- 24 Elizabeth — da — — — 19 Sophia — da — — — 17 Susanna — da — — — 16 there can be no doubt these are the persons to whom you allude, as the church records mention of no other Lorenz Miller’s family— As to your next inquiry, the church records show that Mendel Young died May 26th 1777 aged 72 years— there are but two deaths recorded after his & those in the same year—- I take great pleasure further to add my testimony to the character & standing of Mrs. Hoyd & Mrs. Sophia Umstead both of whom are communicant members of my congregation & have sustained exemplary reputation, for truth, honesty, & strict observance of christian duties— Mrs. Hoyd in consequence of debility & bodily infirmity, does not attend church latterly as regular as formerly— as to Mrs. Moser she is not a member of my church, though she frequently attends it— she is a member of the reformed church & as I understand the oldest person now living in this part of the country, she bears the reputation (& I believe very justly) of an honest, upright & pious woman.— All, or so much of the foregoing as is taken from the record of the church, I certify to be strictly correct & true— Yours with respect H S Miller Pastor of the Ev. Luth. congregation Trap[sic]. Montgy Co. Pa.

We no subscribers having examined General William Barton Late of the State of Rhode Island but now of Danville in the County of Caledonia in the State of Vermont and find scars occassioned as he says by an ounce ball which entered near the (illegible) passed through the Scrotum and through his thigh which round he received as he Says on the 25th day of May 1778 at Bristol in the State of Rhode Island and in conse- quence of Said wound he is in our opinion unfit and has ever been to get his living by labour we have visited him repeatedly and found him (illegible) with pain and distress and he is constantly afflicted with a Swolen Testicle. And we also are fully of the Opinions that if General Barton had applied he would have been put upon the list immediately for a full Pension Samuel Huntington Calvin Jewett Samuel Collins Olney Fuller State of Vermont} Caledonia ss} Danville January 23rd 1815 Personally appeared Doctor Samuel Huntington Calvin Jewett Samuel Collins & Olney Fuller the subscribers to the foregoing Affidavit and made solemn oath that the same contains the whole truth & nothing but the truth according to their best Judgement & belief. We no subscribers having examined General William Barton Late of the State of Rhode Island but now of Danville in the County of Caledonia in the State of Vermont and find scars occassioned as he says by an ounce ball which entered near the (illegible) passed through the Scrotum and through his thigh which round he received as he Says on the 25th day of May 1778 at Bristol in the State of Rhode Island and in conse- quence of Said wound he is in our opinion unfit and has ever been to get his living by labour we have visited him repeatedly and found him (illegible) with pain and distress and he is constantly afflicted with a Swolen Testicle. And we also are fully of the Opinions that if General Barton had applied he would have been put upon the list immediately for a full Pension Samuel Huntington Calvin Jewett Samuel Collins Olney Fuller State of Vermont} Caledonia ss} Danville January 23rd 1815 Personally appeared Doctor Samuel Huntington Calvin Jewett Samuel Collins & Olney Fuller the subscribers to the foregoing Affidavit and made solemn oath that the same contains the whole truth & nothing but the truth according to their best Judgement & belief. Before me John W. Chandler Judge of Country Court I Certify that I am well acquainted with the said Huntington & Jewett Collins and Fuller and that they are all of respectable standing in their professions as Physicians & Surgeons John W Chandler Judge

County being duly sworn states that she is the daughter of Anthony Dawson, deceased, and Mary Darwin, who is now living, a widow, at the deceased husbands dwelling. David Kurby has as he avows, been forty years the Pastor.
