not merely in his own neighbourhood, but he went into the other townships of our own County, as well as into the Counties of Sussex Hunterdon Bergen Somerset &c. & wherever provisions could be had. And I believe my said husband was publicly employed in the line of his duty, as a distributing or issuing Commissary, & in purchasing supplies as aforesaid, not less than one half of each year, from the beginning to the end of the revolutionary war, altho it is not now in my power to specify his various services further than I have done. I have no documentary evidence, either of his services, or rank. I believe he held a commission, or some certificate from proper authority, under which he acted, & my impression is, it was derived from General Winds, or from the Regimental officers. It has however been gone, or lost, for many years, as well as all his various papers & books of public accounts, none of which have I seen for many years. It is probable his papers & accounts were all given up after the war, to the proper officers appointed to settle them. If they or any of them, are to be found in possession of the government, I would appeal to them as the best evidence of his faithful services, in support of my claim for a pension. I was married to the said John Stiles at my father's, (John Sanford's) house in Pequannock Township at Morris County in the month of ['November' crossed out] January 1776, the winter before Independence was declared; & my oldest child, Catharine, now Catharine Davenport, was born a few weeks short of one year after my marriage, & she is now in her 64th year as I believe. I was married by Revd Joseph Groon, Minister of the Gospel of the Presbyterian Church at Parsippany Morris County. The precise day of the marriage, I cannot tell, having lost my family record, which was contained in an ancient family bible, now mutilated & worn out, with many of its leaves gone, & the family record entirely lost, & has not been supplied. There is no record of marriages of that early period in the Parsippany Church, as I am informed & verily believe, nor are there any persons who were present at our manage, now living, to my knowledge. My husband entered upon his duties as Commissary or Quarter Master, soon after the birth of my oldest child, Catharine, & from that period, was absent from home upon his public duties the greater part of his time. My said husband, the aforesaid John Stiles, died at his residence in Pequannock township on the 23d day of October 1830, & I have remained his widow to this day, as will more fully appear by testimony hereto annexed. Sworn to & subscribed on the day & year first written. The erasure of "Hunterdon" & "General Winds", & of "November", also the erasure & addition of the word "Morris" in 3d line, were all done before signing. her Mary X Stiles mark Before me James Wood one of the Judges of Morris County Com. Pleas

Receiver of the Revenue - I have thus stated my very helpless & poverty struck circumstances to your Honor- & do hope that your honor will immediately give such order as will immediately place me in the situation I stood on the Roll of the Pennsylvania Agency be for the Passage of the late act of Congress - there is nothing else can possibly save us in our old age from starvation as we have neither means or ability to procure a living - Your Honors immediate attention to my Distress will stimulate my prayers. & best wishes for your Happiness living & Dying Sam. Kearsley - N.B. you will see the amount of my poor and homely little property is not valued by the Court to more than 60 dollars as they told me & the small house & 8 acres of Land I have on rent is $40 to be paid out of this Pension - - - had not all my papers Re the Honorable Certificate of my Services been Burned in the War office which was given [illegible] by my Coll. & his Excellency Genl Washington on the Destruction of my property by fire by Villains who want to the British while I was out in the Service of my Country I wou [would] not now have to plead for a pension from my country Honorable J. C Calhoun Secretary at War

To whome it may consern This certifies that on the church records of the Evengelical Lutheran Church of Frederick Town M.d. is entered the marriage of Richard Butler and Amelia Fischer on the 21st of May 1736 by the Rev John Andrew Krug and that the same records as well as other historical evidence prove conclusively that the said Rev John Andrew Krug was an ordained minister of the Gospel in good standing in the Evangelical Lutheran Church and a member of the Synod of Penssylvania and adjacent States of said religious denominations and that in the year 1736 as well as for some years prior and subsequent to that date was paster of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Frederick Maryland Geo. Diehl Pastor of the Ev. Luth. Church of Frederick Md. Sworn to before me by Geo. Diehl M Nelson State of Maryland Frederick County Set; I hereby certify that the Honorable Madison Nelson before whom the foregoing Affidavit was made & whose genuine signature is thereto subscribed, was at the date thereof and still is, Judge of the Third Judicial Circuit of the State of Maryland, comprehending the Counties of Frederick and Carroll, duly elected, commissioned & sworn. I, John B Burel of Rochester, in the County of Strafford and State of New Hampshire, testify and say that I am well acquainted with John Richards, of the same Rochester, he lives very near me, is an old man & does not enjoy good health. He is, as he tells me, subject to a debilitating affliction of the stomach, and I have seen him when he was attacked by this complaint as he said, and as I believe; he appeared to be much distressed by them, the sweat poured out of him in large drops and very copiously as from a person in great distress. From his old age and ill health, he is very far from being able to labor all the time or to get a decent support by his labor. John B Burel The State of New Hampshire, Strafford Ss. January 5th, 1821, then the said John B Burel personally appearing made oath that the above affidavit him subscribed is true- Before me, J H Woodman, Justice of the Peace I certify that the said Burel is credible witness J H Woodman, Justice of the Peace

State of Connecticut County of Litchfield ss Salisbury Dec 17th AD 1838. Having been requested to testify as to the fact of the Existence of any records which were made by the Revd Jonathan Lee, of Marriages celebrated by him, while he was pastor of the Church in Salisbury, I hereby State that after diligent inquiry inquiry, I can find no such records, and although he might have kept private records of Marriage I do not know of any, now in existence, and I am satified that as the house was burnt a few years since in which his manuscripts were left, no record of marriages made by him can be found Jonathan Lee Personally appeared Revd Jonathan Lee who hath subscribed the foregoing deposition and made oath to the truth of the same before me & I also certify that the deponent is a creditable Minister Roger Averill Justice Peace Salisbury Dec 17th 1838 State of Connecticut County of Litchfield ss Salisbury Dec 17th 1838. I Adam Reid of said Salisbury do hereby certify and say that I am the Pastor of the Congregational Church in this Town which was the only organized church, as I am in- formed and do believe here previous to 1790 and have in my possession the church records of said Church and have examined and do not find a record of Marriage of Samuel Pierce with Hannah Price and do not believe any such marriage was recorded in said Church records. Further more I perceive that the Revd Jonathan Lee did not keep a record of marriages upon the church records while he was Pastor of said Church. Adam Reid

State of Pennsylvania County of Philadelphia } SS Personally appeared before me the subscriber one of the Alderman in & for said County, the Revd. Gaylord L. More a pastor of a presbyterian church at Fair Mount in said County of Philadelphia, a credible witness, who being duly affirmed according to law, saith, that he was well acquainted with Joel Andrews of Chautauque County in the State of New York, that he was a United States pensioner of the New York agency under the act of Congress of the 18th of March 1818, & that he died in said County several years since; that deponent was present at his funeral; that he is also well acquainted with Anna Andrews his widow now living in York County State of Pennsylvania, & that he knows her to be the identical widow, who was the wife of the said Joel Andrews before mentioned: & that in the year of our Lord 1835 she left Chautauque County & moved into Pennsylvania with her daughter, with whom she now resides, & further this deponent saith not. Gaylord L. More [signature] Subscribed and affirmed before me this 17th Nov, 1840 Witness my hand & seal. Thos. G. Potter Alderman [image: small hand drawn round circle like a seal]

Two swine | - |1821| Killed and used in family One heifer | Henry Daggett |1822| Beef to live on One horse | John Trafton |1822 | His account against me for work twelve dollars One Cow | Matthew Benson |1823| Cash ten dollars About Sixty acres land | Tristram Daggett | 1823 | Debt due him, one Colt for Steers work and assistance to build a house in all one hundred and eighty dollars. One Colt but of my son | Rufus Allen |1824| cash twenty five dollars Pair Steers Do [ditto] | Jabez Norton | 1826 | Part cash part work thirty two dollars Pair Oxen | True Remick | 1826 | Cash forty two Dollars One Cow | Leonard Luce | 1827 | Cash fifteen Dollars The money which I received in payment for the above property sold I have applied from time to time, first to build a house and barn and after several changes to defray the expenses of my family, particularly the expenses of my wife's last sickness, who was confined with a lingering consumption for seven years and died on the fourth of March 1827 - Part of the proceeds I applied to the payment of sundry small debts, and I now owe as much as thirty dollars. A part of the proceeds of my land I attempted to secure against old age but by reason of sickness I have been compelled to make use of all except the note described in the schedule annexed. I have no copy of my first schedule, but I am confident that all I then owned

Virginia Fauquier County to wit: John Dulin aged about seventy three years personally appeared before me William Horner one of the Justices assigned for the peace of said County and made Oath on the holy Evangelist of Almighty God That he the deponent was well acquainted with William Withers the present applicant in the service of the State of Virginia and in Capt. Wm Pickett's Company & in Genl Edward Stephens Brigade at the Battle of Long Bridge and Norfolk in Virginia in the year 1775 & till spring 1776 & until he the said applicant was discharged at Fredericksburg in the Brigade by order of the committee of safety then sitting in Wm Burgh deponent further saith not-- Given under my hand in Fauquier County this 22nd day of July 1826 & in the year of the Commonwealth the 51 Wm Horner Fauquier County Court July 24th 1826 It appearing to the satisfaction of the court from the declaration of William Withers. The affidavits of Joshua Singleton, ^Peter Rust^, John Dulin, William Hughlett, & William Miller, credible witnesses, and the records of this Court. transcripts of which are directed hereto to be annexed, that the said William Withers did perform the services set forth in his declaration & served as a Lieutenant in the army of the Revolution, for more than nine months, on Continental establishment, against the common enemy, and that the proper contained in his schedule is of no value, and that his interest in the claims set forth in his declaration. If the same should be established does not exceed the sum of $300 and that he is in such needy circumstances as to require the aid of his country for support, it is ordered that copies of the said declaration, affidavits and and transcripts from the records of this county, be transmitted to the Secretary of War for the United States, by the Clerk of this Court, with the certificate of the Clerk, and the seal of the court thereto annexed

6 The Epistle Dedicatory. the Light with you, walk while ye have the Light, lest Darkness come upon you ; for he that walketh in Darkness, knoweth not whether he goeth. And it had been better for you that you had never been born, than to die in Unconversion. The Heathen among whom we live, (who seek our Lives, and murder and destroy many of us) will have a far easier Place in Hell than you will, you Children of the Covenant, that live and die in Unconversion. We read, That there are Children of the Kingdom that shall be cast into outer Darkness, where shall be weeping, wailing and gnashing of Teeth ; where the Worm dieth not, and the Fire is not quenched. Rest not then until you find the narrow Way which leadeth unto Life, which few find, Matth. 7. 14. And till you find the good Hope through Grace of an Interest in Christ, 2 Thes. 2. 16. The Time draweth on apace, and how nigh it is you know not, when an Interest in Christ will be of great Value, and when all Things of this World will not profit ; or stand in any stead at all, Prov. 11. 4. nor deliver from Death in the Day of Wrath ; when the Time of Patience is out, then comes a Day of Wrath ; and then there will be no escaping. See Job 27. 22. For God shall cast upon, and not Spare, he would fain flee out of his Hand : Yea but tho' never so fain, it cannot be. Oh ! The Distress and Anguish of Spirit that is seen in some dying ones, under the Arrests of Death, the King of Terrors ; but no remedy, go they must ; and as 1 Thes. 2. 3. Destruction comethin upon The Epistle Dedicatory. 7 upon them as Travail upon a Woman withChild, and they shall not escape. Ponder much and think daily of these and of such like things ; it argues that Persons are sottish Children, Jer. 4. 22. that are so nigh to the Grave ; nor above a Span, or Hand-breadth, and yet should so seldom go thither in their most solemn Meditation. Counsel 2. To such as are Converted : There are hopefully some such among you ; and how many it is not for me to say, but it will one Day appear. But unto you the Counsel is, Grow in Grace, 2 Pet. 3. ult. It is commanded, and it is expected. Be Examples to others. Let your Light so shine before Men that they may see your good Works, and glorify your Father which is in Heaven, Matth. 5. 16. Let your Conversation be as becometh the Gospel, Phil. 1. 27. Or as you have it in Eph. 4. 1. Walk worthy of the Vocation wherewith you are called. Walk as Children of Light, Eph. 5. 8. Yes, much Fruit is expected from us. John 15. 8. Herein is my Father glorified that ye bring forth much Fruit : So shall y e be my Disciples. Not to bear much Fruit will darken our Evidence of being his Disciples, Eph. 3. 10. That ye might be filled with all the Fullness of God and Phil 1. 11. Be filled with the [illegible]teensuess which are by Jesus Christ, [illegible] in the Hearts and the Lives of some, [illegible] hope are truly godly ; and this is a fumbling Block B

I Jeremiah Goodrich of Chatham County of Middlesex & State of Connecticut, aged Seventy Six years, Do testify & say; That Joab Bowers, was indented as an apprentice to me, in the year of our Lord, One Thousand Seven Hundred & Sixty Eight to live with me till Twenty One years of age, that he in the year 1780, (enlisted) in the month of August, enlisted in the Company commanded by Capt. Robert Warner, in the Continental army, to serve during the war, That in year 1783 in the month of June, he was discharged & re- turned to my service, & that he lived with me till he became of age. That I have seen the discharge which he received & that it discharged him as having fully served the time for which he entis- ted. That he is a poor man & that he is entirely destitute of property And further saith not Jeremiah Goodrich

recollects it was but a short time after the defeat of our army at White Plains - from New Ark we marched to New Brunswick; we had been here but a little while till we retreated from it - the Brit ish army under Lord Cornwallis approached it as we left it - The winter was now setting in, and extremely cold, and our army was destitute of shoes & clothing - That on Christmas night of the year, we crossed the Dela ware River some miles above Trenton, it was snowing at this time and the night was unusually stormy. Several of our men froze to death. That early on the next morning (after Christmas) we took all the enemy forted at this place (Trenton) - that in the attack on the morning of 26th he was in the left division, which was commanded by Gnl Greene. That it reached Trenton first - the right division having missed its way a little, did not get in town so soon. That General Washington made Trenton his head quarters for a week or two - but learning that a large body of the enemy was approaching Trenton, under Lord C =wallis, retreated to Princeton N.J., where we had an engagement with a party of the enemy going on to reinforce Cornwallis. We went into winter quarters early in January following, to wit, 1777 at Morris -town in New Jersey - during the time the American Army mar =ched to Trenton & till it went into quarters at Morristown, This Delarant says he was but thinly clad, and entirely barefoot all the while - [and that] Washington remained at Morristown till about the first of the summer, & while at this place, the whole army or nearly all, was innoculated for the small pox - from Morris town, we were marched to Middlebrook, and he thinks also to Quibbletown - The British being as near to us as Brunswick. In the latter part of the summer, the enemy appeared in the Chesapeake Bay. Washington now marched through Philadelphia- Thence to White Clay Creek, Thence to Shaddy's ford on the Brandywine creek, where he gave the enemy battle, some time in [illegible] - Washington was defeated, being deceived by the enemy who crossed at Jones' Ford, some miles above the scene of the engagement, and attacked our rear - in this engagement, this applicant received a wound from a musket ball in his knee, which disqualified him from duty in the line, till in the winter following; That Genl. Washington & Greene commanded the Americans in this

2. Army which was there at New Ark in New Jersey the precise time they reached Washingtons [illegible], he does not remember, but recollects it was but a short time after the defeat of our Army at White Plains. From New Ark we marched to New Brunswick, we had been here but a little while till we retreated from it, the British Army under Lord Cornwallis approached it, as we left it. The winter was now sitting in and extremely cold, and our Army was destitute of shoes & cloathing. That on Christmas night of this year we crossed the Delaware river some miles above Trinton, it was Snowing, at this time, and the night was unusually stormy several of our men froze to death, that early on the next morning (after Christmas) we look all the Enemy forted at this place Trenton. I Ichabod Ives of Wallingford in the County of Newhaven and State of Connecticut being 80 years of age depose and say that in the time of the Revolutionary War I was in the service of the United States at several times and in the year 1782 I enlisted for one year and belonged to general Waterbury Brigade were stationed White Plaines [Plains] in the State of Newyork [New York] and Horse neck in the State of Connecticut the later part of the time We were stationed at horse neck where there was a Fort and I verily believe that Timothy Bishop formerly belonging to the town of Durham but now residing on Long Island in the town of Huntington was a part of the time with me at Horse neck Our Capt name at Horse neck was Edwards he belonged to the town of Watertown in this state Our Lieutenant name was Henry Bull he belonged to the town of Millford in this state Our Ensign name was Whiting he also belonged to the town of Millford and further the deponent saith not Dated at Wallingford this 26th day of October AD 1838 Ichabod Ives Witnesses George Atwell Elisha M Pomeroy State of Connecticut Newhaven County Ss Wallingford Oct. 26th 1838

State of Massachusetts Asa Chase a Citizen of the United States, now resident at Douglas in the County of Worcester in the state aforesaid, do on oath testify and declare, that in the War of the Revolution, on or about the first Day of April in Seventeen Hundred and Eighty one I entered and was engaged in the land service of the United States on the continental establishment, and served accordingly from that time to December Seventeen Hundred and Eighty three in the three year service. as a Private Soldier against the common enemy, without any interruption or absence; that I belonged to Capt King's Company in Col. Brooks regiment being the seventh regiment in the Massachusetts line and that I left on or about the last of December 1783 as above explained and I was honorably discharged from service but have [illegible] my discharge and that, by reason of my reduced circumstances in life and poverty, I stand in need of assistance from my country for support, being now of the age of Fifty three years And I hereby relinquish all claims to every pension heretofore allowed me by the laws of the United States if any may be or hath been so allowed. Asa Chase BE IT REMEMBERED, That on this sixteenth day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen pursuant to a law of the United States, entitled, "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States Revolutionary War," made and passed on the 18th of March, A.D. 1818, personally appeareth before me Edward Bangs one of the judges of the Circuit Court of the Common pleas for the western circuit of said State comprising said County of Worcester the abovenamed Asa Chase after due examination and caution to testify and declare the whole truth, he maketh oath to the declaration aforesaid, and suscribes the same in my presence; and, on examination duly made by me the said Judge, it appeareth to my satisfaction that the said declaration is true. Given under my Hand and the Seal of said Court, the day of the date aforesaid. Edward Bangs

ON this 7th day of June 1825 personally appeared before the County Court for said county of Rutland in open court, (said court being a court of record, agreeably to the laws of this state, having the power of fine and imprisonment, &c.) Nathan M. Lounsbury resident in said county, aged 68 years, who being duly sworn, according to law, doth, on his oath, make the following declaration, in order to obtain the provision made by the acts of Congress of the 18th March, 1818, and the 1st May, 1820, that he, the said Lounsberry enlisted for the term of three years on the 20th day of June in the year 1779 in the state of Connecticut in the company commanded by Captain J Thomas in the regiment commanded by Colonel John Lamb, Artillery in the line of the state of Connecticut & N York on the ----------- continental establishment; that he continued to serve in the said corps until June 1782 when he was discharged from the said service, in Westpoint [West Point] in the state of Newyork [New York] ["that his name has been placed on the pension list, and dropt therefrom on account of his property." crossed out] And in pursuance of the act of the 1st May, 1820, I do solemnly swear, that I was a resident citizen of the United States, on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary war,” passed on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. 3 Shaves[?] 1. ax, 1 barrell [barrel], 1 Clok[?] [clock?], 3 plains[], 3 kettles, 1 pot, 1 Spider, 3 platters, 12 plates, 2 bowls, 5 spoons, 3 knives, & forks, 4 Cups & Saucers, 1 tumbler, 1 teapot, 1 pr. Andirons, Shovel & tongs, 1 old hand saw, 1 Chest, 1 old Scythe, 1 old Shovel, 1 tub, 2 pails, 1 broken looking glass, 4 chairs, 1 table, 1 bible, my occupation is that of a Cooper, but from old age and the loss of my Eye Sight & want[?] of tools I am unable the work but very little, my family consists of my wife named Sally aged 29 years health pretty good, that he has no other evidence of his said services than what accompanies this declaration that he had no more property on the 18th March 1818 nor has he since had then what is contained in the above Schedule that he made application to be placed on the pension ["That since the exhibition of my first schedule, the following changes have been made in my property." crossed out] list in 1818 but owing to the difficulty of procuring proof of his services he has been unable to procure his name inserted on the pension list Nathan M Lounsbury Sworn to and declared on the 7th day of June 1825 before sd Court R. Pierpoint Clk I, Robert Pierpoint clerk of Rutland County Court do hereby certify, that it appears to the satisfaction of the court, that the said Nathan M Lounsbury did serve in the Revolutionary war, as stated in the preceding declaration, against the common enemy, for the term of nine months, under one engagement, on the continental establishment. I also certify, that the foregoing oath, and the schedule thereto annexed, are truly copied from the records of the said court; and I do further certify, that it is the opinion of the said court, that the total amount in value of the property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule is Twelve dollars and [blank] ["cents" crossed out] In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand, and affixed the seal of the said court, on this 26th day of Jany 1826 R. Pierpoint

Nathan L enlist Thomas Co 27 June 1780 Statement of Nathan M. Lounsbury of Rutland in the County of Rutland and State of Vermont, a Revolutionary Pensioner, inscribed on the pension Roll of the United States, the 4th day of February, 1826; made in conformity to letter of the Commissioner of Pensions dated the 17th of January 1835, addressed to Hon. Mr. Slade of the house of Representatives: I enlisted into the service of the United States on the 20th day of June, 1778, for three years, in Capt. Joseph Thomas' Company - Col. John Lamb's Regiment,- and continued in the service three years and four months- and was discharged by General Washington at West Point. I have lost my discharge, many years ago, and do not know now, nor never did know what became of it. When I first entered the service, I served six months in the Connecticut line; and my whole company was then transfered [transferred] to the New York line, in exchange for Sheldon's troop of Horse or light dragoons. The officers under whom I served were Col. Lamb, and Capt. Thomas, above named, and First Lt. Isaiah Thompson, and Second Lt. Alexander Clinton. I belonged to Connecticut while in the service. When I first enlisted, I went onto West Point, and remained there almost a year. I was there when Benedict Arnold went off to the British. From thence I marched to White Plains, and was in the action there. From there I marched to Virginia, and was present at the taking of Lord Cornwallis. From thence we returned to Philadelphia, and remained in the Brick Barracks during the winter. From thence we marched to Burlington in New Jersey. And from thence we marched to West Point- where I was discharged, as above stated. My whole service was in the Artillery, in the same Company and Regiment above named. The length of time I served I have stated before. When I made application for a pension, I resided in the township of Wells in the County of Rutland aforesaid; and I believe my declaration was sworn to before the Honble Amos Thompson, one of the Judges of the County Court, within and for said County of Rutland; and some of the

thority of the United States to furnish a certain quota of men for the service of the United States that he was hired by said Town to go into said service in the Militia for the term of three months that he was enlisted about the first of October of said year, and served according to his remembrance till about the first of December that he belonged to the Massachusetts Militia, was in Capt Luke Wilders Company & Col Samuel Penney Regiment &that he has no other evidence of said last mentioned service but his own declaration, [crossed out] and the pay of Company made verily believe by said Capt Wilder 1779.[end crossed out] accompanying this application - that he was placed on the pension Roll under the act of Congress passed in 1818 for the relief of the Revolutionary Soldiers, but in 1820 was struck from the pension Roll on account of his property. that his pension or certificate was Numbered 2858 that in his application for pension in 1818 he mentioned only the first period of service mentioned in this act, because under the act of 1818 it was only necessary to state & prove nine months service to obtain the benefit of the act - That he hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or an annuity except the present, and he declares that his name is not on the pension Roll of any Agency in any State. Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid. before Nath'l Pain Judge of Probate for the county of Worcester. [crossed out: aforesaid for the County of West And the Court do hereby declare their opinion Clinton --- land and ] We Nath Thayer - D.D. a Clergyman residing in Town of Lancaster, and Nathaniel Rand Esqr residing in the Town of Lancaster hereby certify that we are well acquainted with Joseph Farwell who has subscribed and sworn to the above declaration, that we believe him to be seventy three years of age, that he is reputed and believed in the neighbourhood where he resides, to have been a soldier of the revolution and concur in the opinion Sworn & subscribed the day & year aforesaid Before Nath'l Paine Judge of Probate or the County of Worcester Nath'l Paine Nath'l Rand Turn over

State of Massachusetts Joseph Farwell a Citizen of the United States, now resident at Lancaster in the County of Worcester in the State aforesaid, do on oath testify and declare, that in the War of the Revolution, a[crossed out on] some time in the month of January 1776 - I entered and was engaged in the Land service of the United States on the continental establishment, and served accordingly from that time to Jan 7 1777 as a Soldier against the common enemy, without any unlawful interruption or absence; that I belonged to Captain Williams Company in Col Greatons Regt marched to New York, was then taken very sick & was there left by my Reg. when they marched for the notherd army & season and I recover'd my health was directed by the Genr/ll to Join Cofenwards Regt which I did in Capt King's Company, where I serv'd the remainder of the year that afterwards I serv'd nine months more and that I left the service [crossed out on] [illegible] the same [illegible]on Cap. Wards Regiment I do not know whether any discharge was given me or not in January 1777 & if given it is not in [illegible] that, by reason of my reduced circumstances in life and poverty, I stand in need of assistance from my country for support, being now of the age of about fifty nine years- And I hereby relinquish all claims to every pension heretofore allowed me by the laws of the United States, if any may be or hath been so allowed. Joseph Farwell BE IT REMEMBERED, That on this 16th day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen pursuant to a law of the United States, entitled, ""An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War," made and passed on the 18th of March, A. D. 1818, personally appeareth before me, Isaac Parker Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Massachusetts the abovenamed Joseph Farwell and after due examination and caution to testify and declare the whole truth, he maketh oath to [covered text] declaration aforesaid, and subscribes the same in my presence; and, on examination du- [covered text] me the said Judge, it appeareth to my satisfaction that the said declaration is true. Witness my hand & the seal of said Court the day & year aforesaid Isaac Parker CJSC

Tar" a forty-gun ship commanded by Captain Bell of Baltimore which sailed from Fell's point in company with the "Matilda" also a ship of forty guns commanding name not recollected. It was understood that we had enlisted for a cruise of six months. We had cruised off Cape Henry for about two months when we returned to Hampton Road, we were attached by the British Ship "Perseverance" and after a short engagement in which our vessels were both disabled, we were captured. In this action, the marines of our ship never came into engagement owing to our *** and rigging being so much cut away. Three men were killed on board of our ship one of whom was Captain Bell's clerk by the name of Bussey and several wounded. We were immediately carried on board of the "Perseverance" and put in the hold and sailed to Long Island below New York where we were transferred to the British Prison Ship the "Old Jersey". Here we were confined twelve months wanting one day where we endured incredible suffering. We were taunted, insulted and put upon and maltreated in almost every imaginable way. Numbers died for the want of the necessary sustenance of life and others from sickness proceeding from the manner of our treatment, besides this as many as 6 or 7 of my acquaintance to my knowledge died after their release as I suppose from exposure to the open air after having been confined so long to the gloomy hole of that horrible vessel. Among these I remember the names of Benjamin Howard, Richard Jourdan, and William James all from the same neighborhood with myself. Captain Bell did not remain long with us but was paroled on his honor. Captain Bussey was likewise paroled. When we were released, it was by the influence of two Quakers by the name of John Mason and William Bull who each had a son confined on the prison ship. As well as I can remember, these Quakers procured the release of all with whom they were acquainted amounting to almost forty. We were released upon our parole. And so, this declarant states by way of recapitulation that he served 2 months as a volunteer at Wilmore's Ferry, 2 months at Baltimore, 2 months as an enlisted marine on board the "Jolly Tar" and 12 months was a prisoner on board the "Jersey" prison ship.

[This is part of a journal by Abner Everitt, it is extremely light and faded from age with many words completely faded or missing. ] The Memorandum of Abner Everitt 9th Timothy James Company Colonel Baxter’s Reg. Flying Camp A journal from July 1776 Containing a great grand of the news of the day with the Marches (not legible) of places (not legible too smudged) ~~ I might still keep poning as the years goes round Least I forget and to myself confound. July 9, 17[smudged] FA playing the Committee of Safety to appoint me to go -[illegible] Ensign or third Lieutenant in the above Company Some= Day before the 9th. Intant on that day we raizd our Company July 19th marched from Home to Easton which was 16 ^miles, where we lay until the 26th in the afternoon by which time we had got our [illegible] equip, & Marched out of Town in order to Join the Army at New Brunswick we (Not legible) Delaware and proceeded to Johnson at the Muscanekung[sic] were we lay that night on the 27th we marched to Barragers Tavern near Raratin we stay that night on the 28th proceded to Brunswick and passed the Muster Master then Lay there that night this was 50 miles from Lapeer on 29th we was ordered to Loadbridge Church 12 m. on the 30th we was ordered to Amboy Barrak, distant 4 m while we lay here the Enemy Firing from there Battery on Staten Island killed one of the Sons of Freedom. Nothing more material happened only some of our men having got hard Biscuits for Breakfast determined to go [illegible] in a Body but it coming to the (not legible) they were ordered to Set by their June and contend they (not legible) under pain of being fired on by the Rest of the Regiment on the 13th of August we was ordered to March for New York.

Maryland Charles County to wit - I do hereby certify that I knew Capt Belain Posey and that he commanded a company called the Flying camp, and marched with this company from said County, some time in the Spring of 1776 or 77. I do not Recollect which, that after that corps was Discharged, he returned to the County aforesaid, and as well as my recollection serves-- acted for a time, as Deputy commissary to the northern Army, & that he purchased Cattle of my Father, for that purpose, that he was an active, vigilant man, that he remained in the County, to his death, which happened some time in the year 1791. that he married some short time after he returned from the flying Camp to the present Mrs. Margaret Posey - then Miss Corry, & further I am certain, he commanded a company of Militia in said County, and was in command, when Capt George Dents, house was burnt, by the British which was as well as my recollection serves, some time in the Spring of 1780 or 81. I am not positive which, and further that the aforesaid Margaret Posey, is now & has been ever since, the widow of the aforesaid Belain Posey C Roby Charles County ss Personally appeared before the Subscriber a Justice of the peace for the County aforesaid Charles Roby & made Oath on the Holy Evangelly of Almighty God, that the facts contained in the above certificate are true to the best of his knowledge & belief Sworn before Charles McCann February 27th 1837 - I hereby certify that have known Mr. Charles Roby for upwards of thirty years and that he is a gentleman fully entitled to credit before any tribunal

State of Tennessee} Jefferson County} On this 12th day of January in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and fifty nine [1859] personally appeared before me an acting Justice of the peace in and for the County and State aforesaid Nancy Pogue aged about ninety-five years, a resident of Jefferson County, Tennessee, who being duly sworn according to law, declares that she is the widow of Joseph Pogue deceased, who was a horseman or belonged to a Company of Dragoons in the War of the Revolution for Independence of 1776. That the said Joseph Pogue joined the American Army towards the close of the war in Orange or an adjoining County North Carolina. That declarant does not know certainly the company or No. to which he was attached, nor does she know certainly the names of the officers under whom her said husband served; but declarant has heard her said husband speak of Captain Willis Span and Captain James Farquar [James Farquhar] when speaking of the Revolutionary Army and incidents relating thereto, and of his own services, and she thinks it likely they were out at the same time, and were in the same service that her husband was, if they were not or one of them his Captain. Declarant has heard her said husband frequently in his lifetime say that he was in three different engagements or battles in the Revolutionary War that he never received any pay for his services, & that he lost a mare in one of the battles in which he was engaged, and also his saddle to which he never received any compensation or remuneration. Declarant has the impression that she heard her husband say that he was in a battle at Guilford Court house [March 15, 1781]. That her said husband was in the actual service of the American Army when

State of Massachusetts I Oliver Plimpton a Citizen of the United States, now resident at Southbridge in the County of Worcester in the State aforesaid, do on oath testify and declare, that in the War of the Revolution, on the tenth day of March in the year of our Lord, one thousand, seven hundred and Seventy Seven - I entered and was engaged in the Land service of the United States on the continental establishment, and served accordingly from that time to the tenth day of March in the year of our Lord, one thousand, seven hundred and Eighty as a private soldier a part of said time & part of said time Corporal against the common enemy, without any interruption or absence: that I belonged to the Massachusetts Regiment commanded by Col Timothy Bigelow of Worcester Massachusetts and Capt Adam Martin's Company and that I left the service on the said Tenth day of March 1780 and that, by reason of my reduced circumstances in life and poverty, I stand in need of assistance from my country for support, being now of the age of Sixty Two years- And I hereby relinquish all claims to every pension heretofore allowed me by the laws of the United States, if any may be or hath been so allowed. Oliver Plimpton BE IT REMEMBERED, That on this thirtieth day of September in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and nineteen pursuant to a law of the United States, entitled, "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War," made and passed on the 18th of March, A. D. 1818, personally appeareth before me, Solo. Strong Judge of the Circuit Court of Common Pleas for the Western Circuit, Massachusetts the abovenamed Oliver Plympton and after due examination and caution to testify and declare the whole truth, he maketh oath to the declaration aforesaid, and subscribes the same in my presence; and, on examination duly made by me the said Judge, it appeareth to my satisfaction that the said declaration is true. Given under my Hand and the Seal of said Court, the day of the date aforesaid. Solo. Strong

District of Connecticut ss. County of Litchfield, County Court On this 4th day of July 1820 personally appeared in open Court, being a court of RECORD for said county in said district, having the power to fine and imprison James Pike aged 69 years & eleven month resident in said county, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath declare that he served in the Revolutionary War, as follows: That he served seven months in the year 1775 in Shubel Griswold's company at Crown Point. That in 1775 he enlisted into Capt Aaron Austins company Col. Charles Burralls Regt for one year on the continental establishment, Connecticut line, served said Term and was regularly discharged. In which time he went to Canada where he suffered great hardships & privations took the small pox and was some time sick & taking care of the sick at Chambly-- That he afterwards served in short tours about 7 or eight months. That the money he received for pay was of very little value-- has paid one dollar of it for a night's lodging & ten dollars for a pair of pantaloons And I do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March one thousand eight hundred and eighteen; and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provision of an act of Congress entitled ""An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War,” passed on the 18th day of March, one thousand eight hundred and eighteen; and that I have not nor has any person in trust for me any property, or securities, contracts or debts due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. Wit- 1L acre of Land with a small house & Barn of the value of -$150.00 1 cow old- 15.00 1 old [illegible] .25 2 old [illegible] .50 1 old sickle .10 ___________ $165.85

she further says that she cannot say at what particular time the said James Pike entered the service, or when he left the same nor whether he held any rank above a common soldier. She understood and believes that said James Pike was in the service something over three years; and that when he left the service he was disabled and sick for a long time and suffering from an injury he had received in his leg and which ever afterwards troubled him. That she always understood from said James Pike that he entered the service twice during the revolution that he enlisted once and was draughted once, and that he was in what was called the northern army- That said James Pike drew a pension for some years previous to his death - that he lived in Barkhamstead Connecticut after he left the service and that he lived there when he drew a pension which was up to the time of his death which took place on the 27th day of July 1823 she further declares that she was married to the said James Pike at Simsbury Hartford County Connecticut on the 20th day of May 1788 - that her maiden name was Sarah Parsons, that she at the time of the Marriage was a resident of New Hartford Connecticut and said James Pike was a resident of Barkhamstead Connecticut- that they were married by one - [illegible], a minister of the Gospel of what was then called West Simsbury and afterwards called Canton; that her husband the said James Pike died on the twenty

with clap board roofs. These building are all nearly falling down, and there is no other building whatsoever on the land possessed by the deponent. This tract of land containing go or 100 as [acres]. the deponent does not believe that he could sell for more than four dollars cash per acre even if he had a complete title to it. The deponent is unable to work this land himself. he rents it upon the shares to Daniel Helm the deponents son in law who is a very poor man & has a wife and seven children, five of the children at home with him. Last year the Deponents share of the crops was as follows-- 2 1/2 tons hay which the deponent sold for 16 dollars, 20 bushels of oats & 6 bushels of buckwheat. the deponent got no wheat nor rye. The year before deponent got no rent at all of any kind. The deponent says further that he has no property at all except a note upon John Gore due above three years ago for eighteen dollars. Gore is said & believed to be insolvent, & except also a little mare worth about thirty dollars, a Bible and a chest, The deponent owes a debt of about forty three or forty four dollars to John Hershberger which be contracted on faith of the continuance of his pension. The deponent further says that he is now much poorer & much less able to work for a living than he was when his pension was first granted to him Sworn & subscribed the 10th May A.D. 1827 Before the President Judge of the Court of Common Pleas in Geo. Lucas Sworn and subscribed the 10th May A.D 1827 Before me President Judge of the Court of Common Pleas in & for Bedford County aforesaid. The words "or very near that sum" between the 11th & 12th lines, 2d page being first interlined. John Tod

District of Vermont, SS. On this 22 day of June 1820 personally appeared in open court, being a county court and court of record, which has power to fine and imprison, and is constituted a court of record by a special act of the Legislature of the state of Vermont, creating said court, within and for the county of Bennington and state of Vermont, Daniel Evans aged 62 years, resident in Pownal in said county of Bennington who being first duly sworn according to law, doth, on his own, declare that he served in the Revolutionary war, as follows: I served in the _ company, commanded by Capt Wm Manning in the - regiment, commanded by Colo Charles Will of the Connecticut line, I was in the action on Long Island also in the action below fort Washington, was at the taking the Hessians at Trenton, I was in the battle at Brandywine, at Germantown, and Whitemarsh, win lead at vally forge was in the front guard in pursuing the British till Monmouth of battle when I was wounded in the thigh. as will appear by my original declaration on file in the War office, dated the 11th day of April 1818 on which original declaration I have received a pension certificate bearing the number 7.086. And I do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March, 1818: and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled, "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary war," passed on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts, or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. The following is a schedule of all the real and personal estate, to wit: one cow, one old saddle, wooden clock, two saws, one hammer, 1 shovel, 1 tea kettle, bake kittle, flats, 12 old chairs, 2 old chests, 2 old tabled, thunk, 6 spoons, Iron ware, one old , other house hold furniture. By occupation a carpenter afflicted with partial blindness v diziness almost totally deaf and lame in my right arm. I have a wife Sarah about 60 years of age been a cupple for about 3 years. 1 girl 6 sara aged 14 feeble constitution. I owe as near as I can calculate $70.00. Daniel Evans

State of Massachusetts I Zebulon Elwell a Citizen of the United States, now resident at Gloucester in the County of York in the State aforesaid, do on oath testify and declare, that in the War of the Revolution, on or about the first of January in the year of our Lord Seventeen hundred & Seventy Six I entered and was engaged in the land service of the United States on the continental establishment, and served accordingly from that time for the year ensuing in the Massachusetts line of the army as a private against the common enemy, without any interruption or absence: that I belonged to the Company of Captain Baker in the Regiment of Colonel Little I afterwards engaged in the naval service on board the Continental frigate, Hancock, John Manley commander, & served without any interruption a year.and that I left the service on the expiration of the term aforesd being their honorably discharged. and that by reason of my reduced circumstances in life and poverty, I stand in need of assistance from my country for support, being now of the age of sixty one years. my discharge this lapse of time is now lost & I have in no other evidence to offer than what is herewith exhibited . And I hereby relinquish all claims to every pension heretofore allowed me by the laws of the United States , if any may be or hath been so allowed. Zebulon Elwell BE IT REMEMBERED, That on this third day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen Pursuant to a law of the United States, entitled, " An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the revolutionary war, made and passed on the 18th of March, A. D. 1818, personally appeareth before me the subscriber one of the Associate Judges of the Circuit Court of Common pleas for the middle Circuit within the State aforesd & presiding his advice the abovenamed Zebulon Elwell and after the examination and caution to testify and declare the whole truth, he maketh oath to the [illegible] aforesaid, and subscribes the same in my presence; and, on examination duly made by [illegible]edge, it appeareth to my satisfaction that the said declaration is true the testimony whereof I hereunto affix my name & the seal of Court Wm Wetmore I further certify that the witnesses within named are credible & disinterested June 15, 1828 Wm Wetmore

State of Massachusetts I Zebulon Elwell a Citizen of the United States, now resident at Gloucester in the County of Essex in the State aforesaid, do on oath testify and declare, that in the War of the Revolution, on or about the first of January in the year of our Lord Seventeen hundred & seventy Six I entered and was engaged in the land service of the United States on the continental establishment, and served accordingly from that time for one year ensuing in the Massachusetts line of the army.as a private against the common enemy, without any interruption or absence; that I belonged to the Company of Captain Baker in the Regiment of Colonel Little. I afterwards engaged in the naval service on board the Continental frigate, Hancock, John Manly commander, & served without any interruption a year.and that I left the service on the expiration of the term aforesd being there honorably discharged and that by reason of my reduced circumstances in life and poverty, I stand in need of assistance from my country for support, being now of the age of sixty one years. my discharge this lapse of time is now lost & I have no other evidence to offer than what is herewith exhibited And I hereby relinquish all claim to every pension heretofore allowed me by the laws of the United States , if any may be or hath been so allowed. Zebulon Elwell BE IT REMEMBERED, That on this third day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen Pursuant to a law of the United States, entitled, ""An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the revolutionary war," made and passed on the 18th of March, A. D. 1818, personally appeareth before me the subscriber one of the Associate Judges of the Circuit Court of Common pleas for the middle circuit within the State aforesd & presiding has been since, the abovenamed Zebulon Elwell and after due examination and caution to testify and declare the whole truth, he maketh oath to the declaration aforesaid, and subscribes the same in my presence; and, on examination duly made adge, it appeareth to my satisfaction that the said declaration is true. In testimony Whereof I hereunto affix my name & the seal of Court Wm Wetmore I further certify that the witnesses within named are credible & disinterested. June 15. 1818 Wm Wetmore

Is unable to pursue it on account of infermity - that the {..} disorder and is much disabled thereby can do but little work - his wife, Anne, aged sixty five years is entirely unable to do any work. She has a cancer on her face which has entirely eat away her nose most of her lips and cheeks. She is in constant suffering and is under the care of a physician and has been sick for more than three years. Her sight is much affected and she is wholy disabled from attending her household concerns. This declarant has nine children all of whom take care & support themselves except his youngest daughter Emily [aprox?] 26 years who lives with this declarant and has been sick for more than two years and is now and has been under the declarants care for that length of time. She is wholly dependent on this declarant for her support. That since 18th of March 1818 the following changes have been made in my property on the 1st of March 1818. I had no [...] I had $400 in money a sh.. of horses wagon 4 horses and very little household furniture no more than what I moved in one wagon from Connecticut to the said county of Monroe with this money I bought 37 acres of land.

months by the command of his commanding officer as a recruiting officer, and was emplored in that service where he enlisted as many as sixty according to his best recollection. This deponent further says that some time in the month of July of that year he was ordered to join the army with what recruits he then had being twelve men. The others having been previously sent forward. That he accordingly marched with his twelve men & joined the army in the State of New York. he does not recollect the mane of the place. but it was near a place commonly called Rye- This deponent further says that he remained with the brigade & sensed faithfully until the expiration of the year for which he enlisted except about two monthly during which time he had leave of absence from his commanding officer this place was supplied by his brother Stephen Ellis who this deponent employed & paid- that this [written on the side near this sentence: 7th 1.0 months] deponent received an honorable discharge which has since been lost. This deponent further says that the principle object of the brigade to which he was attached as he understood was to protect the surrounding country from the depredations of enemy & the Tories then usually called Cow Boys- That the main army at this time had been principally withdrawn under the command of general Washington to the attack of Lord Cornwallis and the brigade to which deponent belonged was raised to supply the place of the regular army- This deponent further says that when he was appointed Sergeant in the army as a above mentioned he received a Sergeants commission or warrant which was signed either by General Waterbury of Major Humphry & he does not recollect which, that he kept it carefully as many as twenty years or more

She says the Statements made by him (John Ackerson) in his Declarations concerning the Several places where they have removed to and from are true - and that she has not the least doubt that what the whole of the Declaration is true - All that has come under her knowledge is true She says also that he has been now for three of four years almost helpless - that they have nothing to support themselves with and that they are supported by their son with whom they reside - She says she [illegible] well where the Indians and tories came against Cobuskill [Cobleskill] and burnt the place or nearly all the houses they also burnt nearly all the houses at Schoharrie [Schoharie] they killed about thirty of our people and many of the Riflemen. She says her husband John Ackerson was with the troops at this time. [Document is handwritten.] Philo Bacon a citizen of the United States now residing in the town of Conway in the county of Franklin and commonwealth of Massachusetts do on oath declare that I served in the army of the United States in the Revolution War. I entered the service in the month of July in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and seventy eight for the term of nine months in the company commanded by Captain William Watson in the Regiment of Colonel Wilson in the Massachusetts Line where I continued to serve until my enlistment had expired and I was honorably discharged therefrom. I again entered the service on the sixth day of July A.D. 1780 for a further term of six months in a company commanded by Captain Bailey in Colonel Bailey's Regiment - a few days afterwards I was transferred to the company commanded by Captain Bradford in Colonel Semott's Regiment all in the line aforesaid where I remained until my enlistment then expired and was honorably discharge therefrom at Fishkill, N.Y. When I left the service I received a written discharge which I kept for a long time but I have now lost it and have not seen it or had any knowledge of it for several years. I am now sixty years of age. I am poor and in reduced circumstances in life being wholly destitute of property and [illegible] in great need of assistance from my country for support. [illegible] at Greenfield in the County & commonwealth aforesaid this twentieth day of April A.D. 1818. Philo Bacon

I Abijah Fuller of the Town of Hampton in the County of Windham do testify and say, that I live within about one mile of the aforenamed Beriah Babcock, and an acquainted with him and his circumstances, and believe him to be a poor man and destitute of property, and reduced in his circumstances & to need assistance- Abijah Fuller Sworn before me Jabez Clarke Judge of the Court of Common place for the County of Windham And I do further Certify that Abijah Fuller the above Deponent is a man of God and his testimony to be relayed on Attended by Jabez Clarke I Jabez Clarke Judge of the Court of Common pleas for the County of Windham in Connecticut. Do Certify, that it appears to my satisfaction, that the said Beriah Babcock did serve in the Revolutionary War as stated in the Preceding Declaration. That ? knew him in the army, and before since the War and that he is in Reduced Circumstances and I now transmit the proceedings and Testimony taken and had before me to the Secretary for the Department of War Pursuant to the Directions of the aforementioned act of Congress. Attest Jabez Clarke I Samuel Gray Clerk of the Court of Common Pleas in and for the County of Windham in the State of Connecticut do Certify that Jabez Clarke Esq is Judge of the Court, that the foregoing signatures are his own hand writing, & he Seal Annexed is the seal of said Court.- In Testimony hereof I have unto set my name at Windham in County this 20 day of May AD 1818. Sam Gray

State of New York Washington County ss: Jesse Averil Junior being duly sworn saith that Jesse Averil the applicant for a pension is his father that on the 18th March 18 he was acquainted with the property of the said applicant that the inventory thereof as stated in the annexed declaration for a pension is truly stated and valued according to his best recollection and belief. That he well knows, that his farm therein mentioned was then and had been for many years under a mortgage to Timothy Leonard now deceased and that the said mortgage was foreclosed and the farm sold at public auction on the 22nd August 1827 whereby the said applicant has wholly lost his said farm and he further saith his present property is also truly inventoried and valued, and that the changes which have taken place are truly stated that he has lived in that same house with his father and has known his business and property ever since the time first aforesaid and he knows by reason of a trust that the said applicant has so lost the use of his limbs as to be wholly unable to labour for ten years past which has reduced him to poverty. That the farm so sold at auction was bid on by Martin Lee Esquire or Cambridge in said County who received a conveyance thereof as he is informed and believes. Further saith not. Jesse Averill Jun Sworn this 12th day of March 1829 Before me Isaac W. Bishop Commissioner to take affts

State of New York Washington County ss } Charles Chandler of Granville in said County being duly sworn saith that he is well acquainted with Jesse Averil an applicant for a pension and has been for fifteen years Last past that the inventory Stated for 18th March 1818 in the annexed Declaration is according to his belief truly stated and valued - and that his property has been such diminished since that period that his farm has been sold on an old mortgage to Timothy Leonard who during his Life was in the habit of calling only for the interest that said Leonard had many mortgages in Granville on which he was only in the habit of taking the interest during his life that the farm of said Jesse has been sold on said Mortgage and he lives wholly lost the same and their and that the inventory of his present property as stated aforesaid is in his opinion truly stated and realised, as the said Jesse by reason of a hurt has for few years past been unable to labour and has becme poor and nearly destitute of property further saith not Charles Chandler Sworn this 12 day of March 1824 Before me Isaac W. Bishop Commissioned to take affidavits
