State of New York County of Clinton On the twenty seventh day of January eighteen hundred and forty four personally appeared before the subscriber First Judge of the County Courts of said County Rhoda Drury a resident of Beekmantown in said County aged Seventy Seven years who being duly sworn doth on her oath make the following declaration in order to obtain a pension. That she has been informed and believes that her said Luther Drury deceased served more than two years and a half during the Revolutionary war in the Vermont Troops from 1778 to 1782 part of which time he served as a Sergeant. She has heard him say he served under Col Ebenezer Allen, Col Fletcher Capt Brookins Gideon Bronson Hutchins was in service at Pittsford, Castleton Vt and other places. He made a declaration of his services in 1832 at Plattsburg during which year he was placed on the Pension Roll at $90 per annum under the act of June 7, 1832 and received his pension to Sept 4 1843. Her maiden name was Rhoda Hopkins and she was married to the said Luther Drury at Pittsford Vermont in the twenty third day of February seventeen hundred and eighty six by Mr Harwood- a Presbyterian Clergyman and that she lived with said Luther Drury as his wife from the time of said marriage to the period of his death, which took place at Beekmantown aforesaid on the twenty second day of November 1843. By which event the said Rhoda was left a widow and she has since remained a widow and unmarried - and that she was not married to him prior to his leaving the service, but the mar riage took place previous to the first day of January Seventeen hundred and ninety four — viz at the time above stated. She claims a pension on account of her husband’s services— Sworn & Subscribed to before me on the day & year first above written & I certify that the applicant is personally known to me and is a credible person and is unable by reason of bodily infirmity to attend court which sits five miles from her residence. She is old & feeble, afflicted with rheumatism & has difficulty in walking about. William Hedding First Judge of Clinton County Courts Rhoda Drewry her X marks Note I certify that a part of the word “Seventeen” were written on an [illegible] before [illegible] she made her mark because she could not write on [illegible] William Hedding First Judge of Clinton County Courts

We Israel Keach- a Clergyman residing in the town of Hoosick in the County of Rensselaer and State of New York and Timothy Graves residing the same place, hereby certify that we are acquainted with Richard Covell who has subscribed and sworn to the above declaration; that we believe him to be sixty six years of age; that he is reputed and believed in the neighborhood, where he resides to have been a soldier of the Revolution, and that we concur in that opinion- Israel Keach Timothy Graves Sworn and subscribed the day and year aforesaid} Archibald Bull Clerk And the said Court do hereby declare their opinion, after the investigation of the matter, and after putting the interrogatories prescribed by the War Department, that the above named applicant was a Revolutionary Soldier and served as he states. And the court further certifies that it appears to then that Israel Reach who has signed the preceding certificate is a Clergyman resident in the town of Hoosick in the County of Rensselaer and State of New York and that Timothy Graves who has also signed the same, is a resident in the same place and is a credible person, and that their statement is entitled to credit- I Archibald Bull Clerk of the Court of Common Pleas called the Mayors Court in and for the City of Troy in the County of Rensselaer aforesaid do certify that the foregoing contains the original proceedings of the said Court in the matter of the application of Richard Covell for a Pension In testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand and seal of office this Eighth day of August 1832-- Archibald Bull Clerk

Westmoreland County State of Penna. personally came before me a Justice of the peace in and for Said County John Gress who being Sworn according to Law Sayeth that he was well acquainted with Lieutenant Jacob Holtzinger and Barbara his wife formerly from Northampton County Penna. who belonged to the flying camp of the County aforesaid and was Captured on Long Island and taken prisoner by the Hessians first put into a Church and afterwords put into a prison Ship that he was well acquainted with them and in Respect to his Services he only Speaks by tradition that he served Eighteen Months in the flying camp that he had his information by Reputation and by tradition from other Soldiers that knew him while in Service in Respect to their Mariage they had one Child born in Northampton County that Lived but a Short time and from my acquaintance with the family and particularly in Respect to the Second Child a Girl She was born in the Month of May last Seventy years past that is in May Seventy Seven that the widow is yet living and is poor and from the tradition of her husbands Service and hardships while on the prison Ship She aught to have his pension Granted his Service was in the Revolution. Sworn and Subscribed before me 29th December 1847 (signed) S.N. Kreider (signed) John Gress I do hereby certify that the above witness I am well acquainted with and do say he is a man of veracity and truth I would Receive his Evidence as truth (signed) S.N. Kreider

Commonwealth of Massachusetts. Plymouth ss By the HONOURABLE Joshua Thomas Esquire, Judge of the Probate of Wills, and for granting Letters of Administration on the Estates of Persons deceased, having goods, chattels, rights, or credits in the County of Plymouth within in Commonwealth aforesaid. To Nathan Hayward of Plymouth in the County or Commonwealth aforesaid Esqr. Greeting. Whereas the Selectmen of said Plymouth have made complaint to me, that Quomony Quash of Plymouth aforesaid Labourers, does by [illegible] Drinking & Idleness, so spend waste & [lessons??] his Estate as thereby to expose himself & Family to want & suffering Circumstances, & the Towns of Plymouth aforesaid to the Expense of his & their support & maintenance, therefore [crossed out word] TRUSTING in your care and fidelity, I do, by these Presents, pursuant to the power and authority to me granted, in and by an Act of the General Court, of the said Commonwealth, nominate and appoint you to be Guardian unto the said Quomony Quash, to take care of ihm [os] of his Estate both real & personal, to make a true & perfect Inventory of his Estate & exhibit the same into the Registry Office of the Court of Probate for said County at or before the twenty eighth day of June next, you are to pay all his just debts so far as his Goods Chattels Rights & Credits extend, & you are hereby invested with full power and authority to ask, demand, sue for, recover, receive and take into your custody, all and singular such part and portion of estate as [crossed out: accrues to in right of] [crossed out: or which] by any [crossed out: either] way or means whatsoever, doth of right apertain or belong to him and to manage, employ and improve the same for his best profit and advantage, and to render a plain and true account of your guardianship upon oath, so far as the law will charge you therewith, when you shall be remaining upon you account (the same being first examined and allowed by the Judge or Judges, for the time being, of Probate, &c.) [crossed out: unto the said minor who shall arrive at full age, [illegible]] as the said Judge or Judges, by his or their decree of sentence, pursuant to law, shall limit and appoint. In Testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and seal of the said Court of Probate. -- Dated at Plymouth the twenty eighth day of March in the Year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen Joshua Thomas

State of North Carolina} Ashe County.} SS On this twenty seventh day of December In the year of our lord one thousand eight hundred and forty two Justice of the peace for the county of Ashe and State of North Carolina Franky Toliver (being too aged and helpless and infirm to attend the court of Ashe county to make her declaration a resident of Ashe County North Carolina, aged seventy six years the following Sept. who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on her oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the provisions made by the acts of Congress passed July 7th 1838, the 7th entitled "an act granting half pay and pensions to certain widows: "That she is the widow of Jesse Toliver a private in the army of the revolutionary war and heretofore a pensioner upon the roll of the revolutionary army as will more firmly appear from the pension certificate, and records of the war Department - that he was born in Fauquier County Virginia, on the Rappahannock River removed shorty after to James River 30 miles above Richmond and remained three years, then removed to Wilkes County North Carolina lived about 5 or 6 years before the Revolutionary war. That he entered the service at 18 or 19 years of age as a volunteer under Capt. William Lenoir and Lieu. Barnet Owens against the Cherokee Indians on Readies River New River two months: then marched to the Cherokee nation on the Tennessee River four months there was no fighting as the Indians ran away. General Rutherford commanding Capt. Cleveland and his company who presentation is 2nd trip of two months as a volunteer under Capt. Lenoir and Col. Herndon to Ramsours mill on the Catawba, against the Tories & British The battle was fought when he was in about

I am deprived of the use of my limbs, and rendered helpless and wholly unable to work at my trade, which is that of a weaver I have no dependence but on public charity or the bounty of my Country. My family is a wife 70 years old and quite infirm.- I have no other estate or income than that contained in the foregoing schedule nor any debts due me. I served in the Militia in 1775, '76, and '77 and in the latter part of 1777 I enlisted into the army of the Revolution, for the term of three years as a carpenter, and entered the service in the Company of Capt John wood of Westborough in this Commonwealth in Col. Hay's Regt. in which I served till the summer of 1779, when I left that Company by enlisting for during the war, and entered the company of Capt. Andrew Moody in the 2nd and New York Regt. of Artillery under Col. John Lamb in which I served as a Matross till my discharge June 9, 1783. Edmund E Hill his X mark Test= S. Minot Essex. ss. July 13, 1820. Then the above named Edmund E. Hill made oath that the said schedule and statement by him subscribed are true Before Me Stephen Minot Judge of said Court [Rnd?]

State of Indiana Perry County I Wm S. Lamb Clerk of the Probate Court in and for said county do certify that evidence has been exhibited to the probate court of said Perry County that Abraham Hiley was a pensioner of the United States, at the rate of eighty dollars per annum, was a resident of the County of Perry in the State of Indiana, and died in the County of Perry in the State of Indiana in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and thirty six on the thirty first day of May in said year, and that he left a widow whose name was Mary Hiley who also departed this life in the said county of Perry in the year one thousand eight hundred and thirty seven, and that the said Abraham Hiley also left a son whose name is Abraham Hiley who is of lawful age and still living in said county and is the only child and heir at law of the said Abraham Hiley deceased and his said widow Mary Hiley deceased and it was further proved to said court that the pension certificate of the said Abraham Hiley deceased is not in the possession of his said son and that it cannot be surrendered as evidence of the identity of the said deceased, and that due search and inquiry have been made for said pension certificate and that it cannot be formed, and that said Abraham Hiley deceased was the identical person named in said certificate, all of which testimony adduced was satisfactory to said court. I do further certify that said Abraham Hiley son of said pensioner is administrator of the estate of said Abraham Hiley deceased and is duly authorized to act in that capacity on the estate of the deceased pensioner In testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand and affixed my seal of office at [illegible] said county & state this nineteenth day of November A D 1945 W. S. Lamb Ck

at Brandywine, where we arrived two nights before the Battle & was under the command of Brigadier General Potter, Generals Wayne, Green & Sullivan & Sterling & Armstrong & Brigadier Erwin were all there Washington also the Commander in chief Deponent fought in the battle at Brandywine, retreated to Chester & from thence to Philadelphia & thence up the Lancaster Road & had a skirmish near the 28 mile stone & was marched to Warren Hill Tavern & from thence to the Bull Tavern & from thence to Gordons Ford on Schuylkill river, was taken sick with dysentery where we had a skirmish and was with the Company scattered & deponent joined his company at the [illegible] church & was marched to the Line of the regular army below Pottsgrove & was places as an out guard and staid [stayed] 3 days without food, & we were called into the encampment & ordered rations & to remain there while the army went to the battle of Germantown. Afterwards was selected among others to march to Chester where we went & from there march to a Tavern called The Fox Chase where he was discharged for two months tour, thinks he served two & a half months. Against entered the Light Horse as a volunteer at Shippensburg aforesaid, in July or August 1787 under Capt Johnson, a militia Major was marched to Philadelphia & thence to Newtown Bucks County & there remained until he was discharged by General Lacy (under whose command he was all this last time) for a two month tour Served altogether upwards of seven months 1 was born in Ireland in the year 1758 & came to America in 1763. 2 He has a record of his age in his possession 3 When he entered the service he lived in Shippensburg Pennsylvania, since the Revolutionary War he lived nine months in Baltimore Maryland & drove wag[on]

State of Maryland } Dorchester County to wit. } Be it remembered that on the 30th of April A.D. 1818, before me William Bond Martin Esqr., chief Judge of the Fourth Judicial Dis trict of the State of Maryland, at Cambridge in the County afd. personally appeared Zadock Harvey of the said County, and made oath on the Holy Evangelist of Almighty God, that he enlisted as a soldier in the Maryland Line of the continental Army [words struck out] in the year 1778 to serve for three years; that he served first in the company commanded by Captain Lynch, and which was afterwards commanded by Captains Bensen, Reed, and Burd, and belonged to the 5th Maryland Regiment; and that he continued in the service for the period of his enlistment, and until he was discharged in the year 1781, but the precise days or months of his enlistment and dis charge he cannot recollect. The said Deponent further declares that he was very much injured by being rode over by the British light horse at Gates's defeat, but his wounds or injuries were not such as to enable him, under the strict ness of the pension law of the United States, to obtain a pension from that Government; and that altho' he has long suffered from his poverty, he has never received any aid or support from the public, except an allowance of $40 D. a year from the State of Maryland for the last five or six years; the said Deponent further declares that he is now old, infirm, very poor and wholly unable to support him self. Sworn to the day and year afd. before William B. Martin

AND I William Forbes do solely swear, that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the eighteenth day of March one thousand eight hundred and eighteen, and that I have not since that time by gift, sale, or in any matter whatever, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with the intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War" passed on the eighteenth day of March one thousand eight hundred and eighteen, and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts, due to me: nor have I any income, other than what is contained in the schedule, hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. (Signed) William Forbes Schedule of real and personal estate belonging to me the subscriber, necessary clothing and bedding excepted, viz Real Estate- None- Personal Estate.- one pair of oxen bought on credit, and owe for them their whole value-3 Cows- one pair of steers, 2 years old- one heifer, 2 years old - 1 heifer, 1 years old - 2 swine. I am justly indebted to the amount of - $156, and have no debts due to me that can be collected. Schedule of the family of William Forbes, who by occupation am an husbandman - I am afflicted with the Rheumatism and Cramps. My wife Lucy Forbes, 41 years with a slender constitution and sickley. Son Jefferson Forbes, 19 " - good health- works for me and goes to school Son Daniel Forbes, 18 " - {unable to work on account of fever - core} Son George Forbes, 16 " frequently afflicted with bilious colic Daughter Sally Forbes 11 years - Son Charles H. Forbes 7 years - Daughter Lucy G. Forbes, 2 years (Signed) William Forbes Sworn to and declared on the twenty seventh day of June A.D. 1820 before the Court. Att. Thos. Cobb Cler. I THOMAS COBB, Clerk of the Circuit Court of Common Pleas, for the Third Eastern Circuit, in the County of Penobscot, and State of Maine, do hereby certify that the foregoing oath and the schedule thereto annexed, are truly copied- from the records of the said court : And I do further certify, that it is the opinion of the said court, that the total amount of the property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule, is one hundred and fifty dollars. IN TESTIMONY WHEREOF, I have unto set my hand, and affixed the seal of the said Court, on this twenty seventh day of June A.D. 1820. Thos Cobb Clerk of the said Court for the County of Penobscot.

Durkee Esq. and that the 16th day of March 1779, he was appointed a captain in the 4th Connecticut Regiment in the Army of the United States, to take rank from the 1st of January 1777 -- all which will fully appear by the commissions granted to said Andrew Fitch hereto annexed. That the said Andrew Fitch served in said capacity through the War of the Revolution; that she was married to said Andrew Fitch on the 17th day of May 1781 before the last period of his service expired. That the said Andrew Fitch died on the 22nd day of August 1811. That she now remains the widow of said Andrew Fitch & that she resides in said Lebanon where she was born & where she has always resided. And she herby relinquishes any claims, whatever, to pension of [ ] (except for the pfesent) & declaires that her name is not on the Pension Roll of any State. Sworn to & subscribed this 7th day of June 1837 Abigail Fitch We Edward Bull clergyman residing in said Lebanon & Jason Williams also residing in said Lebanon, hereby certify that we are well acquainted with the aforesaid Abigail Fitch, who has subscribed, &

& sworn, to the above declaration; that we believe her to be eighty-two years of age, as she has stated & that the said Andrew Fitch was reported & so believed, in the neighborhood where he resided to have been a soldier of the Revolution, and that we believe he died as stated on the 22nd day of August 1811. And that the said Abigail Fitch now remains his widow & that she resides in Lebanon aforesaid and that we concur in that opinion. Sworn & subscribed this 7th of June 1837 Ed. Bull Jason Williams And the said Court do hereby declaire their opinoin after the investigation of the matter, & after putting the interrogations prescribed by the War Department, that the above mentioned applicant is the widow of said Andrew Fitch aforesaid dec'd. & that said Andrew Fitch was a soldier in the Revolutionary War, and served as stated. And that said Abigail Fitch now remains the widow of said Andrew Fitch & that she now resides in said Lebanon; & that Edward Bull, who has signed the preceding certificate is a clergyman resident in said Lebanon & Jason Williams is also a resident in said Lebanon and is a credible person & that their statement is entitled to credit. Julius Clark Judge of Probate for the Distrct of Lebanon.

State of Pennsylvania County of Lehigh CP On this fifth day of February in the year of our Lord One thousand eight hundred and thirty three, personally appeared in open court of Common pleas, Before the Honorable Garrick Mallery President John Fogle and Jacob Stern Equire associate Judges of the same Court, now sitting, Andrew Gangwer, a resident of Easton in the County of Northampton in the state of Pennsylvania, in the Eighty sixth year of his age, who being first duly sworn according to Law, doth, on his oath, name the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress passed June 7. 1832. That he entered the service of the United States, and served as herein stated; That in the month of July in the year of our Lord one thousand and seven hundred and seventy six he enlisted in the flying Camp and marched from the town of Northampton, in the county of Northampton, (now Borough of Northampton in the County of Lehigh) and State of Pennsylvania, in the Company Commanded by Captain Henry Hagenbuch, under the Command of Colonel Kechline, through the state of New Jersey to South Amboy, at the time the British lay on Staten Island, that after he was there one month, he was permitted to accompany Captain Orlies to New York & Fort Washington, that on his return he met his Company near New York on their march toward Long Island, that he was permitted to return home and did return home, after selling his gun, sword & other equipment to the Commanding officer, and was allowed, he thinks, Four pounds ten Shillings for the same, but that he never received any pay for them, That Captain Joseph Hiester and Captain John Arndt were with the army aforesaid, with their companies. That in the year seventeen hundred & seventy seven, he then being a first Lieutenant of Militia, he was ordered out with his company, commanded by Captain Francis Roth, under the Command of Major Stephen Ballet and Major Jacob Young, that they marched from the town of Northampton aforesaid, to Farmers Mill, in the vicinity of Philadelphia after remaining there a few days, were ordered back to Northampton and thence to near Morristown in New Jersey, where General Washingtons head Quarters was, that he served two months as First Lieutenant, when his Company were dismissed and he returned home, in the month of March, that he does not remember the names of the other officers nor the Continental Regiment with which he served,- That in the month of May in the same year he was sent by Commissary Britton, to South Carolina to purchase cattle for the army That in the year seventeen hundred & seventy seven, aforesaid, in the month of October, he marched from Northampton aforesaid, in the Company Commanded by Captain Moritz, in the Militia, as first Lieutenant, a substitute for First Lieutenant Edward Sheimes, under

Lehigh County Pa before me the subscriber, one of the Justices of the Peace in and for the County Personally appeared Jacob Newhart Senior who being duly sworn, according to Law deposeths and says that he knows that Andrew Gangeware in the year seventeen hundred and seventy seven turned out in Deference of his Country into the State of New Jersey and served a tour of duty as [something] in the company of Captain Francis Roth and that said Gangeware was sent to Carolina to buy cattle for the Army. Soon after he returned with the [something] of cattle, he turned out again at the time the British lay in the City of Philadelphia and served another tour of duty in that campaign he further says that said Gangeware is very old and poor and is in needy circumstances Signature of: Jacob Newhard Sworn and subscribed before this 3th Day of February 1830 before me Signature of: Christ Beitel

Capable of judging Namely my being thick of hearing can you not think it is more than possible that I being almost worn out with age and other infirmities failing in my hearing as well in other facultie's while have often on this account to have to ask the second time to know what is said to me Can you not think Sir under these circumstances that it is reasonable to think that this might be the cause why I did not notice the mistake in my Claim Not Doubting but that it was correct I wish Sir that you would consider this with Candor Now Sir in view of the whole this and former testimony as I stated in my Claim that the first time I entered the revolutionary Service under Captain Pain I was draughted[drafted] my former witness to this service who was declared according to Law to be a man of truth and veracity the same witness Now testifies that the first time I entered the Service that I was Drafted and that I was 16 years of age or upward or more which is true for I should have bin 17 in about one month Mr Woodruff says and I presume it is so that he has sent the Last Deposition to you which I expect you have rec'd stating my age when Drafted as to my character others have stated among the rest I had recommends from a Number of Churches where I have lived which Mr Woodruff says he handed to you which if you have had you have undoubtedly Learnt that I am it professor of religion I presume honourd[honored] Sir that you will not be prejudiced against me on this account I Live in friendship among my fellow Citisons[citizens] and I am so simple that they will Let me preach among any Christian Denomination where they are acquainted with me when I have ben able Sir I think you are capable of Guessing at the infirmities of old age I am not able to ride in a waggon at all if I was able by Sea or Land to perform such a journey I would see you in person but it cannot be I hope sir in view of the whole matter that you will be satisfied that there was a mistake in my claim and that my claim is Just I hope sir you will have candid feelings in

for more than three years in consequence of a pardidick shock and greatly wants the benefit of his pension bid and supports him to his utmost hardship and affective situation Justice Altman Sworn and described this twenty fifth day of November 1837 before me Henry Gorlee one of the judges of the Court of Common pleas as ? for the County of Greene and State of New York I Henry Gorlee Judge as aforementioned do certify that I have been well acquainted with Mse Justice Altman for than thirty years and so will know that he is highly esteemed as a very pious Christian

District of Connecticut, ss. At a Court of Common Pleas, holden at Brooklyn and for the County of Windham iin Said District On this 30th day of March A.D. 1822 personally appeared in open Court, being a Court of Record for the County aforesaid, [Having the power of fine and imprisonment,] Ezra Fuller of Mansfield in said County aged almost 80 years, who, being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath declare, that he served in the Revolutionary war as follows, viz: That enlisted for the term of one year on or about the 10th day of March in the year 1776 in the State of Connecticut in the company commanded by Captain Jedediah Hyde in the regiment commanded by Colonel Samuel Wyllys in the line of the State of Connecticut on the Continental establishment: that he continued to serve in the said corps until sometime in the first part of January 1777 - having served nine months & two weeks when he was discharged from the said service in Peekskills in the State of New York That his discharge was a verbal one - That by occupation he is a shoe maker but unable to work at the trade -- That he has for many years been afflicted with the Rheumatism & lameness in one hand & also with deafness & decay of my eyesight. - That he has a wife Lydia aged 71 years infirm unable to labor but very little - That he has been a pensioner of Congress of the 18 of March 1818 his certificate is No 10, 487- That he applied for a continuance of said pension under the act of May 1st 1820 but was rejected on account of the amount of property contained in his Schedule. That property has since been disposed of to satisfy his just debts which were due and owing from him at the time he made said application, & for his necessary support except the Annexed Schedule He therefore, prays that the decision rejecting his Appplication may be re-considered & his name restored to the Pension List - And I do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States, on the 18th day of March, one thousand eight hundred and eighteen; and that I have not, since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property , or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled, "”an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary war, passed on the 18th day of March, one thousand eight hundred and eighteen; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts, or debts due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the Schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. Ezra Fuller & Schedule of the whole estate and income of Ezra Fuller aforesaid this 30 day of March 1822 – viz Income from 25 acres of poorland this property of my wife $10.00 per annum 1 Cow 15.00 1 old broken chest of Drawers 2.00 17.00 Two old tables 1.00 1 old foot wheel 1.00 6 old chairs 1.50 3.50 Six old knives & forks 0.50 $21.00 Ezra Fuller

one sow & pigs $4.00 three small pigs $2.00 One Mattock $1.50 one ax $1.25 three small hoes $0.75 grain in the sheaf and in the ground $59.33 ½ Debts due by petitioner $101.50 - My family consists of my wife aged fifty years and six daughters one of whom has two children & one son James aged five years old. I am by profession a labourer and by age and infirmities am now totally unable to work - Sworn and subscribed in open Court the twenty seventh day of September in the year of our Lord one thousand Eight hundred and twenty } John Taylor Prothy (Signed) James Shields his mark State of Pennsylvania Indiana County ss I, John Taylor Prothonotary of the Court of Common pleas of said County of Indiana do hereby certify that the foregoing oath and the schedule thereto annexed are truly copied from the record of the said Court and I do further certify that it is the opinion of the said Court that the total amount or value of the property exhibited in the aforesaid Schedule is One hundred and fourteen dollars and thirty three cents In Testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand and affixed the seal of the said Court at Indiana on this twenty sixth day of October 1820 - John Taylor Prothy

John Bridges In Augt 1822 of Boone Co Ky aged about 66 years in May 1833 age 78 Enlisted for 3 years in (crossed out) 1776/1777 at Va under Capt Wm Washington of 3rd reg Col Heath Discharged in Penn was in the battles at Brandywine 1777, Germantown 1777 & Monmouth 1778 The he again enlisted under Capt Lynn into a troop of horse in the regiment of Wm Washington who had been promoted to a Col continuing to serve until after Lord Cornwallis Surrendered at Yorktown and dischg at Guilford CH to which place he had marched under the command on Gen'l Morgan - both dischg lost. Inventory of his property including a horse, cow + calf with furniture which amounted in 1823 to $70.00. He was a farmer + his family in 1823 consisted of his wife aged 57 years who was lame + decriped in one hand, two orphan grand daughter aged 10 + 12 years without property + one orphan boy aged 12 years He died March 20 1838 He mar'd March 12, 1785 in Stafford Co Va to Jane SS She in April 1839 was living in Boone Co Ky aged 73 years Their daughter Levina Riley was born Oct 28, 1785 alive in 1850 In battles Guilford Camden Reedy river Eutaw Springs Dorchester + 96. rec'd one wound in all his service Lost his discharge in crossing Shenondoah river when moving to Ky Levina Riley born Oct 25, 1785 mar'd Dec 24, 1801 Henry Riley who was born June 1, 1783 - She living in Boone Co 1839 children Seton S June 4 1803 Conny C Oct 22 1815 Isom A Feby 27 1806 Agnes B " 31 1817 Sarah I Jany 8 1808 Henry W " 25 1819 Jesse I " 3 1810 John C " 16 1812 Fielding H Nov 3 1813

At the time when the affair just spoken of took place Col Bailors men were quartered at Tappan and the Inhabitants of the place pre =tended to be very friendly to the cause of the Americans, and all of them made parties for the American soldiers and furnished large quantities of spirits of the [illegible] kind for the troops - and the American soldiers supposing [illegible] safe and in the hands of their friends became merry to excess. In the mean time the Torys sent off runners to New York to inform the Brittish of the [illegible] of the Troops. This applicant was sleeping that night in a Stone Barn at Tappan with many more of the Troops. There were troops quartered at about every house in the place, and he must say it with regret that few of them were in a situation to defend themselves even had they been apprised of the danger which was surrounding them, owing to the carousal a few hours previous as before stated. He was aroused from his sleep by the breaking of doors, without and the cries of the sold =iery for quarters. Two men were sleeping close to him under the same cover and he attempted to awake them for he knew that the [illegible] were surprised by the enemy - but he could not [illegible] of the men having insensible through drunkeness. He therefore thought to make his escape and went to the barn door and slipped a small sliding door (which may contain in the large door) but notwiths =tanding the darkness he could see plainly that the Barn was surrou =nded by armed men, he therefore asked for quarter, They replied to him "God damn your Rebbel soul we will give you quarters" and they demanded of him "how many men are in the Barn"; he answered that he did not know how many. At this time the men within had become alarmed, except (those who were drunk) and were seeing out at the [illegible] places in the Barn where they could make their escape when upon the Brittish and Torys cried out "skiner them" "skiner them" (which meant bayonet them.) The whole party [illegible] were killed, wounded, and taken prisoner except a few of those in the Barn (Eight in all with Capt Stith [illegible]) This applicant was taken prisoner and ordered to stand while an arm =med man stood by to guard him. He took the opertunity when the rest of the Enemy [illegible] [illegible] distance as [illegible] and sprang over a fence to make his escape, the guard sprang at him and as he was jumping over the fence he was stabbed in the back by a plunge of his persuers bayonet which entered near the back bone which wounded him very bad. He however made his escape notwithstan =ding he was almost fainting under the pain of his wound. The horrors of that night will never be effaced from his memory. [illegible] the curses of an infuriated soldiery were [illegible] the cries and groans of the wounded an dying! Maj. Clough was run through with a bayonet while asking for quarter! After this he went to Trenton - from thence to Philladelphia where he remained until the spring of 1779 where he [illegible] to Baltimore where he was honourably discharged in writing by Capt john Stith by the command of Col Bailor - in the Month of May 1779. = This applicant was acquainted with Genl Washington [illegible] Genl Gates, Genl Lee Genl Paulaski, Genl [illegible} Col Washington genl Putnam Genl Wayne & [illegible] were many continental companies, and Regiments, [illegible] with the troops where I saw and experienced at Elizabeth town Trenton Fredericksburg and Monmouth, but the particular companies or Regiments I cannot remember He has no written or dockument his services _ _ _ _

Commonwealth of Massachusetts Be it remembered that on this twentieth day of April in the year of our Lord, one thousand eight hundred, and eighteen, before me Samuel Dana Chief Justice of the Circuit Court of Common Please, for the middle circuit, comprehending the counties of Essex and Middlesex in the Commonwealth aforesaid comes William Bartlett of Shirley in said County of Middlesex, and on oath declares that he served in the War of the Revolution against the common enemy, three years and five months - He enlisted upon Continental establishment, in the month of May in the year of our Lord one thousand, seven hundred, and seventy seven under Capt. Sylvanus Smith in Col Bigelows Regiment in Glovers Brigade, in the Massachusetts line, he was mustered at Concord and that Reg leader James Barnett joined Capt Smith's company at Worcester and did three years service, in that company and received a discharge from Capt Smith at the highlands in New York, the 14th day of May, 1780 Capt. Smith then commanding the 15th Mass'tts Regiment. Before he engaged for the above three years he served five months at Ticonderoga under Capt. Joshua Parker in Col. Jons Rews Regiment in the Mass line in 1776 - He is now seventy seven years of age, is destitute of property, and by reason of his medical circumstances in life, he he stands in need of assistance from his Country for support. William Bartlett Thus made, taken subscribed and sworn to at Groton in said County of Middlesex the day and year aforesaid -- Saml. Dana

Holland for the term of five months. We marched from Headquarters at the house of a certain Amos Garrett in Persooci Hundred in the state of Maryland to the landing on the Chesapeake Bay, thence by the order of Lieutenant Dullam to Persooci Island from which plan we drew to the Maryland side three hundred and fifty cattle through fear the British coming up the bay under the command of Lord Howe would take them. The declarant continued with the company near the bay of the Chesapeake watching the British until his five months expired when he was dismissed with the rest of the company - The declarant again volunteered or was called into service in a company commanded by Samuel Smith (Francis Holland having been advanced to the rank of Colonel) on or about the first of June 1778 for the term of two months - We were marched to the head of Eck thence to New Castle to keep the Tories in order and from stealing cattle for the British then returned to the Head of Eck where we all remained until dismissed which was sometime about the first of August 1778. The declarant further states that the "Harford Greens" the company in which he served as aforesaid had volunteers that served as "minute men" for the term of eighteen months during which term the said company was called into service at the different periods above stated, except the last when this declarant with the few remaining of Capt. Holland's company volunteered in the company of Captain Smith - as above stated - This declarant claims a pension for the term of eight months being the whole time he was in the actual service of the United States - This declarant further states that he had no documentary evidence to establish the fat of his service and that he knows of no person whose testimony he can procure who can testify to the same, except Alexander Ford whose deposition is hereto annexed. This declarant hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present and declares that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any state. John Barns Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid - Attest - Randal McLaughlin - Proth.

To the Department of War of the United States A very old lady the widow of Christian Dentzler, deceased, in needy circumstances wishes to make an application for a pension under the act of July 1836. Her husband was a Revolutionary Soldier and as I am informed drew a Pension under the early laws of Congress. Please to inform me by certificate as in such manner as is usual, if his name is not on the Pension roll, as a Pensioner from Pennsylvania, to receive a pension under the first laws granting pensions and give me also such a description of a reference to the Records of his application, in the proper office, as will be suitable to insert in her application as a reference to said records and state whether the proof of service annexed to contains in his recorded application will be sufficiently satisfactory proof of service to sustain her application referred to [?] Also please state if in a case in which all family record of marriage has been accidentally destroyed by a fire which burnt down the dwelling house and there is no other documentary evidence and no linving witness known who has a knowledge of the first marriage, whether a certified copy [illegible] of an affidavit of the fact of a marriage, made many years ago by one having then a knowledge of the fact, taken in relation to another proceeding and filed on record with proof of the death of the applicant if that he was a man of credibility in conjunction with the declaration of the widow to the same effect; will not be taken as sufficiently satisfactory proof of marriage. James Pleasant Catawissa Columbia County Pennsylvania 30th December 1839

State of New Jersey Gloucester County ss On this twenty third day of June in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and twenty six, personally appeared in open court, before the judges of the Court of Common Pleas of the county of Gloucester in the State of New Jersey, being a court of record, proceeding according to the course of the common law with a jurisdiction unlimited [illegible] of amount keeping record of their proceedings, and having the power of fine and imprisonment, John Cahill aged about sixty seven years, resident in the Township of Waterford in the county of Gloucester, aforesaid, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the provision made by the Acts of Congress of the 18 March 1818 and of the 1st May 1820. That he the said John Cahill enlisted for the term of the continuance or during the War on the ________ day of January in the year seventeen hundred and seventy seven in Philadelphia in the state of Pennsylvania in the company commanded by Captain Samuel Hugg in the regiment commanded by Colonel John Lamb in the line of the state of New York (called the 2nd or New York regiment of Artillery) on the continental establishment, that he continued to serve in the same regiment until the close of the war, that he was discharged at West Point in the state of New York, that he hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension except the present, that his name is not on the roll of any state except as before stated and that the following are the reasons for not making earlier application for a pension, to wit: I had been informed and believed that I could not obtain a pension unless I was absolutely unable to support myself, that before that time I had supported myself by

District of New Jersey Be it remembered that on the twentieth day of December in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and twenty four personally appeared in open court before the judges of the Court of Common Pleas of the county of Gloucester in the state of New Jersey, being a court of Record proceeding according to the court of the common law, having jurisdiction unlimited in point of amount and keeping records of its proceedings, John Cahill, aged sixty six years, resident in the township of Waterford in the said county, who being first duly sworn according to law on his solemn oath doth declare and say that he served in the Revolutionary War as follows: That he enlisted in the month of January Anno Domini seventeen hundred and seventy seven under Captain Samuel Hugg (the company was attached to Col John Lamb's regiment of Artillery) and remained, in the regiment and in the service of the United States until the Army was disbanded in seventeen hundred and eighty three at West Point, that he was in the Battles of Brandywine, Germantown and Monmoth. And I do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March 1818, and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale, or any other manner disposed of my property or any part thereof with an intent so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of the act of Congress entitled "An act to provide for certain persons

State of New Hampshire Grafton Ss. At the Court of Common Pleas being a court of record by law established holden at Plymouth within and for said county of Grafton on the second Tuesday of July in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and twenty - Present the honorable Ezra Bartlett Daniel Blaisdell} Esquires Justices Personally appeared in Open Court James Boies aged seventy seven years resident in Peeling in said county of Grafton who being duly sworn according to law doth on his oath declare that he served in the Revolutionary War as follows viz a private soldier in Capt Ebenzer Frys company & Col Cilly's regiment in the New Hampshire line that his original declaration is dated 28th day of April 1818 and that he has received a pension and his pension certificate is numbered 3,228. And I do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the eighteenth day of March 1818 and that I have not since that time by gift sale or any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress entitled "an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the revolutionary war passed on the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities contracts or debts due to me nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed And by me subscribed. I further declare I am by occupation a farmer and past laborer, blind, sore & lame and decrepit - my wife aged 72 years she is able to be about some for a woman of her age I have one child at home with me viz Mary Boies aged fifty five years she is Non Compus Mentus unable to take care of herself under these circumstances together with my real poverty do stand in need of my country's bounty - James Boies

State of Massachusetts County of Worcester I Francis Blandin a Citizen of the United States, now resident at Oxford in the County of Worcester in the State aforesaid, do on oath testify and declare, that in the War of the Revolution, on or about April AD 1775 I entered and was engaged in the land service of the United States on the continental establishment, and served accordingly from that time to October AD 1776 as a private soldier against the common enemy, without any interruption or absence: that I belonged to Captain Cook's Company in Colonel Gardners regiment, and was afterwards transfered to Colonel Bonds regiment under Genl Sullivan and that I left the service on in October AD 1776 having been in it about eighteen months & was honourably discharged which discharge I have lost, and that, by reason of my reduced circumstances in life and poverty, I stand in need of assistance from my country for support, being now of the age of sixty two years. And I hereby relinquish all claims to every pension heretofore allowed me by the laws of the United States, if any may be or hath been so allowed. Francis Blandin BE IT REMEMBERED, That on this 10th day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen pursuant to a law of the United States, entitled, "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War," made and passed on the 18th of March, A. D. 1818, personally appeareth before me, Isaac Parker Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Massachusetts the abovenamed Francis Blandin and after due examination and caution to testify and declare the whole truth, he maketh oath to the declaration aforesaid, and subscribes the same in my presence; and, on examination duly made by me the said Judge, it appeareth to my satisfaction that the said declaration is true. Witness my hand & the Seal of said Court, the day & year aforesaid Isaac Parker C S C

State of New York Steuben County Daniel Spike, on this 19th day of October 1820, personally appeared in open court, being a court of record for said county, and being sworn, saith that he owes one hundred & sixty dollars, for the land mentioned in his schedule, sworn to in said court, on the 20th June 1820. Which said land, would not sell for that amount at public sale - and this despondent further saith, that his contract for said land, mentioned in said Schedule, has became forfeited - Sworn to & subscribed in open Court the 19th October 1820. Daniel Spike Wm. H. Bull, Dep Clk of Steuben Cou. pleas. Steuben County Clerks Office I do hereby certify the above to be a true copy of the original affidavit no on file in the office of the Clerk of the County of Steuben In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand, and affixed the seal of said Court, at both on this 14th day of November 1820. Wm. H. Bull, Dep Clk

Revolutionary Claim, under Act of Congress, May 1, 1820 State of Vermont, Franklin County SS Supreme Court July, tdy. Term 1920 On this Eleventh day of July 1920 personally appeared in open Court, being the Supreme Court, for the County of Franklin and a Court of Record for said County having the power of fine & Imprisonment Elijah Pratt aged 62 years, resident in Franklin in said County who being duly sworn, according to law, doth on his oath, declare that he served in the revolutionary war as follows: I enlisted during the war on fall of the year before Majr. Andre was hung but the year i donot recollect under Apt. Abner Howard in Col. Baileys Regt. in Learnards Brigade in Massachusetts line and served untill the fall or winter of the next year, when I had a furlough to go home where I got here and was not again called for. I was with Genl. Sullivan on Rhode Island. That my original declaration is dated July 2 1818 and my pension Certificate is Numbered 11483. And I do solemnly swear, that I was a resident citizen of the United States, on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congres, entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary war," passed on the 18th day of March 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities, contracts, or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other that what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed One hundred forty acres land purchased of Saml. Hubbard Esq. for 560 dollars and mortgaged to him for the same sum and Nothing paid. Two horses 40 dollars 2 hogs 8 dolls. one calf 3 dolls. one 3 paid kettle 3 dolls. one spider 67 cents one tea kettle 1 doll. and owe about eighty five dollars have about eight or nine dollars due me. I am by occupation a carpenter but am not able to work at my trade my wife is aged 62 years she has been weakly for 20 years one daughter of 16 years old that is healthy another of the same age that is a cripple and one aged 28 years that is a cripple and helpless. Elijah Pratt Sworn to and declared on the 11th day of July 1820 Before the court Attest Horace Janes Clerk State of Vermont Franklin County, ss. I Horace Janes Clerk of the Supreme Court do hereby certify that the foregoing oath and the schedule thereto annexed, are truly copied from the record of said court; and I do further certify, that it is the opinion of the said court that the total amount in value of the property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule, id Fifty five dollars free from debt nothing In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and affixed the seal of the said court, on this 18 day of July 1820 Horace Janes Clerk (seal)

the deponent further states that her father in the year of our Lord 1818 made an application to the Hon Charles Kellogg for a pension agreeable to a late act of Congress. The judge then and there examined all his papers and witnesses and then said publicly there was not a doubt resting on his mind respecting the honest claims that my father then had on our government for his pension except one - and that was he then had too much property for to take the benefit of that act. Of course he did not apply but a few years afterwards he became poor and needy, and was expressive to his children and remained so until the day of his death which took place on the 18th day of September 1829 - aged seventy five years and nine months. Then his widow Prudence was living in the town of Fairfield Huron County Ohio. And if I mistake not, she made her petition for a pension in the year 1836, now all her witnesses must be circumstantial for all of my father's papers and witnesses is dead and destroyed, and not one can any branch of our family now find. Witness names that went before the Hon Judge was Joseph Coats, Russell Brockway, Capt Seth Burgess and others, all of them men, was of Truth and veracity, and always stated that they was well acquainted with my father, both in the Northern and Eastern army as above stated, and the Deponent further states that the above story has always been stated for truth and that she upon her oath believes the above mentioned statement to be bonded and true, and without contradiction, yet it is with great reluctance that the deponent must make an affidavit and state all those amount military maneuvering that took place with her father previous to her birth. Yet she considers it no sin to state this narrative, as he related it to her. The deponent further states that she has often and repeatedly heard her father and other old soldiers state that he was in Saratoga and Bennington Battles likewise old Ticonderoga. Likewise Borough and Mountain dependence. And a great number on Lake Champlain that there names is now out of her mind.

and furthermore this deponent states that he received all the above mentioned papers from the hands of his father William Greenfield and loosely deposited them with his own military papers until the year of our Lord 1836, in the month of June if I mistake not, I saw no further use for our old army papers. I therefore committed them to the flames, not intending however to destroy our old military commissions and discharges. Yet I do believe that my fathers papers was all committed to that flame. For now not one can be found. And furthermore the deponent thinks that he can safely state that his father was a man of truth and veracity, and that he would die in fighting for the liberty of our country. And that he was repeatedly from his youth up to his father's death been instructed by him, and other soldiers in the same army, that he the said William Greenfield served our Country under the authority of the above mentioned papers signed by men of authority then in officers. Which had the attendance to lead him into many a hard fought battle on Lake Champlain and Lake George, Bennington, and Saratoga to many to now mentions which bound him to suffer much with his wounds, cold and hunger. This statement the deponent saith that his father and others has made in his hearing ever since his infancy. Which he believes to be a true history and without fraud. And further the deponent saith not. Wm. Greenfield And that the whole time would amount to four or five years services. Sworn before me this 4th day of Sept AD 1843 Hosea B. Pierce Justice of the Peace

State of Connecticut,} Middlesex County} ss. Probate district of SayBrook in sd county On this Tenth day of Sept 1832 personally appeared, in open Court, before the Court of Probate within and for the Probate district of Saybrook county of Middlesex and State of Connecticut, now setting at SayBrook in said district Reuben Bull a resident of SayBrook in the County of Middlesex and State of Connecticut, aged Eighty one years, who being firt sworn according to law, doth, on his oath, make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the Act of Congress, passed June 7, 1832. That he entered the service of the United States under the following named Officers, and served as herein stated. That he was Eighty one years of age in November last. That he was born in SayBrook in the County of Middlesex and State of Connecticut, where he has always lived. Thate there is a record of his age in the family Bible of his Father, put there he supposes by him, & that there is no other record of his birth, that he is aware of. That in the month of June A.D. 1776 at the Town of SayBrook aforesaid, he enlisted to serve in the Revolutionary War for the term of six months_ and that he faithfully served out the whole period of his said enlistment, as a corporal. That the officers of the company in which he enlisted and served, Elisha Chapman. Captain, John Hart 1st and Job Wright 2d Lieutenants, and Nathanial Jones Ensign, all of whom are dead, as the applicant supposes. That he joined the said company at Killingsworth in this state, that they went from thence to New York by water, and there joined the Regiment, the same being commanded by Col. Samual Selden of Lyme in this State. Lieut. Col. Latimer, and Majr. Clift. That the said company was stationed in the city, or a little back of, until the British were landed on Long Island, when said company was ordered on to said Island, marched down in to the neighborhood of Jamaica, and went in to (unknown word_ Hill Fort. remained there until the British came up in sight & pitched their tents. Considerable fighting but the said company not engaged in it. The enemy retreated back at Brooklyn in the night. across the Rive to New York the night while and dark. That the said company took its old place again on York Island, remained a short time and then went to Turtle Bay where they encamped and remained until about the fifteenth

The said Reuben Bull hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity, except the present, and declares that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any State. Sworn to, and subscribed, the day and year aforesaid. Reuben Bul; Before me Samuel Ingham Judge of Probate We Aaron Hovey a clergyman, residing in the town of SayBrook and William Bull residing in the same, hereby certify, that we are well acquainted with Mr. Reuben Bull who has subscribed and sworn to the above declaration; that we believe him to be 81 years of age; that he is reputed and believed, in the neighborhood where he resides, to have been a soldier of the revolution, and that we concur in that opinion. Aaron Hovey William Bull Before me Samuel Ingham Judge of Probate And the said Court do hereby declare their opinion, after the investigation of the matter, and after putting the interrogatories prescribed by the War Department, that the abovenamed applicant was a revolutionary Soldier, and served as he states. And the Court further certifies, that it appears to them that Rev'd Aaron Hovey who has signed the preceding certificate is a clergyman, resident in the tow of SayBrook and that William Bull Esq who has also signed the say, is a resident in the town of SayBrook and is a credible person, and that their statement is entitled to credit. Samuel Ingham Judge of Probate I, Richard P Williams Clerk of the Court of Probate for the district of SayBrook in the Statte of Connecticut do hereby certify that the foregoing contains the original proceedings of the said Court in the matter of the application of Reuben Bull for a Pension. In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and seal of the Probate Office this Tenth day of September 1832 Richd P Williams Clerk

I. John Brownlee of Washington County in the State of Pennsylvania, do swear by Almighty God the searcher of hearts, that I served in the revolutionary war against the common enemy from the Month of April A.D. one thousand seven hundred and seventy six, till the month of January one thousand seven hundred and seventy eight. I enlisted in Captain Joseph Irwin’s Company of Colonel Miles regiment, Pennsylvania Riflemen. At the battle of Long Island Colonel Miles was taken prisoner and our regiment in various battles was reduced to thirty five men - In the Spring succeeding the battle of Princeton the remnant of our regiment which had been somewhat recruited during the Winter was consolidated with another and formed what was called the Pennsylvania State regiment. This regiment was for some time commanded Colonel Bull, and afterwards by Colonel Walter Stewart. In this regiment I continued till the expiration of the time of my enlistment, and some time after and was honourably discharged at Valley Forge about the middle of January A.D. one thousand seven hundred and seventy eight. My discharge, which was burned in my cabbin thirty years ago, was signed “Walter Stewart commanding 13th Pennsylvania Regiment.” I was present and engaged in the battles of Long Island, White Plains, taking the Hessians at Trenton, battle of Trenton and of Princeton

OWN Washington County Pennsylvania Sct Personally before me one of the Associate Judges of the Court of Common pleas for the County of Washington, aforesaid, came John Brownlee who being duly sworn according to law doth declare that the facts stated in the aforegoing declaration are true and signed the same in my presence. And I do also certify that I am satisfied that the said John Brownlee is in needy circumstances and that he served as stated in his declaration. I witness whereof I have hereunto set my hand and seal this 26th day of June A.D. 1818. James Allison [seal] Washington County Penns’a Sct I Alexander Murdoch Prothonotary of the Court of Common Pleas for County do certify that James Allen before whom the above deposition was made is and was at the time one of the associate Judges of the Court of Common Pleas in and for said County duly commissioned, and that full faith and credit is and ought to be given to all his Official Acts. In testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand and seal of Office the first day of July in the year of our LORD one Thousand Eight Hundred and Eighteen Alex’r Murdoch Prothy The secretary of war is respectfully requested to cause information to be given to William Baird of Washington Pennsylvania, of his decision in this case

Declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the 3d section of the act of Congress of the 4th July, 1836. State of New Jersey, County of ['Hunterdon' and 'Morris' crossed out] Morris SS: On this 24th day of December, Anno Domini 1839, personally appeared before the Court of Common Pleas of Morris County aforesaid, Mary Stiles, a resident of Pequannock township Morris County, N. Jersey, aged 86 years, who being first duly sworn according to Law, doth on her oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the provision made by the act of Congress passed July 4th 1836:- I am the widow of John Stiles, who was, as I believe, an Issuing Commissary of provisions in the militia of Morris County New Jersey, & served in the war of the revolution, from its beginning in 1776 to its end. It is probable that I may have mistaken the title by which my husband, the said John Stiles was known when upon actual duty; & I admit that I do not know myself, what his proper Military title was. I believe he was sometimes called Quarter Master, & Continuous Commissary. His duties as far as I understood them in the time of the war, consisted in distributing provisions to the Militia troops when they were in service at the various places where they were ordered, & also to purchase & collect from farmers, & wherever provisions could be bought. He was absent from his family almost all the war. When he was not following the soldiers in their marches from place to place, was attending them when in camp or at quarters, he was out buying & collecting provisions for their use. His purchases consisted of Beef, pork, flour, Grain &c. He was a man of considerate property, with a good farm, well stocked with cattle, & money at command, & often when not furnished by government with means, he bought supplies for the Militia with his own means, & often upon his individual credit, & in this way & by means of continental money, I believe he lost a large proportion of his Estate.- I do not believe it will be in my power to specify or particularize in detail the various services of my said husband-- stating under whose particular command he acted, the various places to which his duty called him, or down he was engaged at any one point. I have heard him often speak of General Winds, Colonel Munson, Colonel Seely, Colonel Hathaway: Captain Minn, Bates, Ward, Baldwin & others, under whose command he acted, furnishing & distributing provisions to troops commanded by them, at different times & places. How many teams & wagons loaded with supplies were under his direction, I cannot tell his own team & wagon were almost constantly out, either collecting or distribution, & I believe he often hired & employed others for the public service; & when money was short & public & private and it both failed, he often recd. orders, forcibly if necessary, to take grain & meat to prevent the soldiers on duty from suffering. In the performance of his public duties, he was, as I believe, engaged by order of some of the before named officers, often at Elizabeth town, at Newark, at Morristown, Quibble town, New Brunswick, Amboy, Monmouth, Pompton, Springfield, Connecticut farms- Hackensack, Aquahanack & other places not recollected. At these places,

principally refugees. They were afterwards joined by Col. Sheldon LightHorse & destroyed some stores at the Point after this they were encamped about Two Months at the White Plains where they were marched back within a short distance of Palmers Hill where they were employed in building fortifications and barracks. In the following month of February he received his discharge, And further says this affidavit that he was born in the State of Connecticut in the Town of Wallingford County of New Haven on the 12th of October 1764 & that his birth was recorded in the Office of the Town Clerk of the Town of Wallingford, in which he resided when he was called into the service, that he has since resided many years with a large family in the City of New Haven engaged largely & successfully in maritime commune -(disastrous reverses have now left him destitute, at an advanced age in the Banks of the Mississippi. - That he has resided about ten years in the Parish of East Baton-Rouge, & at present he resides in the City of New Orleans - That as before stated he entered the service first as a substitute subsequently as a volunteer - At this distant date his recollection of names is indistinct, but he thinks that Col. Shipman's Regt. in which he served formed part of a Brigade commanded by Genl. Washington - Adjutants Henry Bull & Henry Whiting were of the Regt, that he has no recollection [illegible] his discharge; if he received one it was at that time of little interest as the war was then drawing successfully to a close - That in the Parish of Baton-Rouge he is known to Capt Josiah Barker & Genl. Davenport & of this City to Dr. J. A. Kennicott & J.H. Kennicott Esquire of whom no doubt would do him the Justice to believe what he should, says & further says this affiant that the annexed affidavit contains all of the evidence he has been able to produce. - [Illegible word] the said Gad Peck hereby relinquishes any claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present & declares that his name is not in the pension roll of any State. [Signed] Gad Peck Sworn to Subscribed the day and year aforesaid [Signed J Bermudez Clerk

That her husband's health and constitution was very much broken down, and he lingered for many years before his death "from exposure and hardships" under disease, and finally died from the effects of same. That she will be enabled to make clear by the fact of the service of her husband which she hopes to produce. That she believes there was due to her husband a large amount for his services which was yet never paid or received. But which is still due. She further declares that she was married to the said James Patterson on the twentieth day of January in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and eighty six and that the said James Patterson her husband died on the twenty seventh day of December, one thousand eight hundred and four at Maghurd aforesaid of Fever [illegible] brought on by fatigue and cold in the America War. And that

Saratoga County ss I Abraham Moe, one of the judges of the Court of Common pleas of the County of Saratoga Do hereby certify that from the character of the applicant Benjamin Palmerton, as to truth and Veracity I am fully satisfied that Benjamin Palmerton, did actually perform the service as stated in his declaration. And I further certify that from the affidavit of the said Benjamin and his brother John I am fully convinced that he is under as Poor Indigent Circumstances as set forth in the said affidavit. I believe to be very poor and in an actual suffering situation, and he is generally called an honist man, and is an Object of charity, and actually stands in real need of assistance from his country for support Given Under my hand at the Town of Grange this 7th day of July in the year of our Lord 1819 [signed] Abraham Moe
