He was, when sufficiently recovered discharged from service but has lost his papers and has had the misfortune to survive all these persons who if now alive could testify to the truth of this statement and that he faithfully served his Country in the Revolutionary War as a soldier in the Maryland line during the whole war except in those intervals mentioned. He states further that he know the late General Smallwood, that Williams, Henry Lee, [illegible] Rawlings Stone and was present when the late Col. Forest had his leg and thigh cut off in consequence of a wound received in an engagement with the enemy by the Southern Army: his memory now fails him as to date & places and can now only detail detached facts he had heard of the name of the late Col Howard of the Maryland line, but does not recollect whether he ever saw him. He further States that from his age and extreme poverty and ^[illegible]^ County [illegible] he was not apprised till lately that such provision was made for old Revolutionary Soldiers by Congress as he now learns, has been. He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to any

Saratoga County ss } We Abijah Peck a Baptist Clergyman residing in the town of Clifton Park in the County of Saratoga aforesaid and Zebulon Mott -- of the same place hereby certify that we are well acquainted with Joseph Lamb who has subscribed and sworn to the above declaration - that we believe him to be seventy eight years old - that he is reputed in the neighbourhood where he resides to have been a soldier in the Revolution and that we concur in that opinion and we further certify that the said Joseph Lamb's character for truth & veracity is good – [signed] Abijah Peck Zebulon Mott Sworn & subscribed this 27th day of August AD 1832 by Zebulon Mott, Before me [signed] William Fowler Justice &c Abijah Peck appeared in open Court on the 4 September 1832 & was duly sworn to the truth of the above affidavit by him subscribed [signed] Thomas Palmer Clerk And the said Court do hereby declare their opinion after the investigation of the matter and after putting the interrogatories prescribed by the war Department that the above named applicant was a Revolutionary soldier and served as he states - and the court further certifies that it appears to them that Abijah Peck who has signed the preceding certificate is a clergyman resident in the Town of Clifton Park in the County of Saratoga and that Zebulon Mott who has also signed the same is a resident of the same place and is a credible person and that their statement is entitled to credit - and further that in their opinion the above named applicant cannot without too much expence and inconvenience to him produce the said Zebulon Mott in open Court upon his said application now made – I, Thomas Palmer Clerk of the Court of Common Pleas of the County of Saratoga, do hereby certify that the foregoing contains the original proceedings of the said Court

State of New York County of Rensselear } ss on this 20th day of September in the Eighteen hundred and Thirty Eight personally appeared before the Justices Court of the City of Troy Martha Lamb a resident of the town of Half Moon County of Saratoga in said State who being duly sworn according to Law doth on her oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benifit of the provisions made by the act of Congress passed July 7th 1838. Entitled an act granting half pay and Pensions to certain widows. That in the year Seventeen hundred and Ninety Two she was married to Joseph Lamb in the Town of Poulding [Pawling] in the County of Duchess in the State of New York by William Pearce a Justice of the Peace, who has been dead twenty years, and that there is no record of his marriages that her husband the said Joseph was a Pensioner untill the time of his death for his services in the New York Militia, and drew a Pension of Twenty dollars a year from the 4th day of March 1831. That the said Joseph was placed on the Pension Roll 11th April 1834 That she is the identical widow of the said Joseph. And the anexed leaf of my Bible is a true Record made by the said Joseph of our marriage, and that I am now in my Sixty seventh year of age. That the said Joseph my Husband died in the town of Half Moon on the 9th day of October in the year Eighteen hundred and Thirty seven, and that the reason of my making application for my Pension in the County of Rensselaer is that I am on a list [?] to my sons John Lamb, and for his assistance in obtaining my Pension and that she was married to the said Joseph Lamb after his leaving the service but the marriage took place previous to the first day of January Seventeen hundred and ninety four Viz at the time above stated. [signed] Martha Lamb + her mark Sworn in open Court this 20th day of September 1838. Signed] Geo. Wheeler Clerk And certify that the said Martha Lamb is a person of truth & veracity.

& the army continuing its retreat, hard pressed by the numerous enemy, by turns, passed through New-Jersey, & crossed the Delaware - a considerable detachment of it, to which the declarant belonged, under the command of - (He cannot remember the name) crossing that river at a place called the "Forks of Delaware." Here, on the Pennsylvania side of the Delaware, after much suffering from the cold, & by reason of many privations, the Regiment to which he belonged, or a part of it, was directed to march down the river, along with Pennsylvania militia under Gen. Irvine, for the purpose of crossing over into Jersey, about the 25th of December, in the night, for the purpose of co-operating with the main army under Gen. Washington, in an attack upon the Hessian Cantonment at Trenton, But the ice made in the river, & the severe inclemency of the weather, prevented this division of Gen. Irvine, from crossing the Delaware at that time. Gen. Washington, nevertheless, captured about a thousand of the Hessians. He was afterwards (but cannot name the precise time) with the army under Gen. Washington, at Trenton, when Lord Cornwallis, arriving about sunset on the opposite side of the creek, the small American force was in great danger. But the army, having raised a line of fires, to deceive the enemy, Gen. Washington marched them off, over the frozen ground, many of us barefooted; & next morning we met, fought & captured some hundreds of British troops near Princeton. At the expiration of this term of service, in February, he with others, who did not, again inlist, was discharged - but without writing. [margin note: 3 mo.] 2. In the summer of 1777. he says, as near as he can remember (being, thro' age, forgetful of dates) he inlisted on board the Continental Sloop, Providence, of 12 guns, Capt. John Rathbone Commander, at Bedford, Massachusetts. The crew consisted of sixty-three men; on board of which, he served three months, & was discharged, without writing, at Bedford, when he inlisted. Cruised of the banks of Newfoundland, & Newyork, Off Sandy Hook, the Providence fell in with a Ship, a Brig, a Schooner & a Sloop - three of them armed; - attached them & captured the Schooner, the rest escaping - lost only one man - the sailing-master. His pay & prise money amounted

substitute for any other. He has stated the names of the officers in the army & navy, with whom he served, & was acquainted, as far as he can recollect them; & also the several corps; but, on account of his great age his memory of these things is very imperfect. That he never had a written discharge, from either term of service, but on one occasion, as he has, already, stated, he had a Passport, which has long been lost or destroyed. Among the respectable gentlemen, in the vicinity, to whom he is known, & who can testify as to his character for veracity & to their belief of his services as a soldier of the revolution. - he names Grove Moore Esq & Dr. John Sargent of Rupert in Bennington County, & Nathaniel Harman Esq. & Phinehas Strong of Pawlet. - but as he lives in a remote corner of the town, & in a very sequestered place, he does not think there is any clergyman who can attest these particulars concerning him. And also, having, for more than thirty years, been absent from the place of his engagements in the service of his county, he does not know that there is any person who can testify to his knowledge of such his services, or any of them. If there are any such, he knows not where they are to be found, & his poverty does not admits of his travelling to distant places in search of them. He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever, to a pension or annuity, except the present, & declares that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any State. Sworn to & subscribed the day & year aforesaid -} /s/Isaac Read. We Nathaniel Harman & Phinehas Strong residing in the town of Pawlet, in the County of Rutland, hereby certify, that we are well acquainted with Isaac Reed (Read), who has subscribed & sworn to the above declaration. - that we believe him to be seventy seven years of age; that he is respected & believed, in the neighborhood where he resides, to have been a soldier of the revolution, & that we concur in that opinion. Sworn & subscribed the day & year aforesaid} /s/N. Harman /s/P. Strong

Stonington October 8 AD 1787 [illegible] seems to be tedious to me for there then looking at it for this six months. Nay I could not help looking [illegible] for to me as son as you can [illegible] one another & converse with and thereby enter but I alone & wheather we shall does see each other again god only knows and if so never see each again in this world I hope we shall meet in heaven where the wicked can from troubling us where the very heart Betts= but if I knew the prefered state of your heart I could better tell what to write however I shall set down some things for your comfort [illegible] say that you are left if god & there is no hope for you I tell you there were enough in god marils enough in hrift power enough in the spirit looms enough in heaven and scope enough in the prounites for you [illegible] the for with him to be final. Call upon him while he is near remember to keep Holy the sabbath fear god and keep his commandments and nigh to go on an he will know maybe more & have you or your letter you sent to me and am glad to hear of you letter as the providence of he first [illegible] to everything but there is a special nonsense over the children of you. Therefore let us live nicely by godI in a preparation for death for we now not how soon it may come [illegible] is all most all the point of Death by headon of his infirmity and is what he shall never see you again here aunt. Nites sits up is never as common but is is helpless as a [illegible] the sell of one our friends and relations as well at Treant & I am as well as is common for me so I profess my love & all the ret to you and the family of yours I remain your true affectionate mamma Mary Wheeler if you do not get out immediately to come over here [illegible] wife the [illegible] you have.

Stonington October the5 1789, the 5th1789 Dear Prudence I long to see you the most of any body in the world but I am so poor of a State of health with other difficulties, I cannot go to see you I have had two severe fits of sickness since last January so poor that I did not get live over them and and now attended with many weaknesses I have a bad cof [cough] which attends me & am troubled with the disorder whereof in the summer before my youngest Child was born but I am thankful that I am yet sound & have one more opportunity of writing to you I hope these lines will find you well and in good health for it is a great blessing I beg of you not to work to hard I am very sorry to hear of your working to hard you have but one life here to live. I would have you make yourself as happy as you can you must have your work done & for self all you can you must take my advice for it was hard work which brought my sickness on me. I have not been able to do any hard work since last January. Due write to me every opportunity you have for it is the satisfaction I can have from you is to hear from you and may the Lord enable each other of us to be a laying up treasures in heaven where nither [neither] [most?] [mornfl [mournful?] corrupt nor thieves broke through and steal my Dear child I wish you all blessings here both Spiritual and temporal & as you have no children. I hope you will come and see me as soon as you can. how rejoiced I should be to have you [illegible] me again miss Denison is married and is moved away & Thankful is a going to be married and of want your company much. Your uncle Thomas is married again my family are all well at present no more at present I remain your affectionate Mother Mary Wheeler I am very sorry to hear such news from [Poor?] [mr bates?] & the rest of your acquaintance which you mentioned in your letter I send you some ginger and some allspice & a pinch of snuf & you was [?] I want to send you some greater presants I want send you half of a rost [roast] pig and some good apples & peaches and many other good things of taste It has been a plentiful year for provisions here and I have grate deal of yarn spun but I have not got it in to cloth yet by Reason of sickness only three pieces of lining and too new bedticks and I have three hundred seams of lining yarn now in the house to weave & one coverlet & Not a thread of any wool spun this year help is very scarce but I hope to get along some how or other but I cant spare one day to go abroad you must excuse my poor writing for it is so long since I wrote any I have almost forget how and my eye sight fails me with all - we have improved the whole of aunt Niles is Land with the rest this year which has made the work more then we yous [used] to have. your Daddy joins with me in love to and all the rest of the family I would help you more if I could but you [words cut off in paper fold] and my reach I cant reach to you as I wasnt

State of Vermont I Shubael Simons of Williamstown in Washington the County of Orange & State aforesaid being duly sworn, depose & say that personally acquainted with James Kilborn of said Williamstown who has applied for a pension in the law of 1818 & May 1820, and will know the he has very little property, & that he has not been able to labor for a number of years part of that his wife is also wholly unable to be support herself. He has no other family. is now mentioned in his church in the department of War, die of disease since them him of his declaration & chide, & he is now entirely destitute The said Kilborn now very my circumstance Shubel Simon Simon Conner of Williamstown adores of lawful lity & that I am acquainted with the said James Kilborn & his wife will be that they are unable to labor & have been so for several part & that this applicant is in very low unto Gideon Corner Sworn to & subscribed before me this 23 day of September A.D. 1822. Declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the act of congress of the 7th of June 1832. State of Ohio Ross County On this 13th day of June 1833 personally appeared before the Judges of the Court of Common Pleas now sitting, John Crouse a resident of Green Township in the county of Ross and State of Ohio, aged seventy-three years who being first duly sworn according to law doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the provision made by the act of congress passed June 7th 1832. That from information derived from the records in his father's family bible, of the several ages of his family, this deponent from the best of his recollection was born on the 13th day of January 1760 - that he enlisted in the army of the United states in the Revolutionary war as a private soldier from Frederick Town in the state of Maryland, under Captain Jacob Good for the term of six months in what was called the flying camp, from the state of Maryland about the month of June 1776 and was attached to a regiment the name of the Col he cannot now recollect but the name of the general was Bell from which place he was marched by the way of Annapolis to the head of Elk to Christen Bridges, thence by water to Philadelphia where he was stationed two weeks, from thence he was marched to New York and stationed on York Island near Fort Washington for a considerable time, in the discharge of the several duties of a soldier with the army at that time under the immediate command of Genl. Washington and was there during the battle at that place but being placed on one of the guard of the baggage was not in the battle from thence this army was marched to White Plains and through several other places but his company having served out their full term returned to Philadelphia where he and the company to which he belonged received their discharge, and being destitute of suitable clothing for the reason returning home not having been in any battle he has no documentary evidence of any of his services and knows of no person whose testimony he can procure who can certify to any of his service - since the case of

New York and stationed on York Island near Fort Washington for a considerable time, in the discharge of the several duties of a soldier with the army at that time under the immediate command of Genl. Washington and was there during the battle at that place but being placed on one of the guard of the baggage was not in the battle from thence this army was marched to White Plains and through several other places but his company having served out their full term returned to Philadelphia where he and the company to which he belonged received their discharge, and being destitute of suitable clothing for the reason returning home not having been in any battle he has no documentary evidence of any of his services and knows of no person whose testimony he can procure who can certify to any of his service - since the war of the Revolution he has resided part of the time in Orange Co North Carolina and part in Huntington Co Pennsylvania and for the last thirty three years in Ross County Ohio - e claims a pension for the six months service above stated, under the act aforesaid, and hereby relinquishes any claim to a pension or annuity except the present and declares that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any state. John Crouse Sworn to & subscribed in open court June 13th 1833 Humphrey Fullerton - Clerk We John Emmett a clergyman residing in the county of Ross and state of Ohio and William Justice residing in the same county do hereby certify that we are well acquainted with John Crouse who has subscribed and sworn to the above declaration; that we believe him to be seventy-three years of age or thereabout; that he is reputed and believed in the neighborhood where he resides to have been a soldier of the Revolution and that we concur in that opinion and believe him to be a man of the strictest truth. John Emmitt William Justice Sworn to and subscribed in open court June 13th 1833. Humphrey Fullerton - Clerk To the matter of John Crouse for a pension the court do hereby declare their opinion after the investigation of the matter and after putting the interrogatories prescribed by the War Department that the above named applicant was a revolutionary soldier and served as he states and the court further certifies that it appears to them that John Emmitt who has signed the proceeding certificate is a clergyman residing in Ross County and that William Justice who has also signed the same is a resident in same county and is a credible person and that their statements are entitled to credit.

Duty to the end of the months I was dismissed. In Apri day of the month not recollected was ? to served a month Tour of duty entered the service under Cap John Ogden marched to Newark joined 11 Col. Phil Van Courtland Reg Sam Hays Maj kept guard at Camp dock Old Ferry neck gate billited at David Grances with TImothy Gould Sergant was on a Scout in the Sold Meadows at a creek called at Jasper Creek found canoe loaded with Salt & other articles brought to Newak & maded prose of it served out the month & was dismissed. In June great distress was warned by Lewis Baldwin Sergant to turn out on a month duty new that the British Army was coming from Philadelphia through 12 Jersey state entered the service made under Capt Amos Dodd marched to Newark joined Col Phil Van Courtland by Caleb Dodd Maj in about a week the Reg was order to march Monmouth provided in far as 5 mile run or ? order countermanded I was ordered to return to Newark that thhe enemy was coming into Newark from New York served his month tour I was dismissed In Setpember was warned by Timothy Gould Seg to perform a month Long 13 duty entered the service under Henry Jarolamon & marched to Belvill joined Col Phil Van Courtland Reg kept quard at the River & Scouted during the month with TImothy Gould billeted gogether of Old Garland at the expiration of the month was dismissed In November does not recollect the day warned by Col Garnder to perform 14 a months Tour of Duty entered the Sevrvice under Cap Abraham Speer John Crane Lieut marched to Newark joined Col Phil Van Courtland Regt Sam Hayes Major recollects it was the time that the Refugees came over from Bergens took Saml Williams prisoner when on centry at Neck gate and one Bruin cows & hogg took away billited with Moses Dodd al David Cranes served outn three onths duty together was dismissed 1779 In January 3rd recollect was warned in time of Holly day by Saml Williams Serg on a month duty entered the service under Capt Henry Jarolomon John Crane Liu marched to Belville joined Col Phil Can Courtland Reg does not recollect the Major 15 kept guard & scouted during the month very cold suffered much that month from cold billeted in and old stone house with Cornelius ? was with him on a scouting party to Seacanius had a skirmish with the Refugees took from them cows belonging to one Doremus Cornelius ? was wounded in his right leg from which wound 24 or 25 years aog it taken off served out the month duty were dismissed

Sworn and Subscribed the day & year aforesaid Simeon William Eliphalet Hall Rufus Harrison Court of Record William Gould State of New Jersy Essex County SS On the Second day of December in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred thirty four personally appeared in Open Court beforethe Judge of the Court of Quarter Session now sitting being a Court of Record Abijah Dodd of the Township of Bloomfield COunty of Essex aged Seventy years who being first sworn according to law on his oath saith that in October 1777 Aaron Crane of Bloomfield County of Essex was with deponent on a months tour of duty at Elish Town under Capt Elijah Squire John Crane Lieu worked together at fortification on guard lay in tents in the same mess and further saith not Abijah Dodd Sworn and subscribed the day & year aforesaid Eliphalet Hall Rufus Harrison Court Record William Gould State of New Jersey Essex County SS On the Second day of December in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred thirty four personally appeared in Open Court before the Judge of the Court of Quarter Session now setting being a Court of Record. Moses Dodd of the Township of Bloomfield County of Essex aged seventy nine years who bein first sworn according to law on his oath saith that Aaron Crane was with deponent on a months tour of duty at Belville County of Essex in December 1777 was together at Seacancus on a Scout took a drave of Fat Cattle & Lond trader billited together at old Garlands In November 1778 Aaron Carne was with deponent on a month tour of duty at Newark under Capt Abraham Speer at the tiem Samuel William was taken prisoner when on centery by a part of Refugees further south not Sworn subscirbed at the day & year aforesaid. Eliphalet Hall Moses Dodd Rufus Harrison Court of Record William Gould

State of Virginia Washington County On this 19th day of November 1832 personally appeared before me Abram Nordyke a Justice of the Peace in and for the county aforesaid duly authorized to administer oaths, Christian Gobble an old and infirm revolutionary soldier, who is unable to travel to the Courthouse, and being first duly sworn according to law doth upon his oath, make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the act of congress passed June 7, 1832. The said Christian Gobble stated his case as follows: I am now about seventy-seven years of age, but have no written account of my birth. I was born in Pennsylvania; when I was very young my father removed to Baltimore County Maryland. These facts I do not remember but have been told them by my parents. From this latter place my father removed to Frederick County in the same state where he died. At this time, I was an apprentice to a saddler. The year New York was taken and about the 1st of June I enlisted for six months at Tawney town under Captain Jacob Goode in the Regiment commanded by Col. Griffin of the Maryland troops called the "flying camp". We marched to New York and arrived there before it was taken. From New York we marched to Fort Washington then commanded by Col. Bull. From this fort the detachment to which I belonged marched to reinforce Gen. Wayne and we were in the battle of the White Plains. After this battle we marched under Capt. Hartman of the Maryland Troops to Fort Lee; then crossed to Fort Washington which was then attacked by the enemy and taken and I with others made prisoners. I was taken to New York by the enemy and confined in what was called the Sugar house between two and three months and suffered greatly. I was then liberated form close confinement on parole

Levi Mundy, for increase, {Act 7 June 1832.} Pensioner declares he entered as a vol(unteer) in company commanded by Capt. Robt Ross in reg(iment) of Militia commanded by Col. Moses Jaques on or about 1 April 1780 & so continued until 1 Sep., 5 mos. in fall of 1780 & winter of 1780 & 81. Capt. Ross' company was frequently called out for the purpose of protecting the residents on the (Staten Island) Sound & Raritan (River) & in this service was engaged 3 mos. On 1st March 1781 again cont(inued) the service under Capt. Ross & so continued until Nov. 8, 9 mos. That during the winter of 1781 & 2 served as a Minuteman, again entered under Capt. Ross 1 April 1782 & so continued until 1 Dec. following, 8 mos. during which he was present with a party of men of Capt. Ross' co. near Crows Mills, on the Raritan (River), where a British foraging party attempted to drive away Maj. Potter's Milch Cows [i.e. Dairy Cows] & assisted to retake them. Again ent(ered) under Capt. Ross on 1st March 1783 & continued until 1 May following, 2 mos. = 26 mos. exclusive of service as Minuteman. Was in numerous skirmishes during s(aid) time with British foraging parties infesting the country bordering on Staten Island Sound & Raritan River. Now receives a pension from State of N. Jersey at the rate of $60.~ per annum, the highest rate allowed by that State to Privates of the Revo(lutionary War); On 12 Feb. last by Special Act of Legislature & certified copy of which is on file in Pension Office. Jos. Sofield (a Pensioner) knew Levi Mundy & entered the service with Mundy at the time named in his declaration & served as Minuteman & vol(unteer) in Capt. Ross' company. That he & Mundy performed the same tours of service as claimed by Munday in his declaration and testifies to Munday's good character on 18 April 1851. Mulford Wilson of Piscataway Township, Middlesex Co., aged Sixty six years, swears to the good character of L. Mundy & to his reputation as a Rev(olutionary) Soldier in the neighborhoods & has himself known him as such from his (Wilson's) childhood. Isaac Stelle of same township & Co., 61 yrs. of age, corroborates [crossed out: Sofield's] Wilson's statement. Hon. Jas. Parker, ex-mem(ber of) Con(gress), certifies to Munday's good character & destitute circumstances.

swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th of March 1818, and that I have not since that time by gift, sale or in any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War", passed on the 18th day of March 1818. And that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts, or debts due to me, nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. 9 old chairs $3. 1 pot & kettle..1. 2 old chest 1.50 = 5.50 2 old spinning wheels 1. 1 old steel .25 = 1.25 6 iron spoons .30 6 knives & forks .25 4 earthen bords .34 = .89 9 earthen plates .75 4 earthen milk [illegible] & 2 platters .75 = $1.50 1 iron crane & 2 hooks 1. 1 tea pot & 6 cups & saucers .50 = 1.50 1 tea kettle .83 fire shovel & tongs 1. = 1.83 1 table .75 2 old candlesticks .10 = .85 ________ $13.32 John Gould That since the 18th March 1818, the following changes have been made in my property viz, on the 18th of March 1818, I owned two cows, one horse & two calves; I sold said cows & horse one year ago this spring, to Patience Gould, for the sum of sixty six dollars, in part payment of a debt of one hundred & thirty dollars, which I owed her for her services in taking care of myself & wife for thirteen years last past. The two calves were sold also to the said Patience Gould for six dollars on the debt I owed her as before stated. This declarants occupation has been a farmer, but has been for a number of years in very poor health. My wife is seventy years of age, and for three years past has been helpless on account of rheumatism and is in a poor state of health. I have one daughter living with me aged 34 years, and has no means to support herself but by her own labor. John Gould Sworn to and declared on the eleventh day of March 1828 in open court. Attest Benj. Swan Clerk

I went on board the said vessel (said vessel was a public vessel & belonged the United States) at New London Conn and sailed in company with an armed vessel but I don't recollect the name of the vessel we soon parted with her, and then we captured a small at of Long Island and sent her into port. We then continued our cruise until we fell in with the British frigate (I think she was called Ship Watt) & after an engagement she came under one Stern & succeeded in getting away the action continued two hours and a half & next morning one main and misen must and rigging went overboard & was lost & we put into Boston Harbor for repairs. Then we sailed in company with the Dean Frigate and put into Delaware Bay & then put out to sea & cruised along the Southern coast of the United States with a view of Capturing some of Lord Cornwallis vessels & on the said court we captured a British Sloop and a British Brig, we came in sight of two British frigates not long afterwards but came to engagement. We then pursued after another vessel & then returned with a vessel to Philadelphia where we were discharged. I was very sick with a fever at the time one ship arrived at Philadelphia + was taken to the Hospital at that place (Continental Barracks, and remained there till the 20th December 1780 when I was dismissed from the Hospital. I do not recollect whether we received written discharges or not & If we did mine is lost.-- After my time was out & my discharge from the hospital I returned to Fairfield Conn and resided there till 1781. When the British came and stripped me of all my cattle and a sailboat and other property of the value of five hundred dollars, I then moved to Fredrickson N.Y. and I remained there till 1785 when I moved to Granville N.Y. & lived there till 1797 when I moved to

The declaration of Peter Fry who served upon the continental establishment in the war of the revolution. State of Pennsylvania County of Chester On this twenty-first day of August in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and thirty-two personally appeared before the court of common pleas of the county of Chester, Peter Fry, a resident of Lower Oxford in the county of Chester and state of Pennsylvania, aged seventy-four years and three months, who being duly sworn according to law doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the provisions made by the act of Congress passed June 7th 1832; that he enlisted in the army of the United States in the year one thousand seven hundred and seventy-five or seventy-six with Captain William Wheatman (or Whitman) and served in the Pennsylvania line and in the fifth regiment thereof, as he recollects; and under the following named officers to wit: Colonel Noggle; the Major's name according to the best of his recollection was Heister; his captain was Mr. Wheatman, his lieutenant Stroud; that he left the service at the end of the War and was then honorably and entirely discharged; that he the said deponent enlisted at Reading in the state of Pennsylvania at which place he then resided; that he accompanied the army into Jersey and was engaged in the battle of Princeton and Trenton; that he was afterward engaged at the battles of Brandywine, Paoli and Germantown; suffered with the rest of the army the hardships and (illegible) which they were subjected at Valley Forge encampment in the winter of 1777-8; that he was afterwards engaged at the battle of Monmouth

STATE OF VERMONT. COUNTY OF WINDHAM - SS. At the County Court, begun and held at New-Fane, within and for the County of Windham, on the second Monday of June, in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and twenty..... PRESENT - Hon. [Honorable] PHINEHAS WHITE, Esq. [Esquire] Chief Judge. Hon. [Honorable] JOHN ROBERTS, Hon. [Honorable] GILBERT DENISON, Esqrs. [Esquires] } Assistant Judges. On this Twentieth day of June, A. D. 1820, personally appeared in open court, being a court of record for the said county, proceeding according to the course of the common law, with a civil jurisdiction unlimited in point of amount, keeping a record of their proceedings, and having, in certain cases, the power of fine and imprisonment, Prince Freeman aged sixty two years, resident in Grafton in said county, who, being first duly sworn according to law, doth, on his oath, declare that he served in the Revolutionary War as fol-lows [follows] - To wit - in Capt. [Captain] Ellis Company in Col. [Colonel] Sherburn's Regiment of the Connecticut Line three years - and that he was then transferred to Capt. [Captain] Buckley's Company in Col. [Colonel] Webb's Regiment of the Connecticut Line where he served about three years - and that he enlisted an served during the War upon the Continental Establishment - That he has received a pension under the act of the Congress of the United States of the 18th March, 1818, that the number of his pension certificate is 2807, and the date of his original declaration is the 10th day of April A.D. 1818. AND I DO SOLEMNLY SWEAR, That I was a resident citizen of the United States on the eighteenth day of March, one thousand eight hundred and eighteen: and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner whatever, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled, "An act to provide for certain persons enga-ged [engaged] in the Land and Naval Service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War," passed on the eighteenth day of March, one thousand eight hundred and eighteen: And that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts, or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the Schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. SCHEDULE of real and personal estate, necessary clothing and bedding excepted. hi Prince x Freeman mark. One Cow - One Hos - Six Chairs - One Chest - and two tables - his Prince x Freeman. mark. AND I do also swear that my occupation is that of a Farmer - that I have a wife and two children. One of them fourteen years old, and the other twelve years old, and that they are all dependent upon me for support. And that I am a crip-ple [cripple] and unable to Labour much. My children's names are Avis Freeman and Prince Freeman. Avis Freeman is unable to labour. I am owing $70 - SWORN to and DECLARED in open court on the Twentieth day of June, A. D. 1820, BEFORE John Roberts, JUDGE. James Elliot Clerk of the County Court for the County of Windham, in the State of Vermont, do hereby certify, that the foregoing oath, and the Schedule thereto annexed, are truly copied from the files and records of the said Court: And I do further certify, that it is the opinion of the said Court, that they total amount in value of the property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule is Twenty Five dollars [marked out] and [marked out] cents IN testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand, and affixed the seal of the said Court, [marked out] in open Court, on this sixth day of July 1820. James Elliot, CLERK OF THE COURT FOR THE COUNTY OF WINDHAM.

To Phinehas White Esq. [Esquire] Chief Judge of the county Court within and for the County of Windham and State of Vermont - I Prince Freeman of Grafton in the County of Windham and State aforesaid, claiming the benefit of an act of Congress passed on the 18th day of March in the present year of our Lord 1818. Entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the Land and Naval Service of the United States in the Revolutionary War." - Do in pursuance of the provisions of the said Act, have, upon Oath make the following Declaration, to wit, - That I the said P. Freeman - served as a private soldier in the War of the Revolution on the Continental Establishment in the following manner - I first in-listed [enlisted] and entered the service in May 1777 for and during the War in the Company commanded by Capt. [Captain] Buckley in the 3d [Third] Regiment of the Connecticut Line commanded by Col. [Colonel] Samuel B. Webb - served till the close of the War and was honorably discharged on the 8th day of June 1783, and here provided my original discharge - - - And I further [illegible] declare that I am destitute of property - advanced in years and by reason of my reduced circumstances in life I am in need of the assistance of my Country for support - - - In witness thereof I hereunto set my hand this 10th day of April Anno Domini 1818 his Prince X Freeman mark. P.S. [Post Script] Information of the service of the applicant is set [illegible] to be given to P White - [illegible] Vt [Vermont]

State of Pennsylvania Lancaster County, SS. On this 11th day of December AD 1843, personally appeared before Michael Carpenter, Alderman in and for the City of Lancaster, Jacob Garber, a resident of the City of Lancaster, aged seventy-three years, who being first duly sworn according to law, says: That he was intimately acquainted with James McEwen, a Drum Major of the Revolutionary War, and the War of 1795. I was quite a young man when I first became acquainted with him. I saw him leave Lancaster and join the Army as a drum Major in 1778. The first battle he was engaged in was at Monmouth in New Jersey. He had been at Valley forge under Washington shortly before. In 1780, he was marched under Gates to Clermont in the South They were attacked by the British under Lord Cornwallis, and were defeated on the road to Camden. Gen. Green afterwards took command of the Army. He was with Green during 1781 and 1782 and was discharged early in 1783. The old man in his lifetime, and other soldiers who were with him in the Revolution, told me of their services as above stated. McEwen mentioned many circumstances that occurred during the war. The hardships he endured and the long fatiguing marches. He was always considered by the people of Lancaster as a Revolutionary Drummer, and was a man of high respectability. In 1775, he went as a Drum Major in Gen. Haynes' army under Capt. [illegible]. I also went out in the same Regiment in this campaign. He told me many of his exploits during the war - how he escaped from the British, etc. - which he had told me shortly after his return from the Revolutionary War, many years before.

Lancaster April 26th 1844 Dear Sir, I received your letter of the 19th instant, and think I have satisfactory complied with your instructions. Although I sent you Mary Stiff's declaration at first, yet I thought I might as well have it taken in part over again, as she made a mistake in the former one in regard to the death of her Father. This declaration, and that of her sister, who at the only daughters and heirs now living, state the exact time of the death of both their parents, as taken from the bible in the possession of Mrs. Sarah Stauffer. As much as I regret that there is no witness now living, who went out in the war, and endured the trials and hardships of a long campaign with James McEwen - yet I know the Department will find pleasure in seeing that the Witnesses testify, beyond all doubt, that he deserted from the British ranks and joined the American forces, immediately married an American lady ([illegible], Mary Stiff's) and served until the conclusion of the War. Jacob Gerber, a former Witness, testifies that he knew him well, and often heard him relate his revolutionary marches to him, while they were out on duty in the War of 1796, and then old Mr. Gonter, who is still in the enjoyment of all his faculties, and whose private character is above all reproach, testifies to his being out and in service in the Pennsylvania Line, and that he was received as a Revolutionary Soldier in his lifetime. And then the Hon. Emanuel Schaeffer, Judge of the Court, who knew old Mr. McEwen well, certifies that he was reputed to be a soldier of the Revolutionary War. And Captain G. Musser, who is an Alderman of the City, certifies as to the common impression among the people as to the reputation of McEwen's Revolutionary claims. The reason why he was spoken so much of as being a revolutionary Soldier was on account of his having deserted the British so soon as he had an opportunity after he had landed in America. In your letter you requested me to have the Court to certify as to the death of James McEwen and his widow, also to the name of her administrator. This the court said it could not do, as the records did not show it, and the only exact knowledge was from the Declaration of Mrs. Stiff and Mrs. Stauffer, which I am sure will satisfy the Department. Neither could his honor certify who was her administrator because there never was any appointed. But when the Department grants the claim, I will have Mrs. Stiff or Mrs. Stauffer or both of them (if necessary) to take out Letters of Administration, so as to be able to draw the claim, as in your letter you say it payable to her administrators as assets. Under the Regulations you sent me, I see that when the declarant swears that there is no witness living, a reputation of being a Revolutionary soldier will be great weight, and I am happy that the present papers contain strong and conclusive traditionary testimony. Please see the former papers I forwarded you for particulars. Pardon me for troubling you with so long a letter, for I thought it proper to explain the case to you so as to facilitate you in a speedy examination. With much respect, I am yours truly J B Kaufman Hon J L Edwards Commissioner of Pensions Washington City

David Lamb was allowed pension on his application executed November 26, 1832, at which time he resided in Walker Township, Centre County, Pennsylvania; he had resided in that vicinity for forty years. The soldier died February 12, 1837; he was survived by a widow, whose name was not given, who died March 7, 1845. There were no surviving children. In 1851, in the Orphans Court of Centre County, Pennsylvania, William Smythe, Junior, and Henry F. W. Schultze were certified to be the Executors of the estate of David Lamb, the deceased soldier of the Revolutionary War. In 1833, Henry Petrikin of Bellefonte, Centre County, Pennsylvania, and his brother, James M. Petrikin, also of Centre County, stated that their father and David Lamb, the soldier, married sisters, but they did not state the name of their own mother. It was shown also, that David Lamb, the soldier, had been an elder in the Presbyterian Church of Lick Run, in Centre County, Pennsylvania, as early as 1809. HENRY MCEWEN-W. 3275. Copied for A.N. F. Joff. 3275. [handwritten] Henry McEwen volunteered in July 1775, served as private in Captain William Hendrick's company, Colonel William Thompson's Pennsylania Rifle Regiment; he marched from Carlisle, Cumberland County, Pennsylvania and arrived in camp near Boston in August, in September 1775, he volunteered to go with his captain on Arnold's expedition to Quebec, and was at the storming of Quebec, where wounded in the head by a bayonet, was taken prisoner, December 31, 1775, was paroled, August 3, 1776 and exchanged in the fall of 1778. About two months of his imprisonment, he was "confined in Irons". He was allowed pension on his application executed April 28, 1818, at which time he was sixty-five years of age and living in Potter Township, Centre County, Pennsylvania. He was also pensioned by the State of Pennsylvania. 2.

Commonwealth of Pennsylvania Chester County, SS: On this first day of August in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and twenty personally appeared in open court of Common Pleas held at Westchester in and for the county of Chester in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania; being a court of record proceeding according to the course of the common law with a jurisdiction unlimited in point of amount and keeping a record of its proceedings Thomas McDowell aged sixty two years and upwards resident in the township of West Nottingham in the said county of Chester and Commonwealth of Pennsylvania who being first duly sword according to law doth make the following declaration in order to obtain the provision made by the acts of congress of the 18th of March, 1818 and the 1st of May, 1820 that he served in the Revolutionary war in the third company commanded by Captain Edward Spurrier in the thirst regiment commanded by Major Landsdale of the Maryland Line on the continental establishment and has obtained a pension under the act of the 18th of March 1818 his certificate being numbered 12741 And I the said Thomas McDowell do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the eighteenth day of March eighteen hundred and eighteen and that I have not since that time by gift, sale or in any manner whatever, disposed of my property, or any part thereof with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of congress entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War" passed on the eighteen day of March eighteen hundred and eighteen and that I have not nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities, contracts or debts due to me nor have I any income other than what is contained in the scheduled hereto annexed and by me subscribed. Thomas McDowell His X Mark Sworn to, declared, and subscribed on the first day of August 1820 in open court of Common pleas in and for the county of Chester in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania; the said court being a court of record by the laws of the said Commonwealth. State of Massachusetts I Abraham Perkins a Citizen of the United States now residing Norwich in the County of Essex in the State aforesaid do on oath testify and declare, that in the War of the Revolution in the month of April in the year of Our Lord One Thousand and seven hundred & seventy five. I entered and was engaged in the land service of the United States on the continental establishment and served accordingly from that time month of December in the year Seventeen hundred & seventy six in the Massachusetts line of the Army. as a Private against the common enemy, without any interruption or absence: that I belonged to Captain Dodge's Company and in Colonel Little's Regiment for eight months & to Captain Lunts Company for one year in the same Regiment having enlisted into said Company on the first day of January 1776 served there one full year following & on the Continental Establishment and that I left the service on the expiration of the term aforesaid being honorably discharged. and that by reason of my reduced circumstances in life and poverty, I stand in need assistance from my country for support, being now of the age of years__________ I have no other evidence in my power to offer than is written And I hereby relinquish all claims to every pension heretofore allowed me by the laws of the United States, if any may be or hath been so allowed John Smith is crossed out Abram Perkins (self written signature) BE IT REMEMBERED That on this seventh day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen. Pursuant to a law of the United States, entitled, "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the revolutionary war," made and passed on the 18th of March A.D. 1818 personally appeareth before me the subscriber One of the Associate Judges of the Circuit Court Common Pleas for the middle circuit with the State aforesaid specializing (?) the above named Abraham Perkins and after due examination and caution to testify and declare the whole truth , he maketh oath to the declaration aforesaid, and subscribes the same in my presence; and, on examination duly made by me the said Judge, it appeareth to my satisfaction that the said declaration is true. In testimony whereof I hereunto affix my name & the seal of the Court Wm. Wetmore June 15, 1818 I further certify that the

obtain the benefit of the act of Congress of June 7, 1832. Printed & Sold by Kemble & Hooper, & State-st. Troy, N. Y. State of New York,} County of Rensselaer ss} On this Fourth day of September 1832 personally appeared in open Court, before the Troy Mayors Court of the City of Troy aforesaid now sitting, Isaac Peck a resident of Sand Lake County of Rensselaer and State of New York, aged Seventy five years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth, on his oath, make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress passed June 7, 1832. That he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers, and served as herein stated... That in the year 1776, in the Spring, he enlisted as a fifer at Southington in the State of Connecticut in a company of Infantry, commanded by Asa Bay, George Smith for the term of Eighteen months in a Regiment commanded by Col John Chester, that immediately after his enlistment he was marched to New York. was at that place when the British took possession of the City of New York was derived to the Eastward, & was at or near Hurlgate, after his enlistment under Captain Bray he became Col. of the Regiment & a Captain Wadsworth took command of the Company - was at New York at the time aforesaid afterwards was marched to Peekskill, remained the interrogatories prescribed by the war Department, that the above named applicant Revolutionary Soldier, and served as he states. And the Court further certifies, that it appears to them that Calvin C. Williams who has signed the preceding certificate, is a Clergyman, resident in the Town of Sand Lake and that Gideon Butts & Marcus Peek who has also signed the same, is a resident in the Town of Sand Lake aforesaid and is a credible person, and that their statement is entitled to credit. I, Archibald Bull Clerk of the Court of Troy Mayor Court do hereby certify that the foregoing contains the original proceedings of the said Court in the matter of the application of Isaac Peek for a pension. The witnesses are personally known to Daniel Gardner Render of his & they are men of undoubted veracity. In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and seal of office, this Sixth day of September, 1837. Archibald Bull, Clerk

there until the term of his enlistment expired, and received a written discharge from Col. Bray, which has long since been lost on the first day of January 1778, he again at Southington under Captain Norten volunteered as a fifer for five months & was marched to Albany, remained at Albany until the cannon taken from Burgoyne were brought to Albany, then the Company took charge of the Cannon went with them to Hartford in Connecticut was there discharged after having served out the term of his enlistment by Captain Norton - on the 7th July 1778 was at Southington again wanted to go to New Haven, accordingly volume and under col Bray outing as Captain, went to New Haven, was in a skirmish at that place, with the British & drove them off was until discharged which he believes about six weeks - That he has no doumentary coldence of his services. Has no record of his age, that he recollects was born in 1757 at Southington aforesaid and there until 1795 then moved to said Lake where he has lived ever since - That reccollects no par ular officers in the revolution except those above named. That he is well known to Gideon Dutter, Stephen Gregory, Isaac B. Fox, William P. Averill, Caleb Finch & others of said Lake who will testify to his character for veracity and their belief of his services as a Soldier in the revolution. He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or an annuity, except the present, and he declares that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any State, [in the agency of the State of] Sworn to and subscribed, the day and year aforesaid. Isaac Peek Archibald Bull, Clerk Mr. Calvin C. Williams a clergyman residing in the town of Sand Lake, Isaac Peck residing in the town of Sand Lake and Gideon Butts, residing in Sand Lake hereby certify that we are acquainted with Isaac Peek who has subscribed and sworn to the above declaration; that we believe him to be seventy five years of age; that he is reputed and believed, in the neighborhood where he resides, to have been a soldier of the Revolution, and that we concur in that opinion. Sworn and subscribed the day and year aforesaid Archibald Bull Clerk Calvin C. William Gideon Butts Marcus Peck And the said Court do hereby declare their opinion, after the investigation of the matter, and after putting the interrogatories prescribed by the War Department, that the above named applicant was a Revolutionary Soldier, and served as he states. And the Court further certifies, that it appears to them that Calvin C. Williams who has signed the preceding certificate, is a Clergyman, resident in the Town of Sand Lake and that Gideon Butt & Marcus Peck who has also signed the same, is a resident in the Town of Sand Lake aforesaid and is a credible person, and that their statement is entitled to credit. I, Archibald Bull Clerk of the Court of Troy Mayor's Court do hereby certify that the foregoing contains the original proceedings of the said Court in the matter of the application of Isaac Peek for a pension. The witnesses are personally known to Daniel Gardner reside of Troy there are men of undoubted veracity- In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and seal of office, this sixth day of September 1837. Archibald Bull, Clerk

the said mortgage in the hands of said Fuller has been fully and justly paid off to the said Edward along as his necessaries required. And further this deponent says that the said Edward travels around the country considerable and that he must of necessity have spent some money, how much no one can know- and the said Deponent further says that the said Edward is in poor and needy circumstances that he has not had any proper for a long time except for a few old farming utensils whish are now gone. Ten sheep which were let out but he has now sold them for his present needy support and one old horse worth probably about forty dollars- which horse is now all the property he has except his necessary learing apparel and the deponent says the said Edward is very old and out of health and decrepit and is so lame as to be a great part of the time conferred to the house occasioned by a very bad fever done upon one of his legs and has been so unfortunate as to have two breached unusually bad which as age advanced increase and under them almost insufferable

I Lyman Andrews of Dudswell in the Province of Lower Canada aged fifty five years depose and say that I am a son of Moses Bishop (crossed out) Andrews late of of said Dudswell deceased that I have often heard my Father state his going to Quebec with Montgomery and being present at his defeat. I don't know how long he served at that time but I have often heard him sat that he joined the army previous to wheat harvest and lost all his wheat that year as he was in the army and depending on other persons to harvest his wheat (which they failed to do) he lost the whole of it--but by what he said they could not have entered Canada until late in the fall of the year as he said they were obliged as they made an attack upon St. Johns to wade through water back of the town where the ice was nearly strong enough to bare them which they had to brake as they marched and he was left sick at Quebec and supposed to have been dead by his companions--but he was so fortunate as get among the French who were friendly to him by which means he evaded the British and worked his way home but what time he got home I do not recollect to have heard him say. (But I have [illegible] heard him say that it was in May when he left Quebec he says he left Quebec on) (what is enclosed in the parenthesis he says is not as he understand but should be as follows). After having had the small pox he learned that the British were about to take possession he left the hospital on the 5th of May and found means to cross the river above Quebec where he found French people that were friendly to him who did assist him in his distress and although he could not travel over two miles a day at first yet he found his way home after being absent eleven months. His companions who reached home before him supposed him to have been dead--I further say that I have heard my Father state his being in several other skirmishes at Hubbervstown at Crownpoint at Rutland Picket one summer and at other

Montpelier, Jan. 18, 1839 Hon. John Kimball. Dear Sir: I send you, annexed, the result of my examination of the Revolutionary Pay Rolls, in compliance with your request of the 16th. If the names of Bishop, Ide or Baxter are on any of the rolls, they have escaped a careful search. There is some four or five papers of persons imprisoned, in the form of memorials to the Legislature for remuneration for loss of time, endurance of hardship etc. etc. but I believe neither of the names you mention are to be found on papers of this character, where remuneration was granted (last four words underlined); but it is not unlikely that petitions or memorials of this kind may be among the files of the Legislature of 1779, '80, etc. which I have not time to examine in season for this letter. Very respectfully Your ob. serv't C.L. Knapp July 1839 paid to C.L. Knapp $2.00 paid postage on letter to Albany - 12 1/2 on letter from Albany - 12 1/2 Hon John Kimball to C. L. Knapp 1839 Jan 8 } to Examination of pay rolls in case of Moses Andrews, $1.50 Certificate of Same .50 $2.00

York Nov 21 1840 Sir Enclosed I send you ["the" crossed out] further proof in the Case of Mrs. Andrews which you required in your last letter to me Which I hope will be satisfactory Mr. More is a Clergiman [Clergyman] in Philada [Philadelphia] of the first Order & Respectability The Mrs. Andrews is a very poor woman Old & feeble I hope you will cause her Claim to be Adjusted soon, you have the Letters of Administration granted on the Estate of her husband you have the Testimony of a respectable Clergiman &c. She is waiting [inserted: "with"] all Anxiety that attends her feeble Old worn out Constitution in poverty & Sickness to receive relief in her present situation Respecfully [Respectfully] your Obt Servant David Corey [signature] Hon'l J. L. Edwards

District and State of Connecticut, ss. BEIT REMEMBERED, That in the County Court, held in and for the County of Fairfield in the District and State aforesaid on this 18th day of July 1820 the same being a Court of Record, and having a Seal, under the Authority of said State, personally came and appeared in open Court, Squire Ambler, aged fifty seven years, resident in the Town of Danbury in the County of Fairfield in said State, and being first duly sworn according to Law, doth on his Oath declare that he served in the Revolutionary War, as follows: as a private in the Col. Lambs Regiment of Artillery in the New York line in Captain Thomas Pattens company. from the spring of the year 1780 until the close of the war as may appear by my discharge in the war office and previous to that service I served 2 years and 2 months in Col Baldwins Regiment that the original Declaration made by him, for the purpose of obtaining a Pension, under the Act of Congress of the 18th of March, 1818, was dated the 1st day of April 1818 that in pursuance thereof he was entered in the List of Pensioners, and received a Pension Certificate No. 3,088 And I do further solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States, on the 18th day of March, 1818, and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an Act of Congress, entitled "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War," passed on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities, contracts or debts due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the Schedule herein annexed, and by me subscribed. And I do further declare that my occupation is that of a carpenter I am in comfortable health for a man of my age, but entirely destitute of property having been unfortunate in life and that I have a wife named Jerusha forty years old but am not a housekeeper at present having very lately married my present wife all which is subscribed by me the day and year aforesaid. Squire Ambler Sworn to, and declared in the Court aforesaid. Whereupon said Court is, on satisfactory proof exhibited in Court, of opinion that the total amount in value of the property contained in the aforesaid Schedule is Thirty five Dollars, and doth order these proceedings to be entered in the Records of said Court. Attest David Burr Clerk

The commonwealth of Kentucky Union County To wit Be it forever remembered that at a county court held for the county aforesaid at the courthouse in Morganfield on the 21st day of February in the year of our Lord 1842 Henry H Floyd a citizen of the County & Commonwealth aforesaid a reputable person and personally known to the court and being duly sworn according to law on his oath made the following statement. that he has been well acquainted with Robert Alvey (now deceased) and Susan his wife, who was named Susan Ketchen before her marriage ever since this intermarriage and for many years before the said Susan was a school mate of said officiant. their marriage took place in Prince William County & State of Virginia in the fall of the year 1782 as well as he now recollect. as this officiant was married in the spring thereafter & he believes his wife had waited on the said Susan Alvey when she married the said Robert Alvey. the officiant states that he was a neighbor to said Alvey & wife from the time of their marriage untill [sic] Alveys death both in the State of Virginia & Kentucky that they lived together as such and was recognized as man and wife by all persons who knew them That Robert Alvey died in Union County & State of Kentucky in the fall of the year 1820 that his wife Susan is still living in extreme poverty and has never again married since the death of her said husband Robert Alvey That he knows that said Robert Alvey was in the actual service of the united states during the Revolutionary war with great Brittain [sic] as a regular soldier but the length of time he served this officiant cannot state but it was always understood he served seven years Sworn to and subscribed before me Henry H Floyd Wm Anderson J.P. Joseph Vaughn JP Nicholas Casey JP Wm Feytelmester JP Aron Waller JP C.B. Ross JP J.H. David JP A. Davis JP Justice of the County Court of Union County Kentucky

the Commonwealth of Kentucky County of Union Be it remembered that at a County Court held for the County and Commonwealth aforesaid at the Courthouse in Morganfield personally appeared in open Court before us the undesigned Justices of said Court Hugh McCloy a reputable person and personally known to us and being first duly sworn according to law on his oath made the following statement-- that he become acquainted with Robert Aley & wife about the 1804 or 1805 that they then lived together as man and wife and was recognized as such and his acquaintance continued with them as such untill [until] about the year 1820 at which time Alvey departed this life leaving the said Susan as his widow who is still alive and has never since married. She is now living in Union County Kentucky in extreme poverty Sworn to & subscribed before me Hugh McElroy Wm Anderson J.P. Joseph Vaughn JP Nicholas Carry J.P. Wm Fightmaster J.P Aron Waller J. P C. B. Ross J.P A. H. Davis J.P A. Davis J.P Commonwealth of Kentucky County of Union Towit I, James R Hughes Clerk of the Courts of Union County in the Commonwealth aforesaid do hereby certify that the foregoing contains the original proceedings of the said Court in the matter of the application of Susan Alvey widow and relict of Robert Alvey deceased for a pension In testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand and seal of office this 21st day of February in the year of our Lord One thousand eight hundred and forty two James R Hughes

New haven 9 of March 1778 Dear Friends I am obliged to Enform you I am much worse than when I left home had a very poor Turn at Lieut Bebes Canaan 5 nights a go I had a Sharp Turn of the Peripmenuoneny such a time as I had in June & July last I had a dreadful pain in my rite side which still continues tho the severity of it is a bate much trouble for Bradn how long it may pleas God to continue me in this world I now not thanks be to his Name for preserving me through so many troubles and still continuing my life Doctr Monson & Hopkins think my wounds incurable my own feeling I am very tired. HA

Know all Men by these Presents, That I Tristram Daggett of Industry in the county of Somerset and state of Maine yeoman In consideration of two hundred and fifty Dollars paid by James Bailey of the town, county & state aforesaid yeoman (the receipt whereof I do hereby acknowledge) do [crossed out] give, grant, sell, and convey unto the said James Bailey his heirs and assigns to their use and benefit forever a certain piece of land situated in said Industry being the south part of lot number ten on a a plan of said town made by Cornelius Norton Esq and bounded as follows northerly by the town road, southerly by the bull horse pond west by land owned by David Luce East by lot number E containing twenty acres more or less together with the house and one half the barn which stands on the land deeded to said Bailey by Tristram Daggett Esq, which were reserved in said Tristram Jr's deed to said Bailey To Have and to Hold the same to the said James Bailey his heirs and assigns, to their use and benefit forever. And I do covenant with the said James Bailey his heirs and assigns, That I am lawfully seized in fee of the premises—That they are free of all incumbrances—That I have good right to sell and convey the same to the said Bailey And that I will warrant and defend the same to the said James Bailey his heirs and assigns forever, against the lawful claims and demands of any persons. IN WITNESS WHEREOF, I the said Tristram Daggett and June my wife in token of relinquishment of dower have hereunto set our hands and seals this thirty first [crossed out] of March in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and twenty three Tristram Daggett Seal Signed, sealed, and delivered in presence of us Bartlett Allen Truman Allen} Seal Somerset...ss. March 31. 1823 Then [crossed out] personally appeared the within named Tristram Daggett acknowledged the within instrument, by him subscribed, to be his free act and deed, before me Bartlett Allen JUSTICE OF PEACE. Somerset, ss. Rec March 29. 1828 and entered with the records of Deeds Book 21. Page 339 Asa Clark Register A true copy of the original Deed in full Attest Asa Clark Register

3. That in the summer of 1781 he volunteered on a tour of duty under Capt Hotchkiss thinks (in) Col. Sheldin Commanded the Regent, Col Wyllys commanded another regiment at the same time & place was on duty then about two months when his regiment was marched to Mohegan to cul factions was then discharged after being there about one month more in all our nine months at this time. That he was on duty again dont now recollect the year with a team transporting Beef from Dunham to Fishkill work with three yoke of oxen was out two weeks, was under the direction of David Scranton, at a time of distress in our army for provision That he has no documentary evidence to prove his service but is well acquainted with David Baldwin who affidant is hereunto annexed and Jonathan Cone a Clergyman of the Town of Durham. that he hereby relinquishes any claim whatever for a pension except in present and declares that his name is not the pension Roll of the Agency of any State Sworn and subscribed the day Abiel Baldwin and year aforesaid in open Court William F. B. Heemance Clerk We Jonathan Cone a clergyman residing in the Town of Dunham and David Baldwin residing in the same Town do hereby certify that we are well acquainted with Abiel Baldwin who has subscribed & sworn to the above declaration, they believe him to be seventy yeas of age; & that he is reputed and believed in the Neighberhood when he resides to have been a soldier of the revolution that we concur in that opinion Sworn & subscribed the day & year Jonathan Cone contain in open Court William V.B. Heemance Clerk David Baldwin ---

Know all Men, by these Presents, That I Jane Bakeman of the town of Onondaga in the County of Onondaga and State of New York, have made, constituted and appointed, and by these Presents do make, constitute and appoint R. F. Trowbridge of the city of Syracuse in the County of Onondaga and State of New York my true and lawful Attorney, for me, and in my name, place and stead to examine into, demand, and receive any monies, or other dues which may belong to me in right of hardship, as widow of Henry Bakeman deceased late a soldier of Colonel Willett's Regiment in the Revolutionary War. Giving and granting unto my said Attorney, full power and authority, to do and perform all and every act and thing whatsoever, requisite and necessary to be done, in and about the premises, as fully, to all intents and purposes, as I might or could do if personally present, with full power of substitution and revocation, hereby ratifying and confirming all that my said Attorney, or his Substitute, shall lawfully do, or cause to be done, by virtue thereof. Revoking all other Powers of Attorney. In Witness Whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and seal, this Twenty-Seventh day of February in the year one thousand eight hundred and fifty-four. /s/ X Her Mark Jane Bakeman SEALED AND DELIVERED IN PRESENCE OF} /s/Jesse Salmons [seal affixed] State of New York, ONONDAGA COUNTY,}ss. On this twenty Seventh day of February in the year of our Lord, one thousand eight hundred and fifty four before me, personally came Jane Bakeman to known to be the individual described in and who executed the within Power of Attorney, and acknowledged that he executed the same for the purposes therein mentioned. /s/Jesse Salmons Justice of the Peace and Commissioner of Deeds. State of New York, ONONDAGA COUNTY CLERK'S OFFICE,}ss. I Barnard Swann Clerk of said County, hereby certify, that Jesse Salmons Esq., whose name is subscribed to the above Certificate of acknowledgement, was at the time of taking the same, a Justice of the Peace in and for said County, and authorized to take the same; that I am acquainted with his hand-writing, and believe the above signature to be genuine. IN TESTIMONY WHEREOF, I have hereunto set my hand and affixed the Seal of said County, this 27th day of February 1854. /s/Barnard Swann Clerk.

Those who are fond of the submarine beautiful, will derive singular gratification from the perusal of the following toast, which was lately given at a dinner in Tennessee : -- By Col. S. D. Jacob -- Andrew Jackson- We anxiously hope for the preservation of his life, until his elevation to the Presidential chair, when his uncompromising honesty, and incorruptible integrity will wither into political non-existence the "left hunded politicians of the day; but, should providence deprive us of him, would it not be well to stretch his skin over a drum head. like that of John Liscas of old, and beat up a crusade against the aggrandizing, patrol nizing, consolidating state-right-trampling, newspaper-crushing, and blard tall of the Administration of all the modes of putting down the administration , the one proposed is the most ingenious and novel, that has come to our notice. -- Constitutionalist. Emigration from Europe to this country Grene tain it is greater than from any other part of the globe for since the first of May, near three thousand steerage passengers must have arrived in the different ships that all ed from England and Ireland. The roll war arrived at Quebec from Belfast with 229 settlers, the Camillus, at New York, with 153; the Howard Douglas, 181; Dalhousie Castle, 70; ship India, 76; Robert Edwards, 44; Clematis, 63; Josephine, from Belfast, 158; Great Britain, 152. To this list many others might be added. The New York Gazette, in noticing the same subject, says, "From Saturday to Wednesday , inclusive, there were 115 arrivals at this port. These vessels brought about feen hundred passengers, the greater pro- S portion of whom are emigrants from Great Britain . Numerous other vessels from Europe , now due, have also on board, as we are informed, a great many emigrants; and ┃ we also learn, from a late number of the Glasgow Chronicle, that several of the persons about to abandon their native home for the United States, have long been in Glasgo , and were considered as the most efficient in their respective trodes. To such persons a hearty welcome is always extended ." -- Philad pup. Another Revolution soldier no mar Mrs. Deborah, wife of Mr. Benjamin Gannett , died at her family residence in Sharon, Mass. on the 29th ult. aged 67. -- The life of this woman must be considered extraordinary and interesting in a number of respects . But the most distinguished feature in her character is that of having been a heraine in the American Army of the Revolution . She enlisted, a volunteer in the Massachusetts corps, in the habiliments and character of a soldier, where she continued three years, to the close of the war. Extraordinary as this may appear she not onon every occasion, performed the arduour duty of a soldier with more than ordinaalertness , gallantry and courage -- having been in several severe engagements, and twice dangerously wounded -- but sustaining a charcter unsullied, and her sex undiscovered the peace was declared. Further, as regards the list of Mr. Canning, nothing is yet known; but the public mind is decidedly in favour of the measures adopted by the sovereign.
