To the Honorable the Senate and House of Representatives of the State of South Carolina. This Petition of the Subscriber Charles Carter humbly & respectfully showeth to your Honorable Body this needy condition and hopes that the just claims which he has for Revolutionary services when once presented for your consideration will induce you to grant him a pension. He is now old & inform having to labour with his own hands for the support of himself his wife & two daughters which united with his superannuated age numbering seventy eight years he hopes with incline you to extend the means provided by an Act of the Legislature for the relief of the soldiers of the Revolution. He has lately applied to the Genl. Government for a pension but for the want of necessary living evidence to substantiate his Revolutionary services he has been denied his application, all his fellow soldiers so far as he can ascertain from a late correspondence having departed this life. The same insufficiency of proof may operate against him in his present petition but he trusts that Justice will be done him. He now proceeds to state that he was enlisted into service in North Carolina under Capt. Sharp sometime in the year 1781 or 82 and was frequently engaged in Scouting parties in pursuit of the Tories and made a trip to Salisbury with some prisoners and was also in service under Capt. Reed at Trowhawk old field abuot the first Oct. the same year as well as he can recollect. Your petitioner entered the continental service under Capt. Davis, the batallion and Regiment to which he was attached were commanded by Maj. Hogg and Col. Ball and were stationed at Halifax North Carolina. The Troops remained at Halifax untill about the first of March following when they were marched into South Carolina under the Command of Lieutenant Lamb, after scouring the country through which

presented to your Honorable Body by the way of petition and inasmuch as he is wanting the necessary proof to establish them we have thought it our duty to furnish you with his general character. Mr. Cater is really in needy circumstances having to labour for the support of himself, his wife and two daughters, and his age being seventy eight years old now disqualifies him for labour. We therefore your Honorable Body that you will make him a pensioner upon the Common Bounty of the State as we really think him entitled to it and hope that you will discharge a grateful tribute now due a Revolutionary soldier who cannot ask your Bounty long but who no doubt feel extremely grateful to your Honorable Body for remembering his Revolutionary services, with is age and infirmities by granting him the prayer of his petition. So. Ca. Edgefield Dist. 18th Nov. 1840 (signed) Richard C. Griffin, James S. Pope, D.E. Davenport, Thos. C. Griffin, R.A. Griffin, Thos. Scurry, John Presley, William Thompson, Robert Chainey, Pierce Little, Charles C. Barnett, Wm. Bradfield, Reuben Cooper, J.W. Cooper, Pleasant Burnett Sen., Carter Burnett, David G. Burnett, Willy Culbreath, Littleberry Burnett. The Committee on pension, to whom was repaired "the petition of Charles Carter praying to be placed on the pension Roll" Respectfully report that they have had the same under consideration and recommend that he be placed on the Pension Roll of the State. In the House of Representatives December 17 1840. Resolved that the House do agree to the Report ordered that it be sent to the senate for concurrence. By order (signed) Wm Glover C.H.R. In the Senate Decr 18 1840. Resolved that the Senate do concur in the Report ordered that it be returned to the House of Representative. By order (Signed) W.E. Martin C.S."

engaged in most of the military movements in and about the State of Vermont during the revolution. that during the second year of the late war with Great Brittain. the northen frontier was almost wholly defenceless. A corps of exempts (mostly revolutionary soldiers) was formed to defend the post at French Mills. Major Wood was commissioned a lieutenant of this corps by Gov. Tompkins, and actually served five months as such officer, until other Troops were raised for the purpose. By refering to the published State papers of Vermont the Department will perceive that John Wood the father of Major Wood as one of the Committee of Safety of the town of Bennington during the revolution, and that Major Wood himself was a member of the Convention of that State, which adopted the constitution of the United States. The undersigned respectfully solicit that the commissioner of Pensions will communicate to Major Wood the charges which have been made against him, fully believing that that any suspicions against his character and of the propriety of his being continued on the pension list, will easily be removed. Dated at Malone June 17th 1835 Benjn Clark Justice of the peace Rich'd G. Foote Atty at Law Jacob Head Co Treasurer Horatio Powell Judge Franklin County Courts Ashbel Parmalee, Pastor of the 1st Congregational Church in this place of which Mr. Wood has been a member for 19 years.

State of New York County of Warren SS John H Barker pasture of the Baptist Church in the town of Hague County of Warren and State of New York being first Duly Sworn according to Law Says that he is personally acquainted with David Boynton a man about Eighty years old Said David is a member of good standing in the Baptist Church over which he presides Believes the said David to be a man of truth and good Morral Charricter and would Depend on the word of the said David as Soon as on the word of any other man and has no reason to Doubt Said Davids Being a Soldier in the War of the revolution Subscribed & Sworn this 17th September 1832 [Signature] John H Barker Pastor of the Baptist Church of Hague aforsaid before me [Signature] Calvin Barnard Commissioner of Hague Warren County State of New York County of Warren SS [Obscured] Griggs resident of the town of Hague [obscured] county being first Duly Sworn according to Law Says that he is and has Been personally acquainted with David Boynton a man Eighty years old or over Believes and considers the said David a man of truth and good Morral Charricter and Believes that the said David is considered a man of fair charricter by the Inhabitants of the town generally has no reason to Disbelieve any Declaration made by the said David Subscribed & Sworn this 17th of September 1832 [Signature] Ira Griggs before me [Signature] Calvin Barnard Commissioner of Hague Warren County

State of Vermont District of Marlboro On this third day of September in the year of Our Lord one thousand Eight hundred and thirty eight personally appeared before the Probate Court within and for the district of Marlboro aforesaid being a Court of Record having by law a seal and Clerk, Deboarh Bishop a resident of Marlboro in the district aforesaid and county of Windham aged seventy nine years, who being duly sworn according to law doth on her oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the provision made by the act of Congress passed July 7th 1838 entitled "An act granting half pay and pensions to certain widows." She is the widow of Sylvester Bishop who was a soldier in the Revolutionary Army of the United States and served as follows to wit that the said Sylvester Bishop in the year 17[Unreadable] enlisted at Brookfield, Mass. into the army aforesaid for the term of Eight months, sent to Boston early in the year, was in the Battle of Bunker Hill and served out the full term of his enlistment and returned home in the autumn. In this campaign she thinks said Sylvester served under Capt. Danforth but she cannot say in no certain terms. That imme--

in that battle. That being estitut of Arms, he borrowed a power form of a man named Gant (which this declarant now has in her possessed) and a gun of another. the afterwards re named and bright a farm in Marlboro near Willington Vt and cleared it and lived there until the time of his deceased. That from age and the consequent loss of memory she cannot more particularly set forth the services of the said Sylusten nor can she name the officers under whom he service other than as above and she further says that repere passage of the Pension act of Welland 1818 the seed spies to rear possessed of a handram real personal estate in said Wilmington and had no need of assistance from his country for support and never applied for a pension as she understood- 1 She further declares that she was married to the said Sylvester Bishop on Eighth day of June in the year of our Lord Seventeen hundred and Eighty - that her husband the forsaid Sylvester Bishop died the twelfth day of March Anno Domini Eighteen hundred & twenty two That she was not married to him prior to his leaving the service but the marriage took place previous to the first of Young seventeen removed & ninety four rowed

State of New York Suffolk County Timothy Bishop of Huntington Suffolk County and State of New York having duly interrogated and sworn according to law and the institutions of the Secretary of war, deposeth and saith that he was born at Durham in the State of Connecticut as he supposed and believed in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and sixty four that he lived at Durham during the American revolution and untill [until] he was twenty seven years of age and the deponent further states that he served as a soldier either under the authority of the state of Connecticut or of the United States at five different times between the year 1779 and the year 1783 The first time he supposed was in the latter part of the year 1779 - he went as a substitute for his father Gordon Bishop who was drafted to go to East Haven for three months that he served under Captain Shepherd of Wallingford that he went from home about harvest time or a little after and served as he believes three months serving six days The second time he believes was in the year 1780 he went again as a substitute for his father who was drafted to go to Stratford for three months that he left home shortly after harvest that he continued at Stratford and remained in service two months that he does not certainly recollect the captains name but that Simeon Person's was the Lieutenant of the company under Col [illegible] of Wallingford The third time was in September 1781 when he was called out with the militia to and in the defence of Fort Griswold and was out six days under Captain Norton The fourth time he supposes was in the year 1782 he went again as a substitute for his father who was drafted to go to Guilford but for what length of time he cannot say - that he continued at Guilford he supposes and he serves for three months from the first of August to the first of November, that the officers were Col Cooke of Wallingford and either Simeon Parsons or at Durham Scranton and he does not recollect with certainty which was Lieutenant of the company The fifth time he supposes was in the year 1782 & 1783 he went as a substitute for Gilbert Gatlin of Saybrook who was enlisted to go to Horse Neck for one year that he left home on the sixteenth day of December 1782 and remained in service untill [until] within two

Declaration of Levi Bishop State of Vermont} County of Windor} ss. District of Windor ss. On this Thirtieth day of July in the year of our Lord, one thousand eight hundred and thirty two, personally appeared in open court before the Judge of the Probate Court within and for the District of Windsor in the State of Vermont, now sitting, Levi Bishop, a resident of Winsor in the County (and District) of Windsor aforesaid, aged nearly seventy three years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the Act of Congress passed June 7th 1832; That he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers, and served as herein stated, vie; That, at Windsor in said County of Windsor where the declarant then resided he stood minute-man", and near the middle of the month of February 1777 upon a call for the militia to [underlined: turn out] an expectation prevailing that the Bristish would come upon the ice of the Lake Champlain, he volunteered as a private and joined the Company of Capt. Phineas Williams in the Regiment commanded by Col. . . . Marsh. The company collected at, and started from said Windsor - marched to Charlestown in Newhampshire and tarried there a few days to collect stores - he thence marched across the mountain to Ticonderoga where he remained until about the first day of April when the ice having become quite thin the company was discharged,

within and for the District of Windsor in the State of Vermont, do hereby certify, that the foregoing contains the original proceedings of the said Court in the matter of the application of Levi Bishop for a Pension. Jabez Proctor Judge In Testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand and affixed the seal of said Court, this thirtieth day of July in the year of our Lord one Thousand eight hundred and thirty two. Reuben Washburn

To the Senate and House of Representatives in Congress assembled, Your most respective petitioner begs leave to State, that early in the winter of 1777 during the war of the revolution, he entered the regular service of the United States for three years, in Captain B. Tutts company under command of Col. Laurence and Genl Lincoln, and that on the 9th Oct 1779. while engaged in action with the enemy at Savannah Georgia, was severely wounded in the ancle [sic] by a ball producing great pain and suffering with ulcerated sores on forty odd years. For the preservation of life it was deemed necessary in the year 1824, to amputate the leg the statement of this fact is more fully shown by the certificate from the Pension Office accompaning this memorial marked No 1- Your petitioners name was placed on the revolutionary Invalid pension roll in the year 1808 at the rate of $21.42 per annum, And under the general Law, "to increase the pensions of invalid in certain cases approved April 24, 1876" The invalid pension was increased at the rate of $34.12 per annum, and by reference to said act 1816 it will be perceived, that under the first section a private for total disability, or disability of the highest degree, 1 a pension of eight dollars per month , was directed to be allowed, had your petitioner been apprized of the act 24th April 1816, and application had been made after the total disability occurred "Decr 10. 1824." See Surgeons certificate No 1 a full pension would have been allowed, But not having known of the act April 24, 1816 until the year 1837. when application was made through by attorney Alexander Ray of Washington for said act And to the application then made, the commissioner of Pension replies. No 2 "If he [John Looney] can show that the loss of his leg was the necessary

27th CONGRESS, 2d Session. Rep. No. 141. JOHN LOONEY To accompany bill H.R. No. 187. FEBRUARY 9, 1842. 187 Ho. OF REPS. Mr. GORDON, from the Committee on Invalid Pensions, submitted the following REPORT: The Committee on Invalid Pensions, to whom was referred the petition of John Looney, report: That early in the winter of 1777, during the war of the Revolution, he entered the regular service of the United States, for three years, in Captain B. Tutt's company, under command of Colonel Lawrence and General Lincoln; and that on the 9th of October, 1779, while engaged in action with the enemy, at Savannah, Georgia, was severely wounded in the ankle by a ball, producing great pain and suffering, with ulcerated sores, for forty years. For the preservation of life, it was deemed necessary, in the year 1824, to amputate the leg. The petitioner's name was placed on the revolutionary pension roll, in the year 1808, at the rate of $21.42 per annum; and, under the general law "to increase the pensions of invalids in certain cases," approved April 24, 1816, the invalid pension was increased at the rate of $34.12 per annum. Under the first section of the act of 1816, a private, for total disability, or disability of the highest degree, was directed to be allowed, after a total disability occurred, a full pension of $8 per month. His leg was amputated on the 24th day of December, 1824, and the disability became total from that day; but, being ignorant of the provision in the act of 1816, allowing a full pension for the occurrence of a total disability, as in his case, he did not apply at the War Department for a full pension, under that provision of the act in question, until the year 1837, when he was told by the Commissioner of Pensions, if he could show that the loss of his leg was the necessary consequence of the wound which he received at the battle of Savannah, he would be entitled to a full pension of eight dollars per month. He accordingly complied with the Commissioner's instructions, and presented the surgeon's certificate and evidence of the fact, in conformity thereto, showing the time when the disability occurred, (the 10th of December, 1824;) and, upon a re-examination of the case, on the 17th of June, 1837, the Commissioner discovered "the law which authorized him to increase the pension had expired," and declined to increase the pension on that sole ground, every thing else being in the petitioner's favor, and satisfactory to the Commissioner, and within the spirit and letter, true intent and meaning of the then late law. Those who applied under the provision of the act of 1816, before its expiration, and obtained an increase of pension on account of total disability, in consequence

State of Maryland Charles County SS On this 14th day of Febuary 1837 personally appeared before the undersigned Margaret Posey a resident in the County of Charles and State of Maryland and made Oath on the holy Evangelists of Almighty God to the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the third Section of the Act of Congress of July the 4th 1836. That she is the Widdow of Belden Posey who was a captain in the Flying Camp in 1776, and after that Camp was disbanded commanded Company of Militia in this County and State - that he served as Captain of a Militia Company at different periods of the War until near its close, that he was in command of a Company of Militia at the time George Dents dwelling was burned by the enemy, said dwelling situated on the bank of the Potomack River in the County and State, and was near the aforesaid dwelling in Command of a Company at the time it was burnt,-- which happened about the year seventeen hundred and seventy nine or Eighty-- And further that she was married to the said Belain Posey on the 11th day of November 1777 by the Rev Wm Bolton officiating as Minister within the Parish of St Thomas's Manor, and that her husband the aforesaid Belain Posey died on the 5th day of June 1791 and that she has remained a widow ever since to the present time as will more fully appear by references to the proof hereto annexed, Sworn and subscribed to before me Chief Justice of the Orphans Court of Charles County Jno Ferguson

State of North Carolina Wake County August yr 1833 This day personally appeared Elisha Pope in open Court & being first duly sworn made the then following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the provision of the act of Congress passed 7 June 1932--that he was raised in Nash County this State--that he enlists on three months tour in the horse in the year 1780 under Howel Ellen--that this was just after Lord Cornwallis traipsed through the County & through the Roanoke at Halifax--that he was in the County Light horse & duly served on Scouts-- after Tories that they caught several & carried them to Halifax Joseph I Clendenin had the command of this Light Horse--that he served three months-- that if he got a discharge it is now lost-- that he another tour of three months in the horse, shortly after the first tour under Capt. John Bond as a substitute for his Brother Demsey Pope --that they only performed County services against the Tories & served the full three months was in no regular engagements --Clinch as the Colonel --that this service was at the time he heard of the capture of Cornwallis. To the several interrogations as read to him from the war department --he answers 1. that he was born in 1761 in what was then Edgecombe County

State of No.Carolina Wake County This 11th day of November A.D. 1833 personally appeared before me Benjamin Rogers one of the acting Justices of the Peace in and for the County & State aforesaid: Elisha Pope in said County & State aforesaid being first duly Sworn maketh the following Declaration on Oath in a way of amendatory to the accompanying declaration & Certificate iin order to obtain the Benefit of the Pension of the Acts of Congress passed 7 of June 1833-- that he was Raised in Nash County this State --that he was called out as a Soldier in the Revolutionary War in the Service of the United and that he Served in a regular Embodied Corps of the Horse Company three months in the year o 1781 under under Howell Ellin Captain that this was Just after Lord Cornwallis passed through the County & crossed the Roanoak at Halifax--that he was in the County light horse and Served another Tower of three months in a Regular imbodied Corps in the Sirvice of the United States. Joseph I Clinch Colonel then had at that time the command of the light Horse to which body he served in the Second Tower of three months--that if he go a discharge it was lost. but served in the first Tower three months & Second Tower three months making the whole Service for the time he Served Six months. Sworn to & Subscribed before me the day & date above written. Elisha Pope Benj Rogers J.P.

[next part is Dup.of previous image] NOTES. 1. Which must be made before a judge of a court of record in open court, unless applicant is from bodily health unable to appear: it then can be made before the judge, who will certify to the fact of the disability to appear. 2. Must here state, whether a revolutionary soldier, or officer, or pensioner, naming the State where the pension was paid: or if the husband served and died in the service during any war since 1780 -- naming them thus: Wayne's, or Indian wars prior to 1800; War with Great Britain, 1812; Seminole War, 1817 and 1818; Black Hawk War, 1832; Florida War, 1835 to 1842; Cherokee and Creek Disturbances, 1836, &c.; Mexican War, 1846 to 1848; and giving the name of the Captain, Company, Regiment, and Colonel: and whether militia, volunteers, or regular army and place of muster, discharge, or death. 3. Deceased person's name and residence. -- 4. The place. -- 5. The date of death. -- 6. Husband's name, or father's name. 7. Name of the minister, or justice of the peace; and if married in any State or county where any public records of marriages are kept, the marriage should be proved by a duly certified copy of the record, or by the testimony of credible witnesses who were present at the marriage; and where such testimony exists, and is not produced satisfactory reasons must be stated, under oath, why it is not produced; and, in all cases where record evidence of the testimony of witnesses who were present at the marriage could be procured and is not, the claim will be rejected, unless other testimony of a very full and satisfactory character is produced. If it is shown by affidavit that no record evidence or testimony of witnesses can be procured, the claimant may then produce the best other evidence in her power. such as the testimony of witnesses, who were acquainted with her and her husband during his lifetime, knew them to live together as man and wife, and that they were reputed to be, and that the fact of their having been married was never called in question by their acquaintances. In no case, however, will the mere statement of the witnesses, that the claimant is the widow of the deceased, be taken as evidence of the marriage; but the witnesses must state the facts and circumstances from which they derive their knowledge or opinion that she is the widow of the deceased. A certificate from the clergyman or magistrate who solemnized the marriage is not competent evidence, unless the genuineness of the certificate be proved, and the person who gave it be shown to have been authorized to solemnize marriages. 9. This blank is left, for the purpose of the applicant's stating whether any bounty land or pension has at any time been received by any one; if so, by whom, and when. 10. Naming the war. All records or copy of records must be attached to the original declaration by a tape, the ends of which must pass under the seal of the court, in order to prevent the improper addition of any evidence after the papers have been duly executed and certified to by the judge and clerk. If the widow was re-married, all the facts of marriage and death of second husband must be proven. A probate court is the most convenient court in which to make these proofs. The law (3d February, 1855, grant pensions to the widows of revolutionary soldiers, without reference to date of marriage,

which is hereunto annexed. Both terms of service amounting at least to seven months and six days. Said Elias Adams was born in the town of Brookfield, Mass. June 10, 1764, and supposes the record of his birth is in the clerk's office in said town. Lived in said Brookfield about twelve years, then removed with his father to the town of Medway, Mass, then removed back again to said town of Brookfield, and lived there about twenty seven years more, then removed to the town of Spencer, Mass. where he has lived ever since, and where he lives now. Lived in said Medway when he entered into the United States service, both tours, was not drafted, but enlisted voluntarily, and has never received a written discharge. Reference may be had to Jonas Bemis Esq, Capt. James Capen, Doct. Jonas Guilford or Rufus Adams, who are some of my neighbours, and who can testify as to my character for truth. Have no documentary evidence, except from the records of the secratarys office, a certificate from Edward D. Bangs, the secratary is hereunto annented[?]. He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or, annuity except present, and declares that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any state. Attest James Draper Elias Adams Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid. Befne [Before] Nathl Paine Judge of Probate For the County of Worcester We Levi Packard, a clergyman, residing in the town of Spencer, aforesaid, and William Pope Esquire, residing in the same town of Spencer, hereby certify that we are well acquainted with Elias Adams, who has applied for a pension, as above, that we believe him to be sixty eight years of age, that he is reputed and believed in the neighbourhood where he resides to have been a soldier of the revolution, and that we concur in that opinion. [Document is handwritten.] Commonwealth of Massachusetts Secretary's Office Dec. 14th 1857. I hereby certify that from an examination of of the Books and Documents relating to Military Services in the War of the Revolution which remain in this department it appears that the name of Simeon Bacon is borne on pay roll of Capt. Elijah Dwight's Company for billeting money to and from head-quarters 150 miles from Ware, as private. Roll not dated, but paid by Captain John Thompson's Company Colonel Seward's Regiment from May 7th, 1777, 2 months, 10 days, as private from Ware. Also the following petition, vis. "Commonwealth of Massachusetts To the Honorable the Senate & Honorable House of Representatives, in General Court assembled September 1st, 1783. The petition of Easter Bacon, of Ware, in the County of Hampshire, widow and [illegible] of Simeon Bacon, late of Ware, deceased, humbly sheweth. That the said Simeon, husband of your petitioner inlisted [sp] in the service of the United States in May 1777 and marched to Ticonderoga under the command of Captain John Thompson, and served there two months, and until the Army of the United States evacuated said Fort and the British Army took possession of the Fort, and on the retreat of our Army, your petitioner's husband being in the rear was unfortunately taken prisoner by the enemy, and carried to Canada, and was there prisoner sixteen months, was then exchanged, and on his way home to this place through many hardships he had undergone during the time he was a prisoner was taken sick and died at Boston, on the first of November 1778. Your petitioner being very poor and left with a large family of small children and no ways able to support them without great difficulty. And whereas your petitioner has receive no consideration for her late husbands time whilst in captivity, she therefore prays your Honors to take her distressed state and condition into your wise consideration and relieve your petitioner in such way as your Honors shall think proper. As in duly bound shall ever pray. Ware, September 2, 1783 Easter Bacon x her mark Also

[Document is handwritten.] come that Simeon Bacon, [illegible] of the town of Ware and county of Hamper and State of Massachusetts Bay served two months in my company at Ticonderoga. And in the retreat he been gin the rear guard, was taken at Hobardstown, in the battle that was fought one Monday morning, and carried to Canada and continued in captivity sixteen months and in his return died at Boston. Pelham, May the 27, 1781 [illegible] John Thompson, Captain. N. B. The time that the service ws done in my company was in the months of May and June in the year 1777. Commonwealth of Massachusetts. To the Honorable the Senate and House of Representatives in General Court assembled: September 1783. The petition of Easter Bacon of Ware, in the County of Hampshire, widow and relict of Simeon Bacon, late of said Ware deceased humbly sheweth: That the said Simeon, husband of your petitioner, inlisted [sp] in the service of the United States in May 1777, and marched to Ticonderoga under the command of Captain John Thompson, and served there two months and until the army of the United States evacuated said port, and the British army took position of the port, and on the retreat of our army your petitioner's husband, being in the rear, was unfortunately taken prisoner by the enemy and carried to Canada and was there prisoner sixteen months; was then exchanged and in his way home to this place, through many hardships he had endured during the time he was a prisoner, was taken sick and died at Boston on the first of November 1778. Your petitioner being very poor and left with a large family of small children and no ways able to support them without break difficulty, and whereas your petitioner has received no consideration for her late husband's time whilst in captivity, she therefore prays your Honors to take her distressed state and condition into your wise consideration and relieve your petitioner in such way as your Honors shall think proper. Is in duty bound shall ever pray. Easter Bacon x her mark Ware, September 2, 1783. In Testimony Whereof, I have hereunto affixed the Seal of the Commonwealth, the date above written. Oliver Warner. Secretary of the Commonwealth

Declaration In order to obtain the benefits of the 2nd section of the Act of 3 February 1853. State of New York Seneca County ss} On this 21sr day of January AD 1854, personally appeared before the Seneca County Court of the State of New York, Rebecca Eddy, a resident of the town of Fayette in the county of Seneca and state aforesaid, aged seventy three years, who first being duly sworn according to law doth on her oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the provision made by the act of Congress passed on the 3d February 1853 granting pensions to widows of persons who served during the Revolutionary War, that she is the widow of Asa Eddy, who was a private as she is informed and believes in a regiment of militia commanded by Colonel Caulfield of New Milford in the State of Connecticut and served in said company in the army of the Revolution for the term of about three months, that at the time he entered the service he resided with his father in Canaan Connecticut, she she, the declarant, was lawfully married to the said Asa Eddy on the 17th day of November in the town of Sauling, county of Tompkins. That the marriage ceremony was performed by Rev. Jabez Chadwick then Pastor of a Congregational Church at that place, that her said husband died on the 11th day of June 1840, in the town of Preston in the county of Ontario and State of New York. That at the time of his death he was a pensioner of the United States and

I Samuel H Kellogg of lawful age do depose testify & say that I am the Town {illegible] of the Town of Pittsford in the County of Rutland State of Vermont, and that I have faithfully examined the Records of this Town now in my office, and cannot then find the Record of the Marriage of Luther Drury & Rhoda Hopkins neither are there any records of Marriages of as early date as 1886 in my office. I further testify & say that my Maternal Grandfather to wit Rev. Elias Harwood was the first settled Minister over the Con. Church in this Town, that he lived with my father [until, crossed out] & deceased at his house in 1807, and his papers & effects were left with my father Amos Kellogg who deceased in 1826, at which time said papers came into my possession as Executor & that I [lived with, crossed out] was born in the same house & still remain the same house in which both my said ancestors deceased. And among the papers of my said Grandfather & made in his on hand writing there is a Memorandum Book of Marriages & Baptisms subscribed by him. The first page is headed with the word “Marriages” then follows sixteen couple entered in the following order Luther Drury & Rhoda Hopkins, Rufus Montagne & Catherine Sanford Abraham Owen & Penelope Boqan & upon this page there is no date. The next page commences in the same order with two couples, then follows the remainder of the page in the following order ([illegible]) Nov 13, 1788 Caleb Churchill & Sarah Holey, Nov 27, 1788 Roger Barnard Matilda Hopkins,, then follows in the same order

Pontotoc, Miss, June 29 1839 Hone [Honorable] J. R. Poinsett Secy of War Washington City Dear Sir I am a pensioner and am very needy, in due distress for the amount due me from the Government and I have applied to I have appraise to the pension agent of Natchez and an answered that he has no funds, I hope you will direct fund to be placed at Natchez forthwith for the payment of those war worn soldiers who have spent the better portion of their days in the service of their country I am dear Sir your friend & servant Charles Cornelius

Hominy, Okla., 12 10 27 Department of Interior, Bureau of Pensions, Revolutionary War Section, Washington, D. C. Dear sir, I am trying to trace my family line. My great grandfather, Charles Cornelius, fought in the Revolutionary War. I think that he married Elizabeth Jennings, 1794, in Culpepper Co., Va., where her father lived at the time. He reared his family mostly at Hadensville, Goochland Co., Va. I feel sure he was of Virginia. Please let me hear whether you have any data whatsoever of him. Thanking you, and trusting to hear from you soon, I am Sincerely yours, R E Cornelius Pastor First Baptist Church Hominy, Oklahoma.

State of North Carolina} Ashe County} This day came John Toliver personally before me the undersigned one of the acting Justices of the peace for the count & state - aforesaid, and after being duly sworn upon the Holy evangilist of Almighty God. deposeth and says. That Jesse Toliver was married to Frankey his wife about the 8th day of October 1782 as he fully believes, and that he was present at said marriage and that one William Hammons a regular Baptist minister married them, and that some other persons was present but as far as he knows they are all now dead. The marriage was made in the then usual way in this part of the country by publishing the Bans of matrimony and do not know when the License or Bone is. if any, and has been informed that neither can be found. I know that they have lived together as man & wife about fifty six years and until his death which took place the 7th Feby. 1838, and for all the above period of time I have been personally acquainted with them and still know the widow. a she lives in a few miles of me now, I further know that she Frankey Toliver has never been married to no other person and I further know that Jesse Toliver her husband got a pension up to his death.

The Family of Charles Witt consists of himself his wife about 47 years of age afflicted with Rhuematick pain so as to render her almost incapable of work and a step son about 18 years of age. Charles Witt was a Shoe maker by trade but has had the misfortune to lose the thumb from his right hand which renders him entirely incapable of pursuing his trade. Charles X his mark Witt Sworn to and Subscribed in open court Oct 29 AD 1824 Henderson Clk

State of Virginia Chesterfield County, se. Personally appeared before me, the undersigned, a Justice of the Peace in the County & State aforesaid, William Hill, who being duly sworn doth on his oath make the following statement, viz. "That from old age & the consequent loss of memory; he cannot swear positively as to the precise length of his service for the United States in the Revolutionary War; but according to the best of his recollection he served not less than the periods mentioned below, and in the following grades, viz. For Eleven Months he served as a private in the Virginia Militia in the United States service, during the Revolution, & for such service he claims a pension. That he is not certain that he can procure the testimony of any person who can testify to his personal knowledge of his service, or of any Clergyman who can prove the reputation of it, as none resides immediately in his neighborhood. In answer to the 7th question directed to be put by the regulations of the War Department, he could mention many persons, but supposes it will be sufficient to name Major Wm Goode, late high Sheriff of this County & James & Richard Elam esqrs [esquires] the former of whom has several times represented this County in the General Assembly & the latter is & has been for many years he Commissioner of the Revenue for the same." Sworn to & subscribed the 4th day of December 1832.} Woodson W Hancock, JP William Hill We, Charles Forsee, a Clergyman, and James Elam & Richard Elam, all residing in the County of Chesterfield & State of Virginia, certify that we are well acquainted with William Hill, who has made the above statement, & have known him for many years; that he is imputed & believed in this neighborhood to have been a soldier of the Revolution; that we concur in that opinion & have never heard it doubted. That he is a man of respectability & veracity, & we believe him to be upward of seventy years of age. Subscribed & sworn to the 4th day of December 1832. Charles Forsee J. Elam Richd Elam Sworn to before me the day & year aforesaid. William Goode, JP I, William Goode Jr., a Justice of the peace for the County of Chesterfield & State of Virginia do hereby certify that Charles Forsee, James Elam & Richard Elam who have subscribed the foregoing certificate, this day made oath before me of the truth of the same; and I further certify that Charles Forsee is a resident minister [crossed out] clergyman in the County aforesaid & that they are all men of great respectability & credit, & their statement is entitled to the utmost confidence. Given under my hand this 4th day of December 1832. William Goode Jr. JP

ELDER & HILL ATTORNEYS AT LAW DEXTER HORTON BUILDING SEATTLE ANDREW G. ELDER CYRIL D. HILL December 17, 1936. [circular stamp]RECEIVED DEC 21 1936 MAIL SUB-DIV. VETS ADM READER #10 Veterans Administration, Washington, D. C. Dear Sirs: Re: BA-J/ILL William Hill W. 2939 Your letter of December 10, 1936, is very much appreciated. I cannot thank you enough for your patience in regard to my inquiries. However, I do have some further information that may help in solving the problem. In Hardesty's Historical and Geographical Encyclopedia, 1884, pages 410 and 411: Revolutionary soldiers from Amherst County, Virginia. Included in a list of two hundred and seventy-nine names, I find the names of Isaac Hill, William Hill and Nat Hill, with the following note at the bottom of the list. "Ordered in service from Amherst county, June 21, 1781, by Daniel Gaines, Colonel of Militia, two hundred and seventy-nine non-commissioned officers and privates, "to march to join the Army of commander by the Honorable Major General Marquis de la Fayette". they were officered as follows: John Pope, Jr., lieutenant colonel Commandant, William Cabell, Jr., Major, Captains: Charles Christian, Reuben Jordan, John Woodroff, Richard Taliaferro, Azariah Martin. Lieutenants. Isaac Rucker, Joseph Edwards, Joseph Burruss, John Watson, James Gressom, Charles Eades. Ensigns. Peter Carter, Robert Wright, Henry Turner. This William Hill is my ancestor. Perhaps he can be identified by reference to the other names given. I will appreciate any [added by hand in pencil left margin]no Nat. or Nathan [illegible] no Isaac [illegible]

Commonwealth of Massachusetts Plymouth County At a Court of Probate holden by the Hon Wilkes Wood Judge of Probate for said County of Plymouth, at Rochester, within and for said County of Plymouth on the sixth day of November D. 1833 personally appeared in open Court. Job Harkell of said Rochester, aged eighty two years, having been born at said Rochester on the sixteenth day of October, old style, one thousand seven hundred and fifty one, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress passed June 7. D. 1832 That in the early part of the year one thousand seven hundred and seventy five he enlisted at Rochester in a Company raised by the State of Massachusetts to aid in the war of the revolution. The officers were Earl Clapp of Rochester, now living in the State of Connecticut, Captain, Isaac Pope and a man by the name of Church [illegible]. On the first of May 1775 said Company marched from Rochester to Roxbury where it remained till the close of the year 1775, and in the first of January 1776, he, with the rest of the company, was discharged, but without any written discharge. He was during this term of [Illegible], tho in some skirmishes. He thinks Major General John Thomas had the principal command while at Roxbury. He was in the regiment commanded by lit Cotton. He even engaged in this [illegible] eight months. He hereby relinquishes all claim whatever to any pension for services in the war of the revolution except the one now preferred.

I Gideon Hammond of Rochester in the County of Plymouth Commonwealth of Massachusetts, (illegible) qualified to give evidence, testify and say that I entered in the spring of 1775 into a company of Militia (illegible) by the State of Massachusetts to and in the War of the Revolution. The company marched from Rochester to Roxbury the first day of May 1775 and remained there in service till first day of January 1776. Where the company was dismissed. The officers were Cecil Class, captain who is still living in the state of Connecticut, Isaac Pope and Charles Church (illegible) who are both dead. Job Haskell, then and still of said Rochester, was a member of service company marched from Rochester till he was dismissed at the expiration of the term for which it was received at Roxbury as I believe. I do not remember now seeing (illegible) the day the company were dismissed but I have no reason to doubt that he remained till the day of discharge. I have been his neighbor (illegible) the (illegible) meeting with him for more than fifty years. The term of service was eight months. Gideon Hammond Commonwealth of Massachusetts Plymouth Cty. Nov 6 1833 Gideon Hammond personally appeared and made oath to the truth of the foregoing deposition by him subscribed before me, the undersigned; and I hereby certify that I am personally acquainted with said deposant, and think he is of good character for truth and (illegible) to credit. Charles J. Holmes, (illegible)

Conisus[Consesus] August 29th 1837 Mr. Edward sir wishing you good health and all the prosperity nessesry [necessary] in your important station. Dear Sir neceessety[necessity] urges me to write it line to your honour I just remark as to any further informa in regard to my pension matter is beyond my power I would just notice that if I have not forgot that one of my witnesses stated that he was knowing to my being in the service as a soldier in the year 1776 it has bin[been] much fategue[fatigue] and some cost to me it has bin[been] on the anvil year after year year after year till my hair is gray if I had as much patience as Job had I should have more than I got now the pension act was a beneveloent act that was established by Congress and has bin a help to many but as it respects me as an indivual if after all my trouble I should loose my claim to which I sincerely feel that I have a just right by the acts of Congress it had been better for me if the act had never been payed it would only be adding hardship and Cost to revolutionary hardships I cannot help having some feelings in the matter but I wish to be governed by reason honourd sir I hope you have not forgot your unworthy friend and as my age tells me in connection with superior historicle[historical] evidence that I must soon leave this world of traffic and go where money will do me No good I want to settle the concerns of time before I go I Doe[do] sincerely wish Sir that your honour would think of me and attend to the matter as soon as you can Conveniently that I may fairly meet my concerns I am Sir yours with due respects Thaddeus Gage N.B. as I have imployed[employed] Colonel Woodruff Esq worthy Gentleman of Note I doe[do] not mean by this to take the business out of his hands but to Express my feelings with a Desire for to have the matter forwarded

Banks Wm Pope Warrick Miller John Jones State of Kentucky Jefferson County Sct On this 22nd day of May 1838 personally appeared in open court being a circuit court for the Jefferson Circuit in said state Nancy N Cox aged

about seventy two years, a resident of Jefferson County and state aforesaid, who being first duly sworn according to law deposes and says that she is well acquainted with John Hughes who has made the foregoing declaration. That she knows said Hughes was at the Academy in Hanover County, Virginia and that he left said Academy and served the Army of the Revolution. That she well recollects that sd. Hughes was with the Army at the Battle of Guilford Courthouse and in the engagement at Petersburg Virginia and at York Town when Cornwallis & his army army were taken but she cannot recollect how long he served or the years. She can only recollect when said Hughes served in the Light Infantry in the winter of 1780-1. She recollects that a report reached home that said Hughes had received a wound in the knee at the siege of York. Sworn to and subscribed on the day and year aforesaid Nancy N Cox And the said court do hereby declare their opinion after the investigation of the matter, and after putting the interrogatories prescribed by the War Department, that the above named applicant was a Revolutionary soldier, and served as he states. [Trappe] Sept 14 1841 Jacob Fry [illegible] Esq. Sir Your letter of the 8th inst is before me, I have examined our church records with great care, & can find no entry therein of the marriage of Frederic Hoyd to Elizabeth Miller, the records of our congregation though apparently kept with care are deficient for a period of time, viz from 1774 & 7 to 1790- There is no marriage recorded from December 1774 to 1790- there is no death recorded from November 1777 to 1790, & no baptism recorded between the same last two periods. From 1790 forward there is a record. Why no record was kept within the period mentioned. I am at a loss to know. Father Muhlenberg was then Pastor of this congregation & this was the place of his residence, at the time- long before & long after the period that this marriage took place, whether the outbreak of the revolutionary war, or what occasioned this deficiency I have never been able to ascertain, though I have made frequent attempts, in order to fill up this deficiency & of time. I have come to the conclusion that there is no record extant, for that period- As to the age of Mrs. Hoyd I find the following that on the 5th June 1774 there were seventeen persons admitted as members, by the rite of confirmation,

State of Pennsylvania Huntingdon County, SS. On this twenty fifth day of March A. D. eighteen hundred and forty, personally appeared before me the subscriber, one of the associate Judges of the Court of Common pleas of the County of Huntingdon and State of Pennsylvania aforesaid (said court being a court of records) Margaret Claubaugh, a resident of the borough of Huntingdon in the County and state aforesaid, aged about eighty eight years, who being duly sworn according to law, doth on her oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the provision made by the act of Congress, passed July 4th A.D. 1836: That she is the widow of Martin Claubaugh, deceased, who at the time of his death was a pensioner of the United States for services rendered as a soldier in the revolutionary war - That the documents on which the claim of her said husband was predicated, and on which a pension was granted to him in his lifetime, and which contain a detailed statement of his services, and of the capacity in which he served in war of the Revolution, are, as she understands, in the proper office at Washington city, to which she begs leave to refer the Honourable the Secretary of War or Commissioners Pensions for the facts as to his services in the Revolutionary army. She further declares that she was married to the said Martin Claubaugh as near as she can recollect, about the year 1772 (having been married when she was about twenty years of age, and being now as near she can till about eighty eight years) by the Rev. Mr. Young, then paster of the Evangelical Lutheran Congregations of Hagerstown, and of Funkstown, Maryland: that her husband the said Martin Claubaugh died on the 15th day of July in the year A.D. 1822; and that she has remained a widow ever since that period, as will [illegible] fully appear by reference to the papers hereunto annexed. That she has no certificate or family record of her marriage; that she well recollects that when she and her said late husband removed from Maryland to the borough of Huntingdon, where she now lives, about the year 1801 or 1802, they endeavoured to procure a certificate from the Pastor of the before mentioned congregations of their marriage and of the baptisms of their children, and that they were told that the was no record, or that the church book was lost. That there is no person now living that deponent

management, or other cause, neither of them succeeded then in getting their pensions. She has heard that her husband enlisted in the army at a very early age (she thinks at the age of 16 years) and that he served throughout a greater part of the war. She recollects mention having been made of his great sickness and distress in [crossed out] [caret] a hospital in some town or city; She can swear positively to having seen large and distinct marks of wounds or bruises on each of her husband’s hips; she has heard that he deserted his father’s house when a boy to fight and suffer for his country; one night, having in company with some 30 men, (she believes a scouting party) taken shelter from the night in the second story of an old house on the road [?], the party were that night attacked by a company of British or Tories, and her husband narrowly escaped with his life, after [crossed out word] refusing to stop when called, and was shot at as he fled. Being in the Battle of Eutaw Springs, he narrowly escaped in a retreat. It appears from what this declarent has heard, that at the time of that battle Gen. Green rode a fine horse which being a present from his father or some other distinguished individual, he highly prized; and fearing the horse might be shot in the engagement, he called to Samuel Williams and said “here my little soldier [crossed out word]mount this horse and escape for your life” and then the General after having given some hasty directions as to his horse, plunged again into battle. She remembers to have heard that her husband was present when the gallant DeKalb fell; and also in some engagement where a sarjeant [sic] [sergeant] hovered over that [crossed out letter] individual, and cried aloud, Save the brave DeKalb. She has also heard her

He was born when deponent was about seven or eight years old and said John Adam Weaver was then out in the War and deponents’s fathers. & family were absent from that neighborhood about five or six years when he moved back into the same neighborhood but about two or three miles from when they lived before said John Adam Weaver had then returned from the War and was living in one of the Rooms of his father’s house. Deponent cannot recollect whether Elizabeth his oldest child was born at this time or not, said John was then living with his wife Ann Maria Weaver and was married to her by a Preacher by the name of Deckert as said John and his wife frequently told deponent the same Preacher married this deponent. there was no record of marriages kept in the parish at that time of People wanted to get married they just went to the Preacher and were married and it was all over- Mr Deckert was the first minister of that Parish or society but he has been dead a good many years- after deponent’s father’s family moved back to the neighborhood they attended the same church which was in a School house that said John Weaver and his father’s family Enoch Weaver did for many years and deponent frequently called at said Weavers in passing to church what makes deponent recollect more about said John of his marriage was that said John’s first child Elizabeth was born to soon after their marriage but said John Weaver always admitted it to be his child but rather intimated he was partly compelled to marry on that account This i based from subsequent conversation when he

in New London Bedford County commanded by Capt. Thomas Leftwich in in the service of the United States and was appointed Orderly Sergiant [Sergeant] of the same and marched to Hillsborough in North Carolina the genl. rendezvous of the Virginia Militia in that campaign where the troops were reorganized into regiments which formed a brigade commanded by Genl. Stevens and Capt. Leftwich, company was attached to A Regt., the number of which he does not recollect but was commanded by Col. Stubblefield or [illegible] a part of the brigade the militia commenced their march for the Southern Ferry about the last of July or first of Augst. and joined the Regular Army at Rugeley's Mills in South Carolina about two days before Gate’s defeat near Camden (where he had the misfortune to witness the most shameful and disastrous battle that occurred during the Revolutionary War the whole of the Ordinance Military Store and Baggage being taken by the enemy. The American Army apparently being struck with despair were consequently routed and [illegible] to fight after which the militia retreated in a scattered and irregular manner in squads and detachments to Hillsborough the original rendezvous where they ginerlly [generally] joined there respective companies and regiments as considerable remember continue their retreat untill [until] they got [illegible] the Militia being partially reorganized were destitute of all kind of Camp Equipage except their arms and accoutrements and frequently without provision and such was the general distress and privation that the Troops [illegible] in on [illegible] income. He states that every man belonging to Capt. Leftwich’s company except the commissioned officer’s one Sergeant one Private and himself deserted. The commissioned officers consequentially became [illegible] and were discharged and the other Sergeant, Private, and himself were attached to Capt. [illegible]’s Company of the same Regt, shortly after which the troops marched to New Garden where they were several weeks. In the mean time Col. James Callaway commanding the militia in Bedford County took effective measures to collect the deserters from that County and sent them on to camp with a commission for Joel Leftwich Orderly Sergeant of Capt. Thomas Leftwich late Company of Militia in the United States service then a deputed Captain to take command of them but the Commanding Genl. did not think proper to [illegible] to serve the remainder of the tour as common Militia and they were sent home in order to be reorganized and to serve eight months [illegible] to the regulation of the law at that time relative to militia [illegible] he states that he continued regularly as [illegible] untill [until] about the last of October or first of November but when his term of service having expired he was Honorably Discharged in North Carolina the name of the place he does not recollect neither does he at present know whether his discharge was signed by the Genl, or Col. having been lost many years. He further states that some time in February 1781 he Contracted with John Hook a merchant of Bedford County to serve A Tour of duty for him as a substitute in Company of Militia in the Service of the United States under the Command of Capt. Bowen Price then stationed at New Garden Bedford County and was appointed Orderly Sergeant of said Company which was shortly after attached to a Regt. of Militia commanded by Col. Chaerls [Charles] Lynch of Bedford which marched immediately for North Carolina. After a few days march Lieutenant John Forqueran who was attached to Capt. Price’s company was taken sick and unfit for duty and either resigned in commission or was discharged. [illegible] having ordered in the [illegible] he states that neither Which

I hereby certify that Genl. Joel Leftwich of this County was attached to a company of Militia in the service of the United States commanded by Captain Thomas Leftwich of the County of Bedford of which company I was a soldier and that we marched from said County some time in the month of May of the year 1780 to Hillsborough in the State of North Carolina where the militia was organized into Regiments which formed Brigade commanded by Genl. Stevens; and the regiment to which Capt. Leftwich’s company was attached to was commanded by Col. Stubblefield and Spencer at which place the Brigade was stationed 5 or 6 weeks; and from there marched to South Carolina and joined the Southern Army at Rudgeley’s Mills about 2 days before Genl. Gates’ defeat near Camden; where he participated in the misfortune of the day after which the Militia returned in a scattering and irregular manner to Hillsborough the original place of rendezvous where they generally joined their respective companies; and such was the distress and frustration of the troops being wholy destitute of camp equipages and frequently without provisions that every man belonging to Capt. Leftwich’s company except the commissioned officers, sergeants of whom Genl. Leftwich was one and myself was attached to Captain Daniels’ Company when we continued unable

[Printed form, filled in with cursive] District of Massachusetts, ss: [Sirs:] On this Third day of July 1820; Personally appeared in open Court before the Circuit Court of Common Pleas, begun and holden at Lenox, within and for the County of Berkshire, in the Western Circuit, on the 4th Monday of June 1820, the same Court, being a Court of records for said Circuit; proceeding according to the course of the common Law, with a jurisdiction, unlimited in point of amount, keeping a record of its proceedings, and having the power of fine and imprisonment, Eliakim Hamilton aged Sixty four years, resident in Stockbridge in the County of Berkshire aforesaid, who being first duly sworn, according to law, doth on his oath declare that he served in the Revolutionary war as follows; that he enlisted in the company commanded by Captain Goodale in the regiment commanded by Colonel Joseph Vose in the line of the State of Massachusetts on the Continental establishment. That his original declaration is dated the 27th day of April Ad. 1818 and that his pension certificate is numbered 4,487. And I do solemnly swear, that I was a resident Citizen of the United States, on the 18th day of March, 1818, and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale or in any manner disposed of my property, or any part thereof with intent, thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an Act of Congress entitled "An Act to provide for certain persons, engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary war," passed on the 18th day of March, 1818, and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities, contracts or debts, due to me, nor have I any income, other than what is contained in the schedule, hereto annexed, and by me subscribed --schedule of property, necessary clothing and bedding excepted--to wit: Schedule of the State of Eliakim Hamilton of Stockbridge, County of Berkshire + [and] State of Massachusetts applicant for a Pension under the act of Congress of May 13 1820 House lot 1 1/2 acres at $30 per acre 45.00 House 350.00 Barn + [and] wood house, old 50.00 Mountain Wood Land 23 1/2 acres at $5.25 123.37 1 Horse 30- 1 Cow 12- 1 2 yr [year] old heifer 10- 1 yearling 4 1/2 an old waggon [sic] 9- 1/2 an old sleigh 3- 1/2 plough 1- [2 illegible words] Kettle 1.50 [ditto marks] Iron Kettle .75 2 small iron spiders .50 Iron tea kettle .50 1 pot 1- 1 broken iron kettle 1.50 Fine [illegible word] tongs .50 2 tables .50 6 chairs 1- 2 old shirts 1- [the rest is cut off]

State of New Jersey Somerset County ss Personally appeared before me Saml S Doty one of the Judges of the Inferior Court of Common pleas in and for said County John Brees who being duly sworn on his oath saith that he has been an Elder in the presbyterian Church [inserted, two words:] at Baskingridge for a long time [inserted, two words:[ fifteen years _is clerk of the session and has the papers & books belonging to the church session in his possession There are no records of Marriages among the books & papers & deponent does not believe any were kept untill the law of the State was passed in 1795 which requires the minister to keep a register and send certificates to the Clerk of the County. Johnson Clerk ------------------------------- 25,400 Claim of Elizabeth Smalley FOR A PENSION widow of Isaac Smalley ACT OF FEBRUARY 3, 1853. War of Revolution F.E. HASSLER, ATTORNEY Washington City, D.C. NOTES. 1. Which must be made before a judge of a court of record in open court, unless applicant is from bodily health unable to appear; it then can be made before the judge, who will certify to the fact of the disability to appear. 2. Must here state, whether a revolutionary soldier or officer, or pensioner, naming the State where the pension was paid or if the husband served and died in the service during any war since 1790 -- naming them thus: Wayne's, or Indian wars prior to 1800; War with Great Britain, 1812; Seminole War, 1817 and 1818; Black Hawk War, 1832; Florida War, 1835 to 1842; Cherokee and Creek Disturbances, 1836, &c.; Mexican War, 1846 to 1848; and giving the name of the Captain, Company, Regiment, and Colonel; and whether militia, volunteers, or regular army; and place of muster, discharge, or death. 7. Name of the minister, or justice of the peace; and if married in any State or county where any public records of marriages are kept the marriage should be proved by a duly certified copy of the record, or by the testimony of credible witnesses who were present at the marriage; and where such testimony exists, and is not produced, satisfactory reasons must be stated, under oath, why it is not produced; and, in all cases where record evidence of the testimony of witnesses who were present at the marriage could be procured and is not, the claim will be rejected, unless other testimony of a very full and satisfactory character is produced. If it is shown by affidavit that no record evidence or testimony of eye witnesses can be procured, the claimant may then produce the best other evidence in her power, such as the testimony of witnesses, who were acquainted with her and her husband during his lifetime, knew them to live together as man and wife, and that they were reputed so to be, and that the fact of their having been married was never called in question by their acquaintances. In no case, however, will the mere statement of the witnesses, that the claimant is the widow of the deceased, be taken as evidence of the marriage; but the witnesses must state the facts and circumstances from which they derive their knowledge or opinion that she is the widow of the deceased. A certificate from the clergyman or magistrate who solemnized the marriage is not competent evidence, unless the genuineness of the certificate be proved, and the person who gave it be shown to have been authorized to solemnize marriages. 9. This blank is left for the purpose of the applicant's stating whether any bounty land or pension has at any time been received by any one; if so, by whom, and when. 10. Naming the war. All records or copy of records must be attached to the original declaration by a tape the ends of which must pass under the seal of the court, in order to prevent the improper addition of any evidence after the papers have been duly executed and certified to by the judge and clerk. If the widow was re-married, all the facts of marriage and death of second husband must be proven. A probate court is the most convenient court in which to make these proofs. The law (3d February, 1853 ) grants pensions to the widows of revolutionary soldiers, without reference to date of marriage who served six months and over. as

deponent with others was marched down to the city of Albany on their way as was said to the Southern Army but this deponent from unusual hardship and fatigue was taken sick and unable to go any farther and was carried home to his residence at New Lebanon, where he remained untill the next Spring, on the recovery of his health he this deponent the next season again entered the service for the term of three months and was attached to a regiment commanded by Col's. Staats & Waterman and during this time performed the duty of Quarter Master of the said regiment, after the expiration of this last mentioned term he this deponent returned home. The next season this deponent again joined Capt Fitch's Company and went up the Mohawk river and through the woods towards Niagara in pursuit of the Indians and continued in the campaign as near as he can recollect about two months during which time he suffered the most severe hardships and privations and then returned home. The next Spring, in the month of April 1781 as near as this deponent can recollect he received a warrant from his Excellency George Clinton Esq. appointing him a Lieutenant in Colonel Marinus Willets regiment, that in pursuance of this appointment he raised his quota of men and joined the regiment at Johnstown in the State of New York and was attached to a company commanded by Captain Cannon, that he this deponent continued in the said regiment doing duty as a Lieutenant in the service of the United States about three years and untill the close of the Revolutionary War and was honorably discharged. And this deponent on his oath aforesaid further says that during the whole of the Revolutionary War

from the commencement untill the end of it, not a year elapsed, but what he was engaged more or less in the service of his country, and on some occasions suffered the most extreme hardships, privations and dangers, and that he was at all times as the affidavits hereto annexed will abundantly show a faithful and honest soldier. And this deponent further says that he made application to the Government for a pension under the act of March 18. 1818, and made a declaration which was sworn to by this deponent before Samuel Haring Esq. a Judge of the Court of Common Pleas of the county of Albany on the 20th day of April 1818, that his application was rejected at the War department for the reasons, as was alledged, that Col. Willets regiment did not belong to the Continental establishment, and this deponent on his oath aforesaid further says that he has applied to the Legislature of this State for a share of Bounty lands which he this deponent believes he is justly entitled to but has never received any, that a committee of the house of assembly on the 24. Feby 1818 reported (which where is hereto annexed) that he was justly entitled to one thousand acres and brought in a bill for that purpose, which however never became a law, and this deponent further says that he is wholly unable to support himself by labour in consequence of old age and disease that for a great number of years past he has been afflicted with a fever sore on his leg, which almost entirely cripples him and further that he has a wife who is also unable to labor and cannot support herself being 72 years of age. And this deponent further says that he has no property of any description whatsoever and both he and his wife are wholly and entirely dependant on their children and the Hon. Stephen Van Renselaer for their daily support, and further that was

duly commissioned & qualified that I am well acquainted with his handwriting and have no doubt that the signed here subscribed to the certificate of the oath of the deponent is genuine - The testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand & affixed the seal of said Court of Probate this first day of May in the year of our Lord Eighteen hundred & thirty seven. Henry W Bishop. Register Probate

The first engagement we had was at Brattons or Williams lane as Greenhaw say in his history after there to Rocky Mount where we did not succeed as we did at Williams (for this we killed and nearly all with [illegible] body After the Rocky Mount engagement we were called to Congaree river and fought our way as well as we could) had an engagement near Monks Corner but had to retreat Before the close of the war we were stationed in that low country in the hot summer months the fall season we had the battle at Blackstocks where our Gen was wounded I myself was there and suffer much fatigue Now Mr. Edwards informs me that our raids when were stationed should be mentioned We traveled so much and st[?] at places 100 miles from home that it would be difficult to acertain the times and places familiar we confide much in your [discretion?] and willingness to help a pensioner in distress

No man can guess or have any idea of my distress My companion in a low state of health, myself not able to walk half a mile. My daughter reduced with hardships I am sunk in debt by reason of hard times The pensions I now receive does not half support me If I can have any relief I will have a sergeants pay from this time forward and let Government refund for what I have lost in the years past I am now 86 years old laking a few days I will [illegible] Government but a short time

State of New York, Montgomery County} ss. Martin J. Stover of Palatine in said County being duly sworn saith that he is the present Minister and has the custody of the Records of Marriages and Baptisms of Trinity Church of Stone Arabia in Said County - That the record of marriages commences prior to the Revolutionary War and are continuous to the year after 1779 and subsequently - that the records of marriage for the same time previous to the War and with the year 1779 were made by the Rev'd. Mr. Ries who was then the minister of the said Church that from the year 1779 to the year 1790 there is no regular record of marriages in said church - that from the best information which this deponent has upon the subject the Rev'd. Mr. Ries towards the close of the War was absent from the said Church for some years when he returned and took charge thereof again and performed the duties of minister thereof. That after his return to the charge of the said church he as the deponent is informed kept a private record of the Marriages and Baptisms but which record was never delivered over by him to the Church, nor has it come to the possession of the Church to the knowledge or belief of this deponent. - And this deponent further saith that he has made particular search in said records for marriage entries therein from the year 1779 to the year 1790 and does not find any entries of marriages of that period. (signed) Martin J. Stover Subscribed and sworn to this 21st day of May 1842 before me Chas. Gray Judge + Counselor and I further certify I am personally acquainted with the Rev./Mr. (continued on page 18 of this record)

I David Crocker of Lebanon in the County of Grafton in the State of Newhampshire do depose and declare that I was born in Norwich in the State of Connecticut and that I am a citizen of the United States of America that in the month of February in the year of our Lord one thousand seventeen hundred and seventy six I enlisted as a private soldier [last four words inserted] in the Company of Captain Benjamin's Troop in the Regiment commanded by Colonel Burrell in (as I understood) the Connecticut line of the army of the United States, [several words crossed out] to serve for the time of one year, that I served in that capacity until sometime in the month of February the year 1777 when the term for which I had enlisted expired, I was dismissed from the army but received no written discharge - I further say that afterwards in the month of March in the year seventeen hundred and seventy eight I enlisted as a marine on board the continental ship Providence, commanded by Captain Abraham Whipple, to serve for six months. In April following we sailed for France charged with dispatches for Doct. Franklin the American Minister there, and arrived at France in May following on our return we brought back a Cargo of Arms ammunition & clothing for the American Government and we arrived in Boston in New England in the month of October following & soon afterwards I was discharged, having served on board, about eight months; but I received no written discharge: and I further say that no pension has heretofore been

Franklin Portage County Ohio March 17th, 1845 Dear Sir I have been applied to by the widow Janett Gaylord to try and procure for her a pension. My impression at first, was, that there were Some difficulties facts in the way of her procuring a pension from the records in the several acts of Congress relating to widows pensions, but from the construction of that act, and more particularly, the late act of Congress had removed those difficulties- As I know thereon some niceties required, I herein give you a sketch of her case, and ask you to let me know from the circumstances, any the evidence she can address, whether she can obtain a pension also please send me a copy of the regulations adopted by the Pension Office relating to the application for pensions. She can testify herself to the day any year of her marriage by whom the marriage ceremony was performed, and that she has never since been married. Her marriage, she thinks, was recorded in the church records, but not any other place, that that church is not any longer in existence, and can conceive of no one in that region (Massachusetts), who may be likely to have these records, even if they were yet in existence. She has the Revolutionary claim granted by the war department, in 1818, signed by J.C. Calhoun as Secretary of war numbered 3070, to her late husband, who it appears was a private in the Revolution, She is also able to prove by her neighbors here, that she was reputed to be his wife, that he so spoke of her and to her, and also prove the children the declarations of her husband, (some of her child are near 50 year of age that she was his wife, &c, but no family record has ever been kept by him, or any one else to her knowledge, and she knows of no record of the marriage, unless one was made by the officiating minister, and she cannot determine, whether it was usual for that church to keep a record of marriages or not, nor does she know of any one now living, that was present at the marriage, Now I know not what to the war department has adopted in regard to the evidences of marriage de facto, but would rather be of the opinion that she would be able to produce evidence that would come within the requirement of any reasonable rule though none other that I know of, than as express above. There is no doubt of her being the wife de facto, as well as de jursof the late John Gaylord, they have lived in this town several years ten, or more I think, and came from Massachusetts directly here with several of his children

State of Pennsylvania County of Lancaster On this 23rd day of April 1851 personally appeared before me a Justice of the Peace in and for said County William Bishop aged Seventy five resident of Lancaster County Pennsylvania who being duly sworn according to Law declares and saith that he was well acquainted with John Musser deceased and Barbara his wife and that they were married near Elizabethtown Lancaster County at a Church called "Bishop Church" by Reverend Enterlein on the 5th day of May 1779 and that they lived and cohabitated together as man and wife and were reputed as such and the said John Musser died January 1st 1827 near Elizabethtown Lancaster County Pennsylvania and as his wife Barbara survived him until the year 1840 the 13th day of November and further that she died on the 13th day of November 13th 1840 and further that he knew that the said and further that I knew that the said John Musser was a soldier and an Officer in the Revolutionary War and that he often seen the said Musser in the service and in the Revolutionary War and that he is confident that the said Musser served in the Revolutionary War two years or upward in the service of the U.S. in the Revolution and that Adam Musser, Samuel Musser, Barbara Seltzer wife of George Seltzer and Rebecca Musser are the only heirs and Children and legal Representatives of John Musser and Barbara deceased. William Bishop [seal] Sworn & Subscribed the 23 day of April 1851 Before me David May

334 Pension office May 28, 1852 Sir In reply to your inquiry you are informed that of Barbara Musser was married on 1779, as alleged, a certified copy of the Record from the Books of "Bishop's Church", on where it is stated the rites were performed [unreadable] I sent to this office with the new declaration your [unreadable] of the error could not be received as testimony. And May I [unreadable] pray to remind you that the regulations [unreadable] must be [unreadable] adhered to to hath this office to make a satisfactory examination of the claim. W. S. Amweg Esq Lancaster Pa
