I Patience Gould of Norwich in the County of Windsor of the age of thirty three years testify and say, that I have labored for my father & mother fifteen years since I was eighteen years of age. During what time my father has clothed me and paid me towards my services the following [illegible] of property - one horse valued at forty dollars, one cow valued at thirteen dollars, one two year old heifer valued at seven dollars, and two calves valued at six dollars. Making in all the sum of sixty nine dollars. I further depose and say that for three years of the above time my mother was unable to do any work at all, and my father has been unwell for a great part of the aforesaid time, and not able to do but little work. I further depose and say that the usual price of womens labor has been for fifteen years past from sixty seven cents to eighty three cents per week. And further this deponent saith not. Patience Gould Subscribed and sworn to before me this 29th day of May AD 1828. Ethan Bernap} Just Peace I certify that the above named Patience Gould is a credible witness. Ethan Bernap} Just Peace

State of New York} Clinton County ss} We John Martin a Clergyman residing in Hemmingford Lower Canada near the Canada line and in the neighborhood of Ephraim Goodsell and Roger Robinson residing in the same place hereby certify that we are well acquainted with Ephraim Goodsell who is making an application for a Pension under the act of Congress of the U.S of June 7th 1832 that we believe him to be Seventy two years of age that he is reputed and believed in the neighborhood where he resides to have been a soldier of the Revolution and that we concur in that opinion John Martin Minister. Sworn and subscribed to before me this 17th day of July 1833 at Moores in said County, and I certify that it appears to me that John Martin who has signed the proceeding certificate as a Clergyman resident in Hemmingford Lower Canada and that Roger Robinson who has also signed the same is a resident in the same town is credible person and that their statements is entitled to full credit. Roger Robson Capt Wm Shurtliff, Justice of the Peace

I Terlius Reynolds of Fairfax in the County of Franklin & State of Vermont, of the age of forty five years do testify and say that at the request of John P. Hunt of this place, I attended, and officiated at the Funeral Services of his mother the widow Elizabeth Grosvenor formerly the widow of Joseph Hunt deceased. The Funeral exercises were attended at the dwelling house of Joseph Hunt Esqr son of the deceased on Sabbath the 29th day of August AD 1841. I the deponent further testify and say that I have examined a record of the Death Mrs Grosvenor formerly the widow Hunt made by William Grosvenor in his family Bible at the time of her death, which is there recorded to be on the 27th day of August 1841. Further the deponent saith not. Terlius Reynolds State of Vermont Franklin County ss Fairfax Jany 17th 1846 Then Terlius Reynolds personally appeared, and after being carefully examined and duly cautioned, made solemn oath that the foregoing Deposition by him subscribed, contains the whole truth & nothing but the truth before me Joseph Parmelee Just Peace This may certify that the Rev Terlius Reynolds is a Minister of the Congregational order in regular standing [illegible] Joseph Parmelee Just Peace

I, John W. Cuningham Prothonotary of the Court of Common Pleas of the County of Chester in the State of Pennsylvania do hereby certify that the foregoing contains the original proceedings in the matter of the application of Peter Fry for a pension. In testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand and seal of office this twenty first day of August Anno Domini 1833 John W Cuningham Prot Chester County We the undersigned citizens of Chester County have been these several years past intimately acquainted with Peter Fry or Frey or Freery formerly of Berks County Pa and we do think that his statement relative to his age and revolutionary services is correct: -We entertain no doubt and we do not know that any one entertains the smallest doubt who is acquainted with the above named applicant that he was a revolutionary soldier:- To the above We have deposed before David Crosby Esq as witness our hands and seals this thirteenth day of May A.D. 1833 Rev Hobert White seal Wm Carlisle seal I do hereby certify that one of the above named witnesses appearing before me is the Rev Holbert White who has been there more than twenty years, Pastor of the Church of Fagg Manor, the other Mr. William Carlisle is a respectable member of the Presbyterian Church at New London y. Woods Chester County Pa as witness my hand and seal this Thirteenth day of May A.D. 1833 D Crosby Seal

Declaration of a widow who has NEVER HAD a Land Warrant State of Connecticut COUNTY OF Tolland ss On this fifth day of April A. D. one thousand eight hundred and 55 personally appeared before me, a Justice of the Peace within and for the County and State aforesaid, Alice Anderson aged Eighty Six years, a resident of Wellington in the State of Connecticut who, being duly sworn according to law, declares that she is the widow of Thomas Anderson deceased, who was a Revolutionary Soldier in the Company commanded by Captain Thomas Knowlton, at Bunker Hill in 1775 about five months, in the —Regiment of —---commanded by — in the Revolutionary War and was there honorable discharged and that I Alice Anderson am getting a pension for the above Sevce. that her said husband Vollentured or Enlisted at Window Connecticut on or about the twentieth day of May or June A. D. 1875, for the term of about five Months and continued in actual service in said war for the term of five months and was honorably discharged at —--- on the — day of – A. D. 1775; but that to the best of her knowledge and belief, her husband never received any written or printed discharge, the said Alice Anderson has not recieved a Land Warrent nor maid plication for a Warrent hereto before. She further states that she was married to the said Thomas Anderson in Willington on the 23 day of February A. D. 1929, by one David Lillibridge a Clergyman, and that her name before her said marriage was Alice Whitmore; that her said husband died at Willington on the 30 day of March A. D. 1835, and that she is now a widow. She makes this declaration for the purpose of obtaining the bounty land to which she may be entitled under the “Act approved March 3, 1855,” and prays that the certificate thereof may be sent for her to Jeremiah Bishop Moose Meadow Conn.; and declares that she has not received a Bounty Land Warrant under this or any act of Congress, nor made any other application therefor. Alice Anderson

field in the County of Litchfield on the 7th day of March 1757; That after the establishment of our present happy and independent government, he entered into the ministerial service, and was the first person ordained in America by Bishop Seabury, in the city of Middletown, on the 3d day of August 1785; That he settled in his native town of Litchfield, and performed clerical services in said town until November 1792; when by the advice of his friends and physicians he removed, on account of the ill health of his family, he removed to the town of Stratford in Connecticut and took the rectorship of Christ's Church in said town, and continued in that station until the year 1825, when he resigned his care in that place, and officiated in the vacant parishes in the state, until his removal to Oxford, where he continued his services in the Church until the year 1832, when he was deprived by sickness from performing any more duties excepting those of patience and resignation to the will of his Heavenly Father. Ashbel Baldwin

Collections Office New Haven Decr 19th 1835 Sir I am induced from a long and personal acquaintance with Revd Ashbel Baldwin who this day forwarded to the War Department through Senator Tomlinson an application for a Pension to say a few words to you respecting the character and standing of that numerable & faithful minister of the gospel. I have known him from my earliest recollection, & his character stands [illegible] & untarnished for holiness of heart and rectitude of life. He is the oldest and was the first ordained Episcopal clergyman in Connecticut and though his advanced age has wrought [illegible] and impaired his bodily health still his intellectual faculties, his mind, appears good. I think there can be no doubt on the correctness of his statement for I know him to well not to know that he would rather fall short than to go beyond a true statement of his services. I sincerely hope he may be a successful applicant for his pension. I am very Respectfully Sir Your obedient servant Wm. H. Ellis Collector James L. Edwards Esq.

Original Claim Declaration in Order to be placed on the Pension List, under the Act of the 18th March 1818 District of Laurens SS. — Richard Butler on this twenty third day of March 1830 personally appeared in open Court, being a Court of record for the district of Laurens resident in said District aged Eighty years, who being first duly sworn according to Law, doth on his oath, make the following declaration in order to obtain the provision made by the Acts of Congress of the 18th March 1818, & the 1st of May 1820; that he the said Richard Butler enlisted for the term of three years or during the War on the fifteenth day of October in the year 1776 in the State of Maryland, in the Company commanded by Captain Clicket, in the regiment Commanded by Colonel Gunby in the line of the State of Maryland on the Continental establishment, that he continued to Serve in the said Corps until about three days after the battle of Guilford C.H., when he was discharged from the Service in Guilford County in the State of North Carolina, that he hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension except the present, that his name is not on the Roll of any State — and that the following are the reasons for not making earlier application for a pension. The despondent did make application through Gen’l Casey many years ago who died while in Congress and that about five years ago he applied through Gen’l. Tucker & so far as his public means allowed him he has been incessant in his applications. And in pursuance of the Act of the 1st May 1820, I do solemnly Swear that I was a resident Citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March 1818, and that I have not since that time, by Gift Sale or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an Act of Congress entitled “An Act to provide for Certain persons engaged in the Land and Naval Service in the United States in the Revolutionary War” passed on the 18th day of March 1818; and that I have not nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities contracts or debts due to me; nor have I any income or property whatsoever. That since the 18th of

Lancaster City ss. On this 27th day of May AD 1841 Personally appeared before John Findley Recorder of the Mayor's Court of the city of Lancaster. George Leonard of the city of Lancaster, a soldier of the Revolution who being first sworn according to law says that he was well acquainted with and had a personal knowledge of the military service performed in the war of the Revolution by Peter Bruner of the City of Lancaster-They are as follows viz: That in the year 1777 or 8 the despondent was drafted out of Captain John Ewings Company and our Colonel was George Ross of the Borough (now city) of Lancaster. I was drafted for two months encampment-at the same time and place the said Peter Bruner was drafted for two months encampment out of the same company which I was-and stood guard at the Lancaster Barracks and stockades, at this time the British prisoners of war of the 26 and 27th Regiment and Hessians where guarded-he served out his tour when he was regularly discharge_ The same year ( 1778) he was again drafted for two months encampment out of John Ewings Company commanded by Colonel George Ross-and stood guard at the Lancaster Barracks, Powder house and store house when he was regularly discharged from the service- To the best of declarants recollection in the year (1779) at said town of Lancaster (now city) the said Peter Bruner was again drafted for two months encampment under the same officers as above mentioned-his services where the same as above mentioned-that he drew his rations in the said town of Lancaster for said two months when he was regularly discharged- Sworn to & subscribed the year and date above mentioned before. JK Findlay Recorder George Leonard his mark

Suttertoh JP And I the said C, Suttertoh hereby certify that Thomas Steel whose signature appears to the foregoing deposition is a resident of Chatham County and is a credible person and that his statement is entitled to credit given under my hand the day and date above written C, Luttertoh

State of North Carolina Chatham County Personally appeared before undersigned a Justice of the Peace in and for the County and State aforesaid Bias Rogers aged 78 years who after being duly sworn according to law depurate and sayeth that during the was of the Revolution he served in Chatham County and was well acquainted with Joseph Hackney of said county that he frequently mustered under said Hackney who was acting as a Captain in the Militia at that then that he understood and believed that Captain Hackney was often in actual service in the war of the Revolution this despondent was in the service with him. State of Pennsylvania } County of Schuylkill } ss Personally appeared before me a Justice of the Peace in and for this said county of Schuylkill Henry Kremer of full age who being duly sworn says he will be eighty one ;years old this 28th day of June next if he lives to that time That he was born in Berry’s County but which is now in Schuylkill county Pennsylvania and at a place with about two miles form where there is now a village a place called Friedensburg and which is tow or three miles from Schuylkill Haven in said county of Schuylkill Despondent states that he was acquainted with John Weaver sometimes and frequently call John Ada Weave r which was his full name but he was called & known by both names. That deponent was born and raised with about one & half mile of where said John Adam Weaver’s father lived & where said John Weaver lived before he went into the War and where he lived after he came back from the war- The said John Adam Weaver fathers name was Enoch Weaver. Deponent cannot say positive as to the services of said John Weaver in the Revolutionary War or the Regiment he was in but he well remembers this that said John Adam Weaver was missing from the neighborhood two or three years or more that his deponent father’s family and the neighbors all said he had gone to the war to stay to the end of it and it was a common talk in the neighborhood of his being out in the War while he was absent and after his return- Deponent remembers that his deponent father moved from the neighborhood when

I Apollos Paddock Woodstock in the County of Windsor and State of Vermont of lawful age do testify and say that in the year 1776 I was acquainted with Mr. John Perkins then of Middlebrough in the County of Plymouth and State of Massachusetts that he enlisted in the month of April into Capt Joshua Pensons Company in Col. John Cottons Regiment in the Massachusetts Line that I saw him in the service at Roxbury and that he served in said Regiment and the term of Eight months and this And I further testify and say that in the month of April in the year 1779 the said John Perkins entered on board of the Ship Warren in the United State service in the expedition to Penobscot and that he was gone as near as I can recollect the turn of four months and further this despondent saith not Apollos Paddock State of Vermont, Windsor Count At Bernard in said County this 2 day of August 1832 Personally appeared Apollos Paddock signer of the above deposition and made oath to the truth of the same before me Calvin Greene Justin Peace State of Vermont, Windsor County Woodstock County Clerks Office 14 August 1832 I Benjamin Swan Clerk of Windsor County Court do hereby certify that Calvin Greene is one of the Justices of the Peace within for said County Court Do hereby certify that Calvin Prence is one of the Justice of the peace written for said county, and that the above is his signature. In Testimony whereof thereto affix the Seal of said County subscribe my name the day year last above Benja Swan

South Carolina Pickens District Mrs Elizabeth Johnston who is a highly respectable and intelligent old lady and citizen of the District aforesaid appears personally before me and made oath in the form of law that she resided many years ago in Marlborough District in this State and then and there knew Stafford Graham and his wife Elizabeth Graham that despondent moved from that district fifty two years ago last March and had known them for the last five of six years previous to her removal; that she lived some there or four miles distance from them but knew them pretty well as she done some weaving for Mrs Graham at the time of deponent first acquaintance with (illegal) the old lady had either two or three children who were older than her own and the eldest is sixty three the 22nd day of February

Secondly The applicant swore she was married in 1778. She stated that "he entered the service very soon after their marriage" see her declaration of April 1848. In corroboration to this statement believe can be found an affidavit of Sammuel Albertson a respectable and truthful citizen who swears that he has known Mrs Graham and husband for upwards of fifty years that thue had a good many children, that their daughter Elizabeth was three months older than despondent and she Elizabeth was their second child and he the deponent is 66 years old on the 27th June last i e in 1847. Mrs Elizabeth Johnson a highly respectable and intelligent old lady swears that she moved from the neighborhood of their residence fifty two years ago last March and had known them for five or six years previous to her removal At that time the had either two or three children who were older than her own and that her oldest is 63 years the 22nd February last i e 1849. The old lady was induced to accept a pension under Act of 7th July 1838 on account of extreme necessity see her statement of 11th May 1849

this despondent was then ordered with half of his company to (illegible) back to the house under a concealment of a orchard while the rest were to attack in front - this despondent company were the first who took possession of the same house in front leaving (illegible) a retreat to draw out the tories which according by succeeded twenty on were killed seven at the house and fourteen at the place where they kept the horses the tories having fled there - to where they were (illegible) the banks of Deep River - and where Colonel Dugan himself had gone with our Lieutenant to surprise them if they (illegible) be driven from the house then marched down the cape fear or fire tower from there to the Brown Marsh near Wilmington where they were again had a battle with the tories on the ground they there again defeated the tories who being reinforced by the British from their shipping at fort Johnson returned and defeated us in (illegible) from thence they the Americans returned by Cape Fear (or fair tour) to Salisbury now Randolph at this time they were out three months and were discharged - soon after this the tories gathered and took Hillsborough where this despondent and his company were again ordered out - this despondent having been elected on the very next day after his return home from his first service as Captain one Woods being his Captain for the same - then Johnes was his Lieutenant William Brown his Sargeant they then marched down to Hillsborough and joined with the Orange - (illegible) the tories and rescuing Govenor Bruck this he believes was in the fall of the year but is not certain they marched to Cane Creek there attacked the tories- at which time John Litteral who acting as Colonel was killed- and numbers of our men they were defeated + returned after a short time to

State of Alabama St Clair County On this seventh day of November personally appeared in open court before the honorable Judge of the circuit court of St Clair County now sitting Edward Beason a resident of said St Clair County and State aforesaid aged between seventy and eighty years of age and as he supposes about sixty six who being first duly sworn according to law doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the act of congress paper June the seventh eighteen hundred and thirty two - that he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers and served as herein stated he entered as a volunteer from the State of North Carolina Guilford County now Randolph it was in the Spring of the year seventeen hundred and seventy eight as he believes David Brower was his Captain James Moore Lieutenant this despondent ensigns and sergeant Robert Mc Gear was their major- the Thomas Dugan Colonel- Butler General their object was the (illegible) of the tories- next day after they left Thomasville their place of Richard - their Captain and three men were killed by the tories who way laid them- the tories were commanded by Major Rains and fired on them from a hill on the side of Branch Creek after Bower was killed - Woods became Captain + (illegible) Lieutenant - they pursued the tories some forty miles to the creek and there besieged them in a Louise belonging to one John Heedhan - in the morning before they put to Newhaven - their Colonel (Dugan) joined their

Goodrich Justice of the Peace I the undersigned justice of the heare do certify that on this 15th day of September 1832 the above named Jeremiah Smith at the said town of Davenport signed and swore before me to the above deposition that I am acquainted with the said Jeremiah Smith and that he is a reputable person and entitled to credit and belief Dated this 15th day of September 1832 J. A. Goodrich Justice of the Peace

The State of Indiana Franklin County JP Be it remembered that on the seventh day of November one thousand eight hundred and twenty three, before me Henry Jenkinson a Justice of the Peace in and for the County aforesaid personally came John Masters a Revolutionary Soldier and after being duly sworn deposeth and saith, that some time about the years one thousand seven hundred and seventy eight or nine that he said despondent did enlist in the service of the United States under the command of Captain Lovely near Petersburg in Virginia, and afterwards he was transferred under the command of Captain Wilson of the third regiment of the Virginia lines which was commanded by Cors Green and Haws, who was commanded by Genl Green; and this deponent saith that at the battle of Utaw Springs that Capt Wilson was killed, after which Capt. Coward took command of said company, and at the close of the war that he this said deponent received his discharge from Major Sneed, and the deponent further saith that at the time he entered the service of the United States that he was promised one hundred and sixty acres of land, which land he never received nor no vouchers to secure said land and pursuant to an Act of Congress approved march first one thousand eight hundred and twenty three he this said deponent believes he is entitled to a warrant to secure said land in Military lands lying between the Little Miamis River and the Scioto River there to be located as other continental rights are, and further saith not. Sworn and subscribed to before me the day and year first above written. John Masters his mark X Henry Jenkinson Justice of the Peace [seal] State of Indiana Franklin County jp Enoch McCarty Clerk of the Franklin Circuit Court for the county afd do hereby certify that Henry Jenkin Esquire before whom the foregoing affidavit was made was at that time and still is an acting Justice of the peace within and for the county afd duly commissioned and sworn into office, and full faith and credit are due to all his

City County and State of New York J.S. Abraham Leggett of said city being duly sworn doth depose and say that he was an Officer in the Revolutionary War, That he knew Abner Everitt deceased-That said Everitt was a Lieutenant in the same war in the year One thousand and Seven hundred and seventy six-that the said Everitt was taken prisoner at the Capture of Fort Washington in the state of New York. That the said Everitt after his capture at Fort Washington while on parole to wit in the year One thousand and seven hundred and seventy nine was married to Susannah Leggett a sister of this despondent and they lived together as man and wife until his death, having had eight children three of whom are no living-And that the said Susannah is now living in Belvidere Warren County State of New Jersey and is aged about Seventy nine years. And further that the said Abner and Susannah Everitt were married by the Reverend Mr. VanSicleren of Flatbush Long Island in the state of New York as this despondent has always understood and verily believes- Abraham Leggett Sworn this 7th day of September 1837 R. Rikes Recorder of the City of New York

cracked - One iron kettle - one chest without hinges - A few cups and saucers - Six pewter spoons - One bucket - One mare about eight years old - a yearling colt - One Cow - one calf, one heifer - one sow and eleven shoats - One plow - one pair of old plow gears - six sheep - two axes, one old - Three hoes and one old mattick (signed) Zadoc Morris That since the exhibition of my first schedule, the following changes have been made in my property, towit - Two cows died - sold three calves - sold four heifers, one mare dead - That the cattle as above stated as being sold, I sold to my son Richard Morriss after they were taken in execution by a constable in order to pay a debt for which I was sued - I have no trade or occupation, the only means I have of subsisting is on my land which is poor indeed -- my wife Elizabeth, who is now upwards of fifty five years of age, lives with me, she is very infirm and decreped [decrepit] and also my daughter Elizabeth lives with me she is about fifteen years of age, she is subject to fits, and deran-ged mind, she can aid in no way whatever to her own support and requires almost constant watching and attention -- I am an invalid myself, my knee was so seriously injured by the falling of a tree, upwards of twenty years ago, as to be ever since stiff, and has decayed away, leaving but very little strength in that limb - I am myself subject to the distressing and awful disease of fits or falling sickness, which together with my age and injury, renders me almost incapable of providing for my wife and child (the only persons that now live with me) with bread sufficient to supply the want of nature - I am indeed a poor distressed and afflicted human being - my time must soon draw to a close. a few years cannot pass without the bounty of my neighbours for an entire support, without the aid of that Goverment, which I strove with thousands of others through innumerable privations and difficulties to establish (signed) Zadoc Morris

State of Ohio Jefferson County ss. Court of Common pleas. In the Matter of Cornelius Tollon a Revolutionary pensioner} Be it remembered that at the August Term of this Court in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred & twenty comes Cornelius Tollon of said County of Jefferson & files a Declaration of his services &c in the words & figures following to wit- On the 25th day of August A.D. 1820. personally appeared in open Court being a Court of Record for the said County Cornelius Tollon aged sixty nine years resident in said County, who being first duly sworn according to law doth on his oath declare, that he served in the Revolutionary war as follows, to wit, In Captain Caleb Norths Company in the Regiment commanded by Colonel Anthony Wayne, Fourth Battaltions [battalion] of Pennsylvania line, he has received a pension certificate from the Government of the United States the number of which is 12.369. the date of his original Declaration was the 10th day of July 1818. And I do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March 1818. and that I have not since that time by gift sale or in any manner dispose of my property or any part thereof with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress entitled an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land & navel service of the United States in the Revolutionary war passed on the 18th day of March 1818, and that I have not nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities contracts or debts due to me, nor have I any income other than what is contained in the Schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed- his Cornelius X Tollon mark 1 Spotted Cow ----- $10.00 1 Mare $25.00 1 Read Calf 3.00 Cotmettle- 2.50 Read Cow 10.00 1 Spinning wheel 1.00 7 Head of Sheep & lambs 7.00 Horse geers 1.50 2 Stacks of wheat 15.95 1 year of a lease 22 acres 27.50 1 Read Muly heifer 7.00 1 Patch of corn & potatoes 20.00 1 Spotted Calf 3.30 Dresser furniture &c 2.25 9 Hogs & 6 pigs 10.00 1 Table .50 1 stack of pots 4.00 1 Meat tub .25 1 Shovel .25 1 Tramnel .25

Two mares, one four years old, the other 16 or 17 years old: a horse 12 years old and a young colt about a Week old - - $60.00 Two Cows & Calves . . . 20.00 Twelve Sheep and three Lambs. 20.00 Two Sows, one having six young pigs, the other six pigs about six months old 10. 00 Two Beds and bedding for the same 20.00 Two Metal ten Gallon Kettles, one crock 6.00 One Dutch oven 2.00 one Stew kettle of iron .50 Three Windsor Chairs 3. 00 and two splinter bottom chairs 1.00 Six Knives and forks. 1.00 One Pewter Platter, one earthan Platter 1.025 Three Plates. .25 Six Tea Cups & Saucers or thereabouts. .50 Doll's [dollars]144.62 ½ That the debts by him owing account to about Two hundred dollars and that debts owing to me do not exceed fifteen or twenty dollars, that he has no house or land, but rents the same This declarant further swears that his occupation is that of a Farmer, but that owing to age and decrepitude he can do little more than half the labor of an ordinary man that he has a wife and two Children living with him and one grand child, that his wife is about Sixty two years old nearly helpless from age and the rheumatism that his eldest daughter named Nancy is 23 years old, but is afflicted with the gravel so as not to be able to do more than to support herself, that his son named David Potts is about fourteen years old and able to assist in labor, that his grand Child named Polly Wolverton is an orphan

Schedule The State of South Carolina, Pendleton District On this twentyfifth day of October 1820, personally appeared in open Court, in the court of General Sessions of the peace byer and Termines Assize and General Gaol delivery being a Court of Record for the said District in the said state, John McEntire aged about Fifty nine years, resident in the District and State aforesaid, who, being first duly sworn according to law, doth, on his oath, declare that he served in the Revolutionary War as follows: That he enlisted under Captain Edward Wood of the second Regiment, commanded by Colonel Stark of the Georgia Line, was in the battles at Sunberry, and Juniper Springs- was taken and kept a prisoner by the British about five months, and when released joined the American Army under Colonel Middleton and served about ten months. All of the time I was in the regular service was about three years. Made an original declaration on the twentyseventh day of October 1818 and received Pension certificate No.15.253 dated Seventh day of October 1819. And I do solemnly swear, that I am a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part there of, with intent thereby so to diminish it or to bring myself within the provisions of an Act of Congress, entitled “An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary war,” passed on the 18th day of March , 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property, or securities, contract, or debt, due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. One mare and colt, two cows and calves, one heifer, three sows and pigs, two hoes one plough, one ax, one old mattock, one smoothing iron, one cow and yearling, nineteen shoat, one hoe, one Tomahawk, one iron wedge, two augers, one handsaw, one gimlet, one drawing knife, one reapkook, one gun, and fifteen chickens - this deponent is not able to follow his occupation as a farmer and is full of pain, and his wife Anna aged fiftyweight years is very sickly and hardly ever able to do anything Ellender aged 16 years; Elizabeth aged fourteen years who is a weakly woman and they are both unable to do much toward their support. Sworn to and declared on twentyfifth day of October Anno Domino, 1820. John {his mark} McEntire Abm. Nott

State of Tennessee At a County Court of Pleas & Quarter Sessions Continued & held for the County of Montgomery at the Court House in the Town of Clarksville on the third Monday in October Anno Domini 1820 Preset Sterling Neblett Stephen Cocke Stephen Thomas } Esquires Justices of the Court of Quorum Schedule of the property of James Baggett to Wit Twenty acres of land, one mare & Colt, four heads of Cattle Seven heads of sheep, five heads of common size hogs & eight pigs one large iron Kettle, two iron pots, one Dutch oven, one Skillet, one Chest, one Table, one raw Cow hide and some few Shelf or Cupboard articles, two dollars due me, & I am indebted thirty five dollars James Baggett State of Tennessee Montgomery County one the [illegible] day of October 1820 personally appeared in open Court being a Court of record (which have the power of fine & imprisonment) for the County of Montgomery James Baggett ages Sixty four years, a farmer by occupation, and now in such indigent circumstances as to be unable to support myself without the assistance of my Country; my Wife Nancy by name aged about Sixty two years no other family living with me, the said James Baggett is a resident of said County of Montgomery who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his Oath declare that he served in the revolutionary war; and hath heretofore been placed on the pension list of the United States & hath Obtained a pension Certificate from the War department dated 17th day of September 1819. And I do solemnly swear that I was a resident Citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March 1818 & that I have not since that time by gift Sale or in any manner disposed of my property, or any part thereof with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of the act of Congress, entitled "an act to provide for Certain persons engaged in the land & Naval Services of the United States in the revolutionary" war passed on the 18th day of March 1818 and I have not, nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities contracts or Debts due to me, nor have I any income

John Moore Sworn in open court this 30th May 1820 H.R. Phelps, Dep. Admin Clk[Clerk] Schedule of property 2 Cows. 1 old mare, 1 heifer 2 calves worth $43.00 6 small pigs, 4 hogs, 20 or 25 fowls at** 10.25 [** Transcriber replaced letters before each price with 'at'; text could be 'co', 'clo', 'do' or 'to'.] 2 tables, 1 stand, 2 pair canirons, shovel & tongs at 10.00 2 Kettles,1 pot, 1 tea Kettle, 12 tea cups & Saucers at 5.00 12 Knives & forks, 1 tea pot, 6 tea spoons at 3.31 6 table spoons, 12 plates, 6 bowls, & 1 milk cup at 2.60 pr spectacles, 1 bible, 1 testament, some small books at 3.75 [Total] 77.91 I have no more bedding and clothing than is necessary to render myself and family comfortable. I have due to me in the aggregate from different persons about $250 dollars, but I deem the whole uncollectable, about $200 having been in Judgment 3 or 4 years and execution having been issued upon the same and returned by the Sheriff nulla bona. I am a farmer by occupation and enjoy tolerable health when free from the rheumatism which is very frequently, and am often confined to the house for a number of days at a time by the same; do not believe I am able to support myself by labor. I have in my family my wife Sarah aged 57 years she is in tolerable health and I think at present able to support herself. Also my father Martin Moore aged about 80 years as I believe he is in a weak and low [end of page]

I have but one child alive to my knowledge he is of age + does not live in my family he is poor + has a family of his own I owe seventy dollars + have no no one to afsist me to support myself my wife being able to do but little I have lived by my pension money + should have been chargeable to one of the towns if I had not received it I have no family except my said wife + have to borrow a few things to cook with I cannot even cultivate the few acres I occupy for my wife but let it out for part of the crop + it usually yields about ten dollars profit a year this cannot do but little to support me + my sick wife afflicted with the king's evil + I must suffer or receive charity if my pension is lost Edward Mardin Schedule containing the whole estate and income of Edwards Mardin (his necefsary clothing + bedding accepted) by him subscribed, exhibited to the Court of Common Pleas for the county of Grafton in the State of New Hampshire on the 2d tuesday of August 1820 and annexed to his oath viz The use + income of about 40 acres of land in Lyman mostly wild which I have no title to except in right of my wife who has a deed of the same from Mr Charles K White I have the right of occupying during her life + coverture + no longer having about ten acres cleared up on it, yearly value of all the dollars ... $10.00 One heifer year old last spring 5.00 four common sheep at 1.50... 6.00 One ax one hoe both old ... 2.00 2 Chairs 3 knives + forks broken table + part of old set cups + saucers ... 3.00 One broken spade ... .50 --------- 26.50 One hog + 2 pigs all small ... 5.60 --------- $32.10 said heifer is mortgaged for nearly her value but I keep her still Edward Mardin

GREENLIEF STREET Fishkill, March 2, 1818. 29 3w N. B. Said situation is in the Village of Fishkill, near the Episcopal Church. --------------------------------- FOR SALE, THAT noted and valuable stand for public business, situate in the town of Hillsdale, in the county of Columbia and state of N. York, eighteen miles east of the city of Hudson, on the Columbia Turnpike road leading from Hudson to Hartford — well known and distinguished as a Stage House, directly opposite the store of Gains Stebbins & Co. consisting of a farm of 160 acres, well proportioned as to pasture, plough, wood and meadow land; a large commodious brick house, two stories high, 44 by 30 feet, one annexed dwelling house together with outhouses, barns, sheds, carriage house, two bearing Orchards, and a good well of water near the door, with a never failing spring of a superior quality. Terms of payment made easy, if applied for soon. For particulars, inquire of JOHN H. BULL of Saratoga county, or of JACOB DAKIN, Northeast, Dutchess county. Hillsdale, Feb. 10, 1818. 29tf -------------------------------- VENDUE. THE subscribers will sell at Public Auction, on Tuesday the 24th day of March, instant, commencing at 10 o'clock, and to continue from day to day until all the personal property of the late Abraham B. Rapalje, Esq. shall be sold, consisting of Horses, Cows, Sheep, Young Cattle, Hogs, And Farming Utensils of all kinds, and valuable HOUSEHOLD FURNITURE, among which are a number of Beds with bedding, two eightday clocks, (one of which is a first rate), a new Sideboard, Looking-Glasses, Carpets, Mahogany Dining, Card and Tea Tables, &c. Jerinemus Rapalje, Richard Rapalje, Abraham B. Rapalje, Richard A. Rapalje, } Executors Fishkill, Feb. 23, 1818. 29 N.B. To be rented a Store and 3 Dwelling Houses. Also one half of the Mansion-house provided a small and respectable family should apply. ------------------------------------- FOR SALE. THAT FARM of the subscriber, formerly the property of Stephen Brinckerhoff, situate in the town of Poughkeepsie, on the Highland Turnpike, containing about 50 acres of land, on the premises is a good two story wood HOUSE, a Barn and Blacksmiths Shop, a well of water, a good orchard, &c.—The above property is about 3 & a 1-2 miles from the village of Poughkeepsie. Any person wishing to purchase may call on Aaron Car [RIPPED] [THIRD COLUMN] in the forenoon of that day, to shew cause, if any they have, why so much of the real estate whereof the said Cyrus Benjamin, deceased, died seized, should not be sold, as will be sufficient to pay his debts. Dated Feb. 27, 1818—28 4w D. B. STOCKHOLM, Surrogate. ---------------------------------- At a Surrogate's Court, held at the Surrogate's office, in the village of Poughkeepsie, in Dutchess county, on Saturday the twenty-eighth day of February, 1818: PRESENT DERICK B. STOCKHOLM, Surrogate. Whereas Israel Ketcham acting executor, &c. of Samuel Myers, late of the town of Poughkeepsie, in Dutchess county, deceased, by his petition presented to the said Surrogate, has set forth that Samuel Myers, at the time of his death, was seized of real estate in the county of Dutchess, that the said petitioner has made a just and true inventory and account of the personal estate, and estimate of the debts of the said deceased as far as he has been able to discern the same, by which it appears that the personal estate of the said deceased is insufficient to pay his debts, and therefore requested the aid of this court in the premises, according to the statute in such case made and provided, and it also appearing that the personal estate of the said deceased as far as the same has come to the hands of the said petitioner, has been exhausted in paying the debts of the said deceased. And whereas the said petitioner has filed in to the office of the said Surrogate, the inventory, account, and estimate in the said petition mentioned, in due season, and in due form attested. Whereupon it is ordered by the said Surrogate, that all persons interested in the estate of the said deceased, shall appear before the said surrogate at his office in the village of Poughkeepsie, in Dutchess county, on Wednesday the fifteenth day of April next, at ten o'clock in the forenoon of that day, to shew cause, if any they have, why so much of the real estate whereof the said Samuel Myers died seized, should not be sold as will be sufficient to pay his debts. Dated Feb. 28, 1818. 28 6w D. B. STOCKHOLM, Surrogate. [WRITTEN SIDEWAYS IN PENCIL] Elihu Ingalls, W. 20156, N.Y.

State of Vermont. County of Windham SS. At the County Court, begun and held at New-Fane, within and for the County of Windham, on the second Monday of June, in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and twenty. . . Present - Hon. Phinehas White, Esq. Chief Judge. Hon. John Roberts, ] Hon. Gilbert Denison, Esqrs. } Assistant Judges. On this 20th day of June, A.D. 1820, personally appeared in open court, being a court of record for the said county, proceeding according to the course of the common law, with a civil jurisdiction unlimited in point of amount, keeping a record of their proceedings, and having, in certain cases, the power of fine and imprisonment, Peter Derry aged 65 years, resident in Brookline in said county, who, being first duly sworn according to law, doth, on his oath, declare that he served in the Revolutionary War as follows: two campaigns of nine months each in the Massachusetts line - Capt. Darby one L - Col. - Bailey one L and Col. - Jackson the other - That he has received a pension under the act of the Congress of the United States of the 18th March 1818, that the number of his pension certificate is 4.125 and the date of his original declaration is April 11. 1818. And I do solemnly swear, that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the eighteenth day of March, one thousand eight hundred and eighteen; and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner whatever, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled, "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the Land and Naval Services of the United States, in the Revolutionary War," passed on the eighteenth day of March, one thousand eight hundred and eighteen. And that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts, [illegible] I any income other than what is contained in the Schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. Peter Derry Schedule of real and personal estate, necessary clothing and bedding excepted. One Ringbone Mare worth $20 - 3 sheep & 4 lambs 6 -1 Cow 15 - pole cutter 2.50 Have old Furniture considered to be worth 25 - $68.50 Peter Derry. And I do also swear that my occupation is that of a laborer on Land - I have nine children, four of whom live with me - I owe about one hundred & fifty dollars - my daughter Rachel Derry aged 42 years is much of the time out of health - Nancy 45 years of age is also at times unable to work & makes her home with me - my son Benjn works out and makes his living mainly he is 22 years of age - these children at times are unable to provide for themselves, we are a family very poor & needy - my wife is 67 years of age - Peter Derry Sworn to and Declared in open court on the 20th day of June, A.D. 1820, Before Phinehas White Judge. I James Elliot, Clerk of the County Court for the County of Windham, in the State of Vermont, do hereby certify, that the foregoing oath, and Schedule thereto annexed, are truly copied from the files and records of the said Court: And I do further certify, that it is the opinion of the said Court, that the total amount in value of the property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule is sixty eight dollars and fifty cents. In testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand, and affixed the seal of the said Court, on this seventeeth day of July 1820. James Elliot. Clerk of the Court for the County of Windham.

Israel Hale Maine Private nine years from 1777, 35 acres of land with all house and barn there. Yoke of Oxen 2 cows 2 Heifers 3 calves 12 sheep-- 2 pigs old horse, a few articles of furniture & some farming utensils, valued by court $532 - owes $259.67 Schedule late of June, 1820 Schedule dated 5th June, 1823 a few articles of furniture 30.75 Sold in Nov 1820 Alpheus Hall all his real estate for $350 copy of the exhibit with which he has paid debts & expenditures in support of his family affidavit of creditors exhibited Alpheus Hales affidavit exhibited states that claimant owed him 460 which he loaned him in 1819 & on Nov. 1820 said Alpheus purchased his farm being all his real estate, for $350 which was considered to be a fair price by the judgment of two judicious men stated and after deducting the aforesaid 60 he paid the balance in money to the creditors of claimant principally in taking of notes which for debts due previous to 1820. The other affidavits exhibit debts paid by claimant to [illegible] to the amount of $328.16, partly paid in stock debts collected between the year 1817 & 1821 for goods for family use, during Month [illegible] bill for stock leather and blacksmithing, & affidavits Daniel Brown & same state that they have long been acquainted with claimant that he is destitute of property sufficient to support himself and family is unable to labor having lately had a fall in [illegible] which he has been and still is confined to bed. Claimant aged 65, farmer unable to work, Wife 59 years infirm sick and entirely unable to do anything, son 18, deaf earns his support in part - daughter 12 - earns her own living by her labor I certify that I have examined this case and am of the opinion that according to the principle, a [illegible] have given in previous decisions the claim ought to be allowed. See letters May 2d 1825. to Joseph Pope Esq Portland Maine Feb 3. 1825 to Hon. E. Lincoln H.R. See letter 21 May 1829 to Chas Whitman of last evidence 6 Feb 1824

Oliver Comee, Foxborough County of Norfolk, a Pensioner of the U States under the Act of Congress of 18th March 1818 - An Inventory of my property- A farm in said Foxborough with a house and barn thereon containing about ninety acres one yoke of oxen - 4 Cows- a mare & Colt two Swine & two pigs 5 Sheep & 3 Lamby- one old waggon 2 Plows - 1 chain 2 old cyths 3 Rakes 3 Thoy 2 cases - 12 old chairs 4 old tables-- 3 cases of drawers 22 Earthen plates & platters 4 wine glasses 1 Decanter 5 pewter plate & platters - 1 tin oven [illegible] small article of tin ware and red Earthen ware Eight pieces of iron hollow ware, 1 dozen old knives & forks, 1 pair of [illegible] 1 shovel and tongs two yearling heiffers an old log chair. I have a feeble wife and five children under age to support - my strength is impaired by a Rheumatic Complaint. I owe the following debts- Mortgage to the State Bank $250 to my Sister $470- to Jacob Leonard 290 to Ira Belcher $105. to S. Pratt $20. to A Morse 18. Lois Wyman 10. S Robinson 37. H Lownard 7. W. Comee 85, T. Rawson to amounting to $1302. I have a daughter afflicted for eight years past with a Scrofulous complaint for which I have been at considerable expense which yet is secured. Oliver Comee.

Of Christ's might. CHAP. 17. Churchestbreatened. of man, clothed with a garment down to the foot, and girt about the paps with a golden girdle. 14 His head and his hair were white like wool, as white as snow: and his eyes were as a flame of fire: 15 And his feet like unto fine brass, as if they burned in a furnace; and his voice as the sound of many waters. 16 And he had in his right hand seven stars: and out of his mouth went a sharp pronged sword; and his countenance was as the sun shineth in his strength. 17 And when I saw him I fell at his feet as dead. And he laid his right hand upon me, saying unto me, Fear not; I am the first and the last: 18 I am he that liveth, and was dead: and, behold, I am alive forevermore, Amen: and have the keys of hell and of death. 19 Write the things which thou hast seen, and the things which are, and the things which shall be hereafter: 20 The mystery of the seven stars, which thou sawest in my right hand, and the seven golden candlesticks. The seven stars are the angels of the seven churches; and the seven candlesticks, which thou sawest, are the seven churches. CHAP. II. What was written to the churches: Unto the angel of the church of Ephesna write: There thing: faith he that holdeth the seven stars in his right hand, who walketh in the midst of the seven golden candlesticks; 2 I know thy works, and thy labour, and thy patience, and how thou canst not bear them which are evil; and thou hast tried them which say they are apostles, and are not, and hast found them lyars; 3 And hast borne, and hast patience, and for my name's sake hast laboured, and hast not fainted. 4 Nevertheless I have forsaken against thee, because thou hast left thy first love. 5 Remember, therefore, from whence thou art fallen, and repemt, and do the first works or else I will come into thee quickly, and will remove thy candlestick out of his place, except thou repent. 6 But this thou hast, that thou hatest the deeds of the Nicolaitanes, which I also hate. 7 He that hath an ear, let him hear what the Spirit saith unto the churches: To him that overcometh with I give to eat of the tree of life, which is in the midst of the paradise of God. 8 And unto the angel of the church in Smyrna write: These things saith the first and the last, which was dead, and is alive; 9 I know thy works, and tribulation and poverty, (but thou art rien.) and I know the blasphemy of them which say they are Jews, and are not, but are the synagogue of Satan. 10 Fear none of those things which thou shalt suffer. behold, the devil shall cast some of you into prison that ye may be tried, and ye shall have tribulation ten days; be thou painful unto death, and I will give thee a crown of life. 11 He that hath an ear, let him hear what the Spirit saith unto the churches: He that overcometh shall not be hurt of the second death. 12 And to the angel of the church in Pergamos write: These things saith he which hath the sharp sword with two edges. 13 I know thy works, and where thou dwellest, ever where Satan's feet be and thou holdest fast my name, O ,

State of Vermont County of Windham Ss At the County Court, begun and held at New-Fane, within and for the County of Windham, on the second Monday of June, in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and twenty...and continued by adjournment at Brattleborough in said county on the third Wednesday of July in the year 1820. Present-Hon. Phinehas White, Esq., Chief Judge Hon. John Roberts, Hon. Gilbert Denison, Esqrs. Assistant Judges. On this 19th day of July, A. D. 1820, personally appeared in open court, being a court of record for the said county, proceeding according to the course of the common law, with a civil jurisdiction unlimited in point of amount, keeping a record of their proceedings, and having, in certain cases, the power of fine and imprisonment, Stephen Putnam, aged 59 years, resident in Whitingham in said county, who, being first duly sworn according to law, doth, on his oath, declare that he served in the Revolutionary War as follows: In company commanded by Capt. j. Blanchard, ninth Regiment commanded by col. H. Jackson, Massachusetts line-enlistment Feby 1781 for the term of three years, honorably discharged 31st day Dec. 1783. that he has received a pension under the act of the Congress of the United States of the 18th March, 1818, that the number of his pension certificate is 761 and the date of his original declaration is April 12, 1818. And I do Solemnly swear, that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the eighteenth day of March, one thousand eight hundred and eighteen; and that I have not since that time by gift, sale, or in any manner whatever, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself withing the provisions of an act of Congress entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the Land and Naval Service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War" passed on the eighteenth day of March, one thousand eight hundred and eighteen; And that I have not nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts, or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other than that what is contained in the Schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. Stephen Putnam SCHEDULE of real and personal estate, necessary clothing and bedding excepted. 7 sheep & 7 Lambs $10.50- 1 hog 4-2 pigs 2-1 case drawers 8- 2 chests 1.50=2 old tables 2.-- (illegible-paper folded over) Plates 1.50- 3 earthen plates 25c-8 spoons 50c=1 earthen mug & 2 bowls 25c

I have not, since that time, by gift, sale or in any other manner disposed of my property with intent thereby so do diminish it; as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress entitled “an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval services of the United States in the Revolutionary War”; passed on the 18th day of March 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities, contracts or debts due to me, nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed: That my family consists in my wife aged about 35 years, one son, aged about 16 years, who is illy able to contribute to the support of my family on account of having the sight of one eye. That my property consists of one cow and calf worth twelve dollars, one heifer worth four dollars, 8 head of hogs, eight dollars, 6 plates, seventy five cents, 1 pot, two dollars and fifty cents, 1 oven, two dollars, 6 knives & forks, two dollars, 6 tin cups, fifty cents, 1 pail, seventy five cents, 3 piggins, fifty cents. That no marginal change has taken place in my property since the 18th day of March 1818, and that were it not for my age, indignancy and the helpless situation of my family, this second application for a pension would not be made. My Family consists of a wife, and one son, about 40 years of age who was born helpless and still continues so. I am by present a Farmer. I owe debts to the amount of about sixty dollars, and have debts due to me to the amount of about five dollars. and I stand in need of my property for support. John Garland We do certify on oath, that we are neighbors to John Garland, and that the above is a fair valuation of his property and that we think he deserves a pension for his services and sufferings in the Revolutionary War. John Ridgell Joseph Payne Alexand Black I James F. Ballinger Clerk of the Circuit Court of Knox County, do certify that it is the opinion of the Court aforesaid, that John Garland's property is of the value of seventy six dollars Which is ordered to be certified to the Secretary of War. To the honourable Secretary of war of the United States of North America Daniel Hosford of Charlotte in the County of Chittenden and State of Vermont on oath declares and says that on the 15th Day of January 1776 he entered into the the service of his Country in a Company under the command of Capt. Zebadiah Sabin of Williamstown in the State of Massachusetts and on the same Day commenced their march for Cana- -da as a reinforcement to the American Army in obedience to a requisition ma- -de by the commander of our forces in Canada immediately after the defeat and death of General Montgomery by express which arrived at Williams -town the the 14th Day of said January that he with said Company ari- -vid at Montreal and reported to Genl. Wooster from whence said Company were ordered to Quebec and there Joined the Regiment commanded by Colo. Seth Warner and did duly In said Regiment until taken with the small Pox and after that abated the petitioner remained in a low and dangerous state of health that on the retreat the sixth Day of May was furlowed and the affect of the small Pox fatige and other hardships so injured his he- -alth so as not able to do his duty in the army for a long time but when recovered is as to return by the arrangements of the Regiments was appointed Adjutant in Colo. Benjamin Simonds Regiment and served faithfully and satisfactorily under the command of Colo. Anthony Wayne at Ticonderoga commander in chief in that Garrison until he with said Regiment were regularly and honourably discharged from the Continental service by General orders from the commander in chief on the 16th Day of March 1777 that he has not at any time received any discharge from his inlistment on the 15 Day of January 1776 before the one menti- oned above that is Commission from laps of time and accident is lost and is and ever has been a resident of the United States and that he is in re- -duced circumstances in life and in the need of assistance of his country for support predicted on his suffering by which his constitution and health have been so distressedly injured which I cannot so clearly prove by reason of the death of those physicians that were more knowing to my suffering and loss of health which cannot be realized from information by no person whatever which I feel to the present Day and has been one reason of my reduced circumstances at this time I have six children three Sons and three Daughters all of age and for themselves and gone from me (except one Son) with very little cloathing and a fiew other articles of any kind to help themselves with [unknown] them needy like my selfe As to property have the Milk of one Cow the wool of ten Sheep but not the [unknown] for the Cow nor the Sheep are not my own property only the milk and the wool and a few house hold articles too trifleing value to innumerate and have security of my Son that is not gone from me for his assistance toward my and my

and by me subscribed that all the property he owned on the face of the earth his necessary clothing & bedding excepted costs of the following articles [final?] one small one eyed mare and colt of little value $30. six head of hogs $4. an old sadle & bridle and four chairs and a few articles of very indifferent quality of household furniture and of little value $5 - $39. That on the 18th of March 1818 all the property he owned in earth which he does noW own was a sorrel mare which he has since sold for $50 and has applied the sale money, exclusively in the payment of debts and procuring the [necessities?] of life. If he owned any other property at that time which he did not now own, he does not remember it. But if he did it must have been some very small article of little or no value, but does not think a single other article of property was then owned by him. That his occupation when able to labour any is a farming. That he has become old and very infirm and much afflicted with diseases and in addition to other diseases his wounded arm often affects so that he is wholly unable to labour for a support. His family consists of himself and his aged wife Susannah, now about sixty three years old. his said wife has had one of her wrists broke & is otherwise much affected and is totally unable to labour any. That she is so perfectly Helpless and he being not able to support himself, much less to support herself that he himself as well as his wife

nor have I any income other than what is contained in the Schedule hereto amended and by me subscribed he further states. That he is old + unable to do hard Labour he has a wife + four children living with him his wife is old and sickly + his children two sons + two daughters his oldest son about nineteen years of age his other son about twelve years his oldest Daughter about Sixteen years of age his other daughter about eight years of age. he follows the Occupation of farming his oldest son is at present of some service to him in his Occupation the rest of his family helpless + himself a Cripple. The following is a Schedule of his property. To wit One mare + two Colts worth about fifty dollars his Stock of hogs worth about thirty dollars Two cows + five calves worth about thirty five dollars some Cooking Utensils + table furniture worth about ten dollars plows Axes + hoes worth about ten Dollars four head of Sheep worth about four Dollars making his property all together worth about one hundred + thirty nine or forty Dollars. Greene County Ss. On this 22 day of June 1820 personally appeared in open Court of Common Pleas for the County of Greene in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania Stephen Hetfield who being duly sworn according to law doth on his solemn oath declare and say that he served in the Revolutionary war as follows in the company of Captain Abraham Lyon in the fourth Jersey Regiment as is stated in my original application certified by and made before the Honourable David Gray Esquire, an Associate Judge of this Court, and forwarded to the secretary of war and I do [word written and crossed out below that] also Swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the eighth day of March 1818 and that I have not since that time by gift, Sale, or in any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof with intent to diminish it so as to bring myself within the provision of an act of Congress entitled an Act to provide for persons engaged in the - land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary war. passed on the 18th day of March 1818; and that I have not nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities contracts or debts due to me nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed. I do also swear that to the best of my knowledge, I am between fifty nine and sixty years of age in bad health as I have been for many years, a farmer by occupation which I am in a great measure unable to pursue that I have the following family; a wife and children as follows Mary aged near eighteen years Elizabith aged fifteen Charlotte aged thirteen Anthony aged ten Letitia aged six Jacob aged five Maria aged three years and Andrew aged six months, and that I owe many considerable debts and rent to the amount of one hundred and seven Dollars for which the executors of Jacob Swartz would have Sold my property under distress but were prevailed on to wait to know the issue of my application for a pension. I also do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not since that time resided out of the same and that all of the property dues and claims to which I am intitled are as follows, two Horses, a colt and one three year old colt and one colt very young, four Cows, two hogs, nine Sheep, one plough and Set of old gears a chain, one old loom, a tea Kettle two pot and bake oven. Six old chains, three old bedsteads, a Dresser to Set dishes on, an old big and two old Spinning wheels, a few old

what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed I further declare I am by occupation a farmer unable to do any work by reason of the Rheumatism have not drest or undrest myself for five years. My wife aged fifty seven years is laboring under a paralitic afflictions unable to labour to any thing. All the children living with me are Sally Heath aged 36 years at times very unwell for several yeras past. Lucy Heath aged 21 years has been insane for four years & very troublesome. Webster Heath aged 18 years & Lewis Heath aged sixteen both able to do some labor but not enough to more than support themselves if so much. The distressed circumstances of my family & my particular inability induces me humbly to pray for the continuance of my countrys bounty. Samuel [X 'his mark'] Heath Schedule of the whole of Samuel Heaths estate 2 cows valued ...........24..00 6 sheep & 5 lambs ........11..00 2 swine val ...........7..50 3 pigs.............2..00 horse waggon............15..00 farming tools ...........5..50 old household furniture not more than...................10..00 2 calves...............5.00 $80..00 Witness N W Sargent Samuel [X 'his mark'] Heath Sworn to and declared on this tenth day of November Anno Domini 1820 before the [word unreadable] of said Court S.P. US Revolutionary War pension and Bounty land warrant application files 1800 to 1904, Benjamin Marshall, alias Greentree and his wife Mary Greentree. Page1. This page is a ruled index card type page. Service Continental Pen. Marshall, Benjamin or Marshall or Greentree. Number W4020. And listed in Maryland. Mary (his wife’s given name). Page 15. Nov 1818 To the secretary for the Department of War city of Washington, District of Columbia Page 16, 13 Nov 1818 Note this is a printed form with spaces that have been filled in in handwriting. Hand written words in italics. District of (space not filled in), 88. On the 13th day of November 1818, before me, the subscriber, one of the associate judges of the third Judicial district of Maryland for the said district, personally appeared Benjamin Marshall, aged 59 years, resident in Montgomery County in the said district, who by me first duly sworn, according to law, doth, on his oath, make the following declaration, in order to obtain the provision made by the late act of Congress, entitled “an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War:” that he the said Benjamin Marshall enlisted in Bladensburg in the state of Maryland on 10 March 1777 in the company, commanded by Captain Benjamin Stoddert of Colonel Thompson Hartley’s Regiment of Pennsylvania; that he continued to serve in the said corps, or in the services of the United States until 10 April 1780, when he was discharged from service in Philadelphia state of Pennsylvania, that he was at the battle of Brandywine and the North Fork of the Susquehanna with the Indians and that he is in reduced circumstances, and stands in need of the assistance of his country for support; and that he has no other evidence now in his power of his said services. Sworn to and declared before me, the day and year aforesaid signed Charles J Kilgoen.?? I Charles J Kilgoen judge, and et cetera as aforesaid do certify that it appears to my satisfaction that the said Benjamin Marshall did serve in the Revolutionary War, as stated in the preceding declaration, against the common enemy, for the term of three years and one month, on the continental establishment; and I now transmit the proceedings and testimony taken and had before me, to the secretary for the Department of war, pursuant to the directions of the aforementioned act of Congress. And I further here by state that appears to my satisfaction that the said Ben James Marshall is in reduced circumstances and stands in need of the assistance of his country for such part. Signed C. J Kilgoen. Seal of the court. Page 17. 13 Nov 1818 State of Maryland, Montgomery County. ?? I hereby certify that Charles J Kilgoen Esquire gentlemen before whom the aforegoing affidavit was made and whose certificate is added was at the time, one of the associate judges of the third divisional district of Maryland (and that Montgomery County) is one of the counties included in said third Judicial district (duly commissioned and sworn). In testimony whereof I have hereto set my name and affixed the public seal of Montgomery County court, this 13th day of November anno domino 1818. Upton Beall, Clerk of Montgomery County Court. Pages 12, 13, 14. 21 Nov 1820 Schedule. State of Maryland, Montgomery County Sec. on the 21st day of November 1820, personally appeared in open court, being a court of record for the county aforesaid constituted by the laws and constitution of the state, Benjamin Marshall, aged 60 years resident in Montgomery County and state aforesaid, who being first duly sworn according to law doth on his oath declare that he served in the Revolutionary War as follows. That on the 10th day of March 1777, he enlisted as a private in the company, commanded by Captain Benjamin Stoddert of the 16th additional Pennsylvania Regiment commanded by Colonel Thomas Hartley. That he was in the battle of Brandywine. That he was in a battle on the North Fork of the Sasquehanna with the Indians; that he was in the battle at the town of Brunswick in New Jersey, that he was discharged from the service on 16 April 1780, that he has received a pension under the act of Congress, entitled an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval services of the United States in the Revolutionary War past 18 March 1818. And that he received a pension certificate number 7375 – and I do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen on the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not since that time by gift sale or in any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof with intent thereby to diminish it is to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress entitled an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval services of the United States in the Revolutionary War past on the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not, nor had any person in trust for me any property or service, or securities contracts or debt deeds to me, nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule here unto next and by me subscribed. My occupation is to tend the garden and 3 acres of land, I have a wife named Mary 60 years of age. One daughter named Elizabeth, a widow 28 years old, she has one daughter named Evaline Brall eight years old, and one son named James Brall six years old, all of whom this deponents supports. Schedule of my property. That I have six chairs, one table, one cupboard and six plates? (paper torn), 6 cups and saucers, one cream jug, one sugar dish one writing desk, two spinning wheels, one trunk, 2 pots, 2 ovens, one teakettle, one fire shovel, one water bucket, one (looks like Pigger - meaning Jar ??) one washing tub, one shovel plough, five knives, and six forks, 5 tablespoons, four tubs, one weeding hoe, one grubbing hoe, one axe, one pair of wedges, one bag, two bedsteads and two fire pothooks, thirty fowl. Benjamin Marshall. (personal note: Evaline and James Beall?) This property valued by the court at $50. Sworn to in open court this 21st day of November 1820. Signed Upton Brall clerk Montgomery County court. I Upton Brall clerk of Montgomery County Court, do hereby certify that the aforegoing oath and schedule sheets annexed are truly copied from the records of said court, and I do further certify that it is the opinion of the said court that the total amount in value of the property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule is $50. In testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand and affixed the seal of said court the 30th day of November 1820. Upton Brall clerk, Montgomery court. Page 46. 9 Dec 1820 Handwritten letter signed Benjamin Marshall. Barnes Ville, Maryland, December 9, 1820. The honourable Secretary at War. Sir, I have forwarded on by mail my certificate agreeable to instructions given me at the city Washington and I wish to be informed how much money I shall be able to draw on 4 March next, please direct the letter to Barnes Ville post office, Your obedient servant Benj. Page 43. 21 Jan 1843 A handwritten letter. Rockville 21st of January 1843. Dear Sir, I received your letter in which you wish to know whether or not there was a record of the marriage of Benjamin Greentree and Mary Greentree. We have no record of that nature, previous to the year 1798. Consequently, no such entry can be found. Your obedient servant … Selley .Clerk. Circular Stamp inscribed ‘Rockville Jan 21’. Page 44. 27 Jan 1843 Hand addressed envelope with circular Stamp inscribed ‘Frederick January 27’, and written sideways is Mary B Greentree. Addressed to J. L. Edwards, Esq, Pension office, Washington DC Page 45. 27 Jan 1843 Handwritten letter. Frederick 27 January 43. Dear Sir, Mrs Greentree, widow of Benjamin Greentree (or Marshall) a revolution war soldier, formerly of this county has applied to me to bring her case before you for a pension. Her husband received his pension up to his death in 39. She can … all that is necessary to her success, except that she was not married prior to 83. It was not until 1786 she married. Is this fatal to her application? For if so, I need not trouble myself to collect … The marriage. With greatest respect I am Sir, yours truly LPW Balek. Page 2. 11 Mar 1843. A two-page document. Continence Montgomery Cpg, Maryland. Page 41. 21 Mar 1843 A handwritten letter. Sir Maryland 21 March 43 I enclose the papers of Mrs Greentree, alias Marshall – which I think you will find stands within the act of 1838 – please act on them speedily as I am ordered by the Atg Gen of Maryland to appear in Hayes town in …. The state in the great case of the … And Maclean bank on a … to repeal its charter and I wish to have this business closed before my departure. With great respect. Yours truly, LPW Balek. Page 8. 21 Mar 1843. 8804. Declaration of Mary Greentree (alias Marshall) widow of Benjamin Marshall a deceased Pensioner, Maryland. Pages 9, 10, 11. 21 Mar 1843. Page 9 goes after page 11. Declaration. In order to obtain the comfort of the Act of Congress of 7 July 1838, entitled an Act Granting half pay and resources to certain widows. State of Maryland Frederick County, Frederick Court Session. On the 21st day of March 1843, personally appeared before me Richard H Marshall, one of the Associate Judges of the Fifth Judicial District of Maryland, Mary Greentree, alias Marshall, a resident of Frederick County and of Frederick town, and by reason of bodily infirmity and unable to appear in open court, aged 81 years on the 15th day of April 1843 – who being first duly sworn according to law doth on her oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the pensions made by the act of Congress passed July 7, 1838, entitled an act generating half pay and pensions to certain widows. That she is the widow of Benjamin Greentree, alias Benjamin Marshall, who received a pension in his lifetime as a revolutionary soldier for proof of which services and pension she refers to said petitioner and its evidence now on record in the pension office at Washington. She further declares that she was married to that identical petitioner Benjamin Marshall as he is therein called alias Benjamin Greentree at George town, then in Montgomery County by the Reverend Stephen B Balek on 8 October 1786, as appeared by the family record cut from the family Bible on 20 March 1843, and to which marked A. She refers as proof of her marriage aforesaid – that said record is in the handwriting of her late husband altogether – that it contains a correct list of her children and their ages, which she had by said Benjamin Marshall, alias Greentree, the identical petitioner aforesaid, who was always called and known in this county as Benjamin Greentree when he was receiving his pension as Benjamin Marshall, he having at the time of his enlistment append the name Marshall to gratify a gentleman of that name, with whom he then settled and in this way was entered on the roles as Benjamin Marshall. She has no further said proof of her marriage as aforesaid. For the reasons stated in paper marked B. Several persons were present when she was married aforesaid, but all have either died, or emigrated to parts of the country where, if alive it would be impossible for her to find them. She has never heard of them since their removal, which was a great many years since, (this is the start of page 24) and believes all to be dead. She further declared that her aforesaid husband Benjamin Greentree (alias Marshall) died in Frederick County within 2 miles of Newmarket on 29 March 1839 and that she was not married to him prior to his leaving the service, but the marriage took place previous to the first day of January, 1794 … at the time al.. stated. Mary Greentree (badly smudged) her mark. Sworn and substantiated the day and year above. Written before Richard H Marshall Associate Judge of the fifth judicial district for the state of Maryland.
