Frederick 10 April 43 Dear Sir, Just returned from Hayes town court and find no dispatches from you relative to my pending application from Mrs Greentree, alias Marshall. Pray let me know this week as on Monday next. I expect to be off for …… to try some causes. Yours truly, LP W Balek Page 34. 22 Apr 1843 Handwritten letter. ….. 22 April 43 Dear Sir, I wrote you several times since I forwarded the papers of Mrs Greentree and as yet received no answer – now my dear Sir, if you only knew how poor and decrepit the old lady is you would write me forthwith, and let me know what defect (if any) in her petition that I may amend it and satisfy it. I hope my old friend Edward will either send me the certificate or inform me what more is wanted. I am dear Sir, yours truly, L. P. W Balek. Page 33. 23 Apr 1843? Looks like an addressed envelope. Circular Stamp, inscribed ‘Free …. ), Apr 23. Written on side ‘Apl Mary Greentree. Address: L J Edwards Esq, Pensions Office, Washington. Page 36. 25 Apr 1843 A handwritten letter. …. 25 Apr 43. Dear Sir, Yesterday as I received yours of the relation to Mrs Greentree’s claim. As there is no person surviving who can prove the marriage except herself, and as her affidavit turns out to be insufficient there is an end to the case. The family record which I enclosed to you, you will please return to me. It being the hand writing of Mr G containing the ages of his children, it is of course dear to his family and can be of no … to the war department! Respectfully LPW Balek. Page 35. 26 Apr 1843? Acts July 7 38, March 3 43 and June 17, 1844. 8229, and 98. Married 8 October, 1786 husband died 29 March 39. Cat: two W S Alison. Present Page 48. 21 Nov 1844 A handwritten letter. State of Maryland, Frederick County On this 21st day of November 1844, personally appeared before me, the subscriber, a Justice of the peace in and for said county Mary Greentree, alias Marshall. Known by me for some years to be a lady of respectability deserving full faith and credit who being first duly sworn according to law, doth depose and say that she is the widow of Benjamin Greentree, alias Marshall, who did receive a pension from the United States who was late a private in the Army of the Revolutionary War, a resident of Frederick County, Maryland. Commenced his pension on the 13th day of November 1818, that he died March 29, 1838, that she is the widow of Benjamin Greentree, alias Marshall, who did receive the balance of said Marshals pension up to the day of his death by reference to his papers will more fully appear filed in the pension office at Washington city. … That there is no church record of her marriage to the best of knowledge, that she made her declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the act passed by Congress July 7, 1838, that this was a family record of the births of her children next to his papers, which was sent by Mr Bailey attorney at law sometime in March 1843, and written by Benjamin Greentree, alias Marshall and has been in my possession ever since, that I have authorised Jacob Baric of Wayne’s Borough unknown word county state of Pennsylvania to receive my certificate for a pension as soon as it may be allowed, or granted as a widow of a soldier of the Revolution. Sworn to and subscribed on this 21st day of November 1844, before me, Justice of the peace William Lowe Mary Greentree, alias Marshall her mark. State of Maryland … Etc. County … I do hereby certify that I was since acquainted with Benjamin Greentree and he frequently told me the reason why his name was called Marshall, was that he was raised by a man by that name of Marshall and he always went by that name. And so he entered into the service of the United States by the name of Marshall, but his real name was Greentree. Signed William Lowe. Page 49. 21 Nov 1844 Handwritten letter. State of Maryland Frederick County. On this 21st day of November, A.D., 1844, personally appeared before me, the subscriber, a Justice of the peace in and for said county. William (name smudged) age 63 years known by me to be a man of good character deserving full faith and credit who being first duly sworn according to law doth depose and say that he was well acquainted with Benjamin Greentree, alias Marshall, who did draw a pension under the name of Benjamin Marshall of Frederick County, Maryland. (Inserted) That the deponent knew him for 30 years and knows that he did always acknowledge the within name. Mary Greentree, alias Marshall he did acknowledged her to have been his lawful wife. That he first knew him as a teacher in Montgomery Co and did send his children to him, that his wife now lives in Frederick city and continues to be his widow and further saith not. Sworn to and subscribed on the 21st day of November 1844, before me, William Lowe, JP. Signed William Wilsonow (?). Frederick County November. I hereby certify that I have known Mrs Mary Greentree, alias Marshall, and also did know Benjamin Greentree, alias Marshall, and he always did acknowledge the said Mary Greentree to be his lawful wife. I have known him for about 14 years before his death and his widow ever since, and she is now 80 odd years of age and is a respectable old lady, but poor. I also know that she drew a pension from the United States and that there was a balance at his death, which was received by the said Mrs Mary Greentree, alias Marshall afterwards. Signed William Lowe, JP Page 50. 21 Nov 1844 State of Maryland Frederick County … I hereby certify that William Lowe gentlemen before whom the foregoing affidavit appears to have been made and whose name is thereunto subscribed was at the time of so doing, and still is, a Justice of the peace of the state of Maryland in the aforesaid County duly commissioned …. and to .. His acts and such full faith ag.. credit is and ought to be given as well in Courts of Justice as thereout. In testimony where of I hearing to subscribed my name and apply the seal of Frederick County court this 21st day of November 1844, signed Henry Lockley, Clerk, Frederick County, Maryland. Page 40. 25 Nov 1844 Handwritten letter. November 25, 1844 Sir, I enclose a paper of Mrs Mary Greentree, alias Marshall, who wishes to obtain a pension. She alleges that Mr Balek of Frederick town did send her declaration with the original family records along as soon as you do examine the claim. Please let me hear from you and oblige. Yours respectfully, Jacob Barrich (??) Direct Yours …. Franklin County, Pennsylvania. Col. J. A. Edwards, Commissioner of pensions, Washington City DC Page 52, 53, 54, 55. 18 Oct 1845 District of Columbia Washington County. Personally appeared before me Richard Key Watts a Justice of the peace in and for said county, Mrs Eleanor Ward, now a resident of said county, and formerly of Frederick and Montgomery’s, Maryland, aged 58 years in June last, who being first duly sworn, deposes and say that she is the eldest daughter of Mrs Mary Greentree, alias Marshall and applicant for a pension, the widow of Benjamin Greentree, alias Marshall, now deceased. That her father the aforesaid Benjamin Greentree, alias Marshall, was pensioner of the more Maryland agency, under the act of March 1818 that the circumstances under which her father bore the name of Marshall and Greentree are as follows. – Her father as she has often heard him state was born at sea on his mother’s passage from England to this country; that when his mother arrived here, being in destitute circumstances, her father then an infant was taken charge of and adopted by a family named Marshall, that he went by the name of the family who adopted him, from his childhood and enlisted under the name of Marshall. Some time after his return home. His adopted parents informed him of his true name of Greentree, which name he then took; that her father always called his adopted parents, father and mother, of which last facts. This deponent has a personal knowledge her father’s adopted parents considered him the child and treated him as such. His adopted father died many years since, and his adopted mother who married the second time, died a few years since in Washington stop this deponent always called her grandmother, and went said deponent visited Washington made her home at the home of her father’s adopted mother. This deponent married in 1807 bypass and read in January, and was 20 years old. The following June. She was christened as were also her sisters bypass and read of Montgomery County Maryland’s. She this deponent as a sister, Elizabeth living at Frederick with whom her mother now resides. She would further state that she this deponent has four children married and that she has about 20 grandchildren. She would further state that her father was known by the name of Marshall and Greentree, and having listed under the name of Marshall, applied for and obtained a pension under that name. He was a state pensioner during the latter part of his life, and deponent’s mother now receives a state pension of $40 per as the widow of Benjamin Greentree, alias Marshall. Her father was for a number of years clerk to the churches under the charge of pass read, and further this deponent saith now sworn to and subscribed this 18th day of October 1845 in the presence of, and before Richard Key. Watts JP. Signed Eleanor Ward her mark I certify that the above deponent is a credible and respectable witness, and any statement which she now makes whether under oath, or otherwise is entitled to the fullest credit to the best of my knowledge and belief. Signed, Richard Key Watts. October 22, 1845. Acts of March 3, 1843 and June, 17, 1844. Recorded in book a volume 1, page 252. Page 22, 23. 4 Mar 1911 This page is a typed and ruled form with information about the person written in by hand. Section and end division. 3 – 585. Department of the interior, Bureau of Pensions Washington, DC …….. , 19…. W. Files 4020. Mrs Charles S Ridgway, Auburn, Alabama. In reply to your request of 1, received 4’ Inst for a statement of the military history of Benjamin Greentree, a soldier of the Revolutionary War, you will find below the desired information is contained in his end (or his widow’s) application for pension or file in this bureau. Pensioned as Benjamin Marshall. Dates of enlistment or appointment March, 10, 1777. Length of service three years one month. Rank private. Officers under whom service was rendered Captain Benjamin Stoddert, Colonel Thomas Hartley. State Pennsylvania. Battles engaged in Brandywine, a battle with Indians on North Fork of Susquehanna and Brunswick, New Jersey residents of soldier at enlistment enlisted at Bladensburg, Maryland date of application for pension November 13, 1818. Cl.al. Age at date of application 59 years. Remarks: soldier was born at sea, on the passage from England to this country, was adopted by a family named Marshall, and enlisted and was pensioned under that name. He married et cetera. He died near Newmarket, Frederick County, Maryland. March 29, 1839, leaving a widow, Mary Greentree, she was allocated a pension, on an application, executive, March 21, 1843, while residents of Frederick County, Maryland. Very respectfully, (No signature) Commissioner ….. Division. March 9, 1911. Mrs Charles S Ridgeway, Auburn, Alabama. Madam: In addition to the military history of Benjamin Greentree or Marshall, VID.file number.4020, you are furnish the following family data found in the papers in said claims: – Benjamin Greentree, born May 16, 1760, and Mary Cash, born April 15, 17, 60, were married in Georgetown, Montgomery County, Maryland, October, eight, 1786. Children Eleanor, born June, 22, 1787, married January 13, 1807, John Wesley Ward. Margaret, born November, 8, 1788. James C, born August 24, 1790. Elizabeth, born August 11, 1792. Mary, born June 4, or 5, 1794. John D, born August 27, 1795. Ezra, born October 14, 1795. Asa, born February, 7, 1801. In 1820 soldier refers to Eveline Brall, aged eight years, and James Brall, six years, children of his daughter Elizabeth, a widow. Very respectfully, (No signature), Commissioner. Page 20, 21. 20 Jan 1930 Handwritten on the top of a typed letter: Page of letter of enquiry sent to record division for reply relative to soldiers of civil war. The page is torn and some information missing. …… And 1812 wars section. MGS/HMH. February 20, 1930. Mrs Walter Heyn 8 Holland Terrace, 2 Montclair, New Jersey. Dear Madam I advise you from the papers in the Revolutionary War pension claim, W.4020, it appears that Benjamin Greentree, alias Marshall, was born May 16, 1760, at sea, on the passage from England to America. When an infant he was adopted by a family named Marshall, and he enlisted and was pensioned under that name. He enlisted in Bladensburg, Maryland, March, 10, 1777 and served three years and one month as a private in Captain Benjamin’s Stoddert’s company in Colonel Thomas Hartley’s Regiment. He was in the battle of Brandywine and battled with the Indians on the North Fork of the Susquehanna River and the battle of Brunswick. He was allowed pension on his application executed November 13, 1818, at which time he was living in Montgomery County, Maryland. He died near Newmarket, Frederick County, Maryland, March, 29, 1839. He married in Georgetown, Montgomery County, Maryland, October, eight, 1786, Mary Cash, who was born April 15, 1760. She was allowed pension on her application executed March, 21, 1845, at which time she was a resident of Frederick County, Maryland. Benjamin and Mary Greentree had the following children: Eleanor born June, 22, 1787, married January 13, 1807 John Wesley Ward. Margaret born November, 5, 1788. James C born August 24, 1790. Elizabeth born August 11, 1792 Mary born June 4 or 5, 1794 John D born August 27, 1796, Ezra born October 14, 1798, Asa born February, 7, 1801. In 1820, the soldier referred to Evaline Brall, aged eight years and James Brall, six years, children of his daughter Elizabeth, a widow. (personal note: Evaline and James Beall?) Very truly yours, Earl D Church, Commissioner Page 25, 26. 18 Apr 1938 This page is a hand written letter with an official stamp indicating it was received on April 18, 1938. It is very difficult to read. Bureau of pensions, Washington DC. Dear Sirs Our US pension roles 1835 #/05. P. 260 - ….. record of pension granted to Benjamin Greentree crossed out and Marshall inserted and register of …… Office directed to issue …. 5& A. Of an unappropriated land in Allegheny County … ……. , Is … From the state to revolutionaries soldiers who served as .. ….42 Which they can consider him entitled. ……………………. under name Benjamin Marshall: names which …………….. him placed …….. To roll of ………., Under law of 3.18. 1818. Re— these: Benjamin Marshall, …. Jan 1820, His marriage is as Benjamin Greentree and he is buried under this name – which his descendants continue to use. Tradition claims he was born on trip from England to …. and was adopted by a family of name of “Marshall”. Evidently used this name in enlistment and but reverted “Greentree”. Will you kindly send to me any data which may be in the record concerning 1. Benjamin Marshall or Greentree. 2. Did he ….. 3. Is there any data for any members of the family with mother aboard the ship when he was born? Date arrival, name of ship, etc? 4. Any records identifying in any way the Marshall family. I am eligible for various societies and would appreciate any information you can give me truly yours, Minnie W Heyn. Page 18, 19. 19 Apr 1938 This is a typewritten letter. (Personal note. Minnie Heyn, maiden name Watkins, b 1778, d 1945 was the great grand daughter of John Dorson/Dawson Greentree, son of Benjamin Greentree/Marshall.) April 19, 1938. Benjamin Marshall or Greentree. W.4020. BA-J/MOS. Minnie W Heyn. 8 Helland Terrace, Montclair, New Jersey. Dear Madam: Reference is made to your request for information relative to the Revolutionary War soldier, Benjamin Marshall or Greentree. The data which follow were obtained from papers on file in the pension claim, W.4020, based on the Revolutionary War service of Benjamin Marshall alias Greentree. He was born May 16, 1760, at sea on the passage from England to America. It was stated that his mother being in destitute circumstances when she arrived in America (name of ship and date and place of arrival not given). He was adopted by a family named Marshall (the given names not shown) and he used that surname until sometime after his return from service in the revolution when his “adopted parents” informed him that his true surname was Greentree, which name he then used. The given names of his real parents were not shown. He enlisted and Bladensburg, Maryland, March, 10, 1777, and served three years and one month as private in Captain Benjamin’s Stoddert’s company in Colonel Thomas Hartley’s Regiment. He was in the battle of Brandywine, in a battle with the Indians on the North Fork of the Susquehanna River and in the battle of Brunswick. He was allowed pension on his application executed November 13, 1818, at which time he was living in Montgomery County, Maryland. He applied for pension under the name of Benjamin Marshall. He died March 29, 1839, near Newmarket, Frederick County, Maryland. (Next page of letter.) Said Benjamin, who then used the surname Greentree, married in Georgetown, Montgomery County, Maryland, October, eight, 1786, Mary Cash, who was born April 15, 1760. She was allowed pension on her application executed March 21, 1843, at which time she was living in Frederick County, Maryland. In addition to the Federal pensions noted above, it was stated that both the soldier and his widow received state pensions (which pensions were probably paid by Maryland). Benjamin and Mary Greentree had the following children: Eleanor born June 22, 1787, married January 13, 1807, John Wesley Ward, and in 1845 she was living in the District of Columbia and stated she had for married children and about 20 grandchildren, their names not given. Margaret born November, 5, 1788. James C born August 24, 1790 Elizabeth born August 11, 1792 resident of Frederick in 1845, and her mother was then living with her. Mary born June 4 or 5, 1794 John D born August 27, 1796. Ezra born October 14, 1798. Asa born February, 7, 1801. In 1830. Reference was made to Evaline Brall, aged eight years and James Brall, age 6 years, who were children of the soldier’s daughter Elizabeth, who was then a widow. In 1845. It was stated that the soldier’s adopted father died many years ago and that his adopted mother married the second time and died a few years ago in Washington. There are no further data relative to the soldier’s family. The land referred to in your letter was granted by Maryland and for information relative to this land being patented and by the soldier, it is suggested that you consult the archive said and Annapolis, Maryland. (personal note: Evaline and James Beall?) Very truly yours A.D. Miller, executive assistant to the administrator. Page 32. 1938 This is a two-page document. First page. 1911, March 9 – history to Mrs Charles S. Ridgway. 1914 January 26, Mrs G. H. Kinsley and 1930 February 2 history to Mrs Walter Heyn no letter last page of (Inserted) required sent to record division for reply re-to soldiers of civil war. 1938, April 19 history to Mrs W Heyn, Nil. Second page. Rev window and see. State of Ohio City of Cincinnati SS. On the 5th day of September 1820 before me the subscriber Mayor of the city aforesaid personally came Robert Faulkner, of lawful age, who on his oath declares that he is at this time unable to support himself by bodily labour for the following reasons to wit, that he is in the first instance a man, of a feeble and broken constitution that he is at this time and has been since the year 1777, afflicted with an asthma and pain in the breast which he in curred in consequence, of hardship and suffering in the revolutionary war, which increasing with the infirmities of the old age, almost wholly prevents him from following his trade and actually does to such a degree that he cannot maintain himself by it, that he, he has been for the last three years severely afflicted with the rheumatism in the left shoulder and right hip so much so that he has been confines for months together , under the hands of a physician and was entirely helpless and compelled to be lifted into and out of his bed, that

State of Ohio Laven County ss. ⎬ Court of Am Plea Nov. Term 1827 Personally appeared in open Court (being a court of Record) Thomas Hyette of lawful age, who being duly sworn, upon his oath deponontt & saith that in the year 1817, he married a daughter of John Randall of sd[said] County an applicant for a Pension, that since that time he has been personally acquainted with said John & with the situation & amount of his property, that on the 18 March 1818 said John owned no real estate, he lived on a tract of land which he rented from year to year - He was then personed of one man & colt, two cows - 5 or 6 sheep, a few articles of husbandry or farming utensils & houshold fur- niture- all of which deponant believes did not exceed ninety Dollars in value- That in 1819. s'd [said] Deponent & Randall entered of sutrine land in their joint names- said Randall paid only twenty Dollars toward his part, nothing was ever paid oftnard-ye surtie in in 17.82 I- [in] the 8 years otery was taken & will expire next mont-[month] This deponent & Randell resided on it till 1825 when Deponent by consent of Randall disposed of it. In 1823 said mare of Rundell died & one cow died also- all the sheep were killed except 2 & what became of these deponent cannot say - they were sold to some be as he believes - at same time 1823 a suit of slander was brought by one John Bayley at said Randall & wife for now spoken by his wife, the counsel fees & c attending said suit (which abate by death of wife & the funeral expenses & left sickness consumed all his property. This was in 1824 as deponent believes from this time till 1825 s'd [said] Randall resided with his son Peter to supported him since 1825 This Deponent hath taken & supported him in his family, by private charity-- said Randall from age & nat- real bodily infirmity has been unable to do any business for about five years past he is not unable to go out of the house without assistance- his memory is much impaired he rem embers nothing scantly of matters lately transpired- seems to remem- ber events of his youth much better- has seven children - all married & all poor none of them able to render him these comfort, which he needs without injury to their own families & further this deponent saith not Thomas X Heath His Mark Sworn to in open court Nov. 23. 1827 [illegible] Wheeler Clerk

And I do solemnly swear, That I was a resident citizen of the United States on the eighteenth day of March one thousand eight hundred and eighteen: and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner whatever, disposed of my property or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled, "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the Land and Naval Service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War," passed on the eighteenth day of March, one thousand eight hundred and eighteen: And that I have not nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts, or debts, due to me, nor have I any income other than what is contained in the Schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. Aaron Hitchcock Schedule of real and personal estate, necessary clothing and bedding excepted. One small Rocky Farm, containing about sixty acres in the whole, about twenty five of which are cultivated with a small house and barn upon it. The annual income or rent of the same would be about thirty or thirty five dollars. One old mare worth 20. Three cows worth $40 one two year old steer 15. Two yearling heifer worth 12. One spring calf 2. Ten sheep & 7 Lambs worth 14. About 160 lbs. of live swine worth 4.80. One old ox cart. One old wagon and harness, both worth 30. Sundry other articles of farming tools, old, all worth about 15. One old one horse sleigh and harness, all worth 10. Sundry articles of Household furniture- old- barely comfortable for family the whole worth 18 [$180.80] I am owing about seventy dollars more than I have debts due to me. Aaron Hitchcock. And I do also swear that my occupation is that of a farmer. Am in very feeble health. Am unable to labour. My wife Mary is 57 years of age-in feeble health- Unable to support herself by labour. Son Aaron, aged 29 years - in consumptive habit - unable to labour- in a great measure dependant on me for support. My daughter Anna, aged 25 years, is also sickly - unable to labour - dependent on me for support. Also my son James, with a family consisting of a wife and three small children, living with me, and somewhat dependent on me for support. Sworn to and declared in open court on the 21st day of June, A.D. 1820, Before Phinehas White, Judge. Last words of the Rev. Joseph Cheuvront who died at his home near West Milford, Harrison, County, Virginia, (now West Virginia) March 25, 1832. Since it has pleased God to Deprive me of the power of speech, I bless His Holy Name that I enjoy my mental faculties; my fingers can communicate my wishes on the slate. I address this to you, my children, as a memento which I request each of you to transcribe and keep for future generations. I was born in the city of Strasburg [Strasbourg] in the Empire of France on the second [2] day of February, 1755, was reared in the city of Nantes and received my education when very young. In the year 1771, in the fifteenth [15th] year of my age, I went to England where I remained until 1774, when I embarked for America and landed at Fredricksburg, [Fredericksburg] Virginia, in 1778. I was converted to God in the year following. I united my self with the despised Methodists and by them have been employed in various stations 9viz.) as class-leader, exhorter, steward, local preacher, travelling preacher and presiding Elder, in all of which I have, I believe, given satisfaction to my brethern [brethren]. I have now been in the church fifty-three [53] years and have never had a charge brought against me. I do not say this to boast, but to stimulate you to support and maintain a good character. In the year 1781, at the siege of Yorktown, God delivered me from all tormenting fear and gave me two [2] seals to my ministry. I have filled some important stations in the state, in all of which I have endeavored to establish mine and your character. I have tried to be to you a father and through great difficulties, I have raised you to be what you are. I have often conselled [counselled] you and have endeavored to set good examples before you, yet some of you who profess religion are, I fear, very superficial and luke-warm. I am going to leave you. Must I leave you in the hands of the wicked one? May the Good Lord hear and answer my prayers in your behalf. Try to set the fear of God before your eyes. Do not grieve one another. Live in peace and love together. Be good to your mother, and do not lay anything in her way that might distress her. This is the last advice of your dying father. I now bid you farewell. I am truly resigned to the sufferings I experience.

He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or an annuity, except the present, and he declares that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any State, John Vanantwerp Sworn to, and subscribed, the day and year aforesaid. Stephen Ostrander former Pastor of the church at Schaghticoke H. Knickerbocker Sworn and subscribed the day and year aforesaid. -pension of payments. Can not these claims, at least, that are supported by living evidence, be an exception? Christian Snidow, I believe, is supported, almost entirely, if not wholly by living witnesses. If there are no exceptions to this general suspension, permit me to suggest to the Department to appoint some competent person to examine all the claims in this part of the State, in order that it may be at once ascertained whether they are legal and genuine or fraudulent. If the suspension should be continued for the time, implicated by Mr. Singleton, I doubt not that many very worthy and very needy persons on the pension roll will suffer much. [illegible] Snidow, however, though as worthy as any man under the sun, is not in need, and therefore, would not, probably, suffer by the suspensions; but, if the laws of his country entitle him to a pension, he should be permitted to receive it at once, and not denied the enjoyment of his right on account of the fraud and villainy of some-- If, however, the fraud in the Pension Department have been such as to require the suspensions, I have been informed of, most certainly the honest pensioners ought not to tremble at a temporary inconvenience, though some of them should thereby be subjected to much suffering. STATE OF CONNECTICUT, County of HARTFORD, ss. Special County Court, or Court of Common Pleas, holden by order of the Chief Judge of said Court, on the first Tuesday of August, 1820. On this 1st day of August, 1820, personally appeared in open Court, the same Court being a Court of record for said County, having the power of fine and imprisonment, Luke Adams aged 64 years, resident in Bristol in the County of Hartford, who being first duly sworn according to law doth, on his oath, declare that he served in the Revolutionary War, as follows: In 1776 he inlisted into the company commanded by Capt John Lewis which company was annexed to Col William Dongless's [?] regt where combined 7 months during said time he was in the battle of White Plains in the year 1777 he inlisted for three years into Capt Eli Leavenworth's Company Col Ret[?] Meiggs regt in which company he faithfully served the full three years & was honorably discharged on the 5th of May 1818 I made oath to my services as above stated & received a pension certificate numbered 1156 "And I do solemnly swear, that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March, 1818, and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War," passed on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts, or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the Schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed." To wit 35 acres of broken mountain land together with a small poor old decayed dwelling house & an old barn thereon standing at $490.00 1 yoke of working oxen at ___ 45 3 cows at $15 each ___ 45 2 yearling cattle at $6 each ___ 12 13 Sheep at 75 cents each ___ 9.75 a number of articles of household furniture consisting of Chests tables chair pots etc etc sundry astrites of farming utensils that have been in use about forty years in the whole of 40.00 --- $641. 75 Luke Adams I do also further solemnly swear that I now owe I am indebted to several persons in the full sum of three hundred dollars & I do further swear that my occupation now is & ever has been since I left the army a farmer or husbandman & my ability to pursue it is small & constantly failing by reason of disease & infirmity which infirmity is a painful rheumatism that has been seated upon me.

of the United States on the 18th of March 1818 and that I have not since that time by gift sale or other wise [otherwise] disposed of my property or any part thereof with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provision of an act of Congress entitled an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United states in the revolutionary war" [illegible] on the 18th. day of March 1818, and that I have not nor has any person in Trust for me any property, or securities, contracts or debts due to me; nor have I any income, other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed Schedule of property [illegible] 2 horsed valued at $60 each $120.00 1 little wagon " 30.00 1 Cow and calf [illegible] 18.00 5 [illegible] hogs 7.50 [illegible] 175.50 That he is by occupation a farmer that is in very [illegible] able to pursue it on account of a [illegible] on his shoulder and a general debility. East Rutherford, 21st day of [illegible] Sir, I send this case off for examination it may require to [illegible]. I thought I would send it to your honor for examination it is said by their old esquire her husband was in the revolutionary army. [illegible] or [illegible] this is a woman of his and is now the widow. He left he never applied for a pension for the reason he was worth a little to much to be in [illegible] and in need of assistance among the poor class, But this old lady is now destitute of property and now appeals to our persons for a pension for her husband service in the regular army of the revolutionary War. She prays for such an amount of pension as she may be entitled to in proportion to the length of time of service or may be found on the record of her husbands service and also the bounty land as she is now [illegible] your honor will carefully examine this case soon as possible as she is very needy and reports the case to me. I can send you the copy of this record of her Marriage Certified from the Ministers records if you wish. I took the copy of her Marriage from her bible and also his death. of the highest respect Noah Pastor attorney for Jemima Durkee a Widow of John Durkee deceased

1928 ORIGIONAL CLAIM. Declaration, in order to be placed on the Pension List, under the Act of the 18th of March, 1818. County of Count Fayette State of Penna, [Pennsylvania] SS. On this 16th day of August 1827, personally appeared in open court, (a) being a Court of record (b) for the [lined out: district, county, corporation, as the case may be,] Fayette and State aforesaid Charles Dunnon a resident in said county, aged 70 years, who being first duly sworn, according to law, doth, on his oath, make the following declaration, in order to obtain the provision made by the acts of Congress, of the 18th March, 1818, and the 1st May, 1820: that he, the said Charles Dunnon enlisted (c) for the term of during the war on the ___ day of ___ in the year of 1777 in the state of Maryland in the City of Baltimore in the company (d) commanded by Captain Depont also [served?] under Capt Calaski in the regiment commanded by colonel Carwatt & Col Booce in the line of the state of Penna of Gen Pulaski legion on the ____ continental establishment; that he continued to serve in the said corps [lined out: (or vessel)] until the year 1783 when he was discharged from the service, in Baltimore by Captain Paul Bantalow in the State of Maryland that he hereby relinquishes every claim whatsoever to a pension except the present; that his name is not on the roll of any state, except Maryland [illegible] Penna [illegible] & the state of Georgia & that the following are the reasons for [lined out: not] making [lined out: earlier] application for a pension: that he had made an application before the Honorable Judge James Finley in the year 1820, and that two Witnesses was required to prove his said services that of whom it have not been in his power to procure. That he had previously sent his discharge to the city of Washington by the Honorable J. Smiley a member of [illegible - Congress?] of Said County, and that the said Smiley deceased soon after his return, that the said discharge was left at the City aforesaid. That the said Dunnon was in the Battles and skirmishes of Egharbour, Minisink, in New Jersey, Charlestown South Carolina, Dorchester, Savannah, and Monks Corner that at the latter he the said Dunnon was taken prisoner that at the said Battle of Savannah the said General Pulaski together with many officers and his Soldiers was held, then there few remaining troops was attached [illegible] the Regiment or troops near Charlestown commanded by Colonel Washington. That the said Duncan was ^wounded^ in the leg by a musket ball, at Savannah, also wounded at Monks Corner and that his Major Bernies and those Captains was held who had belonged to General Pulaski Legion. And in pursuance of the act of the 1st May, 1820, I do solemnly swear, [lined out: (or affirm, as the case may be)] that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March, 1818, and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the revolutionary war,” passed on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property, or securities, contracts, or debts, due to me; nor have I any income, other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed (f) That, since the 18th of March, 1818, the following changes have we made in my property: (g) And that there has been no particular change in his property, that his said property are as follows viz One Cow valued at $11.00} four Sheep at 6.00} 3 pigs or stots at 3.00} 1 large Kettle 2.00} 1 Pot one oven Teakettle 3.00} 1 Dreser & contents worth 2.00} 1 pair of trasers 1.00} } and that he has a family viz, his wife Jane aged 61 } years, and a grand child Catharine aged, 8 } years which is all his Family. And that he is a } tanner by occupation though unable to pursuit } That the greater part of his time he is much afflicted } with the rheumatism and lameness, that he has been } unable to labour for about one year past Charles Dunnon Sworn to and declared, on the 14th day of August 1827 before James Todd Prothy I James Todd Prothy of the common court of Layette County do hereby certify, that it appears, to the satisfaction of the court that the said Charles Dunnon did serve in the Revolutionary war, as stated in the proceeding declaration, against the common enemy, for the term of nine months, under one engagement, on the continental establishment. I also certify, that the foregoing oath, [lined out: (or affirmation)] and the schedule thereto annexed, are truly copied from the records of the said Court; and I do further certify, that it is the opinion of the said court, that the total amount in value, of the property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule, is twenty six dollars and fifty cents. In testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand, and affixed the seal of the said court on this 27th day of February 1882 James Todd Prothy

some time in May, was in the battle of the Short hills and then joined the main army at Middle Brook and was drafted into Captain Clarks company in the Artilery and afterwards placed under Capt Carns in said Artilery and was in the battle of Brandywine on the 11 of September 1777 & also in the Battle of Germantown and then moved to Winter Quarters at the Vally forge and remained there until March following and there drafted into Gen. State of Ohio Scioto County ss~ On the Fourth Day of December in the year of our Lord One Thousand Eight hundred and Twenty personally appeared in open Court being the Court of Common Pleas in and for the County of Scioto Southy Copes aged Sixty years Resident in said County of Scioto, who being first duly sworn according to Law doth on his Oath declare that he served in the Revolutionary war as follows, In a company Commanded by Capt John Creppes in the Ninth Virginia Regiment Commanded by Colonel Matthews for and during the period of two years, and that he this Deponent on the Twenty Fourth Day of July in the year of our Lord one Thousand Eight Hundred and Eighteen Petitioned Justice to the law of the United States of the 18th of March 1818. And Received opinion on Certificate Dated the First day of May 1819 and numbered 10.185~ I do Solemnly swear that I was a Resident Citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March 1818. And that I have not since that time by gift, sale, or in any agreement, disposed of my property or any trust thereof with intent thereby to diminish it and bring myself within the provisions of an Act of Congress entitled an Act to provide for Certain persons engaged with the Land and Naval Service of the United States in the war of the Revolution passed on the 18th day of March 1818. And that I have not nor has any person in trust for me any property or Securities Contracts or debts due to me. Nor have I any investments than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed Schedule Two Twelve Gallon Kettles......................$6.00 Southy Copes I do further solemnly swear that the above Schedule is a just and true Inventory of all and every particle of property that was possessed of on the 18th of March 1818. But that I will Receive my Pension Certificate, And have drawn my money present to the said Certificate. I have Purchased with my pension one Cow which has since had a Calf a Number of young Hogs and some articles of Household furniture of the value of about Fifty Dollars. That I have no occupation other than a labourer, That my wife is living aged Sixty years and very infirm. That I am so weakly and infirm and have so helpless a family as to require the assistance of my Country for Support. And I say not~ Southy Copes Sworn to, and declared on the fourth day of december 1820 before the Court. Attest. John R. Turner Clerk.

I find I must retract a word, viz: that the colourd man Supthen was the last case. I had [illegible] the name of Tunis Felter, a case of much hardship from extreme poverty & of much [illegible] There was at first no proof that could be found & the case was suspended: proof was afterward found & has been sent to the office & that case is much better sustained, than some which has been admitted - [illegible] from the very instructions of the Deponant. it is evident, that from the [illegible] of year & [illegible] of individuals it was not believed by the Department that proof could be had in all cases. - In Sutphin's case I believe one [illegible] of objection was that his name was not found on the rolls in the expedition of the Indians This may be the key, viz: _ he was a slave till after the war. & his 2nd name always changed. as he changed master. It is only since the war that he lived with [illegible] Sutphen & has been called Saml. Sutphen. When [illegible] Borger or Bergher. (his new declaration tells) & may stand on the rolls, I am a cold man _ or I am Berger. He was [illegible] in the stead of his master, with is own coment or condition of being [illegible], after [illegible] throughout the whole war, his life, for his masters. _ This perill he undertook & performed faithfully _ but the white man proved faithless & sold him to another person for £192.10.0 [illegible] money & I am at last [illegible] himself by his own have earnings & [illegible] again , the price of his freedom. _ Do not permit our County to visit upon [illegible] I am hear a 2d.. time, the affect of a broken promise, refering in his old age, the little [illegible] promise to faithful military service. _ He is now, & has been for years, a communicant, in good standing in the Barking Church _ a sober, industrious_ meek, humble & [illegible] Christian. whose [illegible] walk & consistant deportent would put the blush many a [illegible] [illegible]. I have some other things on another subject, to say _ but the mail closes in 5 minutes & I must defer them till the morrow. All well with love to [illegible] yours truly L. Conut Hon. F. Fulinghugyer

State of North Carolina Wake County Court of Pleas and General Sessions February Term 1844 commencing on the nineteenth day of February in the year one thousand eight hundred & forty four. This court being a court of record. Personally appeared here in open court on this the day aforesaid to Wit, William Pope a citizen of said county, who made oath in due form of said that he is in the seventy third year of his age, that he was born and has resided his lifetime in the said county. That he was the very near neighbor of John Harrison of said county now deceased and resided very near to him very many years before his death and was personally & _ acquainted with him a great many years and has often heard the said John Harrison speak of his being a soldier in the revolutionary war and recount his hardships and suffering as a soldier at that time, and especially after his capture & detention as a prisoner of war under Lord Cornwallis at Little York, and of his joyful release from his said captivity by General Washington on the surrender of Cornwallis and his army at Little York, and furthermore that the said John Harrison was while he lived a most estimable man and regarded as of the strictest veracity and entire confidence was always placed in his statements as matter of fact. State of North Carolina Wake County I Jas. J. Marriott clerk of the court of pleas & quarter sessions do certify that the foregoing is a true copy of the declaration of Mr. Pope made in open court as above stated and ordered by the said court to be entered of record. In testimony where of I have hereunto affixed the seal of said court & subscribed my name at office in Raleigh 5th March 1844. /Jas. J. Marriott/ CC

life. Three of her neighbors who stayed back were murderd the next day after they left. about two weeks afterward her husband moved to Fort Edwards where he remained about two years. while at fort Edwards her husband was much of his time on duty but the full extent of his services while they resided there. She would not [illegible] but in the spring, summer and fall of 1775 and 1776 her husband was constantly on duty and from early in the spring of 1777 until he was taken prisoner, he was constantly in the service. She further declares that in addition to the distruction of her husbands buildings the British took from her husband and carried away one pair of horses and fifteen or sixteen head of meat cattle and all the valuable property he had and from insufficient inventory was reduced to poverty. That her name before he marriage was Irina Buck. She further declares that she was married to the said John Fisk in the town of Bridport on the fourth day of June in the year seventeen hundred and seventy five by the Reverend Wm Cutler Baptist minister who resided at Ticonderoga. that her husband the aforesaid John Fisk died on the 4th day of July eighteen hundred and two and that she has remained a widow since that period as will more fully appear by reference to the proof hereunto annexed. sworn to and subscribed on the day and year above written before me Joseph Clark, Judge of Madison County Court Irina Fisk (her mark) I further certify that I have been acquainted with the above deponent for many years; that she sustains a good character; is unable from body infirmity to attend Court and from nervous affliction cannot write her name but retains her reasons remarkably and is very intelligent. Joseph Clark Judge of Madison County Court

FINIS Thomas Dixon was born on the day of August 1761 and died on the 9th day of April 1826 being in the 65th year of his age. Ann Dixon was born on December 1771 - And was married in 1793.

was in the Battles immediately preceding the Capture of Lord Cornwallis - and also with the Regiment at the execution of Major Andre. The said Willson has shown me a me a furlough signed by John Lamb Coll. the hand of Coll Lamb was very familiar to me and I have no doubt it is genuine. I therefore have concluded that Willson must have belonged to Coll Lambs Regiment, and also that he was honourably discharged as there was no desertion as late as the date of the furlough. I feel assured that if a correct roll of Capt Samual Lockwoods Company afterward commanded by Capt William Stevens of Lambs Regiment can be found, that the name of David Willson will be found on it. And I am the more confident in this opinion from having conversed with a person transiently in the City of New York, who belonged to the said Regiment, who informed me that he remembered the name of Willson in the said Company. Willson according to his account, immediately after his discharge, went into the Western part of Pennsylvania, and never has received his Land, and of Course he is not on the Register of Persons having received Land - He now appears to be an upright & needy old Man -. New York 2d Nov 1829 Eben Stevens

DISTRICT OF VERMONT, SS. On this 22d day of June 1820 personally appeared in open court, being a county court and court of record, which has power to fine and imprison, and is constituted a court of record by a special act of the Legislature of the state of Vermont, creating said court, within and for the county of Bennington, and state of Vermont, William Pratt aged 59 years, resident in Pownal -- in said county of Bennington -- who being first duly sworn according to law, doth, on his oath, declare that he served in the Revolutionary war, as follows: I served in the company, commanded by Capt Wait Hopkins in the regiment, commanded by Col Seth Warner of the Connecticut - line. Continental troops for the term of three years, served my time out and was honorably discharged-- as will appear by my original declaration on file in the War office, dated the 4th day of April 1818 on which original declaration I have received a pension certificate bearing the number 2,334. AND I do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary war,” passed on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts, or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed. and by me subscribed. The following is a schedule of all the real and personal estate, to wit: 10 acres of land with buildings-- 10 acres of Mountain land-- 1 old horse, old woollen wheel - handsaw - 1 Cow. Sow & 6 young pigs--1 Chest- 1 old chest & drawers, 1 dinner pot, 1 flat iron, old hay rake, 2 Tables, 1 Candlestand, 5 chairs, 6 knives and forks, 6 silver washed tea Spoons, 1 old bush hook, Crockery, 1 looking Glass, 3 or 4 old books, 1 shovel & tongs, 1 Wire Sieve, 1 old pitchfork, 2 small tin trunks, tin & Pewter ware a few articles, 1 Wooden Pail, 1 Chain, 2 old Saddles, 1 axe, 1 scythe, a draft chain, irons for a plough, & Clevice [clevis] & pin, Harrow teeth. I am justly indebted to sundry persons for clothing subsistance & necessaries the full amount of two hundred & eighty nine dollars & 59 cents, most of which are pressing hard for Collection. My occupation has been lately working on a farm when my health has admitted. I am by reason of sickness & infirmity unable to labour any for my support- I have a wife named Rosanna aged 55 has been confined to her bed for five years of a consumption complaint. She never will be able to labour any more-- I have six children viz Nehemiah W. aged 28, Susanna aged 19, David aged 16, Thankfull aged 14, Lucinda aged 12, William aged 10.-- The oldest Nehemiah is now in a State of derangement. He has lived with me ever since he was of age he is a bill of expence to me; he cannot earn any thing. Susanna the 2d one living with me is afflicted with a rheumatic complaint-- she cannot support herself. The four youngest are tolerably healthy but they cannot earn enough for their support- I am so embarrassed & crowded with debts and distressed with sickness of myself & family that had it not been for the charity of my neighbors and the little aid I have received from my pension I could not have subsisted until the present time. I feel myself in need of public or private aid for support. William Pratt Sworn to and declared at Bennington in the county of Bennington and state of Vermont, on the 22d day of June 1820, in open court, before Joel Pratt Clerk I Joel Pratt-- Clerk of Bennington County Court, do hereby certify that the foregoing declaration, oath and the schedule thereto annexed, are truly copied from the record of the said court; and I do further certify, that it is the opinion of the said court that the total amount in value of the property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule, is 350 dollars and 00 cents and upon full proof it is the opinion of the Court that after discharging his just debts the amount of the estate of the said William Pratt does not exceed 60 dollars and 41 cents. In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and affixed the seal of the said court, on this -- 27 day of June ---- 1820 Joel Pratt Clerk of the Court for the County of Bennington 350.00 property 289.59 debt —--------------- 60.41

received during the war, a severe wound in one of his legs, for declarent has often seen the wound. Declarants father during the war re sided on the Savannah river in Screveir County, State of Georgia, where the royalists, in course of the war, deprived him of all he possessed, drove away and killed and appropri ated all his cattle, his principal property, robbed him and his family of the necessary means of subsistence, and burnt down all his houses, so that declarants father and family were cast upon the world without house or home, suffering every hardship and privation and misery that poverty and war could inflict. This Declarant believes that his father had already formed the resolution to apply for his pension, when death in the year 1807, defeated his good purpose. And since then, declarent has failed to apply for his fathers pension. by reason of the many obstacles which seemed to present themselves in the prosecution of such an undertaking. Yet, declarent hopes and believes, that he will be entitled to by the equity of the Statutes of Congress in such cases made and provided, to whatever sum of money that might have been drawn by his father for his services, had he survived to have established his claim. Declarants father died

State of New York Oneida County Alexander Torrence born in the State of Massachusetts, now residing in State of New York in the County of Oneida, being duly sworn on the holy Evangelists testifies and says, that in the month of December in the year 1775 he enlisted into the service of the United States under Capt. James Perry, in Col. [unreadable] Woodbridge's Regiment, in the Massachusetts line, that he remained four or five years in said service & was part of the time in Col. Nixon's Regiment. He received a written discharge from the said Capt Perry, some time after the Indian villages were destroyed by General Sullivan, in which service he was but he has lost his discharge, and cannot recollect the date of it, that he is destitute of learning, and memory very poor that he is sixty nine years of age, that he has no property but one cow, and two young cattle, that by his age and infirmities he is unable to labour but very little, and that he has been under the necessity of having help from the town where he lives, that he is under such needy and low circumstances as to require him to call on his country for assistance, for his support, and further faith not. Alexander Torrence X Mark I hereby Certify that the above deposition was signed and duly sworn to by the above named Alexander Torrence before me at Western in the County of Oneida the 9th day of April 1818: And that I am fully satisfied that Alexander Torrence the above named deponent and applicant served in the revolutionary war against the common enemy, for more than nine months continuous service, and that from personal acquaintance, and knowledge. I have no reason to doubt of the statements contained in the said Deposition, which I transmit --- To the honorable Secretary of War. Prosper Rudd one of the Secretary of War Judges of Oneida County Com. Pleas

For the Christian Advocate and Journal. MR. EDITOR - By giving the following a place in your widely circulating paper, you will confer a favour on the friends of the deceased, and perhaps furnish a useful hint to come of your numerous readers. CAPT. JOHN MAPP, the subject of this notice was born in Virginia, about the year 1759. From thence his father, Littleton Mapp, moved to South Carolina about the commencement of the revolutionary war, where he suffered much from those who were opposed to the liberty of this country. John was active in the defence of his country, and although not more than nineteen years of age, he was promoted to the rank of captain in the army, which office he filled with credit until the close of the struggle for independence. He married the daughter of Col. White, and in 1792 emigrated to Georgia, there he and his companion sought for and obtained the peace and joy of the gospel of Christ. In 1794 they united themselves to the Methodist Episcopal church, of which he continued a useful member until his death. He had been for many years a class steward, and was liberal in the support of the gospel, as also kind to the poor. Brother Mapp had enjoyed good health for many years for a man of his age. On Sabbath morning the 23d of March, he went out to church in good health; in the class meeting he said he still felt as much or more than ever determined to hold out faithful to the end of life; a little time after he felt a pain in one of his teeth and in a moment after in his breast-he then rose, spoke to his wife and they went out, when it was ascertained that he was very ill. Medical aid which was at hand was baffled in every attempt to restore him. He verbally made some distribution of his property. His wife bathed in tears inquired of him what his future prospects were, when he replied with all that confidence and composure that bespoke his entire resignation to the will of God; that his way was clear and that he had no objections to going. By this time preparations were made and he was carried to a house near at hand and laid on a bed, from which, in a few seconds his spirit took its flight (we humbly trust,) to the land of rest. Thus in the short space of an hour's warning he was numbered with the pale nations of the dead, and his spirit ushered into eternity. On Monday the 24th, his remains were removed to his own garden, followed by a number of weeping friends, and there interred to await the resurrection of the just. Oh how uncertain is life! R. SMITH. Greene County, Ga. April 8, 1828.

New Geneva January 28th, 1807 Dr Sir I wish I could interest your feelings in behalf of an old soldier by name Ebenzr Blackshire whose claim of land I lodged in [illegible] Gallatin hands two years ago but on acc. of a deficiency in his Certificate was laid by for some time. Last fall I gave Gallatin one more satisfactory and I believe all that is requisite now, is attention, to the business. This I know from the multiplicity of business which requires the attention of the Secy of the Treaty during the sitting of Congress Mr. G is incapable of applying and in the mean while the poor soldier must suffer the pain of suspense aggravated by the chance of loosing his claim altogether by death, having been for some time past extremely ill, unless some friend to the distressed will interfere in his behalf. To interest you more in his behalf I might add that Blackshire has a large family of helpless children. I remain Dr Lin with sincere regard Your most obdt Servt J W Nicholson John Smilie Esqr

And I do solemnly swear, that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March 1818, and that I have not, since that time, by gift, sale or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War." passed the 18th day of March 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. The number of my family residing with me is two: Their names as follows: My wife, Margaret; and Grandchild John Donaway. Their ages as follows: wife 70 and upwards, boy 12 and more: their capacity to contribute to my support, but very small: wife very infirm in body and fast declining - boy too young to do much. To The Honourable the Representatives of the people of the United States of America in Congress Assembly The Petition of William Scott late a Major in New Hampshire Line, in the Army of the United States, now of the County of Saratoga and State of New York (illegible word) Sheweth That is was with peculiar pain your petitioner was (illegible words) request body in New York January 17_ (year cut off) constrained thereto from motives of misfortune and distress He has struggled with difficulties year after year in hopes that each would be the last, but has been disappointed and finds his embarrassments thicken and become more complex; in his exigence he is again compelled to apply for relief. That he is among that class whose hardships are exceedingly disproportionate to any other Citizens of America Let recurrence be had to the final Settlement with the Army Invalids unfit to return to their usual labor, to support themselves and families. Debts necessarily contracted must be paid. Those securities the only resource; of which to discharge a debt of one pound, required Eight. This or a goal was the only alternative, the former has been preferred by every person of honesty. That the commutation under such circumstances was an adequate compensation for Eight years hard service to those who have been so unfortunate as to lose the use of their limbs and have their constitution ruined cannot be supposed at best it only leaves them upon a footing with those who never received a wound and what is still worse is to exist as objects of Obloquy in the vicinity of those unprincipled men who deserted and bore arms against their Country and are now enabled through the Liberality of their Master to live in splendour and affluence whilst many of those who have aided in conquering them are suffering under the most Distressing Penury.

The Reverend and much beloved Brother George Frankling was born the 15th of May 1761. Entered on the ministry early in life and devoted much of his time in the service of God and was a great blessing to the church that knew him, He was one of the Convention of this state, afterwards was one of the General Assembly for several years, spent his life much to the satisfaction of his friends and acquaintances and died from home on a rout of preaching on the 16th of February 1816 having been our pastor for nearly seven years Georgia Washington County This is to certify that the above is a true extract from the Regular Church Book of the Baptist Church at Jordan's Meeting House (state & county aforesaid Given under my hand this 22nd February 1845 Owen C. Pope Church Clerk Davisboro Washington County Georgia

Berlin (New Britain) Feby 21st 1833 Dear Sir This letter will accompany the application of Lemuel Smith whose papers were returned - we hope for evidence will be satisfactory as to proof of his claim - much pain has been taken, some further proof is annexed - I have supposed the objection No. 10 in the brief was an error. as it was the same text that the Clerk has affixed to all the papers - is the only one when in the Office - and is on the same [illegible] orPhrase used in the different Office in this vicinity - the name of the district, with the word Probate An early decision is urgently requested - none have been granted to my knowledge in their District; - the applicants are disheartened thinking they never to get their rights - many are very needy - some are dead 3 have died since their papers were sent 3 have gone to the poor house 2 are near the close of life by cancerous affliction - the expectation of something to assist them in their distress in the closing terms is great indeed! Yours with Esteem Thomas Lee

Westmoreland County State of Virginia On this the 6th day of March 1834 personally appeared before me a justice of the peace for said county William Brann Sr. a resident of the county and state aforesaid. Aged 85 years and 10 months who being first duly sworn according to law doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the act of congress passed June the 7th 1832. That he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers and served as herein stated. I was born in the aforesaid county of Westmoreland on the 6th day of May 1748 according to my fathers family record which I now have in my possession in my fathers family bible. I have ever lived and do still continue to live in the aforesaid county only when I was in the service of my country. To the best of my knowledge in the year 1777 I was drafted to perform an 18 months tour of duty and having no person to work but myself and having a wife and several helpless children (which wife is now living and is 82 years of age), I concluded if I left them for so long a period of time they must suffer. I therefore hired a man to take my place who was at that time bound to serve as a servant for seven years for which I gave the enormous sum of nine thousand pounds of tobacco which amount by the assistance of my friends I actually paid and was then of having the liberty of remaining with, and labouring for my wife and children. But contrary to my expectation, I was immediately enrolled with the militia and ordered on guard and marched to Sandy Point on the Potomac River under Captain Daniel Morgan and Lieutenant William Atwill where we continued to the best of my recollection 5 months from thence we marched to Peckalone where we stayed 2 months from thence to Baileys warehouses where we stayed 5 months from thence to Momony ferry where we stayed one months under Captain George Garner from thence back to the Rapahanock River where I was placed under Captain Harrison for 2 months. I was then ordered down to the siege of Wallis at Yorktown but in consequence of a desparate rising under my right arm I was examined by Captain Harrison and sent home as being entirely unfit for duty where I remained for several months unable to render any service to myself or family during the aforesaid time of duty I served under command of three different colonels. To wit Colonel Lee, Colonel Washington, and Colonel Lane. I have no documentary evidence of any service but am well satisfyed that I served at least sixteen months during which time I rendered no service for myself or family.

hereby Certify, That I have known and been acquainted with Samuel Billings of Newport in the County of Newport and State of Rhode Island &c a Tailor by trade, for upwards of Fifty years, that he has been one of the Watchmen of the Town for several years, and continued a Watchman as long as he was able to do his duty, he is now in the Seventy ninth year of his age, weak afeeble needy and destitute of the comforts of life, he not being able to work but very little at his trade if he could get it to do. In Witness whereof I have hereunto set my hand and affixed the Seal of the said Town of Newport this Thirty first day of July in the year of our LORD. One thousand eight hundred and Eighteen. [signed] Jonathan Almy Town and Council Clerk for the Town of Newport

Applicant was in the service of the U.S. one town of a month under Capt. Ferguson [crossed out] no Fulkinson - Applicant served one tour under Capt Vanosdol of a month's duration: In this tour he was between Pluckamin & Bound Brook when intelligence arrived of the capture of Genl Lee and applicant with others cut across by the mountain road from Puckamin towards Benj Vale's woods and came out some four miles South of Baskingridge meeting house; but the Brittish had taken a different road from the one they came upon. Freelinghyson was colonel on this occasion - Applicant cannot say who was the Captn at the battle of Monmouth but thinks it was Rickey-- he well remembers of suffering from heat & thirst on his march from near Princeton to the field of battle - after getting on the trail of the Brittish the wells were found to have been injured by them Cow's paunches nails logs stores and all manner of filth having been thrown into them. He is sure of having served more than a month at the time in which the battle of Monmouth took place - Applicant has no doubt he served more than three years out of the five first years of the war 1 applicant was born in Morris County NJersey apl. 14. 1754 2 I have a record of my age in my big bible copied from a record in my father bible 3 When called into service I was living in Sommerset County NJersey-- I have lived since the Revolutionary war thirteen yrs in Washington County Penn and the rest of the time in Belmont County Ohio 4 Requisitions were made for a draft, but applicant volunteered and agreed to continue to volunteer as often as the requisition should be made and no draft was made on his company that he recollects there being a sufficient number of volunteers he never served as a substitute 5. Col. Wines. Col Frelinghuysen Major Davison Genl Heard Capt Bailey, Helms, Vanosdol, Parker, Cory, Tunison, Fulkinson 6. I never received a discharge. I served in the capacity of sergeant the whole time I served- 7. David Lockwood Jeremiah Hays Zachariah Hays Robt Dent Esq, Benjm Ruggles late Senator John Patterson formerly of Congress H. R., Jas Caldwell Do There are many towns that for want of remembering the names of the captains cannot be particularized, the applicant however is certain that he is not wrong in the aggregate
