We the heirs of George Clark Decicesd (deceased?), who was a Lieutenant of the fourth batalion of Lancaster County do request & petition & desired request Congress & War Department to give us a reward for our afflicted fathers Labours who is now deceased for we are Needy of Some Support & would be glad if Congress and war Department would remember & give the Heirs of George Clark deceased something now for our father never Got any Reward nor no other person for him which we trust that there is no record. Neither Congress or War Department that he received pay for his sufferings & Labours for in the year of seventeen hundred and seventy seven on the fifteenth Day of November General Ervin gave Command to meet the british on Chesnut Hill Where they had an engagement our father being a Lieutenant and Having a detachment of the Militia being under command of Cournal John Rogers who returned our father thanks for his brave performance & Soldiership who gave from under his hand at Head Quarters near to white mash the Second Day of January Seventeen Hundred and Seventy Eight under the Militia General Ervins Brigade which paper we send with the within with John Rogers Cornals Signature to it wherein my father received a flish [flesh]wound in his left arm & in the time of the battle a field officer by the Name of Bull Said George Clark Lieutenant you are wounded your shoe is full of blood See how the Blood Gushes out of your Shoe who also said Clark watch behind yanders Logg a Heshion is aiming to Shute you our father who was in danger turned & shot the top of his head off the Heshion Had a singular good Gun or riffle they wanted my father to take his gun but my father Refusd to take his Gun also in a battle a Bullet when he had his Hair pinnd up with a silver wire above his ear pinen it his eye the bullet took the pin and could Hair away & it Causd his right eye to run water & was weak untill the Day of Death also in a Battle our father said when fighting with the English a Canon Ball fell just at his feet & Splasht the black mud on his stockings that the stain never came out till they were wore out when on a retreat he said he stoopt Down as he run & lifted up a hand full of Mud & water & oh how good it tasted he said they were at one time three days & three nights without any thing to eat on Centery at another time He got behind a tree the Hesshions tryed to kill him the tree he was behind ┃ Next to them was cut to peices from the Roots higher then a mans head with the bullets also Elizabeths Hubleys Description of Hearing my father say he was glad to see her a widow of Captain Barnard Hubley for he was well┃

[Lexington?] March 18, 1837 Dr Sir Enclosed please find the papers of John Christian a Revolutionary Pensioner. Mr Christian is blind and has been for some time in the city Poor House & has failed to draw his pension; and by your regulations it appears necessary to send his papers for your inspection - I will thank you to return them as spedily [quickly] as possible, as the old man is very needy and helpless - being confined to his bed. In haste your respectfully James S. Hickman Col. J. L. Edwards Comr. of Pensions

adelphia in considerable pain and there joined his company. He rode part of the way to the City, but finding it much more painful than walking in consequence of the jolting of the vehicle, he was forced to go nearly the whole of the way on foot, after being there for about ten days, he was discharged, but unable to return home immediately in consequence of the wound in his knee, having gathered and become worse, he accepted of the friendly shelter offered by Captain Wood an accquaintance [acquaintance] with whom he remained for about three weeks, at the expiration of which time he returned to his residence in Westtown. When he first entered the service he lived in West Town Township County of Chester, and at the commencement of each of the two successive terms he lived at the same place. He has no documentary Evidence in his possession, nor does he know of a single person living whose personal testimony he can procure as to his Services Answers to the Interrogatories prescribed by the War Department 1. Where and in what year were you born? According to the best of my recollection I was born in the Township of Westover, County of Chester and State of Pennsylvania, on the 17th day of January in the year 1758 2. Have you any record of your age; and if so, where is it? I have no record of my age, it was contained with that of my brother's and sisters in the Family Bible which was destroyed together with many other articles of property, on the day of the Battle of Brandywine by the English who broke into my fathers house.- 3. Where were you living when called into the service; where have you lived since the revolutionary war, and where do you now live? When first called into the service I lived with Titus Taylor (now deceased, who was an Elder and married brother of Captain Thomas Taylor under whose command I served a portion of time) in the Township of West Town and County of Chester. I have lived in different places since the revolutionary war To Wit in New London Township in said County for about 13 years, in East Bradford Township in the same County about 14 years, in Kennett Township of this County about 10 or 12 years. From the last named Township I moved into Delaware State and resided there about five years. From this State moved to Birmingham Township in this County about a year since where I at present live 4. How were you called into service; were you drafted, did you volunteer or were you a substitute? And if a substitute for whom:

The Court Propounded the following interrogatories to the applicant who made the following answers First. Where and in what year were you born? Answer. I was born in the City of Burlington State of New Jersey, January 1st 1764 Second. Have you any record of your age, and if so where is it? Answer. I have a record of my age in the family Bible which is now in the possession of my Step Mother who lives in Burlington New Jersey Third. Where were you living when called into service; where have you lived since the revolutionary war, and where do you now live? Answer. I was living in Burlington New Jersey when I entered the service, I have lived in Burlington, New Jersey and the City of New York since the Revolutionary war and I now live in the City of New York. Fourth. How were you called into service, were you drafted, did you Volunteer, or were you a substitute? And if a Substitute for whom? Answer. I was a Volunteer Fifth. State the names of some of the regular officers who were with the troops where you served such Continental and Militia Regiments as you can recollect, and the General circumstances of Your service. Answer. I can State the names of General Wayne, Colonel Stevens, Colonel Lamb / French Count Dillon Major Lee, Captains Payton, Cairns and Rudolph of Major Lee's Corps of Horse. Captain Doughty of Col. Steven's Regiment Lieutenants James Giles, ~ Peck ~ Morris ~ Guion and William S. Pennington of Colonel Lamb's Regiment of Artillery I can recollect Col. Stevens' Regiment of Infantry Colonel Lambs Regiment of Artillery. Major Lees

Schedule of my property, Necessary bedding & clothing excepted One Horse 15 years old $25 00 two cows $16 00 the house hold furniture Kittles Sugar & Mettle including tea Kettle as aforesaid included in said Bake oven and other iron kettle 20.00 4 hogs heads 4 00 our plough 2.00 1 set Gee is house hold furniture chairs, 1 Small Pitcher of every kind & discrip tion owned by me $20.00 part of an old waggon 6 00 one Loom 2.00 part of a log chair 1. 75 2 Small Stacks of hay 7.00 a Quantity of corn 20.00 [Totaled] $126.25 The house hold furniture of every Kind and discription as aforesaid included in said $20.00 consists of one chest two old tables, six knives & forks 6 Iron Table Spoons no Tea Spoons, 7 or 8 plates 6 cups & Saucers, one churn, 6 chairs, 1 Small pitcher 1 wheel Spinning, 1 Reel our meat Tub, and few other articles of little or no value- the said George King declarant as aforesaid on his oath aforesaid further declares and States that he is by occupation a Farmer, that from his advanced age, and in creasing infirmities together with his poverty he is unable to pursue it, and that his family consists of his wife aged fifty four years after debilitated with Rheu matism, his own mother Jane King aged Eighty nine and his wifes mother Priscilla Bowling aged Seventy six years, that they are all dependent upon him for Support and are unable to contribute any thing towards their own maintenance in conse quence of their great age feebleness & ill health George X King his mark Sworn to and declared in open Court on the twenty first day of October AD 1828 before the said Court Ellgry Hedges Clerk

Declaration In order to obtain the benefit of the Act of Congress of the 7th of June 1832 State of New York Allegany County ss On this third day of October 1838 personally appeared in open court before the Court of Common Pleas in and for the said County of Allegany now sitting Francis Postle a resident of the town of Friendship in the County of Allegany and State of New York aged Eighty three years who being first duly sworn according to law doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress passed June 7th 1832. That he enlisted in the army of the United States in the year 1778 as a private in a company commanded by a Captain Moody whose Christian name the declarant does not now recollect which company belonged to Col Antony Lambs Regiment General Knox's Brigade. This declarant enlisted in the early part of the year 1778 at Fishkill in the State of New York, the period of his enlistment was for during the war. This declarant was born in the city of Prague in Bohemia and came to America in the year 1777. He was a tailor by trade and previous to his enlistment was working at his trade at Fishkill, soon after his enlistment and he thinks in the spring or summer of 1778 he was marched with a detachment of the American Army to Danbury in the State of Connecticut and thence to a place called White Plains in the State of New York where he remained till in the month of October of that year, when by order of Col. Lamb he was transferred to West Point in the State of New York and attached to the garrison where he was employed in his capacity as a tailor in the manufacture of clothing for the American Army. That he continued at West Point in that employment with the exception of occasional calls on

part of the time with Genl. Rutherford. was stationed a while at Swan's plantation and Monroe's Bridge on little River. and was next marched to North East bridge. when we first had intelligence of the surrender of Lord Cornwallis. this was now as well as this Declarant can remember on the 1st of November 1781. That he was at Raft Swamp when his three month expired but of the request of his superior officers he (with many others) remained one month longer and at the expiration of the four month [four month underlined]was duly discharged on having served for months by Capt. Dickerson [having...Dickerson underlined] and returned home. that in this tour this declarant was in a legally organized Corps and called into service by competent authority. that he knows of no person living that served with him in this tour. that in all he served ten months [ten months underlined] and as private [private underlined]. this declarant states that he was born in this County on the 14th day of February 1763 as appears by a record of his age. that he was living in this County when he entered this service and has been living there ever since. that when he entered the services he was drafted [drafted underlined] and volunteered [volunteered underlined]. that he knew Col Lytle, Colonel Mebane, Col. Nash and others cont. that he knew Col Moore, Col Thaxton, Col Murphey, Genl Butler, Genl Eaton, Genl Rutherford, and other militia officers. that he received discharges but that they were now lost. that his 1st discharge he received from Capt. Jamm. that his 2nd he received from Capt. Nichols. that his 3rd he received from Capt. Dickerson. that he is known in his neighborhood to Genl. Joseph Allison and Samuel Madden. who testify to the declarant's being a man of truth and reputed to have been a revolutionary soldier. that there is no clergyman living near to him who has any knowledge of his revolutionary services that he knows of. that the reason he did not apply earlier for a pension was that he did not know of any living witness of his services till within a few weeks back. that he is now old and infirm and cannot travel without much pain. He hereby relinquishes ever claim whatever

Moore State of North Carolina }ss Edgecombe County On this 3rd day of May in the year of our Lord one thousand and eight hundred and forty eight personally appeared before me John G Williams one of the acting Justices of the Peace in and for said County Micajah Pettaway a Revolutionary soldier and after being sworn upon the Holy Evangelist of Almighty God, saith that he is in his eighty eighth year and that he is a pensioner at the rate of one hundred and twenty dollars and seventy nine cents per annum. That he was well acquainted with Simon Edwards and Sally his wife, that they moved [illegible] in his neighborhood about forty years ago from the lower part of the County

Declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress, passed June 7th 1832- State of New York County of Chenango ⎬ ss. On this twenty fourth day of August in the year of our Lord, 1832, personally appeared before Hezekiah Read Esq. one of the Judges of the court of common pleas in and for the County of Chenango aforesaid, at [illegible] the in said county, John A. Alden, a resident of the town of [illegible] in said County, aged Seventy years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth, on his oath, make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress passed June 7th 1832. That by reason of bodily infirmity, having not been able to labor for some time, or be about without pain, he does not feel able to attend court to make this declaration That he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers, and served as herein stated- That he was born at Medway in the State of Massachusetts, in the year, 1762; there it is recorded, and he has a record in his bible at home-- That he enlisted, at said Medway, where he then resided, the latter part of July or forepart of August, 1778, for one month under Capt. Adam Peters of Medfield, adjoining Madway, in Col Hawes Regiment -- he does not remember the names of the other officers of either the company or regiment-- On joining said regiment they marched to Rhode Island, and the second day after arriving there, was in a battle fought there at that time under Gen. Sullivan, and retreated with him off the Island after serving eighteen days in this town he was dismissed at Howlands Ferry, not being [illegible] longer-- the regiment returned In the month of May 1779 or first part of June, he again enlisted at Medway, for six months- He does not recollect the names of his company officers, but on enlisting he entered his company and joined Col. Hawes Regiment at Providence in Rhode Island, he believes- soon after went to Bristol, and remained there among the other troops, perhaps, 2 weeks, in the meeting

STATE OF VERMONT, ) Orange County, ss. ) On this third day of July 1820 personally appeared before the County court for said county of Orange in open court, (said court being a court of record, agreeably to the laws of this state, having the power of fine and imprisonment, &c.) Josiah Eastman aged 59--years, resident in Bradford in said county of Orange who being first duly sworn, according to law doth on his oath declare, that he served in the revolutionary war, as follows: that he enlisted for three years in March 1781 and served untill the End of the War and was discharged. he served in Capt Fryes Company and Col Dearborns Regiment Newhampshire line that he made his original declaration on the Seventh day of April 1818 has received a Pension Certificate, No. 12399 And I do solemnly swear, that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War," passed on the 18th day of March, 1818;---and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. 47 acres of land two baskets of Corn 1/2 bushel of Beries 2 bushels of Beans, two bushels of potatoes three small hogs, farming tools valued at $11 household furniture valued at $1 Bible & hymnbook & Testament all amounting to the Sum of $383.50 [underlined] and I am honestly owing persons the sum of $125--[underlined] I am by occupation a farmer and by reason of sores on my legs for many years and giving pain I am unable to work to earn my living, and by reason of a sore on my face I am afrade of loosing my eye sight my wife is about my age and not able to work but a small part of her Time my Son Hazen B Eastman aged 16 years troubled with Deafnefs & a Sworn to and declared on the third day of July 1820 before said court. HEG McLaughlin--CLERK. STATE OF VERMONT, ) Orange County, ss. ) I, HEG McLaughlin clerk of the County court for the county of Orange do hereby certify, that the foregoing oath, and the schedule thereto annexed, are truly copied from the record of the said court:---And I do further certify, that it is the opinion of the said court, that the total amount in value of the property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule is three hundred Eighty four dollars fifty Cents [illegible seal affixed to the left of the above paragraph] In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand, and affixed the seal of said court, at Chelsea ["Bradford" stricken out] this third day of July 1820 HE G McLaughlin Clk

4th Judicial District of Maryland On this 9th day of March 1821, personally appear in open Court in the County Court of Caroline County, in the 4th Judicial District in the State of Maryland being a Court of record, constituted by the laws of this State a court of (ill) Law, with civil and criminal Jurisdiction to an unlimited extent. James Due aged some more than sixty years, resident in Caroline County in the State Maryland who being first duly sworn according to law doth on his oath declare and say, that he served in the revolutionary war as follows to wit, that he enlisted in the spring of the year 1778 under Captain John Hawkins of Queen Anne County in the State of Maryland for the term of nine months that at the expiration of that time he enlisted for three years & soon after he returned home on furlough, and on his return to the Army, he again enlisted for during the wars, that he was a little in the rear of the Army at the Battle of the White plains and was in the Battle at Elizabeth Town and was there taken prisoner by the Refugees and detained some more than ten months and that after he again joined the army, he was in several skirmishes, and finally in the seige of little York and Capture of the British army under Lord Cornwallis that he did by a declaration made in Queen Annes County Court on or about the fourth day of November 1818. obtain a certificate of Pension No 5876 and has since received his pension to the 4th day of March 1820. And I do solemnly swear that I was a resident Citizen of the United States on the 15th day of March 1818 and that I have not since that time by gift sale or in any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress in title and act to provide for certain persons engaged in the Land and Navel service of the United States in the revolutionary war passed on the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities, contracts or debts, due to me nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereunto annexed, and by me subscribed to wit. 15 acres of poor sandy Land-- 6 horned cattle of different ages- 8 hogs do do de 2 cupboards and some Cupboard ware - 2 tables -- 6 chairs, some articles of Iron & wooden ware - 1 old horse Cart (small)-1 old plough & Harrow (very ordinary that this deponent owes about the sum of $41.00 to J. Bradly F. H. Hawley, H. Meeds J. Dyett, D. Capon, R. Cooper & K. Godwin that I am by occupation a country Shoemaker and with the increase of years, I experience the failure of my sight together with my other bodily powers, that I have residing in my family one woman named Elizabeth Cevil, a house keeper aged about forty years, one son named Enock aged 26 years who works for his own maintainance, one other son named John aged 17 years employed in the tillage of my lot of ground - one daughter, named Rachel, aged 17 years, and one daughter named surrena, aged 12 years both of whom are employed in my family James Due (his X mark) March Term 1821. The Court value the property in this case to the sum of One hundred Dollars, William B. Martin, James B. Robbins, William Whittington I Joseph Richardson, Clerk of Caroline County Court aforesaid, do hereby cer tify that the aforegoing oaths, and the schedule thereto annexed, are truly copied from the record of said Court; and I do further certify that it is the opinion of the said Court that the total amount in value of the property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule is forty Dollars

[illegible]iz. 1 old waggon y. head of horned Cattle Old and young 2 horse creatures, 9 hogs all sizes, 16 hist draw-[illegible], 2 sets gears, 1 old plough, 3 hoes, Matlocks, 3 A[illegible], 5 pieces cron ware, 1 Old Cupb[illegible]ds & Cupb[illegible]ed furnature - I have bargained for 90 acres of poor land for which I owe $300. and which had been valued by men at 220 dollars; and the per-son from whom I have chased will not take back the land for what remains due - Should my pension be Hoped I must loose all as that is the only means I have of ever paying it - My family consists of my wife [illegible] aged 56 years, lotterebly [illegible]thay, son Thomas 16 healthy, daughter Elizabeth 18 do healthy, daughter Jane 10 do healthy, grand child Michael 3 do, healthy - I was a farmer while able to follow it, but from age and bodily infirmities am now unable to work; I am indebted to sundry persons including the price of the land 610 dollars and have due me from sundry persons 170 dollars Sworn to, and declared, on the third day of October, in the year of our Lord 1820, before the [illegible] President and his associate Judge - Michl Dolin Wm Sample Washington County ss Prothy I William Sample Prothonotary of [clerk of crossed out] the Court of Common Pleas in and for said County do hereby certify, that the foregoing declaration and the sche-dule thereto annexed, are truly copied from the record of the said court; and I do further certify, that it is the opinion of the said court that the total amount in value of the property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule is three hundred and fifty nine including the [illegible] piece of the [illegible] dollars and fifty - - cents. great pain and difficulty. His discharge, which he received from General Maxwell has been lost, these many years. He was discharged about the twentieth of October A.D. Seventeen hundred and seventy eight. He further saith that about the fourth of February A.D. Seventeen hundred and seventy nine he again enlisted at Carpenter's or Station point, under Captain Abraham Westfall and Major Thomas Dewitt, that he and the rest of the men were stationed at Westfall's fort in Peenpack, State of New York, for the protection of then frontier inhabitants, that during the eleven months he was out on the tour his services were those of a ranger, and Indian spy, that their duty was, to be out on the scout four days, and four days in the fort, that he then served eleven months, after which time he went to Montague township Sussex County New Jersey where he married and moved into Pennsylvania, on the Masthope Creek in now Lackawaxsen township, Pike County, where he lived twenty one years thereabouts. He further says that after the period of his return from his enlistments he was drafted in the New York Militia, under Captain Miller and Colonel Sowards, and served one month, that about six months after this he went out as a volunteer with about twelve others to Aquaga (this part stricken by hand: his brother Benjamin Cox, Henry Wilhelmus and Solomon and Henry Vanetten were of his party) they captured two tories of the name of Increase Miller and James Wood and also took from the Indians and tories twenty two horses, apart of which had been taken from Peenpack where he then lived, that about one year afterwards he again went out as a volunteer, as one of a scouting party, and was out ten days. They went from Minisink up to the mouth of Mangap a distance of eight or ten miles. They captured two tory spies of the name of Robert Land and Ned Heeks. They delivered their prisoners up to a garrison which was then at what was called the Point meeting house near Carpenter's point. The prisoners afterwards as he understood made their escape and went to Canada. This party consisted of himself, his brother Benjamin Cox, Wilhelmus and Solomon Kirkendall, Henry Vanetter and five or six others. He also further saith that on several occasions, and at various times other than those enumerated, he was warned out, to scout, and reconnoiter on the frontiers for the protection of the inhabitants. He saith that he has no documentary evidence other than that annexed to his declaration, that he never received any discharge than the one above alluded to, that Edward Allen is a minister of the Gospel of the Presbyterian Church and that Toby Rockwell and John Brink are two of the oldest inhabitants and residents in the neighborhood where he now resides and has resided for the last twenty four or twenty five years, and will as the deponent

in the schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed he further states that his occupation is a tiller of the ground. As date as followeth viz he has a wife Rachel about 44 years of age. She is unhealthy often afflicted with a cough & as he thinks effected with the consumption and illy able to labour that he has eleven children, 2 [?] of whom are married, nine living with him, eight of whom are daughters, 4 of whom are nearly grown, none of whom are healthy & are unable to support themselves and one of them deranged the others are small and unable to do but little labour. 2 of them nearly deaf he further states that he has one horse beast worth about the sum of $20 no more. 5 head of Cattle worth $25 and no more. 16 head of hogs worth $20 and no more. 3 beds furniture worth $30 and no more. Small articles of household & Kitchen furniture worth $20 & no more. 3 geese worth about 00.75. That there is nothing owing to him and that he earns about four dollars. He prays for support agreeable to the several acts of Congress upon that subject William Warmack William Golding & Henry Smith personally appeared in open Court and made oath they are acquainted with the above named William Warmack that they believe the above statements made by him are true, as also the Schedule of Property thereto annexed This day John Stone & Thomas White also

I am a drowning. The cry of my companion in distress gave me a fresh impulse. I swam to the shore run opposite to him & directly found three poles, which had been washed up on the beach about 12 or 15 feet long . I flung one toward him but it did not reach him; I flung the second without success, the third I pushed toward him until the further end reached him, he [hired] it & [sank] to the bottom. I then exerted myself with all my might & drew him out I hardly know how. As soon as he came to a little & could speak, he cried out O Lord, God, York, Wallace if it had not been for you, I should have been in the eternal world. I told him not to make any noise as the enemy might be watching us in ambush. I thus wrung his clothes & dressed him & put on my own & we set out to find the American encampment. But it soon became so dark that we lost our way and in a short time we found ourselves in an open field near the enemy Guard. We then returned into the woods & remained in a secure place until the moon rose which appeared to rise directly in the water. I [however] told Webster the moon must be right. And we traveled on until we came to the road that lead north & south just as the enemy fired their [nine] on clark Gen. But we did not know whether to go north or south. Our object was to find Genl Warners encampment & deliver our excerps to him. But we were not certain whether he was north or south of us & we might fall into the enemys hands let us go which way we would. & the whole plan of our officers fail or success. [] this trying dilemma we agreed that one should go north followed

[handwritten] State of Vermont Rutland County ss} I Timothy Prince of Benson in the County of Rutland and State of Vermont depose and say that I was born in ^[insert] at Stoningtown [Stonington] Connecticut the year 1752 that I was sixty five years old the10th day of June in the year 1817 that in the month of December 1775 or January 1776 if I recollect the dates correctly I enlisted into the Continental army for the term of thirteen months under Capt Chapman of New London Connecticut who was ^[insert] afterwards appointed a Major and was killd [killed] in the retreat from New York in 1776 and a few days after I enlisted I joind [joined] Col Persons Regiment at Roxbury near Boston Connecticut Line of troops I was stationed at Roxbury until the British retreated from Boston and then marched to New York, adn after we arrived to New York Colonel Persons was appointed a Brigadier General and commanded over Brigade and Col Tyler commanded one Regiment I was in the retreat from Long island to New York & out of New York to Harlem plains near Kings bridge and in Jany [January] I was discharged with honor from the army at Peekskill after serving out the time of my Enlistment and returned home and in the month of March 1777 I again enlisted in the Continental army for nine months under Capt Eldridge Col Prentiss's Regiment and Genl Persons Brigade I immediately joind [joined] the regiment at New haven and I believe in the month of June following joind [joined] the main army under General Washington at a Place called White marsh in Pennsylvania near Philadelphia and put up for winter quarters at Valley forge and after having served out my enlistment was discharged and returned home & in the month of August 1778 was again one month in the service and in the retreat with Genl Sullivan from Rhode Island and int he month of March or April as near as I can recollect in the year 1779 I again enlisted for one year into Captain Carr's company Genl Conwill's Boat guard Col I forget I was stationed at tivertown [Tiverton] until the British retreated from Rhode island and then was stationed at Newport until my year expired and was honorably discharged and returned home my discharges are long time worn out and lost by moving many times from place to place I have always been poor and am now an old man and reduced in circumstances as I am less able to labor have no property either real or personal except one cow four sheep and one old horse worth not more than fifteen dollars have a family and stand in real need of assistance from my country and further this deponent saith not attest Phiny Smith Timothy his X mark Prince State of Vermont Rutland County ss} Sworn before me at Ansell this 11th day of April 1818 attest Phiny Smith Chief Judge of Rutland County Court I the subscribing authority hereby certify that I am of the opinion & it appears to my satisfaction that the above named Timothy Prince Belonged to the army ^[insert] of the revolution & served against the enemy as stated in the above deposition and that I am fully satisfied he is as destitute of property as above represented in his testimony - In testimony whereof I have set my hand and caused the County Court seal to be affixed the date above written Phiny Smith Chief Judge of Rutland County Court By order of Judge Smith R. Temple Clk

Billings of | Elba | 12.00 To | Roswell Turner of | " | 3.75 To | Calvin Jacobs of | " | 3.50 | | | $60.60 And the deponant [deponent] further says his necessary wearing apparel, and bedding, for himself and family, does not Exceed forty dollars in value. That his occupation is a farmer. and being very unwell, in consequence of the fever and Ague, has not been able to do any labour [labor] of consequence for Ten months past. that he has a wife named Phebe, aged fifty three years, whose health is very good for a person of her age, and further he has Six children, whom he had to support. Vis. Polly, aged 17 years. Stephen aged 20. years, Orrin, aged 12 years. Philemon aged 10. years. Samantha aged 8. years. Phylinda aged 6. years. which compose his family, his situation is particularly needy, and stands in need of assistance John Wellman Sworn and Subscribed June 16th 1820 in Open Court Before Mr S Cumings Clerk of Gen. The deponent Henry Holdaway further maketh oath that he is by Occupation a farmer or Labourer and that by reason of a sore leg he has for nearly three years been unable to procure a Maintenance by his labour, and that his leg continues sore and renders him almost helpless that his family Residing with him consists of his wife Eleanor aged fifty eight years and two Daughters Eleanor aged twenty years and Rebeca aged fourteen Years. that his wife and Youngest Daughter are both feeble and infirm from continual Indisposition, but that his Daughter Eleanor is able to work and is the Principle support of the family but that with all their efforts they have not been able to raise bread for the family for several Years and that he must sell a part of his small Flock for bread this Year. The deponant [sic] Henry Holdaway further maketh Oath that the original declaration upon which he obtained a pension is not in his Possession, and he supposes is filed in the War office at Washington bearing date the 15th day of September AD. 1818. and that his Pension certificate bears date the [blank] day of [blank] AD. and Numbered his Henry X Holdaway mark Sworn to and subscribed in open court Augt. 1st, 1820} R. Martin C.W.C.C.

Page 4 State of Virginia Rockingham County Sch. This day personally appeared David Rolston aged between 76 & 77, before the subscriber a Justice of the Peace in and for said County and made oath in due form of law that in the year 1781 he served a tour of Militia service under Richard Ragan who was the Captain of the Company: The draft was for three months, but they served three months and ten or twelve days, and were discharged only one or two, or perhaps three days before the British army under Lord Cornwallis, publicly marched out & surrendered although he understood the treaty of capitulation was concluded upon before they were discharged. The regiment to which Capt. Ragan's company was attached was commanded by Col. Dark. David Rolston Sworn to & subscribed by said David Rolston, who is known to me as a man of the very highest character for veracity, and his statements on oath entitled to full credit: he is also known to me as a revolutionary pensioner of the United States. Given under my hand this 23rd day of March 1837. Abraham Smith State of Virginia Rockingham County Sch. This day personally appeared Daniel Ragan aged between 64 and 65 years before the subscriber a Justice of the Peace in and for said County and made oath in due form of law that he was born in the year 1772, and he has always understood from his parents and believes that he has a distinct recollection N of his father the late Richard Ragan deceased setting out from his residence near Harrisonburg, Rockingham County, Virginia; to go on an expedition against the Indians. This affiant supposes he might have been five, or six years old at the time, and it might have been in the year 1777 or 1778. He had a perfect recollection of his younger brother, his mother and himself being left at home together during the winter, of his father's absence, and their suffering considerable hardships; he recollect well the persons who attended to procuring firewood

...has rheumatism & unable to earn anything to support us. I have only two children at home with me named Reuben aged 9 years unable to support himself Dustin Hodge aged seven years unable to support himself. The real estate I held when I applied last May I have been obliged to sell to pay the expense of medicine of my son Caleb Hodge aged 16 which was above seventy dollars I am really poor & distressed and do say I have no other property than what is retained in my schedule & I have not disposed of said real estate with a view of getting my pension continued to me but was necessitated to do it. All the evidence I have of my services in the revolutionary war are in the war office & humbly pray to be again enrolled in the pension list. Thomas Hodge A schedule of all the property that I the subscribed now owns direct or indirect 1 small hog...10'00 1 chair...2'00 1 pail full pot...1'50 1water kettle...50 1 skillet...34 five shovel & tongs...1'75 1 old chest...25 1 old chains...1'00 1 set of home tre[..] chains...1'50 18'84 The above schedule is all the property that I now own direct or indirect in remainder or retention Thomas Hodge Sworn to and declared before the Justice of the said court on this eight day of November in the year of our lord one thousand eight hundred & twenty S.P. Webster clerk

State of Virginia City of Richmond On this 9th day of November 1846 before me George P Crump - a justice of the peace in and for the city aforesaid personally appeared Elizabeth Pritchard a resident of the city aforesaid aged Seventy six years who first being duly sworn according to law doth on her oath make the following Declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the provision made by the act of congress passed July 7, 1838. That she was the widow of Brampton Hitchcock deceased who was a soldier in the war of the Revolution and who served as she verily believes during the whole of said war, that he was in service from the commencement of the Revolutionary War to the close of it and although she is unable to set forth the different engagements he was in yet there is one that she remembers of hearing him speaking viz a place called Redbank or Red Hook having married her said husband several years after the close of the war she did not take that interest in the matter to make her fully acquainted with the [illegible] &c connected with his service. She knows however that at some time during the war he was in Colonel Lamb's Regiment of Artillery of New York for she has visited Col Lamb's house in company with the aforesaid Brampton Hitchcock after she was married to him and heard them converse of the difficulties and hardships they had to encounter during the Revolutionary struggle. She thinks also that she recollects the names of two of his Lieutenants- viz Campbell and Lawrence. That she was married to the said Brampton Hitchcock in the year Seventeen hundred and ninety in Burlington state of New Jersey by a magistrate named Horne that her Bible containing the family record has been stolen or lost , but she has in her possession a piece of canvass on which, the year is marked on which her oldest child was born, which was marked by the

To help widows and orphans of our comrades who have answered the last roll call and have passed into the "Great Beyond." 3 Cav USA A record of outstanding service for GOD and COUNTRY since 1846 RECEIVED MAR 14 1938 [stamp] Oakland, MD, March 12, 1938 Gentlemen: If you have the pension application and record of Richard Task or Tasker, who served in the 3 Reg, Maryland Line, Revolutionary War, and was granted a pension in 1820, then in Allegany Co., Md., please send me a copy of application and record in connection with marking his grave here. all dead, not having heard from any of them in many years. That he is now very old helpless and extremely poor, and cannot possibly go to the court of his county, (which is about fifteen miles distant) owing to bodily infirmity and poverty, having only one child (and she a daughter) to support him. That he served with John Jarrett, Benjamin Pike, Saml Hancock and Hazekiah Hancock, but they are probably all dead, as some of them were older than himself- that he knows of no documentary evidence of his service unless the records of North Carolina will furnish it. And to the proper interrogatories being put to him (those directed by the War department) he answered as follows: That he was born the 14th day of October 1752 in Sufax county State of Pennsylvania, and when a boy, moved to Onslow County North Carolina and lived there near forty years- that he left N Carolina upwards of thirty years ago, and has been living in this county a good many years, and now lives here- that he was drafted into service, and made a corporal as before stated- that he did not serve with any regular troops that he knows of, and has mentioned the names of all the militia officers with whom he served, or that he remembers- that he does not remember of receiving any written discharge- that he is known by many, if not all his neighbours, the names of some of whom are , John Drennon and James Clinton (two revolutionary soldier, but unknown to him at that period), Coleman Brown Esqr. Abner W Smith Esqr. Edmond Wilcox a clergyman Henry Cartwright and many others he could name, all of whom could testify as to his character for veracity, and their belief of his services as soldier. He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present, and declares that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any state. [signed] John Hart Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid. attest Coleman Brown JP CC We John Drennon, [crossed out- Abner W Smith and ] John Cannon and Warham Easley residing in the county of Caldwell and in the neighborhood of the above named John Hart) hereby certify that we are well acquainted with the said John Hart, who has sworn to and subscribed the above.

he states he was in the following actions during the war [illegible] the Battle at Monmouth, Germantown, Brandywine, Ironhill, Cooches Bridge, Paoli, near the white horse on the Road from Lancaster to Philidelphia where Genl Wayne Commanded and a member of small skirmishes; that he is now infirm and in reduced circumstances and stands in need of the aid of his Country. he hath a wife aged about 63 years who is infirm and almost helpless, & also five sons & three daughters & they being of age have all left him, so that he has now no family but himself and wife and in pursuance of an act of Congress passed the 1st May 1820, I do solemnly declare that I was or resident Citizen of the United States on the 18th March 1818 and that I have not since that time by gift sale, or in any manner disposed of my property, or any part thereof with intent there by so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land & naval service of the United States in the revolutionary War, passed on the 18th day of March 1818. [illegible] that I have not nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts, or debts due to me nor has I any income other than what is contained in the schedule here to annexed and by me subscribed [illegibe], and horse [illegible] [illegible] Cows worth $64. 1 shovel plow $1.50 3 [illegible] & 2 Chisels $1.50, 1 falling axe & Wedge $2.25 2 feather Beds $20 & 1 Chest & 6 plates 1 pot & oven 5 knives & forks $7 and Mallick & Broad has $1.75 - I have no debts owing to me But one above 49 or $50. Monmouth State of New Jersey County ⎬ On this thirty first day of July in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and thirty two personally appeared in open Court before the Judges of the Inferior Court of Common Pleas, in & for said County now Setting Courtenus Hyer and John R W Hyer Executor of the last Will and testament of John Hyer late of the County of Monmouth their Father the above named John Hyer was in the Revolutionary War as will be set forth by the depositions hereunto annexed which is in order to obtain the benefitt of the Act of Congress passed June 7th 1832 for the belief of Officer Non Commissioned officer & soldier of the Revolution; and in behalf of the Widow of said deceased who is needy and helpless; and aged about Eighty one years Aaron Sutfin and John Holshart Esqr appearing in open Court and being duly sworn according to law did depose and say that they were well acquainted with John Hyer the person named in the above declaration and believes he was and what Seventy Nine or Eighty years and that the ┃ said John Heir de did in the year seven teen hundred and Seventy six enter the service of the service of the United State ┃ under Capt Aaron Hartley in the mili in and monthly service and afterwards of recollects he that he was in the Company Capt Samuel Carhart and was more or less if not all the time during the war under different officer in Case of Alarms

State of New York, Oneida County Stephen Cleveland a revolutionary soldier, now residing in the County of Oneida, State of New York being duly sworn upon the holy Evangelists, testifies and says, that sometime in the month of February in the year 1776 he enlisted into the service of the United States under the command of Capt. Stone, in Col Patterson's Regiment, that he served nine or ten months, and was dismissed from said service in regular form, on or about the first of January 1777, soon after the battle at Trenton. That in the beginning of the month of April 1778 he again enlisted into said service under the command of Capt. William Hutchins of Vermont, that he was discharged from said command in the month of December following. And that on or about the first of March in the year 1780 he enlisted again into the service aforesaid in the company commanded by the said William Hutchins and Major Ebenezer Allen's Regiment, in the Vermont line, that he was regularly dismissed from said Service in the month of November following- The deponent further saith that he hath no property but one cow, and a little household furniture. That he is much afflicted with the Rheumatism in consequence, as he believes, of hard service during the revolutionary war , in which he was engaged, almost from beginning to end. That he now finds himself in such low and needy circumstances, as to require him to call on his country for assistance for his support. - Stephen Cleveland

Kirkwood of the Delaware regiment Commanded by Colonel Hall: It was at the urgent request of said Kirkwood that declarant entered the service to continue to the end of the war, declarant entered as a cadet and Capt. Kirkwood engaged & has on any vacancy of a subaltern office in his company: that declarant should be commissioned - the officers then commanding a company were a Captain and two lieutenants, but shortly afterwards, an Ensign was added to the command and declarant by orders of Capt. Kirkwood. Acted and was considered by Capt. Kirkwood and the other officers of said company in the said regiment as [illegible] in Kirkwood's company, and that on the said Regiment being ordered to the southward under Genl Gates declarant was engaged and employed as Ensign in the recruiting service and that during this service declarant enlisted for the American Army, at least five soldiers and delivered them at Christian bridge to Captain William McKennon and continued in the said service until the termination of the war in the year 1783. Sometime after the the [duplicate] termination of the war declarant met with Capt. Kirkwood who addressed declarant and observed that as soon as he returned home he would furnish declarant a certificate of his service, which would be satisfactory evidence of the time he served and the rank he held in the Delaware regiment; this Capt. Kirkwood neglected to do and before

Talbot County Nov 25th 1849 This will certify that I am well acquainted with Mrs Mary Leonard the widow of Joseph Leonard late of Talbot County deceased I was also acquainted with her husband for many years, I have often heard my father s speak of said Leonard and of their having served together during the Revolutionary ^War. I also know that my father gave a certificate to said Leonard relative to his Services in the War I should be glad of the [illegible] Mrs Leonard could recover any money due to her said Husband, as she is now advanced in years and Very Needy. to find in so immon a few, a deeper devotion to Country, or a greater amount of suffering than is here exhibited, and yet these facts can all be established in living witnesses, or by documentary evidence. She was married to my father Deacon Peter Lane about four years after her first husband 's death and resided with him at [illegible] Whitchester County between 35 - 40 years, when, at his death she removed to the city of New York, where she now resides with her son in law Mr. Caleb Leveriel 69 King street where she can be found and examined by anyone in the city, in whom you can confide. - she has ever born most exemplary character, having been a consistent member of the Presbyterian church for more than 50 years. She is, I believe at present attached to the [illegible] Street Church, of which the [illegible] Flavel S. Minis is pastor. She has lived a retired life and consequently has few acquaintances among public men, and nearly all her cotemporaries are removed by death, but the validity of her first marriage on the testimony of her son Levi Blancet was never questioned. As she is in indigent circumstances, and as I am certain her claims are perfectly valid, I have taken the liberty to have tell you with this, some what lengthy communication, in the hope that you would cause such further investigation to be made as shall incline you to give the subject a speedy and favorable decision Tuckerton N Jersey Nov. 14th 1838 Respectfully James B. Lane

Subscribed. My occupation is a farmer and I have not sufficient ability to pursue it on account of a violent pain in my head which often attends one and renders me incapable of prosecuting my occupation for the major part of my time in family residing with me Elanor Stanton my wife aged sixty two years Elanor Stanton my daughter aged twenty five Mariana Stanton to my granddaughter aged fourteen years Jay Burnham, aged ten years.-- Their capacity to contribute to their support- my wife's constitution is as good as persons of her age and can in part support herself. Elanor my daughter has been for this year past unable to help herself and I have been obliged to have her under the care of a Physician the whole time. Mariana and Jay are dependent on me for support. (signed) Elijah X Stanton his mark Ebenezer L. The deposition of Levin Magraw of Dorchester County in the state of Maryland aged sixty-six years being first duly sworn on the holy Evangely of almighty God deposeth and sayeth that he is well acquainted with Saladdy Stanley a coloured (colored) man who is now an applicant for the benefit of the act of congress for the relief of old soldiers.

State of New York, Chautauqua County SS. Lydia Spencer, daughter, and Joel Spencer, son of Rev. John Spencer deceased, a Lieutenant in the army of the Revolution, being both first duly sworn do upon their respective oaths depose and say - And first the said Lydia Spencer doth depose and say that she is now 47 years old and single woman and always resided in the family of John Spencer, her said Father, until his death which occurred on the 25th day of August A.D. 1826. That she never saw or knew of any record either or Church Record, Town Record or family Record of the marriage of her said Father with Rebecca Spencer, Mother of this deponent, except in a family Bible which was owned, kept and used in the family from her earliest recollection for a good many years and until it became very much warn and mutilated in about the year 1807 when our family moved into the said County of Chautauqua, about which time or soon after, her said Father, John Spencer, transcribed the foregoing and annexed paper containing the birth and marriage of my said Father and Mother, and the births and deaths of their children; and said Bible continued to remain and be kept in our said family some few years after it was so transcribed as aforesaid and until it was gradually and by piecemeal wholly gone and destroyed. That this deponent has [illegible] frequently seen the annexed paper in her said Fathers family, both before and since the said Family Bible was gone and destroyed. That it is in her Fathers own proper hand writing, with which she is well acquainted, except what is written below the black line drawn across the paper which she this deponent wrote herself. That she verily believes that she saw her said Father draw off and transcribe the said paper from the said Family Bible, but cannot say positively. This deponent further saith that she has often heard her father talk to his family & particularly his children, stories about his services, hardships and sufferings in the army of the Revolution, in which he always gave us to understand that he was a Lieutenant and served under Col. Vose and other officers whose names she cannot now recollect. And this deponent Joel Spencer for himself doth depose and say that he has seen the annexed paper in the family of John Spencer

The Deposition of William McMurray of the County of Jefferson, State of Ohio Sheweth - This Deponent entered the service of his country in the army of the Revolution, about the first of June in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and seventy five-- enlisting as a private soldier in the Company of Capt. John Lancers of the first Regiment in the Pennsylvania Line commanded by Col Thompson for the term of one year. In this time the Deponent marched from Northumberland County, Penn to Boston where his time having expired he reenlisted in the same Company, Regiment for two years and served therein at the Battles of the Brandywine & German Town. He was among those unfortunate Americans who were inhumanly massacred by the British at Paoli, where he was wounded and escaped with difficulty. He was honourably discharged at the Camp Valley Forge in Pennsylvania in June Seventeen hundred and seventy eight. This discharge the Deponent has unfortunately lost. he again entered the services on board an armed vessel called the "South Carolina," commanded by Comodore Gilleland (Capt John Gainer) and he was taken in this vessel, put into a Prison Ship at New York and confined for three months, suffering many and great hardships untill he effected his escape by strategy. Further he deposes and says that he from the reduced state of his circumstances is in great need of the assistance of his country for support, that he never has received any pension or compensation whatever from the United States William McMurray

To the Honorable J C Calhoun Secretary of the War department. The Representation of Old George McCloud a revolutionary soldier, and late on the pension list is respectfully submitted. That he is old and has been unable to do any thing for a living for ten years part that for the last six months he has been afflicted with palsy. That his property consists of an old one Story Log House with four acres of poor ground along side of a swamp. One third of which is flooded with the swamp water that the fence around the lot is insufficient to [illegible] the creatures, and that he is unable to purchase rails to repair it. That he has one Cow, which together with all his goods has been valued at Sixteen dollars and considered a fair valuation. That his helpless State is from an infirmity in his back occasioned by a bruise whilst in actual service on Staten Island in the revolutionary war that his wife Brittania is about fifty eight years of age and that they together have no means of subsistence, but by her daily labor, and that if his pension be not continued he must necessarily become a pauper. This is a true representation of your poor old subscriber of [illegible] State of New Jersey Gloucester County October 5th 1820 George [his x mark] McCloud We whose names are hereunto subscribed being well acquainted with the above petioner George M Cloud do not hesitate to say that the above representation is just and true. and that in our opinion he is a more worthy object of attention by the Government of the United States, than many others whose pensions are continued - Th Wilkins John Willson Michael Londenslagar John Spart Samuel Cooper James Russel Jacob Loudenslagar Thomas Willson Jacob Lippincott Saml P. Paul [illegible]
