First Judicial District of Maryland Charles County Ss. On this 5th day of June 1820 personally appeared in open Court being a court of record for said county. Robert Halker= =stone aged sixty five years, resident of Charles County in said District who being duly sworn according to law doth on his oath declare that he served in the revolutionary war as follows. In the fourth Maryland Regiment commanded by Col John Smith, in a company commanded by Capt. Edward Spurrier attached to the Maryland line, that the date of the original declaration is the 2nd day of April 1818. the number of his pension certificate 15159 - And I do solemnly swear, that I was a resident citizen of the United Stats on the 18th day of March 1818, and that I have not since that time, by gigt, sale or in any way disposed of my property or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the revolutionary war" passed on the 18" day of March 1818. And that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities contracts or debts due to me nor have I any income other than what is contained in the Schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed viz. 1 old mare 1 young colt Annuity from the State of Maryland of 160 Dolls. Robert Halkerstone And I do solemnly swear that my occupation is that of a farmer, that I am unable from my advanced age & poverty to devise a support therefrom - My family consists of a wife, aged about 50 yrs, two orphan relations, a niece aged 22 yrs & a nephew aged 6 yrs, whose labour constitutes but little to their support & maintenance. Sworn to and

I, Joseph Billings of Hatfield in the County of Hampshire and Commonwealth of Massachusetts, of lawful age depose and say that the following is a true copy of an entry made in a Record of Marriages solemnized by the Rev. Joseph Lyman formerly pastor of the Church in said Hatfield, and who died in the year 1828. 1778 Nov 5th Timothy Guildford and Sarah Hayden both of Williamsburgh - The foregoing extract is from the Records of the Church in said Hatfield of which the deponent is now Clerk, who keeps said records whenever said Church is destitute of a pastor, as is now the case. Said deponent is perfectly familiar with the handwriting of said Lyman, having been for many years deacon of the Church of which he was pastor, and I have no doubt that the above entry under the head of intermarriages was recorded by him. And further deponent saith not. Hatfield Dec 20th 1830 Joseph Billings Stated Clerk Hampshire Ss. Dec 20th 1836 Personally appeared Joseph Billings above names known to me to be a credible person and made solemn oath that the foregoing affidavit by his subscribed is here Before me Sam F. Lyman Justice of the Peace

To the Honorable, the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America in Congress assembled. The petition of the undersigned humbly and respectfully represents that some time in the summer of the year seventeen hundred and seventy six he enlisted at "Bergan" town near Paulus Hook in the state of New Jersey after having previously served two months as a volunteer under Captain Ross into Captain Lairds Company in the regiment commanded by Colonel Richard McAlister in the Flying Camp during the Revolutionary War; that being one of a detachment of 29 men ordered out of said company (say as volunteers) to cross the river from Fort Lee to the defense of Fort Washington at the capture of which on the 16th day of November, 1776, while engaged in the line of his duty he was wounded in the left knee and fell into the hands of the enemy as a prisoner of war, from whence he was carried to North Church in the city of New York where after remaining about two weeks, he was removed to the prison, the "grovenor" where after extreme suffering and privations he was in his wounded state removed from the ship and carried across the lines, whether by exchange or parole or otherwise knows not except the fact of being discharged. - That on arrival at the American camp he together with many others were provided with assistance to return home (deponent returning to York County Pennsylvania his original place of residence) when at the suffering under the affliction of a wounded leg he endeavoured to procure a support by industry and frugality without descending to burthen his country with a pension until by misfortunes and advanced age (say 77 years) being incapable of supporting himself and not

1st tour 3 months 24 days 1778 Mill's Company about 5 mo. 1778,1779 & 1780 in [illegible] & Shank's company 18 months Total 26 months and 24 days The want of stating the time of these last-mentioned services were performed in my humble opinion should not prejudice the statement - Mr. Bullock recollects he performed the services, but he does not undertake to say certainty the years he performed therein. He informs me in the 1st mentioned services he was engaged longer than he states. Being personally acquainted with you I beg to have to refer you to the Hon. P.H. Pope one representative to congress - who will also inform you ir interrogated that Mr. Lord's whose deposition is forwarded is entitled to credibility as far as any other person. Please suffer all the papers forwarded to be fully examined and consider and I have no doubts that Mr. Bullock will be allowed a pension for at least two years services - as I am entirely persuaded, he is fully entitled there to. Respectfully Your Obt Servant Geo. Armstrong J.L. Edwards Esqr. Commissioner of Pensions P.S. If not allowed for 2 years services please to have made such allowance as you may think proper.

[handwritten letter] ['but' crossed out] our Independance from Great Britain. but in many cases the Law is worse than useless as it is extremely difficult in many cases to make such proof as is required - In the present case of Betsey Brown it has been so far an extremely hard case as her children all except the one with whom she lives are dead or gone to parts unknown and what has been done toward obtaining a pension for her has been done by persons no way related to her but by others from charity or by [illegible] as her son in Law is a very poor man. I was at his house which was a log house of one room only of about 14 or 20 feet each way in which lived (her son in Law) Mother and his wife - 5 or 6 children (the oldest a fool) and the old Lady Mrs Brown - who was unable to walk or to be moved without difficulty and they were extremely destitute even of food to make them comfortable - even in that situation the old lady said Mother was kind to her and did all he could for her comfort, which could be but little as he had his only cow taken for debt (to pay a Doctors bill) and it was with difficulty that he could procure bread and meat or any thing to make his Mother & family comfortable - I do hope in all money that (if you cannot give a full pension) you will send a certificate giving her such a pension as you may be satisfied she is entitled to receive - her neighbours have done much for her, some part of which she the old Lady is expecting to compensate for, when she receives a pension - I saw her at ['then' crossed out] this time mentioned when I took the leaf from the bible she was unable to walk or stand on her feet and doubtless she will soon go to the grave but her mind was not impaired but appeared as bright as it thirty years ago - I must Beg & Pray that you will grant her immediate relief - Respectfully Yours /s/John Kimball Barton Orleans County Vermont August 13th 1838

218 HYMN CLXII. Book II. 2 Beloved self must be deny'd, The mind and will renew’d, Passion suppress’d and patience try’d, And vain desires subdu’d. 3 [Flesh is a dangerous foe to grace, Where it prevails and rules; Flesh must be humbled, pride abas'd, Lest they destroy our souls. 4 The love of gold be banish'd hence, (That vile idolatry) And every member, every sense, In sweet subjection lie. 5 The tongue, that most unruly power, Requires a strong restraint: We must be watchful every hour, And pray, but never faint.] 6 Lord, can a feeble helpless worm Fulfil a task so hard? Thy grace must all my work perform, And give the free reward. HYMN 162. Common Metre. 1 MY thoughts surmount the lower skies, And look within the veil; , There springs of endless pleasure rise, The waters never fail. 2 There I behold with sweet delight The blessed Three in One; And strong affections fix my sight On God's incarnate son. 3 His promise stands for ever firm, His grace shall ne'er depart; He binds my name upon his arm, And seal it on his heart.

for veracity and their belief of your services as a soldier of the Revolution. I take pleasure in referring the department to the Honorable Thomas Carlin ex-Governor of the State of Illinois residing in the County of Greene of said state. To the Hon. D. M. Woodson Judge of the Circuit Court of Greene County Illinois or any of the principal citizens of said County, the above named Gentlemen have known me for the last twenty-three years. I will here state that I have been often solicited to apply for a pension but thought that I had enough means to do me my lifetime but live only to so great an age and being unable to labor I have become very needy and have made this application for the truth of this last statement I refer you to the above statement gentlemen or the Judge of this Court. George Stewart (signature) We Christopher T. Gardner, a clergyman of, the Methodist Church, residing in the County of Greene and State of Illinois and within one mile of said George Stewart and Franklin Witt residing in the same County and state hereby certify that we are, and have been well acquainted with the above named Goerge Stewart who has sown and subscribed the above declaration, for the last twenty years; that we believe him to be ninety-two years of age; that he is reputed and believed in the neighborhood where he resides to have been a soldier of the Revolution; and that we concur in that opinion. C. T. Gardiner (signature) Franklin Witt (signature) Subscribed and sworn to the day and year aforesaid before said Cout M. S. Link (signature) Judge of Said Court

State of New York City & County of Albany, Towit Clerks office this is to certify that Apollas Moore Esquire is first Judge of the Court of Common pleas in & for the County of Albany and that the signature to the following certificate and the Annexed Certificates and Affidavits is in his own proper hand writing In testimony whereof I have caused the seal of the said Court to be affixed this 8th day of June1819 George Merchant Clk United States of America. By the Honorable Apollos Moore Esquire, one of the Judges of a Court of Record in the State of New-York, to with of the Court of Common pleas in for the County of Albany in the said State. To the Honorable the Secretary of the Department of War of the United States of America. SIR, I do respectfully certify to you, in pursuance of the Act of the Congress of the United States of America, passed March 18th, 1818, entitled "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the Land and "Naval Service of the United States in the Revolutionary War," that Samuel Palmer of the town of Born in the County of Albany and State of New-York, personally appeared before me at Rensselaerville in the County of Albany, in the State, on the Twentieth day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen, and then and there was carefully and minutely interrogated and examined by me under oath, touching the facts stated in his foregoing Declaration and thereupon he then and there subscribed the said Declaration in my presence, (after the same was deliberately read and explained to him by me) and at the same time made solemn oath before me, on the Holy Evangelists of Almighty God, that the said Declaration was, in all respects, true. Whereupon, I required of him to produce such other evidence as was in his power, to support the truth of his said Declaration - Accordingly he produced as testimony the Deposition of Samuel Holmes & Thomas Allworth and which accompanies this Certificate) and I having duly considered the said Declaration and the said testimony produced in support thereof. I DO CERTIFY to you, Sir, that I am fully satisfied that the said Samuel Palmer did serve in the Revolutionary War, against the common enemy, the time and in the manner by him stated in his said DECLARATION; and I am likewise satisfied, that the facts in that Declaration stated, are in like manner, true I do therefore, respectfully transmit to you the testimony in the case, and the proceedings had thereon, according to the Act of Congress aforesaid. GIVEN under my Hand and Seal, at the City of Albany, the Seventeenth day of October in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen. Apollos Moore First Judge of Albany common pleas State of New York County of Albany Lorviz In the above manner Judge do Duly certify that I am well acquainted with Samuel Palmer the soldier in within Declaration named, and that he the said Samuel Palmer is Extremly poor and in reduced circumstances and almost destitute of support and I do further certify that to the Samuel Palmer Stands in need of assistance from his Country for support Given under my hand at Rensselaerville this 20th day of May 1819 Apollos Moore First Judge of Albany Common pleas

(brot over) This applicant hereby relinquishes every Claim whatever to a Pension or annuity except the present and declares that his name is not on the Pension Roll of any agency or State In Answer to the questions put by the Judge the deponent says- 1st I was born at Stoningtown Point in Connecticut 2d I have no record of my age it was formerly in my fathers bible 3d Was called into Service from New Fairfield Conn Since the Revolutionary War have lived in [1illegible] in New York State 8 years and in Steuben County the greater part the time since except the last four years mostly in Pennsylvania 4 Enlisted and Volunteered, never Served as a Substitute for any one 5 Col Bragilla Beebe, Adg't John Bull, Capt. David Ulmstead, Liut Amos Hubbel, Ensign Thos Avery were some of my officers 6 I Received one discharge in writing by Capt David Ulmstead which is lost with my house [signed] Abel Lamphear Sworn and subscribed before me stated above [signed] Ira Kilburn Judge From the old age, poverty and infirmities of the applicant he is not able to attend Court - - - - - -[signed] Ira Kilburn Judge Date as above Cyprian Wright Esq appeared before me and on his solemn oath declares and says that he has been acquainted with the above named applicant four years or upwards and that his reputation as to truth and veracity is good, and that he was a soldier in the revolutionary war by common report- [signed] Cyprian Wright Sworn and subscribed before me [signed] Ira Kilburn Associate Judge

State of Vermont Rutland County ss. On this 6th day of Feby 1829 personally appeared before the [illegible] court for said county of Rutland in open court, (said court being a court of record, agreeably to the laws of this state, having the power of fine and imprisonment, etc.) Peter Reynolds esq resident of said county, aged 68 years, who being first duly sworn, according to law, doth on his oath, make the following declaration, in order to obtain the provision made by the acts of Congress, of the 18th March 1818, and the 1st of May, 1820; that he the said Peter enlisted for the term of eighteen months in the spring in the year 1776 in the state of R. Island in the company commanded by Captain Garzee in the regiment commanded by Colonel Elliott for Artillery, in the line of the State of R. Island on the continental establishment; that he continued to serve in the said corps until the fall of 1777 when he was discharged from the service, in Providence in the State of R. Island that his name has been placed on the pension list, and dropped therefrom on account of his property. And, in pursuance of the acct of 1st May, 1820, I do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March, 1818, and that I have not, since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent, thereby, so to diminish it, as to bring my self within the provisions of an act of congress, entitled, "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War,"; passed on the 18th day of March 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts due to me; nor have I any income, other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed-- One acre of land and a small house and barn in Sudbury-and two acres of wood land on the hill--1 horse 1cow 1 wagon and harness, hay enough to keep my house thru this winter --2 tables 3 chests 9 chairs 2 washtubs set knives and forks 1 doz plates 6 bowls 1 doz cups and saucers 1 tea 1 shovel and 1 pr iron. That, since the exhibition of my first schedule, the following changes have been made in my property. I sold the land mentioned in my former schedule to John Jackson and took the acre and horse above mentioned in part pay and bought this 100 acres of wood above mentioned and some [illegible] with this because I have [illegible] 2 or 3 cows, and fatten a hog every year for meat. My occupation has been that of a farmer, but am in feeble health and lame and wholly unable to labor. My wife Lucy age 67 is in tolerable health, my children have all left us but I have 5 young grand children left by my son, who is dead, destitute of property-- and from the town nearest [illegible] them. Peter Reynolds Sworn to, and declared on the 6th day of Feby1829 before said Court R. Pierpoint Clerk I Robert Pierpoint Clerk of the Superior Court do hereby certify that it appears to the satisfaction of the Court, that the said Peter Reynolds did serve in the Revolutionary War, as stated in the preceding declaration against the common enemy, for the term of nine months, under one engagement, on the continental establishment. I also certify that the foregoing oath, and the schedule thereto annexed, are truly copied from the records of the said Court; and I do further certify, that in the opinion of the said Court, that the total amount in value of property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule is seven hundred twenty three dollars, and cents, In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand, and affixed the seal of the said Court, on this day of Feby 1829 R. Pierpoint Clerk of the County of Rutland

in the first of September 1781 and by some ensigns was called to march toward Carolina and was attached to a regiment commanders by Colonel Campbell but was in no particular engagement at the time the news of several engagements in which the Americans had came off victorious and not being needed in that part the company was ordered to return and guard planters in the State of Maryland and was there engaged for several months. But from old age and consequent loss of memory he cannot swear precisely as to the precise length of his service by according to the best of his present mentioned below viz in Capt. Armstrong Co_ as a private full six months and for such service he claims a pension, after the expiration of his service he returned home and lived in St. Mary's County State of Maryland for 7 years then Co. removed to Prince William County State of Virginia and lived there for twenty years hence to Overton County State of Tennessee where he has remained ever since and this is the first application this applicant not knowing of any person by whom he can prove his service had concluded not to apply til lately being now quite helpless and needy and being informed that he may make his declarations in the present manner he can prove by Joseph Conner who is the nearest clergyman to his present residence and by many other good citizens of this county that he is a man of veracity and reputed and believed in the county where he lives to have been a soldier of the Revolution and that the same is not doubled by any person he hereby relinquishes any claim to a pension or annuity except the present and declares that his name is not on the pension list of any State Sworn to and subscribed the day and year above written. William S. Hill Benjamin Reeder (before me) a Justice of the Peace

I John Kilgore of Newry in the State of Maine declare and say that I am the same John Kilgore named in an original Pension Certificate No 7890. dated the 17th of March 1819. I also declare that in June last I gave in & subscribed a schedule of my property family & occupation before the rent Court of Common Pleas at Paris in the County of Oxford - in which schedule my property was considered by said Court to be worth a bout Eighty four Dollars - I was at that time in debt more than that sum. The land mentioned in my said Schedule I had paid for only in part ver, six dollars forty four cents - having bot the same since I was a pensioner- and was by agreement to make a small payment out of each pension due, as I should be able to reserve it for that purpose - but since my pension has been stopped I have been obliged to relinquish and give up not only the land aforesaid but all the little personal property I had except one pig & my bedding & clothing to pay debts for the necessaries of life which I had contracted in expectance of my pension - and for which kind of necessaries, my pension had enabled me to fulfil my promises - I am now destitute and needy, and were

Appear; as coinning?, more was to what She would be Entitled to, honestly and Conscientiously, as I verily belief, to be true, but if your honr cannot Consistantly advocate? from your former location, you will please to transmit the Same to me without any delay, and as many more as your honr may find it Practiceible, it would mucyh lessen my trouble and expences in procuring the Pensions for Several, at one and Same time, in going to Albany with Powers of Attornies & I sincerely hope that your honr will excuse myself from Searching for any more additional Testimony in Support of the best Service which has been rendered Under the Command of Capt Saml Gray, if the Officers have been deficient in furnishing the War department, with Rolls and documents, & in due Season, it would be very wrong to let the boat? man Suffer in consequence of his Superiours neglect wore Esspecially when Possetive Testimony has been exhibited with each and every Declaration heretofore transmitted to his honr. the Pension Commissioner where the Applicaint had his boat Service embraced in his declaration, When as allows war made, Beg leave to mention to your honr, ? Gross & Obesus (obvious) mistakes hereafter Should be made to appear, I Shall hereafter be willing to accept of Such decissions as your honr may deem proper and rightous, in having the Certificates send on as soon as possible if any to be fond, the time will be but Short, when the places Will know none of the present Old race and Applicants, any more --- not willing to encounter any more censure in consequence of any delay on my Part, I have yet Several who have Arrived to the Age of Eighty, and from Eighty to go - years May the Lord incline your hearth and mind, in caring for the minds of your Old Applicants, endeavoring in doing that Justice to which those poor helpless Mortals are Entitled to, -- My dear honerable Sir. I hope you will pardon my once more repeating to you, Assuring your hon* that in General as for the County of Tryon, in the Revolutionary War, you do not Allow, not exceed % part procured including the year 1779, from the said year, from year to year Until the Conclusion of the Revolution. I beg the liberty only to refer your honr to the decission you was Pleased to transmit the Same to me, as the Application of Nancy Gross for Widow of Henry Gramfor deceased Stateing the Short lenght of Service, found by the rolls and documents of the Company Commanded by as I feel constraint to call his Leverous? Cook only one Month & ten days, for and during the Space of exceeding four years from the year 1779, to the Conclusion of the Revolution, whereas if it was practicable to ascertain correctly the Services renderad during said Period to the United States as a brave Soldier, your honr will excuse me to State, in which I am warrented

transferred to the company commanded by Capt Thomas Doyle in the Regiment commanded by Col Richard Butler of the Pennsylvania line - I Continued at Lancaster until I was honorably discharged by Col Richard Hampton who was sent from Philadelphia for that purpose - the date of my discharge I do not recollect and I have no other evidence now in my power except as stated above and as contained in my original Declaration dated the thirteenth day of June Eighteen Hundred and Eighteen the original pension certificate is numbered 13262 and I do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the Eighteenth day of March Eighteen Hundred and Eighteen and that I have not since that time by gift sale or in any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an Act of Congress entitled "an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the Land and Naval Services of the United States in the Revolutionary War" passed on the Eighteenth day of March Eighteen Hundred and Eighteen - and that I have not nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities contracts or debt due to me nor have I any income other that what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed I am by occupation a labourer but by reason of age and infirmity I am unable to Support myself or family by my labour, my family consists of myself and Seven children all of whom live with me the oldest is fifteen and the youngest three years old their names are Nancy Rebecca Melinda Hannah Isaac Jacob and Susannah the five youngest of these are incapable of taking care of themselves the two oldest I suppose could support themselves my property consists of one Horse worth Twenty five Dollars one Cow worth Fifteen Dollars one sow and eight pigs worth Five Dollars one Axe worth one Dollar one Bible worth Seventy five Cents. Three old spelling books worth Thirty Seven Cents Robert Creigo Sworn to and subscribed in open court this 13th day of September Eighteen Hundred and Twenty Attest Jos C. Hawkins Clk

" One cow and calf worth~ $5.00 " One bed and furniture worth~ 10.00 " One yearling calf~ ~ ~. 4.00 _______ $19.00 that he is a farmer by occupation & has a very poor land inland at one cent per acre of his own worth not more than ten or fifteen dollars; Is now old and very infirm and not able to cultivate said farm, and he has a wife about forty five year old & four small children living with him, who make out to cultivate about four acres of said land, from which he processes his scarce subsistence -that he has no body else to assist hm in any way towards making a support. That since the 18th of March 1818 little or no change has taken place on my property ,except that about three years ago he lost fourteen head of cattle and three head of horses which died of some distemper that the most of what was left, which very little but little ,has been consumed in the satisfaction of debts which he had contracted without extravagance, but to procure the necessities of life, until he is reduce to his present distressed situation. flying with the chains over the horses' backs, our men running in almost every direction, and run any which way they could they were almost sure to meet the British or Hesson(?)s and the enemy bugling when they took prisoners, made it truly a day of distress to the Americans. I escaped by getting behind the British that had been engaged with Lord Sterling and entered a swamp or marsh through which a great many of our men were retreating. Some of them were mired and crying to their fellows for God's sake to help them out but every man was intent on his own safety and no assistance was rendered. At the side of the marsh there was a one which I took to be a mill pond numbers as they came to this pond jumped in and some were drowned soon. After I entered the marsh a (illegible) commenced from our battery on the British and they retreated and I got safely into camp. Out of the eight men that were taken from the company to which I belonged the day before the battle I only escaped, the others were either killed or taken prisoner. At the time I could not account for how it was that our troops were so completely surrounded but have since understood that was another road atop the ridge several miles above Flatbush that was left unoccupied by our troops. Here the British passed and got between them and Brooklyn unobserved, this accounts for the disaster of that day. The night after the battle as well as I recollect a heavy rain commenced and rained (illegible) nearly all the time we were on the Island. We were at length marched of in the night behind fires and made a long and (illegible) to the East River, here boats were ready to receive us and we were landed in New York a little before the break of day. We continued but a short time in New York we were then marched in the night over Kings Bridge and encamped several miles to the east or northeast of the bridge. We continued here I think about two months or (illegible). While we lay at this place nothing important transpired in which we were engaged except some little skirmishing with the Hessons(?) of length the British made their appearance

the claim when on his visit to Herkimer he would have been obliged according to the published regulations to assert in the County where he resided - New York County and to come the long distance down to New York City the place of his residence and as she has the right to assert his claim she equally inherits the right to assert it in the place where he had the right to assert it, and it would be a hardship of immeasured severity to her for you to insist on her - a female - single and unprotected - a stranger to Herkimer - to [ what is under the circumstance an impossibility for her to do so] to travel away the long distance there to assert the claim. But this acquisition is not insisted on in the case of a claimant living nearer the place of sitting of a Court although that Court was out of the County, it is known that it has been allowed to make the declaration in the next County [illegible] by the Regulations of [illegible] 1832 the claims may be asserted [illegible] at Washington perhaps two thousand miles from where the claimant resides, and it would be a grievous hardship and wrong to her if under the circumstances herein stated and the evidence herein furnished and the fact existing of these cases where the Declaration is made even out of the County of Residence, that at any further declarations than the two already made by her should insisted on. This is [illegible] intelligent and respectable lady who is stated under oath by the Reverend [illegible] to be a "Devout Communicant of Trinity Church" who has twice before her God sworn to a Declaration the fact of which Declaration are corroborated by oath in open Court of three of the most respectable one of whom swore that he is well acquainted with Euphemia Graham for" who had subscribed the aforegoing declaration a fact she is believed to be the daughter of John Graham who died in Schuyler as aforementioned" Citizens of Herkimer county would swear to [illegible]if she was in Herkimer, but her [illegible] to them in the town of Herkimer (where the court sits which is nine miles from Schuyler) cannot add any force of evidence to that herewith to fully furnish it. Under these circumstances and ample fully an equal amount of evidence being herewith furnished as though the claim was asserted or rather the declaration sworn to before the Herkimer Court, and more because traditionally evidence is not alone relied

State of New York Genesee County Aretas Pierce being duly sworn says he is personally acquainted with Daniel Foster mentioned in the annexed affidavit that the property owned by the said Daniel consists of one yoke of oxen, one cow and a few articles of household furniture of little value not sufficient for the comfort & convenience of his family, that the said Daniel is a cripple and has not been able to do any kind of labor for the season past. that he is in need of assistance from his county for support and it is the opinion of this deponent that the said Daniel Foster must be assisted by his county or by the town or suffer for the necessaries of life and further saith not sworn & subscribed this 10 day of September 1818 before me Aretas Peirce James W. Stevens Judge as within mentioned. [crossed out along the bottom] I certify that it appears to my satisfaction that the said Daniel Foster is in indigent, needy circumstances and this him a fit subject for a pension.

UNITED STATES OF AMERICA RHODE-ISLAND DISTRICT Providence, sc. District Court, August Term, AD 1820 On this first day of August 1820, personally appeared in open court, being a Court of Record within and for said district Consider Miller - aged 69 years, residing in the town of Providence in said county & District who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath declare, that he served in the Revolutionary War as follows: That he served one year as a private in Col Green Regiment of the Rhode Island line - that he made a previous declaration on the twenty seventh day of November - 1818, and that he has received a certificate for a pension, being No. 17.587 And I do solemnly swear, that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the eighteenth day of March, one thousand eight hundred and eighteen; and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner whatever, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an Act of Congress, entitled " an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the revolutionary war" passed on the eighteenth day of march, one thousand eight hundred and eighteen: that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the Schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed. Consider Miller A SCHEDULE of Property and Income (necessary clothing and bedding excepted) of Consider Miller i8 chairs, 1 table some cups, saucers, 1 spindle, 1 kettle, 2 old chests some knives forks 1/2 doz silver tea spoons, 3 bowls, 1 pig, 1 cow, 1 looking glass, 1 warming pan, 2 soap dishes, 18 glasses of different descriptions, 1 pine chest of drawers. - and the said Consider further saith that he is a laborer and works by the days work when he is able that he has a wife aged 45 years & four children, 1 named Elyjah aged 17, one aged 14 named Sylvania, one aged 12 named Phebe & the other named Prudence aged 9 years, all dependent on him for support, that in his destitute circumstances , he thinks himself entitled to his pension. Consider Miller Sworn to and declared in Open court on this first day of August 1820 before Hon D. Howell U.S. District Judge Histry Benjamin Cowell clk RHODE - ISLAND DISTRICT Clerk's Office of the District Court, A.D. 1820 I, Benjamin Cowell - Clerk of Said Court - do hereby certify that the foregoing oath, and the schedule thereto annexed , are truly copied from the record of the said Court and I do further certify, that it is the opinion of the said Court that the amount in value of the property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule, is thirty two dollars and In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and affixed the seal of the said Court, on this third day of August 1820 Benjamin Cowell, Clerk of said Court.

passed on the 18th day of March, One thousand eight hundred and eighteen - and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed. Schedule of Property One hundred acres of land valued by the assessors, at two dolls. per acre - It cost me $1. per acre ... 200.00 One horse at $50 ... 50.00 Two cows and three Calves and one yearling at $30 all ... 30.00 Eleven hogs at Eleven dollars ... 11.00 one cupboard $15 One Desk $20 One table $2.50 ... 37.50 Some articles of household furniture $10. Farming utensils $6 ... 16.00 Total $344.50 Att James Taylor clk Jacob Mefford, his mark I am by occupation a farmer; but am unable to pursue my calling in consequence of the pathsick with which I am very much and very frequently troubled - being confined a great part of my time to my room & bed on account of it and also in consequence of a wound received on my foot by a broad ax which often makes me lame in my hip and occasions much pain. As to the number and names of my family. I have a wife and ten children eight of whom are living with me - my eldest daughter who is living with me is twenty six years of age and is able to support herself I suppose by her labour, my next child living with me is a daughter and is now twenty years old and can support herself by her labour. My next is a son and is about 17 and can support himself by labour; My next is a daughter and is twelve years of age and is unable to support herself by her labour - My next is a son and is ten years of age and is also unable to support himself by labor. My next is also a son and is about seven years of age and unable to support himself

We Jess H Goss a clergyman residing in the County of Harrison in Virginia and Isaac Johnson residing in the same county and state aforesaid also appeared before me a Justice of the Peace as already recited and being likewise duly sworn upon these oaths do say that they are well acquainted with William Pepper who has subscribed and sworn to the foregoing declaration that they believe him to be seventy two years of age as stated by himself that he is refuted and believed in his neighborhood to have been a soldier in the Revolutionary War and that they concur in that opinion and they do further state that said William Pepper is now helpless poor and destitute of the means of support and blind - Sworn & subscribed the day and year aforesaid Jacob Coplin Hamilton Goss Isaac Johnson And I Jacob Coplin said Justice of the Peace in and for said county and state do hereby declare my opinion after the investigation of the matter and putting the investigation prescribed by the War Department that the above named William Pepper was a Revolutionary soldier and served as he states. And I do further certify that Jess H Goss who has signed the preceding certificate is a clergyman residing in the county and state aforesaid and that Isaac Johnson who has also signed the same is also a resident in said county and state and are credible persons and that their statement is entitled to credit. And I do further certify that said William Pepper can not without great inconvenience as being blind & by reason of great bodily infirmity attend the court of this county for the purpose of making the foregoing declaration Given under my hand this 10 day of April 1833 Jacob Coplin JP

a pitchfork, i wash tub, 1 small churn, fire shovel, 2 qt. bottles, 1`pint bottle, 1 stone jug holds 2 qts, 1 water pail, 1 milk pale, 1 small pail, 3 hogs purchased with pension money, some few articles of other old & unsailable household furniture as 5 old chairs, pounding barrel, 1 table near 40 years of age, 1 old chest, a few articles of crockery viz 3 white bowls, 12 home made earthen bowls, 3 milk pans, 6 white plates, 6 knives, 6 forks, 7 pewter and 2 iron spoons, 6 tea cups, 6 saucers, 6 pewter tea spoons, 1 fire shovel, 1.5 pail kittle, 1 dish kittle, 1 tea kittle, 1 broken spider, a brokin pot 1 leg out & cracked up to the top, 4 pint tin casons, 1.3 pint tin cason, 1 broom, 1 seive I am justly indebted to sundry persons for necessaries for myself and family the amount of $80.00 - I am a day laborer by occupation & by reason of age & infirmity am unable by labor to support myself - my wife Cyntha aged 45 years is weakly still earns measly her living - I have residing with me her mother aged near 80 years who is destitute of the means of support she is infirm by reason of age & having broken her shoulder last year has become nearly helpless & unable to earn anything - I have residing with me four children. Phineas aged 16 about earns his living. Joseph aged 13 cannot earn his living, Oney aged 10 years. Susanna aged 8 years who is now very sick and subjects me to much expence for necessaries & medicine under these circumstances & with my humble means I consider I am unable to support myself & family without private or public aid Aaron Hewlett Sworn to and declared at Bennington in the county of Bennington, and state of Vermont, on the 23rd day of June 1820 Joel Pratt Clerk I, Joel Pratt clerk of Bennington County Court do hereby certify that the foregoing declaration, oath, and the schedule thereto annexed, are truly copied from the record of the said court and I do further certify, that it is the opinion of the said court that the total amount in value of the property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule, is 40 dollars and 75 cents. Upon full proof it is the opinion of the Court that all the property of the Aaron Hewlett is not sufficient to satisfy his just debts. In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and affixed the seal of the said court, on this 29 day of June 1820 Joel Pratt Clerk of the Court for the county of Bennington

State of Kentucky Pulaski Court } Sct. On this 21st day of October 1839. personally appeared before the Judge of the Pulaski Circuit Court in open court presiding and sitting as a Court. Charity Armon, Widow of Thomas Armon, Deceased, a resident citizen of Pulaski County State of Kentucky. who being first duly sworn, according to law, doth on her Oath make the following Declaration. in addition and by way of Amendment to the Declaration she has heretofore made, and now on file in the department of the Hon. The Commissioner of Pensions. in order to obtain, the benefit of the provision made by the act of Congress, granting pensions to, certain widows. She states on Oath that there was no family Record of the time of her marriage with the said Thomas Armon Deceased. She further states. that there was a family Record of the births of her children. made and kept by her said Husband Thomas Armon Decd. in a Bible which a short time previous to his death, in the state of Missouri, he gave to his daughter Elizabeth Crump wife of George Crump, who had the Bible in her possession. when this affiant left the state of Missouri, and owing to the great distance, her daughter the said Elizabeth Crump lives from her. her own extreme poverty and destitute situation and the poverty of her Son in law with whom she lives she comides and states that it is not in her power to produce before the department the said Bible that contains the Record of her children's births She further states. that Charles Ashley her son in law when her husband was about removing to Missouri

Trenton Dec. 11th. 1777 Sir, To a mind possesed with tender feelings of humanity, it is even painful to be the messenger of sad tidings, but circumstances may arise, in which we forgoe the sensation of sympathetic tenderness, and it becomes humanity nay even charity to tell the unwelcome tale--Such, Sir, is the situation I stand in with respect to you, to whom I am intire stranger of it is more than improbably had ever remained so, unknown even by name , had not your son Lieut. Joseph Andrews, who was wounded at the Battle of Brandewine in Pennsylvania, on the 11th of September, last, fallen under my care as a surgeon---Before you read thus far, your anxious mind full of paternal tenderness, will have anticipated the worst of consequences and I need scarcely add, that after suffering much, which he bore with the fortitude of resignation, characteristic of a good soldier of a christian, he resigned his breath on the morning of the 22nd November, last----As it may afford you some consolation to know the particulars of his case: your son received the fatal stroke, before he was brought to the hospital at this town & put under my care----- His wound was in the thigh, just above the knee, and went pretty deep so as to touch the bone---at first, as he

Iron Kettle, I Cake kettle, 1 pot, 1 frying pan, 1 spinning wheel, 1 Trammel, one old blind mare, one cow, one old Ladder, 2 old Horse Geers, 2 old oxen, 2 hoes, 2 iron wedges, 2 maullings, 1 small grindstone, one ol plough, and one bucket. I also have a pension from the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, of forty eight dollars per annum payable semiannually, for my services in the Pennsylvania line during the Revolutionary war By occupation I am a farmer, but unable to pursue it, having been sorely afflicted with the Gravel more than 20 years, and having lost one of my eyes, in consequence of the fall of a tree upon my head about 17 years since, which has materially injured my health and am occasionally severely afflicted with pains in my head. The following is the number and names of my family residing with me my wife Catharine aged 45 years Children as follows to wit 1 Eleanor aged 17 years, 2 Margaret aged 15 years, 3 Patrick aged 13 years, 4th George Washington aged 11 years 5th Melly aged 9 years, 6th Catherine 7 years old, 7th Nancy aged 4 years 8th John aged 3 years, 9th Robert Reed aged 4 months, most of whom are too young to be of any essential service to me Wm Davidson Sworn to and declared the 17th day of June 1820 before John Vincent and John Grubb, Judges of the Court of Common Pleas for the County of Erie aforesaid. It is the opinion of the Court that the value of the property within stated is sixty dollars [signed] John Vincent J Grubb

State of Ohio, Scioto County SS On this Ninth day of December in the year of our Lord 1820. Personally Appeared in open court being the court of common pleas in and for said County of Scioto. Moses Malt aged Eighty years of age who being first duly sworn according to law doth on his oath make the following declaration to obtain the provisions made by the act of congress of the 18th March 1818 and May the 1st 1820 That he the said Moses Malt is a citizen of Scioto County in this State. That he served in the Revolutionary war as follows, that at the commencement of the war he enlisted in a company commanded by Captain Armstrong in a regiment of the Virginia line Commanded by Colonel Leadbetter in the Brigade of General Gates during the war, That during his period of service he was in the Battle of the Brandywine, of Camden and with the army during all its various operations in North and South Carolina, and was at the Battle of Yorktown and was at the close of the war duly discharged at Norfolk after having served in the war of the Revolution for near the period seven years This Deponent further states that he is in reduced circumstances and stands in need of the assistance of his county for support and that he has no other evidence in his power of his said services or discharge other than which is here transmitted Having lost his discharge some years since. And in pursuance of the act of the Congress of May 1st 1820 I do solemnly swear that I was a Resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March 1818. And that I have not since that time by gift sale or in any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring himself within the provisions of the act of Congress entitled an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service in the Revolutionary War passed on the 18th day of March 1818. And that I have not nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities, contracts or debts due to me nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed ~ Two Horses worth about … $100.00 8 neat cattle … 80.00 12 hogs … 18.00 Old House Hold Furniture … 25.00 Moses Malt his mark

Island of Canonicut [Conanicut] in said State; and the day before Capt Wallace of the British fleet then at Newport landed on said Island and burned several houses, the said company of minute men was relieved, but her husband although his time of enlistment had then expired, remained on said Island, and that night was taken prisoner, carried off with this applicant's father, William Greenman, & her younger brother, on board one of the British ships, in which her said husband & brother were carried [round?] to Boston, but her father was released in a day or two after he was taken. She was thus left with five children of her husband's by a former wife entirely destitute & subjected to much hardship and distress. She went over to Newport shortly after her husband was carried off and was there attending on her brother Job Greenman (who had been wounded in a skirmish with the enemy at Prudence Island) when her husband returned; having escaped from the ship on board of which he was a prisoner, whilst at anchor in Boston Harbor. State of New Jersey Mercer County Before me Samuel Evans one of the Judges of the Inferior Court of Common [illegible] in and for the county of Mercer, personally appeared Hannah Reeder (formerly Hannah Wilkinson) wife of Abner Reeder Esquire, of the city of Trenton in the county and State aforesaid a person with whom I have been personally acquainted for more than thirty years last [illegible] and who I do know that full credit ought to be given to all her statements, and she being first duly sworn upon the Holy Evangelist of Almighty God doth depose and say that she is in her sixty-first year of age that when she was in her fifteenth year of her age she attended the wedding of her sister Nancy Smith (formerly Nancy Wilkinson) sometime called Ann [illegible initial] Smith by way of designating her from others of the same name, widow of Captain Samuel Smith late of the county of Bucks in the state of Pennsylvania deceased that the Reverend Thomas Grant formerly Pastor of two Presbyterian Churches one of which was located in Amwell township, Hunterdon County New Jersey, not far from what is called Ringoes old town and the other in Flemington in the township county and state last aforesaid, long since deceased was the person who solemnized the marriage of the said Captain Samuel Smith to the said Nancy Smith (formerly Nancy Wilkinson) on the twenty second day of October in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and ninety-three the said marriage took place at the before mentioned

I hereby certify that with the bearer Mr. William Eddy, now stooping with weight of years, I have been acquainted upwards of forty years and have known him to have sustained the uniform character of industry honesty and integrity as well as that of true Christian piety and sincerity and from credible information, have learned that in a neighboring church he served as deacon until the infirmities of old age rendered it requisite to resign that office. And although I have never been acquainted with his military life, which took place before my acquaintance with him, yet having during any years lived his near neighbor, I am fully persuaded and assured that no pecuniary considerations whatever would induce him to assert anything untrue in respect to military services. James Wilson Pastor of the Beneficient Cong'l Church in this city, Providence. October 6 1832

DECLARATION, in order to secure the benefit of the Act of Congress, passed June 7, 1832. COMMONWEALTH OF MASSACHUSETTS. COUNTY OF WORCESTER, ss. ON this fourteenth day of August in the year of our Lord, eighteen hundred and thirty two personally appeared in open Court, before Nathaniel Paine Esquire, Judge of Probate for said County of Worcester now sitting at Worcester, Elijah Warren a resident of Leicester in the County of Worcester and Commonwealth of Massachusettes, aged seventy three years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress, passed June 7th 1832. THAT he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers and served as herein stated. He was born in Leicester in said County of Worcester on the 27th day of August 1758, and will be seventy four years old if he lives to the 27th instant, and has always lived in said Leicester. In November 1775, a certain number of militia men were called for from Leicester, and this declarant was one of the members, that turned out. He can not recollect the day of the month, but is sure it was about the middle of said month of November. He marched immediately to Dorchester, near Boston, Mass. under Lieut Samuel Green of said Dorchester. On their arrival at Dorchester, Capt Pope (he thinks, William Pope of Lunenburg) took command of the company and said Green acted as Lieutenant. This [illegible] was called "two months min", but the term of service was but about almost six weeks. He remained in the service at said Dorchester until the 1st Jan 1776 or thereabouts and then discharged there. He had no written discharge, and he believes same of the company had. This declarant entered the union again on a call for men to go to New York in June 1776 (he thinks the 20th) and marched immediately to New York in the company commanded by Capt. Loring Lincoln of said Leicester [illegible] Green of Spencer was 1st Lieutenant and he thinks a Mr. [illegible] Holden 2 Lieutenant. He was attached to a regiment commanded by Col. Holman of Sutton. The names of one of the Captains of other companies in the same Regiment were Wilcott of Brookfield, Gates of Harwick and Wm. Gates of Worcester. His company was stationed a few weeks at New York - then at Harlem Heights a short time - [illegible] situated up the north river as far as the White Plains where this declarant was engaged in the battle with the British. The evening after the battle, they retreated up the river about a mile and half. Soon afterwards General Washington croped over the river into the Jerseys, and the declarant remained above the White Plains until about the first of December 1776 he thinks it was the 10the day of the month when he and the rest of his company were discharged and returne home to Leicester. This last term of service was five months and ten days. He had no written discharge. The only records which the declarant has his age, is contained into Family Bible, owned by his late father, in his hand writing the entry is made. He has no documentary evidence of service but annexed hereto as deposition of Peter Silvester, who was his fellow townsman found with him on both occasions above specified: He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present, and declares that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any state. Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid. Elijah Warren Before Nathaniel Paine Judge of Probate for the County of Worcester

I Israel Chesley of Lee in the County of Strafford and State of Newhampshire [New Hampshire] present Pastor of the first Christian Church in said town on oath depose and say that having had my residence in the town of Lee for twenty three years I have never been able to to find any church records that were kept by Elder Hutchins also that since the death of Elder Orsborne I have not been able to find any records kept by him or any other person a church has since been organized a part of which is composed of those that were considered members of the church of which Elder Orsborne was pastor, said church of which Elder Orsborne was pastor was originally composed in part of those that were considered members of the church of which Elder Hutchins was pastor all the members of the last named church of which Elder Hutchins was pastor are now dead therefore of course no record can be found of the marriage of Simon Haines and Phebe Page which is said to have been solemnized in the year 1781 Israel Chesley April 24th 1841. Then personally appeared the above named Israel Chesley and made solemn oath that the above deposition by him subscribed is true Before me N.D. Pendergast Jus Peace

ARMY AND NAVY CHRONICLE. 233 [Left column:] host of the Indian Queen, refused all compensation for entertaining the old here at his house. One of the officers, with a provident foresight, had taken care to convert KELLY's capital into United States Bank notes and gold -- a sure passport through any part of Uncle Sam's domains, KELLY might be compared to a scathed oak in a forest of vigorous saplings; his trunk was left, but its branches were lopped off -- his offspring had pre- ceded him to the tomb, and he was left childless. With a comparatively light heart, KELLY started on his journey homeward, and being provided with a letter to Messrs STOCKTON & CO., the enterprising stage proprietors, of Baltimore, they generously franked the veteran in their line "scot free" to Wheeling; and we would that we could add the pleasing information that he reached his home in safety. But we have a far different story to relate -- that of his death by accident. A letter was received a few days since by a gentleman in this city, from W. FREY, Esq., the postmaster at Somerfield, Somerset County, Pa., giving the melancholy intelligence that the old soldier had been upset in the stage near that place, by which accident his collar bone was broken, and he was otherwise so seriously injured that no hopes of his recovery were entertained. Though languishing on the bed of pain, the veteran was not unmindful of those who had assisted him here in his distress; he dictated a letter expressing his grateful acknowledgements to the gentlemen in Washington who had aided him; and as he might not in all probability, have another opportunity to make his feelings known to them, he could not die in peace until he had eased his overcharged heart. Another letter from Mr. FREY, under date of the 26th March, announces that poor KELLY had breathed his last. Every attention that kindness could dictate was extended to him during the few days that he lingered on the bed of death, and his remains were followed to the grave by the clergy and many respectable citizens of Somerfield. --- In the North American Review for January, 1839, is a notice of "STEPHEN'S Travels in the East," written, it is understood, by the late Secretary of War, Gov. CASS, who, it will be remembered, passed over subsequently a portion of the country described by Mr. STEPHENS, when he made a tour in the U.S. frigate Constitution, with Commodore ELLIOTT. On Mr. STEPHENS'S visit to Mehemet Ali, Pasha of Egypt, the previous visit of Commodore PATTERSON in the U. S. ship Delaware was mentioned, and the Reviewer thus speaks of the 'incident.' "We take pleasure in transcribing the following tribute of justice, and in adding our own feeble testimony to its truth. 'He,' the Pasha, 'knew America from a circumstance, which I afterwards found had done wonders in giving her a name and character in the East; the visit of Commodore PATTERSON, in the ship Delaware.' That gentleman has the present campaign will be brought down to a behind him an enviable reputation in the various [Right column:] countries of the Mediterranean, which he visited. We have followed him in his route, and have heard but one report of his hospitality, urbanity, and correct demeanor. His superb ship was a proud monument of the naval skill of his country, and the conduct of her officers and crew confirmed the favorable impression she was fitted to produce." --- Maj. Gen. SCOTT arrived in Washington on Thursday, 4th instant, and left again last evening, for his head quarters at Elizabethtown, N. J. Maj Gen. JESUP will leave the city in a day or two for his residence in Kentucky. It is understood that he will return shortly with his family. The Board mentioned in our last number adjourned On Monday. The naval architects, we understand, are still in session, but it is probable will adjourn to meet again in Philadelphia some time next week. --- Correspondence of the Army and Navy Chronicle. FORT KING, FLA., [Florida] March 7, 1839. DEAR SIR: General TAYLOR arrived here yesterday, accompanied by his staff, and Col. T. CROSS, Assistant Quartermaster General. Capt. MACKAY and Lieut. BLAKE, Topographical Engineers, are ordered set about the survey of the country to be occupied with the "system of squares." This place proposed by General Taylor, and lately sanctioned by the War Department, and which has created no little discussion among the people of Florida and army officers in the country, is simply this: The peninsula between the Georgia line and a line parallel to it from a point on the Oklawaha, ten miles south of Fort King, is to be cut up into squares of twenty miles. In the middle of each, or as near the middle as health will permit, a small work will be built, garrisoned according to the nature of the country; generally, however, one company is deemed sufficient, one-third of them being mounted. If you take the map and divide the country in this manner, the results of the plan are obvious. Each officer in command of a district is held responsible that no Indians remain for a long time in it, or at least that they commit no murders or depredations with impunity. If the scouting party, daily sent out by the officer of each garrison, discovers a body of Indians too large for its immediate attack, how easily can a force sufficiently strong be raised from the contiguous post? The Indians will find it impossible to remain, or even to come within the districts. One reply can be brought against the objections to this plan. Every other heretofore tried has failed, and the only proof of the inefficacy of any plan is experience. The regiments will be more concentrated than they now are; the troops will be relieved of the toll and hardships they have so long undergone; the inhabitants of Florida, driven from their homes, can return; while ample protection is afforded to new comers. And, more than all, the expenditures of the public money (although greatly lessened during the present campaign) will be brought down to a mere trifle. This plan is very similar to that pro-

has also been reputed to have rendered important services as a volunteer, in the cause of American Independence. That while said Spotts resided in Wilmington, said Croxon was known & Designated by the title or name of "The Revolutionary Soldier" or "The Old Soldier of the Revolution." That he the said Spotts often heard remarks made and anecdotes told of the said Croxon in reference to his skill and expertness as Drill Sergeant & Fugleman. and of his [illegible] activity & fidelity as a soldier in the discharge of his duty. That he the said Spotts has heard Colonel Gunning Bedford John Sellers, James Rice and others, now deceased, speak of said Croxon's being of the first volunteer Company organized in the state of Delaware and of his being in the service till the close of the war, and of their being a part of the line in the same company with said Croxon. Of his the said Croxon's activity & boldness in opposing the landing of the British in the spring of 1777 when the British armed vessels, Roebuck & Liverpool came up the Delaware, of of his fortunate escape when a ball passed near his head. Of his being at the head of [illegible] at the time [crossed out of] the British landed there. Of his being sick at the time of the battle of Brandywine. Of his vigilance and care in concealing from the British the military stores, deposited in Wilmington. Of his being taken prisoner by the British, and carried to Philadelphia. Of the fears intertained by his [illegible] that they would hang him as a Rebel, as loud complaints were then made against him by the Tories to the Britch. And said Croxton would probably have lost his life, but for the circumstance that his principal accuser was a man in whom the British had little confidence & who at the time was intoxicated. The British Officer after hearing the accusers statements exclaimed You are drunk. You know now what you said, you contradict yourself. You are not worthy to be trusted. I do not believe you. & no [illegible] were further taken against Croxon. And said Spotts is strongly impressed with the truth of the facts set forth in said Croxon declaration, not only from what he has repeatedly heard from different & respectable sources but from the universality of that sentiment among the people of Wilmington & vicinity. And so far as said Spotts knows and believes, that the fact that said Croxon did render essential service to America in the struggle of the Revolution, has never then been doubted, nor questioned. George Spotts Subscribed & sworn to the day & year aforesaid. R. Tyler [illegible] P. T. J. C. C. [next column] We David C. a foraging party of British Tories came. They charged me with being a rebel & having a husband out & knowing where they were. I denied knowing where they were (as I did not know in fact & a man called Conner rushed at me with his bayonet & gave me a severe wound in the left brest (sic) and I believe he would have killed me if one Blainey had not rushed him back as he made his lunge which shortened the blow. I still bear the scar of this wound from which I suffered a long time & felt the pain many years after it was healed particularly when nursing I feel it even yet sometimes. My husb-and died the 17th October 1812. In the latter part of his life when he was hypocondriac (sic) a set of swindlers got away his land which was all he had & I was left in poverty. My two sons died young - My daughter are married or dead & all of them at a distance but one & she very poor. I am solitary & destitute & have made this declar-ation at the earnest request of the writer who went to school when he was a boy to my husband, but if I could get my ( illegible) I would ask for nothing but the laws of my country and what they would give me. 25th November 1836. (Signed) Christiana Teulon. This written declaration was this day( illegible) before me by the declarant Christiana Teulon & I believe in the correctness of the statements therein contained. Abbeville District (illegible) to this 25th November 1836 before me Joshua Hill J.P. (signed) Christiana Teulon I knew Charley Teulon & went to school (illegible) in the year 1799 but never saw him since the year 1806 or 1807. I believe firmly all that his widow has stated & have not the least doubt that he did serve. My impression is that he had the scar on his head that his widow speaks of & that I have heard in his lifetime of his services but all his contemporaries from whom I should have expected inform-ation about him are dead except his widow. (Signed / L L Pettigru
