State of New York City and County of New York } ss Nicholas Dean of the said City & County being duly sworn says that he was born and brought up in Dutchess County in the State aforesaid, within four miles of the farm where Zaccheus Newcomb Esq. (spoken of in the annexed affirmation of Margaret Amerman) lived for many years preceding his death. That the said Zaccheus died before this deponents recollection but that he knew the sons of the Said Zaccheus named Christian, Thomas, John and Zaccheus (one other named Daniel he did not know). That Zaccheus the son was bred to the Medical profession, and was during the whole of this deponents youth the family Physician of this deponents father. That this deponent family, and the said Newcomb family were upon terms of great intimacy for many years, and this deponent always understood and has no doubt the Said Zaccheus the elder was for a long time about the period of the Revolutionary War, a Justice of the Peace. And this deponent further says that all the sons of the said Zaccheus the elder are dead, and that their descendants are scattered over a large extent of Country, Some of them residing in the Northern or Western part of this State, and others of them in different parts of Dutchess County. And this deponent further says that John H. Newcomb (the grandson of the said Zaccheus the elder) whose deposition is hereunto annexed now occupies the farm and homestead of the said Newcomb family, and is the eldest son of Thomas Newcomb who was the acting Executor of the last Will and Testament of the Said Zaccheus Newcomb Esquire, and as such most likely to have the Custody and care of old family papers and Records. That this deponent has sought to discover if any of the official Registers of the Said Zaccheus Newcomb Justice of the Peace have been preserved and are in existence, and that such enquiry has resulted in the Conviction, that if he kept any, they are all lost or destroyed. And this deponent further says that records of Marriages in this State cannot be found in Churches unless the parties were married by the Minister or Elder having the pastoral charge of such church for the time being, and that a marriage contracted before a Civil Magistrate could not be made matter of Record in a Church by any mode within this deponents knowledge. And this deponent further says, that he never heard of, nor does he believe there exists within the State of

DECLARATION In order to obtain the benefit of the Act of Congress, passed June 7, 1832. STATE OF NEW-YORK, COUNTY of Rensselaer ss On the fifth day of September 1832, personally appeared in open court, before the Troy Mayor Court now sitting Abraham Witbeck a resident of the Town of Greenbush, in the county of Rensselaer and state of New York aged 22 Dec next Eighty five years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath, make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress, passed June 7, 1832. That he entered the service of the United States, under the following named officers, and served as herein stated. That in the year 1776 he was enrolled as a militia private in Captain James Cole's company and in Col. Killian Van Rensselaer Regt in the County of Rensselaer (then Albany County) and that he was ordered to march with the Reg. to Lake George, and remained on duty there from 14 to 16 days, when he was discharged and returned home. In the year 1777 he was again ordered out with the regt and marched to the northern and on the approach of Burgoyne and his army from Canada, and after being out on duly for sometime but having long he cannot now recollect, be with a portion of the militia, not deemed to be longer than he [illegible] were permitted to return home - Some time after which he was again ordered out, and having mounted as for as Mc Nicols ferry, he received an injury occasioned by a fall which disabled him in a considerable degree to do duty, and he was permitted to return home - in 1778 he was again ordered out and performed militia duty - in 1779-1780-1781 & 1782 he was out in each of them years, and performed military duty, and marched to various places of whom he remembers Scholraid, Fort Hunter and Caughnawaga, but for what length of time on each occasions the declarer cannot after the great lapse of intervening time, now recollect; but he is Confident, and doth declare that he has performed services as a soldier in the course of the revolutionary war, for a period of not less than twenty four months - [illegible] having been one of a class of six, who at their joint expense kind an able [illegible] its served for nine months He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity the present, and declares that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any state. Sworn to and subscribed, the day and year aforesaid. [signed] Archibald Bull Clerk. [signed] Abraham his x mark Witbeck We [blank] a Clergyman, residing in the [blank] hereby certify, that we are well acquainted with [blank] who has subscribed and sworn to the above declaration ; that we believe him to be [blank] years of age ; that he is reputed and believed, in the neighborhood where he resides, to have been a soldier of the revolution, and that we concur in that opinion. Sworn and subscribed, the day and year aforesaid. [blank] I Archibald Bull Clerk of the Troy Mayors Court DO HEREBY CERTIFY, that the foregoing contains the original proceedings of said Court in the matter of the application of Abraham Witbeck for a pension. In Testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and seal of office, this fifth day of September A.D. 1832 Archibald Bull Clerk

we staid at West Point about two weeks when three regiment under the command of Genl La Fayette Marchd for a towne called Herrington in the Jerseys staid there a short time & then made an attempt to take Staten Island got as far as Elisabeth [illegible] when the boat- became injured and we returned to our tents at Herrington from thence we marchd to Fort Lee remained a few days & went to Bargain drove off the Cattle & horses in order to prevent the enemy from getting them who were stationed at or were in New York after removing them we marchd back to Fort Lee remaind there a short time thence to Herrington, thence to Peekskill for winter quarters where I remained until I was discharged in the month of December after serving six months faithfully in the year 1780 the above is as true a statement I am able to give of my services, I have no documentary evidence of my services in my possession, nor do I know of any person whose testimony I can procure who can attest to my services. I do hereby relinquish every claim whatever to a pensionor annuity except the present and declarethat my name is not on the pension ever of the agency of any State Allen Breed [signature] Sworn to & Subscribed the day & year aforesaid Atten road in open Court, Geo: D. Ferguson Clerk [signature] We Aaron Semans a Clergyman residing in the [illegible] of Northampton County of Montgomery & Samuel A Gilbert residing in Mayfield County aforesaid hereby certify that we are well acquainted with Allen Breed who has subscribed & Sworn to the above declaration that we believe him to be seventy five years of age that he is reputed & believed in the neighborhood where he resides to have been a soldier of the Revolution and we concur in that opinion

[final edits transcribed] I Mary Clough of Wendell in the County of Sullivan and State of New Hampshire Aged Sixty three years depose and say that I am the daughter of Robert and Genet Boyes formerly of Londonderry that I ever lived since my recollection in my fathers family up to the time of his death which was on the twenty seventh day of July A. D. 1803 that I saw him die. that I have lived with my Mother Genet Boyes from the time of my fathers death up to the present time. that my Mother has lived a widow ever since my fathers death and still remains the widow of said Robert Boyes. that according to my best recollection when I was in my Seventeenth year my father moved his family to Derryfield now Manchester, from said Londonderry where he lived one year, than moved to Hopkinton, where he lived four years then moved to Dunbarton where he lived one year than moved to Wendell where he lived untill [sic] the year A. D. 1803 when he moved in to Springfield and died there as above stated I further say that I have often heard my father conversing with other Revolutionary Soldiers up on their hardships and exploits in the Revolutionary War and I fully believe from the knowledge I gained from their conversation that my father served two or three years in the Revolutionary War. I further depose and say that the family Record that is attached to this deposition is two leaves taken from our family bible, which I have known to the Record of my fathers family from forty to fifty years past [signature] Mary Clough State of New Hampshire Sullivan County} Wendell April 23 1840 Then personally appeared Mary Clough above named who is a credible witness and entitled to belief subscribed and made oath to the truth of the above statements Before me Richard Sanborn Justice Peace

State of New York Allegany County}ss George Gearhead being duly sworn deposes and says that he is the Brother of Margaret Boyers. That he is sixty six years of age and this despondent further says that in the year 1786 he this despondent lived with his Father in the town of Whiteland in the state of Pennsylvania said further stated in the month of April of that year (but cannot give the day) that Jacob Boyers and his this desponents Sister Margaret even then at his father's house and they then made preparations and said they were going to be married and that they in company with them Father left the house to go to the Rev. Mr. Simmonton a [illegible] Minister of that town and living about [illegible] miles arrived for that purpose and that they all arrived the same evening and said they were married and this despondent farther says that the said Jacob and Margaret Boyers from that time ever after lived together as man and wife until the of his, Jacob Boyers death, and this deposed has no hesitation in saying and believing Jacob to be the fact and has never heard it said or doubted to the contrary, Subscribed and sworn this 6th day of March 1840 Before me J.E. Parmelee [illegible] George Gearheart

The declarant add, as required by Law, that he is at this time favored, transiently with the situation of Sexton to a Church with a Salary of L [symbol] 43. Pennsylvania Currency besides small perquisites: but, being unable to perform all the duties of the station himself, is constrained to hire assistance, whereby his pittance becomes so much reduced as to be utterly insufficient, even with the rigid economy he is in the constant practice of, to support his family, without the restoration of his suspended pension. Besides, he has no certainly of retaining this humble station, it being elective annually; and should he unfortunately be visited with sickness, he and family would be subjected to the want of common necessaries, his little pension money not withstanding. Names and ages of the declarants family, residing with him. His wife Margaret, aged 64 years, much debilitated and weak, very little able to give any material assistance towards gaining a livelihood.- Three Orphan grand children, (both parents dead) totally unprovided for and destitute, except only such assistance and support as the declarant may be enabled to extend to them viz. Sarah Johnson aged 9 years. Thomas & Margaret Johnson (twins) aged 5 years. The tender age of these, of course, preclude their contributing much, if at all, to their support. Elijah Bowman Sworn to in open Court July 6th 1821 - D. Caldwell Clk: Dist. 6h I, D. Caldwell Clerk of the District Court of the United States in and for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania do hereby Certify, that the foregoing oath and the Schedule thereto annexed, are truly copied from the Records of the said Court; and I do further Certify that it is the opinion of the said Court that the total amount in value of the property exhibited in the aforesaid Schedule is Forty seven Dollars and twenty five cents. In Testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand and affixed the Seal of the said Court, on this sixth day of July A.D. 1821 and in the forty sixth year of the Independence of the said United States. D. Caldwell - Clk. Dist 6.}

State of North Carolina, County of Cabarrus. In open court before the C L Daily [illegible] of the Court of Judges [illegible] a court of record, held in and for the said county on this 25 day of June in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and fifty five, personally appeared Frederick Bost, aged 54 years a resident of Cabarrus County in the State of North Carolina, who being duly sworn according to law doth on his oath, for himself and in behalf of his brothers and sister, John Bost, Rachel Blackweder, Abram Bost, and Jacob Bost under the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefits of the provisions of the act of the 7th July 1838 and of the various acts supplemental thereto: That he is one of the children and heirs at law of George Bost, deceased who was a private of the North Carolina Militia in the service of the United States in the War of the Revolution, That his said father was a resident of Mecklenburg County of Salisburg District during the said war and was drafted into the service from said county and served at various periods for several years, the exact time or the officers under whom he served this despondent is unable to state. That despondent has no documentary evidence of the service of his said father, George Bost, that the said George Bost died in South Carolina while on the road to Market on the eighth day of June in the year eighteen hundred and eight leaving surviving him his widow (despondents mother) Hannah Bost who has also died on the nineteenth day of March in the year eighteen hundred and forty three: that the following are the only surviving children of the said soldier and widow vz: John Bost aged 69 years: Rachel Blackweder aged 58 years, Adam Bost aged 67 years, Jacob Bost aged 71 years and this desponent. That his mother the said Hannah Bost was married to his father the said George Bost in the county of Mecklenbugh, in the said state from Cabarris

DECLARATION. In order to obtain the benefit of the Act of Congress, passed June 7, 1832. State of New Hampshire, County of Grafton} ss. On this 27th day of August 1832, personally appeared in open Court, before the Judge['s' crossed out] of the Court of Probate for said County, now sitting, Samuel Bixby a resident of Lyme in the County of Grafton and State of N.H. aged 78 years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the Act of Congress, passed June 7, 1832. That he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers, and served as herein stated on or about the first of February in the year of our Lord, he enlisted into the company of militia commanded by Capt. Carrol (Carroll) in the Regiment of Col. Holman for the term of two months enlisted at Charlton Massachusetts marched through Lester (Leicester) Worcester Sutton Sudbury Charlestown & Roxbury to Dorchester where he was stationed for the term of two months assisted in building a fort was fired upon by the British [illegible] at that time, next day action and continued at s'd Dorchester every morn to Charlton the first of April in the same year - he further states that on or about the first of July in the year 1776 he enlisted into a company of militia commanded by Capt John Nichols in Col. Jonathan Holman's Regiment for a term of five months to go to New York marched from Charlton Massachusetts through Dudley Woodstock Ashford and to Hartford Connecticut to New Haven then took a sloop and went to the city of New York by water was stationed in said City about four or five weeks when the British entered the city of New York he [illegible] the American troops retreated to Harlem Heights was there stationed about the last of October marched from there to the white plains stationed there two or three weeks during which time there was a battle between the British and our forces that he was out with [illegible] on a scout when the battle was fought and was not in the [illegible] marched from white plains to court house manner so called when I was stationed until the term of his enlistment expired it being about the first of December in the same year was Dismissed and returned home to Charlton having service the full term of five months agreeably to his enlistment he further states that in the fore part of the m month of August in the year 1777 he was drafted at Charlton Massachusetts for the purpose of joining the army under under the command of General Gates at Stillwater that he immediately marched with others the most direct rout(e) from Charlton to Bennington from thence to Stillwater and joined the army under General Gates in the company commanded by Captain Abijah Lamb was stationed at Stillwater until about the time of the surrender of General Burgoyne was present at the surrender of Burgoyne & his army at Saratoga from there marched down North River to Albany from thence to a place called Lopas(?) from there to a place called New Windsor and there took shipping Down North River near White plains and was there stationed until he was dismissed about the first part of December in the same year making a tour of four months and twenty four days and marched home Charlton - he further states that in the month of October in the year 1780 at Lyme New Hampshire he volunteered and joined a company of Militia commanded by Capt John Sloan

he was born in this County (which was then called Buto) & State. - He has no record of his age - He was living near Sandy Break in the County when he volunteered, - & has lived here ever since He received a discharge from service from Genl. State of New Jersey Somerset County ⎬ SS On the 11th day of October A.D. 1845 Before the Subscriber a Justice of the peace in and for said County Personally offered Peter Vantilburgh a Resident of the Township of Franklin in the County and State aforesaid in the Eighty second year of his age a person of truth and Credibility to me personally known who being duly sworn according to law on his oath deposeth and saith that Mary Berrian Widow of John Berrian is the sister of deponent that he was present personally at the Marriage of John Berrian to his sister Mary in the month of January 1789 it took place at her fathers house and the ceremony was performed by the Rev. Isaac Skillman A Prebyterian Clergyman who was from the State of New York and after Settled in one of the Western Counties of this State John Berrian departed this life on the fifteenth day of January A.D 1797 and his widow still remains unmarried deponent has often heard him speak of his services and suffering as a prisoner in the Revolutionary War s/ Peter Vantilbrg Sworn to and subscribed today and year above written Before M. Elnatt Moore Justice of the Peace

State of Maryland City of Baltimore, Set: On this Twenty first day of May in the year of our Lord One thousand Eight hundred and Thirty three, personally appeared before the Orphans Court for Baltimore County Henry Cook, a resident of Baltimore City, in the County aforesaid, and State of Maryland aged Seventy years, who being first duly sworn according to Law, doth, on his Oath, make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the Act of Congress, passed June 7, 1832: That he entered the service of the United States , under the following named officers, and served as herein stated; that he served under Captain Vanheer; that he entered the service on the Third day of January in the year One thousand seven hundred and Seventy seven and left the same on the Third day of January in the year One thousand seven hundred and eighty: that he at the time of entering the service resided in Fishkill or Pigs kill in the State of New York. that he enlisted and was immediately ordered to repair to the Head Quarters of General Washington, who was then in (the)

then recieving orders. again, recrossed said river and was marched to a place. called the New Bridge near Hackensack, where they were on duty until Lord Cornwallis came there with his army. when they retreated to Paramus and y there continued until Lord Cornwallis had returned with his army to New york when they returned to the Newbridge and after some time stationed there was marched to Tappan and there discharged on the first off January 1779, That early in the spring of the year 1779 he was again called upon to perform his share of Guard duty and served under his said Capt as sergeant from early in the spring until late. in the fall during said year and the years 1780 and 1781, serving not less than one fourth of the time. and not less than two months in each year. guarding along the Hudson River 8 other places or on patrol guard that the service of the said William Conklin was not always performed under the said Capt. as the officers changed sometimes one commanded the guard on duty and sometimes another as he served under Capt Wm Sickles Capt John M Hogenkamp. Lieut Cornelius Blanvelt- as they changed their tours of duty as well as the men That the above set forth by this deponent. has been done us correctly. as his memory will permit him to do, from the recital there of by his father to him and others in his that he has often heard his father relate the services by him rendered during said war. the hardships and dificulties he experienced that being sorounded by refugees and Torys and the enemy frequently visiting that section of the country. there was no safety at his home and for safety had either to be with the yard or secreted in the woods especially at night That as to proof of the first tour of duty set forth, he has not been able to find or single person living who served the in the same and as to his other services rendered the accompanying affidavits and Certificate as all that he at this late period has been ena bled to obtain- That during the short time his mother lived after the act July 4. 1036, he nor she was ever informed of the passing of said act. and it was not until this last spring that he was informed by a letter he received from his sister Rachel at Utica. that the children was entitled to the pen sion his mother was entitled to if she had applied. He further declares that his Father the said William Conklin was married to his mother Elizabeth Hunt by the Rev'd Mr Yerbryck (as he was inform by his parents) in the year seventeen hundred and seventy three

when they were moved to New York, where they remained about one month. They were transported from the City in sloops to Albany, in April or May - thence to Fort Edward & Fort George, across Lake George, & to Lake Champlain-- thence to Crown Point, where they drew provision-- crossed Lake Champlain to St. John's fort, where they landed, & proceeded by land to Chamble?-- thence to the mouth of Lord? river, where they encamped. All the effective troops (amounting to about 1500.) excepting Winds Regiment, were detailed to go to the 3 rivers to meet the enemy, then in force there to the amount of about 7000. as was said Deponent believes that a Col. Thompson of Pennsylvania Regiment, commanded troops destined to the river. This was probably early in June. On the following day, a heavy firing was heard, & it was concluded that a battle had begun. Col. Wind's Regiment was soon got in readiness, & proceeded in battans down the Lord? to its junction with the St Lawrence, thence down to the Three Rivers where the battle was fought, & which was made on before Winds arrived. The whole American force retreated by the same route to Ticonderoga, when they arrived about the beginning of July as he believes. Here they commenced fortifying, & remained till December following when this Deponent with several others his comrades, being sick of what was called the Camp disorder (Dysentry) & his time of enlistment having expired, he was verbally discharged by order of Doctor Barnett, Surgeon of the Regt & reached home about the 20th December 1776, a few days before the news was rec'd of the capture of the Hessions at Trenton. - This deponent refers for some further particulars & proof of service to a Declaration & testimony made & taken under the act of Congress of March 18th 1818 now on file as he presumes in the War Department. under that Declaration & that's why he was placed on the Pension roll agency of the State of New Jersey, but was stricken therefrom for want of the poverty qualification, not being a pauper, & charge to the town. He has long since been totally unable from bodily infirmities, to labor expended the whole of his little worldly estate, & is entirely dependent on his children for his bread & clothing.-- He now claims to be restored to his pension, or rather that his pension be restored to him, if consistent, under the the former law of 1818, if not under the act of June 7th 1832.- Beside the services already stated, he performed several tours of Militia duty in defence of his Country after his discharge in the winter of 1775.6. But the impressed state of his memory, & the entire want of evidence from the death of his associates, renders proof almost hopeless. He does not now know a single living witness on whom he can call. -- The winter of his return home, he was sick the whole time not recovering from the effects of Dysentery. In the summer preding Burgoynes capture, probably in 1777, he was drafted on a tour of militia duty of two months, under Captain Austin (or Augustin) Baily & Lieutenant George Bockover. Marched from Morris town to Succaranny?, with the expectation of striking his Hadfor river at Newburg or New Windsor, to act against Burgoyne. No ? was informed that the Hudson was blocked up by British vessels, & the company continued thro' Essex county to Elizabeth town, when they come stationed under command of Genl Wind, to guard the shores & landing places, & protect the inhabitants from being ? by the enemy, continued on this duty till the two months expired

House of Representatives 16 Feby 1849 Col Edwards, My dear Sir [faint - 'no pax is enclosed' I send you today the application of widow Keturah Collins, wife of Oliver Collins, decd a revolutionary pensioner, enlisted in Mass & for a pension under the Act of last March - I ['know' is crossed off] am confident there can be no doubt in the case. The widow is aged & needy - May I ask of you as a personal favor to cause the case to be immediately considered Very respy yours W Collins [signature] [side writing] P.S. the family Bible record accompanies application W.C.

District of Vermont ss. at Chasburgh in the county of Orleans on this 4th day of January 1821 personally appeared in open Court being a court of record for sd [said] district and county made such by the statute law of the state having a jurisdiction unlimited in point of amount and having the power of fine and imprisonment John Cole aged sixty eight years resident in Morristown in said county and district who being first duly sworn according to law doth on his oath declare that he served in the Revolutionary war as follows, In the year 1775 served in Colonel Derky's regiment and company commanded by Lieut Jeddidiah Waterman and in 1776 in Colo Person's Regiment and company of Capt John Dorrow, Connecticut line agreeable to an original declaration by him made dated May the 8th 1818 on account of which he has atained received a pension certificate from the war office of the United States dated May 6th 1819 Numbered 10.817. And I do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale or in any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof with intent thereby as to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary war" passed on the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities, contracts, or debts owed me nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed The use of a farm during the natural life of the said John Cole granted to him by his son Harvey Cole in consequence of the needy circumstances of his aged parent at $36.00 yearly being one hundred acres with an old house and Barn thereon; one horse at $27.50 two cows at $32.50 with sundry articles of old household furniture to the value of $10.00 i the whole. I am by occupation a farmer or husbandman unable to labour at my occupation on account of age and infirmity my Family consists of my self and wife named Jemima aged sixty one unable to support her self one son Daniel aged 19 a cripple from his birth now learning the shoemakers trade, on daughter Betsy, aged 36 in a weak state of health, one daughter named Anstrus aged 17 healthy as usual and I honestly owe one hundred sixty dollars. [signed] John Cole Sworn to and declared on the 4th day of January A.D. 1821 Before William Howe Judge of OC[illegible]

services. He hereby relinquishes every claim what so ever to a pension or annuity except the present and declares that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any State. He further states that about six years last past he has through infirmity of body been generally confined to the house in which he has resided and in consequence of poverty has lived with several of his children in different places. that he now lives with a daughter in the town of Eaton in the county of Madison aforesaid where he has lived not yet a year that there is no Clergyman in the town where he now lives who has been acquainted with him and that in consequence of frequently changing the place of his abode as above stated he knows no clergyman who has become so acquainted with him as to be able to make the certificate required by the instructions from the War Department and has therefore procured the certificate and affidavit of two lay-men who have long been acquainted with him which is annexed Joseph Tucker Sworn to and subscribed the 27 day of August 1832 before me James B. Elderedge first Justice Madison County

that he was in the Battle at Trenton, at the taking of the Hessians; that he was at the battle of the white Plaines, at the Battle of Monmoth at the battle of Stony point; at the battle of [[Powbr?]] & at the battle of Sandy hook - that the Army then went in to winter quarters at Burlington and in the Spring following Deponant marched with the army to North Carolina where he continued untill the surrender of Lord Cornwallas at which place said Deponant received an Honorable discharge in writing signed by Captain Rudolph and Col: Henry Lee but which said discharge he hath long since lost or destroyed; Deponant states that he is old and infirm and is in very reduced and needy circumstances; and needs the assistance of the country for support; And that he has no other evidence now in his power of his said services and further saith not. - (Signed) - Jacob Humphrys sworn to and subscribed before me the day and year aforesaid.- William Wilson

Declarations In order to obtain the benefit of the [net] of Congress of the 7th July 1838, entitled, "[In not] granting half pay and pensions to certain widows". State of New Jersey On the twenty seventh day of September in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and thirty eight (1838), personally appeared before the Inferior Court of Common Places of the County of Cumberland in said State, Ruth Ogden is a resident of Fairfield in the county of Cumberland in the State of New Jersey. Being of sixty seven years, who being needy, secondly, according to law, doth on this oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the monies coming made by the act of Congress, passed July 7th 1838 entitled "The act granting half pay and pensions to certain widows" That she is the widow of James Ogden who was a Lieutenant in the Revolutionary [illegible] army of the United States during the past Revolutionary War. That the said James Ogden volunteered or was drafted over entered into the service in the Revolutionary War in the early parts of the War. and was one in actual service as a Lieutenant and Captain of a Company during a greater part of the war that he was out in actual service at least three years probably more [Perform] to always heard [ g...] , that said James Ogden was engaged with his Company in the Battle of Trenton in 1776 and in the Battle of Princeton in 1777 that he at the time of said battles he had been in the Revolutionary army several months made [contributions] in the army most of the

[Spelling mistakes in document are included in the transcription] if right, whatever.- under the former law, i should be intitled to full pay, but under the latter, half pay only, on the allowance of said county.- It will be recolected that I have made solemn oat before a court, that the services have ben performed.- It is but a poor compliment to an old man, wome oute in services is much of it, for his country's. good. to sopose, that he would go down to his grave with a [ILLEGIBLE] in his right hand. A The following declaration, will compose substantially, my reasons under oath, why I did not long since, apply, for a pension, and on the Act. of the 18th of March 1818.- That act admitted none, to its [ILLEGIBLE] but those, who ware in, or under indigent sircumstances; (Pensions.) Through the good providence of God. Helping my industry & economy I have not, as yeat, ben under the sircumstances, that people with property, ask a pension under that law. - Should indeed, have applyied, for the Benefits, of the Act. had it have be, left open, & free, and instrumented, with disgrace, & ignominey; The late law, is the only one that I could come forward under, to receive, one sollutorey gent, from my country, for all the privitations, & hardships, that I have indured for my Countrys sake. I do not apply for this pittance on the score of grace. I consider my Country indebted to me, not, merely gratitude, but for services, indered in Militarey services, unpaid, for & due.- A With Sinceer Respect, I am yours.- [SIGNARTURE] Ichabod Nye The Honourable J. L. Edwards Commisioner Pension office The state of Ohio Washington County JS. At Marietta on this 9th day of May 1835 before me personally came Col. Ichabod Nye, to be well known, who made solemn oath that the matters & things stated in the above declaration by him made hubris(?) [ILLEGIBLE]. The letter clause on this sheet written designated by the letter. AA. are true. [SIGNATURE] David. H. Buell Just. Plea

That in the year 1779 he went in the Light Horse as a substitute for Abner Smith of East Haddam foresaid and joined the army on the line between Con. N. Y. States and signed the Enlistment for three months and was under the command of Capt Bull of Hartford in the Regiment commanded by Col. Sheldon of Litchfield and Maj Benjamin Talmage and our duty was to guard the american army lines that he went about the tenth and was dismissed on the fourteenth and arrived at home the Seventeenth day of December following having been absent about ten weeks and as before specified has no documentary evidence or knows of no person whose testimony he can procure who can testify to the above services and that he is unable to attend the court of Orleans County to make this declaration He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present and declares that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any State. Asa Clark Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid before me William James one of the Judges of Orleans Court of Pleas. We, Medad Ferry, a clergyman residing in the town of Murray, and Horace Hibbard Justice of the peace in said town hereby certify that we are well acquainted with Asa Clark who has subscribed and sworn to the above declaration that we believe him to be 77 years of age that he is reputed and believed in the neighborhood where he resides to have been a soldier of the revolution and that we concur in that opinion. Sworn and subscribed the day and year aforesaid before me Horace Hibbard Justice Medad Ferney William Jameson one of the Judges of the Court of Common Pleas for the County of Orleans

They were both taken in one day, the scow was a copper bottom. Joseph Parsons was put on board one of these-- They were both taken to Boston. The Dean soon after this returned to Boston where she arrived in the month of October 1780. I remained on board the Dean till she was stripped. Her guns taken out & her masts [unstipped] making as I believe ten months that I was on board the ship - The marines were all dismissed in one day without, so far as I remember, any written discharge being given to any of us-- I then went home to Stratham and did not enter the service afterward. While on board the Dean, I did not receive any commission, but was a private with marines during the whole cruise - After leaving the service I continued to live in Stratham who I was born in the year 1765 and always lived before entering the service till the year 1787 when I removed to Wolfboro in the County of Strafford & State of New Hampshire where I resided most of the time till the year 1815 when I removed to the aforesaid town of Stewartstown where I here have resided and now reside-- I once had a record of my age in a bible which was carried by my children to school about twenty seven years ago, & the bible was burnt in a school house, which was burnt when I lived in Strafford County, & I have since kept no record of my age. I am known in the neighborhood where I reside by Saml. G. [Pipes], Ths. [Pipes], Barzillis Brainard, Libbens Hall, L.F. Hall, Charles Sargent & Moses Pickard, who can testify as to my character for veracity and their belief as to my service in the war of the revolution - Jeremiah Young of Colebrook in said County of Coos, & Richard Tibbets & Chs. Wiggins in a distant neighborhood of the aforesaid Stewartstown have known me before my living in Stewartstown & can likewise testify to the same - my poverty and means of information have not put it in my powers to [ ] the testimony of any witness of my service except that furnished by the affidavit of John Marble, hereunto annexed, and I do not know of any other living witness, by whom I can prove it. The reason of my delaying the present application to the present time, is that the papers setting forth my claim to a pension which were furnished to the war department in the year 1833 were mislaid in the office of said W. Williams, Esq. so that I have not till within a few weeks been able to regain them-

I Alexander Chartier of the town of Massena County of St Lawrence of Lawful age do testify and say that Sally Chartier (The wife of John Chartier late a revolutionary pensioner deceased) is my mother; That my Grand-mother (a French woman) always called my mother by the name of Mary Therese as did also my father when speaking of, as to my mother in French but when speaking in English he called her name Sally. And further this Deponant says not. /s/Alexander Chartier Sworn and subscribed to before me the 14th day of July 1838 /a/A Ransom Com. of Deeds I Sally Chartier of the town of Massena County of St Lawrence and State of New York of lawful age do testify and say that I am the widdow of John Chartier late a revolutionary pensioner deceased That my christian name was called by my parents when spoken to in the French language Mare Therese but in the English language Sally. That my parents always when speaking of my Baptism informed me that I was christianed by the name of Mary Therese and further this Deponant says not. /s/X her mark Sally Chartier Witness A Ransom John Hitchcock Sworn and subscribed to before me this 14th day of July 1838. /s/A Ransom Com. of Deeds I hereby certify that the person who has sworn to the above affidavits are credible persons and are worthy of credit. /s/A Ransom Com. of Deeds

We Charley Pain a Clergiman resideing in the State of Georgia Habersham County and Jefse Sanford residing in the (Same) Hereby Certify that we are well acquinted with Garrett Vandegrift who has Subscibed to the above Decloration, that we believe him to Eighty years of age; That he is reputed and where he lived in the Neighborhood where he resides to have been a Soldier of the revolution and that we concur in that opinion Sworn to and Subscribed the day and year afforesaid William Kinsey TP Charles Pain TP Jefse Sanford And the Justice do hereby Declare his opinion after the investigation of the matter after puting the interogatoring prescribed by the War department that the above name applicant was a revolutionary Soldier and Served as the States, and the Justice further Certifies that it appears to him that Charles Pain who has signed the preceding Certificate is a Clergyman, resident in the State and County afforesaid and Jefse Sanford who has also Signed the same is a resident in the State and County afforesaid and is a credible person and that their Statement their Statement is intitled to Credit William Kinsey TP

State of South Carolina Richland District On the eleventh day of September in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and forty six personally appeared before me Saml R Black one of the magistrates for the district and state aforesaid Aberhart Fetner a resident of the District of Richland state of South Carolina, aged eighty six on the 21st day of October next, who being first duly sworn according to law doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the provision made by the Act of Congress passed the 7th June 1832 that he enlisted in the army of the United State in the year 1777 in August of the same under Capt Derrill Hart in Col William Thomson's regiment of foot as a musician and served in the same, the third regiment of the continental line-- That he continued in said regiment until the Battle of Briar Creek at which time he was taken prisoner and confined on board a prison ship at Savannah in the state of Georgia-- that he was afterward retaken by Col Lee and served under Capt Rudolph in Col Lee's regiment in which he served until the close of the war of the Revolution-- that before entering the last mentioned regiment he served under Capt. Felix Warley who also belonged to Col William Thomson's Regt of foot-- that he is aged and in needy circumstances-- He also answers to the following interrogations upon oath. 1st Int Where and in what year were you born Answer In Charleston on the

[printed fillable form] State of Massachusetts I John Ferrie a Citizen of the United States, now resident at Natick in the County of Middlesex in the State aforesaid, do on oath testify and [n?] declare that in the War of the Revolution [overwritten: on] in the month of may [crossed out: I think] in the year of Our Lord One thousand seven hundred & seventy five I entered and was engaged in the land service of the United States on the con- tinental establishment, and served accordingly from that time to the month of January in the year of Our Lord Seventeen hundred & seventy six that I again entered the same service on the ninth of April AD 1781, for three years & served accordingly to the end of the said war as a private against the common enemy, without any interruption or absence : that I belonged to Captain Joseph Morse's Company, in Colonel Patterson's Regiment & for eight months & to Captain Drew's company in Colonel Sprout's Regiment, in the Massa chusetts line of the army for three years, or thereabouts and that I left the service on the expiration of the term aforesd [aforesaid] being honorably discharged and that by reason of my reduced circumstances in life and poverty, I stand in need of assistance from my country for support, being now of the age of sixty one years — I know no other evidence in my power to offer than is herewith exhibited, being the promissory note of hand of the Committee appointed by the town of Natick to have Soldiers for the Continental army in the year 1781 for Which town I inlisted to serve as aforesaid, & which note has been pained & cancelled. And I hereby relinquish all claim[s: crossed out] to every pension heretofore allowed me by the laws of the United States, if any may be or hath been so allowed. John his mark Ferrie BE IT REMEMBERED, That on this first day of May in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen Pursuant to a law of the United States, entitled, "An Act to provide for certain persons engage din the land and naval service of the United States in the revolutionary war," made an passed on the 18th of March, A. D. 1818, personally appeareth before me the Subscriber one of the Associate Judges of the circuit court of Common Judges within the State aforesaid. — And presiding [illegible] the abovenamed John Ferrie and after due examination and caution to testify and declare the whole truth, he maketh oath ot the declaration aforesaid, and subscribes the same in my presence ; and, on examination duly made me the said Judge, it appeareth to my satisfaction that the said declaration is true In testimony whereof I hereunto affix my name & the seal of sd [said] Court Wm Wetmore

contracts or debts due to me; nor have any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed- March Farrington Sworn in open Court this 30 August 1820- H R Phelps Dep Clk Schedule of property 2 spinning wheals. 2 old chests worth $3.00 1 old vet. 1 Chair 1 shovel, [illegible] $2.18 1 large Bible 1 psalm book. 1 other shovel $3.50 2 pigs $2.08 in Cash I have due to me from one man $10.00 I have no more bedding and wearing apparel than the use of for my family - I am by occupation a farmer but from feableness produced by Rehumatism and other infirmities common to old age I am unable to pursue the same. I cannot support myself by my labor. I have a wife and two daughters who together with myself reside with my son Morris - my wife named Betsey is fifty five years of age she is unable to support herself being weak and feeble from age and frequent attacks of the Rhumatism, my daughter. My daughter Florilla aged 16 years is in good health and able to support herself. And my daughter Polly aged 10 is also in good health but is not able to support herself as yet. We are dependant upon my son Morris for what we cannot provide by our own labor to support ourselves - I our to different persons in the aggregate to about $50.00 Signature of March Farrington

Original Claim The State of South Carolina Pendleton District [illegible] On the twenty sixth day of October in the year of our Lord one thousand Eight hundred and twenty four and in the forty ninth of American Independence in the court of common pleas and General [illegible] of the peace for said district of Pendleton being a count of Record Personally appeared in Open Court Robert Farr aged about seventy two years resident in the district of Pendleton aforesaid who being first duly sworn according to law doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the provisions made by the Acts of Congress of 18th of March 1818 and first of May 1820 - What he then said Robert Farr enlisted for the Term of three years on or about the first day of April one thousand Seven hundred and Seventy six in Philadelphia in the state of Pennsylvania in the company commanded by Captain Dover in the Regiment commanded by Colonel Butler in the line of the State of Pennsylvania on the continental establishment that he continued to serve in the said corps untill about the fifteenth of April one thousand Seven hundred and Seventy nine When he was discharged from the said Service in Morristown in the State of New Jersey- That he then said Robert Farr enlisted a second time for the tern of four years on or about the first day of May one thousand seven hundred and seventy nine near to Morristown in the State of New Jersey in the Rifle Corps for four years and was discharged after the battle of the Cowpens he thinks about the first of May one thousand seven hundred and Eighty three - that he has lost both discharges - That he was in the battle of Brandywine and Germantown that he was in active service under the command of General Wayne when they were attacked by the British troops in the night on the Schuykill near to Valley Forge and received two wounds or stabs from a bayonet in the groin - that he was at the battle of Monmouth and the Cowpens at which latter place he was severely wounded in the head by a cut from a sword - That from this [illegible] of his discharge he has no other evidence now in his posession of his said Services except this affidavivit of Baker Ayers and John [Ullin]- And in pursuance of the act of this first of May 1820 I do Solemnly swear that I was a resident Citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not [illegible] time by gift sale or in any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of congress entitled "an act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the revolutionary war" passed on the 18th day of march 1818 and that I have not nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities contracts or debts due to me - nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed [illegible] One bed containing about ten pounds of feathers together with the furniture - one plain pine table- one dish- one plate- [illegible] knives and forks - one barshare plough (old) one shovel plough (old) one winding hoe - one chopping axe - one spade one shovel (old) the present crop consisting of a [illegibole] field of corn off of which a [illegible] probably gather about [illegible] barrel and the fodder - that he then said Robert Farr follows as well as able his occupation of ditching but from his age and infirmities is half his time unable to work at all and at other times able to do very little that he has no family except his wife who is near ninety years old who is quite helpless unable in any degree to contribute to his support - Swore to and declared on in Open Court this day and date above written Robert + (mark) Farr [illegible} Richard [illegible] Presiding Judge

Common Wealth of Massachusetts Be it remembered that on this twentieth _ day of April in year of our Lord One Thousand Eight hundred and Eighteen, before me Samuel Dana Chief justice of the Circuit Court of Common Pleas for the middle Circuit comprehending the counties of Essex and Middlesex being a court of Record duly established by law within the Commonwealth aforesaid comes William Farr of Ashby - in said County of Middlesex and on oath declares that he served in the war of the Revolution; against the common Enemy for the space of twenty one months - On the first of January in the year of our Lord One Thousand Seven hundred and Seventy six he enlisted (illegible) the Continental establishment into the Company of artillery commanded by Capt. Diamond Morton, in Col Knox Regiment, in the Massachusetts line, he proceeded with his company by the way of New London to New York and was stationed within the State of New York, and there he did duty in Cpt. Mortons Company until the first of January AD 1777, when he was dismissed, no discharge was given to him He first entered the service at Cambridge, and these completed eight months service before he enlisted as aforesaid - He was in the Company of Capt. Bryand and in Col (blank) Regiment for the Newhampshire (New Hampshire) line, six weeks at the capture of Burgoynes Army and he was about one month on Capt. Darbys Company in Col (blank) Regiment in the Massachusetts line at the city of Troy in the State of New York - He is sixty five years of age destitute of property and by reason of his reduced circumstances in life he stands in need of assistance from his country for support. Wm Farr This made taken subscribed and sworn to the day and year aforesaid at Groton in said county of Middlesex Saml Dana

Genl. [Griffith] Rutherford and Col. Posley he thinks of Guilford [North Carolina] commanded.Was a volunteer as before under his Father Capt. Falls [William Falls] during the Fall of 1777 or 18. Served six weeks and was then sent express to Salisbury [North Carolina] with Letters. Was next in a scouting tour of three months through Lincoln and Rowan [Counties, NC] (now Iredell) on Catawba River guarding the Fords on said river under Capt [William] Falls and Lieutenant [James] Kerr. And was in frequent tours of som kind afterwards a few days at a time dates not Recollected. Was next out about the time of Ramsours Battle [Battle of Ramsour's Mill, North Carolina] in June 1780, a week or so previous to is was in the Scout through Lincoln [County] and when it was perceived that the Tories was embodied he rode express to Genl. [Griffith] Rutherford between Charlotte & Salisbury [both NC] who imediatly [immediately] detached Capt [William] Falls and Lieutenant [James] Byers, with their companys which he joined as Volunteer. marched to Lincoln [County, NC] by Shirrerlls ford [Sherrills Ford County, NC] on Catawba River to a camp on Mountain Creek- went to Ramsour's [Mill,NC] under Col. [Francis] Locke and Mjr [Major [Griffith] Rutherford was present in the Battle in which his father Capt. [William] Falls was killed. he then came home being in service about twenty days. In the fall of 1780 as well as he now recollects he again Volunteered for Three months was selected with others to furnish the army with Beef Cattle under the discretion of James Kerr purchasing commissary. After this he as occationally [occasionally] a guard on Catawba River no regular command On Cornwallis [General Charles Lord Cornwallis] appearance from South Carolina

H. Kuh. April 20 1840 Mr Sir I send you enclosed this application of stated needy soldiers for small pensions, who are no doubt honest and meritorious men and state I would never urge a public officer to do wrong: I most earnestly request him not to look with a too rigid eye on an honest claim—I hope the papers of Mr. Connelly are sufficient and I ask you to review with care of Mr. Pohon with the papers now sent and if his claim can’t pass your orderly please to return them with the papers you now have, as I want to try Congress a slow and tedious and doubtful herewith high respect yours truly John Pope

State of Vermont Windham County Brattleboro July 8, 1833 All the subscribers being in habitant of said Brattleboro & having long known who has made application for a pension and some of is having been near neighbors to him do cheerfully certify that we have ever considered him as an honest man and that he has been reported & understood to have been in the Revolutionary Service - that he was formerly an active industrious man, about 10 years as near as we can recollect been blind & somewhat infirm in body and mind - he is very aged and destitute of property. Reuben Stevens Sam'l Bailey Paul Chase Samuel Clark Stephen Greenleaf Reuben Church Leonard Whitney State of Vermont - Windham Brattleboror July 8, 1833. Personally appeared the several subscriber to this statement & made oath to the same (except Mr. Bailey whose oath I forgot to require) Samuel Elliot Justice of the Peace

no pay from the time he went home altho he was generally out in the Frontier against the Indians who were very troublesome in the neighborhood where his family then lived which was the real reason why he did not stay with the detached part of the Army where there was no danger and for further proof produces the Commission as Stated And he further States that from his reduced Circumstances he needs the assistance of his County for Support such as in the honor they are bound to give him. True it is that in his advanced age with difficulty he can make a kind of support for himself and family as an attorney at Law and through the blessing of God and the humanity of our Laws no man woman or child is to suffer for the want of support but are given Common food and raiment by the County where they reside. And altho his County at the present honors him and has many years honored him as their

Deposition of John Ellis a soldier serving under Maj. Gen. Anthony Wayne, of the second sublegion belonging to Capt. Andrews Company, now residing in the town of Sempronius County of Cayuga and State of New York deposethand sayeth that while in the service of the United States in the year of our Lord one these seven hundred & ninety four in the month of August he being in the advanced guard received a wound in the right arm Just below the shoulder joint and shattered the bone from which a piece to be taken out about one year afterward he also sayeth that this took place on the river Miami- of- the- Lakes in Gen. Wayne last battle with the Indian he also sayeth that he of hath ever since Labored in pain by means of the wound it caused weakness and debility by reason of part of the bone being taken out the reason why he never before made application is that he has ever been able to subsist without it but now being reduced to want he now makes application & he sayeth that the season why he has not obtained the affidavit of some other officer but Reuben King Cor. is that he hath never seen since discharge any other but the aforementioned R. King-- John Ellis Dated at Sempronius this fourteenth day of February in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred & Eighteen The above deposition taken Before me at Sempronius in Cayuga County this fourteenth day of February 1818 Ebene Smithy Justice Peace

This 14th day of April 1818 Joseph Parker as credible witness aged ninty two years appeared before the subscriber a Judge of the Superior Court of Fauquier and state of Virginia and made oath that he and the above named Samuel Elliot enlisted as soldiers at nearly the same time in a Company of Infantry commanded by Capt. William Blackwell of the 11th Virginia Regiment on Continental Establishment during the Revolutionary War that the said Samuel Elliott did this Deponent believes serve three years the period of his enlistment, that this Deponent until he was detached from this Company was one of the Guards of General Washington served in this same Company with the said Samuel Elliott and afterwards saw him a soldier in the American Army at various times and places which he does not now remember. *that this said Samuel Elliot is in such needy circumstances as to require the aid of his Country for support. Sworn to before me the day and year aforesaid Judge Robt. White I Robert White, Judge of the superior Court of Fauquier Va do certify that it appears to my satisfaction, that the said Samuel Elliot, did serve in the Revolutionary war, as stated in the preceding declaration, against the common enemy. And I now transmit the proceedings and testimony taken and had before me, to the secetary for the department of war, pursuant to the directions of the aforementioned act of Congress ~ Robt White I Berkeley Ward clerk of the Superior Court of Law of the County of Fauquier in the Commonwealth of Virginia do hereby certify that the above named Robert White is the sole and presiding Judge of the said Court. In Testimony whereof I have hereunto subscribed my name and annexed my private (there being no Official) Seal this 18th day of April in the year of our Lord 1818. B. Ward

I James Tongue, physician, depose and say, that I lived more than 25 years, about 4 miles from John Smith and Sarah his wife-- I was well acquainted with them; and was their family physician many years - The said John Smith and his wife were respectable people, and were believed and considered by the whole neighborhood to have been lawfully married and I do further declare, that on or about the 5 day of this present month I read in the family Bible of Astridge Kirty (a widow) one of the daughters of the said John Smith and Sarah his wife, and I distinctly remember, their oldest child ( John whom I know), was recorded in that bible as the son of the said John & Sarah his wife was born in 1786, and that the next child (now a widow Wayon, whom I also know) was born in 1787 and I do concientiously believe, that the above named Sarah Smith is the widow of the said John Smith-- that she is very old and helpless and has been perfectly blind for about 14 years- is an object of charity, and richly deserves the bounty of the goverment-- and if she comes under the pension laws of the United States-- she is now in great need James Tongue District of Columbia Washington County to wit acknowledged & sworn before me this 28th day December 1842 Clem't T Cooke JPeace

State aforesaid till April 1831 when they moved to Rhea County East Tennessee where they lived as husband and wife till May _1833 when the said John Carrol Adams died; that she returned in October 1835 to Richland District South Carolina; that she has remained a widow ever since her husband's John Carrol Adams' death, that she has no family Record showing either the date of her marriage or the births of her children having left the family Bible in Tennessee. She further states that the said John Carrol Adams was a private and corporal under Captain [Joseph] Warley Col William Thomson's Regiment, third South Carolina Continental line three years, was at the battle of Savannah and several smaller engagements, was regularly discharged which discharge she has seen but is now lost; that he was afterwards Sergeant in Sumter's Brigade (General Thomas Sumter) State Troops, that he was at the battle of King's Mountain and Cowpens; that he served seven years having enlisted under Col William Thomson when about twenty two years of age; that they were engaged to be married before the war begun; that he was born in North Carolina; that he served the United States in the armies of the Revolutionary war against the common enemy. she further declares that her oldest child Ann Rona Adams was born the 2nd day of January 1786, that she (Sarah Adams) is the mother of nine childrren and that she is very poor and needy being quite infirm and aged. She hereby declares that her name is not on

Rensselaer County Archibald Bull Clerk of said County do hereby certify that Herman Knickerbocker Esquire before whom the within Declaration purports to have been sworn and also before whom the within certificates were sworn and signed was on the day of the date of the same. First Judge of said County courts and that I am well acquainted with his hand writing and verily believe his signatures within subscribed are genuine. Howard Depy there in active service and was in several engagements until after the surrender of General Burgoyne, That in 1778, the company to which he belonged were called upon to garrison & did guard the different posts & forts on the northern frontier that in March 1780 this deponent was called out & marched to Ticonderoga where he continued three months to discover where the British shipping then lay that he was employed actively all the time in making & repairing forts - this deponent transferred to a company commanded by Capt Hodge & served nine months at one time at Lake George & fort Adam, this deponent served at different stations & under different commanders during the whole of the war, at one he was called out to Fort Edward & Lake George in the regiment commanded by Col. Peter Yates Governor Clinton was also out and commanded did person his actual services as would exceed three years and more. Deponent was born in Esopus Ulster County and at the age of fifteen years moved to Schaghticoke, Rensselaer County where he has ever since resided and is now seventy eight years of age and too disabled and infirm to attend any court or even leave his house. that he is known by John Van Antwerp, Solomon Acker and generally by all the old and respectable inhabitants, residing in the town of Schaghticoke, who can testify to his character for truth & veracity and their belief of his services as a revolutionary soldier-- but he further saith, that he knows no settled Clergyman now living who can concur in the above belief - nor has he any documentary evidences of service now remaining - he hereby relinquished every claim to a pension or annuity except the present, & he ceases that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any State

I John Lindley of the age of sixty six years do testify and say that I came to america with Burgoines army during the revolutionary war & that I deserted from said Burgoines army a few days before his capture and went to Albany and enlisted in to colonel Willets regiment of the New York line and served during the remainder of the war & further testify and say that I was well acquainted with James Austin Now an inhabitant of Highgate in the county of Franklin & State of Vermont who was then a soldier in said regiment and served with me for more than one year in capt Harris company of that regiment and untill [sic] the regiment was discharged John Lindley [signature] Franklin county ss January 16 1825 Personally appeared John Lindley & after being duly cautioned and carefully examined made solemn oath that above deposition by him signed contains the whole truth and nothing but the truth before me Jesse Carpenter Justice of the Peace Joshua Barnes Jr of Ferrisburgh in the county of Addison and State of vermont testify and say that I am acquainted with the above named John Lindley and believe him to be a man of truth and veracity and further testify that he is in verry indigent circumstances wholly destitute of property except one old mare Joshua Barnes [illegible] Franklin county ss January 16 = 1826 personally appeared Joshua Barnes Jr and made oath that the above affidavit is true before me Jesse Carpenter Justice of the Peace I hereby certify that I believe J Barnes to be a man of truth and veracity Jesse Carpenter Justice of the Peace

SCHEDULE. __ First Judicial District of Maryland 88. Composed of Saint Marys Charles and Prince George County. Being a court of Record with Jurisdiction unlimited in amount with a power of fine and imprisonment - On this Seventh day of April 1822, personally appeared in open court (a) being a court of record (b) for the said districted and county, of Prince George, Benjamin Duvall of Elisha as the Court of Prince George aforesaid aged sixty three years, resident in said county, in said district, who, being first duly sworn, according to law, doth, on his oath, declare that he served in the Revolutionary war as follows: (c) That he enlisted in the year 1776 as a soldier in the army of the revolution for the period of four months in the flying Comp under Captain Robert Bowie & he there reenlisted for three years under Captain William D. Beall of the sixth Maryland Regiment under Colonel Joseph Ford. That he was in the battles of the White Plains, Fort Lee, Fort Washington, Brandywine, German Town and Monmouth. And I do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States, on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress, entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary war," passed on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property, or securities, contracts, or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. (d) A Schedule of Property as follows 2 negro women of small value $400.00 4 small negro children now an expense in supporting 200.00 2 horses old 30.00 4 head of cattle 20.00 Sworn to, and declared, on their Eleventh day of April Eighteen hundred and Twenty two in open Court - That his family consists of an aged and helpless wife aged sixty eight years, a daughter aged 3 years - with (?) - I, Aquila Beall clerk of Prince George County Court do hereby certify, that the foregoing oath (or affirmation) and the schedule thereto annexed, are truly copied from the record of the said court; and I do further certify, that it is the opinion of the said court that the total amount in value of the property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule is 650 dollars and - In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand, and affixed the seal of the said court, on this Eleventh day of April 1822 Aquila Beall Clerk of the Court for the County of Prince George

State of Massachusetts County of Worcester I, Samuel Dunton - a Citizen of the United States, now resident at Southborough in the County of Worcester in the State aforesaid, do on oath testify and declared, that in the War of the Revolution, In April AD 1777 I entered and was engaged in the land service of the United States on the continental establishment, and served accordingly from that time to April AD 1780 as a private soldier against the common enemy, without any interruption or absence; that I belonged to Capt Bejam Gates Company in the fifth Massachusetts regiment Col. Putnam for 3 years ending in April 1780 - and that I left the service in April 1780 - having received an honorable discharge which I have lost. and that, by reason of my reduced circumstances in life and poverty, I stand in need of assistance from my country support, being now of the age of 65 years & infirm - I further declare that I served two other campaigns in the army of the United States of 5 months & three months that I was in the battle of White Pains & that the above services were performed in the Massachusetts line And I hereby relinquish all claims to every pension heretofore allowed me by the laws of the United States, if any may be or hath been so allowed. His Samuel X Dunton Mark Att. E. Bangs BE IT REMEBERED, That on the 13th day of May in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and 18 pursuant to a law of the United States, entitled, "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the and land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War," made and passed on the 18th of March, A.D. 1818, personally appeareth before me, Edward Bangs Judge CC Com Pleas [illegible][illegible] the abovenamed Samuel Dunton and after due examination and caution to testify and declare the whole truth, he maketh oath to the declaration aforesaid, and subsribes the same in my presence; and, on examination duly made by me the said Judge, it appeareth to my satisfaction that the said declaration is true. Given under my Hand and the Seal of said Court, the day of the date aforesaid. Edward Bangs

From Lancaster County Pennsylvania, he removed to Augusta County Virginia: from Augusta to Montgomery County Virginia, and from Montgomery County, after the Revolutionary War had terminated, he removed to Washington County Tennessee, and from Washington to Greene County Tennessee where he has resided for the last thirty years. He has no documentary evidence by which to establish the veracity of his statements and knows of no person whose testimony he can procure, who can testify to his Service: Anthony Dunkin [his mark] X Sworn to and subscribed before me this 25th day of October 1832 Cornelius Smith Justice of the Peace for Greene County State of Tennessee Greene County Personally came before me Cornelius Smith an acting Justice of the Peace in and for the County and State aforesaid Edwin Grubs and Azariah Doty (there being no clergyman resident in Anthony Dunkins vicinity) and make oath they are well acquainted with Anthony Dunkin the above applicant for a pension and believe him to be eighty eight years of age - That he is reputed and believed in the neighborhood where he resides, to have been a soldier of the Revolution and that they concur in that opinion and believe he served as he states. And the said deponents further certify that they believe the said Anthony Dunkin is so enfeebled and afflicted by age, that he could not, without great danger to his existence, undergo the fatigue of being removed from his residence to the Court House (a distance of twelve miles ) in order to have his examination taken there. Sworn to and subscribed before me this 25th day of October 1832 Cornelius Smith Justice of the Peace for Greene County Edwin Grubs Azariah Doty [his mark] X

District of Pennsylvania On this Twenty Seventh day of March A.D. 1818, before me Richard Peters, Judge of the District Court of the United States in and for the Pennsylvania District, personally appeared William Drake, who, being duly sworn upon the Holy Evangelists of Almighty God, deposes and declares that during the war of the Revolution he served as a soldier in the Continental army, against the common court that on the 2d day of October 1777, he enlisted as a private in Captain George Flemings Company belonging to the Second Regiment of Artillery commanded at that time by Lt. Colonel Stevens, of the New York Line that he faithfully served in the said company for the time of Five Years and upwards, that is to say, until the 12th day of June 1783 when he received an honourable discharge from the commanding Officer of his Regiment that in the course of this long term of service, and previous thereto while acting in the Waggon Masters Department, he was present and assisting at the Battles of Brandywine, Germantown Monmouth and the Siege of York Town, that now in consequence of old age and infirmities, he is reduced to circumstances of peace indigence and distress and is in need of assistance from his country for support. And this Deponent further declares that he is now and always has been a resident Citizen of the United States, and that he does not at present relieve and never has received or been allowed any pension by the Laws of the United States, and that he is unable to produce other evidence of his Signature of William (his X Mark ) Drake Sworn and subscribed on the day and year aforesaid, before me Signature of Richard Peters

State of New York County of Rensselaer Ss} On this fifth day of September 1832 personally appeared in open Court before the Judge of the Troy Major Court now sitting John Doty a resident of Stephentown in the County of Rensselaer and State of New York aged seventy years who being first duly sworn according to law doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress passed June 1. 1832. That he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers and served as herein stated, that he enlisted in Captain James Smiths Company of the Regiment commanded by Colonel Mead in the fall of the year 1779 for nine months and served his time out vis. nine months that at the time he enlisted he resided in the Town of Saybrook in the State of Connecticut that during the aforesaid service he was stationed at Horseneck in the State of Connecticut aforesaid that the next year (vis. 1780) he enlisted in Captain Abner Smith Company of the Regiment commanded by Colonel Beebe and served in said Company six months was stationed at Horseneck aforesaid resided at the time of enlistment at Saybrook aforesaid, that during year aforesaid (vis. 1780) he enlisted in Captain Star's Company of the Regiment commanded by Colonel Samuel Canfield and marched from Saybrook aforesaid where he then resided, to West Point, in the State of New York marched through New Haven and other places in going to West Point served at West Point three months as a Corporal and had a Warrant but it has since been lost, that he has no documentary evidence and that he knows of no person whose testimony he can procure who can testify to his service he hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present and declares that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any State or (if any) only on that of the agency of the State of New York John Doty Sworn to & Subscribed the day & year aforesaid Archibald Bull Clerk I Samuel Dean a Clergyman residing in the Town of Stephenton, County of Rensselaer and State of New York hereby certify that I am well acquainted with John Doty who is named [crossed out] in the above declaration that I believe him to be seventy years of age that he is reputed and believed in the neighborhood

State of North Carolina Orange County Personally appeared before me Frederick Nash one of the Judges of the Sup. Courts of Law & Equity in and for the State aforesaid William Steel who being duly sworn upon the holy evangelist of Allmighty [sic] God deposeth & sayeth that in the year 1779 he enlisted in the army of the United States as a common soldier in the company commanded by Thos Donnoho of the 4th Regiment of North Carolina continentals commandd by Colonel Thaxton-- that he enlisted for the term of nine months & faithfully served out his time of service that he was duly discharged at Salisbury in said State--that he joined head quarter at Purysburg [sic] in South Carolina where Genrl. Lincoln then lay with his army early in the year 1779-- that he has lost his discharge-- that he was a corporal [illeg.] in that capacity in the battles of Brier Creek & Stone-- That he is in needy & reduced circumstances & stands in need of the assistance of his country & that this declaration is made for the purpose of entitling himself to the benefit of the Act of Congress made for the relief of the Soldiers of the Revolution William Steel his X mark Sworn to & subscribed before me this 29th of February AD 1820 F Nash JSCLE
