Troy Pa Oct 15th. 1837. Hon J. L. Edwards Dear Sir In the absence of Esquire Strait who has hitherto been engaged in behalf of Mrs. Joanna Corey widow of Ebenezer Corey decd I am requested to forward to the War Department the Copy of the family record of the said Ebenezer Corey decd with the affidavit of said Strait, which it appears to had been sent to the Department by Mr. Strait and returned by yourself with instructions for additional proof in regard to the manner time & the record was made & the transcription from the original as they had had their house burned. They have now procured as I conceive the necessary & required proof as respects the copying, and old Mrs. Coreys statement as I have it in the hand writing of a Mr Burritt who is a Son in law Esq S Strait and Superintends the Squires business in his absence is that the old Bible was not burned, that She had it in her hand and secured it, and that after the transcription was made she gave the old Bible to one of the family relatives and that he has moved to the West. This it is true is not evidence that would be I suppose considered by the Department. But I am inclined to believe that the Department will be fully satisfied of the relationship of Mrs Corey as widow of Ebenezer Corey decd and grant to her the arrears at this time and the continuance of her husband Pension for the very small amount of her life as she is now very aged & destitute and very much enfeebled by age & infirmity; and I am as well satisfied from her character & appearance and my acquaintance with her and her husband Ebenezer Corey decd for about twenty years and having drawn his Pension the most of the time while he received it, that she is his said Ebenezer Coreys decd only lawful widow and was his wife during the Revolution, as I am that this is a Pension Agency or War Department, and I hope and trust the Department will now so considered the

(14) we came in sight of them; but the river being high and rising General Greene considered it not safe to undertake a cross for the British were on the opposite bank. I think the British used about ten thousand rails in the formation of a floating raft to pass over upon and after they had passed were destroyed as much as was in their power the means they had used in crossing General Greene considered it safest and best for our common Country to retrace his steps. and push for the Eutaw Springs. Upon our arrival near this place we discovered the British We halted and prepared for Battle. I think this Battle was in Sept. 1781. but will not say certainly. General Greene gave Lord Rawdon a fight and compelled him to retreat unto his British subjects and flee the Country. During the Battle I and my company and several others was reserved by the orders of the commander in chief to cover his retreat should he deem it necessary for the safty of his Country to make one. From the above place I was sent back with my company & several men to our proper County & state to protect and defend it and our women & children from the plundering of the tories & British; for they were scattered over the whole Country and distress and dismay covered our whole land. I was by General Greene^ ordered not to disband my company upon our return home but to be ever vigilant and scout the whole upper Country of our State. untill he should require our assistance and if he should we would immediately be informed of it & ordered to march. I done as ordered untill I received instructions from Head Quarters that peace was made and ["know" crossed out] no more war for us. Upon which news I was discharged from the service & ordered to discharge my company. I done so which ended my labors. I think it was in the spring of (1783) that we were discharged as above stated. In this declaration amendatory of my former. I have endeavored to be as particular and definite in relation to my services as was in my power I know one thing, that, if I cannot satisfy the war department of my services my country is enjoying the fruits of my of my labor for six years spent in her service-- In all of the above service I was called upon regularlly & legally by my Country & for the periods above maintained I was in the field as a regular embodied Militia soldyer as above stated--As I have formerly stated I was not

The State of South Carolina Beaufort District In the Court of Common Pleas On this Ninth day of April in the year of our Lord One thousand Eight hundred and twenty four personally appeared in Open Court in the Court aforesaid being a Court of Record expressly made as by the laws of the State proceeding according to the course of the common law and having unlimited jurisdiction in all civil [matters] and keeping a record of its proceedings and held at Coosawhatchie in and for the District of Beaufort aforesaid John Cook aged seventy years and upwards, a resident of Prince Williams Parish in the District of Beaufort aforesaid who being first duly sworn according to law doth on his oath declare as follows – I John Cook do solemnly swear that I served in the Revolutionary War, for three years, that I enlisted about the 15th day of July 1775 in the company commanded by Captain [Richard] Shubrick in the Regiment of Colonel [Isaac] Motte, in the line of the State of South Carolina on the Continental establishment, and that I continued to serve in the said Corps until the 13th day of July 1778, when I was discharged, having served out the time of my enlistment. That I was in the Battle at Fort Moultrie, and received a regular discharge. And I do solemnly swear that I am a native born citizen of South Carolina, and was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March 1818, and that I have not since that time by gift, sale or in any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provision of an act of Congress entitled an act to Provide for Certain persons engaged in the land and Naval Service of the United States in the Revolutionary War, passed on the 18th of March 1818, that in fact I have neither sold, given away or disposed of any property at all since the 18th of March 1818. And that I have not nor has any person in trust for me any property or securities, contracts or debts due to me nor have I any income at all, nor the use of any property other than the property contained in the Schedule hereto annexed and by me subscribed; and I further swear that I am aged and infirm, being of the age of seventy years & upwards and broken with years. That I live and have lived for more than 20 years last past in Prince Williams Parish in the District of Beaufort aforesaid, that my only occupation is that of a labor, and husbandman, and that I am not now capable of labor, and never had or exercise any other trade or calling, that my children are all grown and settled in life, that they are needy, and neither contribute nor are able to contribute, to my support. That no one lives with me but my wife who is without property and about two years older than myself. That I made a declaration to obtain the benefit of the Act of Congress herein before mentioned, after the passing thereof, which said Declaration having been mislaid and lost I am unable to give the date thereof, but that I was inscribed on the Pension list Role of South Carolina agency at the rate of $8 per month commencing on the 16th day of September 1818 as by the Certificate of the Honorable J C Calhoun Secretary of war No. 14866 dated the 10th September 1819 and now in my possession will appear. That since the 4th March 1820 I have not received any part of said pension. That the following are the reasons why I did not exhibit a Schedule of my property prior to the passing of the act of 1823 (having been told of such an act at the time of making this declaration) that I did not know why my pension was stopped nor how I could have it restored until very

State of Maine County of Lincoln SS Be it known that o this 4th day of August in the year of our Lord 1846 Dorcas Wallace the applicant named herein being proved to be of the age of ninety eight years the present month of August and lining in Phipsburgh and unable by old age to stand from her dwelling to attend Court, I at her request visited her habitation & personally examined her under oath and proved her to be of sound mine & memory. And in extreme poverty. And she being sworn by me and fully understanding the nature of an oath she dictated and from her own lips the foregoing declaration of the Revolutionary services of Samuel Wallace her late husband. I further certify that I carefully read over the same in her hearing and she being unable to write her name made her mark thereto in the presence of witnesses and then made solemn oath that said declaration is true. In testimony whereof I have hereunto caused the seal of the Probate Court for the County of Lincoln the same being a Court of Record, to be affixed subscribed my name as Judge of said Court the day & year first above written. Nathe Groton Judge of Probate

State of New York [Otugo] County [ Sg John R. Bowdich ]of New Lisbon in Said county aged 53 years being duly sworn according to law doth depose and say that he was well acquainted with Benjamin Wells and Rachel Wells his wife, that this deposant taught a school in the neighborhood of the said Benjamin Wells requested this deposant to transcribe his family Record from an old and much decayed Bible, that agreeable to said Record into a new Bible, that agreeable of said request, this desponent did transcribe said Record into a new Bible. That the leaf of the said Bible containing said Record As hereunto attached, and is in the hand writing of this desposant and is a correct transcript of the record in the old Bible as aforesaid, that this despondent has been well aquainted with the said Benjamin & Rachel Wells for many years, that this desposant has frequently heard his Father ( Asa Bowdich) and the said Benjamin Wells converce upon the war of the Revolution, that this deponant understood they were both in the service together, this deponant has heard them speak of being in the Monmouth battle together. That the father of this deponant is Mr Bowdick died in 1812. This deponant further says that he has been informed and believes that the said Benjamin Wells is now dead, that he died at the Residence of his Son in the State of Ohio. And that he was a Pensioner of the United States at the time of his death. That the said Rachel Wells now remains the widow of the said Benjamin Wells and resides with her daughter Anna Mathewson in the town of Butternuts in this county. This deposant further

Georgetown, Brown Co. Ohio July 20 1853. Dear Sir: We received some weeks ago a certificate for a Pension in form of Mary Wells, widow of Benjamin Wells, a revolutionary soldier, which will be found evidence in the Pension Office, underact of Feb, 3. 1853 Page 170 Vol. 8. The certificate is only for $20 per year. We write this to inquire if the Department is not laboring under some mistake in the matter. We understand from [illegible] [illegible] that Benj. Wells Served Seven years in the revolutionary war. Would not that entitle his widow to mare that $20 per year. We understand that the act of Feb. 3. 1853, said widows married subsequent to Jany 1. 1800 all the rights and privileges of those married at an earlier date. Will you be so good as to give this matter an investigation, as the widow is very poor and needy and will be but slightly benefited by so small a sum as the one granted, as it would [illegible] her half the amount granted to [illegible] is from Cincinnati. Is she not entitled to back pay on pension money. We had before [illegible] she was entitled to receive under the act of July 29. 1848, by virtue of the act of Feb. 1853, an amount equal to the Pension of his [illegible], to commence on the 11th of March 1848, and continue [illegible] life or widowhood -- also, one years pension under the act of March 3d, 1843, section 1, and four years under the act of June 17 1844, section 100. We hope the department

State of South Carolina { Pickens District { Before me Miles M. Norton a Notary Public + Ex-officio Magistrate in and for the District aforesaid, personally appeared Joseph Young Esq. who is at present an acting magistrate, and to me well known as a respectable truthful citizen, and one in whom every confidence may be placed; and after being duly sworn, sayeth on oath that he mother Nancy Young is the widow of Levy Young decd (sic deceased) who was a Revolutionary Pensioner, and who was reputed to have been a soldier of the Revolution; that for about one year before his death, the said Levi Young and his wife Nancy Young (this Deponents Father + Mother) came to the House of this Deponent to live with him, they being old and helpless, and there remained until the death of the said Levi Young. That this Deponent started to August Ga. [Georgia] in (?) 1838 and left his Father an Mother at his House, and on his return in about two weeks, found his mother yet there, and his Father said to be dead. That at the time his Father and Mother came to his House to live, they brought with them their old Family Bible. "Edinburgh. Printed by Mark and Charles Kerr, his Majesty's "Printers. MDCCXCIV" the foregoing is an extract from the Title Page of the new Testament annexed to said Bible, (the title Page of the old Testament being out) That this deponent is knowing to the fact of the said Bible being the same which his Father Levi Young kept in his Family and is which he recorded the marriage of himself + wife, and the births of their children, amongst which is to be formed the birth of this deponent, which is in the following words "Joseph Young was born March 25th 1785" and the marriage of Levi Young and Nancy Marchbanks (the maiden name of this deponents mother) in words as follows "Levi Young married to Nancy Marchbanks March 15th 1782" This deponent further sayeth that the Record in the Bible as above mentioned and quoted, is in the hand writing of

The Deposition of Isasc Webster of Bennington in the County of Bennington & State of Vermont, who testifies & says that on the first day of March in the year one thousand seven hundred & seventy seven he enlisted for three years, as Serjeant [Sergeant] in the Regiment commanded by Capt. Seth Warner, & continued in said Regt - untill the expiration of his term of service - your Deponent further says that that [sic] he was well acquainted with all the officers of said Regt - and well knows that Benjamin Hopkins of Bennington in April 1777 was the Adjutant of said Regt - untill one Pain, whose Christian name I have forgotten was appointed to that office, which your Deponent believes took place in the latter part of 1778 or the beginning of 1779. when the said Benjamin Hopkins received the appointment of Captain in sd. Regt as was understood, & the said Benjamin Hopkins continued in that office, & did the duty of a Captain untill he was slain by the Enemy near Lake George in September 1779. Isaac Webster Bennington March 11th 1822 - Sworne [sworn] to before me Aaron Robinson Justice of peace Aaron Robinson was on 11th March 1822 justice of the peace for Bennington County Vermont & the above signature of Aaron Robinson is in his hand writing R L Mallary Rep from Vermont

see if they could find any tracks of Indians which they expected were those found on back which after following some time they found was Steering for canidy, and they left it and returned was out two weeks at this time he believes that during those years he was out in actual service one half of the time and his duty was as arduous as if he had been stationed in the fort all the time and in fact as to the hardships he would have preferred to have him in the regular service. he has no documentary evidence of his service. the Clergyman of his town is out of health and unable to attend court he is known to William Andrews Butterfield of Homer who can state as to his reputation. Colonel Fletcher was occasionally over at the fort several of Gen E Allen's brothers were at the fort after He here relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present, and declares that his name is not on the Pension Roll of any agency of any State & Subscribed the Increase M Hooker day & year aforesaid Samuel Hotchkiss W. STATE OF VERMONT. COUNTY OF WINDHAM ss. At the County court, begun and held at New-Fane, within and for the County of Windham, on the second Monday of June, in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and twenty..... PRESENT—Hon. PHINEHAS WHITE, Esq. Chief Judge. Hon. JOHN ROBERTS, } Hon. GILBERT DENISON, ESQRS.} Assistant Judges. ON this 20th day of June, A. D. 1820, personally appeared in open court, being a court of record for the said county, proceeding according to the course of the common law, with a civil jurisdiction unlimited in point of amount, keeping a record of their proceedings, and having, in certain cases, the power of fine and imprisonment, Amos Holbrook aged 63 years, resident in Townshend in said county, who, being first duly sworn according to law, doth, on his oath, declare that he served in the Revolutionary War as follows: one year in the Newhampshire line - Capt. Joseph Easterbrooks Col Tim'y Beedle - That he has received a pension under the act of Congress of the United States of the 18th March, 1818, that the number of his pension certificate is 13.265 and the date of his original declaration is April 11, 1818. AND I DO SOLEMNLY SWEAR, That I was a resident citizen of the United States on the eighteenth day of March, one thousand eight hundred and eighteen: and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner whatever, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress entitled, "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the Land and Naval Service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War," passed on the eighteenth day of March, one thousand eight hundred and eighteen: And that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts, or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the Schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. Amos Holbrook SCHEDULE of real and personal estate, necessary clothing and bedding excepted. Personal property principally attached by creditors - I deeded one half of a small Farm worth in the whole about eight hundred dollars to my son Franklin twelve or thirteen years ago - Since that time my said son has helped me more than to pay for the half which I hold and have note deeded. I owe more than I am worth and cannot pay Amos Holbrook AND I do also swear that my occupation is [crossed out] ^was that of working on land. I have not gone across the house without help for more than two years - my wife is also very infirm her ancle [ankle] is drawn nearly out of joint with disease and we are in a good measure helpless - my Daughter Lydia is 22 years of age of feeble constitution - a son 18 years of age, of common health - My son Franklin has left his farm and gone to Canada to work for the use of the family he is 36 years of age & unmarried and has done much for my support before I had a pension Amos Holbrook SWORN to and DECLARED in open court on the 20th day of June, A. D. 1820, Before Gilbert Denison JUDGE. I James Elliot, Clerk of the County Court for the County of Windham, in the State of Vermont, do hereby certify, that the foregoing oath, and the Schedule thereto annexed, are truly copied from the fines and records of the said court: And I do further certify, that it is the opinion of the said Court, that the total amount in value of the property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule is Five Hundred dollars, and annual income of the same 35 dollars. In testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand, and affixed the seal of the said Court on this seventeenth day of July 1820. James Elliot, CLERK OF THE COURT FOR THE COUNTY OF WINDHAM.

State of Georgia Green County ⎬ Be it Known that on this 21st July 1845 before me Samuel M Davison a Justice of the peace in and for Said County personally Came and appeared Eleanor Hogg a resident of said County, who being first duly sworn according to Law deposeth and Said on oath that She is the Widow of Samuel Hogg now deceased, that she has alway understood and verily believes that the said Samuel Hogg was a soldier and faithfully served as a private in the War of the Revolution in the South Carolina Militia, that said Samuel Hogg before his death made application for a pension under an act of Congress passed on the 7th June 1832. That from bodily infirmity (he having lost use of his speech some time previous to his death he was unable to prosecute the same to a successful conclusion, and that for proof of his services she refered to his declaration now on file, and deponent further declares that was she legally married to the Said Samuel Hogg in Green County State of Georgia. The only proof which she is now in posession of having a record of the marriage in a small family bible and owned by her at the time of their marriage.. the date for which is on the leaf hereunto annexed. that the birth of their first Child was in 1794 which died in infancy. and the date of the birth of the balance of her Children which is recorded in a Bible of larger sise which was procured by her husband some time after their marriage the leaf of which is hereunto annexed is the only record which She is in possession of. That She he was Married by William Greer an acting Justice of the peace who is now dead, and despondent further declared that the said Samuel Hogg died on the 1st day of November 1838 leaving her his widow, and that she is still his widow and makes these statements in order to obtain the pension due the said Samuel Hogg her deceased husband. under the act of congress of the 7th June 1832. and for proof of his Services She refers to the Evidence hereunto annexed. Sworn to and subscribed before me this 21st day of July 1865 Samuel M Davison J.P. Eloner Hogg

Witness whereof I have hereunto set hand & seal this Twenty sixth day of July in the year of Our Lord one thousand eight hundred & Thirty one Sealed & Delivered In presence of William Hoff his X mark N.B. part of the word “Department” written on an [erazure?] before signing I McConihe State of New York County of Rensselaer}ss. I hereby certify that On the 26th day of July A.D. 1831 before me personally appeared the above named William Hoff to me known to be the same person described me who executed the foregoing instrument and he acknowledged that he executed the same for the uses & purposes therein mentioned and further certify that the reason why he the said William made his mark to the said Instrument is that he never learned to write even his name & cannot now write. Virginia At a Hustings Court [see comments] continued and held for the City of Norfolk on the 27th day of July 1849 William Jennings having departed this life in this City intestate as it said more than three months, and no person applying for administration of his estate, on the motion of Robinson and Clark it is ordered that William B Lamb Sergeant of this City [term "Sergent of the City" was replaced by Sherriff in the 1960s] take into his hands the estate of the said William Jennings and administer the same according to law [entered by the same hand:] I John Williams Clerk of the Hustings Court of the City of Norfolk aforesaid, in the State of Virginia, do hereby certify that the above is a true copy from the records of the said Court. In Testimony whereof I have hereunto affixed the seal of the said Court, and subscribed my name this twenty eighth day of July in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and forty nine [July 28, 1849], and of the commonwealth the seventy fourth Jno. [John] Williams cc [ cc = Clerk of Court] [to the left of the last paragraph is an image of a seal placed on the document. (continued from previous page) ...I was attached to marched to West Point, while we lay at West Point I was one of the three thousand men ordered out on a foraging party over the North River within the British lines. W as gone seven days and nights, after returning to West Point (word crossed out) remaining there about six weeks, the Jersey Troops returned to New Jersey winter quarters, and Hutted at the Pompton Mountains, while we lay at that lace I was honorably discharged by Capitol Hendry in the month of December 1780 my term for which I enlisted having the expired which was just before the Troop revolted, he was in no general engagements yet he endured many hardships and perils, and served his country faithfully during all the time for which he enlisted being six months. That previous to his enlisting in the regular services as aforesaid, and while the British were in Philadelphia he volunteered in the State Militia and matched out with Captain Platt's company to Haddon Field in New Jersey. While he was in the service under Captain Platts he aided his company in capturing the Brig "Lord Howe" on the Delaware, by marching to her on the ice made all the English on board prisoners being seven in number and dismantled her and took out all the things they could, and burnt her. He served in Capt. Platts company and in Captain Wheatons company as a volunteer bout three month. That he has no documentary evidence nor knows of any person by whom he can prove his service. He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or an annuity except the present and he declares that his name is not on the pension roll of any agency in any State. Sworn to and for.... The facts stated will afford one of the principal means of corroborating the declaration of the applicant, if true, or of detecting the imposition, if one be attempted ; and unless, therefore, these are amply and clearly set forth, no favorable decision can be expected. An applicants will appear before some Court of Record in the County, in which they reside, and there subscribe and be sworn to, one of the declarations above provided, according to the nature of his case. The Court will propound the following (m) interrogatories to all applicants for a pension, on account of service in the Militia, State troops, or Volunteers, except the Militia of New Hampshire and the State troops of Virginia. 1. Where and in what year were you born? 2. Have you any record of your age, and if so, where is it? Where were you living when called into service; where have you lived since the Revolutionary war , and where do you now live? 4. How were you called into service; were you drafted, did you volunteer, or were you a substitute? And if a substitute, for whom? State the names of some of the Regular Officers, who were with the troops, where you served; such Continental and Militia Regiments as you can recollect, and the general circumstances of your services Did you ever receive a discharge from the service, and if so, by whom was it giv- 6. alien and what has become of it? Did you ever receive a commission, and if so, by whom was it signed, and what Office has become of it? State the names of persons to whom you are known in your present neighborhood, and who can testify as to your character for veracity, and their belief of your services as a soldier of the Revolution. The Court will see that he answers to these questions are embodied in the declaration, and they are requested to annex their opinions of the truth of the statement of the applicant. The applicant will further produce in Court, if the same can be done, in the opinion of the Court, without too much expense and inconvenience to him, two respectable persons -one of whom should be the nearest clergyman, if one lives in the immediate vicinity of such applicant, who can testify, from their acquaintance with him, that they believe he is of the age he represents, and that he is reputed and believed in the neighborhood to have been a Revolutionary soldier, and that they concur in that opinion. If one of these persons is a Clergyman, the Court will so certify, and they will also certify, to the character and standing of other persons, giving such certificates. proof, except the declaration of the party. And the Courts are requested to be very particular in the enquiry whether the belief is general, and whether any doubts have ever existed upon the subject. Applicants unable to appear in Court by reason of bodily infirmity, may make the declaration before required, and submit to the examination, before a Judge or Justice of a Court of Record of the proper county, and the Judge or Justice will execute the duties, which the Court is herein requested to perform, and will also certify that the applicant cannot, from bodily infirmity, attend the Court. Whenever any official act is required to be done by a Judge or Justice of a Court of Record, or by a Justice of the peace, the certificate of the Secretary of State or Territory, or of the proper Clerk of the Court or County, under his seal of office, will be annexed, stating that such person is a Judge or Justice of a Court of Record, or a Justice of the Peace, and that the signature annexed is his genuine signature. 3 will be indispensable to a favorable action upon his case The facts stated will afford one of the principal means of corroborating the declaration of the applicant, if true, or of detecting the imposition, if one be attempted; and unless, therefore, these are amply and clearly set forth, no favorable decision can be ex-expected. All applicants will appear before some Court of Record in the County in which they reside, and there subscribe and be sworn to, one of the declarations above provided, according to the nature of his case. The Court will propound the following (m) interrogatories to all applicants for a pension, on account of service in the Militia, State troops, or Volunteers, except the Militia of New Hampshire and the State troops of Virginia. 1. Where and in what year were you born? 2. Have you any record of your age, and if so, where is it? 3. Where were you living when called into service; where have you lived since the Revolutionary war, and where do you now live? 4. How were you called into service; were you drafted, did you volunteer, or were you a substitute? And if a substitute, for whom? 5. State the names of some of the Regular Officers, who were with the troops, where you served; such Continental and Militia Regiments as you can recollect, and the general circumstances of your services. 6. To a Soldier. Did you ever receive a discharge from the service, and if so, by whom was it given and what has become of it? To an Officer. Did you ever receive a commission, and if so, by whom was it signed, and what has become of it? 7. State the names of persons to whom you are known in your present neighborhood, and who can testify as to your character for veracity, and their belief of your services as a soldier of the Revolution. The Court will see that the answers to these questions are embodied in the declaration, and they are requested to annex their opinions of the truth of the statement of the applicant. The applicant will further produce in Court, if the same can be done, in the opinion of the Court, without too much expense and inconvenience to him, two respectable persons--one of whom should be the nearest clergyman, if one lives in the immediate vicinity of such applicant, who can testify, from their acquaintance with him, that they believe he is of the age he represents, and that he is reputed and believed in the neighborhood to have been a Revolutionary soldier, and that they concur in that opinion. If one of these persons is a Clergyman, the Court will so certify, and they will also certify to the character and standing of other persons giving such certificates. The traditionary evidence of service is deemed very important, in the absence of any direct proof, except the declaration of the party. And the Courts are requested to be very particular in the enquiry whether the belief is general, and whether any doubts have ever existed upon the subject. Applicants unable to appear in Court, by reason of bodily infirmity, may make the declaration before required, and submit to the examination, before a Judge or Justice of a Court of Record of the proper county, and the Judge or Justice will execute the duties, which the Court is herein requested to perform, and will also certify that the applicant cannot, from bodily infirmity, attend the Court. Whenever any official act is required to be done by a Judge or Justice of a Court of Record, or by a Justice of the Peace, the certificate of the Secretary of State or Territory, or of the proper Clerk of the Court or County, under his seal of office, will be annexed, stating that such person is a Judge or Justice of a Court of Record, or a Justice of the Peace, and that the signature annexed is his genuine signature. No payments can be made on account of the services of any person, who may have died before the taking effect of the act of June 7, 1832; and in case of death subsequent thereto, and before the declaration herein required is made, the parties interested will transmit such evidence as they can procure, taken and authenticated before a Court of Record, showing the services of the deceased, the period of his death, the opinion of the neighborhood respecting such services, the title of the claimant, and the opinion of the Court upon the whole matter. [a] The declarant must appear in open Court, unless prevented from delay so by reason of bodily infirmity, in which case the declarant will for on the rule laid down for his guidance. [b] The declarant must make his declaration in the county where he resides. If he should fail to do so, he must assign a sufficient reason for conforming to the rule. [c] The age of the claimant must invariably be mentioned. [d] The declarant must mention the person or persons of the war when he served. [e] Every continental officer or soldier must give the name of the Colonel under whom he served; otherwise a satisfactory examination of the claim cannot be had. Every claimant must state, with precision, the length of his service, and the different grades in which he served, in language definite as to enable the Department to determine to what amount of pension he is entitled. In a case where the applicant cannot, by reason of the loss of memory, state precisely how long he served, he should amend his declaration by making an affidavit in the following words "Personally appeared before me, the undersigned, a Justice of the Peace, &c. A. B. who, being duly sworn, deposeth and saith, that, by reason of old age, and the consequent loss of memory, he cannot swear positively as to the precise length of his service; but, according to the best of his recollection, he served not less than the persons mentioned below, and in the following grades: --For----year---months, and ----days, I served as a ---For---months and ---days, I served as a ---; and for such service I claim a pension." It is important, in all cases, to determine with precision the other for which each applicant served, and the particular rank he held, as the law directs the pension to be paid according to the grade of the pensioner and the length of his service. The use of the phrase about three or four months is too indefinite, and all such qualifying expressions are objectionable. Some persons who apply for pensions merely state that they served two years in the militia, &c, without specifying the tours, the names of the officers, and other particulars respecting their service. This form of a declaration is highly objectionable. It must, in every case, be clearly shown under what officers the applicant served; the duration of each term of engagement; the particular place or places where the service was performed, that the applicant served with an embodied corps called into service by competent authority; that he was either in the field or in garrison; and for the time during which the service was performed, he was not employed in any civil pursuit. [f] The law makes the relinquishment indispensable. [g] The opinion of the Court is always required. [h] The Clerk must give his certificate in every case. [i] The Clerk must affix his seal, and if it has no device or inscription by which it can be distinguished from any other seal, or if he has no public seal of office, the certificate of a Member of Congress, proving the official character and signature of the certifying officer, should accompany the papers. Mode of authenticating papers. In every instance where the certificate of the certifying officer who authenticates the papers is not written on the same sheet of paper which contains the affidavit, or other papers authenticated, the certificate must be attached thereto by a piece of tape or narrow ribbon, the ends of which must as was the seal of office of the certifying officer, so as to prevent any paper from being improperly attached to the certificate. Proof of Service. [j] Is a case where the name of the applicant is not found on the records of the Department, he must prove his service by two credible witnesses who are required to set forth in the affidavits the tree of the claimant's staring the service, and the pain and manner of his leaving the same, as well at the regiment, company, and but to which he belonged. The magistrate who may administer the oaths must certify to the credibility of the and the state character and signature of the magistrate must be certified by the proper officer, under his seal of office. The notes from [a] to [i] are all equally applicable to the cases of Militia men, Volunteers and State Troops. The proof required by rule is note [j] applies to continental troops only. [k] This traditionary death is indispensable is militia cases. [l] If a witness cannot be found, a declarant must state the fact. [m] The answers to the interrogatories must all be written, and sent to the War Department, with the declaration.

Mr. Whittier served as Captain of a company of Militia in the last war with Great Britain for which service he has with many others received a Bounty Land Warranty of 40 acres. He has ever been a worthy man-an upright citizen-a devoted Christian one who deserves our kindly sympathy and notice. Amid all of his troubles he has ever been remarkable for those exhibitions of Christian sympathy and good will, which will always secure the confidence and esteem of those around us. he supported his mother during her last sickness (she having been confined to her bed with a lingering, painful disease for more than 6 years) and was assiduous in his attentions, watching by her side a great portion of the time with all the solicitude of a child. He also supported his father in law (Mr. Lunt) for some 10 or12 years. After the Revolution the family suffered severely from the great depreciation of the Continental currency as Bills of Credit reducing them to a state of comparative destitution, from which our worthy friend has not been able to rise. Mr. Whittier was always a patriot and a true Whig. I should be pleased to hear from you as soon as you can make it convenient.

State of New Jersey Hunterdon County Ss Personally appeared before me Uriah Lance one of the Justices of the peace in for said County William Roberson a credible witness on his oath saith that in taking the affidavit of Christy Little a Revolutionary Soldier and a Revolutionary pensioner, and the said Christy Little Stated to this deponent that Hezekiah Jones acted as teamster in the regiment with the said Little for the space of Eighteen months or two years under Robert Little as team Master in the service of the United States in the revolutionary war and then was pressed in hearing arms served for three years and upwards and the best of this deponents knowledge and belief, that the name of the commander of the regiment in which he and Little served was Colonel Lamb, and the said Little stated that in coming from stony point that Jones Waggon was upset and Jones fell under the waggon and caused a great alarm amongst the teamsters thinking he was killed and with difficulty he was extricated, deponent also saith Elijah Humel a revolutionary Soldier and pensioner who stated to this deponent that Jones served as a soldier with him in arms in said war, and that Leonard Martin also a revolutionary soldier and and pensioner stated the same facts as Elijah Hummel, This deponent believes what they stated to be a fact as they were respectable and creditable men and this deponent was a Justice of the peace at the time taking these affidavits, above mentioned, and also deponent makes this affidavit without any fear or reward or compulsion whatsoever. William Roberson Sworn and subscribed before me Uriah Lance (at Baptist town). One of the justices of the peace in and for said county this seventeenth day of July in the year of our Lord one thousand Eight hundred and Fifty four Uriah Lance J.P

District of Pennsylvania ss} On this Twenty fourth day of March A. D. 1818 before me Richard Peters, Judge of the District Court of the United States in and for the Pennsylvania District personally appeared Michael Joiner, who being duly sworn upon the Holy Evangelists of Almighty God, deposes and declares that during the war of the Revolution he served as a Soldier in the Continental Army against the common enemy. That on the 13th day of February 1777, he enlisted as a private in Captain Jesse Row's [Roe] belonging to Colonel Benjamin Flower's Regiment of Artillery Artificers, then in service of the United States. That he remained in the said Company and faithfully served therewith for the term of Four Years and upwards, that is to say until the 6th day of March 1781, when he received an honorable discharge from Major General Knox, then commanding the Artillery of the Continental Army at, New Windsor on the North River - that after his discharge from the army, he entered, in the Year 1782 on board the ship Washington, then commanded by Captain Joshua Barney, as a landsman, and remained on board the said vessel during the service for which he enlisted - that in the consequence of infirmities and disease incurred during the course of his Service as aforesaid, he is now reduced to circumstances of great indigence and distress, and is in need of assistance from his country for support. And this Deponent further declares that he is at present and always has been a resident citizen of the United States and that he does not at present receive and never has received or been allowed any Pension by the laws of the United States. Sworn & subscribed before me} this 27th day of March 1818} Richard Peters Michael [his X mark] Joiner

and proceeded on until they reached Wilkes CH when Col Cleveland directed this deponent to convey his brother home, as he was in a very helpless condition and to remain with him until he should recover - which this deponent accordingly did - In this expedition, this deponent believes he was absent nearly three months from the time that he rendezvoused at Wilkes CH until his return to that place - not counting the time that he remained with his brother after their return - Though it was counted to him for a three month tour and he drew pay for that length of time - In the spring of the year 1781 when Lord Cornwallis was marching through North Carolina this deponent again volunteered himself and joined a company commanded by Capt Nathaniel Gordon - The company to which this deponent belonged endeavored to form a junction with Genl Greenes army, which was supposed to be at that time somewhere on the waters of Dan River in the borders of Virginia - but before they had reached the shallow ford of the Yadkin, it was ascertained that Lord Cornwallis was ahead of them, and that he kept scouting and foraging parties constantly scouring the country so that they found it would be impossible to reach Genl Green without running a great risk of falling into the hands of the enemy - They accordingly took post at a place in the County of Surry where the village of Jonesville now stands - and where they remained until they were discharged - In this expedition this deponent believes he served about two weeks - This deponent has resided in Wilkes County ever since the revolutionary War and resides there at this time - He never received any written discharge from the service nor has he any documentary evi-

Daniel McLeary, Ensign Nat Robinson twas mustered into the United States Service, under General Greene we marched to the Fort known as ninety six, in the month of June. The Fort at that time was occupied by the British under Colo. Cruger. The object of Genl Greene was to storm the fort which was invested at that time by the main army. The siege continued three weeks, and future success appeared certain when intelligence arrived that Lord Rawdon having received a reinforcement, was approaching with a large army to the relief of the place. General Greene determined to evacuate his position and break up the siege. General Greene then retired towards North Carolina, our company went with to the North Carolina line where we were dismissed and returned to our homes. During this year the inhabitants of the Carolinas endured calamity and distress, the country being ravaged and plundered by both armies. It was in the fall of the same year (according to the best of my recollections) that I was drafted for a three month tour under Captain John Thompson, 1st Lieutenant Nicholas Jasper, our company rendezvoused on Brown Creek, and joined Colo. Brannon' regiment. We were marched down Broad River to F'core? for a, thence crossed and marched down the River to Ancram' plantation on the Congaree River, where we were stationed during the term of our service, which was three months -- there was a portion of Colo. White' command stationed there with us, also some Dutch under the command of Captain Frazier -- a short time before the expiration of service, a Tory scout of light Horse, commanded [illegible] then by Cunningham or Guest committed some

Virginia Washington County to wit On the 6th day of October in the year 1834 personally appeared in open court before Benjamin Estill Judge of the Circuit Superior Court of Law and Chancery being a Court of Record Ezekiel Hobbs resident of the county of Washington in the State of Virginia aged seventy [five struck through] two & upwards. Year, who being first sworn according to law upon his oath doth make the following declaration in order to obtain the Pension or provision made by the act of Congress of the 7th of June 1832. That he was drafted in the year 1776 in the County of [blank space] but now the County of Washington having been divided, and sent to Fort Shelby where he did duty two months under the command of Captain Fulkerson at that time the Army under the command of Col Christian marched into that country with which he went as a volunteer against the Cherokee and was in that served two months fully. In the [crossed out] 1777 he was drafted to do duty in Benham Fort on the North fork of Holston River remained there one month and then march over the mountain to Cowans fort on Clinch to prevent that fort from being taken by the Indians which was ef[f]ected and the lives of a large number of Women and Children as well as men saved - there he served one month, he then was marched back to Benham fort and there employed two months as a guard in that year (1778) he believes in the month of August an expedition march[e]d to Kentucky against the Indians in which he was drafted and put under the command of Capt George Adams who was commanded by Major Daniel Smith, they returned not long before Christmas [illegible] a tour of service of four months in which he encountered great hardships he was in that year 1778 nearly the whole year in as [illegible] hard service against the Savage enemy on the frontier. In 1779 he was drafted for one months service at Benham fort being all of his service in that year. in 1780 he was drafted to march against the British [illegible] Forces in Carolina they rendezvoused of one Even Baker and march[e]d with the Regiment commanded by Colo William Campbell on the expedition to Kings Mountain but being taken sick was left and did not share in the glory of that Battle _ he was only two weeks in that service and was the last. He was living on the north fork of Holston River

State of Kentucky Barren County [illegible] Be it known that on this third day of November the year of our Lord Eighteen hundred and forty ;thee personally appeared before the undersigned a justice of the Peace in and for the county and state aforesaid Eizabeth Forbis and now a resident of Barren County state of Kentucky and makes with according to law and solemn affirmation that she is now the age of Sixty Six years. And that she is well acquainted with one Mrs. Sarah Hiser wife o John Hiser deceased who was a soldier of the Revolutionary War, and that she has been intimately acquainted the the said Sarah Hiser many years, that she knew her before her intermarriage with said John Hiser and that she was present and an eyewitness to the marriage of said John and Sarah Hiser, and as well as she recollects it took place in the winter of 1792 and he verily believes from her best recollections and from all the circumstances which she is enabled to bring to mind that they were married about the fist day of February in the year seventeen hundred and ninety two or there abouts that she was then residing in the state of Tennessee and in the Eastern portion thereof when sad i marriage took place-and since said time. This Despondent and said Sarah Hiser with her [illegible] land both moved to the state of Kentucky and County of Barren where they both now reside, an she states that she has been particularly and intimately acquainted with the said Sarah Hiser ever since, she well knows and is enabled with certainly to state that she the said Sarah Hiser is the identical person who is now applying for a pension for the services of the said husband as a soldier of the Revolution, from the government a pension as such at the time and some years before his death and as well as she recollect said John Hiser died some time in the spring of 1839, She further states that said John His an Sarah Hiser his wife, had a numerous and large family of children the most of whom she knows, and she is especially and well acquainted with Benjamin Hiser their oldest son and child and she verily believes

State of Massachusetts I Barnabas Sullivan a Citizen of the United States, now resident at Wiscasset in the County of Lincoln in the State aforesaid, do on oath testify and declare, that in the War of the Revolution, on or about June [crossed-out 77] 1777 I entered and was engaged in the land service of the United States on the continental establishment, and served accordingly from that time to the time hereafter stated. as a private Soldier against the common enemy, without any interruption or absence: that I belonged to Capt. John Sheppards Company Col. Sheppards Regiment being the 10th in the North Carolina line afterwards the Regiment was reduced or consolidated, I found myself in a new Regiment called the 2nd North Carolina Regiment, Col. Hogan, & in Capt. Hall's Company and that I left the service as hereafter stated and that by reason of my reduced circumstance in life and poverty, I stand in need of assistance from my country for support, being now of the age of fifty-nine years. I enlisted for three years in 1777 as above stated and I think in the month of June. I well recollect that I served the time not within one fortnight, when I was taken in Charleston S. C. when that city surrendered. I was then held a prisoner by the British about one year & a half more when I was exchanged & set at liberty. I was sick for a time after I had been in the army about six months during said service I broke my arm. had the small pox at Valley Forge. was at the Battle of Monmouth. And I hereby relinquish all claims to every pension heretofore allowed me by the laws of the United States, if any may be or hath been so allowed. When I was sick or above stated, I was at Col. Shepperds house in North Carolina. Barnabas Sullivan Commonwealth of Massachusetts Lincoln ss. BE IT REMEMBERED That on this third day of April, in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and Eighteen Pursuant to a law of the United States, entitled "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the revolutionary war," made and passed on the 18th day of March, A. D. 1818, personally appeareth before me Jeremiah Bailey Judge of the Court of Probate within & for the County of Lincoln in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, the same being a Court of record. Of said County, the abovenamed Barnabas Sullivan and after due examination and caution to testify and declare the whole truth, he maketh oath to the declaration aforesaid, and subscribes the same in my presence; and, on examination duly made by me the said Judge, it appeareth to my satisfaction that the said declaration is true. Jere Bailey I John H. Sheppard Register of the Court of Probate for the County of Lincoln, hereby certify that the aforesaid Jeremiah Bailey is Judge of said Court of Probate above named

1788 or 1789 - that the Deponent knew both from General reputation and from information from his father that the said William Stewart was a revolutionary Officer and known and called [lined out "an] Captain Stewart and at one time an officer in the Regiment to which his father was attached. he thinks an Adjutant- This Deponent further states that the widow Catharine Stewart have applying for a pension [lined out illegible] after her husbands death continued their farming business on the same farm owned by said Capt William Stewart in his life time, and continued to occupy and improve the same for many years (during all of which time this Deponent as well acquainted with said widow Catharine Stewart) until her children grew up and took charge of their fathers property, when it was disposed of and divided among the children, and the said widow Catherine went to reside with one of her sons, where he is informed and believes she has resided ever since and does still-- that this Deponent has known said Catharine Stewart since the Revolutionary war and a short time previous to the termination of said war, and knows her to be the widow of the said Capt William Stewart that he has often seen her before and since the death of her said Husband & that she never has been married since but remained his widow. This Deponent further states that some time this spring he had occasion to pass the house where the said Widow Catherine Stewart now resides, he called to see her, found her in bed and very helpless and aged but appeared to retain her mind as usual-- This Deponent further states that recently on a journey to Salsbury about 30 miles from this place, he passed through the neighborhood where the Stewart and the Row families resided-- that he was requested by a nephew of the said Capt Stewart to stop at the Church Yard as it was adjoining the road and see the grave & Tomb Stone of said Capt William Stewart, which from the request and partly from curiosity this Deponent did do. He there saw a large Tomb Stone erected as he was informed by the family very old in appearance with the inscription or it "Capt'n William Stewart - died March 10 - 1788 aged

Personally appeared before me [illegible] a Justice of the Peace of the County of Essex and state of New York. Ezekiel strong who being duly sworn deposeth and saith that by reason of old age and the consequent loss of memory he cannot swear positivity as to the lengths of his service but according to the best of his recollections the first term of his service as mentioned in his declaration and not amount to less than four months and that he served under the officers and in the war in these mentioned. that the second term of service when we went to Royalton to amount for would amount to at least fifteen days-that at the time he was engaged in taking the rove of cattle mentioned in his declaration, he was detained in that service not less than one month that after this and during the continuance of the war the country where he resides (Thetford Vt) was very frequently alarmed by the invasions of he Tories & Indians-that for the safety of the inhabitants a number of public boats are kept on the (Connectticutt) [Connecticut] Rivers and that he this deponent was actually employed in guarding said boats under an express engagement for three months and that he was st other and different times called out and performed various services of which he is unable to give the precise times- And this deponent further state that from reflections he is confident and verily believes that the time mentioned in his said declaration as the time when he first entered the service is an error that it must have been as early as the first of (June 1777) and further saith not his Ezekiel X Strong mark Subscribed and Sworn before me this 16th day of April 1834 Nathan Sherman Justice of the Peace [{The} erasure} The deponent has been capabel [capable] of writing his name but from a severe nervous affection [affliction] and other debility he is now unable to write but has made his mark to the above in my presence Nathan Sherman Justice of the Peace

State of Pennsylvania York County On the twentieth day of July AD 1832 Before me one of the Judges of the Court of Common Pleas in and for the said County of York personally appeared John Stroman a resident of York in the County of York and State of Pennsylvania, aged about Seventy Six years and upwards, who being first duly affirmed according to Law doth on his affirmation make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress passed June 7 1832. That he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers and served as herein stated. That in the month of July 1776 when I was between the age of 20 and 21 years I marched from York in the County of York and State of Pennsylvania in a militia Company commanded by Captain William Bailey to Philadelphia and from thence we proceeded on through the State of New Jersey to New Ark at which place I enlisted as a private in Captain Christian Stokes Company under the command of Col. Michael Swope for six months, designated and known by the name of the Flying Camp and that up to the [illegible] of March and proceeded to Fort Lee, the above under the command of Genl Ewing and from thence to Fort Washington in the State of New York, at which place on the 16th of November 1776 early in the morning we were attacked by the Brittish Army under the command of Genl Howe, and after a severe engagement we were overpowered and taken prisoners. I was then taken to New York and confined as a prisoner for about 2 months. In January 1777 after suffering hunger and cold almost intolerable, all that were alive were sent home on parole of Honor pledged by our officers, as was then said, not to take up arms against the British until we were exchanged, when that occurred I am unable to State

where he at present resides and has resided for the last three years - He cannot prove his service by any one but Edward Blurton who resides somewhere in Sumner and is a pensioner of the Government as this applicant is informed and believes - where Blurton lives affiant cannot tell as he is too infirm and helpless to prosecute his enquires in person and can only make this application to the court in person by the charity of neighbors in loaning him a horse to get to court. He has never received any pay for his services from the government nor is his name upon the pension list of any State or agency in the United States that he knows of and he hereby relinquishes his every claim to a pension but the present and declares tht his necessities and infirmaties are such that unless he receives the timely support of the govenment he will be cast upon the world cold charity - a beggar - William Haygood X his mark [Signature] Sworn to & Subscribed in open court this 28th day of October 1832. [Sigantures] Wm. Gower Neal Hopkins This 28d October 1832. J. L. Edwards Esquire - Tremont, Tazewell County, Ill. 12th 6th mo.1849 Sir I did not (as usual) go to the trouble, and expense of getting our Clk of C. Common Crts to attest the majistracy of Sherrod Williams a new J.P. here until we should see our prospects, Have the goodness to make it known to Robt T McGill Esqr of 4th Auditor's Office that both he & my valued correspondent- Mr. Basil McGill were mistaken. The Lawyers, eminent men, Archd. & Chs. McGill - both say Cols in the Va Contl line, were will known to me, as "Exsanquin Dibernia & also Mssrs Boyles, there Va. ? connections-- perhaps Mr McGill being of Md. could kindly aid in developing something of this ? Contl. Martin Lugart on whom W H Boyle letter is then included. The Js McGill Lt of Va State line, like is the mined the Mill of State line, in Gen. J. R. Clarke's Brigade to which this penns alludes is the offr about whose on consanguinity to Mr. R. T. Mcgill, I was inquiring-- These letters an now for your revision & some information may yet be elicited the records being examined. It is a painful task to trace out the alliance of these dead centerarians where those most concerned, some to know so little, I have a letter from Tho. Posey= Corydon, former Indn agent, in which he says that the late Genl Govr. Tho. Posey, married his mother - a widow Mrs Thornton, on the 22d Jany 1784 That she died on the 18th May 1837 & that his father died on the 19th March 1818, These things are all proveable-- from the Spottsylvania Pa Clerk's office and the Posey family Bible. Was not the law of 7th July 1838 being retrospective to the 4th March 1836, give these heirs some small amount! A memorandum of a late well known agent at Washn Col & Northup me says that some residue of land was still due to the heirs of Genl T Posey for his long services, & the different to the ranks of Major & Colonel most respectfully thine John Boyle Agent &c

[ State of Tennessee Warren County] On this the 2nd day of July A.D. 1833 personally appeared in open Court before Mr. William Mc Gregger , Samuel Denby and Aron Higginbotham Esqs and presiding Justices of the Warren County Court now in session, John Fisher a resident in the County and State aforesaid and aged Seventy six years who being first duly sworn according to law doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress passed the 7th day of June 1832. That he entered the service of the United States under the following named officer and served as has stated. In the latter part of the year of 1776 or the first of 1777 as he now recollects, he entered the service as a volunteer for four [underscored] months. He volunteered in Rutherford County State of North Carolina the Company to which he attached himself was commanded by Captain Jones, he thinks his given name was James. He does not recollect the names of the Lieutenant or Ensign of the Company. He was mustered into the service at Mc Fadgin's fort Rutherford County North Carolina, and attached to a Regiment commanded by Col. William Graham, alias, Gaines. This regiment was stationed at Mc Fadgin's fort for the purpose of ranging the Country and thereby to defend the defenseless Citizens from the attacks and incursions of the Tories and Indians who at that time concealed themselves in the White oak & Green River Mountains and wherever a favorable opportunity would present itself would attack & butcher the unsuspecting inhabitants whilst thus employed he was sent by Col Graham to a little Town called Gilbert for some beef Cattle. On his way he came across a Tory who had been with the Indians, he attacked, took and safely conducted him back to the fort. Applicant was thus employed for four months, at the expiration of which time he was discharged at Mc Fadgin's fort in writing by Col Graham he then returned to his residence which was in the same County. In 1780 or 1779. at least about two months before the battle at Kings Mountain he again entered the service of the United States he volunteered in Rutherford County North Carolina for Ten Months [underscored. He was marched by Ensign William Thompson to a place called Liberty hills above Cambell Town in South Carolina, he was then attached to Captain Pitts Company whose Christian name he does not at present renumber. Heads with his company attached to a Regiment of Cavalry Commanded by Col Leroy Hammons and was constantly employed as a ranger in North and South Carolina, during this Term of since he and eight or nine others were sent into Rutherford County North Carolina in a ranging expedition, to their surprise Col Furguson was in that County with his army of British, the first indication that they received of that fact was from the actual from the actual presence of a Company of British and Tories. When they made their appearance applicant was a short distance from the balance of his company.

Know all men by these presents that I John Vermilyea of the town of Delhi in in the County of Delaware in the State of New York yeoman late a matross in the 2d of New York regiment of Artillery commanded by John Lamb in the service of the United States during the American revolutionary war with great Britain, Do make constitute and appoint Gurdon T. Mumford Esquire member of Congress my true and lawful attorney for me, in my name and to my use to ask demand and receive for my benefit at the War Office of the United States a land warrant, for my service as a matross aforesaid; and on receipt thereof acquittances and other sufficient discharges for me and in my name to make seal and deliver, and generally all and every other act and acts thing and things whatsoever needful and necessary to be done on for me and in my behalf to do. In Witness whereof I have hereunto set my hand and seal the tenth day December in the year of our Lord One thousand eight hundred and five [signed] John Vermilyea Sealed and delivered in presence of [signed] Elihu H D Camp [illegible]

State of Massachusetts, County of Worcester J John Gassett a Citizen of the United States, now resident at Marlborough in the County of Middlesex in the State aforesaid, do on oath testify and declare, that in the War of the Revolution, in the months of June in the year 1777. I entered and engaged in the land service of the United States on the continental establishment, and served accordingly from that time to the month of December in the year 1788. as a private soldier against the common enemy, without any interruption or absence: that I belonged to Captain Hugh Maxwells Company in the Second Massachusetts Regiment under Colonel John Bailey on the Massachusetts line and that I left the service in the month of December 1778. and that, by reason of my reduced circumstances in life and poverty, I stand in need of assistance from my country for support, being now of the age of Seventy one years. My discharge is not in existence. And I hereby relinquish all claims to every pension heretofore allowed me by the laws of the United States, if any may be or hath been so allowed. John Gassett BE IT REMEMBERED, That on this 12th day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen pursuant to a Law of the United States, entitled, "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War," made and passed on the 19th of March, A.D. 1818, personally appeareth before me, Edwd Bangs a Judge of the C.C. of form Islees for the Western Circuit of that Company [illegible] County of Worcester the abovenamed John Gassett and after due examination and caution to testify and declare the whole truth, he maketh out to the declaration aforesaid, and subscribes the same in my presence; and, on examination duly made by me the said Judge, it appeareth to my satisfaction that the said declaration is true & have affixed the [illegible] Edwd Bangs

June 10, 1940 xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx ANDREW GARNER S. 15127 BA-J/MLB [something handwritten but smudged possibly accompanied by a check mark] Miss E.F. King 78 - 12 Cypress Hills Street Glendale, Queens New York Dear Madam: Reference is made to your letter in which you request the record of Andrew Garner who, you state, may have served in the Revolutionary War, instead of as a colonel in the War of 1812 as previously stated by you. A careful search of the Revolutionary War records of this office has been made and only one claim for pension found based upon military service in that war of a soldier with the name Andrew Garner. His record follows as shown in the papers of pension claim, S. 15127, based upon his service in the Revolutionary War. Andrew Garner was born March 8, 1759, in Marbletown, Ulster County, New York; his age was recorded in the church records of the Lutheran Congregation at Kingston in Ulster County. The names of his parents were not stated. While residing in Marbletown, New York, he enlisted in August, 1778, and served one month in Colonel John Cantine's New York regiment. He enlisted in June, 1779, served three months as private in Captain John DuBois' company, Colonel Malcolm's New York regiment, and was discharged at Fishkill. He enlisted in the summer of 1780, served three months as private in Captain Moses Cantine's company, Colonel Malcolm's New York regiment, engaged in driving cattle to Fort Stanwix and on his way there was in an engagement with the Indians near Fort Schuyler. He enlisted in the summer of 1781, served four months as private in Captain Henry Dodge's company, Colonel Weisenfels' New York regiment and assisted in building the fort at Saratoga, where he was discharged. He enlisted in the spring of 1782 at Esopus, Ulster Couny, New York, and served between eight and nine months as a private in Captain Henry Pawling's company, Colonel Weisenfels' New York regiment.

I will not pretend or enumerate the duties and hardships and dangers I encountered while acting as a spy--they were many and peril. and after this I remained in the fort under Stroud and Schoonover, but performing no particular service as the danger had nearly ceased, until January 1780 when moved to a fort on the Susquehanna, at a place called Wyoming, where I performed several short tours of duty, but they are not worth mentioning. This is the [bain?] and substance of my service. I will mention, that just before the battle of Long Island, there was a general review of the troops at Amboy, by the general officers, and the day before the battle two companies of light infantry were ordered from Amboy to Long Island. I declare that I have no documentary evidence now in my possession which would prove my service, having long since lost my discharge, and I do not know of any person now living with whom I served and who could prove my service, which was as a private soldier. I hereby relinquish every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present, and I declare that my name is not on the pension roll of the Agency of any State or Territory whatever. And the said court propounded to the said Huey the following interrogatories as prescribed by the War Department to which he made the subjoined memories: Question 1. Where and in what year were you born? Answer. I was born in the County of Newcastle, Delaware, on the 14th day of October 1754. Question 2. Have you any record of your age, and if so where is it? Answer. I have, in a family Bible at home. Question 3. Where were you living when called into service, where have lived since the Revolutionary War, and where do you now live? Answer. I was living in Northampton County, Pennsylvania when I was called into service--after the War I moved into North Carolina and lived there several years; then to the State of Indiana, then to this County, where I have lived for the last 19 years. Question 4. How were you called into service, were you drafted, did you volunteer, or were you a substitute and if a substitute for whom? Answer. I was drafted in the expedition to Amboy, but was a volunteer in all the rest of my service. Question 5. State the names of some of the regular officers who were with the troops when you served, such continental & militia Regts that you can recollect and the general circumstances of your service. Answer. Being stationed at Amboy in my first expedition, amongst militia, while the regular troops were toward Long Island, I did not become acquainted with any regular officers, except some general officers, and those principally from having them talked off. My other service was amongst militia and on the frontier where no military served.
