He has not one dollar of income, and is now , in consequence of a fall from the spout of a pump he was repairing about six months ago, rendored entirely unable to do any work. there is not a man on earth more worthy of credit and he states his condition to be as follows; he is indebtes in sundry small sums for necessaries for his family about $100, and should he be [illegible] for $10, his property must be executed and his family turned out of doors. and in the event of the death of himself of wife, his family would not have the mean to bury them decently. Had he been a drunken and prof[illegible] man, instede of a sober, religious and industrious one. he would have a pension. When I consider the case of this food old man. I [illegible] God that I have been able to raise my self above the want of any favour. or act of sheer Justice from such a government. Could the President or Secretary at war see this venerable old man, covers with his patched leather, which indicate the case and industry of his family, they could not and would not, were it in their power, with hold from him the pittance which he can now want but for a very short time; and if it should be your opinion that it would answer any valuable purpose, I will take him down at my espence. My friend, had there who have the power to believe, [illegible] the sufferings of our poor fellows in the winter of 1879 & 80 near Morristown, N.J. where many of us has neither shoes or shirt, they would enter into all my feelings in behalf of galant spirits who endure so much for their country. Forbid it my country that the gray hair of this venerable man should descend to the Grace in poverty & sorrow - Yours, Most truly, James Moshor

State of Rhode-Island & Providence-Plantations, WASHINGTON, sc -- Court of Common Pleas, Special Term, A.D. 1820 On this fifth day of July 1820, personally apppeared in open Court, being a Court of Record within and for the County of Washington, in the State of Rhode-Island, &c. Henry Sherman aged Sixty one Years residing in the Town of North Kingstown in said County who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his Oath declare, that he served in the Revolutionary War as follows: that he served as an officer in the Regiment commanded by Col Greene and Col Olney of the Rhode Island line upwards of five years. That he made a previous Declaration on the Thirteenth Day of April 1818, and that he has received a certificate for a pension, being No. 7817 And in pursuance of the Act of Congress, passed May 1st, 1820, I do solemnly swear, That I was a resident Citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner whatever, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an Act of Congress, entitled ""An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the Revolutionary War, "" passed on the 18th day of March, 1818; And that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the Schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed. Henry Sherman A SCHEDULE of Property and Income, ( necessary clothing and bedding excepted) of Henry Sherman (Viz) 1 Loom and tackling 1 Linen wheel 1 Woolen Wheel 1 Tin Cup 1 Iron Candlestick 1 asp 1 farl 1 pair Bellows 1 pair Tongs 1 Iron pott 1 Iron Kettle 1 Tea Kettle 1 Cate Kettle 1 Reel 1 Large Wooden Bowl 5 Common Chair 1 Shoemakers Bench 2 pails 3. Baskets 2 tin Cups 2 tin Basons 1 Tin coffee pott 1 case Rasors 1 meat Cask 1 flour Barrell ½ Doz plates 1/2 doz Cups and Saucers ½ Doz knives 1/2 Doz Spoons 1/2 Doz Small Spoons 1 Salt Cellar 1 Vinegar Cremit 1/2 doz bottles 1 Server 1 Table 1 Chest 1 Small Looking Glass 1 Rul 1 Cradle 1 Stone Jar 1 Soap barrel 1 Cow And this declarent further saith that he is a Shoemaker by trade but being partially blind cannot work at that business that in fact he is entirely dependant on the pension whether to received hitherto received that he has a wife & 4 Children all Daughter Dependant on him that he is involved in debt that he now owes more than Two Hundred dollars + for Nerfaries of life under all these destitute Circumstances he must depend on charity if his pension is taken away. Henry Sherman Sworn to and declared, on the fifth day of July 1820 before said Court We Sam Helme Clk of Court Washington, sc. Clerk's Office of the Court of Common Pleas. A D 1820 I Samuel Helme Clerk of the Court of Common Pleas, for the County of Washington, in the State of Rhode-Island, &c., do hereby certify, that the foregoing Oath, and the Schedule thereto annexed, are truly copied from the Records of said Court; and I do further certify, that it is the opinion of the said Court, that the amount in value of the Property exhibited in the aforesaid Schedule, is Thirty Dollars, and - Cents In Testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my Hand, and affixed the seal of the said Court, on this Sixth Day of July 1820 Sam Helme Clerk of said Court wife aged 45 Abigail du 14 Charlotte du 10 Patty du 9 Catharine du 6

State of Massachusetts I Epes Jewett a Citizen of the United States, now resident at Ipswich in the County of Essex in the State aforesaid, do on oath testify and declare, that in the War of the Revolution, in the month of January in the year of our Lord One thousand seven hundred and eighty one I entered and was engaged in the land service of the United States on the continental establishment, and served accordingly from that time to the month of November in the year Seventeen hundred & eighty one. That in March 1782 I again entered the service aforesaid & served accordingly till the close of the Revolutionary war as a private against the common enemy, without any interruption or absence: that I belonged to Captain James Tisdales Company in Colonel Greatons Regiment in the Massachusetts line for ten months & to the Regiment of Invalids commanded by Colonel Nicola in Captain Moses W Farlane's Company the remainder of the term aforesaid and that I left the service on the expiration of the term aforesd being honorably discharged at West point in June 1783, and that by reason of my reduced circumstances in life and poverty, I stand in need of assistance from my country for support, being now of the age of more than sixty years. I have no other evidence in my power to offer than is herewith exhibited And I hereby relinquish all claims to every pension heretofore allowed me by the laws of the United States, if any may be or hath been so allowed. Epes Jewett BE IT REMEMBERED, That on this Sixth day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen Pursuant to a law of the United States, entitled, "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the revolutionary war," made and passed on the 18th of March, A. D. 1818, personally appeareth before me the subscriber one of the Associate Judges of the Circuit Court of Common pleas for the middle Circuit within the State aforesd & presiding [illegible] the abovenamed Epes Jewett and after due examination and caution to testify and declare the whole truth, he maketh oath to the declaration aforesaid, and subscribes the same in my presence; and, on examination duly made by me the said Judge, it appeareth to my satisfaction that the said declaration is true. In testimony whereof I hereunto affix my name & the seal of sd Court Wm Wetmore May 20, 1819. I now further certify that annexed

State of Georgia Troup County October 26th-1837 To the President of the United States. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Troup County respectfully sheweth, that they are, &, have been for a long time acquainted with William Brooks, a citizen of the state & county_ And from their knowledge of him as an upright citizen & honorable man, & many other things unnecessary to be mentioned, they believe him to have been a soldier of the Revolution. They understand that he has made application to the government under the acts of [redacted] congress for a pension, & that owing to the particularity of government in some of its requisitions, he has been unable to procure it_ Your petitioners express their entire confidence in the revolutionary services of the said Brooks, & do petition the government, if there are any means known to the laws, by which his application for a pension can be granted, that the same may be adopted in behalf of the said Brooks, who is an old, poor, but most honest citizen & soldier_ and is known to have been a worthy member of the Baptist Church for more than fifty years Orville A Bull Alford B Gary James Reeves NG Collins Rogers I.J.C.F.C. Jesse L Bull William Henslee Wilie Womack Matthew Peters Joel D. Newsom

On this 19th day of February 1820, before me, the subscriber, [two words crossed out]Judge [an "s" crossed out] of the Pennsylvania District of the United States, [the words "for the said district" crossed out] personally appeared George Dias (or Dice,) aged 57 years, resident in Blockley Township in the said district, who, being by me first duly sworn, according to law, doth, on his oath, make the following declaration, in order to obtain the provision made by the late act of Congress, entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary war:" That he, the said George Dias or Dice, enlisted for the term of Three years on the 28th day of April in the year 1778 in Queen Anne's County in the state of Maryland in the company commanded by Captain John Hawkins of the Regiment commanded by Colonel William Richardson in the line of the State of Maryland on the Continental Establishment; that he continued to serve in the said corps, or in the service of the United States, until the Peace of 1783 (having reinlisted [sic] during the war, in the same company, after the terms of his first inlistement [sic] were expired), when he was discharged from the service James Island state of South Carolina, that he was in the battles of Stoney Point, was taken prisoner at Elizabeth town in 1779; & escaped from the enemy the same night in inclement [illegible] suffering from wounds received in Battle at Elizabeth town; in a skirmish between the enemy, & a detachment of the Troops commanded by Lord Sterling, and that he is in reduced circumstances, and stands in need of the assistance of his country for support, and that he has no other evidence now in his power of his said services. Sworn to and declared before me, the day and year aforesaid. [signed] Richard Peters. I, Richard Peters Judge, &c. as aforesaid, do certify that it appears, to my satisfaction, that the said George Dias, Dice or Deas, did serve in the revolutionary war, as stated in the preceding declaration, * against the common enemy, for the term of nine month at one time, on the continental establishment. I am also satisfied that he needs the assistance of his country for support. And I now transmit the proceedings and testimony taken and had before me, to the Secretary for the Department of War, pursuant to the Directions of the aforementioned act of Congress. February 19. 1820 [signed] Richard Peters *I judge by circumstances known to me, which [illegible]; the printed papers signed Thos Karney, and State of Maryland, annexed to the Dept. taken before Judge Gibson. State of North Carolina Rutherford County John Denton states that he served with the minute men that marched to Williamsburgh against Lord Dunmore in the early part of the revolutionary War. he entered for a year on board a small (?) commanded by Capn Banon, and on leaving he enlisted in Hanover County Virginia with Capn John Dandridge of the 1st Regiment of Virginia artillery commanded by Coln Chas Harrison for three years which time he served, but being an unlettered man and his memory impaired by age labour and fatigue he annot at this time intend to state exacty the time of his enlistment but thinks it was in the year 1777. Said Denton further states that he was in several actions that at the battle of Mommouth his knee was dislocated by the recoil of a gun. and at the storming of Stony Point where he and several of the corps to which he belonged acted as infantry he received a wound from a musket ball in the foot. at the expiration of his time he was honourably discharged at (?) in Jersey and his discharge signed by Coln Harrison. but not calculating that it would ever be of any service to him it has been by some means that he Can not now account for lost or mislaid a number of years ago. Said Denton further states that when he was paid for his three years service it was in continental Currency which was then so much depreciated as to be of scarcely any value. he further states that he does not know of any person now living and within his reach by which he could prove his service in the continental army. and also that haivng a large family to raise he never had it in his power to accumulate much property. he now owns a piece of very poor land. and being near seventy years of age and having gone through great hardships and fatigue is Not able to labour in his farm as he was formerly. and all his children who were able to help him have left him except some daughters who are not more than able to support themselves. This (?) said Denton thinks that he comes within the (?) of the Late act of Congress for granting a pension to revolutionary soldiers and therefore prays to be placed on the pension list in conformity with said act State of North Carolina) January Count 1819 Rutherford County ) In open Court John Denton Makes Oath that the different Statements in the afforesaid Memorial is Just & true to the best of his knowledge

STATE OF VERMONT RUTLAND COUNTY, ss. On this 19th. day of July A.D. 1832 personally appeared in open Court before the Judge of the Probate Court of Rutland Dist: now sitting, Nathan Denison a resident of the County of Rutland and State of Vermont, aged 72 years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress, passed June 7, 1832. That he entered the service of the United States under the following officers, and served as herein stated. In 1775 he lived in Stonington, Connecticut & in June of that year he enlisted for one month, in Captain Palmer's company, & Col. Oliver Smith's Regt. to work on the battery at Stonington, & immediately after his time expired he enlisted in said company for nine months more, Lt. Belcher & Stanton & Ensign Niles - does not remember the names of the other field officers -served his whole time of ten months he served in working on the battery & the guard. A British Frigate came in & fired on the Town just before he enlisted, - does not remember the names. was discharged at Stonington, but recd. no written discharge. In 1776 he was drafter & served two months at Groton Fort / Fort Griswold, & worked on the Fort under Col. Ledyard who commanded the Fort. In 177 he was again drafted & served two months at New London under Col. Mc.Clallen - during this service he was detached for a week or ten days & marched to Long Island under Capt. Champlin with a party to picket & bring off some of the inhabitants & cattle, whilst the [illegible] were there. Afterwards, he forgets the year, but it was the year that Norwalk & Fairfield were burnt, in March of that year he volunteered & marched to Horse Neck under Lt. Wheeler who commanded the party, & served under Col. Mead, who commanded the port ^ & served one months as ^ sergeant of Dragoons, [illegible] his own horse & accoutrements - there marched to Hartford & was discharged by Gov. Trumbull. In 1777, after he was at New London, he engaged on board the Nancy a Privateer of 12 guns, commanded by Capt. Robt. Palmer, & sailed on a cruise was Captain's Clerk, after being not one month was taken by the Unicorn & carried into New Port, R. I, where he was detained in the Prison ship Lord Sandwich two months, when he was exchanged. He was in prison when Col. Barton took Genl. Prescott. In 1778 he sailed in the Lively a Privateer of 18 guns, Capt Latham, on

[handwritten letter] Hornellsville April 21st 1843 J.L. Edwards Esqr Dear sir Some two or three years ago I made application for a pension for Mrs. Closson widow of Nehemiah Closson under the act of July 1838. I forwarded to you the necessary affidavits proving her marriage, a leaf from the family Bible containing the original record of the marriage &c.&c. - The application was then denied o account of Mr. Closson decease being subsequent to the passage of said act of July 1838 - he having died in April 1839 - Will you please inform me if there is any modification of the several pension laws that will allow the old Lady a pension at this time your reply much oblige her - she is very needy and a pension would be of great service to her could she obtain it I am very Respectfully Your obt servt /s/Martin Adsit J. L. Edwards Esq Com Pensions &c &c -

Kingston N J December 3rd 1836 William S Allison Esqr Dear Sir we have come to the conclusion to trouble you with the application of Mrs Clendenning of Kingston the old lady you had refference to in your letter It has been some time in progrees getting the papers ready and possibly there may be something wanting please lay them before the pention officers and State what your knowledge is of her She is needy & could not subsist if it were not for the Charity of the place - her marriage cannot be proved but their is no doubt of the fact the minister of the Kingston Congregation says it was not the custom to make a record of the marriage till he came in the congregation. She was married in this congregation and of course no record kept if anything is wanting please drop me a line Respectfully your very obt sevt [illegible] John Van Tillurgh

The evidence in this case is conclusive, that Clarke enlisted for 3 years as a regular soldier; that he had actually served 18 mo. Up to the battle of G. town which was in Oct 1777 at which time he was taken prisoner; which accounts for his name appearing on the pay roll, no longer than Oct. 1777. He was a prisoner 8 mo. And 12 days and no dout (sic) served out the bal. of his 3 years of the war enchanged (sic) – this may be inferred from his certificate of pay – It is also clearly in proof, by 3 respectable witnesses that claim he was in service after he was married – the witnesses differ it is true a little in regard to the time he Clarke (that is by month) went into the service, but agree exactly as to the month and year he came out. Which was the latter part of May 1781 – they all agree that he was in service after he was married and that it was winter when he left home. I think that the evidence is sufficient to entitle his widow to full pay as a corporal in the regular service. It was therefore only necessary to prove any of his services after marriage, in order to bring her under the law of 1836. Clarke was a deserving man, a good Christian, and a valiant soldier, and his widow is very needy. Do the best you can for him at any rate taking his regular, and militia services together, you can safely allow full pay as corporal. We have a number of cases before your please report some of them if the finances alow (sic) That we may be doing something. Ro. H. Evans

some thirty years ago from the old to a newer bible, so that the “children might use the old bible at School.” Judge Gilkey's certificate therefore is but a copy of a copy, but if it will be evidence, I will send in the leaves of this bible together with the affidavits of two or three of the family as to the parts of the record. The extreme poverty of the old lady induced Judge Gilkey & myself to go 20 miles to her house to prepare the papers & we cannot go again at uncertainties, but if we could know it would be of use we would not care the travel & time so much. It does not appear from your communication to Mr. Inge that your attention was directed to the case which the applicant made out for arrears of pension. For that purpose the time of the marriage is not material. The widow or the heirs of a pensioner are entitled to arrears. I this by inspection of the papers you will be satisfied a clear case is made out for arrears & the reports of Capt. James Dearing pension agent at Tuscaloosa Ala. will corrob[orate]

State of North Carolina Union County personally appeared before me James Marsh one of Judges of the Court of pleas and quarter Sessions for said County Celia Williams a resident of the County & State aforesaid aged 85 years who being first duly sworn according to law doth on her oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the provision made by the act of July 7th 1838 and Act 23 August 1842 embracing March the 3rd 1843 & 17th June 1844. Granting half pay and pensions to certain widows. that she is the widow of Job Williams and who was a pensioner of this United States at Forty dollars per annum She further declares that she was married to the said Job Williams, in Hobbs County, N. Ca, in the 18th year of her age & that she was born on the 15 day of January 1762 as my parents told me that Abraham Baker a Clergyman married she & her husband & that her husband the aforesaid Job Williams died on the 7th day of October 1842 that she was married to him before January the 1st 1794 to wit at the time above stated, that he yet remains a widow Sworn & Subscribed this (illegible) day of July 1847 Jas Marsh her Celia X Williams mark I further certify that Celia Williams who has sworn & subscribed to the above declaration is an old lady of five (illegible) for (illegible) that her statement is entitled to full credit an from her looks & appearence She is at least 85 years of age and is helpless & blind & cannot travel to the court house Given under my hand this 3d day of July 1847. Jas Marsh JP

Timothy Wilcox of Whitingham in the County of Windland and State of Vermont a citizen of the United States depons testifies and declares that in the month of May AD 1775 he enlisted into the army of the United States for right months that he served as a private soldier in a company commanded by Lieutenant Fall Called the Colonel Company in Colonel Wards Regiment in the Connecticut line until some time in the month of November or number 1775 when he was dismissed said Colonel Ward at St John in Canada that he left the army at that time without any written discharge and in the month of March 1776 he again the United States in the same enlisted into the acting Company and term of inlistment out and was regularly discharged in the month of August or September 1776 and left the army and that in February AD 1778 he again enlisted into the army of the United States under Captain William Size in Colonel Baldwins Regiment in the Connecticut line for three years in the Mechanic Service and served the whole term of three years and received a regular discharge at West point in March 1781 that he has lost his said discharge or they are discharged he further certifies that the service rendered as aforesaid was an the Continental Establishment in the eve of the revolution against the Common Enemy that he is now sixty seven years old and that he received while in the service of his country aforesaid a trust which occasions a breach that is at this time and has been for many years extremity painful and distressing that he has no real Estate and no personal proports except a man trope of household furniture not even a law or sheep and that from his reduced circumstances he stands in need of assistance from his country for support Timothy Willcox Sworn to and declared the 21st day of April 1818 before John Roberts Judge of Windham County in the State of Vermont

Saml. Dean proves his services under Chs. Smith in '78. - & proves indeed more time than Defrees claims - his other Services are not indeed shown by this testimony of witnesses - But all give him (what I well know he possesses) a good character for truth [underlined]. And I cannot forbear remarking again that the incidents related by him in connexion with his different statements, must I think [illegible] impress the mind with the conviction of his truth. That the dates [underlined] of his enlistments & services ^ are not precisely recollected is not to be [illegible] considering his great age & any great infirmities - I cannot but think that the applicant has fully entitled [illegible] to an allowance or a full pension, according to the liberal & just view of the law exhibited on the 2nd page of your printed [illegible] of June 15. 1832 - [underlined] It is thus observed that "to demand positive proof independently of their own statements would be to deprive many of them of the benefit of the act" - "That if the applicant has no living or documentary evidence he should transmit a detailed statement [illegible][underlined] " He has sworn he has given you the best evidence & all the evidence [underlined] in his power - & he has certainly given a much more detailed statement, [underlined] than most applicants have done - He swears that there is no living witness within his knowledge by whom he can prove more - The rolls of one comptroller would I presume show nothing in relation to his services; as he was but a private [underlined] & I believe the names of privates are not to be found there - He has given a reason for not obtaining the certificate of a clergyman - I suppose the positive evidence [underlined] of three reputable men, that they knew him in actual service is equivalent to any hearsay [underlined] that could reach the ears of a clergyman. - Defrees is miserably poor [underlined] - by reason of his age & infirmities certainly helpless [underlined] - There is no man in the United States who needs a pension more than he - I cannot but hope that a review of his papers will eventuate in his obtaining one - at all events an allowance of less than a full pension (if he has not entitled himself to a full one) will be preferable to his present utter destitution - C. Hawley

Page cont State of Pennsylvania Pike County On this seventh day of May AD Eighteen hundred and thirty three————-before the honorable Daniel W. Dingman Esq. one of the Apeciate Judges of the Court of Common pleas in and for the County of Pike appeared Abraham Decker a resident of Delaware Township in the said County now on the Seventy ninth year of his age who being duly sworn according to law doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefits of the Act of congress passed June Seventh AD Eighteen hundred and thirty two, that he was born in Delaware Township Pike County and state of Pennsylvania, near Dingman’s Ferry, in the year of our Lord One thousand seven hundred and fifty four and has resided in the same place } except what time he was absent ini the revolutionary war as a soldier} Ever since that in the year Seventeen hundred and Seventy six he entered the service of the United States a a drafted Militiaman in the Company of Pennsylvania Militia Commanded by Captain Johannes Van Etten(underlined) marched through the State of Newjersey to Amboy where the troops were stationed under the Command of General Robert Doe or O. The regiment to which despondent was attached was commanded by Major Elisha Barton, during this tour despondent served four months(underlined) after performing the aforesaid tour of duty returned home with the said Captain Johannes Van Etten, that in the fall of the same year he again turned out as a drafted Militiaman in the Company of Pennsylvania Militia Commanded by the said Captain Johannes Van Etten marched through the State of Newjersey to Amboy where where Deponent remained with a part of the Regular Army for the space of six weeks from Amboy Deponent (underlined) with his company marched to Trenton and arrived there in the beginning of the year Seventeen hundred (end of page)

County of Monroe, of State of Georgia On this tenth day of March, 1827, personally appeared in open court, being a court of records for said state & county. Tolliver Davis, resident in said county aged between sixty five & seventy years, who being duly sworn, according to law, on his oath makes the following declarations, in order to obtain the provision made by the act of Congress of the 18th of March 1818, & the 1st of May 1820. That I the said Tolliver Davis, enlisted for the term of eighteen months, some time in the year 1779, in the state of Virginia, in the company commanded by Captain Lamb, in the regiment commanded by Colonel Feebecker, in the line of the State of Virginia, on the continental establishments, that he continued to serve in the said corps, until his said term had expired, when he was discharged from the service in the State of Virginia. That he hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension, except the present. That his name is not on the roll of any state, & that the following is the reason of his not making an earlier application, sig, that he has led an obscure life, being in poverty[?] by & was ignorant until recently of the law under which this application is made And in possession of the act of 1820, I do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March [1827 x'd out] 1818, & that I have not since that time by gifts and sales, or in any manner disposed of my property or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to de[illegible] it, as to being myself within the provisions of act

State of Massachusetts I Thomas Davis a citizen of the United States, now resident of Holden in the County of Worcester in the State of aforesaid, do on oath testify and declare, that in the War of the Revolution, on or about the 6th of June, 1778, I entered and was engaged in the Lands service of the United States on the continental establishment, and served accordingly from that time to the 6th of March, 1779, being nine full months as a private soldier against the common enemy, without any interruption or absence: that I belonged to Capt. Daniel Shay's Company, Col. Rufus Putnam's Regiment, being the fourth in the Massachusetts Line and that I left service on the 6th of June 1779 and that, by reason of my reduced circumstances in life and poverty, I stand in need of assistance from my country for support, being now of the age of sixty four years. And I hereby relinquish all claims to every pension heretofore allowed me by the laws of the United States, if any may be or hath been so allowed. Be it remembered, That on this 14th day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and 18 pursuant to a law of the United States entitled, "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War", made and passed on the 18th of March, A.D. 1818, personally appeareth before me, Edward Bangs Judge C. Court (Comptroller?), Western County The above named Thomas Davis and after due examination and caution to testify and declare the whole truth, he maketh oath to the declaration aforesaid, and subscribes the same in my presence; and, on examination duly made by me the said Judge, it appreareth to my satisfaction that the said declaration is true. Given under my Hand and the Seal of said Court, the day of the date aforesaid, Edward Bangs

has not ever made an application for a pension as the widow of the [crossed out] aforesaid Benjamin Yates or in any other way previous to these presents for further proof of her said marriage, She refers to proof here with inclosed sworn to and subscribed before me a Cincinnati - in the County of Hamilton and State of Ohio - Sarah Yates her mark - This eighth day of May in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and fifty four - The testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand and affixed my official seal at the time and place last above written. And I certify that said Sarah Yates being unable to write I have at her request written her name as above, and that she made her mark thereto in my presence Jos Warren [Swanson?] Probate I Jos Warren - the Probate Judge before whom the foregoing declaration was sworn to do here by certify that the erasure made on the second and third written line of the second page of this affidavit was made previous to its being sworn to. Eighteen Hundred and fifty-four Jos Warren Probate Judge [Within Newspaper clipping] May 3, 1848 Benjamin Yates, a soldier of the War of Independence, and now one hundred and seven years old, came a day or two since to the Mayor's Office in Cincinnatti, to get the necessary papers to draw a small pension. He resides in Fulton, Ohio, and is said to be in very destitute circumstances. [Within Newspaper clipping]

the State of Alabama Shelby County Circuit Court Fall Term 1834 On this [scratched]th day of October 1834 personally appeared in open court before Plolemy Harris Judge of the Circuit Court of the laid County of Shelby now letting Dennis Carrol [Carroll] a resident of the County and State aforesaid, aged seventy two years who being first duly sworn according to law doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress passed June 7th 1832. That he entered the service in 1780 as he believes calculating from his age as well as he can now recollect being there about fifteen years old that he was drafted in the Militia of North Carolina under Captain Joshua Hadley and his son was their Lieutenant in the Regiment commanded by Colonel Thomas Armstrong, that they marched down Cape Fear river to Wilmington where they encamped for three months waiting for the arrival of General Morgan. That at Wilmington he was discharged having served three months- From Wilmington he returned to Fayetteville on his way home and was there at the pressed to guard some prisoners by one Colonel Emmet who was then in command there, that he continued in Fayetteville about three months longer, that after this he marched again under Captain Mc Craney dawn drawing creek where he again joined the company commanded by Captain Hadley explored [unknown] and Blawton swamps in pursuit of the tories, [unknown] or fifteen of whom, with some cattle, they took prisoners. That he was then marched up Black River to Fayetteville where they remained two or three weeks and were again marched through the several swamps above named in pursuit of tories several of whom they captured. That he was principally in Sampson Cumberland and in the neighborhood of Wilmington, their main object was the capture of a tory by the name of Fanning, who had become obnoxious - That on Cape Fear River in a skirmish with the Tories his captain was killed and was succeeded by his son. That he was in several skirmish but in no important battle-- that they finally marched to Fayetteville with several prisoners when news was received of the capture of Lord Cornwallis, having spent nine months in all when he was discharged that he never was in the Regular service. That he knew General Morgan who commanded the Riflemen, and once only saw General Green on Cape Fear River who was then proceeding towards Charleston

Declaration in order to obtain the benefits of the Act of Congress passed June 7th 1832. State of North Carolina, Orange County On the 27th day of November 1832 personally appeared in open court before the Justices of the Court of Pleas and Quarter Sessions now sitting George Carrington a resident of the County of Orange North Carolina, aged about seventy seven (77) who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress passed June 7th 1832. That he entered the service of the United States under his brother Captain James Carrington, when he first served. - I hear this deposed saith that his mind is so shattered and his memory is so frail, that he cannot trust it. This deponent saith that in early life and for many years after he had passed the middle of life, he was industrious and prosperous and possessed of a good estate. That misfortune with mismanagement brought his private affairs into confusion, which terminated in the entire dispersion and destruction of the whole of his estate. And that in this helpless condition, he was rendered much more helpless and his situation more deplorable and wretched, by the [illegible] of God, in the detraction of his intellect for a considerable time. That in the years 1818 and 1819 as he thinks, there was an entire alienation of mind for the most of the time, and that ever since his mind and memory have been so weak and treacherous, that he cannot, nor can is friends trust them. And yet he has always been temperate or reasonably so.

I Richard Dodge jnr. of Grantham certify and say that I live within half of a mile of Thomas Carr who has lately been a Pensioner of the Revolution who now lives with his son Joseph F Carr and know him to be verry [illegible] almost if not [illegible] destitute of Property I further say that some time in July last Samuel Powers Dept Sheriff for the County of Cheshire delivered to me a number of articles together with a horse and 3 hogs which he had attached as the Property of Thomas Carr which I visited to him as sherriff and said Property was not [illegible] by nor received by said Carr afterwards it was and now is Considered that the Dept Sherriff took all the property that was attachable by law that belonged to said land excepting some verry trifling articles thought not worth moving Richard Dodge Jr. State of New} December 11th 1820 Personally Hampshire } Appeared the above named Cheshire Ss }. Richard Dodge jnr and Made Solemn oath that the above statement Contains the truth before me Abijah Powers Jus Peace I Ezekiel How Testify and say that I live nigh Thomas Carr of Grantham in the County of Cheshire and State of Newhampshire who has lately been a Pensioner and know that he possesses no Property or nother name worth mentioning nor has not since last July as his property was then taken by an officer and that he lives with his son Joseph F Carr who aids them in their support meaning him and wife Ezekiel How State of New} Croydon December 11th 1840 Came before Hampshire } me Ezekiel How above named Cheshire Ss } and Made Solemn oath that the above Affidavit by him subscribed contains the truth Abijah Powers Jus Peace

Know all men by these Presents That I Warren Carpenter in Col Willets Regt of State Levies for divers good causes and considerations me hereunto moving have made, ordained, authorized, and appointed and by these presents do make, ordain, authorize, and appoint, Henry Hart of the City of Albany, Merchant, my true and lawful attorney for me and in my name, and to my use, to ask, demand, sue for, recover, and receive of Coll. Marines Willett or any other appointed for that purpose of said Regs. of State Levies all such sum and sums of money, debts and duties whatsoever, which now are due and owing unto me the said Warren Carpenter by and from the said Coll Marine Willett or any other appointed for that purpose and to have, use and take all lawful ways and means in my name or otherwise for recovery thereof, by attachment, arrest, distress or otherwise, and to agree and compound for the same and acquaintances or other discharges for the same, for me and in my name to make seal and deliver and to do all other lawful acts and things. Whatsoever concerning the premises, as fully in every respect, as I myself might or could do if I were personally present; and attornies, one or more under him for the purposes aforesaid, to make, and at his pleasure to revoke; ratifying and allowing all and whatever my said attorney shall in my name lawfully do, or cause to be done in and about the premises, by virtue of these presents. In witness whereof I have hereunto set my hand and seal this seventh day of July in the year of our Lord one thousand and seven hundred and eighty four. Warren Carpenter Witness Present Job Wright Thomas Carpenter

[written] I William J Card of Warwick in the County of Kent and State of Rhode Island do testify and say that I am now Seventy four years of age, that I am the son of Stephen and Lydia Card and next to the youngest of their childre, my mother had Eleven chojdrentheir names were as follows, Edward, Isbella, two by the name of Betsy one having died in fantcy, Isreal, Nathaniel, Stephen, myself, William J. Card and Ruth ann now a widow, Isabella myself and Ruth Ann Northup are the only ones now living, said Isabella is now Eightytwo years of age, and I further testify and say that therecord of my father's death and also of my father and mother's marriage was taken from an old paper which was cracked to pieces and was copied into the old Bible, I have seen the old paper and it contained the same dates as that in the Bible- I believe that the record in the Bible is in the handwriting of my Sister or her daughter, I remember that hte old Bible was a gift to my mother and after her death the memorandum were made as above mentioned, I further testify that I have a great many times heard my father say that he served in Colonel Elliot's regiment of Artillery in the Revolutionart war William (his X mark) J. Card Witness Wm Harrisno State of Rhode Island Kent County} Sc Warwick September 17th AD 1856 Signed and Sworn to before me and I further certify that I have been acquainted withe the despondent a great may years and his statement is entitlled to full credit Wm Harrison Justice of the Peace

thing of importance to relate, that the place during the time he lay at Chestnut Hill - He recollects seeing at Chestnut Hill, General Potter (who afterwards lived in Centre County Pennsylvania), General Bull and Mayor Stewart - General Potter and Mayor Stewart were near fighting, with swords, one day, on account of a dispute that arose between them about the treatment of the militia - His company was discharged at the expiration of the tour, and they returned have having been absent again better than two months. That the whole term of his service was six months, which was in the Pennsylvania militia as a private, being drafted and service rendered as above stated – To the interrogatories propounded by the court, he makes the following answers – 1st Where, and in what year were you born? Answer - I was born in Derry Township Lancaster County, in the State of Pennsylvania, in the year Anno Domini Seventeen hundred and fifty four - 1754. 2d Have you any record of your age and if so, where is it? Answer - I have a record of my age in my Bible, which I have in my possession 3d Where were you living when called into service; where have you lived since the revolutionary war and where do you now live? A - I lived in Derry township Lancaster when called into service; and lived there until the year Anno Dominu seventeen hundred and eighty seven, when moved to Buffalo Valley, Northumberland (now Union) County, Pennsylvania. I lived on Esquire Gray's farm one mile above Lewisburg in said County, one year; the next year he moved to another farm of Esquire Grays on Buffalo Creek in the same valley and County, near Samuel

Miss Irene Shipp Roome Mississippi Madam: I advise you from the papers in the Revolutionary War pension claim, S. 12686, it appears that Charles Campbell was born in 1759 in Augusta County, Virginia. While a resident of Augusta County, Virginia, he enlisted in 1777 and served a little over three years as a private in Captains David Lord's, Nathan Lamb's, and Blackwell's Companies in Colonels Stephens' and Samuel House's Virginia Regiments and was in the battles of Brandywine and Stony Point. He moved from Augusta County to North Carolina, from there to Tennessee, and from there to Lauderdale County, Alabama. He was allowed pension on his application executed May 7, 1833, while a resident of Lauderdale County, Alabama. He died, August 23 or 31, 1843, in Hinds County, [handwritten] letter of Feb. 14, 1845 To Hon. R. N. Roberts added to Cl. after this [illegible] was written

and now that the law is such that the heirs are entitled to pensions that was due to their fathers who did not receive the same for their service before their deaths ths is the case with Augustus Levake he was entitled to A pension and did not receive it therefore by the request of my father and the advice of Judge A Bull of Troy I send this in the hopes you will be friend me so much as to send me all the evidence if any there is to show that he was entitled to A pension and I would have to say I would if I had any thing [anything] to send it to you for the trouble you may be at in furnishing me with what I have asked or require but you shall have the greateful [grateful] thanks and warmest wishes of your obiedient [obedient] servt [servant] George J Levake PS please attend to it as soon as convenient for we are needy I know not what became of the last papers he had made out but it was in the year 1822 or 3 I think they were sent to washington

The State of South Carolina April Term 1822 As a court of common pleas began to be holden at Spartanburg courthouse for Spartanburg District on the second Monday after the fourth Monday in March being the eighth day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred & twenty-two Present his Honor Judge Colcock South Carolina Spartanburg District On this 8th day of April 1822 personally appeared in open court to wit the court of Common Pleas beginning a court of record for the said District, James Lett aged seventy three years, resident in Spartanburg District, who being first duly sworn according to law oath, on his oath declare that he served in the Revolutionary War as follows “ I was enlisted by Captain Clement Hall of Fayetteville in South Carolina in the regiment of regulars commanded by Col. Archibald Litte under General Greene and continued in the service of the United States for the term of seven years, when I was regularly discharged by Col. Litte at Wilmington in South Carolina. I do not recollect the date of my enlistment and have lost my discharge. I was in several battles in the battle of Eutaw. I received two sever wounds, one in my head and the other through my left foot, the last of which has ever been and is now extremely painful to support me so that I greatly need the assistance of my Country. And I do solemnly swear that I was a citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not since that time by gift, sale or any manner deposed of my property or any part thereof with intent thereby so to diminish it as to

State of Massachusetts I John Bolton a Citizen of the United States, now resident at Bridgewater in the County of Plymouth in the State aforesaid, do on oath testify and declare, that in the War of the revolution, in the month of April in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred seventy five I entered and was engaged in the Land service of the United States on the continental establishment, and served accordingly from that time to the end of the said war as a private against the common enemy, without any interruption or absence: that I belonged to the company of Capt Pots + Col. Paul Dudley Sargents regiment, for the first year + eight month, For the residue of the time to Col. Ebenezer Sprouts regiment + capt Adam Baileys company and that I left the service on the termination of the said war honorably and that by reason of my reduced circumstances in life and poverty, I stand in need of assistance from my country for support, being now of the age of sixty five years+ upwards And I hereby relinquish all claim to every pension heretofore allowed me by the laws of the United States, if any may be or hath been so allowed. John his X mark Bolton BE IT REMEMBERED, That on this first day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen, Pursuant to a law of the United States, entitled, "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the revolutionary ware," made and passed on the 18th of March, A.D. 1818, personally appeareth before me the subscriber one of the Associate Judges of the Circuit Court of Common Pleas within the State aforesaid+ presiding [illegible] the abovenamed John Bolton and after due examination and caution to testify and declare the whole truth, he maketh oath to the declaration aforesaid, and subscribes the same in my presence; and, on examination duly made by me the said Judge, it appeareth to my satisfaction that the said declaration is true. In testimonies whereof I hereunto affix my name + the seal of said County. I also certify that the within name Deponent is a credible and disinterested witness. Wm Wetmore

he died - and Colonel Washington came to see her and said if she would go home with him she never should suffer. The said Edward further declares that he received no education - that his mother had no family record and that if there ever was any county, Parish, church or family record made either of the marriage of his mother and Robert Stark or the death of said Stark he has not been able to hear of it - and he has used all the names his limited circumstances & capacity enabled him, in order to collect all the evidence he was advised was material in the case. He also declares that - the only means he has of proving the time at which Robert Stark died is by the evidence of Capt John Robinson - which may be seen in his testimony - to which he would add that he had always understood from - this mother that Nr. Stark died not long after this marriage He therefore declares that he supposes said Stark must have died in the year 1783. He further declares that his mother lived till the third day of November Eighteen hundred & forty three 1843 on which day she died. X his mark Edward Graham Sworn to & Subscribed before me this 15th day of Feby 1847 Richd B Parker

[Following language is from bottom of prior page: West Indies in company with the schooner "Felicity" Capt Jeremiah Yellott of eight six pounders. A night or two after being at sea we fell in with some British privateers, and the next morning gave chase to one called the "Flying Fish" Capt Blair from New York of eight six pounders and twenty eight men-came up with her and laid her aboard. Only ten of us suc ceeded in boarding her, of which number I was one. We captured her and sent her to Philadelphia, where she arrived in safety. The next day our vessel sprung a leak and filled in a heavy gale. Toward the close of the gale the Continental frigates Boston of 36 guns, Capt Saml Tucker of Salem commander, and Deau of 34 guns Capt Saml Nicholson commander hove in sight, and seeing our signal of distress bore down upon us. Capt Tucker] sent two boats to our relief, in one of which I reached the frigate Boston, where I was immediately put upon duty. In this cruise after taking several prizes, the two frigates aforesaid captured the British sloop of [illegible] of twenty odd guns. When the British troops came up the Chesapeake Bay under Lord Howe and landed at the head of Elk to march for Philadelphia, Captain Josias Bowen's company was called out to keep watch, and prevent marauding parties from landing on the western shore and plundering the inhabitants thereof. I volunteered as a private in said company and served until all danger from said troops was removed. Soon after this a vessel belonging to the United States was [illegible] into Chinkotegue [Chincoteague] Inlet in Acco mac County Virginia. I think she was in possession of important dispatches [illegible] Giles

State of New York, County of Livingston S.S. On this twenty first day of August AD one thousand eight hundred and fifty two, personally appeared before the undersigned, County Judge of the County of Livingston and State of New York, in open court, Catharine Johnson, formerly Catharine Spicer, aged eighty seven years the fifth day of January next; a resident of West Sparta in the County and state aforesaid, who, being first duly sworn according to law, doth on her oath, make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the provision made by the acts of Congress, passed July 7th 1838, entitled "An act granting half pay and pensions to certain widows;" and the Act of the third of March 1837; as those acts have been modified by the act of August 23rd 1842, and explained in the opinion of Hon. John C. Spencer November 17th 1842, and the opinion of Hon. J.L. Edwards of June 26th 1844. That she is a widow, frail and needy; that her maiden name was Catharine Filkins; that she was married to Nathan Spicer a Revolutionary soldier of the State of New York, by a Dutch Clergyman (name forgotten) at [illegible] N.Y. on the 29th day of February A.D. 1784. That her husband, the aforesaid, Nathan Spicer died on the first day of January A.D. 1815; that she was not married to him prior to his leaving the Service, but the marriage took place

I Henry Sherburne of Newport in the County of Newport & State of Rhode Island Do Certify on honor, that Pearce Spear the bearer hereof Inlisted a Soldier in May 1775, In one of the Regiments raised by their State Command by Col^n [Colonel?] Thomas Church of which the undersigned was Major, that [invested?] the Town of Boston, that during the said Campaign he the said Spear Conducted himself as a faithful good Soldier, - That the next year he Inlisted in the Col^n James M. Varnum Reg^t raised by the State for the Continental Service, & afterward he Inlisted in Col^n Cranes [?] Reg^t of Artillery & continued therein until the Close of the Revolutionary War. I do further certify; That the Said Pearce Spear is about Seventy Years of Age, is very Infirm, Extremely Needy & not Capable of getting a living by Manual Labour, & is an Object of the Clemency of his Country. Given Under My hand at Newport the Sixth day of January AD 1818 & forty second of American Independence [H?] Sherburne Major of One of the Continental Regts Raised by this State, & afterward Colonel of One of the Sixteen Battalion raised for the Continental Army Under the Appointment of his Excellency Gen: George Washington

the act of the 1st May 1820 I do Solemnly swear that I was a resident Citizen of United States on the 18 March 1818 that I have not since that time by gift sale or in any other manner disposed my property or any part thereof with intent thereby so to diminish it as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress entitled an act to provide for certain persons engaged the land and naval service of the United States in the revolutionary war passed on the 18th day of March 1818 and that I have not nor has any person in trust for me any property or Securities contracts or debts due to me nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereunto announced and by me subscribed --- Schedule of property owned his Zadock Sowell on the 24th day of Feby 1824 three beds and furniture Six hogs with other (illegible) articles of household furniture not worth in the whole, ten Dollars I do further declare my occupation is that of a cobler (sic) & sometimes that of a cooper (though now attending of a mill) which I am unable to attend to with but little profit to myself & family. And that my family consists of myself & wife who is about my own age, & almost helpless, two daughter, the oldest about thirty years

State of Vermont} Rutland County [mark]} On this 29th day of November, in the year of our Lord, one thousand eight hundred and thirty six, personally appeared in open Court, before the Honorable Probate Court now sitting at Rutland within and for the District of Rutland in said County of Rutland, Silas Pratt, a resident of said town of Rutland, aged 73 years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth, on his oath, make the following declaration m in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress passed June 7, 1832: That he entered the service of the United States, under the following named officers, and served as herein stated: That in the spring of the year, he believes in the month of April, 1779, residing then, and ever since in said Rutland, he was drafted for the term of three months. Was stationed and served at the stockade fort at Mead's falls on Otter Creek in said Rutland. Does not remember the names of the Commissioned officers there, but recollects the orderly Sergt. whose name was Sardius Blodged [Blodgett] who lately died at Georgia, Vermont. Believes the Captain, Lieutenant, and a part of his Company were at another station, most of the term-and, that a Capt.-Gale commanded, the latter part of the 3 months. Was employed, during this time, in garrison duty, and in scouting up and down Otter Creek. In November, 1779, the enemy, consisting of something like 100 men, tories and Indians, made an incursion into the County from the north, burning, some houses, killing cattle, and taking some prisoners. In order to repel them, the militia was ordered out, en map. They turned out from Rutland and vicinity, and marched under the command of Lt. Col. James Claghorn, then of Rutland. Applicant then belonged to Capt. Simeon Wright's Company of militia, and

Lewis County Court} Virg} Margaret [illegible] appeared before me the subscriber a Justice of the Peace in said County and made oath on the holy evangelist of almighty God that in the years 1781 (as near as she can recollect) she there lived and resided in the South Branch of Potomac, about a mile from the place where [illegible] now stands in the County of Hardy [illegible]. In that year she became acquainted with Christopher McVaney, who then resided with William Murphy, that said Christopher McVaney was there in low state of health, and that the cause was attributed to and in congruence of the hardships he was exposed to in the army, having there lately returned from a tour of service. The further that at [illegible] said Christopher came to the [illegible], that some folks suspected said Christopher to be a deserter, but that it had been ascertained that he had a discharge from his Captain; this she heard and understood at the time from the neighbors. The said Margaret [illegible] states that she is now 78 years of age. Sworn and Subscribed to before me this 25 of July 1836. Jacob Lorentz Margaret [illegible] her mark

To J C Calhoun Esquire Secretary of War for the United States the subscriber one of the Judge of the Court of Common Pleas for the State of Delaware Do hereby certify that aforegoing depositions herewith transmitted respecting the service of Benjamin McLane an Ensign in the Revolutionary war has proven to my satisfaction that he the said B McLane did serve in a manner and form as in therein stated and that from my personal knowledge, he is reduced to extreme poverty independent on the Trustee of the Poor of the County of New Castle for a substance State of Delaware New Castle County of I Joseph Roberts Prothonotary of the Court of Common Pleas of the said State of Delaware in and for the said County of New Castle do hereby certify that the Honorable John Way before whom the foregoing depositions were taken & who hath certified the same was at the time of his so doing and now is one of the associate Justices of the Court of Common Pleas of the said State of Delaware duly commissioned & qualified and that full faith and credit are and ought to be given to all such his acts and attestations In Testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand and affixed the seal of the said Court at New Castle the thirteenth day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen Jos. Roberts Prothy

Weakley County Tennessee Near Winston April 17th 1844 Honored Sir, Some time in the Autumn of 1843 Mrs McKenzie widow of Colonel John McKenzie deceased, (who had been for a considerable long time a pensioner) made the necessary proof to entitle her to a pension at certain pay during life under an oath of Congress, all of which was sealed and directed to your office. it was mailed at Huntingdon, Carroll County, Tenn, she has not heard a word from it since it was mailed, she desires to know if her claim and proof was received at your office, and if it was what disposition was made of it, she feels great anxiety about it as she is very old and needy. The Colonel her husband during his life drew a pension of $480 per annum, he acted as aideddeccamp [aide-de-camp] to General Green at the Battle of Guildford in the revolutionary War, was a good officer & a brave soldier during that memorable contest for the receipt of this please give the information asked above and direct to any address at this place or to the old lady of Flemings Post Office in this county. Her Christian name is Patsey (Martha) Same Sir yours very respectfully, Samuel Winn M.D. Honorable Pension Agent Recd October 14, 1844

State of North Carolina Iredell County [squiggly brackets] On this 24th day of August 1844 personally appeared before me one of the acting Justices of the Peace in and for said County James M Morrison a resident of the County and State aforesaid aged 64 years who after being duly sworn according to law deposeth and sayeth that he is well acquainted with Mary McKee and that she is the widow of the Identical William McKee who was in the Revolutionary war. And he further says that he was also well acquainted with the aforesaid Wm. McKee and has oft heard him talk of events and circumstances which transpired during the Revolution, one of which was that in the Cherokee Nation at the time the Indians were hastilo [sic, archiac for hostile] to the Americans and to the success of the American Militia he the aforesaid Wm McKee under Capt [ink blot] pursued one Hicks and Scott for two or three days and after coming up with them they fired upon them expecting to find a camp of Indians but they wound only a small Company most of whom were women. They took the aforesaid Scott & Hicks prisoners - and all the Cattle and some three or four negroes which they and brought to the American Line ANd he further sayeth that the aforesaid William McKee was all [caret] ways accounted and believed to be a revolutionary soldier where he lived up to the time of his death and further this despondent cannot say. Sworn to and subscribed on this the day and year above written Before me. [signed] W F Cowan JP [signed] J M Morrison

Virginia Giles County Court to wit I David French Clerk of Giles County Court do hereby Certify, that Christian Snidow before whom the affidavit of Henry Chapman was taken . and Thomas Kirk before whom the affidavit of William Chapman on was taken and William Chapman before whom the affidavit of James Hall was taken, which Several affidavits accompany the declaration and other papers of Daniel Hall praying to be placed on the pension list of the United States for Revolutionary Services by him performed, that the aforesaid Christian Snidow Thomas Kirk and William Chapman before whom this affidavit aforesaid were taken were at the time of Subscribing the Same, and now are Justices of the peace for the County of Giles aforesaid duly commissioned by the Government of Virginia and Sworn into office agreeable to the laws of virginia and that due forth is & ought to Given to their official acts given under my hand & seal of office this 6th day of October 1826 David French CGC [round illegible seal attached] Dear sir I hope the Certificates now forwarded to your office will be satisfactory and that the old man will obtain a warrant.
