exposure to cold & extreme hardships or privations. I was taken sick & remained there, until the arrival of my father, who conveyed me home to Bucks County, after an absence of near three months. I continued extremely sick, the whole winter. Sometime in the month of March or April 1778, a party of about twenty (illegible) were taken, & I formed one of a guard, to convey them to East town jail in Northampton Co Pa. I was absent in this service about two weeks. In the autumn of the year 1779 I was again taken out on a two months tour under Capt Tennison, & marched to Lamberton N. Jersey. We lay here for near two months, & not receiving the orders that we expected we were discharged & returned home. I feel safe & clear in saying that I have serve my Country for at least eight months. I was born in Bucks County, about the year 1754 as aseens by a record in my fathers family bible & lived in the said County of Bucks, when I entered the service. I voluntered & draughted. Since the Revolutionary war. I live in Bucks County, afterwards about ten years, in Franklin County & since that in Greene andWashington County, I am not able now to state the name of regular officers, or of continental regiment never received a written discharge, I am well known by George Plummer Esq. , David Archer Esq. & Richard Carter & James Bell, who can testify to my character for recruits, & who believe that I was a soldier of the revolution. I have no documentary testimony to prove my services, & I know of no living witness for the purpose. I do hereby relinquish every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present, & declare that my name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any state. Sworn & subscribe the John Hair day & year aforesaid in Open Court. We George Plummer & David Archer both Justices of the Peace, in Hopewell Township County of Washington & State

Heidelberg, Nov. 1st 1834 Sir, Your favor of the 9th Sept. was forwarded me by the Honble H. A. Muhlenberg some few days ago and felt deeply wounded and disappointed by the contents. It may however not be simple to say in reply that in the spring of 1774 I took an oath of allegiance, and in 1775 I continued to learn military exercise under the instruction of a Mr. Whitterson. I know not what was his rank in the Army but he was sent out in our neighborhood to instruct us in military tactics. I am now an old man of 84 years and of course forgetful, and I do solemnly protest before God & my Country that in the sending of discharge which now you hold, I had not even remotely an intention to deceive. The Wars being over and peace restored, many of the soldiers of those times received donation lands, some of which I purchased from them, they left me these Deeds and papers, and doubtless the discharge alluded to must be one of theirs. I beg therefore with deep humility to apologize and fervently declare to the Judge of all hearts that I took it to be my own through error or neglect, and that I did not obliterate or otherwise decipher a word of the same. The stupidity of such conduct wd be too prominent, and the discrepancy too glaring for ever an Idiot not to notice. I have already sworn that I did serve my country as a volunteer from 1780 to 1783 in tour & in the manner before mentioned as close as I could recollect and this is all I have to say. If in your judgement you think proper to award me nothing I must submit & say with painful reflections that I did more for my country in the hour of Peril than any man I know of within 20 miles of my residence. Yours respectfully Frederick Hain J. L. Edwards Esq

State of Massachusetts I Benjamin Hadley a Citizen of the United States, now resident at Lexington in the County of Middlesex in the State aforesaid, do on oath testify and declare, that in the War of the Revolution, sometime in the month of December Anno Domini one thousand seven hundred & seventy six I entered and was engaged in the Land service of the United States on the continental establishment, and served accordingly from that time to the month of January in the year Seventeen hundred & eighty. as a private against the common enemy, without any interruption or absence; that I belonged to Capt. John Woods company & Col Baldwin regiment for the first year, & to Capt Nathan Dix's company & Col. Wilson's regiment for the last three years and that I left the service on the expiration of said term, & was honourably discharged and that by reason of my reduced circumstances in life and poverty, I stand in need of assistance from my country for support, being now of the age of sixty years & upwards, & have no other evidence now in my power to offer the Certificate of my discharge as aforesaid, being long since lost or destroyed And I hereby relinquish all claim to every pension heretofore allowed me by the laws of the United States , if any may be or hath been so allowed. Benjamin [his X mark]Hadley. BE IT REMEMBERED, That on this thirteenth day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen Pursuant to a law of the United States, entitled, "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the revolutionary war," made and passed on the 18th of March, A. D. 1818, personally appeareth before me the subscribed one of the Associate Judges of the Circuit Court of Common pleas within State & presiding law has viz the abovenamed Benjamin Hadley and after due examination and caution to testify and declare the whole truth, he maketh oath to the declaration aforesaid, and subscribes the same in my presence; and, on examination duly made by me the said Judge, it appeareth to my satisfaction that the said declaration is true. In testimony seal of Court. affix my name & the Wm Wetmore

other small services which he performed at other times-my Father is 86 last February he fails fast and will not need your bounty long he was one of many, the thousands of others that placed you in a situation to have justice done to our states and laws--we look to you to extert your influence that my Father may receive his full pay--please to let us no how many months is allowed pay for, and what is the reason if you do not allow his all--that we may not feel that some unknown person is benefited by what you expect he yearly receives--you may think I have taken great liberty to write in this way--But we think it is so strange that one part of the certificate should be good and the other good for nothing-the mear fact that my father's first declaration (which was only from memory) set forth less time, than the certificate (obtained from the records of the state of Massachusetts) can not in your mind [illegible] of any other good and just man be any reason that he should not receive pay for all the time that the certificate specify--Sir so it will be imposing two great a burden upon you , we request that you would see the certificate of Massachusetts your self, and will you please to answer this letter your self, and give us a full explanation of the subject. We are needy but still we ask for nothing but justice--My Father & Mother have raised 13 children I am the oldest and the only one now at home, my health to poor that it has been a great effort for me to write this letter-My Father & Mother now old and feabel and a long winter before us if they should live Father die hope to receive at the September drawing something more to help himself with-again I must ry to cast them an my self on the Lord-his word and promis never fails. God has for 86 years watched over My Father and Mother and their large offspring-One dear brother was out in the campaign after Blackhok he took sick and died in the service of his country-a nother Brother has been [illegible] years garding our coasts in the United States services and this somer he again [illegible] his name for three years on bord the United States ship Independence. So you see Sir that from Father to son that go forth to [illegible] or gard our country-May God incline the hearts of all those

State of Pennsylvania Union County Declaration on order to obtain the benefit of the Act of Congress passed June 7, 1832 On the twenty fourth day of September in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and thirty two, personally appeared in open court before the Judges of the Court of Common Pleas at New Berlin in and for the county of Union in the state of Pennsylvania no sitting, John Kuntz, a resident of Center Township, in the county of Union and state of Pennsylvania, aged about seventy eight years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his solemn oat makes the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the Act of Congress of June 7, 1832. That he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers and served as herein stated: I lived in Linton Township, Northampton County, Pennsylvania where I entered the service of the United States. I entered the service as a substitute for a man named Conrad Bilman, who was draughted for two months. I marched in Capt. Adam Stahler and Lieut. Nicholas Cally's company and under Major Benighoff from the house of Michael Bobats in Linton Township to Phila. - I think this was in August 1777. At Phila we got under the command of General Irwin. Genl. Washington with the regular army lay there at the time. I saw General Washington frequently; also Genl. Bull; after having laid there several days we marched to Chester at a distance of sixteen or seventeen miles; from Chester we marched to Wilmington; from Wilmington back to Brandywine where we had a battle with the British. This was I think in the month of September; we ran out of ammunition & were therefore obliged to give way; The British crossed the Schuylkill & we came up on the other side; Having marched faster than they did. They crossed over again behind us & proceeded to Germantown where we over took them and had another battle with them. At Brandywine I was wounded in the breast by a musket ball; When the two months were up - the term of our service - I was discharged - but whether by a written or a paid discharge I don't remember. After my discharge I returned to Linton Township, Northampton County. Soon after my return home I turned out again as a substitute for Andrew Kunkle who was draughted to go against the Indians; I marched in Capt. William Moyer's company, under the command of Col. Geyer; This was in the fall of the year, not long after the Battle of Germantown; under(??) at Anthony Tavern in Linton Township whence we marched over the Blue Mountains to watch the Indians and prevent them from coming over the mountain to commit depredations; We had a battle with them at what was called the "Big Pine Swamp" where three of our men were killed and one John Moyer taken prisoner; then our two months were expired we were discharged & the rest went home, but I remained till another class of militia was draughted and had come over the mountain to the place we were. One John Deitrick was draughted in this class & came out; I was in Capt. Reader's company this tour, which was still under the command of Col Geyer; We again spent two months in watching the Indians & scouting every day; We were again discharged and the rest went home but I again remained. In the new class that was drawn was my brother George Michael Kuntz who marches in Capt. Greflo's company and under Col Geyer across the Blue Mountains where I still remained;

State of North Carolina Rockingham County Court of Pleas and Quarter Sessions for Nov 1818 On the third day of December during the term aforesaid Amos Griffin aged about sixty eight years came into open court for the purpose of making the declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the act of congress making provisions for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States during the Revolutionary war who being first duly sworn according to law declareth and saith that he was a soldier of the continental line and engaged in the service of the United States against the common enemy during the revolutionary war. That he enlisted in the city of Annapolis State of Maryland early in the year 1781 under a Captain David Lynn a recruiting officer of the first Maryland regiment during the war - that he was placed under the command of Capt Francis Revilee of the forth regiment of the Maryland line commanded by Col John Stewart that previous to his entering into the continental service he had performed two tours in the militia service of six months each that after his enlistment as above stated he was marched into the south was as the battle of Stono was a soldier of the [illegible] and surrender of Lord Cornwallis at Little York that he was discharged sometime in the year 1783 as, that during his militia and regular service as aforesaid he received a wound in the arm, thigh and one of his eyes of which he has since become perfectly blind - that he is an abject state of poverty and from this old age and great infirmity unable by manual labor to

State of Massachusetts J James Griffin, Junior a Citizen of the United States, now resident at Gloucester in the County of Essex in the State aforesaid, do on oath testify and declare, that in the War of the Revolution, in the month of May in the year of Our Lord one thousand seven hundred & seventy five I entered and was engaged in the land service of the United States on the continental establishment, and served accordingly from that time to the month of January in the year Seventeen hundred & seventy seven as a private against the common enemy, without any interruption or absence; that I belonged to the Company of Captain Dodge in the afterward commanded by Col. L Baldwin Regiment of Colonel Gerrish. In the Massachusetts line --- I also served one year as a mariner on board the continental Frigate Boston, Capt. McNiel commander, and that I left the service of the expiration of time, being then honorably discharged and that by reason of my reduced circumstances in life and poverty, I stand in need of assistance from my country for support, being now of the age of sixty two years my discharge this lapse of time is lost & I have no other evidence in my power to offer than what is herewith exhibited I enlisted first for eight months, after the expiration of which time I enlisted [illegible] and served in the same Company & Regiment for one year And I hereby relinquish all claims to every pension heretofore allowed me by the laws of the United States, if any may be or hath been so allowed. James Griffin Junior BE IT REMEMBERED, That on this third day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen Pursuant to a law of the United States, entitled, "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the revolutionary war," made and passed on the 18th of March, A. D. 1818, personally appeareth before me the subscriber one of the Associate Judges of the Circuit Court of Common pleas for the middle Circuit within the State aforesaid & presiding pro hac vice the abovenamed James Griffin Junior, and after due examination and caution to testify and declare the whole truth, he maketh oath to the declaration aforesaid, and subscribes the same in my presence; and, on examination duly made by me the said Judge, it appeareth to my satisfaction that the said declaration is true. In testimony whereof I hereunto affix my name & the seal of s Court. I further certify that the Deponents within named are credible witnesses & disinterested and have been duly sworn June 15 1818. viz. Isaac Elwell, C.S. Robert & John Allen Wm Wetmore June

driven back, the same day ^that^ Genl Davidson was killed (Feby 1, 1781 at Cowan Ford) After his death the Bristish succeeded in crossing where he fell. The Americans rallied at the land of Mr Terrance suffering a defeat but reassembled together at the Yadkin river & joined Genl Greene. The retreat continued to South Boston on the Dan river. Grisham (unreadable) under Capt Shadrack Parrish was in charge of the Baggage wagons which conducted to Halifax CH then to Charlotte County House in Va to wait for orders from them to meet the main army at Harrisburg in Granville County. His Co consisting then of only 14 men marched down Roanoke river on the North side which was crossed at Taylor's Ferry to join Colo Butler with 200 men at the Granville old CH- They followed the British who had then evacuated Hillsboro,, to High Rock on Haw river which was reached before their fires were extinguished. A large number of recruits were arriving to aid the Americans without (unreadable) of his other 5 terms of service had nearly expired they (unreadable) (unreadable) & he arrived home March 12, 1781 His next ^3 mos^ tour of duty was ^from June 11 1781^ was in the public factory at Harrisburg under Comd of B Birdsong when he had charge of it, which commenced June 1, 1781 His next tour of 3 mos was as a substitute under Colo Bestor in feeding & taking care of the (unreadable) of public homes, cleaning, pickling & drying fish brought from the public fisheries, making halters for (unreadable)(unreadable)(unreadable) in a small degree to the public Tan yard & carrying one of the Cattle was to Tarboro then to Smithfield in (unreadable) for a life guard to (written along left side of page) protect Gov Abner Nash who was in Williamsboro at the residence of Judge William in vicinity of Williamsboro

I Jonathan Mehuren of Boston in the County of Suffolk and Commonwealth of Massachusetts [illegible] of more than sixty six years of age, on oath do testify and say, that I was a private soldier for seven years in the Revolutionary War between America and Great Britain, and was in the company commended by Captain Jacob Allen belonging to the Regiment of Colonel Joseph Vose that while in the service aforesaid I was well acquainted with a private, a man of colour, called Prince Green, for more than three years, during all which time he was a private soldier in the Continental service; that I knew him both before and since his enlistment and believe that he is now living in Bridgewater in the County of Plymouth and Commonwealth aforesaid; that he is now very aged and infirm and entirely destitute of property - Attest Cyrus Alden Jonathan Mehuren + his mark Suffolk ss. On the twenty second day of July in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and nineteen [1819] the aforesaid deponent was examined, and cautioned, and sworn, agreeable to law, to the deposition aforesaid by him subscribed taken at the request of the said Prince Green, sometimes called Robert Green, to be used as evidence in obtaining a pension granted by the Congress of the United States to indigent sol

When, in consequence as he understood of peace or a cessation of arms, he received his discharge, which discharge he believes was signed by said Captain Robinson, but of this he cannot be certain by reason that he has lost said discharge as herein after stated; that he served under said Capt Robinson in manner aforesaid nearly eight months; that he was born Sussex County State of New Jersey February 26th 1767, that he has a record of his age in his bible in the handwriting of his father, that after he was discharged he continued to reside at said Muncy until June 2nd 1788, when he removed to Chemung Tioga County State of New York, where he lived until the 30th day of July 1817, when he removed to Madison aforesaid, where he has ever since resided and now resides; That in March 1789, his house at Chemung was destroyed by fire and his said discharge burnt up in it. That he has no documentary evidence remaining to prove his service; That he has procured the affidavit, which is hereto annexed of Stephen Oliver, who was a fellow soldier of this applicant in said Captain Robinson Company to prove his second term of service; that he knows of no other person, whose testimony he can procure to prove his service. That the reason he has not before made application is that he hoped to be able to get along without applying for a pension, and the expense and trouble of making the application, besides, has operated to deter him; but his children having now left him, and he and his wife become more aged infirm and needy, he has now been induced to ask his country for support. - By reason of old age and consequent loss of memory, he cannot swear positively to the fore said length of his said second tour of service, but according to the best of his recollection he served not less than the period mentioned below, and in the following grades;-for three months as a private in Captain Samuel Brady; Company, and for seven months as a private in Captain Thomas Robinson Company of Rangers, and for such service he claims a pension . He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension, or annuity, except the present and declares that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any State or Territory. Sworn and subscribed the day and year aforesaid in Open Court Before me D.D. Aiken Clerk. Joseph Green ~~~~~~~~

COMMONWEALTH OF [Image of an eagle with a branch in its beak is between ] MASSACHUSETTS. COUNTY of Hampden SS. On this tenth day of July 1820, personally appeared, in open court, before the Circuit Court of Common Pleas the same being a Court of Record and so established by a Statute of said Commonwealth, said Court being now in session at Springfield within and for said county of Hampden Eliphalet Arson aged Sixty three years, resident in Willburham in said County of Hampden first duly sworn, according to law, doth, on his oath, declare that he served in the Revolutionary War as follows: In the of our Lord 1774 he enlisted as a private man at Granby in the State of Massachusetts [illegible] in April following marched to Cambridge near Boston in the Company Commanded by Capt John Cowle & Regiment commanded by Col Ruggles Woodbridge that he continued to serve in said Company untill January 9,1776 when he was discharged from said service at said Cambridge that during the aforesaid time & service he was in the battle fought at Hogg Island near Boston in 1775 also in the Battle of Bunker Hill in 1775 that afterwards to wit about and first of February 1776 he again enlisted for the term of one year at said Granby in the company commanded by Capt Josiah Lyman in the Regiment commanded by Col. Elisha Porter in the line of the State of Massachusetts in the Continental establishment that he continued to serve in said last mentioned Corps as near as he can recollect untill about the last of November next following (Vis) in 1776 when he was discharged at Mount Independence by a written discharge signed by Wm Clajon by the General Command the date of which has now become illegible said discharge accompanies this application. [the next lines are along the fold of the form and difficult to read] And I do solemnly [tear and water stain] property of [ink blot], contracts, of debts, due [strike through date hereto annexed, and by [water stain] absorbed] or any other property except Company[water stain] clothing & Bedding. SCHEDULE [STRUCK THROUGH] And the said Eliphalet Green further on oath declares that his wife is infirm and aged & that they are both dependent on charity & the Assistance of their son with whom they live, for subsistence that their said son is destitute entirely of property & has a wife and six children to support, except one daughter who is put out to service- and that he said Green is himself infirm by age and in consequence of having broke two of his ribs one of his legs since he was discharged from said service- that he was tied [difficult to read may be bied]to no particular trade and when able to Labour at all he labours at Farming & gardening Eliphalet Green Sworn to and declared on the tenth day of July 1820 before the Circuit Court of Common Pleas at the John Ingersoll [difficult to read Court] I John Ingersoll Clerk of the Circuit Court of Common Pleas for the County aforesaid do hereby certify, that the foregoing oath and the schedule thereto annexed, are truly copied from the record of the said Court and I do further certify, that it is the opinion of the Said Court that the [struck through total amount in value of the property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule is] Said Greene has no property. [struck through Dollars and Cents] In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and affixed the seal of said Court, on this Seventeeth day of July 1820 Clerk of the Court for the County of Hampden John Ingersoll

Elizabeth town Ky 24th Novm 1836 Capt Presley Gray, My old friend and Brother sufferer in arms. I have Just received yours of 15th inst, and am Glad to find that a kind providence has preserved your life up to this date. I have no doubt from my own experience that you feel yourself much worn out by time & Hardships. I am about three years a head of you if I live untill the 29th of this months I shall be 75 years old and am labouring under much infirmaty. all this I ought to be resigned to if it should by the Mercy of God that I am ripning for a better world which I pray God may be the lot of us both. my wife is in her 64th year by a fall from a horse she was so crippled as to be unable to walk with 2 Crutches without help. May the God of Mercy take care of you the remnant of your days is the prayer of your old Friend [signed] John Helm Sr. I Hereby Certify that Capt. Presley Gray & myself Served on the Campaign under Gel. A. S. St. Clair in the fall of 1791 against the Indians & that on the 4th of November 1791 the Army was defeated by the Indians & that the said Gray went out a Captain and Commanded a Company from Nelson County Ky. I went from Nelson County also and was appointed Paymaster to the Ky troops a considerable part of the time I performed the duty of both Paymaster & Quartermaster Give under my hand this 24th day of November 1836 [signature] John Helm Sr P. Helm was wounded

I David Harris of Washington in the County of Chesire and State of New Hampshire Husbandman do make the following declaration upon Oath- That in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and seventy five I enlisted as a private soldier in the Revolutionary War for eight months and was ay Cambridge in Massachusetts my eight months enlistment expired on the last day of December AD 1775 at which time I engaged to serve again in said War for one year in Col Sergeants Regimen the years service to commence on the first day of January AD 1776 I was at the time permitted to go home on furlough six weeks I accordingly went home and did not return so soon as I expected and intended as I was taken sick at home and was not able to return to camp untill (sic) some time in March next following after which I recovered my health and did duty in time in August or September I went to New York and there I continued in said Company and Regiment untill, some time in December when my health was again impaired when I went to General Sullivan and informed him of my situation and General Sullivan gave me a furlough covering the remaining part of my time accepting one day and advised me to make the best way home which was the reason of my not having regular Discharge-Also I further state upon my Oath that I am poor and needy and stand in need of the assistance of my Country for a Comfortable support. (signature) David Harris This may certify that the above named David Harris says he thinks it was in New Hampshire Line if not it must be from the Massachusetts Line and he thinks, the Regiment was part of one state and part from the other. (illegible) enlisted at Cambridge after his first Eight months expired is the (illegible) of his not being positive in which State he was considered (illegible, looks like "Marked or Marched" Sept (illegible number) 1819 Elisha Huntley, Judge of Court

State of Massachusettes I Noah harrington a Citizen of the United States, now resident at Rutland in the County of Worcester in the State aforsaid, do on oath testify and declare, that in the War of the Revolution, in the spring of 1782. I beleive in April I entered and was engaged in the Land service of the United States on the continental establishment, and served accordingly from that time to the end of the war as a private soldier against the common enemy, without any interruption or absence: that I belong to Capt. Watson's Company, Col Henry Jackson's Regiment, being the 9th in the Massachusettes line; and that I continued in the service till the disbanding of the army in 1783, and afterward remains in serice in the ( ) establishment and that, by reason of my reduced circumstance in life and poverty, I stand in need of assistance from my country for support, being now age of fifty three years BE IT REMEMBERED, that on this twentieth day of Apil in the year of our Lord One thousand eight hundred and eighteen pursuant to a law of the United States, entitled, "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War," made and passed on the 18th of March, A.D. 1818, personally appeared before me Edward Bangs, one of the judges of the Circuit Court of common pleas for the ( ) Circuit in Ss. State- the abovenamed Noah Harrington and after due examination and caution to testify and declared the whole tuth, he maketh oath to the declaration aforesaid, and subscribes the same n my presnce; and, on examination duly made by me the said judge, it appeareth to my satisfaction that the said decloration is true. **words covered up* under my hand and seal of said Court, the day of the date aforesaid. (signed) Edw bangs

Sir will you have the goodness to write to Washington for me and see how the case of my Deceased husbands Claims there for a pension from the United States my Husband John Simson Made aplication [application] about 10 years agone H Stewart was his agent the aplication [application] was made at Cooperstown before the Court we resided in German town New Jersey in the time of the war of the Revilution [Revolution] was under Col Taylor Capt Bery Major Rhinehart and others & Served nerby [nearby] durin [during] the war as his declaration will give it more definite I wish you would take it in hand for me and see if you can not obtain my husbands wrigts [rights] as he has suffered very great in the war and be[e]n in several battles as he stated he was a fife Major he mostly was Drafted & volunte[e]red through the war he served under Lord Steirling I want you to take my Case in hand and not deny me I want somebody to see to it my husband died about 11 years ago several has spoken to me to get my pension but have neglected me altogether I am very needy and want your help Jane Simson Springfield Otsego County December 27th 1845 Jacob Slingerland Esqr The name is John Simpson In presence

State of Massachusetts I Thomas Burbeck, a Citizen of the United States, now resident at Boston, in the County of Suffolk, in the State aforesaid, do on oath testify and declare, that in the War of the Revolution, on or about the first of May, in the year of our Lord, one thousand seven hundred and seventy five, I entered and was engaged in the Land service of the United States on the continental establishment, and served accordingly from that time to the January following when I was discharged, the time having expired for which I enlisted, at which time I again entered the service for one year, and continued to serve as aforesaid until February AD 1777 as a soldier against the common enemy, without any interruption or absence: that I belonged to Capt. Edward Burbeck's Company of Artillery, in Colo. Gridleys regiment. for the first enlistment of eight months. and for the remainder of the time was in Capt. Henry Burbeck's Company of Artillery, in Colo. Henry Knox's regiment and that I left the service on or about the middle of February AD 1777 being duly discharged and that by reason of my reduced circumstances in life and poverty, I stand in need of assistance from my country for support, being now of the age of fifty seven years and being lame in consequence of having my thigh broken, And I hereby relinquish all claims to every pension heretofore allowed me by the laws of the United States, if any may be or hath been so allowed. Thomas Burbeck BE IT REMEMBERED, That on this eighth day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen Pursuant to a law of the United States, entitled, "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the revolutionary war," made and passed on the 18th of March, A. D. 1818, personally appeareth before me the abovenamed Thomas Burbeck and after due examination and caution to testify and declare the whole truth, he maketh oath to the declaration aforesaid and subscribes the same in my presence; and, on examination duly made by me the said Judge, it appeareth to my satisfaction that the said declaration is true. Jno Davis Dist Judge Mass Dist.

State of Tennessee, Rutherford County. December 24th 1828 Mr. Richard Rush Sir I received your letter of the 27th of November 1828 assuring my, that my claim was examined–and further, that it appairs [sic], did not corobrate [sic] with public records–and do not know what was the reason. If I was able to travil [sic], I might perhaps find some of the old soldiers, that serve with me in the same company, (if alive) though a number of them ware [sic] killed, at the Battle of Guilford, and other places.–But I will, in addition to my Declaration–give you and the government a short narative [sic] of my enlistment and service during the Revolutionary war. I served in the Militia, about four years, before I enlisted in the United States Army. and while in the militia service, I was at Genl. Gate's defeat, and taken prisoner and afterwards escaped from them and I was also at Genl Blufords defeat–and sufered [sic] many other Hardships and privations. During that time–I then enlisted in the Regular Army of the United States during the war–in Dumfrees, in the County of Prince William, State of Virginia, with two others, one by the name of William Rock, and the other by the name of William Flanigan and we took the Oath before a Squire Lithco–and also received the bounty of $100.00 each from a Capt. Ewell, and remained in his company–in the first Virginia state regiment, commanded by Col. Gibson, in Genl. Mulenburgh's [sic] and I believe that was in fall season of the year 1780–and not long after Gate's defeat. Then we marched to Williamsburgh. From that place. we ware [sic] marched to the south–and at Petersburg Genl. Bluford took command–and marched us to Hillsborough N Carolina–then General Green [sic] took command and from thence marched us to a place called Cherran [sic] Hills on Pee Dee. Then we marched to Guilford, where we have the battle with Lord Cornwallis, and there I was wounded and unable to march at that time–and remained so untill [sic] the time Cornwallis was taken–at York–and after that time

He had no documentary evidence of his services & he believe it was not customary to get discharges regularly made out in that quarter of the country where it fell to his lot to be situation. He knows of no one by whom testimony he can establish these services. He believes any neighbor he has on earth would cheerfully testify to his honest & veracity. Some of the most respectable of his neighbor are Colonel Groves who lives just over the river in Madison County & his brother the first for several years past & at this time a Senator in the State Legislature & the other a Justice of the Inferior Courts. Brittain Stamps of this county (Oglethorp) for a member of hears the high sheriff of the same & Francis Callawya a baptist clergyman. The testimony of some or all of these deposed will endeavor to obtain & respectfully asks to have it considered a part of this his declaration. Judgement, his property, real & personal have been sold, & altho its value was not equal to the amount of debts. The manly & honest deposition of the Old Gentleman manifested in all the transactions induced us to sign off in full to him. The debt of about two thousand dollars was accumulated with myself & brother not at the time knowing or thinking about a mortgage lean on the place. When this was brought forward by Mr Griffith of N Jersey who had it of John B Wallace it quite alarmed me & my brother, we hardly knew what to do, whether to let our debt go or pay up the mortgage & save a little if we could on our debt after much hesitation on the subject & knowing the place must go on the mortgage sale we purchased it in, which increased our debt against Brownson to between three & four thousand dollars. He turned out what stock he had, amounting to rising of a hundred dollars, reserving some household furniture, a cow, & a family horse, under these circumstances we discharged the whole debt we had against him. There had not been one particle of fraud, or illegal conveyance of property on the part of Mr Brownson, every thing has been done, open fair & honest,& legally, & he is poor & needy & entitled to the pension. The principles of humanity have induced me to make this request to have you call on the secretary & request his attention to the subject. It does appear to me that there cannot be any objection to his having a pension, unless some ill disposed person is secretly interfearing against him & if there is objections, I wish he might be informed of them. your compliance will ever be acknowledged by a worthy old soldier & your friend & servant- Charles Miner Esq. Isaac Post

Providence Nov 10 1841 Sir I have been requested to forward to you the enclosed evidence for the claim of Mrs Sarah Brownell widow of Nathaniel Brownell His claim was first sent by John Cross Esq Since his death I have been requested to attend to it — Mrs Brownell claims for 8 months served by her husband in Capt Wilburs Co & Col Church’s regiment of R I Troops & also for further services in the Militia — I presume the evidence of Sylvester Brownell who enlisted & served with him and the the testimony of Francis Wilbour & John Springee now enclosed will be satisfactory of the 8 months service The Roll of Capt Wilbours Co is now lost, but Francis Wilbour, his son recollects the names both, of the applicants husband & the witness were borne upon it A great deal of pain has been taken by me & others to account if there were any Rolls of Col Church’s

Commonwealth of Pennsylvania County of Northampton Ss On this thirtieth day of January in the year of our Lord one thousand Eight Hundred and Thirty Three personally appeared in the open Court of Common Pleas of Northampton County, Before the Honorable Garrick Mallery President and John Cooper and Daniel Wagner associate Judges of the said Court Adam Teal a resident of Lower Mount Bethel Township in said County aged near Seventy Three years who being first duly sworn according to Law, doth on his oath make the following Declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress passed 7th June 1832. That he entered the service of the United States and under the following named officers and served as herein stated. He became a substitute for Lewis Klippinger of the said County in the month of December 1776 and marched from his place of rendezvous in Plainfield Township Indiana County under Captain Henry Strouse of the same County to Philadelphia and arrived there the day after the Hessions were taken by Washington and fetched into the City. We remained in the City some time and were discharged after a Service of Better than one month. But to be certain he only swears to one month. He then came home and remained him until the next fall and then became a substitute for Tawalt Hawn of said County and marched under Captain Charles Heimer of the same County to the Township Saucon in said County where we joined Several other Companies under the command of Col Abraham Miller from there We marched under the command of said Miller to Neshaminy about 2 miles above Philadelphia, where we joined the Army of the militia under the command of Col or Genl Bull. We remained there some time when we marched to Bartholemews (Montgomins Square), and remained there that time in the woods and from there marched near Philadelphia, where we fired a Salute which was returned, we remained there a short time when the Battalion I belonged to, under the command of Col Miller were ordered to March to Smithfield, he thinks on the Road leading from Phila to Trenton and remained there a short time until the Two months expired then the whole Battalion marched to Allentown on the Lehigh River then in Northampton County (now Lihigh) where they delivered up their arms and accouterments after a service of two months. Then he came home and remained home some time when he was called out (having been drafted) under Captain Alexander Forsman of the same County in the year 1778 in the month of July for Two months, marched up the River Delaware, first to Fort Penn, (now called Stroudsburg) remained there about Two weeks and then marched further up the Delaware to the Burk Rice Creek (now in Pike County) about 40 miles from Easton, remained then to protect the inhabitants from

District of Columbia County of Washington On this twenty sixth day of June A.D. Eighteen hundred and fifty-four, personally appeared before me, a Justice of the Peace, within and for the County and District aforesaid Philip Swartzwelder a resident of Pittsburgh Pennsylvania 70 years of age, who, first-being duly affirmed according to law; doth on his affirmations make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the Act of Congress, paped the 7th day of June 1832. - That he is the fifth son of Christian Swartzwelder of Pennsylvania, who died, on the 16th day of May A.D. 1833 in Cumberland County Pa, aged about 70 years, leaving no widow - but a family of nine children (Viz) John, Samuel, Benjamin, Jacob, Susan, Lydia, Philip, Peter and Margaret, of whom but three are living to wit, Philip, Peter & Margaret. That he the said Philip hath often heard his father the said Christian Swartzwelder tell of the perils and hardships and engagements he was in when a soldier in the war of the revolution, that he was Drafted in Lancaster County Pa, some time before the close of teh war, in the company commanded by Capt. Scott of the tenth Battalion under the command of Major Henry Markley and Col. James Ross, that he has heard his said father often say that he was Brandewine Philadelphia and Yorktown, and that he received a wound in one of his legs which caused lameness during life; that to the best of his knowledge his said father served 6 months, that he never heard that his said father ever applied for a pension under the act of Congress, the 18th of March 1818. His said father being then in good circumstances. He also doth on his affirmations make the following declarations, in order to obtain the benefit of the Act of Congress, passed the 7th of June 1832.

loss of memory I cannot state all the Circumstances attending my services: but Refer to my neighbors where I have lived for sixty years to state my former assertions, and the belief of the Community in which I reside Relative to my services as a Revolutionary soldier - I further state that when able to work I was a man of means sufficient to subsist on plentifully and thought I would never apply for a pension - but old age has disabled me so I now ask the favor of a Pension for my services which is now needful to my support - I served as a Private in Both the tours 2 served and never received any pay from the Government for either of the tours He hereby Relinquishes every Claim whatever to a Pension or annuity except the present and Declares that his name is not on the pension Roll of the agency of any State or Territory Abner x his mark Lee Sworn to and Subscribed before me in open Court this day & year aforesaid David Griffith {J.P.} for said County of Jackson. We Isaah Van Zandt a clergyman residing in Jackson County state of Tennessee and Allen W D.Whitt and William P Witcher Residing in the same do hereby certify that we are well acquainted and have been for many years well acquainted with the said Abner Lee who has made subscribed and sworn to the above declaration That we believe him to be upwards of ninety years of age That He is Reputed and believed in the neighborhood where he resides to have been a soldier of the Revolution and that we concur in that opinion and that we believe he served as stated in his said Declaration: His remarks relative to the time places and nature of his said services have always been the same and he is a man of good character for truth and Honesty and was never needy until now being reduced by advanced old age A W. North Castle and afterwards went into New Jersey and at the expiration of his term of Enlistment they were requested to remain till the Army could be somewhat reenlisted or for some other purpose and he with others of his company remained perhaps ten days and were then dismissed without discharge - A part of his company who were in a destitute condition had been left at Peekskill N.Y. - he recollects Colonel Hamilton La Fayette Baron Steuben and General Washington in the Continental Service, as also General Putnam and Lord Sterling. In the year 1777 and he thinks in August or September he volunteered at Canterbury aforesaid for two months under Ephraim Lyon who he believes was a Major to go on General Spencer's Expedition to Rhode Island, went to Providence Rhode Island when he his arms ascouterments and was quartered at the College - from there he marched to Tivertown and served in Colonel Barton's regiment according to his recollection, in General Spencer's Brigade - he does not recollect that he was attached to any Company and if he was, he does not recollect any officers - he returned from Tivertown to Providence where he remained some time and was dismissed at Providence without discharge. On or about the 1st of November 1779, he enlisted at Canterbury aforesaid for four months in Connecticut State Troops in Captain Joseph Dugg's Company in which Timothy Cleveland was Lieutenant and Asa Gear was Ensign and Jonathan Downing was a Sergeant - as also one Fenton a Sergeant - marched to New London when he joined Colonel Levi Wells Regiment - remained at New London near 2 months according to his recollection - then marched to New Haven where he remained a few days and then marched to Stratford where he served out his time and was dismissed early in March 1780 without discharge - when he arrived at New London a vacancy occurred and he was elected a Sergeant - and served as such Sergeant during his enlistment.

in whose service I spent the prime of life and endured with cheerfulness the many deprivations and hardships so inseparable from that glorious contest, that from the unfeeling & unrelenting disposition of an Individual Land lord callows to all the tender feelings of human nature, and to prevent a recurrence of a like similar treatment resolved to become the Tenant of the Bank, in other words to obtain a Lean which has enabled me to rear a House only nominally my own that now rents for 650 dollars depending upon contingency for its continuance at that rent, in addition to which I receive a pension from the State of Maryland of 240 making with that of the (illegible) 1130 dollars, out of which I pay Bank Curtails, Bk discount, Taxes, insurance, & repairs leaving me a balance wherewith I just subsist as I hope it will to appear to you-- the House I now reside in belongs to my Son in the Bk of Washington who is also indebted to the Bank so that it takes all that he can save & that of his Brother to comply with the unceasing importunities of the BK which increase with the depressure of the times, all which facts are respectfully submitted, the result of which I hope may be that I am fairly entitled to receive the pension

He further states that he has no documentary evidence of his service, nor does he know of any person now living who can testify to his services- He also states that his application has been so long delayed from his inability thro' age & infirmities, from recollecting more in detail the services he performed, and an unwillingness to ask for the bounty of his country, but he has been obliged by poverty & infirmities, to make his application, upon such facts as he can remember-- he also states that the provisions of the Act of Congress under which he now applies was unknown to him for two or three years after its passage-- & he had intended residing with his daughter, who is now dead There is no Clergyman that he can procure to testify to his reputation for truth & veracity, not having been known to any for any length of time, in this ca'ty. He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present, and declares that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any State-- Sworn to & subscribed in open Court the day & year aforesaid - Robt. Patterson. Prothy [Signed] George Ream We William Ziegler & Solomon Hass Esqrs-- residing in Walker township Juniata County do hereby certify, that we are well acquaint with George Ream, who has subscribed & sworn to the above declaration that we believe him to be seventy nine years of age, that he is reputed and believed in the neighborhood where he resides to have been a soldier of the revolution, & that we concur in that opinion Sworn & subscribed in open Court the day year aforesaid Robt Patterson Pro... [Signed] William Zeigler Solomon Hass And the said Court do hereby declare their opinion after the investigation of the matter after putting the interrogatories prescribed by the War Department, that the above named applicant was a revolutionary soldier & served as he states. And the Court further the certifies that it appears to them, that William Zeigle & Solomon Hass Esq who have signed the preceding certificate are residents in the township of Walker & County of Juniata, and are credible persons, and that their statement is entitled to credit is-- John Reed Danl Christy Benjm Hepmer

[Sold by J.B. Janseu. appears small in the upper right corner] NEW-YORK MAYOR'S COURT. IN the Court of Common Pleas, called the Mayor's Court of the City of New-York, held at City-Hall, in and for the said City, before the Judges of the same Court, of July — term, in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and twenty — PRESENT the Honorable Peter Augustus Jay Esquire Recorder of the City of New York. City of New-York, ss. Be it Remembered that on the twenty second day of July — in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and twenty personally appeared in the Court of Common Pleas, called the Mayor's Court of the city of New-York, in open court, the said court being a court of record for the city and county of New-York, according to the charter of the said city and the laws of the state of New-York, Daniel Reed aged sixty four years, resident in the city of New York in the county of New York in this United States of America. Who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath declare, that he served in the revolutionary war was follows: that is to say he enlisted in the continental establishment on the 20th day of March 1777 in a regiment commanded by Colonel Malcolm in a company commanded by Captain James Black for and during the war in 1779 deponent was transferred to Col. Spencer Regiment in a Co. commanded by Capt. William Bull in the Jersey line and was again transferred to the New York Line, deponent having been transferred so often he cannot recollect the names of his [illegible] officers, he served until the close of the war in 1780, when he was honorably discharged but by what officer he cannot tell. He further saith his discharge was burnt when his house was burnt down at old Shawangunk in the State of New York. and that his original declaration is dated the sixth day of April one thousand eight hundred and eighteen and that his pension certificate is No. 2270 — Daniel (X) Reed His Mark

I hereby relinquish every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present and[illegible] that my [illegible] is not on any pension roll of the Agency of any state. I know of no living soul by whom I could prove my [illegible] Jesse Kimball sworn and subscribed the day and year aforesaid before me at my office William Pollard [illegible] Justice of the Peace An amendment to the Declaration according to the [illegible] State of Indiana Gibson County ss On this 30th day of August A.D. 1847 Jesse Kimball personally appeared before me in my office the undersigned Justice of the peace. And who being first duly sworn [illegible] that by reason of old age and consequent life of pain he cannot recollect the precise time he served but to the best of his knowledge it was 3 months. And he recollects he got his discharge maby one month or shortly before the town of New London was burned. and for said services as a Revolutionary soulder but he cannot recollect the day and date. Jesse Kimball Subscribe and sworn before me at my office the day aforesaid William Pollard Justice of the peace Interrogatories of the Court according to the [illegible] Department. Where and in what year were you born? In Preston Connedicut. 19th March 1760 Have you a record of your age? Where is it? I have it is in my Bible. Where were you living when called in to service [illegible] [illegible]

(2) the men of the distress of our country and see if volunteers can not be obtained. They had not confidence in the project But requested me to step out and address the company upon the subject and by the effect which I did in the best manner I was capable of and in reaching round for volunteers there were fourteen turned out and I volunteered among others six besides myself out of the fourteen marched to Manchester when we arrived there we were formed into a company under command of Capt John Benjamin of Windsor Vt. I was appointed orderly Sargent we were in a Regt Commanded by Col Benj Wall of Windsor Vt. While we lay at Manchester Genl Benjamin Lincoln from Massachusetts and to the with a detachment of Light Horse when he arrived an expedition was placed against the garrison that Burgoyne had left at by Ticonderoga. There was a detachment of five hundred men was sent from Manchester across the lake for the purpose of effecting the object This expedition was commanded by a Col. Brown from the State of New York Col Benj Wait was second in command Col Herrick who commanded a Regt of Rangers was the third in command. Major Rowley was also in the detachment, I was one who volunteered for this expedition This detachment was called the green mountain boys although we had men in it belonging to Massachusetts among whom was a Captain Lamb who incurred some censure for unmilitary conduct - among the officer who commanded the Vermont troops was Capt Asa Burton John Benjamin, Capt Allen and Lieut Banon we crossed from Pawlet Vermont to the Cold Spring when we look two [illegible] loaded with possessions the property of Torys going to Skinshaw for their families we crossed to the New York side of the lake; and then over the almost impassable mountain to Lake George Landing when we got into the top of the ridge between Lake Champlain and Lake George Captain Allen was detached from the main body of our party of five hundred with a company of men to take Mount Defiance, and his accomplished the work. We arrived at Lake George Landing about day break

this tour, to gather cattle for the support & maintenance of the men at that time called out. He was under a draft subject to the orders of Genl Marion. At the expiration of the aforesaid two months he recd his discharge and returned home & was not called out again during the war. He served in the whole to nine months actual service as a private in the militia during the Revolutionary War. His discharges are lost. He further Swore that during the time for which the above services are charged he was either in the field or in Garrison, & was not employed in any civil pursuit - that he was called out by competent authority as he believed. He hereby renounces all claim whatever to any Pension except the present and declares that his name is not on the Pension Roll of the Agency of any State. John Jones Sworn before me this 13 Oct AD 1834 } in open Court } Edward B. Wheeler C. C P South Carolina } Marion District } We Edmund Herrin a Clergyman and Edward B. Wheeler a Citizen, both residing in the District & State aforesaid, do hereby certify that we are well acquainted with John Jones who has Subscribed & Sworn to the above Declaration - that we believe him to be seventy eight years of age - that he is reputed & believed in the neighborhood in which he resides to have been a soldier of the Revolution & that we concur in that opinion. We also certify that the said Jones has supported an unimpeachable character for veracity Edmund Herrin Edward B Wheeler Sworn before me this 13 day of Oct 1834 Wm W Grice JP

Port Tobacco Augt 28th 1846 Dr Sir On the proceeding page I send you the only certificate which a clerk can give, it only being his duty to keep a record of licenses granted. It is customary here to get a certificate from the minister who performs the service, to prove marriages, but as I presume the minister who married these parties is long since dead and the [illegible] here are not in the habit of entering marriages upon their Record, it will be impossible to get any other certificate other than the one here given you. Also the cost of this certificate we would say that commending as we do all acts of Charity, and always feeling glad when we have it in our power to assist in any manner the poor and oppressed, and more especially the desolate widow, you need not trouble yourself. Perhaps some day we may take a trip South West and if so we should be distressed we will call upon you for it. Yours Respectfully Walton Mitchell D pr Richard H. Mitchell

Patrick County Va May 25th 1841 This day James Lyon Esq appeared before me Wm Critz a Justice of the peace for the county and state aforesaid and after being duly sworn upon the Holy Evangelists of Almighty god, in addition to an affidavit heretofore illegible in favour of Nancy Critz who has said in a petition for a pension for the services of her husband Hamon Critz, as a Capt in time of the Revolution , daposeth and safety that he was well acquainted with Capt Hamon Critz in the Revolution and that knows of his having served two tours in the service of his country of three months each in the year 1780 and 1781, and further states that he knew of his serving of three months tours in the western part of Virginia after toured in Jan of 1779. And further this despondent sayeth not. Sworn to and subscribed the date above Written list. Pat Lyon Wm Critz JP

been commanded by the notorious Simon Girty--the attack was about 12 o'clock noon--the American troops maintained their ground till the next evening after dark when the Indians made a renewed attack, and the troops after suffering severe loss, were thrown into confusion & retreated. Col. Crawford was taken prisoner, and afterwards killed by the Indians as the declarant has understood. This declarant, having accidentally separated from his companions found his way alone, after much privation and sufferings, to the Mingo bottom, where he arrived about the 17th of June 1782--he left there two days after for his home which he reached on the 24th of June after an absence of of one month [underlined] & 12 days {underlined]. During the whole of his service declarant was not in service in company with any continental regiment or corps nor did he come acquainted with any regular officers. He has no documentary evidence by which to prove his service, as the only written discharge which he ever received has been lost through time and account, nor does he know of any person now living by whom he can prove said services. The only record he has of his age is on his bible, now in his possession. After the close of the revolutionary war, he lived at Mingo creek until the fall of 1795-moved then to Waynesburgh, Greene Co., Pennsylvania--from there, after a residence of two years, moved to Mercer County, Pa. for the last twenty three years he has lived in Knox township, in said Jefferson County, where he now resides. He was born [word if crossed out] in Hartford County in the State of Maryland and on the first day of April 1744--He hereby relinquishes any claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present, and declares that his name is not on the pension roll of any agency of any state. known to & subscribed this day} & year of aforesaid ----- } JR Wells Clk David Crawford [signed in large letters with heavy dark ink]

Commonwealth of Pennsylvania City and County of Philadelphia Ss On this twenty [crossed out] ninth day of [crossed out] Sept in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and thirty two, personally appeared in open Court, before the Judges of the District Court for the City and County of Philadelphia in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania Frederick Burkard aged seventy one years on the 13th day of July--last, who being first duly sworn according to Law, doth, on his oath, make the following declarations, in order to obtain the benifits of the act of Congress passed June 7th D.D. 1832 That he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers, and served as herein stated. That he first entered the service in the militia as a substitute for his stepfather John Keyser in Capt George Rinehards Company in a Regiment whereof Joseph Copperthwait and John Browne was Major, that he marched from Philadelphia, to the Swedes ford on the Schuylkill and remained in the neighborhood of Philadelphia during his term of service which lasted two months, that during this term of service he was with Major John Browne in several scouting parties and particularly when he attacked the British Piquet on Chestnut Hill; on the day of the battle of Germantown, he was with Col Knox and Major Cassedy on the west side of Schuylkill in a skirmish with the British, at which time they took a drove of Cattle from the British troops, He was also with Capt [blank] (the name he cannot recollect in an attack on the brittish

State of New York Rensselaer County SS On this Thirty first day of May 1820, personally appeared in open court, being a court of record in and for the said county according to the solemn adjurations of the Supreme Court of this state, and being a court which proceeds according to the course of common law; with a jurisdiction unlimited in point of amount; keeping a record of its proceedings; and possessing the power of fine and imprisonment) Bangs Burgess -- aged Seventy three years, resident in the Town of Hosick in said County who, being first duly sown according to law, doth on his oath declare, that he served in the revolutionary war as follows: - from 1778 to 1783 in fourth Regiment of Massachusetts line commanded by Col Wm Shepards in a Company commanded by Capt. Pope and afterwards by Capt. S. Learned that his original application for a pension under the act of 18 March 1818 was dated eight day of April 1818. and the number of his certificate is 5422. And I do solemnly swear that I was a resident citizen of the United States on the 18th day of March, 1818; and that I have not, since that time, by gift, sale, or in any manner, disposed of my property, or any part thereof, with intent thereby so to diminish it, as to bring myself within the provisions of an act of Congress entitled "An act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the revolutionary war," passed on the 18th of March, 1818; and that I have not, nor has any person in trust for me, any property or securities, contracts, or debts, due to me; nor have I any income other than what is contained in the schedule hereto annexed, and by me subscribed, Bangs his x mark Burgess Sworn to and declared on the 31 day of My 1820. Archi Bull, Deputy Clerk State of New York, Rensselaer County SS I, Joseph D. Selden - Clerk of the Court of Common pleas held for the County of Rensselaer in the State of New York do hereby certify, that the foregoing oath & affidavit and the schedule thereto annexed, are truly copied from the record of the said court; and I do further certify, that it is the opinion of the said court, that the total amount, in value of property exhibited in the aforesaid schedule is Thirty three dollars and Thirteen cents. IN TESTIMONY WHEREOF I have here hereunto set my hand, and affixed the seal of the said court, on this 31 day of May 1820 Joseph D. Selden, Clerk.

State of Georgia } Cass County } SS. On this nineteenth day of September in the year of our Lord One thousand Eight hundred and thirty four, personally appeared in open Court William Thompson of the County and State aforesaid, residing in said State and County aged Seventy years on the fourteenth day of March last, who being first duly sworn, according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the provision made by the act of Congress passed June 7th 1832. That he entered the service of the United States as a private in a horse Company in the 1778 or 1779 in Abbeville District in the State of South Carolina as a Volunteer under Captain Dunn from Georgia, from old age and affliction and consequent loss of memory he is unable to state positively as to the precise time he entered the service, that shortly after he entered the service that the detachment in which he served was defeated at a place called Long Cane in South Carolina where the American forces were commanded by General Benjamin Few of Georgia, between the time of entering the service and the battle at Long Cane, he was transferred from Capt Dunn's Company to the company of Capt Black under Colonel McCall. Captain Black and first Lieutenant Raney Lockhart were both killed in said battle, from Long Cane he marched under the command of Colonel

State of Georgia Chatham County. Personally appeared before me Edward Tenney who being duly solemnly sworn on the Holy Evangelists of Almighty God, deposes and says that he entered into the service of the United States at Hillsboro in the State of North Carolina in the year 1778 as a private in Captain Henry Bell's Dragoons under the command of Colonel William Washington, that he continued in service until the year 1782, during which time he was in the following engagements, Battle of the Cow Pens, Guilford Court House, Camden South Carolina, Eutaw Springs, and that he was severely wounded between his hand and wrist in an engagment with a small party of the enemy at [illegible] South Carolina which rendered useless two of his fingers. And this deponent further states that he is upwards of sixty five years of age, that he was born in the state of Virginia. Sworn to before me this 6th January 1819 Moses Sheftall SSGGG his Edward X Tenney mark I do certify that I am a Justice of the Superior Court of Chatham County duly elected & qualified and that said court is [illegible] agent of record. January 1819 Moses Sheftall

[handwritten] He volunteered under Captain Malcolm & shipped on board [illegible inked out] Montgomery Frigate & was transferred to the Lady Washington as stated above. State of Kentucky County of Christian Personally appeared James M. Wilson of Christian County who being duly sworn state that he was acquainted with Mistress Holly Gillaspie a very old and helpless woman She lived with Berry who had the care of her for many years. she was entitled to a pension and I on several occasions attend to Swear her to her application and shortly before she died I attended and swore her to some papers to obtain an increase of Pension. The Pension she drew was not compensation to Mr Berry for clothing and attending to her and had to pay funeral expences as I understand. She has no [illeg] here that I know of and have no interest in the Claim she was quite feeble for many years before her death and required much attention, and deed after swore her to her application in 1870. I cannot give the date J. M. Wilson Subscribed and sworn to by James M Wilson before me In witness whereof hereto set my hand and [illeg] the 15th day of July 1872 B. M. Harrison Clk Christian, County Court

State of Delaware Kent County Be it remembered that on the Seventh day of August in the year of our Lord One thousand Eight Hundred and Eighteen, Before one Isaac Davis one of the Judges of the Supreme Court for the said State Personally appeared John Gibbons, Aged sixty four years or thereabouts and being duly sworn uppon [sic[ the Holy Avangals [Evangels] deposeth and says that in the year One thousand Seven Hundred and Seventy Six he Inlisted as a souldier [sic] in Captain Samuel Smiths Company in the Delaware Blues for one year, that he Marched from the [illegible] in New Castle County, that he performed regular duty, for one year and returned at the end of his term with his Captain, obtained a discharge which is Lost, and has remained in the Said county ever since, that he is poor and indigent and needs some assistance in the decline of Life, being unable to perform hard labour and destitute of support without it. Sworn and subscribed before on the 7th of Aug 1818 - Isaac Davis X his Mark John Gibbons State of Delaware Kent County Ss I do certify that John Gibbons of New Castle County in the State of Delaware served as a soldier in the Company of Samuel Smith, Captain, in the Delaware Regiment for one year in the year, one thousand seven hundred and seventy six in the Revolutionary War between Great Britton and the United States of America, and that he is initiated to be placed on the Pension list of the U. States, for his services. Agreeably to the Provisions of an act of Congress Passed [illegible] he being old, poor, and indigent in testimony where I have hereunto Set on my hand the 7th of August 1818 Isaac Davis

was born a few months before her father Isaac Gelden left home to enter the service in the Revolutionary War this [illegible] the mare thoroughly [illegible] the time of the birth of her daughter on her memory Especially as she was left alone with her child and experienced a great many hardships during his long absence that her husband the aforesaid Isaac Gelden died in Johnston County on the 10th day of March 1832 aged as she always understood 78 years all which will [illegible] fully appear by reference to the Proof hereunto answered that she has been but recently made acquainted with her right to a pension On account of the services of her husband which she [illegible] she is justly intitled [entitled] to [signed] Mary Gelden (her mark) Sworn to and subscribed day and year above written before me J G Gulley JP

State of Massachusetts County of Worcester I Ichabod Geary a Citizen of the United States, now resident at Sterling in the County of Worcester in the State aforesaid do on oath testify and declare, that in the War of Revolution on or about the first day of May in the year 1780 I entered and engaged in the land service of the United States on the continental establishment, and served accordingly from that time to the second day of September in the year 1782, or thereabouts as a private against the common enemy, without any interruption or absence : that I belonged to Captain Adam Bailey's Company in Col. Sprout's Regiment on the Massachusetts line - Having enlisted for the term of three years and that I left the service the second day of September 1782 or thereabout, having received an honorable discharge in consequence of a wound in my hand and that, by reason of my reduced circumstances in life and poverty, I stand in need of assistance from my country for support, being now of the age of Sixty nine years - Having served the United States for two years and four months. Having lost my discharge. I also served in the laboratory at Springfield M's for the term of three years as a private in the revolutionary war in the service of the United States, and was honorably discharged. And I hereby relinquish all claims to every pension heretofore allowed my by the laws of the United States, if any may be or hath been so allowed. Ichabod Geary BE IT REMEMBERED, That on this 14th day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen pursuant to a law of the United States, entitled, ""An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the Revolutionary War," made and passed on the 18th of March, A. D. 1818, personally appeareth before me, Edward Bangs one of the Judges of the C. C. of Com pleas for the [illegible] County of Worcester the above named Ichabod Geary and after due examination and caution to testify and declare the whole truth, he taketh oath to the declaration aforesaid, and subscribes the same in my presence; and, on examination duly made by me said Judge, it appeareth to my satisfaction that the said declaration is true. & have affixed my seal of said County. Edward Bangs [embossed seal]

Nicholasville Oct. 14, 1832 My dear sir I am truly sory [sorry] as I did not send my papers to you as you directed. I sent them on the 22d of August. I have not received any answer. The Hon. Wm. T. Bery told me to wright [write] to you as he knew you could get my benefits done. M. Edwards wrote me informing me I came under the Law of 1832 and directed me to apply to Court which I did and get the Certificate of the Court. M. Edwards sent me all my paper on the 22 August sent Saml [Samuel] Jackson who I supposed was dead from information arrived at my house who served in the 3d Regiment of Georgia. I took his deposition on that day thinking that he believed that I was a Capt. I then acting as such I forward his deposition, with his Figures & the Certificate of the Court. Also my affidavit [illegible due to smeared ink] M Edwards sent to me which he states that was on his files. Wm. Bery said if you would brought [?] him he would attend to to any benefits you requested I hope my dear Sir you will excuse me for the tarbel [trouble?] I put you to I will pay you what ever you say and I no [know] you must be at some Expence [expense] I am Neady [needy] & I shall ever look on you my true Friend. May God bless you. B Netherland Jr B. I stated in my affidavit in 1828 that I had a Certificate of General Elbert I got in 1780 I served as Capt. which I lost which I stated in my deposition of the Court BN let me hear from you as Early as convenient

[handwritten, continued from previous] called the Two Bridges after Staying there a Short time we were ordered back again thence we marched to providence & there to Greenage & after a Short period then back to Rhodeisland Island and next marched to New London & was there when it was burnt - & under the Command of Capt. Daniel Rose & from there was ordered to the Island to prevent the Enemy from landing at that place. State of Massachusetts I josiah Gorham - a Citizen of the United States, now resident at Edgecombe in the County of Lincoln in the State aforesaid, do on oath testify and declare, that in the War of the Revolution, in the month of February (as near as I can recollect) [illegible] 1777. I entered and was engaged in the land service of the United States on the continental establishment, and served accordingly from that time to the end of the war in 1783, I have enlisted for [illegible] the war as a private soldier - against the common enemy, without any interruption or absence: that I belonged to Capt Warren's Company, Col Aldens 7th Massachusetts Regiment, until about the year 1780 (as near as I can recollect) when Capt Warren resigned and the Company was commanded by Capt Mills and that I left service at the close of the war in 1783 at New Windsor in the State of New York where I received a regular discharge which I have lost, any that by reason of my reduced circumstances in life and poverty, I stand in need of assistance from my country for support, being now of the age of fifty eight years soon after my first enlisting I was attached to the music as a fifer in said company and served afterwards in that capacity. part of the above time we were at West Point where Col. Brooks commanded our Regiment. And I hereby relinquish all claims to every pension heretofore allowed me by the laws of the United States, if any may be or hath been so allowed. Lincoln Commonwealth of Massachusetts BE IT REMEMBERED, That on this fourth day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen Pursuant to a law of the United Stated, entitled "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the revolutionary war," made and passed on the 18th of March, A.D. 1818, personally appeareth before me, Jeremiah Baily Judge of the Court of Probate within [illegible] the County of Lincoln, in the [illegible] aforesaid, the same being about of records of said bounty. the abovenamed Josiah Gorham and after due examination and caution to testify and declare the whole truth, he maketh oath to the declaration aforesaid, and subscribes the same in my presence; and, on examination duly made by me the said Judge, it appeareth to my satisfaction that the said declaration is true.
