South Carolina} Greenville District} We Leroy McWorter clergyman residing in Greenville District and Robert Cox residing in Greenville District aforesaid hererby certify that we are weel acquainted with William Goodlett who has subscribed and sworn to the above declaration; that we believe him to be seventy two years of age; that he is reputed and believed in the neighborhood where he resides, to have been a soldier of the Revolution and that we concur in that opinion. Sworn and subscribed to the 8th July 1833 Before me William Choice Comr & Register in Equity & J.Q Robert Cox Leroy McWhorter

Letterhead: FORM S PENSIONS. PAREMES, LANDS, CONTRACTS, &c. Proceeded. EDMUND F. BROWN NOTARY PUBLIC. COMMISSIONER OF DEEDS & C. FOR STATE OF ILLINOIS, AND Public, Private, and Confidential Agent For settling Business of every description, with Congress, the Officers of the different departments, Companies, and Individuals. Attention prompt. Charges reasonable. Letters must be Postage paid. Penn Avenue, near 13th st. WASHINGTON CITY. United States Agency and Notarial Office, Washington City, 29 July 1845. NOTARIAL AND OTHER Official CERTIFICATES Prepared. Acknowledgemens Taken, Sc. J. L. Edwards Esq. Commmissioner of Pensions Sir, Your letter of this date, stating that you have carefully examined the papers in the case of John Goff, and can discover no good reason for requiring less than your letter of 18th June called for, has just been received; and your letter of 18th June to which you refer, is now before me. Knowing the strictness of your rules, I am not much surprized that you decline to admit Mr Goff as an Ensign, altho I have no doubt he was one and is so unfortunate as to lose all his evidence but that of (underlined) one Commissioned officer; but I did expect to receive a Certificate for him as a (underlined) Private, because the evidence of his (underlined) identity which I filed on 21st inst. is sufficient to satisfy any unprejudiced mind. That your office, which professes to be governed so much by principles of law, should let the caveat of the 3 Justices weigh (underlined) one feather against the claim, is (underlined) really surprizing, because it is well known that such unmeaning charges, entirely destitute of any specifications to enable us to contradict them, if presented in any Court, Society, Church, or any other

State of Massachusetts I Casar Godfrey a free black man + a Citizen of the United States, now resident at Boston in the County of Suffolk in the State aforesaid, do on oath testify and declare, that in the War of the Revolution, and at the time Capt Barry first took the command of the Continental Frigate Alliance, but the month and year I have forgot, being then a boy, I entered and was engaged in the Naval service of the United States on the continental establishment, and served accordingly from that time to the termination of the said war, an uninterrupted time of more than nine months as a [illegible] + mariner against the common enemy, without any interruption or absence : that I belonged to the Continental Frigate Alliance then commanded by Capt John Barry, from the time he took the command of her as aforesaid and that I left the service on the termination of the sd war and that by reason of my reduced circumstances in life and poverty, I stand in need of assistance from my country for support, being now of the age of fifty six years– I also testify that I lost an eye in the engagement between [illegible] frigate Alliance + the Sloops of war Atlantic [Atalanta] + [illegible] [Trepassey] while on board her as aforesaid And I hereby relinquish all claim to every pension heretofore allowed me by the laws of the United States, if any may be or hath been so allowed. [signed] Ceser Godfrey BE IT REMEMBERED, That on this [crossed out "ninth"] thirteenth day of April in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eighteen Pursuant to a law of the United States, entitled, "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United States in the revolutionary war," made and passed on the 18th of March, A. D. 1818, personally appeareth before me the subscribed one of the Associate Judges of the Circuit Court of Common Pleas within the State aforesaid + presiding [illegible] the abovenamed Casar Godfrey and after due examination and caution to testify and declare the whole truth, he maketh oath to the declaration aforesaid, and subscribes the same in my presence ; and, on examination duly made by me the said Judge, it appeareth to my satisfaction that the said declaration is true. In testimony whereof I hereunto affix my name + the seal of the Court aforesaid– I also certify that the within named deponent [illegible] [signed] Wm Witmore [seal affixed to document]

Westminster Vt. 28 July 1832 At the request of some of my neighbors, I have taken down their statements and assisted them in making out their papers for the purpose of obtaining pensions. If there is any want form in the authentication, I shall esteem it a favor to have them immediately returned with the defect pointed out that it may be remedied. As to the substance, I have no doubt they have all stated truly to the best of their recollections. (??) are among our most respectable and independent men. Mr. Wright is a farmer and Mr. Abbe was formerly a Blacksmith and both have unimpeachable characters for honesty - They are all highly credible men. In addition you have the certificate of our clergyman who has preached here for more than 40 years and of our (??) magistrate. If more recommendations of their character is wanted I have no hesitation to add my own. Lastly Gov Richards has also made out his own paper which with a letter to Mr. Edwards he has requested me to analyze. I think the latter gentleman must distinctly remember Mr. Richards who was a member of Congress from this state when the first pension was law under Mr. Monroe was passed. I believe he then little thought it wants can be extended to persons as wealthy as himself. It having been so, he probably finds objects whereas to bestow it more needy than the government in its present condition. Earnestly requesting as early a return as possible. I have the honor to be your very respectful servant Wm C. Bradley To Gov. Cass. (??)

State of Maryland | Personally appeared Prince Georges County |before me the sub [illegible] a Justice of the peace and for said County Bazel Hatton Revolutionary soldier and pensioner and personally known to me and who I hereby certify to be a man of great truth and personal respectability and integrity of character who being duly sworn according to law saith some time in the month of March 1777 the deponent enlisted at a place now called centerville in the State of Virginia in the company commanded by Capt John Jarrett of the third Georgia Regiment that the same time and place John Frazier whom he was then intimately acquainted with entered as an Ensign in the same Company and Regiment that they were marched with much expedition to Georgia when Capt Jarrett was killed by the enemy on a march from Augusta to Savannah late in the spring or Summer of said year when the said Ensign John Frazier became second Lieutenant and served in that capacity untill captured by the enemy in the hospital at Savannah in 1778. The despondent escaping being on board this legally. The Regiment was commanded by Col Scriven [Screven] who was killed marc to Midway Church during the war. he knows not whether the said John Frazier had any commisions or not. but knows

Jan [illegible] 1821 Scipio Cauga [Cayuga] New York deer [dear] sir a few days past i received a return from you that my name is stricken from the penshtion [pension] list on the amount of my property which was valued at one hundred & eighty Dollar and a few odd cents and the debs which i justly owed and still owe them was ninty [ninety] seven dollars and by reason of sickness in my family my debts have increased to nineteen dollars and fifty cents more and all the property i possess will not sell for a sum sufficient to pay my debts and i can afirm [affirm] in truth i cannot labour to get muney [money] to pay my debts and that i have nether [neither] house nor home except i have. i know the State Law will soport [support] me by the towne that i live in but [Deer Sir??] pray consider how much more pleasent it would be to have a little of my own then to call on the town for support it is truth i earned my penshtion [pension] due by serving my Country three Long years and underwent both hunger and coald ? [cold] and was once obliged to flee before my enemies and leve [leave] my pack on the ground and it was six months before i could get a shirt to put on or any other clothes to [cover??] me and Deer [Dear] Sir must my name be stricken from the penchstion [pension] list i believe no one needs it more than myself and that Congress desired that such as i should have it i once thought to have learned my son which is 17 years old my trade but the infirmity of old age forbids it and he must be put apprentice to some other man and their son i am left alone to grope about and proform [perform] but a very little work to suport [support] myself and poor old weakly wife i cannot help flatening my self that you will consider me one of the objects of pitty [pity] which have their names on the penshtion [pension] list and place my name once more there on : i thought that Congress did a good deed when [crossed out illegible word] they pased [passed] an act to give a small penshtion [pension] to help some poor only like me and it apears [appears] almost imposable [impossible] but that i must be benefited by it for i now live almost four hundred miles from my native towne and having lost my discharge caused me to send for my evidance [evidence] of my service in the revolutionary war and turned out my [last/lost??] Cow to get the exspenses [expenses] muney hoping i should [receive??] the muney by my penshtion to [ridans??] [hunger??] and most all this be last o deer Sir it Cannot sufer me to depend on your goodness to relieve my destress [distress]

Wilmington and served three months as a private, that he was drafted; that he was in no battle, that he marched from Duplin County to Wilmington, that about two days before he arrived there, the enemy had evacuated that place, and the small pox (?) was prevalent there at that time, that from Wilmington he marched back to Duplin County and was discharged a short time after Christmas, that he has no documentary evidence, but thinks he can prove this service by his brother Davit Merritt of this county. 5th.--Soon after the expiration of the above mentioned service, he was drafted to guard some tories confined in a place called the Bull pen, near Duplin Old Court House on the land of Gen. James Kenan in January he thinks 1783 and guarded them three months, left there in the first of the spring; he forgets the officers of the guard, the prisoners were taken from thence and carried to Halifax jail, that he has no documentary evidence but thinks he can prove at least that he guarded said Bull pen by his brother David Merritt, [rest of line crossed out...........} Answers of Daniel Merritt the aforesaid applicant to the questions prescribed by the War Department propounded to him by the Court aforesaid. 1. I was born in Duplin County N.C. on the plantation where I now reside, on the 9th October, I presume in the year 1763 because when I first entered the service I was a little over sixteen years of age. 2. I have no record of my age now, it was recorded in a Bible of my brother Frederick Merritt, & after he died it was destroyed by the family.

and property contained therein and said nothing excepting the clothing which he wore, that his house was burned early in the spring of 1831 in the County of Morgan Ohio. That he has not now in his possession any documentary evidence of his service as a soldier in the revolutionary army, and knows no living person who has any knowledge of said service, except Wm Davis here in before named. That he is as before stated about 86 years of age and is destitute of property and means of procuring a livelihood, but is dependent upon the charity of people. He is not acquainted with any clergy man in the neighborhood where he resides and therefore he cannot obtain a certificate as to the truth of the above statements from a Clergyman, he hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity and furthermore claims he is not on the pension roll or equary of any state. - James Meloy his mark Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid E. T. Cox Clerk 1st Ques by the Court Where and in what year were you born? Answer I was born in the County Armaugh, Ireland, but do not recollect the year. 2d Have you any record of your age, and if so, when is it? Ans. I have not, as the books were burnt (with my other property) which contained the record. 3d Where were you living when called into service where have you lived since the Revolutionary war, and where do you now live? Ans. I left the British army immediately before; and I lived in Maryland and in Ohio six years before the war admitted into the Union and have resided in Ohio ever since 4th How were you called into service; were you drafted, did you volunteer, or were you a substitute? And if a substitute, for whom? I enlisted with Capt. Harris as stated in my declaration 5th State the names of some of the regular officers who were with the troops when you served; such continental and Militia Regiments as you can recollect, and the general circumstances of your service. Ans. I cannot state any thing more particularly than what I have stated in my declaration, as aforesaid

State of New York} County of Niagra} On this fourth day of September in the year of our Lord one thousand Eight hundred and thirty two personally appeared in open court before me Joel McCollum one of the Judges of the Court of Common Pleas and General Session of the said county of Niagara now sits Silas Mead a resident of the Town of Somerset in said County of Niagara and State of New York aged seventy years on the sixty day of May last, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath ma[] the following declaration in Order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress passed June 7, 1832. That he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers and served as herein stated That he resided in the year 1782 at Amenia Precinct in Dutship [Dutchess] County in the state of New York. That about five hundred men were musturd at Fish Kill in said County. That the militia companies were divided into class of about nine and each class were to send one person into the army or one was to be drafted from among each class, that he went into the service as a substitute for one class on a term of service of nine months when he arrived at Fish kill he was under the command of Captain Livingston in the Regiment of Colonel Musenfills where he underground one month after this he was one of eighty selected by Capt. Matcham belonging to Col. John Lambs regiment of artillery Genl Knox's Brigade and under

arrived that [Lord] Rawdon was coming to aid Genl [John Harris] Cruger we raised the Siege and marched to Babb's Mill on Bush River crossing the Saluda [River] at the said Island ford then we met with a call to go to the aid of Col. [Joseph Hayes] Hays on Little River at Edgill [Edgehill] Station who was engaged with the Tories who were arrayed under one [Major William] Cunningham a Tory captain. Here they were all taken prisoner and he was paroled and Captain [Daniel] Williams, Col. Hayes, Peter Yearley, Joseph Wilkins, & Several others killed. The British had possession at 96 & they together with the Tories over ran the Country for about 13 months. he did not enter the service for any particular time, but to serve as a Militia man as long as required to repel in various & depredations Scouting and Scouring the Country in the Counties of Lawrence [Laurens], Abbeville, Greenville. He was told by Capt Williams that if he did not turn out he would be drafted & being acquainted with Williams he volunteered to serve as long as the present distress required & continued with him not less than 11 months before

We Epephnes Thompson Jr. a Clergyman residing in the town of Wheeler and Erastus Skinner residing in the town of Prattsburgh both of the County of Steuben aforesaid hereby certify that we are well acquainted with John Phelps of the town of Prattsburgh who has subscribed and sworn to the above declaration that we believe him to be Seventy two years of age that he is reported and believed in the neighbourhood where he resides to have been a Soldier of the Revolution and that we concur in that opinion. [signed] Epephnes Thompson Jr. Erastus Skinner Sworn & Subscribed the day and year aforesaid [signed] Wm. H. Bull Clerk of Steuben Com. Pleas And the said Court do hereby declare their opinion after the investigation of the matter and after putting the interrogatories prescribed by the War Department that the above named applicant was a Revolutionary Soldier and served as he states. And the Court further Certifies that it appears to them that Epephnes Thompson Jr. who has signed the preceding certificate is a clergyman resident in the town of Wheeler & that Erastus Skinner who has also signed the same is a resident in the town of Prattsburgh and is a creditable person and that this statement is entitled to credit. I William H. Bull Clerk of the Court of Common Pleas do hereby certify that the foregoing contains the original proceedings of the said Court in the matter of the application of John Phelps for a pension

I Susannah Grimes, a resident of the town of Granville, in the county of Washington, and State of New York, aged sixty four years, do testify depose and say, that I am the reputed daughter of the within named Bartimeus and Anna Hewett, that they ever within my recollection, until the time of his death, which took place on the 27th day of November, 1849, lived together and were known generally as Husband & wife. I even understood from them & others that they were married in Dorset in the State of Vermont on the day of August 1784, but I have no knowledge of any record wither public or private of their said marriage but formerly they kept such a record & of the births of their children in a Bible which has been destroyed or lost for several years. I had one sister Rachel, who was older than me, who was married to on John Seeker & who lived in Manchester in the state of Vermont and Died several years since in Salem New York State. Our said parents resided with us sever years prior to his death which happened as above stated, at our house & she has ever since resided & still resides with us & has since his death remained & still is a widow, unmarried & in feeble health. They have both been very infirm, nearly helpless, for many years. I have knowledge that my said father was in the receipt & enjoyment of a pension for his revolutionary service from the United State for several years previous to his death. Susannah X Grimes her mark Sworn to & subscribed the day & year first above written, before me Martin Lee Washington County Judge I Archa Grimes, a resident of Granville, New York as above stated aged 76 years do testify , depose & say that I am the husband of the above named Susannah that we were married on the 7th day of January, 1804 _ that i became acquainted with the said Bartimeus & anna Hewett nearly one year previous to that time they then lived together & ever afterwards until the time of his death, which took place at the time by her stated & were & have been generally reputed & known as husband & wife that at the time of our said marriage the said Susannah called herself & was called in the family & appeared to have been eighteen years of age _ that all the subsequent facts stated by her in her said Affidavit I was, & am knowing to & agree with her, therein that previous to the said Anna's applying for the arrears of pension, due to the said Bartimeus, at the time of his death. I copied his Pension Certificate which was then surrendered, which copy I now have it was under the law of June 7, 1832 & was for forty four Dollars & 84 cents. Archa Grimes Sworn to & subscribed the day & year first above written before me, Martin Lee Washington County Judge

of which Company he does not now remember and that he this declarant served in said Company three months and upwards, during which the company was marched from Harford County to Cecil County in Maryland and placed by Colonel McComas under the command of Colonel Hollingsworth whose first name he does not now remember and was stationed for some time at the head of Elk River at Elkton, and marched from thence to amb(?) and to various places where their services were supposed to be most necessary. 232 JOURNAL OF THE SENATE. [March 21. protest of the President against the aforesaid proceeding of the Senate, was rejected and repulsed by that body, and was voted to be a breach of its privileges, and was not permitted to be entered on its Journal or print- ed among its documents; while all memorials, petitions, resolves, and re- monstrances against the President, however violent or unfounded, and calculated to inflame the people against him, were duly and honorably received, encomiastically commented upon in speeches, read at the table, ordered to be printed with the long list of names attached, referred to the Finance Committee for consideration, fied away among the public ar- chives, and now constitute a part of the public documents of the Senate, to be handed down to the latest posterity: And whereas the said resolve was introduced, debated and adopted, at a time and under circumstances which had the effect of co-operating with the Bank of the United States in the parricidal attempt which that institution was making to produce a panic and pressure in the country; to destroy the confidence of the people in President Jackson; to paralize his administration ; to govern the elections; to bankrupt the State banks; ruin their currency; fill the whole Union with terror and distress; and thereby to extort from the sufferings and the alarms of the people, the restoration of the deposites and the renewal of its charter: And whereas the said resolve is of evil example and dangerous prece- dent, and should never have been received, debated, or adopted by the Senate, or admitted to entry upon its Journal: Wherefore, Resolved, That the said reserve be expunged from the Journal; and, for that purpose, that the Secretary of the Senate, at such time as the Senate may appoint, shall bring the manuscript Journal of the session 1833 -'34 into the Senate, and, in the presence of the Senate, draw black lines round the said resolve, and write across the face thereof, in strong letters, the following words: "EXPUNGED BY ORDER OF THE SENATE, THIS ----- DAY OF ----- , IN THE YEAR OF OUR LORD 1836;" And, after debate, On motion by Mr. Hubbard, The Senate adjourned. MONDAY, MARCH 21, 1836. The Vice President communicated a report of the Secretary of the Navy, made in answer to a resolution of the Senate of the 16th instant, in relation to the navy hospitals of the United States; which was read. The Vice President also communicated a report of the Secretary of the Treasury, made in compliance with a resolution of the Senate of the 4th instant, showing the amount paid by the United States on account of lands purchased from the Indians; which was read. Mr. Knight presented the petition for Samuel Warner, of Massachusetts, who has been engaged in the service of the United States as a seaman, praying a pension; which was referred to the Committee on Naval Affairs. Mr. Tomlinson presented a memorial of a number of merchants of the city of New York, [illegible here due to fold in page] which they have paid on imported goods may be refunded; which was referred to the Committee on Finance. Mr. Walker presented documents in relation to a claim of the heirs of

upon a small piece of [?] land. I am unable to cultivate it from the injury sustained by me during the Revolution in the abdomen and in the [folly?] of my intestines on both sides of the [?] of my belly and also from the debility of age. I have a wife aged fifty seven years who is feeble but in other respects healthy. she contributes to the support of my family by [?] after females in their confinement. I have six children. Thomas twenty three years old. Milly eighteen years old and William fourteen years old who live with me. Thomas receives the principle [?] of his earnings. Milly [?] and assists my wife in cooking. Milly does not aid me. Thomas ploughs and assists in the support of my family. I have three children besides, David aged twenty eight; Joseph twenty-five; Jenny aged twenty, and they are married and live to themselves. They furnish me no assistance. I have an old Negroe named George nearly seventy years old who is an expense and burden to me. My wife has a daughter by a previous marriage and a grandchild Sally Freeman and her son John , the one aged thirty one and the other nine. Sally weaves and spins occasionally for the family but principally for herself and child when she can get employment. I am in needy circumstances and unable to live in humble comfort or ease without p[?] or private aid. I have several debts and am unable to pay [?]. My property is not sufficient for that purpose. I have been permitted to keep it by the clemency of my land lord and creditors. Joseph [his + mark] Anderson Sworn to and declared in open court this 22'd day of April 1821. J. Y. W. State of Kentucky Mason County SCT On this fourteenth day of December in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and fortysix personally appeared before the county Court for the county of Mason and state aforesaid Mary Daulton a resident of said State and County now being in her eightythird year of age And being first duly sworn according to Law doth on her oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the provisions made by the act of Congress passed July the fourth eighteen hundred and thirty six and subsequent acts That she is the widow of Moses Daulton who was an orderly sergeant in the war of the revolution and served as follows My late husband Moses Daulton was born and brought up in Princewilliam County in the State of Virginia His services I now state according to the best of my recollect having often conversed with him on the subject of his services and hardships - Moses Daulton often stated to me he entered the army of the revolution and in the continental establishment at a very early age being not quite sixteen years old and was marched from Dumfries in to the main army in the year 1776- I cannot now recollect the month nor can I recollect officers names under whom he entered the service owing to advanced age and loss of memory I do yet recollect the names of places where Mr Daulton often stated he was in some of the hard fought battles Namely the battle of Monmouth the battle of Trenton the battle of the Cowpens in North Carolina commanded by Colonel Morgan those are some of the battles he stated he was in but was in more which I cannot now recollect

State of Georgia Effingham County Personally appeared before me John R Morgan, one of the Justices of the peace in and for the County and State aforesaid Daniel Dampier of the same place, who being duly sworn as the Holy Evangalist of Almighty God deposeth and saith that he was a revolutionary Soldier. That when he was discharged from the service of the Unied Stated as a revolutionary Soldier that he sold his eight und title of all the bounty land that he might be entitled to for said Service to Lieutenant Colonel Joseph Pannell of the United States service who was attached to the same battalion this deponent was, and that he received his Note for four pounds money, He has no knowledge that the land was obtained he only sold his eight to it. He gives as his reason, for not applying at an earlier date for the pension, that he was in tolerable circumstances and did not stand in greed it was some time after the passing of the Act of 1832 that he heard he was entitled to it and made some enquiries about it, that seven or eight years back that one Doctor Hill, and since then a W. Matthews. both promised to do something for him in the way of obtaining it, but both failed in their promises nor was he acquainted with any one to befriend him untill last year, when a Gentleman called upon him & informed him that it could be done for him to which he consented and the result was his present application which he hopes may be successful, being old and needy further he says not. Sworn to this 9th day of November 1864 Jno. R. Morgan J.P Daniel Dampeer

State of Vermont District & County of Caledonia On this fourth day of October AD 1832 personally appeared in open Court before the Hon. C. Benjamin F. Deming Judge of the Court of Probate for the District of Caledonia aforesaid now setting Jonathan Curtis a resident of Hardwick in the District and County aforesaid aged 79 years who being first dulyt sworn according to law doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the provisions of the Act of Congress passed June 7, 1832. That he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers and served as herein stated. I, Jonathan Curtis of Hardwick, Caledonia County & State of Vermont, depose and say that I was born in the year of our Lord 1753 in the town of Mansfield, County of Windham and State of Connecticut. There is a record of my birth in the town Clerk's office of Mansfield. I lived in Mansfield until I was five years old. I then lived in Ashford, a town adjoining Mansfield about six years where my mother died. I then lived in Coventry and Pomfret about four years. When fifteen years old I left Pomfret and came into Hanover County of Grafton and State of New Hampshire. I lived in Hanover when I enlisted which was in the early part of Sept 1775 being 22 years of age. I volunteered in company of about 30 men all from Hanover.. Israel Curtis was Capt John House first Lieut. Daniel Clapp second Lieut. Blake was ensign. At the time I enlisted there was a call for more men to attack St. Johns with this view I volunteered for six weeks. Our march commenced the next day after enlistment up the Connecticut River through the towns of Lyme and Oxford New Hampshire; at the last place we crossed the river in boats the n John House first Lieut. Daniel Clapp second Lieut. Blake was ensign. At the time I enlisted there was a call for more men to attack St. Johns with this view I volunteered for six weeks. Our march commenced the next day after enlistment up the Connecticut River through the towns of Lyme and Oxford New Hampshire; at the laext morning. We tranported four upon horses and drove several cattle. We crossed the River into Moretown now Bradford, Vermont. We received two men at Oxford from Piermont, N.H. from Moretown we marched Corinth and halted for the night at the house of one Brown. Thence we marched coast-wardly through the wilderness towards Lake Champlain. We were directed by marked trees and found no more inhabitants until we arrived at the residence of Thomas Chittenden afterward Governor of Vermont who had recently made a clearing in the present town of Williston, VT. In the same day of our arrival at Chittenden's residence, our company encamped for the night at a lace called Baker's Falls on Onion River near Burlington, VT. There were then but two families there whose names were Baker and Bradley. On the

and each of them of the age of twenty one years or upward, to wit Stephen Ballard, Rhoda Kendell, Mary Ann Manson, Margaret Parkhurst, Martha Rathbun, Lucrecia Bull, Mary Pratt & Elizabeth Gamage Sworn & Subscribed this 4th day of March of John V. To the Congress of the United States of America Convened at Washington in the City of Washington and District of Columbia, within the United States of America on the first Monday of December in the year of our Lord 1830 The Petition of Ebenezer Chaplin of Suffield in the County of Hartford and State of Connecticut, within the United States of American Humbly therewith - That your Petitioner in the Winter and Spring of the year 1776 voluntarily tendered his services as a soldier to the Continental Army, nearby Boston in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and was one of the first men that broke ground on Dorchester Heights was then poor and destitute of property, and not a subject of military duty - war absent from his family two months, was honorably dismissed without fee or reward returned home to Suffield on the 20th April 1776 - and your Petitioner would further state that in the month of May following he voluntarily enlisted (not being then a subject of military duty) in the Company of Capt. John Harmon of said Suffield, and with said Company did march to the northern army to Ticonderoga

our service was to defend the settlement, that he the said John Carey was engaged in many expedition on that part of the County against the Indians & Tories or refuges; that Capt Spalding and company and Capt Dunkis, who was killed in the Indian Battle 30 July 1778 were consolidated that he was in an expedition with Col Hartleys Regiment to the (?) where they retook a large number of cattle that had been drove off by the Indians the Indians followed and fired upon us killed and wounded several of our men that the said John Cary was detailed to guard some boats that belonged to the Garrison at WilkesBarre where he was shot in the right arm above the elbow and wounded very severely; that after his had recovered so far as to travel he was employed to carry the mail for the Army until the close of General Sullivans expedition; that for the wound thus received a pension of sixteen dollar per annum was granted him by the United States on the certificate of three surgeons & the testimony of Col. {Seal} RECEIVED DEC 11 1931 PENSION FILES Franklin, Tenn., Dec 8, ‘31 Mr. A.D. Hiller, Washington, D.C. Dear Sir, I acknowledge the reception yesterday of your of Sept. 3, and thank you for the information you give me. It seems that your letter was held up somewhere for quite a while. We have had the information as to Wm. Bransford, and his warrant for a great while, but it was not official, at least to us. Those, who first had it, may have obtained it officially. We succeeded at last in getting Mrs. B. L. Bishop, Patchogue, N.Y., the great, great-granddaughter of William Bransford, the Revolutionary Hero, into the D.A.R. We have written up the genealogy of the Bransfords from John Bransford, the English Emmigrant, who, & wife, Mary Kingsford, both of them English nobility, came to Va. In 1729, to the present. The large volume will shortly be given to the Tenn. Historical Society for preservation and perusal. I am a [illegible] preacher for the Tenn. Conf. M.D. Church South, now in my 85th year, and am the acknowledged Vestor of the Bransfords. Again thanks for writing to me. Very truly Yours, Samuel W. Bransford

which consisted in the loss of one finger entirely and another cut and lying in the palm of his hand (the left) and several deep saber cuts in his head, which later affected your declarant's intellect occasionally for a period of 7 or 8 years, the injury to his left hand or fingers has ever since rendered him unable to labor efficiently at any business which required the use of both hands, being a prisoner of war and confined by his wounds when the period for which he had enlisted expired prevented him from obtaining a discharge. He never received any compensation for his services whatever. He knows of none of his compatriots in arms who are living, if there be, is remote situation, his poverty, age and infirmities occasioned in a great measure from his wounds, would prevent his seeking after them. He believes however that evidence sufficient to establish his services may be found accompanying his petition for a pension presented to the House of Representatives of the United States at or about the Session of 1819 – 20 or 1820 – 1 and which he presumes are to be found filed at Washington City. Chesley Kinney whose testimony accompanied said petition he is informed has since departed this life. He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present, and declares that his pain is not on the pension roll or agency in any state. Edward Moody, his X mark And the said Court do hereby declare their opinion, that the above named Edward Moody was a revolutionary soldier

...he had measurably recovered and then returned to his former company & regiment where he continued to serve. But the period of his enlistment and about the time thereof was so affected that he was left by the army and was unable to return. In consequence whereof he never got a discharge but does most positively state that he served upwards of the years under his enlistment (exclusive of several tours in the militia) in the Continental service in the Revolutionary War. That he, in consequence of his wounds received in the army, never has been sufficiently healthy to pursue manual labor and is now in distress & poverty and stands in need of the assistance of his country for support. That he is a resident citizen of Sullivan County, state aforesaid, and has resided therein for twenty years and never has been placed on any pension list of the United States. And that he, at this late period of life has no other means of establishing his said services than his own disclosure but refers the Honorable, the Secretary of War, to the Rolls of the Revolution of the first Regiment of the Jersey Line and company of Captain Pratt. s/ Nathaniel Osbourne (X - his mark) Sworn to & subscribed in open Court this 19th November 1818 s/ Wm. Anderson, D(eputy) Clk.

That he served in the Revolutionary War as follows. Enlisted under Captain James Winchester but was commanded by Captain John [illegible] 2nd Regiment Maryland line for three years that he has received a Pension Certificate number 6,779. And that I have not nor h, three head of as any Person in trust for me any property or Secretive Contracts or debts, due to me, nor have I any income other than what is contained in the annual schedule + by me subscribed as follows viz one mare about 18 years old and a mare Colt about four years old, three head of katte[?] + two [illegible], 1 dozen [illegible], ten spoons, three or four knives + forks, 1 pot + 1 pan + a kettle, and one tea kettle. That he has a wife aged about 55 or 56 years now lying at the point of Death, that he has no other person living with him, + that he is unable to support himself + hands in [illegible] distance of his County for support Sworn to + subscribed in open Court George Norton his mark

State of New York County of Seneca SS Rev Abraham Brokaw appeared before the Subscriber a Justice of the Peace for said County, after being duly sworn, says that he was a minister of the Gospel for forty eight years that he is of the age of eighty six years, that he is a pensioner of the United States, that during the war of the Revolution, he was a resident of Somerset County New Jersey, and at that time was acquainted with Jacob Van Doren, & his brother Abraham Van Doren and that the latter was a Lieutenant in the army in the war of the revolution & that he was the late husband of the present Mary Low of said County who has applied for a pension, that this deponent knew of no such person as Abraham Vadon as a Leutenant in Somerset County or out of it, that he knew of no such name as Vadore in the State of New Jersey the name of Van Doran have been written down, as it was a such name and pronounced in both ways Sworn & Subscribed before me ● this 30 day of June 1846 by law Joseph Dunlass a justice of the peace I certify that the above named Abram Braham has long been a highly respectable minister of the Gospel & that he is in all his walker a christian Joseph Dunlap J.P.

State of New Jersey Middlesex County} Personally appeared before me Merrill Mundy one of the Judges of the Inferior Court of Common Pleas in and for the County of Middlesex Martha Magee widow of John Magee who being duly sworn upon the Holy Evangelist of Almighty God did depose and say that she is the widow of John Magee That she is in the Seventy third year of her age since the 16th Aug. last past that she was married to John Magee in the year of 1782 or 1783 she cannot now tell the record having been lost, but recollects distinctly that it was before the close of the war as she knows that her husband was out in the Militia in the Revolutionary war after they were married, that they were married by Parson Ayres Episcopal Minister at Spotswood in the County of Middlesex, that Joshua Smith was present at their marriage that her husband John Magee was in the war before they were married She only knows from his telling her that he served under Capt Morgan a great deal of the time, she recollects of his telling her that he was in the Listed troops a year under Captain Asher Randall & St Nicholas Morgan and in fact that he was out during the whole of the war sometimes listed and his time Expiring, then in the Militia and further that her husband has been dead about six years, and that she has not married since and further saith not her Martha her X mark Magee mark Sworn & Subscribed before me the 11th Sept 1837. Merrell Mundy, Judge State of New Jersey Middlesex County} I do hereby certify that the above named Martha Magee is altogether unable from her great age and bodily infirmity cannot attend in open Court Merrell Mundy Judge

COMMONWEALTH OF MASSACHUSETTS. YORK, SS. On this eighth day of April 1818, before me, the subscriber, Chief Justice of the Circuit Court of Common Please, for the first Eastern District, in said Commonwealth, personally appears Isaac Pope resident in Arundel in said county of York and state aforesaid, who being by me first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath, make the following declaration - in order to obtain the provision made by the late act of Congress, entitled "an act to provide for certain personas, engaged in the land and naval service of the United States, in the revolutionary war." That he, the said Isaac Pope, being seventy four years of age, entered the american army on the twenty second of april 1775 and on the 19th of May 1775, received a commission from the provincial congress of the state of Massachusetts as a Lieutenant in the second foot company of the regiment commanded by Theophilus Cotton Esq and that on the first day of January 1777 he was appoi a captain in the fourth Massachusetts regiment and on the sixteenth day of September 1782 he [illegible] a commission as Captain, giving him his rank from the said First of January 1777, from the United States and that he continued in the army from the [illegible] 22 of April 1775 untill the [illegible] of 1783 when he was honorably discharged from the service - and that he is the same person to whom the annexed commissions were originally delivered - And that he is reduced in his circumstances and stands in need of assistance from his country for support, and that he has no other evidence now in his power of his said services except the annexed commissions. Sworn to and declared before me the day and year aforesaid. Benj. Greene I BENJAMIN GREENE, Chief Justice of the Circuit Court of Common Pleas for the first Eastern District, in the Commonwealth aforesaid, do certify, that it appears to my satisfaction that the said Isaac Pope did serve in the revolutionary war, as stated in the preceding declaration against the common enemy, is reduced in his circumstances and [illegible] in need of assistance from [illegible][illegible][illegible] and I do now transmit the proceedings and testimony taken and had before me to the Secretary for the department of war, pursuant to the directions of the aforementioned act of Congress. Testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand a affixed the seal of said Court at Wells this [illegible] day of April in the year of our Lord 1818 Benj. Greene

Oneida County, On this fourteenth day of August 1832 personally appeared before the Subscriber a Judge of the court of Common Pleas of Oneida County, Zephaniah Smith, a resident of said county and state, aged eighty-two years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress, passed June 7, 1832. That he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers, and served as herein stated: That he was born at Taunton Mass. September 1750. There is a record of his age at Taunton. Lived at Bridgewater, Weymouth Co, Mass. Since war lived at Bridgewater, New Salem Ma, Chatham NY, Vienna NR, now [illegible], Oneida Co, NY. That he enlisted in the fore part of the season of 1775 for eight months in Capt Frederick Pope's Co, Lieut Eleazer Snow, Zachary Thayer, Ensign, in Col Sargents's Regt in Col Cleveland, under commant Genl Putnam. Marched to Cambridge and was stationed about two miles from there at a place called Hinman White house-- and was stationed there and while there assisted in building a breastworks on prospect Hill. And was discharged in January 1776 having served out his 8 months but did not receive a written discharge. In December 1776 volunteered in Capt Aldens Company of Militia of Bridgewater in Col Halls Regiments for a tour of three months and marched to Bristol Rhode Island and then served for said term and were discharged in March 1777. In the Summer of 1777 was drafted in Capt. John Ames Company and marched to Providence Rhode Island and served one month. This was all the service performed amounting to 12 months. This deponent knows of no witness to prove his service and refers to annexed certificate and affidavit as to his character and reputation. He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present, and declares that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any state. Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid. Zephaniah Smith Israel Stoddard, Judge of [illegible] We Eliakim Stoddard clergyman and Ezra Devereux Farmer residing in Camden, Oneida County, hereby certify that we are well acquainted with Zephaniah Smith who has subscribed and sworn to the above declaration; that we believe him to be about Eighty two years of age; that he is reputed and believed in the neighborhood where he resides, to have been a Soldier of the Revolution, and that we concur in that opinion and that he is a man of truth and veracity Zephaniah Smith Eliakim Stoddard Ezra Devereaux I Stoddard, Judge of Oneida And the said Jududge do hereby declare in my opinion, after the investigation of the matter, and after putting the interrogatories prescribed by the War Department, that the above named applicant was a Revolutionary Soldier and served as he states: And the Judge further certifies, that it appears to him that Eliakim Stoddard who has signed the same, is a resident in Camden and is a farmer and is a credible person and that their statement is entitled to credit. And I further certify that I have been long acquainted with said Zephaniah Smith and know that he has been reputed an old soldier, which opinion I concur. From bodily infirmity he is unable to attend court. Isreal Stoddard I George Brown, Clerk of the Court of Common Pleas of Oneida Co do hereby certify that the foregoing contains the original proceedings of the Judge in the matter of the application of Zephaniah Smith for a pension. In testimonty whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and seal of office, this 15th day of August 1832. And I further certify that the above named Israel Stoddard is one of the judges of the court of common pleas of said County and the signature about are his. Geo Brown

Declaration In order to obtain the benefit of the Act of Congress of the 7th July 1838, entitled an act granting half pay and pension to certain widows State of New Hampshire, Grafton Ss On this 16th day of August 1838 Personally appeared before me David C. Churchill Esq one of the Justices of the Court of Common Pleas within and for the County of Grafton, Orpah (Orpha) Aldrich a resident of Canaan in said County of Grafton aged 69 years, who being first duly sworn according to law doth on her oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the provision made by the Act of Congress passed July 7, 1838, entitled an Act granting half pay and pension to certain widows - That she is the widow of Richard Aldrich, who was a private in the War of the Revolution and served as follows - That in the year 1775 he enlisted at Johnston, Rhode Island into Col (Colonel) John Angel's (Angell's) Regiment. She does not recollect the name of the Captain or other Officers, went to Boston, Massachusetts, was there at the time of the Battle of Bunker Hill, he stayed at Boston and in its vicinity one year, then went in the same Regiment to the State of New York and to Newport Rhode Island, was at Newport when there was a battle there, served in New York and Rhode Island two years, she does not recollect where, nor the time when he was discharged, but she knows that he was brought home from the Army by his Father, sick, and she believes that he served three years or more but cannot state any further particulars. She often heard of her late husband tell of his revolutionary service in great deal, and of hardships he suffered, being at times almost destitute of food and clothing-

The Major Part of the COUNCIL of the Massachusetts Bay, in New England, To, [handwritten] Robert Earl, Gentleman [end handwritten] Greeting, YOU being appointed [handwritten] Second Lieutenant of the Seventh Company whereof William Hix is Captain, in the second Regiment of militia in the County of Bristol whereof Edward Pope Esq. is Colonel. [end handwritten] By Virtue of the Power vested in us, WE do by these Presents, (reposing special Trust and Confidence in your Loyalty, Courage, and good Conduct,) Commission you accordingly. - You are therefore carefully and diligently to discharge the Duty of a [handwritten] Second Lieut. [end handwritten] in leading, ordering, and exercising said [handwritten] Company [end handwritten] in Arms, both Inferior Officers and Soldiers; and to keep them in good Order and Discipline: - And they are hereby commanded to obey you as their [handwritten] Second Lieut. 1 DECLARATION. IN ORDER TO OBTAIN THE BENEFIT OF THE ACT OF CONGRESS, PASSED JUNE 7, 1832. STATE OF RHODE-ISLAND,} COUNTY OF Newport}ss. On this Eighth day of Septem[?] 1832, personally appeared in open Court, before the Judges or Justices of the Court of Probate of for the town of Tiverton, now sitting, Capt. Richard Durfee a resident of Tiverton in the County of Newport and State of Rhode-Island, aged Seventy four years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the Act of Congress, passed June 7, 1832. That he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers, and served as herein stated. That is to say. In the year 1775, when the British Troops under General Gage were in Boston- and the English vessels of War, Rose, King Fisher, and Glasgow, under the command of the notorious, Capt or Commodore Wallace, occupied the waters of Narragansett Bay, and were harassing our shores- and menacing with destruction, the town of Newport, Bristol, and other places in Rhode Island bordering on the shores of said Bay-the Militia, the only sort of defense that we then had, were called out to defend the most vulnerable [illegible] on the shores- to guard the towns, and watch the movements of said vessels of War- I then belonged to a company of militia in said Tiverton under the command of Capt Benjamin Durfee - he was in the-- Autumn of this year ordered into the public service and marched to Newport and attached to a Regiment under the command of Col. Babcocks of which he believes and Richmond was Lieut Col.- in this service he continued six weeks --- In December 1775 or in January 1776 he enlisted into Capt. Loring Pecks Company, at Bristol [town "Tiverton" lined through], in Col Lippitts Regiment for one year- in the early part of this service he was stationed at Bristol, from there in the spring he with the company to which he belonged, were marched to Bristol Ferry on the Portsmouth side of the Ferry, and worked for some time on the fort there- then marched to Newport-and worked on the fort on Brentons Point- & other places in the vicinity of the town- there we staid till sometime in Augt or September when the Regt. was was ordered on to the westward. We crossed from Newport to the South ferry on Boston neck and there by land through, New[illegible]on, New Haven &c. to Kingsbridge & Haerlem[Harlem] when we joined the American Army under General Washington. Staid there but a short time-we then retreated North to White Plains.-he was in the action fought there-- after the action we situated a short distance northerly where he was encamped in the rear of the main Army on a Hill. We then marched to Peekskill on the north river where the Army immediately prepared to crossover-- here he was taken sick, and was no longer able to follow the Army. After staying here some time, I sufficiently recovered my health to travel, a short distance in a day, and when my time was about out, I received my discharge, and through much suffering and distress, and almost with out, shoes, money, or clothing, reached home, after having been absent in the service a full year or more- from the time he entered into Captain Pecks Company as aforesaid. ~

Does not the Secy know that the great Washington had power from Congress to make his officers as the great distress & want of Troops were beyond description which never found there way to the War Office, the army so distributed & distressed through the several States on the frontiers & Sea board &c to render & aid you kind Sir Permit me to call your attention as a pioneer in my case when Congress adjourned to Lancaster in Pennsylvania 1777 I was appointed a Second Lieut. Under Captain Myers since dead only two of us and was advised to assume a popular Name to encourage enlistments as our Army was small times expiring &c as Col. Hazens Regiment was called Congress "Own” on the same principle to add to his enlistments We called ourselves Rangers and was so successful as to bring in the field nearly two hundred for three years or during the War, I was after appointed a Captain, the following copy of Esquire Kennedy Certificate in my possession will show, State of

How were you called into service; were you drafted, did you volunteer or were you subscripted? Ans: I volunteered several times and I was sometimes drafted. State the names of some of the regular officers, who were with the regular troops where you served, such Continental and volunteer regiments as you recollect, and the general circumstances of your services. Ans: I remember no other Regular Field officers except Col Pope. I cannot tell what regiment he commanded. Did you ever receive a discharge for your services and if so where is it now? Ans: I never received any written discharge. amount brot. up $12.62 1/2 1 earthen pitcher .25 1 meat tube .50 1 Reg. .37 1/2 1 do .25 1 chest .75 2 old buckets .50 1 wire sieve 1.00 1 foot wheel 2.50 $18.75 My present residence is about eight miles south of the village of Lebanon Ohio, I have a wife & two sons living with me to wit Sibbel Stevens, Jefferson Stevens & Sullivan Stevens. My occupation is that of a brick layer which I am now entirely unable to pursue in consequence of my frequent attacks of the Rheumatism which in addition to many other bodily infirmities usual to me of my age who have had to undergo the difficulties, hardships & privations of the Revolutionary war render one almost entirely unable to contribute any thing towards the support of my family & my wife who is nearly of the same age with myself has for a number of years been severely affected with the Saint Anthony's fire which renders her (illegible) competent to ^attend to the domestic concerns of my family. Jefferson Stevens is about sixteen years of age has for a series of years been afflicted with a white swelling in one of his knees which renders him entirely unable to contribute to our support, indeed he is rather an expense--Sullivan Stevens fifteen years of age is measurably able to contribute to our support in consequence of an eruption in the abdomen, needs schooling which at present I am unable to give him. Ephraim Stevens Affirmed & subscribed to in open Court 20th Nov 1829-Matthias Corwin Jnr. Clerk

Dear Sirs:- I am asking for information with reference to one John Wells who I think is the ancestor and the information you can give will determine. In the Pension records you should find that one John Wells a private in the Maryland Militia was placed on the Pension Roll May 14, 1833 at the age of 77 years (This being on record in the Archives of History of the state of West Virginia. At the time the Pension was granted he was a citizen of Monongalia County, Virginia, what is now West Va. being at that time as you know a part of the state of Virginia. Please give me the entire record of this John Wells as set out in the application for a pension, particularly Date of Birth _________________ Place of Birth _________________ Family relation and children_______________ Names of parents if given ________________ Date of enlistment, regiment, Company etc. _______________________________________ Date of Discharge _______________________ Battles in which engaged if given _______________________________________ Date of Marriage and to whom ____________ Please give me the same information as to Colonel John Evans, a Revolutionary soldier and XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX Colonel Dudley Evans, a soldier in the War of 1812 who are both my ancestors. Thanking you very kindly I am, Very sincerely yours, Jacob Elbert Wells (signed: Jacob Elbert Wells.) P.S. My father, Richard D. Wells was a corporal in Co. F, 12th W. Va. and my youngest brother was a commissioned officer in the World War doing service in the War Department. J.E.W.

Nelson County, Ky, Jany 25th 1832 My Dear Colonel, Being on my way to the Cherokee nation in Georgia, and passing through this County which is my native place. I have been applied to by an old soldier of the Revolution Mr Henry Shonty whom I have known from my boyhood and who is now in indigent circumstances and [crossed out: "in"] distress, [crossed out: "who"] residing in this vicinity. He is making application for a pension and from your accustomed readiness and promptness, to step forward in behalf of the distressed soldier, widow, and orphan. He has appealled to you for your exertions in his behalf. Rogersville Tennessee Sept. 17th 1819 Sir, William Johnson residing adjacent to this place to whom you forwarded a pension certificate for Revolutionary Services has applied to Licke Lead Esqr. Pension agent for East Tenn. without receiving his pay; it was payable the 4th Sept but she had 15 or 16 months pay due - Mr. Lew says his name does not appear on the list forwarded from your dept. to him and that it has been neglected and that he is not authorized to pay on the original certificate. The old man is in great distress, and while others are drawing their pay; he is suffering for the want of his. Respectfully I am Your obt. Servant C Alexander

State of New York County of Chenango On this thirteenth day of August 1832 personally appeared in open Court before the Hon. Robert Monell, Vice Chancellor of the Sixth Circuit of the State of New York at a Court of Chancery held at the residence of the Vice Chancellor in the town of Greene in the County of Chenango and State of New York, now sitting Daniel Johnson, a resident of Guildford in the County of Chenango and State of New York, aged 72 years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the Act of Congress passed June 7, 1832. That he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers, and served as herein stated, that he, living at Farmington, in Hartford County and State of Connecticut, on or about the first day of June 1776, volunteered and enlisted in, and going from Farmington and passing through the towns of Cheshire and Wallingford, arrived at East Guilford about 40 miles from Farmington on or about the 20 June and there joined Captain Jehiel Mays, 1st Lieutenant Samuel Barker, 2nd Lieutenant James Peck, Ensign Levi Gaylord. From East Guilford on the day after joining the company, went with the copmany on board of vessels, and sailed to New York, where arrived in about two days after leaving East Guilford, at New York city joined Colonel Andreas Ward's Lieut Colonel (believe, Obadiah) Johnson's. Mayor Isaac Burks regiment of Connecticut State troops. After remaining at New York about 4 days went with the Regiment to Fort Lee in the State of New York. After remaining at Fort Lee 4 or 5 weeks, from Fort Lee went with the Regiment to Valentine Hill in Westchester County where they encamped and there remained 'till about 15 October 1776 and from thence marched to White Plains and there remained until the Battle with the British on or about 28 October 1776 and he was in the ledt wing of the American Army at the Battle of White Plains and after battle fell back 2 or 3 miles, and there encamped and there remained until after the British had taken forts Washington and Lee, and there remained until about 15th November and trom thence with the trooped went to Peekskill and being sick at Peekskill with about 40 soldiers (sick) under care of Captain Phelps. From Peekskill went to Hospital in Norwalk, Connecticut where he remained until January 1777 when he went back to Peekskill, and from thence about the middle of January went to Chatham in New Jersey where he joined the aforenamed Regiment, and from Chatham marched with the Regiment through Springfield and Westfield to the lines near New Brunswick. The British were then in New Brunswick. About 1st February 1777 they had a skirmish with the British troops on the lines - remained on the lines until March when by order of Genl. Washington the troops fell back to East Morristown where the regiment had the small pox, and from thence went below Chatham to a town (name forgot) where remained 2 or 3 weeks, and from thence went to Newark and there remained about a week, and from thence marched to East Morristown where he remained with the troops until the 14th May 1777 when he was discharged and went home to Farmington aforementioned. It then being 11 1/2 months from the time of his enlistment. - That he being at Farmington aforementioned on or about the 25th June 1777 volunteered and enlisted for 6 months, when about 1st July the company assembled at New Haven in Connecticut, about 75 miles from Farmington under the command of Captain Peter Curtis, 1st Lieutenant (Christian name forgot) Roberts, 2nd Lieutenant (believes John) Churchill, Ensign Levi Gaylord, remaining at New Haven 2 or 3 weeks, from thence marched to Norwalk and there remaining 2 or 3 weeks went to Danbury. At Danbury the company divided and from Danbury with half the Company under command of the aforementioned Captain and Ensign, marched to Fredericksboro in the State of New York and in October from Fredericksboro marching to Fishkill where the whole company again united and joined Colonel (Christian name forgot) Enos or [illegible], Lieutenant Colonel (Christian name forgot) Smith, Major (forgot), Regiment of Connecticut State troops, remaining at Fishkill 2 nights. From thence marched with the Regiment to a place called Colonel Drake Stand and there remaining a week or two, from thence marched to Merrimack on Long Island Sound, there remained a short time and from thence marching to Horseneck in the State of Connecticut, remained at Horseneck until the last of December 1777 when the term of his enlistement expired and he was discharged and returned home after an absence of six months. That he living at Farmington aforesaid on the 1st July 1779. Was drafted for 5 weeks, and soon after went to New Haven, and then joined Captain Woodruff, Lieutenant Foot, Ensign Hitchcock, company of Connecticut, State Militia, and from New Haven in Connecticut went with the troops to Horse Neck in same state about 100 miles from Farmington aforesaid, and at HorseNeck joined Colonel Hookers Regiment (Lieutenant Colonel and Major (forgot name) Wadsworth was adjutant of the Regiment, remained at Horse Neck until the time for which he was drafted head captain when he was discharged and returned home after an absence of 5 weeks. That he living at Farmington aforesaid on or about the 1st September 1779 as a substitute for Jesse Allrose, went to Norwalk in the State of Connecticut and there joined a Battalion of Connecticut State Militia under command Major Norton in Captain Hotchkiss, Lieutenant Hamilton and Ensign Nathaniel Lewis Company. Went as a Substitute for five months, remained with the troops at Norwalk until about the 1st November 1779 when his time of service expired and he was discharged and returned home after an absence of two months. That he living at Farmington aforesaid about 25 July 1780 as a Substitute for John Pastor for two months went to Horseneck in the State of Connecticut to fight the tories and refugees in Captain Samuel Grangers (Lieutenant forgot) Ensign Bissell, Company of Connecticut State troops in Colonel Wells (Liet Colonel & Major forgot) Regiment. He remained at Horseneck until about 25 September 1780 when the term of his service expired and he was discharged and returned home after an absence of about two months. That he living in Farmington aforesaid about 10th February 1781 went as a Substitute for two months for David Frost to Horseneck in the State of Connecticut, joined Captain (thinks John) Churchill, (Lieutenant forgot) and Ensign Johnathan Morgans Company and Colonel John Meads Regiment of Connecticut under State Militia. Thinks there was no Lieutenant Major or Colonel for when the Colonel was gone. Captain Churchill commanded the Regiment, remained at Horseneck with the troops until about 10th April 1781 when his term of service expired and he was discharged and returned home after an absence of two months. That he living in Farmington aforesaid about the 1st of September 1781 was drafted for 3 weeks to serve in the Connecticut State Militia, that the company in which he served mustered at Southington in the State of Connecticut, and under command of Captain Westford, Lieutenant Heacock and Ensign Jospeh Bench, marched to New Haven and then joined a Regiment (Colonel, Lt. Colonel and Major forgot). He remained with the troops at New Haven until the latter part of September 1781 when the term of his enlistment expired and he was discharged and went home after an absence of about three weeks. That he living at Farmington aforesaid on the 25 December 1781, went as a Substitute for

other officers of that Company were Lieut Gibbs and Ensign Jesse Woodruff. We did not join any Regt and I do not know to what Regt we were attached. We were stationed all the time at a part of Norwalk then called Middlesex. We were the only company there and kept guard. I remember that Norwalk was at that time in ruins from the fire. In 1780 in the month of April I enlisted for nine months into Capt Peter Curtis' Company (of Farmington) in Col Beralkel Beebe's Regt Connecticut State troops. Abner Wilson of Harwinton was Lieut, and Lewis of Southington was Ensign of said company. Major Shipman and Adjutant Bull were officers in Col Beebe's Regt Our company was formed in Southington Ct, and from that place we marched through New Haven and Fairfield to Horseneck where our Regt was formed and stationed Col. Wells Regt was also stationed there at that time, the Regts lay separate but near each other. I was there during the whole period of my enlistment. We were employed in keeping guard, and were sent out occasionally in small scouting parties, we had several slight skirmishes, but no general action. Our Regt was sent for by Col Arnold to march to West Point. We marched as far as the corner of Bedford where we heard of Major Andre's Capture, and we returned. I remember that Capt Burnell's Company was in our Regt I had no written discharge from the service have no documentary evidence of my service but sent herewith the affidavits of John Trisbie, John Colt and Ebenezer Miller to Substantiate my own statement I am known to the Rev George E Pierce, William Abernathy and others in said Harwinton who can testify to my character for veracity and to their belief of my services &c.
