Washington Apr 3 1832 To the Hon [Honorable] Chairman of the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions Sir. I yesterday offered a resolution in ^the^ House, instructing (word crossed out) the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions to enquire into the expediency of restoring the names of John Fox, Jacob Fleisher, Michael Spatz and Adam Gramling to the pension roll. I take the liberty of handing you some papers relating to the three first mentioned cases and of submitting a few remarks. The petitions handed me from Fox & Fleisher only, but by referring to them and the annexed depositions, it will immediately be perceived that the cases stand on the same footing & are exactly similar. Spatz was on the Pension List of 1818 as well as Fox & Fleisher. I have known these three men personally about 25 years. They are admitted by all who know them, to be honest & worthy men, of the strictest veracity, whose assertion would be admitted without an oath. It is a matter of notoriety among the old people of the place where they reside that their statements as to services & sufferings are correct. Fox and Fleisher are in very reduced circumstances, poverty stricken, as well as aged & infirm. The latter particularly has been contracted in his limbs by rheumatism & confined to his bed & room for many years, in consequence, it is supposed, of the hardships he induced on the Jersey Prison ship. He is maintained by poor relatives. Spatz has a house and lot which may be worth about $500 in which he resides. He gets along with great difficulty, principally thro' the assistance of his wife, who is such by a second marriage

deponent a written discharge which he has long since lost In 1782 deponent states that he was out as a volunteer under Colonel Crawford [in crossed out] against the indians at Sandusky where Crawford was defeated on this tour he was out six weeks. Deponent states that he has a written record of his age, that he was born in Bartley County Virginia in March 1762 at the time he first entered the service of his county he lived in Fayett [Fayette] County Pennsylvania but served in Washington County as before stated - he never received but one written discharge which as stated has long been lost. deponent knew Captains Jack, Stoakley, and Springer, Colonels Lauherty and Byard, and General Broadhead there is no clergyman living in the neighborhood of deponent - he is well known to William Boyle Martin Bishop and others residents of Brown County by whom he can as he believes prove a good character for truth and veracity and that he is believed and reputed in his neighborhood to have been a soldier of the revolution - Deponent has procured the deposition of Philip Smith and Agnes Smith residents of Wayne [township crossed out] County Ohio by whom he can prove part of his services which depositions accompany this declaration. he knows of no other living witnesses by whom he can prove his services, he has lived at his present residence in Brown County Ohio for the space of twenty eight years previous to which period he lived in Kentucky Deponent has never received a pension he hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present and declares that his name is not on the pension

for the dysentary with which I and almost all were affected with the same disease labored under had reduced our so low that I was unable to perform any duty. The physician told us that as he had no medicine, and being poor & scanty means to supply our wants that if any of us chose & felt ourselves able we might go home and myself and two other men determined to try and reach our homes. In about two weeks after Genl Green left Ramsay Mills we set out on our journey home and after quite suffering and distress without money to buy our food, having to pass through a small part of the counties inhabited by Torries in which we had to hide ourselves in the day & travel by night, I arrived at home on the sixteenth day from my discharge as aforesaid. I am unable to state the day of my arrival at home or discharge from the hospital but I know very well that I was sixty three days laboring under my disease aforesaid, and that when I arrived at home, a field of Rye & had sowed had gotten into the "Boot" as farmers called it. In a week or two, by proper application and medicine I was relieved from my disease & soon gained my usual health and strength. Of course received no written discharge when I had have to go home. I am not apprised that there is a person living who can prove this service, but there are many men serving & now resident of the same county with myself, who were in this

I Daniel Gale of Gilmanton in the County of Strafford and State of New Hampshire depose and say that I enlisted into the service of the United States in the Revolutionary War in the month of April 1775 and continued in said service untill the last of January 1776, then enlisted into said service in the month of July 1777, for the term of two months in the Company of Capt. Chase Taylor and the Regiment commanded by Col. Stark and went in the Battle at Bennington in August 1777, and was wounded in the Battle in my left leg by a cleft of wood driven against me by a cannon shot from the enemy pafsing through a hedge from near me in the time of Battle. I continued home for some time not so but that I could walk about but was not put on duty, but have ever since by times been afflicted with swelling and great sorenefs to a great degree which has caused me to have considerable medical aid--And further Testify that about two weeks after the aforesaid Battle (I being a blacksmith by Trade) was put into a shop to Shoe horses for the troops and while in the act of Shoeing a fractious horse was broken in the lower region of the intestines which caused great pain and distrefs and so continues by times causing me to wear a trufs--And further say that I served the time I enlisted for. And that my employment for a livelihood has been that of a blacksmith as to my health other then the wounds aforesaid has been tolerably good, my places of residence since leaving said service has been in Sanbornton untill about fifteen years since I moved to Gilmanton and lived there about seven years, then moved to Northfield

Declaration in order to obtain a pension. State of New York County of Clinton [illegible] On this third day of March 1845 before the subscriber First Judge of the County Courts of said County personnally appeared Elizabeth Howard a resident of [illegible] in said county aged seventy six years, who being first duly sworn according to law doth on her oath make the following declaration in order to obtain a pension under the laws of the United States, that she is the widow of Stephen Howard who was a private in the first Maryland Continental Regiment, and served therein as she is informed and believes for more than three years. She has heard him say that he was enlisted at Leonard Maryland in Sept 1776 into Col Smallwood's first Maryland Regt. for three years or during the war, and that he served in that Company or Regiment four years and one month, and while in such service, and engaged in the Battle of Camden, he was wounded and taken a prisoner by the enemy, and carried to Charleston South Carolina, and put on board a British Prison Ship, where he remained until March 1781 seven months and a half, when he was taken to Kingston in the West Indies, and remained there about three years, During said time, [illegible] on some day of June in the year seventeen hundred and eighty four at the place aforesaid she then said Elizabeth was married to the said Stephen Howard by a Bishop whose name she does not recollect. He gave her a certificate of Marriage which she kept until the month of October 1833 when it was burnt, and destroyed by fire, together with her dwelling house at [illegible] aforesaid She also had a record of her said marriage in her family bible which was likewise burnt at the time and place aforesaid. Her maiden name was Elizabeth Roy. In the year 1786 her said husband effected his escape from the British and came into the United States where he resided up to the period of his death. She further declares that her said husband was a prisoner under the act of March 18, 1818 at $96 per annum and placed on the roll of the Vermont agency in 1819 and afterwards transferred to the New York agency. Hewent on a visit from his residence in [illegible] to [illegible] Lower Canada and died there at the house of his son, on the sixth day of March 1843. Leaving the said Elizabeth Howard a widow and she still remains a widow and unmarried. She further declares that she has no record of her husbands

1879 [upper right corner] In the Year 1775, Congress ordered many Regiments of Soldiers to be raised for the defense ^(&) the liberty of the American (then) Colonies) to continue in service for one year. New Jersey was ordered to raise four of them ^(the first) to be commanded by Mathias Ogdon the 2nd by Wm Maxwell the 3rd by Colo Dayton & the fourth by Colo Morton. my father Isreal Shreve was Colo Maxwells Lieutenant Colo:, My father took me into the service with him when I was but about fourteen Years Old. In July 177[illegiable] I was appointed an Ensign by General Orders, previous to that time I returned home to go to School. Shortly after the Year Service had expired I was reappointed and received recruiting orders from Wm Livingston Govenor of New Jersey, which is with ^(several of) My Commissions. the 4th Regiment was reduced (I think) in 1777. when Colo: Morton retired on half pay. Shortly after the revolt of the Pennsylvania and New Jersey lines revolted. (I believe it was in the early part of the Year 1781.) the 3rd regiment was reduced & the Officers & the privates in both Instances distributed among the other Regiments, at the reduction of the 3rd Regt. my father (being a very corpulant Man) retired on half pay. I at the time got a furlou for a few months and returned home with him. I wrote to the commanding Officer of the Regiment Informing that I had a wish to leave the service, but if they wished me to return to the Regiment I should wait for his orders. - and I never knew how I was returned whither as resigned or on half pay, but expect I was returned as resigned, as I received certificates for the average of pay. - and never got a certificate for five Years full pay which was allowed to all those who retired on half pay. or remained to the end of the War. - So I remained from November 1775 until (I think) until March 1780. Being five Years and a half. Colo Maxwell was appointed Brigadier General after the Year Service had ended & my father was appointed Colo: of the 2nd Regiment which was then raised for during the War. I am at this time very infirm, probably in part [illegible] opened [?] by my suffering and hardships while I commanded in the service - I include with this statement my recruiting warrant and those of my commissions. which I wish may be

State of Ohio Washington County On this 8th day of May in the year of our Lord 1818 before me the subscriber, one of the Associate Judges for the County of Washington in said State, personally appeared Godfrey Shreve, aged sixty years a resident in the township of Fleming, County and State aforesaid who being by me solemnly affirmed doth on his aid affirmation make the following declaration, in order to obtain the provision made by the late Act of Congress entitle "An Act to provide for certain persons engaged in the land and naval service of the United State in the revolutionary war" that he the said Godfrey Shreve, engaged as a Minuteman (then do called) on the nineteenth day of April AD 1775 in Rochester, Plymouth County, Massachusetts and in said Rochester on the first day of May 1775 he enlisted into Captain Clapp's company in Col. Cotton's regiment of infantry of the troops of Massachusetts, in which service he continued until the time for which he enlisted expired - that he then enlisted again in Roxbury, in said Massachusetts, for the term of one year into Captain Hamlin's company in Col. Barley's regiment in the troops of Massachusetts, which term he served out, that he then enlisted again at Trenton in New Jersey, into captain Pope's company in the third regiment in the Massachusetts line, commanded by Col. William Shepard, on the first day of January AD 1777 for during the war, in which Corps he continued until the end of the war and was discharged by Col. Henry Jackson, at Newburg, State of New York - his discharge he sent, last winter to the City of Washington, by Col. Levi barber who informs him, that it is now on the files of the House of Representative of the United States - that he was in a Battle at the heights of Hasslin on York Island in Seventy Six - again he was in the Battle of White Plains in the State of New York in the same year 1776-in the battle of Trenton in New Jersey 26th December, same year-that on the 3rd day of January 1777 he was again in the battle of Princetown, New Jersey-he was again at a battle of Burness Heights in the State of New York on the fifteenth of September 1777-and again on the seventh of October of the same year at Stillwater, in said state shortly before the surrender of General Burgoynes Army-again at New Rochelle in said State, on the 9th day of August 1779-again at Kingsbridge in said state on 1781-again at the Siege of Yorktown in Virginia where General Earl Cornwallace surrendered the British Army-that his in in reduced circumstances

State of Pennsylvania County of Northumberland SS. On this 21st-- day of August,-- eighteen hundred and thirty two, personally appeared in open Court before the Honorable Seth Chapman Esq President, and Jacob Gearhart and Henry Shaffer Esqs. Associate Judges of the Court of Common Pleas of the County of Northumberland, John Shipman, a resident of Augusta township in the County of Northumberland, and State of Pennsylvania aged upwards of seventy two years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth, on his oath, make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress, passed June 7. 1832 That he enlisted in the army of the United States, in the State of New Jersey, in the year seventeen hundred and seventy eight, in the company commanded by Capt. Paul Shipman, and served in the Regiment commanded by Col. William Bond. That he enlisted at Sussex County in the State of New Jersey aforesaid, for the term of nine months; and immediately, or very soon after, the Company to which he was attached, marched to Wyoming, in the County of Luzerne, Pennsylvania, from thence to Tioga Point, Chemung and Niagara, and after during the indians to Niagara, returned to Wyoming, suffering severely from want of provisions, and hardships endured. That from Wyoming deponent returned to Jersey continuing in the service of the United States, until the expiration of the time for which he enlisted, and received a discharge from Col. Wm. Bond, which was destroyed by fire on the 25th day of March AD 1786, a thereabouts- Deponent further states, that he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers and served as herein stated, viz. two months in the militia in the company commanded by Captain Winters, at South Amboy, and that he served two months in the same company at Perth Amboy, that he was there pressed to Elizabeth Town, and remained there at intervals, for three months. Thomas Hartley was then Colonel of the Regiment to which deponent was attached. Deponent was acquainted with Col. Hartley, Gene Maxwell and General Sullivan. Deponent further states, that he was 3 month at the

No.1 State of Georgia Madison County} ss Before me The subscriber a Justice of the Peace in and for said County duly authorized by law the administer oaths, Personally Came Susannah Shields and being duly sworn declares. That she is The widow of Littleberry Shields who was a private in the revolutionary army in Colonel Lee's [illegible] and served as she believes both on foot and horse, from Halifax or Pittsylvania County, Virginia. That his Christian name was Littleberry- but that in the family and among the neighbours he was known and often called Berry, that the father of said Littleberry, at all times, uniformly called him Berry, and by no other name. That many persons wrote it and considered it a double name as Little Berry that said Berry Shields was not able to write but made his mark and responded to or recognized the name written in either way that she was married to said Berry Shields in the month of December 1787 in Pittsylvania County Virginia, one Lazarus Dotson a minister of the Gospel, and that her name before her said marriage was Susannah Rogers, that she has no record of said marriage, nor record of Births of children, of deaths, or any other thing whatever by which the date of her said marriage is shown that her husband the said Berry Shields died in the county of Madison in the state of Georgia on the 17th day of December 1827 - and that she has remained a widower ever since his death. his x mark Susannah Shields Sworn to and subscribed this 19th day of November 1851} before me Dudley. J. Chandler J.P. and I do

for some time they were marched into Orangeburg for the purpose of attacking the British under Rawdon. Gen. Sumpter Commanded the militia. The British would not give battle & they then marched on down the Country to Biggan Church within 32 or 33 miles of Charleston. The British were encamped there & Deponent acted as a guard & guarded prisoners 12 or 13 which were taken by Col. Hampton. The British burned the Church & retreated to Charleston. Deponent’s regiment was then marched to Murray’s Ferry in Santee where about fifty more prisoners were brought in & Deponent assisted to guard them. They were marched to Sumpters plantation in Sumpter District. The Regiment then dispersed. The whole of this tour Deponent thinks was about three Months. 2nd The next service was in the same years at Orangeburg which Deponent performed as a drafted militia man. This was in Col. Tho. Taylor’s Regiment & Deponent was commanded by Lt. Brown. This service was about three months. 3rd In the following year Deponent was again drafted & performed duty as a soldier three months at the Four Holes in Orangeburg, under a Captain Pope in Col. Taylor’s regiment. The Deponent performed duty in all at least nine months. Since short tour performed times of service not particularly recollected.

I Ebenezer Elmer of the County of Cumberland in the State of New Jersey, do hereby certify that I was well acquainted with Almerin Brooks who has applied to Government for a renewal of his pensionary warrant, under a late supplement to the act of Congress "to provide for certain persons engaged in the Land & Naval service of the United States in the revolutionary war", and was a witness to many of the hardships & sufferings which he endured from the beginning to the end of that eventful period:- That I have lived near to, & known him ever since, and that he has been a cripple & infirm incapable of any efficient labour, for about twenty years past. - And further, that for several years he has been in such a destitute situation that he & his family must have been without the conveniences of life had they not recieved the beneficent assistance of others, particularly from the Society of the Cincinnati of New Jersey which has been frequently afforded trust therefore that he is a proper object for the notice of the Government s/ Eben Eller June 24, 1823.

H of R Dev 23. 1833 [House of Representatives] Sir Inclosed I send you a letter from W. F. Leak Esqr of Rockingham N.C. in relation to the application of Edwin Ingram for a Pension with some remarks of my own on the last page of his letter This letter is directed to me but I have thought proper to submit it to you I also enclose the papers of Thomas P. Williams an applicant for a Pension with a letter from Francis T. Leak a highly respectable man on the subject I am and have been almost from infancy well acquainted with this applicant Thomas P Williams and know him to be entitled to full credit as to the facts contained in his Declaration He is generally reputed to have been a true whig and an active Soldier in the Revolutionary service From a long course of distress and affliction it is believed his mind has been somewhat impaired but sufficiently strong to retain principal facts Please inform me of the results of these applications Respectfully [signed] Edmund Deberg

early part of the year 1780. I served one tour as a substitute, in the place of my father for three months, under the command of Captain John Cleveland called into service by the competent authority of the United States, which services was performed as military and as follows in Wilkes and Rowan Counties North Carolina and in the regiment commanded by Colonel Isaac during which time marches through South Carolina perhaps it was in the months of July or August and did suffer great distress with my fellow soldier for the want of food and shortly after the army or served at Clearmount before the battle of that place known as Gates' defeat, which I was [word ineligible] was transferred from the Infantry to the Calvary commanded by Colonel Armand after this tour of service was cut I went home to Wilkes County North Carolina and entered the military service of the United States as a volunteer for three months under the command of Captain Wilson and Major Gordon which was in the year 1781 I was in the Battle of Eutaw commanded of that place Colonel Malmedey, in this hard fought battle I saw the brave Colonel Washington when he made the bold charge upon the British line and was made a president during the same action I also saw the brave intrepid Colonel Lee make three charges upon the British and at the last charge it was believed that he brought out upwards of three hundred presences Shortly after General Green withdrew the infantry from the galling fire, from the brick building myself and four or five other soldiers was sent out as spies to view the selection of the British Army this tour service was performed in Wilkes and Rowan Counties North Carolina

Commonwealth of Massachusetts Bristol County On this fourth day of March in the year of our Lord on thousand eight hundred and thirty four, personally appeared in open court, before the Honorable Judge of the Court of Probate [?] now sitting at [Taunton?] in and for said County of Bristol, Benjamin Carpenter of Seekonk in the County aforesaid agied Eighty six years, who being first duly sword accroding to [?], doth on his oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress passes June 7th 1832. That he was born in the town of Rehoboth in said County of Bristol and State of Masschusetts, on the Eighth day of April 1747. That there is a record of his birth in the Office of the Town Clerk of said Rehoboth, a copy of which is hereunto annexed. That, on the 20th day of April, 1775 he enlisted as a private in the Company commanded by Capt Phoneiel Bishop and on the same day he marched from said Rehoboth to Roxbury in the State of Massachusetts, and joined Col Thomas Carpenters Regiment in General Heaths brigade, and there served three weeks, until he was relieved by the arrival of other troops, that he was in no battle, and at the end of his service he received no written discharge, that no regular Officers were known to him while there, and that he knows of no person living by whom he can prove the above service. ; Also that, in the year AD 1776. he was residing in the Town of Western in the County of Worcester and State of Mass., that while residing there, on the first day of August AD 1776 he entered the Massachusetts State Service, as a substitute for John Comer, who was drafted as a private in the Company Commanded by Capt Thomas Jones of Hardwick, in the Regiment Commanded by Col Congress of Brookfield, that he marched from said Western, to North River in the State of New York, and there joined the Troops Commanded by General Washington, and there served untill the first or second day of October follwing making a term of service of two months, that he was stationed about five miles from White Plains at the time of the engagement with the British Troops at said White Plains that he was engaged in Guarding the shores to prevent the British Shipping from going up said North River; That he was in no

Declaration of Philip Carnes in order to Obtain the benefit of the act of Congress passed 7th June 1832 State of Tennessee McNairy County On this the Eighteenth day of November in the year of our Lord One thousand Eight hundred and thirty three personally appeared in Open Court before the Honorable Judge of Our Circuit Court now sitting Philip Carnes a resident of McNairy County and State of Tennessee aged Seventy Two years who being first duly sworn according to Law doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress passed June the 7th 1832. That he was Born in Rowan County State of North Carolina on the 24th day of December in the year of our Lord 1761 hear I continued to reside before the Revolutionary war until the year 1781 when he entered the service of the United States as a volunteer soldier for the Term of three months under Captain Peter Frost. Major Robert Gillespie when the said Volunteer Company was made up we marched to Salisbury where we joined Col Barenger's Regiment for the purpose of marching to the State of South Carolina but after we joined his Regiment my captain together with Maj Gillespie was ordered to remain in Salisbury which we did during the time I volunteered for he was stationed here for the purpose of Guarding some British prisoners which was sent there for safe keeping and to take care of the Magazine which was then located at that place. I remained here until my term of three months had expired when I was discharged having received a written discharge signed by my Captain but the same is now lost or destroyed. A few weeks after I was discharged at Salisbury I again entered the service of the United States as a volunteer soldier in the year 1781 the day & month not now recollected under Captain John Pope and in the mounted Infantry as soon as we got ready to march we went directly on in the direction of Wilmington when we intended to join the American Army but when we arrived within sixteen miles of that place we met some troops from Virginia as I understood, they informed us that the British and their shipping had left that neighborhood and that our services would not be required there. So we turned about and marched back to Salisbury in Rowan County there I was discharged I served in this tour six weeks and forty five days for these services I received a written discharge signed by Captain Pope but it is now lost or destroyed. In the fall of the year 1780 I again entered the services of the United States as a volunteer horseman in Rowan cty North Carolina under Captain Fredrick Smith after the company was organized we joined another company in the same county commanded by Captain Cool then both companies marched through Rowan Montgomery [next]

Forkville S.C. 24th of May 1841 Dear Sir Enclosed is the declaration of Elender Caldwell of York District former by of Fisher District S.C. which you will please examine and report to me as soon as convenient. I will send you the claim without the increase evidence which I have sent forth and will forward as soon as received. The old lady is in great distress from infirmity and poverty you will therefore send relief as soon as possible. Very respectfully yours A.S. Wallace J. L. Edwards Esquire Commissioner of Pensions

/Copy/ Know all men by these presents, that we James Blackwell and Thomas Banks both of Granville County in the Province of North Carolina are held and firmly bound unto our Sovereign Lord the King His heirs and Successors in the sum of fifty pounds Proclamation money, which payment well and truly to be made we bind ourselves and each of our heirs executors and administrators jointly and severally firmly by these presents sealed with our seals and dated this second day of April Anno. Dom. one thousand seven hundred and seventy two. The condition of the above obligation is such that whereas the above bound James Blackewell hath this day of the day of these presents obtained a license for a marriage to be celebrated between him and Temperance Pope. Now if it shall not hereafter appear that there is any lawful cause to obstruct the said marriage then this obligation to be void otherwise to remain in full force and virtue. Sign'd Seal'd and delivered in presence of Reuben Searcy James Blackwell (Initials of James Wiggins follow) Thos Banks (Initials of James Wiggins follow) North Carolina Granville County I James M Wiggins, Clerk of the Court of Pleas and Quarter Sessions for the County and State aforementioned, certify, that the foregoing is a full, true, and perfect transcript of the marriage bond of James Blackwell (except the date which is in plain and legible figures) arguably to the original on file in my office. In testimony whereof, i have hereunto Subscribed my name and affixed the Seal of my office at Oxford, the 5th day of November AD 1844 James M. Wiggins, CCC

William McMillan was born in May, 1756; the place of birth and name of his parents not stated. He enlisted in Harford County, Maryland, in December, 1775, and served as sergeant in Captain Thomas Ewing's and Daniel Bowie's companies, Colonel William Smallwood's Maryland regiment. He was taken prisoner at the battle of Long Island, put on a prison ship, carried to Halifax, Nova Scotia, where he made his escape in April, 1777, and after much suffering and many hardships finally reached Boston, having been in the "wilderness" ten weeks. He joined the "Boston Troops" and was in the battle of Monmouth, shortly after which he joined the Maryland troops and was appointed in the spring of 1779 lieutenant and served until the close of the war. William McMillan was allowed pension on his application executed January 26, 1828, at which time he was living in the Borough of Mercer, Mercer County, Pennsylvania. He died December 10, 1839. William McMillan married Nancy Anderson in the fall of 1821 in Mercer County, Pennsylvania. She was sixty-six years of age in 1845. In 1828, the soldier referred to his daughter, Margaret Patterson, aged forty-one years, and to her two children - O.H. Perry Patterson, thirteen years old, and Susanna Patterson, ten years old. In 1851, Mrs. Margaret Patterson was residing in Allegheny County, Pennsylvania, and was the only surviving child of the soldier. No further reference was made to children. Very truly yours A.D. HILLER Executive Assistant to the Administrator -3-

[handwritten letter] At the retreat from Ticonderoga he was in that [illegible] & ['at' crossed out] in Hubbardton Battle & in Bennington Battles, and in Still-Water Battle, & in the Battles of Beemus' heights and in the Battle as Saratoga, when he was one that assisted in taking Gen. Burgoine (Burgoyne) and his army he says that in some of the above named Battles the Balls Whistle around him, men fell on Eventide but he was spared to live & grapple with Poverty & Distress to a great age & now cannot get his Pention - he mentions some of the Officers which serve with him in the above Battles among which he says Gen. Gates. Gen. Benedict Arnold after ward then traitor Gen Lincoln, Maj. Morgan Maj Fay - Now Sir, If there is not any Prospect of his obtaining a pension, for his services in the regular Army, is there no prospect for him in the Militia? he says he served in the Militia 7 Mo. or More - and was in all the above named Battles - Please to reconsider his case & do what can consider be done for the Poor old Man & write me I send Directions what to do - Your Respectfully /s/James Cook Hon. Lewis Cass

State of Pennsylvania and County of Adams} On this 13 day of November 1846 Personally appeared before the subscribe one of the Judges of Common Pleas (crossed out from one to Pleas)N Bushey a Justice of the Peace in and for the County of Adams and State aforesaid Polly Gross in behalf of her (crossed out) John Gross a soldier in the Revolutionary war Polly Gross who being first sworn according to law doth on her oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the provision made by the act of Congress June 7th 1832. My father has lost his mind and become insain By age and bodily infirmity many years ago when his mind was yet sound he told me his age he was ninety two years of age last August 1846. He also told me that he served along time in the Revolutionary war he also told me he served three tures in the war. The first ture he served was compeled to take his fathers wagon and horse and headed for the army a ture of of six months during the time of the flying camp. He told me that he was drafted twice after that time and served out that time of six months Each time he also told me the names of the officers that he served under but for my life I cannot think of there names But I remember that he sed that he was in the Battle of Trenton town and the Battle of Brandywine and that he crossed the Delaware on the ice and that he indured many hardships during his service in the war and that he served at least on year and a half in the Revolutionary war and for his services I claim a Pension from the United States for him the reason that he did not call on the Secretary of war sooner is that John Gross was not fit to do any Business for the last fifteen years and had no knowledge that the war intideled to a Pension his nabours a few years ago got him a Pension from the Sate of Pennsylvania [illegible] and with that sade I could still support him on till he becomes intirely helpless and not only that had no way to attent and see about his Pension for (crossed out illegible) us on till the present time Polly Gross Sworn and subscribed November the 23rd 1846 Before N. Bushey I certify that I was called after this day to Court I examined John (crossed out) into the situation of John Gross in where behalf a Pension is about to be applied for, and that I was unable to attend by reason of [illegible]- I gave this certificate at the agent of the gent of said Gross in my private capacity alone--and further that I am well acquainted with N. Hamburgh ( State S.C.)} Feb 20 Day 1838- } From Hamburgh S.C.} To the honorable gentlemen of the War Department City of Washington Gentlemen I received your certification yesterday morning signed 9th and when I saw the pitiful sum your Honors assigned in order for to compensate you address it really struck me with horror for to think for the suffering hardships I had for to endure of the first start of the Revolution in South Carolina and Georgia & thirty one dollars and seven cents is all your consciences have allowed me and the trouble and expense of my attaining it From Charleston will in about sink it gentlemen I am a Man uncommon for these times I was bred and born in Culpepper County State of Virginia most strictly brought up to truth, honor & honesty and in sobriety have conducted myself by the same rule ever since and all who is acquainted with me gives me the name of an industrious worthy member of society witness Judge Richard .. ( illegible ) with twenty seven other gentlemen as any to be found in Edgefield D.. gentlemen I was out on a mission from 1814 to this day and never heard of the provisions made in favor of the Old Revolutionaries until 3 or 4 years ago being out as far far as the Mississippi River from above Memphis down or near Ponchetrain and from the sea coast over East & West Tennessee the Western District Cherokee, Chickasaw, Choctaw and Creek Nations of Indians being only returned into Georgia and South Carolina and in that route five times robbed purse and money took out of my pocket by the Murdletes (?) had for to quit my pursuit and have returned to South Carolina have had eighteen months in order to hunt up vouchers for to prove my revolutionary services and all dead and gone but Captain Ambrose Hudgcings and Mr. Ambrose Rippley they were sworn to all the powers of duty that they know of and myself also confirmed it 2 or three times and signed by this Judge Johnston at Edgefield Court House on 9 Day of June 1837 forward it on to your Honors by Esqr. Winbush and gentlemen I feel inclined for to detail as near or possible in brief of my present situation at the present time after I render up to your Honors the services I have aimed at for to advance & dignify the ( U. S. ) for no man could ever be possessed with a warmer zeal for to elevate the welfare and prosperity of the ( U.S. ) than I have been possessed of evidence we gained our independency and none more I acted with our form of government of the ( U.S. ) than I have been until here of late I have been very doubtful our Constitution was likely to be dead instead of being graced by Amendment but I still hope for the best I could have been possessed of many letters such as Honor & .. ( illegible ) as Justices Member to States legislator Also a Member of Congress but I did not conceive myself possessed of

I America Hamlin, a resident citizen of the United States of America in the town of Waterford in the County of Oxford and State of Massachusetts, testify and say, that in the year of our Lord seventeen hundred and seventy nine forth of nine months, as a private soldier, on the eighth day of August I enlisted into the army of the United States of America on the continental establishment in the company commanded by Captain Isaac Pope in the fourth Massachusetts Regiment, commanded by Colonel William Shepherd in General Glover's Brigade, which term of time I fully and faithfully served and received from Colonel Shepherd an honourable discharge, since lost by accident. In the year seventeen hundred and eighty on the sixteenth day of June I again enlisted as a private soldier into the army of the United States on the continental establishment, for the term of six months, in the company commanded by Captain Isaac Pope, in the Regiment and Brigade aforesaid, during which time I continued to serve as aforesaid and at the end thereof I received from George Webb Capt. Comma t my discharge which is hereunto annexed. I Samuel Davis of Standish in the County of Cumberland and State of Maine being now in the seventy seventh year of my age, do testify depose and say, that in the year seventeen hundred and eighty one, I was a Soldier in the service of the United States and at that time I was stationed at, and in the Neighborhood of West Point in the State New York. I at that time became acquainted with one Africa Hamlin who was, when I first became acquainted with him a sergeant Major in the service of the United States, and that in the same year he the said Hamlin was promoted to the office of Ensign in the Company commanded by Captain Isaac Pope and the fourth Massachusetts Regiment, the same Company to which I belonged) and that he the said Hamlin remained an officer in said Company untill I was discharged from the service in December in the year seventeen hundred and eighty three Samuel Davis Cumberland Ss On the twelfth day of October in the year of our Lord one thousand eight him ed and thirty eight the aforesaid, deponent was examined and cautioned and sworn agreeably to Law to the deposition aforesaid by him subscribed, taken at the request of Susanna Hamlin and to by her need for the purpose

Matthew Patton was allowed pension on his application executed January 8, 1834, at which time he resided in Christian County, Kentucky; he was referred to then as Matthew Patton, Senior. He had resided in that neighborhood about twenty years. The soldier made no reference to wife or children. In order to obtain the date of last payment of pension, name of person paid and, possibly, the date of death of this pensioner, you should apply to The Comptroller General, General Accounting Office, Records Division, this city, and furnish the following: Matthew Patton, Certificate #26880, issued June 24, 1833, Rate $25.60 per annum, Commenced March 4, 1831, Act of June 7, 1832, Kentucky Agency. JOHN WHITAKER — W. 9001. The data which follow are found in pension claim, W. 9001, based upon service of John Whitaker in the Revolutionary War: John Whitaker (as he signed his name) was born May 21, 1753 in Harford County, Maryland, and resided about twenty miles from Baltimore, in said Harford County, during the Revolutionary War. The names of his parents are not shown. In 1776, John Whitaker belonged to Captain Aquilla Hall’s company, Colonel John Rodgers’ regiment of Maryland militia, was called out in the fall of that year and served three weeks on an alarm at Baltimore. He enlisted early in June 1777, served as sergeant in Captain Francis Holland’s company, Colonel John Rodgers’ Maryland regiment and returned home about December. He enlisted “soon after the harvest” in the next year and served three months as sergeant in Captain Samuel Griffith’s company, Colonel Josiah Hall’s Maryland regiment. John Whitaker resided in Harford County, Maryland, until about 1784, then moved to York County, Pennsylvania, and remained until about 1789, then moved to Washington County, Maryland, and resided until about forty years of age, then moved to Bourbon County, Kentucky, near Paris, and moved from there to Harrison County, Kentucky. He was allowed pension on his application executed September 17, 1832, at which time he resided in Harrison County, Kentucky; he had resided there then “upwards of twenty years”. In 1832, he was a Minister.

State of Indiana Knox County Before the undersigned an Associate Judge to the County of Knox and State of Indiana on this 9th day of May Eighteen Hundred Thirty Four personally came John Parker long and personally known a citizen of said county who having duly sworn according to law, commeth and vaill that he was born in the year 1767 in the State of Pennsylvania and resided there untill he was 21 years of age when he emigrated to Kentucky. That in the year 1791 he joined Capt Prestly Grays company of drafted militia men, then collected men the Valley of the Ohio and with said company under the command of Colonel Oldham joined the Army under General St Clair near Port Hannittor, that near Port Recovery on the 4th day of November 1791 the army was attacked and defeated by the hatted Indians in an engagement which is commonly termed "St Clair's defeat", that which in the arduous discharge of his duty as a soldier and acting at that time as a Sergeant he was severely wounded by a musket or rifle bullet through the lite thigh, while opposing the enemy as the accompaning certificate of two redjuet abled physicians, and the Affidavats of Capt Thomas opened then an Ensign in Capt Gray's company and that of Thomas Piety then a private soldier in the same company with them who was seen both present at the said defeat. that he staid at Port Jefferson has dags suffering much from the pain of his wound he was then removed on a horse by Ensign Thomas to Cincinatti where he was verbally discharged, that he never got a written discharge, and that he served the whole term in which he was drafted, that he huvious to his residence in Indiana that he lived in Nelson County Kentucky but for the last nineteen years

I William Snow of Lawfull age do depose Testify and Declare, That I was a Soldier in the late Revolutionary war, and was under the Command of Capt Frederic Pope in Col Sargents Regiment, Benjamin Croswell Enlisted into our Company in March Seventeen Hundred Seventy six and Served in said Company the year out, Ending January One thousand seven - hundred Seventy Seven; I also Certify that he Served Honorably and faithfully During Said Period. Easton March 23rd, 1819 - William Snow I Samuel Bisbee Hiram Manley of Lawfull age do Certify and Declare that I belonged to the same Company with Mr. William Snow and the Said, Benjamin Croswell, and that the above declaration of William Snow is True and Correct. claim a pension -- The names of persons in my present neighborhood and who can testify to my character for veracity and their belief of my services in the Revolution are John Wells, John Roberts Waterman Eells Elisha Arnold Silas Arnold Mathew Rick, Elisha Button Benjamin Ketchum Ebe Bromley & others. I am very much afflicted with Rheumatism & have had it for two years, and am unable to get about without great pain & difficulty. I have been unable to attend Court at Plattsburg a distance of ten miles from my residence since the act of June 7, 1832 & I am still unable to attend Court by reason of bodily infirmity & the debility of my old frame I am wholly unable to labor. I hereby relinquish every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present and declare that my name is not on the Pension Roll of the agency of any State [I have no documentary evidence and know of no person whose testimony I can procure who can testify to my service]- Josiah Terry Sworn and subscribed to before me this 26th day of December 1833, & I certify that Deponant is a credible person, & that he is unable to attend Court by reason of bodily infirmity being severely afflicted with Rheumatism which causes him much pain & dificulty & getting about & also declare my opinion after investigation of the matter and after putting the interrogatories prescribed by the war Department that the above named applicant was a Revolutionary Soldier and served as he states. Wm F. Haile Judge of Clinton Com Pleas.

and deponent further says that Philip Gilman late of Sparta aforesaid deceased the father of this deponent and the husband of said applicant had a scar in his chest just above the Pit of his stomach about as large as a dollar and also on his back by the side of his backbone which deponent has often seen. that said Philip was reputed to have received a wound at the Battle of Germantown in the Revolutionary war whilst he was fighting in the Continental Army - that said wound was made by a musket ball which went quite through his body and left the scars aforesaid. Rev. and 1812 Wars Section MCS/[illegible] am March 18, 1930. Hon. Richard P. Freeman House of Representatives Washington, D. C. My dear Mr. Freeman: In response to your request of March 15, 1930 for information desired by Mrs. Mary B. Bishop of Putname, Connecticut, I h ve the honor to advise you that from the papers in the Revolutionary War pension claim S. 36,539, it appears that Ebenezer Gilbert enlisted in Connecticut in 1776 and was in the battles of Long Island, Trenton and Princeton, but no further details of this service were given. He enlisted April 29, 1777 in Captain Wills Clift's Company in Golonel Samuel Wyllys' Connecticut Regiment, and was discharged June 8, 1783. He was allowed pension on his application executed May 13, 1818, at which time he was sixty-one years of age and was a residentof Brooklyn, Windham County, Connecticut. In 1820 he referred to his wife Ruth as being sixty-two years of age. There are no datea relative to children. Bery truly yours, EARL D. CHURCH Commissioner. Made no refernce to rank of soldier. He gave no rank in application ; is recorded as sgt cpl 7 [illegible] in Comm. [illegible] in Rev. Made no reference to Invalid pension as soldier did not refute it when he applied in 1818 & as we have no evidence on file in support of data taken from american state papers thought best to use only that found in papers in file.

[not legible] March 20, 1829 Dear Sir, I submit this case to your own sound discretion. The only difficulty I can see in the case at all, is the fact that he only served, including his detention as a prisoner of War, about 1 year & 9 months. He, I mean says that his company had gone into the southern states beyond his means of reaching them- that he went home after is escape from the British - that he got married and was never called on to serve any longer. He is very poor, perfectly so, and needs a support from some quarter as to his wife are part labor & have a [not legible]. t appears to me, that the few days he has to live and they are few indeed, might be only properly made happier by extending to him the provisions of the acts of congress, under said he claims. Submit his case as it is to your sound discretion, hoping that some hope of mercy may be [not legible] with justice, in this case of distress and want. If any difficulty should be felt by you about granting this pension, I would thank you Sir to state it to Gen. Jackson, himself, who will fee for a soldiers suffering, tho' I suppose not more than yourself. The applicant is extremely ignorant, and it was owing to that circumstance, I believe that he did not join some other corps, after his escape from the British, as his own were some off out of his way. Respectfully Yours Caleb Atwater Hon J. H. Eaton Sec'y of War

I John Ness of Littleton in the County of Grafton State of New Hampshire of the age of seventy seven on the 18th day of May A.D. 1837 depose & say that I was present at the marriage of Susanna Bemis with her late husband Henry Bemis late of said Littleton deceased -- said Susana is my sister. I was a boy at the time of said marriage & well remember it was before the commencement of the war of the revolution -- the marriage ceremony was performed by the Rev Mr Parker whose Christian name I do not remember, but who was the Christian minister in the town where my father then resided, said town being called Hubbard'stown or more commonly honored Hoveystown in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts I have ever since except one year, lived near my said sister -- she dine with her husband, the said Henry Bemis as his wife until his decease, which was in the year 1833. They reared a large family of children she has remained a widow ever since his decease, & is now a widow -- said Parker has been commonly reported to have died many years since -- State of New Hampshire Grafton County Ss Littleton July 17th 1837 Then & there the said John Ness personally appeared & made oath that the above deposition by him subscribed is true. Before me -- Edmund Carleton Jr Jus Peace. I, Edmund Carleton Jr aforesaid Justice of the Peace aforesaid do certify that I am well acquainted with John Ness where aforesaid the signer of the above deposition, having known him, & lived within about two miles of him, about seven years. He is a man of credibility, sustaining a perfectly

McConnelsville Morgan County Ohio Hon J H Eaton Dear Sir Enclosed I send you an application for a pension by Benj Beckwith They are the original papers from which the minutes were made up Professional callings have prevented me from forwarding them sooner & you will bear with me while I say that among the antiquated remnants of mortality whose most familiar inmates are distress & poverty I do not remember having seen one who possessed a spirit so untamed, & independent as this applicant Some ten years ago when his whole property would not amount to 100 dollars he applied for a pension but felt too independent to take the oath prescribed He is now unable to support himself & has only the alternative of appling for a pension to save himself from becoming a township charge His crippled daughter is a terrible object of pity The court have set his property full high & all who think the revolutionary veterans entitled to a claim upon the general fund believe that that of Benj Beckwith should be postponed for no mans I have 2 or 3 of these old monuments under my protection & I can not hear them tell of marching barefoot-sleeping blanketless & houseless in the winter - of paying 10 & 12 dollars in such pay as they received their wages in for a gill of whiskey on a day of battle & of paying 3000 [??30.00] dollars for a horse worth 25 without thinking they have severely strong claims upon us who reap the harvest in peace that they have sown in blood For my trouble I shall ask no hope for any other reward than the consciousness that I have helped them obtain the last remants of justice I remain Yours Respectfully James L Page May 15-1830

Minden La February 12th AD 1849 Dear Sir I write you in behalf of Benjamin Goodson of this Parish, an old revolutionary soldier who receives a pension, Mr. Goodson some two years since applied to the Pension office in Washington City to have his pension payable in New Orleans and he has not been able to ascertain what has been done. Mr. Goodson has received a letter from his agent in Mississippi stating that the fault was caused by the General Pensions office in Washington City but has not been able to ascertain the cause of the delay of receiving his pension— Mr. Goodson is actually in distress for want of means not having drawn his pension for two years or more— You will do him a great favour if you will examine the matter and ascertain the difficulty and arrange it so that he will receive his pension regular in the city of New Orleans. Mr. Goodson is very old and needy. You will please write to me on the subject Respectfully Geo W Peets N B You will have to win again in my opinion for Congress or we will be defeated in our District. Write me on this subject.

I was wounded in the hip, having received two balls in the right hip, which has greatly disabled me ever since, & from which I now suffer constantly great pain – & also a severe wound in the right shoulder in the same action. I fortunately was able to sit my Horse, & was aided in making my escape by my friend & brother soldier Joseph McAdams who resided in the State of Illinois, at the last account I had of him. The same evening after the above battle, another detachment of the American Army had an engagement with the enemy – the Americans being commanded by Gen’l. Butler & Colo. Mayben. I understood there were a good many killed & wounded on both sides – but the enemy made good their retreat with the Prisoners taken from Hillsboro’. I lay confined with my wound for near 6 months & immediately after, resumed active service, being engaged until the Close of the War. I have examined the [distress?] or scars of Peter Francisco which are said to be effects of wounds which he received during the revolutionary war of which fact I have no reason to doubt, they are numerous and the wounds must have been serious & extensive in their consequences [on] the limb on which most of the wounds were inflicted appears much debilitated and is affected with. [illegible malous] inflamation which in my opinion will in all probability, always deter Mr. Francisco from taking much exercise and using the necessary exertions toward the support & maintenance of his family notwithstanding the use of the curative affirmative means such as the roller [go go?] Mr. Francisco is said to be about sixty years old, his head is silvered over with age & his constitution appears much Shipwrecked & the vital sparks gradually exhausting itself & he must [illegible] long tread that road which has been trodden by the other of revolutionary heroes who are gone before him. Mr. Francisco often reminds me of the old adage Age & want. (I may say infirmity) are ill matched pair. He informs me that he is frequently confined fifteen or eighteen days to his house with an inability to raise the wounded limb & that is very painful to him I have been acquainted with Mr. Francisco for the last nine or ten years and believe him to be a very sober & temperate man. A man of uniform habits therefore no part of his indisposition is the affect of dissipation of any kind & I further believe him to be a fit subject for a pension during life & therefore recommend him to that Government in which he [illegible] acted so conspicuous apart. Jno. Spencer Cumberland county May 7th 1819

To the Senate & House of Representations of the United States The petition of the undersigned respectfully represents That your petitioner has been from age, blindness, & other fortunes reduced to great distress and poverty that he is a native of Pennsylvania, where he lived for several years, and served during part of the revolutionary War in the militia of that State. that he belonged to Capain Sheafers company in Col. Grubbs Battalion in Lancaster County and accompanied it, through all its in marches in New Jersey, and was at Paulus Hook at the time of the battle of Long Island. Your petitioner further states that he obtained an ensigns commission in 1777 in the fifth class & served he thinks under Colonel Elder in the company of Captain Holterbomb, and was at the skirmish at Chesnut Hill when Gen. Erwin was taken prisoner- Your petitioner understands that some provision has been made for the infirm & disabled officers & soldiers of the Pennsylvania Militia and is emboldened to make this appeal to the magnanimity and justice of the legislature of his native State. He encloses his commission and begs leave to refer your honorable body to the records of that period for the truth of what he has stated as there is no one where he now resides (Washington) who knew him then, or is acquainted with the circumstances which he has stated; your petitioner being old and almost blind and having no means to go to Pennsylvania to seek information or collect evidence-

State of Kentucky Christian County ⎬ On this third day of Sept personally appeared in open court before the justices of the Court of Christian County now sitting John Philips aged Ninety Eight years a resident of the County of Christian and state of Kentucky who being first duly sworn according to law doth, on his oath make the following declaration in order that he may obtain the benefit of an act of Congress passed June 7 1832. John Philips states that he was born May 7th 1734 in Cecil County Maryland & has the record of his age in his house. When young moved to Frederick County same State and from thence moved to Rowan County State of North Carolina - was there drafted by Col Frank Locke, Capt John Lopp (the year he does not recollect) & marched to the river Savannah & camped or stationed at Toobly white House who was a Presbyterian minister, thinks the distance marched was near two hundred miles during this service he was employed scouting up & down the river & had a slight squirmish with the British but the river was between and does not know that any injury was done, was out five months & two weeks on this trip. At a subsequent period he was drafted & taken by General Rutherford & Col Locke down to Salisbury to guard some prisoners & was in this service 3 months & 2 weeks. During the time the prisoners were exchanged and he was discharged - He never got any other discharge than the verbal declaration of his officer. During the first time he was in service he performed the office of Butcher when in camp & was promised a recommendation for 5 months labour(sic) but never received a cent

That he hath no trade or profession, therefore was under the necessity for several years past, of keeping a common school, which does not at present furnish the means of support and being far advanced in age and greatly afflicted with a Rupture occasioned by sever cold & hardships while in the service he is unable to support himself except by the pension allowed him, unless it were by resorting to public or private charity. The Rev Robert Andrews was appointed chaplain to the 2nd Virginia Regiment, commanded by Colo Gibron at an early period of the Revolutionary war, and was subsequently transferred to the first Regiment of State Artillery, commanded by Colo Mayhall, and continued to act as such until the year 1780 when the Regiment being broken up into detachments, for different Garrisons, and a portion of it sent to reinforce the southern army under General Greene the staff of the Regiment was declared to be supernumerary by the Legislature - By reference to the proceedings of the board of officers which sat at Richmond by order of the Execution of which Colo Marshall (the Commander of this regiment) was president it will be seen that they notice particularly the case of Dr. Pope surgeon & Mr Andrews Chaplain, both of whom contended that the resolution of the Legislature (which was to save expense) only reduced them to the State of supernumerary. The board did not determine, but referred the decision to the Executor: Very recently Dr Popes claim has been allowed ( by the late Secretary of the Treasury) and the heir of Mr Andrews hope for a similar result in their case, as it Is precisely analogous, both belonging to the same regiment & both by the resolution of the Legislature becoming supernumerary at the same time. The supernumerary officers were when the State was invaded by Phillips and Sinoto again called into service, and continued therein until the capture of Lord Cornwallis. Mr Andrews was in service at the siege of York, and received thanks in a general order for his patriotic services. These services were not performed in the Regiment of Artillery to which he had belonged, because it was not at the siege, having as before stated, been distributed at different places. Mr. Jeffersons letter to Baron Stueben filed herewith shows that the supernumerary officers were called into service when the state was invaded - Mr Andrews obeyed the call and according to the decision of the Court of Appeals was entitled to half pay for life - All which is respectfully submitted Wm Lambert Thos Green Attorneys for the Heir Washington 17 June 1833 Endorsed they allowed half pay as a Chaplain from the 19 October 1781 to the 1 January 1804 - W T Duane, Secy of the Treasury 17 Aug 1833 to be paid to the attorney of the Administrator

the service aforesaid for more than eight months and was discharged sometime in January 1776. I was born at Shrewsbury in Massachusetts on the second day of May A.D. 1745. where I suppose my age is on record. I lived in said Shrewsbury during the Revolutionary War and soon after the conclusion of the war, I removed to Spencer, in Massachusetts, when I have lived ever since and where I now live. I did not receive a written discharge when I left the service. Nicola County State of Kentucky This day personally appeared John Couhey before me a circuit judge for the state of Kentucky and made oath that the above named John Burns is in indigent circumstances and a cripple and unable to work for his living and so as this as this despondent believes the said Burns is about sixty-nine years of age and poor and needs the assistance of the covernment for his support and maintenance. State of Vermont Franklin County On this 21st day of February A D. 1851 personally appeared in open court before the Hon William Bridges Judge of the court of Probate for the district of Georgia in County Lucinda Benjamin aged Eighty two years a resident of Caldwell Maud Cancella Ecest. and after being duly sworn according to law doth on her oath make the following Declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress passed July 29, 1848. That she was formerly the widow of Elijah Lawrence. That the said Elijah Lawrence was a resident of Canaan Connecticut & entered the army of the Revolution from that town, as she believes. She does not remember the names of his officers, but understood that he entered when sixteen or seventeen years old under an engagement for three years. That he served until his discharge, & that he recived [received] an honorable one, but that it is now lost, but that it has been in the possession of declarant until within about one year. She states her sd husband often told despondent that he was taken prisoner & detained a captive for some time a part of the time, with the Indians, she often related the manor of his escape from massacre by the interposition of a British officer. That after the war was over [illegible] husband the said Elijah settled in Hinesburgh Vermont and married his first wife there, and his oldest children were born there, that subsequently he moved to Shefford Cascade East & his first wife died there. Declarant states that her maiden name was Lucinda Butterfield and that she was married to the said Elijah Lawrence on the day of November AD 1796 by Samuel Peckham a Just. of the Peace in Franklin Vermont. and that her late husband the said Elijah died on the 15th day of March AD 1809 aged forty six years. Declarant further states

had to attend muster on the call of the roll drew station & served the time out and was paid off and discharged by James Glen; In the month of February 1779 he entered on board the commissioned sloop Ranger carrying eight guns bound from Philadelphia to Cape Francois commanded by Captain John Hunn. The sloop carried provisions to the French authorities and brought back [ill] for the American Government. In this service, he continued five months when he was discharged, upon the return of the sloop in to the port of Philadelphia; On the 10th day of [August?], in the same year he shipped on board the ship Jay carrying 18 guns commanded by Captain Harmon Courter and sailed for St. Ustatia[St. Eustatius?] on the voyage had an engagement with a British 16 gun brig she made her escape from us, we gave chase, but could not overtake her, our ship had under convoy a fleet of Merchantmen, about ten days after the engagement, a British frigate have on sight said to carry 36 guns, our commander gave signal for the merchantmen to continue their course whilst he changed course to the north the frigate gave him chase and continued to chase until late at night, when we again changed our course to the port of our destination and saw her no more, we arrived safe at St Ustatia[St. Eustatius?] where we found the company had arrived before us, In this ship's service he continued three months when he has discharged, being afterwards cast away on the Spanish main. He shipped as a passenger on board the Dutch vessel bound to Carrizon, and was taken prisoner by the British and carried into Jamaica where he remained a prisoner two months, he made his escape together with four more from the British vessel by swimming. In the year 1783 being in the service of a merchantman off north [ill] on the coast of South Carolina was taken by two British privateers, was carried to St Augustine in East Florisa where he remained a prisoner three months and was discharged about time of general peace. York County} State of Pennsylvania} SS Personally appeared before the subscriber George Barnitz one of the judges of the Court of Common Pleas in and for the County of York and State of Pennsylvania. John Koons who upon his solemn oath taken according to law saith that he is a native of York County and will be sixty one years old on the 2nd day of January next, that he is well acquainted with Peter Krumbine, the foregoing applicant for a pension, and has known him personally and by observation for more than forty years. That the said Peter is a man of strict integrity of character, and of undoubted [illegible] that he is respected and believed in the neighborhood where he resides to have been a soldier of the Revolution, and that this despondent does ow and always has concurred in that belief. that he is acquainted with the Honorable John L. Hinkle, Esquire, Luther H. Skinner, Esquire and Benjamin Welsh whose affidavits accompany the foregoing declaration and application, and he knows them to be men of truth and integrity of character. That the Honorable John L. Hinkle who is as this deponent believes about fifty years old, was born in the neighborhood of Hanover, York County and has resided in or near Hanover to the present time. And has had every opportunity of being acquainted with Peter Krumbine. That Benjamin Welsh is a native of Hanover and is as this deponent believes was forty years old. That Luther H. Skinner is a magistrate in the Borough of Hanover of about the same age as Benjamin Welsh, but not a native of Hanover. And further, this deponent saith not. Sworn and subscribed this 2nd day of October 1832 before me, a judge of the Court of Common Pleas of York County, and I do certify that I am satisfied that the foregoing declaration and affidavits are true. Signature: George Barnitz York County} State of Pennsylvania} SS I, Richard Porter, Prothonotary of the Court of Common Pleas of York County, State of Pennsylvania, do hereby certify that George Barnitz, Esquire, before whom the foregoing affidavit of John Koons was taken is and was at the time of the taking of said deposition a judge of the Court of Common Pleas of York County. That his name to the foregoing certificate is in his own proper handwriting. And that full credit is and of right ought to be given to each and every each and every act of the said George Barnitz, judge of the Court of Common Pleas aforesaid. In witness whereof I have hereunto signed my name and caused the seal of said court and do hereunto affix this second day of October A. D. 1832. Signature: Richard Porter, Prothonotary

Commanded by Col Sumpter, This deponent saith he was ultimately acquainted with the said John Hamilton & was in the army together and done duty for three years or near in, That the said John Hamilton did do duty in the said Sixth Regr or in the first Regiment to which this deponent believes he was transferred_ And this deponent knows that he was a good faithful soldier & done his duty well And further that the said John Hamilton is a very poor man & needs the assistance of his Country for support. Thomas Farrar Sworn to 22. February Anno Domini 1820 Before me. Joseph Grisham Public Notary Pendleton J.C.V Ex. off J.W.O

Cherokee nation That during this last tour that he marched from the Station in Tennessee aforesaid first thro Burke County & then Rutherford County in North Carolina Thence into South Carolina on Poekelett [Pacolet] River where he joined Col [Daniel] Morgan where he was stationed awhile thence he marched to Rutherford County in North Carolina thence across the upper part of South Carolina to Georgia crossing the Savannah river at the cherokee ford into the upper part of Wilkes County in Georgia thence to Augusta where this despondent was engaged at the second siege of Augusta thence he the deponent marched back again to the upper part of Wilkes County in the State of Georgia where on the first of June 1781 this deponent was verbally & honorably discharged & no written discharges were given by Captain Joseph Nail being on his death-bed when discharged this deponent & there being no further call for the company was the reason why they were discharged before the expiration of said last tour and deponent saith that during all his [illegible] tour of [illegible] of some months And the said Austin Webb Senr. hereby, relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or an annuity except the present and he declares that his name is not on the pension roll of any agency in any State Sworn and Subscribed the day & year aforesaid Austin Webb his X mark And the said Court do hereby declare their opinion the above named applicant was a revolutionary soldier and served as he states Robt M Echols JIC Woodson P. State of New jersey Bergen county No2 Personally appeared before the subscriber a Justice of the Peace in and for said County Samuel Helms of the same place aged 72 years who being duly sworn saith that he is personally aquainted with Cornelius Terhune also of the same place who has applied for a pension under the Law of Congress of June 7th 1832who on his oath disposeth and saith to the knowledge of the said depondent the said Cornelius Terhune served under the following named officers in the War of the Revolution -despondent well Recollects of having served for one month under Capt Mouerd (illegible, may be Mauritius) Goetschius in the year 1777 stationed at the Liberty Pole & Closter doing guard duty-when the said Cornelius Terhune was in the same company & served his time faithfully until the month was ended& this deponent further saith that in the Spring of the year 1778 he Recollects of the said Cornelius Terhune having served for one month in a Company Company commanded by Thom Blanche stationed at Closter- Tenafly & the Liberty Pole and along the North River during guard duty and this despondent further said that in the year 1778 he recollects of the said Cornelius Terhune having served for one month under Capt John Outwater then stationed at Hackensack marching from that place to Aquackanonk in the county of Essex performing guard duty as neccessity required- And this depondent further saith that in the Spring of the year 1779 he well recollects of a call being made for militia when the said Terhune served for one month under Capt John Huyler then stationed at Closter liberty pole doing guard duty & other services as necessity Required-and this depondent further saith that in the Fall of the year 1779he served as a fellow soldier with the said Terhune in a Company commanded by Capt John Mead stationed at New Bridge Hackensack Liberty Pole& along the North River doing guard duty served the time and was discharged- Sworn and subscribed to before me the 26th day of November A.D.1833 David I Christie Justice of the peace Samuel Helm
