Lewis's company of Horsemen, then commonly called & distinguished by the name of Washington's Guards: - that this despondent frequently saw said Martin performing duty in said company of Guards, at his quarters, & in the same uniform dress: that he continued in said company until the Army removed to Middle Brook, which was sometime in May or June of the Same year; that this despondent

State of Indiana Dearborn County}set Before me Daniel Hagerman Justice of peace for Dearborn County personally appeared James Dill of [illegible] age and on his solemn oath duly administered, despondent and said that the pension certificate of John Demoss a United States revolutionary pensioner was lodged with this deponent for safe keeping-and was by this deponent deposited in the Clerks office of the Dearborn circuit court-that the said pension papers together with all the records of the county was consumed by fire on the night of the 5th Instant, evidently the work of an Incendiary- James Dill 10th March 1826 Sworn to and subscribed before me 10th March 1826 Danl. Hagerman JP

Personally appeared before me Joseph Stiles of the City of Savannah and State of Georgia who being duly sworn deposeth that he knew well Daniel Alexander Cuthbert to have been in the Georgia Continental line, during the revolutionary war. That the said Daniel Alexander Cuthbert, was known as, and called Alexander Cuthbert, as frequently as he was by the name of Daniel Cuthbert. Despondent further states that he was well acquainted with all the Cuthberts at that time in Georgia (one of the Cuthberts and himself having married Sisters) that he knew no other Alexander Cuthbert than Daniel Alexander Cuthbert, and is firmly convinced that the Alexander Cuthbert of Georgia, on the records at Washington, can mean and must allude to none other than Daniel Alexander Cuthbert. Joseph Stiles Sworn to before me this 29th feb 1836 William H Stiles Not. Public

State of Connecticut Litchfield County ss. On the 21st day of April AD. 1818 personally appeared the witness named John Allen and made solemn oath to the truth of the within affidavit by him subscribed and on the same day appeared Brainard Lindsly of said Plymouth and made solemn oath that he was and is acquainted with the said Allen and that said Allen served in the army in the manner by him within depond [despondent]. Before me Augustus Pettibone Chief Judge of Litchfield Court of Common Pleas

The deposition of Elkanah Andrews aged about 57 years - The Despondent being first duly sworn deposith and saith that he served on board the gally Accomack Capt Underhill in the fleet of Commander Barron from the year 1777 to the year 1779 that during the whole period of his Service aforesaid William Andrews also served on board of said gally as a common seaman. A Schedule of my property taken this 3rd day of June 1824 1 Bed 1 Chest one old trunk 2 Sheets 9 Blankets 1 Bed cover 1 Tea Kettle 2 doz old knives & forks 1 Decanter 1 axe Teste A. P. Upshear Wm. Andrews x his mark A copy Teste (?) by A (?) At a Court held for Accomack County the 3rd June 1824. The deposition of George Bluxom aged about sixty four who being first duly Sworn deposeth and saith that he enlisted for three years on board as galley callido the Accomack which aforesaid Gally was Commanded by Capt William Underhill and afterwards upon the resignation of Underhill was Commanded by Capt John Heacris the aforesaid Gally was generally in a fleet which was Commanded by Commander Barron, that he knows Elkanah Andrews (who is now aged about 57 years) and William Andrew (who is now aged about 83 years) served on board said gally when he then departed i said Service that he

Discharge. The members of this regiment this deponent does not recollect. It was commanded by Col John Waterman. That on the first day of May in the year 1777. This deponent again entered the service of the United States as a volunteer that he resided in East Greenwich. That he entered the service for the term of one month. That Captain Allen Johnson commanded the company, Col John Waterman commanded the Regiment that he was stationed at East Greenwich in the state of Rhode Island that he received not written discharge. This despondent further says that in the year 1778. He removed to the town of Exeter Rhode Island these l--- Kings County. That he was called into service by draft in the month of July of that year that he was moved to North Kingston at Boston Neck. The company was commanded by Capt. Stephen Whitmans that he faithfully served out his term of one months and was discharged at Boston Neck in said state of Rhode Island that he received no written discharge that in the year 1779. He removed into Petersburgh Rensselaer County New York that in the year 1779 – the company to which he belonged. Was required to furnish

Westmoreland County of Before me the Subscriber a Justice of the peace in the said County of Commonwealth of Penna came Andrew Ralston who being sworn as the Law directs depose to of saith that he was a private soldier in Capt. William Peebles company (of Cumberland County Penna) in Col. Miles Regiment. The company was afterwards commanded by Capt. Mathew Scott of the Regiment by Col. Walter Stuart——- and h this despondent saith that Alexander McCurdy was a private soldier in the same company & Regiment with this deponent from the month of March or April One thousand seven hundred & seventy six until the first day of January one thousand seven hundred & seventy eight at which time he was Honorably discharged at the Valley Forge—— And the deponent forth with said Sworn & Subscribed before me this 7th day of April 1818 Ephram A. Robison Andrew Ralston

State of Pennsylvania Clearfield County On this thirteenth day of April AD eighteen hundred and thirty-three. Personally approved in open Court of Commons pleas of Clearfield County of the state aforesaid, Abraham Goss aged sixty-seven on sixty-eight years a resident of the said County of Clearfield who being duly sworn according to law doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to entitle him to the benefit of the United States pensions made by the Act of Congress passed June 7. 1832. That in the time of the Revolutionary his father George Goss lived in Northumberland County Penn and left the family of which he had said Abraham was one and went to the War, that he the said Abraham was then young, and the year which his father started he cannot recollect, but he does recollect that he it was said he was enlisted as a fifer_ The Dependents father rescuing away remained away perhaps a year or a year and a half and returned with Regimentals on. Then be bound hired to be a Tailor to a man named Brown, now dead, with whom he lived perhaps 3 or 4 years when his Father & Mother returned from the Army, and took him the said Abraham along with him to the Army. The Regiment to which he & his father were attached was Co. Stewarts, Commonly Called “the Irish beauty” – He was enlisted for the purpose of being a Fife and was taught by his father. He [illegible] it was in the Jersey he & his father joined the Army – He remained in the Army for 3 or 4 years marching backwards & forwards to & from different places which he can’t now recollect – The said Abraham Goss saith that he received from Col Stewart at Trenton on Some Such [illegible] and since that a Certificate of Service from Col. Stewart who lived near Philadelphia in 1793. The discharge he has lost & the Certificate he gave to Wm Petrikins Esq now decd. & Roland Cusbrie – that Wm Petrikin died in the year 1821 & Roland Cusbrie has lost it as he says. The despondent saith that when he got the Certificate from Col. Stewart it was for the purpose of taking to the proper Office at Philadelphia. This was when the yellow fever raged there. He saw the Clerk then showed him his name on the Roll of Col. Stewart Regiment. The said Abraham Goss saith that during the period aforesaid he was young & has not a distinct recollection of the places where Battles were fought nor the year. He thinks the name of the Captain of the Company was Moon but not certain. He well recollects Gen. Washington & Col. Stewart, and also that when a Battle was about to come on he was directed, being young, to remain from it. He saith that he was altogether complied as a Fifer, and being young he frequently played by the direction of Washington & Stewart & others on particular occasion. He returned to North Country with his Father & from thence returned to Lycoming County, thence to the Bald Eagle in Center County & now lives in Clearfield County. I hereby relinquish every claim to a pension or annuity except the present and declare that the name is not on the Pension Roll of any Agency in any

State of New Jersey Sussex County On this 4th day of January 1845 before the subscriber a Justice of the Peace in and for said County personally appeared Doctor James T Clarke of the City of Trenton known to me as a person of the highest credibility, in the fifty seventh year of his age who being duly sworn according to [illegible] on his oath smith that he was well acquainted with Dr. Nicholas Belleville late of the City of Trenton despondent married his daughter Mary in the year 1809. And practiced medicine with the said Dr. Belleville for some time, and has often heard his said father in law speak of his arrival in this Country[illegible] in the year 1777 with Count Pulaski from France to [illegible] the Americans in their struggle for freedom. Soon after his arrival he was Commissioned a Surgeon in the army of the United States which commission despondent has often seen and read it was dated 1777 at Valley Forge in Pennsylvania and signed by Surgeon General Shippen of the American army, he has not seen the said commission since the death of his said father in law, it being kept with many other important papers among which were high testimonials of his profession of Surgery from the Paris School of distinguished [illegible], all of which appear are lost or destroyed, having made diligent search for some years for the same. Despondent is unable to specify how long his father in law was in the [illegible] and Hospital department of the United States believed he had [illegible] the latter when he came [illegible] when he married Ann [illegible] of this City in the early part of 1780 when he permanently settled himself in the practice of medicine in this city. He died on the Eighteenth day of December Eighteen hundred and thirty one leaving Ann Belleville his widow and one child [illegible] Marty Clarke deponents wife, the said widow Ann Belleville died on the twenty Eighth day of June Eighteen hundred and thirty seven. Deponents wife died before her mother 1.

State of Tennessee Madison County SS On this twenty third day of August 1832 formally appeared before me John M. Johnson an acting Justice of the Peace for said county Michael Freeman, who being first sworn according to law upon his oath states the he is sixty eight years of age and lives at this time in Caldwell County Kentucky, and being here on a journey, met unexpectedly with Jonas Clark Sen. who is an applicant for a pension under the act of congress passed 7th of June 1832. That he is well acquainted with said Clark and they were raised near each other and lived near each other in Mecklenburg County North Carolina during the Revolutionary War and until the year 1806. When despondent left there and over to Tennessee and from thence to Kentucky, and had not seen said Clark from the time he left North Carolina until meeting unexpectedly with him in this county. That he recollects very well seeing said Clark in the service of the United States, during the winter of 1779, when he volunteered under Capt. Simmons and as the despondent always understood, performed a three months tour at Charleston and that might have been during the winter and spring of 1779 & 1780. He has always understood he was at the battle of the Hanging Rock and at Gates defeat and Sumpter defeat in August 1780. During all this time he knows said Clark was absent from home in the service and has heard many who were in the said battles speak of said Clark being there, amongst them, he has heard his step brother speak of _ after Sumpter’s defeat the despondent volunteered himself about 19th of August 1780 immediately after hearing of Sumpter defeat by Col. Tarlton and was in the service from that time until April 1781, and was in the company of volunteers

Chester County, ss. Personally came before subscriber one of the parties of the Peace in and for the said County of Chester, James Denelson, signed to this deposition, when on his solemn affirmation doth say: That he forty nine years of age, that he served his the membership to the blacksmiths trade, in the borough of Wilmington, State of Delaware that he was there at the time the French troops which aided the Americans against the Bristol forces in the revolutionary war (illegible) in that leave in that he knew Peter Clear to belong to the French squadron of Light horse, that he was a tailor by to trade and not leave to work at one Starnd's opposite his master's shop and there the despondent became acquainted with him the said Peter, and that to know the said Peter to be the same person who now heirs in Brandywine township, County of Chester, Pennsylvania that he is now poor, and infirm and in his opinion has not the means of supporting himself. And further saith not. Jas Denelson Affirmed before me the 29th day of Dec. 1817 ⎬C. Mowry J. P. I Jesse John Prothonotary of the Court of Common Pleas and for the County of Chester in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania do Certify that C. Mowry Esquire before whom the two annexed Depositions of John Nicholas and Jos Denelson were to him at the time of taking the said Depositions was a Justice of the Peace duly commissioned and qualified to all whose of act as such full faith and credit are and ought to be In Testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand and affixed the seal of said Court at West Chester the 8th day of April A.D. 1818. Jesse John Prot

State of New York Clinton County ss on this 4th day of August 1845 personally appeared before the undersigned A Justice of the Peace in and for said County Frederick Perrigo of the Town of Ellen Bush County & State aforesaid aged Eighty years and upwards who being duly sworn according to Law deposes and says that he was well acquainted with Anthony Coffee now Deceased that the said Coffee and this Deponent both Resided in the town of Pownall in the State of Vermont during the Revolutionary war, this deponent further says that the said Anthony Coffee was a Soldier in the Army of the Revolution and this deponent saw him in the service in Capt. Hutchins Company in 1780 and believes he served nine or ten months this deponent is also quite certain that the said Coffee had been in the service previous to this Campaign but as he did not serve with him cannot tell the Exact length of service he performed. This deponent further says that the said Anthony Coffee was married to Abigail Hays in the Town of Pownal in the State of Vermont by Elisha Barber a Justice of the Peace sometime in the Spring of 1781; that this Despondent was present and saw them married and knows that he is not mistaken in the year because that not long after the marriage of Said Coffee he the said Coffee and this Deponent enlisted in the service of the United States in Captain Daniel Comstock Company Col Samuel Fletcher Regiment and hath went into the service together, and the said Anthony Coffee Continued to seven in said Company & Regiment until the latter part of the Summer of that year when he hired one Aaron Powers as a substitute to take his place who continued to serve to the end of the Campaign This Deponent further says that his acquaintance with the said Anthony Coffee and Abigail his wife continued until his death and that they were living together in Pownal aforesaid when he this deponent Commenced of Service as husband and wife and lived together as such until his death and that he is informed his widow is still living in Jefferson County in the State of New York Francis Perrigo Sworn and subscribed the day and of August 1845 year first above written before me James B. McLean Justice of the Peace

Paulding and Col. McCloughey and General George Clinton commanded. There were some Continental troops and other Militia at these forts during this time, but despondent recollection is too indistinct to describe their particular Co. He however remembers Evert Terwilliger who served there two months in Captain John Hardenbergh's Company. That said Terwilliger and this deponant were discharged and returned home together as stated in the affidavit of said Terwilliger accompanying this declaration. About the first of October this year (1777) an alarm was made on the approach of Burgoyne's Army at the north. Department vounteered under Captain John Hardenbergh and Lieutenant Abraham Deyo in Col. Hornbeck's Regiment. We marched directly to Stillwater in the County of Saratoga and after the surrender of the British Army we took charge of one hundred and fifty prisoners and brought them to Albany. While there Henry Paulding brought the news to Col Hornbeck that Fort Montgomery was taken. We shortly returned home having been absent about two weeks. General Cantine was with us at this time. During the years one thousand seven hundred and seventy eight, seventy nine, and eighty deposant was kept (?) readiness to meet the enemy, which was the case with all the Militia in this town (New Paltz) and within this time deposent was in actual service for five months, in terms of one month each. Service was under the command of Captain Abraham Deyo. At these times Evert Terwilliger above named was with me. The other times I was under the command of Capain John Hardenbergh, and of Joseph Hasbrough who was either a Lieutenant or an Ensign. We were employed in guarding the Indian Frontier in the town of Rochester and (?). The surrounding mountains were at times filled with indians, and we were out as scouts nearly all the time, sometimes in one place and then in another. John York was with me at one of these terms of service as stated in his affidavit appended. This depondent first says in answer to the question put to him by the said Court in the County of Ulster. That he was born near Staatsburgh in the County of Dutchess, State of New York, on the twenty fourth day of October in the year one thousand seven hundred and forty six. He has a record of his age written in High Dutch by his father. During the revolutionary war I lived in the town of New Paltz aforesaid and have lived there ever since. Depsoant when called into service entered as a volunteer. In addition to the aforegoing above other officers commanding me have been General Putnam at Kingsbridge and General Williams(?) at East Chester. He cannot recall the Continental or Militia Regiment which he served (?)., or state the (much is illegible). Despondent never received a written discharge. Despondent is known to Abraham A Deyo Esq one of the Judges of Ulster County and to Levi Hasbrouck Esq, residing in the neighborhood with this deposant who can testify to his character for verasity and their beleif of his services as a soldier of the Revolution.

State of New York Columbia County Is on this first day of November Eighteen hundred and forty five, personally affuaud [?] before me the [. . .] of the peace of the county aforesaid Levi Lovering a resident of the county aforesaid, Who being duly [?] according to law. I testify in order to obtain a pension and a certificate for the service of his Father, Jesse Lovering. that his Father often rehearsed over his services in the Revolutionary War. that this defronent [?] known of no Jesse Lovering that known of his Father's service. that was a sergeant in Captain Laland of Cornhenry that the [?] not go and the Cornhenry appointed his Father who took command and went to the Battle of Bunker Hill. and done other services that his Father then resided in Holliston state of Massachusetts and is now dead and also his widow. the despondent thinks he enlisted for 8 months and also served in the militia of said state of Massachusetts.

aforesaid under the following named officers Abraham Jennett as Captain & Thomas Pew as Lieutenant of the company in which he served. The name of the only field officer despondent recollects at this time occassioned by his loss of memory is John Butler Brigadier General. That he received from Brigadier General Butler a discharge in writing at the Camp near Salsberry on the third day of November one thousand seven hundred & Eighty the original of which is hereto annexed. That at the same time he received from his Captain Abraham Jennett a certificate the original of which is also here to annexed. That he did faithfully serve a tour of six months duty in active service. That he was during said period in no way [illegible] but was employed constantly in watching the movements of the Tories and was marched out of the County of Terrel across the [illegible] for that purpose. That subsequent to the Revolutionary war he resided for about Twenty years in the said County of Terrel and then removed into the County of Bulloch in the State of Georgia where he has ever since resided & now resides. That from old age and a fall lately recovered

that he enlisted under Genl [General] Proctor and Capt. [Captain] Rice for three years and that he was Engaged in the following battles to wit at Qebic [Quebec] Halifax Albany Germantown and that he had engaged with the indians in different parts and that is all that I can recollect of what was spoken S. A knew Anna Ragina Eyler to be the identical widow of Jonas Eyler and remain his widow up to the date.
